family service could not open its doors to a single family without the financial support of the united givers fund .	64.32535
anticipated heavy traffic along the skyline drive failed to materialize yesterday , park rangers said , and those who made the trip got a leisurely view of the fall colors through skies swept clear of haze .	176.10033
one of the initial questions put to president kennedy at his first news conference last january was about his attitude toward a meeting with premier khrushchev .	74.961426
`` i ' m hopeful that from more traditional exchanges we can perhaps find greater common ground ' ' .	172.59776
the president knew that a confrontation with mr . khrushchev sooner or later probably was inevitable and even desirable .	96.23196
but he was convinced that the realities of power -- military , economic and ideological -- were the decisive factors in the struggle with the communists and that these could not be talked away at a heads of government meeting .	103.290474
he wanted to buy time to strengthen the u . s . and its allies and to define and begin to implement his foreign policy .	39.02488
president kennedy will meet with soviet premier nikita s . khrushchev in vienna june 3 and 4 .	78.06644
the announcement came after a period of sharp deterioration in east-west relations .	23.401432
the heightened tension , in fact , had been a major factor in the president ' s change of view about the urgency of a meeting with the soviet leader .	25.79561
he was not going to vienna to negotiate -- the simultaneous announcements in washington and moscow last week stressed that no formal negotiations were planned .	65.43136
but mr . kennedy had become convinced that a personal confrontation with mr . khrushchev might be the only way to prevent catastrophe .	33.89094
that objective set the high stakes and drama of the vienna meeting .	43.70756
despite efforts by washington last week to play down the significance of the meeting , it clearly was going to be one of the crucial encounters of the cold war .	34.758396
the u . s . and soviet heads of government have met three times since sir winston churchill in 1953 introduced a new word into international diplomacy with his call for a fresh approach to the problem of peace `` at the summit of the nations ' ' .	83.900826
the first time was in 1955 when a full-dress big four summit meeting produced the `` spirit of geneva ' ' .	38.591732
the spirit served chiefly to lull the west while moscow made inroads into the middle east .	114.547295
in 1959 president eisenhower and premier khrushchev held an informal session in the u . s . .	17.722137
that meeting produced the `` spirit of camp david ' ' -- a spirit , it later turned out , that masked a basic misunderstanding about progress toward a berlin settlement .	108.22333
on the third occasion -- another big four summit session at paris a year ago -- there was no problem of an illusory `` spirit ' ' .	52.73886
premier khrushchev wrecked the conference at its initial session with a bitter denunciation of the u . s . for the u-2 incident .	14.856107
the episode tended to confirm the u . s . belief that propaganda , the hope of one-sided concessions , and the chance to split the allies , rather than genuine negotiation , were the soviet leader ' s real aims in summitry .	61.749565
thus when premier khrushchev intimated even before inauguration that he hoped for an early meeting with the new president , mr . kennedy was confronted with a delicate problem .	36.367607
shortly before his nomination he had set forth his basic view about the problem of negotiations with the soviet leader in these words	68.096794
`` as long as mr . khrushchev is convinced that the balance of world power is shifting his way , no amount of either smiles or toughness , neither camp david talks nor kitchen debates , can compel him to enter fruitful negotiations ' ' .	139.35832
the president had set for himself the task , which he believed vital , of awakening the u . s . and its allies to the hard and complex effort necessary to shift that balance .	94.66293
he did not want the effort weakened by any illusion that summit magic might make it unnecessary .	226.89018
he wanted time , too , to review the united states ' global commitments and to test both the policies he had inherited and new ones he was formulating .	99.311356
above all , he did not want to appear to be running hat in hand to premier khrushchev ' s doorstep .	79.49198
at the same time the president took pains not to rule out an eventual meeting with the soviet leader .	96.23916
ideally , he knew , it should be preceded by concrete progress at lower levels .	161.24883
but mr . kennedy saw value even in an informal meeting , provided that undue hopes were not raised in connection with it .	110.97657
it would give him an opportunity to take the measure of his chief adversary in the cold war , to try to probe mr . khrushchev ' s intentions and to make clear his own views .	34.91564
moreover , an eventual meeting was desirable if for no other reason than to satisfy world opinion that the u . s . was not inflexible and was sparing no effort to ease international tensions .	81.66013
both elements -- the caution about a meeting , the willingness eventually to hold one -- were reflected in a letter from the president which ambassador llewellyn e . thompson brought back to russia late in february .	118.74196
the letter , dated feb . 22 , was delivered to premier khrushchev in novosibirsk , siberia , on march 9 .	26.92006
it dealt mainly with a broad range of east-west issues .	32.61502
but it also briefly suggested the possibility of a meeting with mr . khrushchev before the end of the year if the international climate were favorable and schedules permitted .	49.91321
developments over the next two months , however , caused the president to reconsider the question of the timing .	50.411808
there were intense discussions in the inner councils of the white house about the advisability of an early meeting , not because the international climate was improving , but precisely because it was deteriorating alarmingly .	58.958885
the president was especially concerned about the deadlock in the nuclear test ban negotiations at geneva .	12.49481
the deadlock has been caused by the russians ' new demand for a three-man ( east , west and neutral ) directorate , and thus a veto , over the control machinery .	125.87795
in the u . s . , strong pressures have been building up for a resumption of tests on grounds that the russians may be secretly testing .	86.757645
mr . kennedy was less troubled by that possibility than by the belief that a geneva breakdown , or even continued stalemate , would mean an unchecked spread of nuclear weapons to other countries as well as a fatal blow to any hope for disarmament .	87.652916
there was reason to believe that premier khrushchev was also concerned about a possible spread of nuclear weapons , particularly to communist china .	46.16879
the question arose as to whether a frank discussion of that danger with the soviet leader had not become urgent .	78.02683
moreover , moscow appeared determined to apply the tripartite veto principle to the executive organs of all international bodies , including the u . n . secretariat and the international control commission for laos .	35.343468
mr . kennedy was convinced that insistence on the demand would make international agreements , or even negotiations , impossible .	171.10596
developments in cuba and laos also suggested the advisability of an early summit meeting .	35.252064
initially the white house reaction was that the bitter exchanges with moscow over cuba and the conflict in laos had dampened prospects for a meeting .	51.01071
at the same time , there was increased reason for a quick meeting lest the soviet leader , as a result of those episodes , come to a dangerously erroneous conclusion about the west ' s ability and determination to resist communist pressure .	46.477886
in cuba , the u . s . had blundered badly and created the impression of impotency against communist penetration even on its own doorstep .	105.85556
in laos , the picture was almost equally bad .	42.021126
u . s . willingness to accept a neutral laos may have led premier khrushchev to believe that other areas could be `` neutralized ' ' on soviet terms .	39.157803
beyond that , allied disagreement about military intervention in laos -- despite warnings that they might do so -- allowed moscow to carry out with impunity a series of military and diplomatic moves that greatly strengthened the pro-communist forces .	106.71739
as a result , the west is in a poor bargaining position at the current geneva negotiations on laos , and south vietnam and other nations in southeast asia are under increased pressure .	57.884174
in the light of those events , there appeared to be a real danger that premier khrushchev might overreach himself .	31.816635
ambassador thompson reported from moscow that the soviet leader ' s mood was cocky and aggressive .	25.961588
he has indicated that he plans new moves on berlin before the year is out .	108.36084
the president and his advisers felt that the time might have come to warn premier khrushchev against a grave miscalculation in areas such as berlin , iran or latin america from which there would be no turning back .	73.71957
it was in the midst of such white house deliberations that premier khrushchev on may 4 made new inquiries through the u . s . embassy in moscow about a meeting with the president in the near future .	50.05129
mr . kennedy told moscow he would give his answer by may 20 after consultation with the allies .	116.27455
the response from london , paris and bonn was favorable .	135.65907
firm arrangements for the meeting in vienna were worked out in a final exchange between moscow and washington last week .	49.318672
apparently at the insistence of the u . s . , the simultaneous announcements issued in washington and moscow last friday emphasized the `` informal ' ' nature of the meeting .	43.42544
`` the president and chairman khrushchev understand that this meeting is not for the purpose of negotiating or reaching agreement on the major international problems that involve the interest of many other countries .	71.81293
the meeting will , however , afford a timely and convenient opportunity for the first personal contact between them and a general exchange of views on the major issues which affect the relationships between the two countries ' ' .	59.958363
the vienna meeting will bring together a seasoned , 67-year-old veteran of the cold war who , in mr . kennedy ' s own words , is `` shrewd , tough , vigorous , well-informed and confident ' ' , and a 44-year-old president ( his birthday is may 29 ) with a demonstrated capacity for political battle but little experience in international diplomacy .	63.892002
the announcement last week of the forthcoming encounter produced strong reactions in the u . s . of both approval and disapproval .	63.654896
the approval did not arise from an expectation of far-reaching agreements at vienna .	102.01119
the inclination was to accept the statement that there would be no formal negotiations .	17.352514
but those who were in favor of the meeting felt that a frank exchange between the two men and an opportunity to size one another up would prove salutary .	113.85967
mr . khrushchev is known to rely heavily on his instincts about his adversaries and to be a shrewd judge of men .	63.86541
the feeling was that he would sense an inner core of toughness and determination in the president and that plain talk by mr . kennedy would give him pause .	76.07603
apart from the personal equation , another reason advanced in favor of the meeting was that too often in the past the u . s . appeared to have been dragged reluctantly to the summit .	46.53926
premier khrushchev has made propaganda capital out of that fact and in the end got his summit meeting anyway .	210.86804
this time the initiative came , in part at least , from washington .	77.70407
there was also the fact that by the time he meets mr . khrushchev , the president will have completed conversations with all the other principal allied leaders .	57.822548
thus he will be in a position to disabuse the soviet leader of any notions he may have about grave allied disunity .	135.199
finally , there was a wide area of agreement on the value of the president ' s making a final effort in the summit spotlight for a nuclear test accord .	47.121117
there is no single issue that has aroused stronger feelings throughout the world .	35.717197
if tests are to be resumed , the argument went , it is vital that the u . s . make plain that the onus belongs to the soviet union .	54.77782
disapproval of the meeting was based largely on the belief that the timing could hardly be worse .	39.488544
after cuba and laos , it was argued , mr . khrushchev will interpret the president ' s consent to the meeting as further evidence of western weakness -- perhaps even panic -- and is certain to try to exploit the advantage he now believes he holds .	89.63421
moreover , the president is meeting the soviet leader at a time when the administration has still not decided on the scope of america ' s firm foreign policy commitments .	76.26933
the question was raised , for example , as to what attitude the president would take if mr . khrushchev proposes a broad neutral belt extending from southeast asia to the middle east .	61.56558
there are , so my biologist friends tell me , mechanisms of adaptation and defense that are just too complete and too satisfactory .	112.47668
the shell , which served the strain so well at a relatively early stage in the evolutionary scheme , tended to cancel out the possibility of future development .	70.59467
though this may or may not be good biology , it does aptly illustrate the strength and the weakness of american catholic higher education .	79.37532
there can be no doubt that the american catholic accomplishment in the field of higher education is most impressive our european brethren never cease to marvel at the number and the size of our colleges and universities .	71.923996
the deeper wonder is how this miracle was accomplished in decades , rather than in centuries and by immigrant minorities at that .	248.29
by way of explanation we ourselves are prone to imagine that this achievement stems from the same american catholic zeal and generosity which brought the parochial school system into existence .	105.69859
there is , however , one curious discrepancy in this broad and flattering picture .	48.794674
viewing the american catholic educational achievement in retrospect , we may indeed see it as a unified whole extending from grade school to university .	76.41319
but the simple truth is that higher education has never really been an official american catholic project	210.37852
certainly not in the same sense that the establishment of a parochial school system has been a matter of official policy .	26.663671
official encouragement is one thing , but the down-to-earth test is the allocation of diocesan and parochial funds .	160.44917
american catholics have responded generously to bishops ' and pastors ' appeals for the support necessary to create parochial schools but they have not contributed in a similar fashion to the establishment of institutions of higher learning .	82.30853
they have not done so for the simple reason that such appeals have hardly ever been made .	75.3305
diocesan authorities generally have not regarded this as their direct responsibility .	114.10371
all of this may be understandable enough it is , however , in fact difficult to see how diocesan authorities could have acted otherwise .	63.483448
yet for better or for worse , the truth of the matter is that most american catholic colleges do not owe their existence to general catholic support but rather to the initiative , resourcefulness and sacrifices of individual religious communities .	82.15482
community esprit de corps has been the protective shell which has made the achievement possible .	85.325806
to understand the past history -- and the future potential -- of american catholic higher education , it is necessary to appreciate the special character of the esprit de corps of the religious community .	47.81797
it is something more than the arithmetical sum of individual totals of piety and detachment .	59.398247
a religious community with a vital sense of mission achieves a degree of group orientation and group identification seldom found elsewhere .	122.84924
the fact that the group orientation and group identification are founded on supernatural principles and nourished by the well-springs of devotion simply give them a deeper and more satisfying dimension .	77.670135
the net result is a uniquely satisfying sense of comradeship , the kind of comradeship which sparks enthusiasm and blunts the cutting edge of sacrifice and hardship .	43.52484
american catholic colleges and universities are , in a very real sense , the product of `` private enterprise ' ' -- the `` private enterprise ' ' of religious communities .	18.126537
had it not been for such private enterprise , diocesan authorities might of course have been goaded into establishing institutions subsidized by diocesan funds and parish collections and staffed by religious as paid employees .	121.46369
there is however no point in speculating about such a possibility the fact of the matter is that our institutions of higher learning owe their existence to a spirit not unlike that which produces the `` family business ' ' .	55.004356
this `` family-community ' ' spirit is the real explanation of the marvel of our achievement .	79.68849
it is this spirit which explains some of the anomalies of american catholic higher education , in particular the wasteful duplication apparent in some areas .	60.022354
i think for example of three women ' s colleges with pitifully small enrollments , clustered within a few miles of a major catholic university , which is also co-educational .	36.788788
this aspect of the total picture has been commented upon often enough .	429.27942
it would seem to represent esprit de corps run riot .	261.55417
apart , however , from the question of wasteful duplication , there is another aspect of the `` family business ' ' spirit in american catholic higher education which deserves closer scrutiny .	46.49246
for while the past needs of the church in this country may have been adequately met by collegiate institutions , which in temper and tone closely resembled junior colleges and finishing schools , it would seem that today ' s need is for the college which more closely resembles the university in its `` pursuit of excellence ' ' .	72.319695
at the earlier `` pre-academic excellence ' ' stage of catholic education , the operation could be conducted on an intra-mural community basis .	69.27039
but with today ' s demand for professional qualifications and specialized training , the need for `` outsiders ' ' becomes more pressing .	46.62093
the problem is not merely that more `` outside teachers ' ' are needed but that a different brand is called for .	72.69087
commenting on the earlier stage , the notre dame chapter of the american association of university professors ( in a recent report on the question of faculty participation in administrative decision-making ) noted that the term `` teacher-employee ' ' ( as opposed to , e . g . , `` maintenance employee ' ' ) was a not inapt description .	35.038994
today however , the `` outsider ' ' is likely to have professional qualifications of the highest order ( otherwise the college would not be interested in hiring him ) and to be acclimatized to the democratic processes of the secular or state university .	66.34678
and while no one expects total democracy on the academic scene , the scholar will be particularly sensitive to a line between first and second class citizenship drawn on any basis other than that of academic rank or professional achievement .	106.5054
in the above mentioned report of the notre dame chapter of the american association of university professors , the basic outlook of the new breed of lay faculty emerges very clearly in the very statement of the problem as the members see it `` even with the best of intentions he ( the president of the university ) is loath to delegate such authority and responsibility to a group the membership of which , considered ( as it must be by him ) in individual terms , is inhomogeneous , mortal and of extremely varying temperament , interests and capabilities .	82.12682
it is natural that he should turn for his major support to a select and dedicated few from the organization which actually owns the university and whose goals are , in their opinion , identified with its highest good and ( to use that oft-repeated phrase ) ' the attainment of excellence ' ' ' .	104.390976
the pattern here pictured is clearly not peculiar to notre dame it is simply that the paradox involved in this kind of control of the institution by `` the organization which actually owns ' ' it , becomes more obvious where there is a larger and more distinguished `` outside ' ' faculty .	57.129383
it is particularly interesting that those who framed the report should refer to `` the organization which actually owns the university ' ' this seems to show an awareness of the fact that there is more to the problem than the ordinary issue of clerical-lay tension .	67.457825
but in any case , one does not have to read very closely between the lines to realize that the situation is not regarded as a particularly happy one .	57.857548
`` outside ' ' faculty members want to be considered partners in the academic enterprise and not merely paid employees of a family business .	71.79735
there are two reasons why failure to come to grips with this demand could be fatal to the future of the catholic university .	55.873188
in the first place there is the obvious problem of recruiting high caliber personnel .	40.90376
word spreads rapidly in the tightly knit academic profession , much given to attending meetings and conferences .	208.6108
expressions of even low-key dissatisfaction by a catholic college faculty member has the effect of confirming the already existing stereotype .	89.61716
in the academic world there is seldom anything so dramatic as a strike or a boycott all that happens is that the better qualified teacher declines to gamble two or three years of his life on the chance that conditions at the catholic institution will be as good as those elsewhere .	123.37294
to appreciate the nature of the gamble , it should be realized that while college teaching is almost a public symbol of security , that security does not come as quickly or as automatically as it does in an elementary school system or in the civil service .	90.88768
much has been made of the fact that major catholic institutions now guarantee firm tenure .	301.48254
this is a significant advance but its import should not be exaggerated .	36.173676
when a man invests a block of his years at a university without gaining the coveted promotion , not only is he faced with the problem of starting over but there is also a certain depreciation in the market value of his services .	74.549644
a man does not make that kind of gamble if he suspects that one or more of the limited number of tenure positions is being reserved for members of the `` family ' ' .	45.213154
just as it is possible to exaggerate the drawing power of the new tenure practices , it is also possible to exaggerate the significance of the now relatively adequate salaries paid by major catholic institutions .	82.94455
yet adequate compensation -- and particularly merely adequate compensation is no substitute for those intangibles which cause a man to sacrifice part of his earning potential by taking up college teaching in the first place .	118.88955
broadly speaking the total catholic atmosphere is such an intangible but the larger demand is for a sense of creative participation and mature responsibility in the total work of the university .	64.80405
religious who derive their own sense of purpose through identification with the religious community rather than the academic community are prone to underestimate both the layman ' s reservoir of idealism and his need for this identification .	87.97441
there is no need here to spell out the conditions of creative teaching except to point out that , at the college level , the sense of community and of community responsibility is even more necessary than it is at other levels .	75.83702
the college teacher needs the stimulus of communication with other faculty members but he also needs to feel that such communication , even informal debates over the luncheon table , are a contribution to the total good of the institution .	79.93933
but this in turn means that decisions are not merely imposed from the top but that there be some actual mechanism of faculty participation .	144.38745
the second reason for being concerned with the dichotomy between faculty members who are part of the `` in-group ' ' that owns and operates the institution and those who are merely paid employees , is , therefore , the baneful effect on the caliber of the teaching itself .	42.021175
this is a problem that goes considerably beyond questions of salary and tenure .	174.08032
yet though it may seem difficult to envision any definitive resolution of the problem of ownership and control , there are nevertheless certain suggestions which seem to be in order .	57.94388
the first is a negative warning there is no point in the creation of faculty committees and advisory boards with high-sounding titles but no real authority .	138.07957
in the case of academic personnel the `` feeling ' ' of participation can hardly be `` faked ' ' .	20.983051
competent teachers are well versed in the technique of leading students to pre-set conclusions without destroying the students ' illusion that they are making their own decisions .	83.16986
those who have served as faculty advisers are too familiar with the useful but artificial mechanisms of student government to be taken in by `` busy-work ' ' and ersatz decision making .	119.71019
in any case it is by no means clear that formally structured organs of participation are what is called for at all .	251.45836
in the notre dame report , reference was made to the fact that faculty members were reduced to `` luncheon-table communication ' ' .	26.223263
in itself there is nothing wrong with this form of `` participation ' ' the only difficulty on the catholic campus is that those faculty members who are in a position to implement policy , i . e . , members of the religious community which owns and administers the institution , have their own eating arrangements .	52.310528
sen . john l . mcclellan of arkansas and rep . david martin of nebraska are again beating the drums to place the unions under the anti-monopoly laws .	70.9926
once more the fallacious equation is advanced to argue that since business is restricted under the anti-monopoly laws , there must be a corresponding restriction against labor unions the law must treat everybody equally .	147.08522
or , in the words of anatole france , `` the law in its majestic equality must forbid the rich , as well as the poor , from begging in the streets and sleeping under bridges ' ' .	62.18113
the public atmosphere that has been generated which makes acceptance of this law a possibility stems from the disrepute into which the labor movement has fallen as a result of mr . mcclellan ' s hearings into corruption in labor-management relations and , later , into the jurisdictional squabbles that plagued industrial relations at the missile sites .	69.05731
the senator was shocked by stoppages over allegedly trivial disputes that delayed our missile program .	136.90903
in addition , disclosures that missile workers were earning sums far in excess of what is paid for equivalent work elsewhere provoked his indignation on behalf of the american taxpayer who was footing the bill .	105.680855
it is now disclosed that the taxpayer not only pays for high wages , but he pays the employers ' strike expenses when the latter undertakes to fight a strike .	75.074425
business week ( aug . 9 , 1961 ) reports that the united aircraft company , against which the international association of machinists had undertaken a strike , decided to keep its plants operating .	86.74668
the company incurred some $10 million of expenses attributable to four factors advertising to attract new employees , hiring and training them , extra overtime , and defective work performed by the new workers .	86.18637
the company has billed the united states government for $7 , 500 , 000 of these expenses under the defense department regulation allowing costs of a type generally recognized as ordinary and necessary for the conduct of the contractor ' s business .	53.332226
rep . frank kowalski of connecticut has brought this problem to the attention of the armed services committee .	48.72389
neither has congressman martin nor senator mcclellan been heard from on the matter	107.72808
they are preoccupied with ending labor abuses by extending the anti-monopoly laws to the unions .	15.994191
the recent publicity attending the successful federal prosecution of a conspiracy indictment against a number of electrical manufacturers has evoked a new respect for the anti-trust laws that is justified neither by their rationale nor by the results they have obtained .	89.68218
the anti-trust laws inform a business that it must compete , but along completely undefined lines	248.89346
it must play a game in which there never is a winner .	141.06538
the fact is that any business that wants to operate successfully cannot follow the law .	112.69415
hypocrisy thus becomes the answer to a foolish public policy .	68.05336
let us look at the heavy-electrical-goods industry in which general electric , westinghouse and a number of other manufacturers were recently convicted of engaging in a conspiracy to rig prices and allocate the market .	69.172
the industry is so structured that price-setting by a multi-product company will vary with the way overhead charges are allocated -- whether marginal or average pricing is applied .	115.091896
the problem becomes even more complex where an enterprise is engaged in the manufacture of a wide variety of other goods in addition to the heavy electrical equipment .	41.156994
accounting procedures can be varied to provide a rationale for almost any price .	108.80752
naturally , enterprises of the size of general electric are in a position to structure their prices in such a way that the relatively small competitors can be forced to the wall in a very short time .	70.27607
should these giants really flex their competitive muscles , they would become the only survivors in the industry .	56.123413
uncle sam would then accuse them of creating a monopoly by `` unfair competition ' ' .	21.917303
but if they show self-restraint , they don ' t get the orders .	19.572227
under the circumstances , the only protection for the relatively small manufacturers is to engage in exactly the kind of conspiracy with the giants for which the latter were convicted .	86.427284
engaging in such a conspiracy was an act of mercy by the giants .	88.441666
the paradox implicit in the whole affair is shown by the demand of the government , after the conviction , that general electric sign a wide-open consent decree that it would not reduce prices so low as to compete seriously with its fellows .	67.59235
in other words , the anti-trust laws , designed to reduce prices to the consumer on monday , wednesday and friday , become a tool to protect the marginal manufacturer on tuesday , thursday and saturday .	79.465225
and which theory would govern the enforcers of the law on sunday ? ?	39.3565
the question might be asked `` don ' t the managements of the heavy-electrical-goods manufacturers know these facts ? ?	86.376686
why did they engage in a flood of mea culpas , throw a few scapegoats to the dogs and promise to be good boys thereafter , expressing their complete confidence in the laws ' ' ? ?	89.51897
the past usefulness of the anti-trust laws to management was explained by thurman arnold , in the folklore of capitalism , back in 1937 .	176.95505
he wrote `` ( p . 211 ) the anti-trust laws were the answer of a society which unconsciously felt the need of great organizations , and at the same time had to deny them a place in the moral and logical ideology of the social structure .	47.68741
( p . 214 ) anti-trust laws became the greatest protection to uncontrolled business dictatorship .	105.38355
( p . 215 ) when corporate abuses were attacked , it was done on the theory that criminal penalties would be invoked rather than control .	57.532063
in this manner , every scheme for direct control broke to pieces on the great protective rock of the anti-trust laws .	122.44944
( pp . 228-229 ) in any event , it is obvious that the anti-trust laws did not prevent the formation of some of the greatest financial empires the world has ever known , held together by some of the most fantastic ideas , all based on the fundamental notion that a corporation is an individual who can trade and exchange goods without control by the government ' ' .	55.79478
this escape from control has led to management ' s evaluating the risk of occasional irrational prosecution as worth while .	231.56607
a plea of nolo contendere , followed by a nominal fine , after all is a small price to pay for this untrammeled license .	100.97741
( the penalties handed out in the electrical case , which included jail sentences , were unprecedented in anti-trust prosecutions , perhaps because the conspirators had displayed unusual ineptness in their pricing activities .	73.22921
if a substitute mechanism is needed for the control of a fictitious impersonal market , quite obviously some method must be devised for representing the public interest .	143.04681
a secret conspiracy of manufacturers is hardly such a vehicle .	18.275375
however , one can argue that no such control is necessary as long as one pretends that the anti-trust laws are effective and rational .	78.68074
quite clearly the anti-trust laws are neither effective nor rational -- and yet the argument goes that they should be extended to the labor union .	68.08147
those who favor placing trade unions under anti-trust laws imply that they are advocating a brand new reform .	74.547905
before 1933 , individuals who opposed trade unions and collective bargaining said so in plain english .	87.93432
the acceptance of collective bargaining as a national policy in 1934 , implicit in the writing of section 7a of the national industrial recovery act , has made it impolitic to oppose collective bargaining in principle .	75.114784
the wagner act , the taft-hartley act and the landrum-griffin act all endorse the principle of collective bargaining .	24.037308
the basic purpose of an effective collective-bargaining system is the removal of wages from competition .	103.06283
if a union cannot perform this function , then collective bargaining is being palmed off by organizers as a gigantic fraud .	64.70605
the tortured reasoning that unions use to deny their ambition to exercise monopoly power over the supply and price of labor is one of the things that create a legal profession .	80.64364
if laborers are merely commodities competing against each other in a market place like so many bags of wheat and corn ( unsupported , by the way , by any agricultural subsidy ) , then they may be pardoned for reacting with complete antagonism to a system that imposes such status upon them .	91.12905
human labor was exactly that -- a commodity -- in eighteenth- and nineteenth-century america .	62.733524
as early as 1776 , adam smith wrote in the wealth of nations `` we have no acts of parliament against combining to lower the price of work	102.39653
but many against combining to raise it ' ' .	1.3926017
eighteenth-century england , upon whose customs our common law was built , had outlawed unions as monopolies and conspiracies .	66.90638
in 1825 , the boston house carpenters ' strike for a ten-hour day was denounced by the organized employers , who declared `` it is considered that all combinations by any classes of citizens intended to effect the value of labor tend to convert all its branches into monopolies ' ' .	103.7298
there were no pious hypocrisies then about being for collective bargaining , but against labor monopoly .	118.938255
the courts shared the opinion of the employers .	9.457324
in people vs . fisher , justice savage of the new york supreme court declared	20.849474
`` without any officious and improper interference on the subject , the price of labor or the wages of mechanics will be regulated by the demand for the manufactured article and the value of that which is paid for it	56.749573
but the right does not exist to raise the wages of the mechanic by any forced and artificial means ' ' .	63.926525
compare this statement of a nineteenth-century judge with how congressman martin , according to the daily labor report of sept . 19 , 1961 , defends the necessity of enacting anti-trust legislation in the field of labor `` if we wish to prevent monopolistic fixing of wages , production or prices and if we wish to preserve the freedom of the employer and his employees to contract on wages , hours and conditions of employment ' ' .	58.865707
senator mcclellan is proposing the application of anti-trust measures to unions in transportation .	67.46426
his bill , allegedly aimed at hoffa , would amend the sherman , clayton and norris-laguardia acts to authorize the issuance of federal injunctions in any transportation strike and would make it illegal for any union to act in concert with any other union -- even a sister local in the same international .	126.893715
paradoxically , the same week in which senator mcclellan was attempting to extend the anti-trust act to labor in transportation , the civil aeronautics board was assuring the airlines that if they met in concert to eliminate many costly features of air travel , the action would not be deemed a violation of the anti-trust act .	88.324585
indeed , it is in the field of transportation that congress has most frequently granted employers exemption from the anti-trust laws	184.2766
for example , the organization of steamship conferences to set freight rates and the encouragement of railroads to seek mergers .	126.74967
at the very moment that every attempt is being made to take management out from under the irrationality of anti-trust legislation , a drive is on to abolish collective bargaining under the guise of extending the anti-monopoly laws to unions who want no more than to continue to set wages in the same way that ship operators set freight rates .	62.726284
the passage of the sherman act was aimed at giant monopolies .	68.74214
in the famous danbury hatters case , a suit was brought against the union by the loewe company for monopolistic practices , e . g . , trying to persuade consumers not to purchase the product of the struck manufacturer .	56.441544
the suit against the union was successful and many workers lost their homes to pay off the judgment .	103.13155
in 1914 , the clayton act attempted to take labor out from under the anti-trust legislation by stating that human labor was not to be considered a commodity .	71.554825
labor remained a commodity -- but presumably a privileged one granted immunization from the anti-trust laws .	90.53814
the courts , by interpretation , emasculated the act .	78.62471
in 1922 , the united mine workers struck the coronado coal company .	33.447613
the company sued under the anti-trust laws , alleging that the union ' s activity interfered with the movement of interstate commerce .	40.3195
( what other purpose could a striking union have but to interrupt the flow of commerce from the struck enterprise ? ?	99.29976
) the court first ruled that the strike constituted only an indirect interference with commerce .	141.39922
at a closed-door session on capitol hill last week , secretary of state christian herter made his final report to the senate foreign relations committee on u . s . affairs abroad .	35.6286
afterward , tennessee ' s democratic senator albert gore summed it up for newsmen .	72.06891
what herter presented , said gore , was `` not a very encouraging review ' ' .	28.12666
that was something of an understatement in a week when the underlying conflict between the west and communism erupted on three fronts .	80.3927
while communists were undermining united nations efforts to rescue the congo from chaos , two other communist offensives stirred the eisenhower administration into emergency conferences and serious decisions .	104.65918
hours after a parade of his new soviet tanks and artillery , dictator fidel castro suddenly confronted the u . s . with a blunt and drastic demand within 48 hours , the u . s . had to reduce its embassy and consulate staffs in cuba to a total of eleven persons ( the embassy staff alone totaled 87 u . s . citizens , plus 120 cuban employees ) .	46.16539
president eisenhower held an 8 30 a . m . meeting with top military and foreign-policy advisers , decided to break off diplomatic relations immediately .	64.35532
`` there is a limit to what the united states in self-respect can endure ' ' , said the president .	52.43402
`` that limit has now been reached ' ' .	1.247569
through secretary herter , ike offered president-elect kennedy an opportunity to associate his new administration with the breakoff decision .	99.82521
kennedy , through secretary-designate of state dean rusk , declined .	26.044395
he thus kept his hands free for any action after jan . 20 , although reaction to the break was generally favorable in the u . s . and latin america ( see the hemisphere ) .	59.72469
after a white house huddle between the president and top lieutenants , the defense department reacted sharply to a cry from the pro-western government of laos that several battalions of communist troops had invaded laos from north viet nam .	45.861988
`` in view of the present situation in laos ' ' , said the pentagon ' s announcement , `` we are taking normal precautionary actions to increase the readiness of our forces in the pacific ' ' .	33.41828
cutting short a holiday at hong kong , the aircraft carriers lexington and bennington steamed off into the south china sea , accompanied by a swarm of destroyers , plus troopships loaded with marines .	58.63926
on the u . s . ' s island base of okinawa , task force 116 , made up of army , navy , marine and air force units , got braced to move southward on signal .	92.64396
but by week ' s end the laotian cry of invasion was read as an exaggeration ( see foreign news ) , and the u . s . was agreeing with its cautious british and french allies that a neutralist -- rather than a pro-western -- government might be best for laos .	84.9865
there was a moral of sorts in the laotian situation that said much about all other cold-war fronts .	125.248924
political , economic and military experts were all agreed that chaotic , mountainous little laos was the last place in the world to fight a war -- and they were probably right .	85.956154
`` it would be like fighting the french and indian war all over again ' ' , said one military man .	104.786964
but why was laos the new southeast asian battleground ? ?	59.440266
at geneva in 1954 , to get the war in indo-china settled , the british and french gave in to russian and communist chinese demands and agreed to the setting up of a communist state , north viet nam -- which then , predictably , became a base for communist operations against neighboring south viet nam and laos .	68.11063
the late secretary of state john foster dulles considered the 1954 geneva agreement a specimen of appeasement , saw that resolution would be needed to keep it from becoming a calamity for the west .	89.84551
he began the diplomatic discussions that resulted in the establishment of aj .	38.6149
`` the important thing from now on ' ' , he said , `` is not to mourn the past but to seize the future opportunity to prevent the loss in northern viet nam from leading to the extension of communism throughout southeast asia ' ' .	45.475872
russian tanks and artillery parading through the streets of havana , russian intrigue in the congo , and russian arms drops in laos ( using the same ilyushin transports that were used to carry communist agents to the congo ) made it plain once more that the cold war was all of a piece in space and time .	60.526814
soviet premier khrushchev sent new year ' s hopes for peace to president-elect kennedy , and got a cool acknowledgment in reply .	66.62129
considering the state of the whole world , the cold war ' s three exposed fronts did not seem terribly ominous	96.30425
but , in senator gore ' s words , it was `` not a very encouraging ' ' situation that would confront john f . kennedy on inauguration day .	38.910946
as the 87th congress began its sessions last week , liberal democrats were ready for a finish fight to open the sluice gates controlled by the house rules committee and permit the free flow of liberal legislation to the floor .	73.0278
the liberal pressure bloc ( which coyly masquerades under the name democratic study group ) had fought the committee before , and had always lost .	192.17055
this time , they were much better prepared and organized , and the political climate was favorable .	70.47329
they had the unspoken support of president-elect kennedy , whose own legislative program was menaced by the rules committee bottleneck .	40.265675
and counting noses , they seemed to have the votes to work their will .	172.06258
there were two possible methods of breaching the conservative barriers around the rules committee 1 ) to pack it with additional liberals and break the conservative-liberal deadlock , or 2 ) to remove one of the conservatives -- namely mississippi ' s 14-term william meyers colmer ( pronounced calmer ) .	75.459274
caucusing , the liberals decided to go after colmer , which actually was the more drastic course , since seniority in the house is next to godliness .	106.45757
a dour , gangling man with a choppy gait , colmer looks younger than his 70 years , has gradually swung from a moderate , internationalist position to that of a diehard conservative .	84.2121
he is generally and initially suspicious of any federal project , unless it happens to benefit his gulf coast constituents .	243.12253
he is , of course , a segregationist , but he says he has never made an `` anti-negro ' ' speech .	18.828226
for 20 years he has enjoyed his power on the rules committee .	44.184715
there his vote , along with those of chairman howard smith , the courtly virginia judge , and the four republican members , could and often did produce a 6-6 deadlock that blocked far-out , democratic-sponsored welfare legislation ( a tactic often acceptable to the rayburn-johnson congressional leadership to avoid embarrassing votes ) .	159.68034
there was sufficient pretext to demand colmer ' s ouster he had given his lukewarm support to the anti-kennedy electors in mississippi .	40.978676
reprisals are not unheard of in such situations , but the recent tendency has been for the congress to forgive its prodigal sons .	60.29694
in 1949 the dixiecrats escaped unscathed after their 1948 rebellion against harry truman , and in 1957 , after congressman adam clayton powell campaigned for dwight eisenhower in 1956 , his fellow democrats did not touch his committee assignments , although they did strip him temporarily of his patronage .	117.113106
( in the heat of the anti-colmer drive last week , judge smith threatened reprisal against powell .	146.49767
said he `` we will see whether whites and negroes are treated the same around here ' ' .	63.16715
) but speaker sam rayburn , after huddling in palm beach with president-elect kennedy , decided that this year something had to be done about the rules committee -- and that he was the only man who could do anything effective .	56.043774
in a tense , closed-door session with judge smith , rayburn attempted to work out a compromise to add three new members to the rules committee ( two democrats , including one southerner , and one republican ) .	75.58121
smith flatly rejected the offer , and mister sam thereupon decided to join the rebels .	48.744408
the next morning he summoned a group of top democrats to his private office and broke the news he would lead the fight to oust colmer , whom he is said to regard as `` an inferior man ' ' .	69.788124
news of rayburn ' s commitment soon leaked out .	15.525841
when missouri ' s clarence cannon got the word , he turned purple .	135.51094
he shouted , and rushed off to the speaker ' s room to object `` a dangerous precedent ' ' ! !	39.70096
cannon , a powerful , conservative man , brought welcome support to the smith-colmer forces as chairman of the appropriations committee , he holds over each member the dreadful threat of excluding this or that congressional district from federal pork-barrel projects .	234.00764
sitting quietly on an equally big pork barrel was another judge smith ally , georgia ' s carl vinson , chairman of the armed services committee .	43.290245
as the battle raged in the cloakrooms and caucuses , it became clear that judge smith could lose .	65.46975
his highest count of supporters numbered 72 -- and he needed nearly twice that number to control the 260-member democratic caucus .	312.7584
the liberals , smelling blood , were faced with the necessity of winning three big votes -- in the democratic committee on committees , in the full party caucus , and on the floor of the house -- before they could oust colmer .	53.597126
( one big question if colmer was to be purged , what should the house do about the other three senior mississippians who supported the maverick electors ? ?	96.29374
) in all three arenas , they seemed certain of victory -- especially with sam rayburn applying his whiplash .	113.5921
but in the prospect of winning the battle loomed the specter of losing a costlier war .	62.66309
if the southerners were sufficiently aroused , they could very well cut the kennedy legislative program to ribbons from their vantage point of committee chairmanships , leaving sam rayburn leading a truncated , unworkable party .	128.75037
with that possibility in mind , arkansas ' wilbur mills deliberately delayed calling a meeting of the committee on committees , and coolheaded democrats sought to bring rayburn and smith together again to work out some sort of face-saving compromise .	96.83763
`` here are two old men , mad at each other and too proud to pick up the phone ' ' , said a house democratic leader .	68.9752
`` one wants a little more power , and the other doesn ' t want to give up any ' ' .	16.155476
the senate launched the 87th congress with its own version of an ancient liberal-conservative battle , but in contrast with the house ' s guerrilla war it seemed as pro forma as a capitol guide ' s speech .	52.113285
question at issue how big a vote should be necessary to restrict senate debate -- and thereby cut off legislation-delaying filibusters ? ?	55.56825
a wide-ranging , bipartisan force -- from minnesota ' s democratic hubert humphrey to massachusetts ' republican leverett saltonstall -- was drawn up against a solid phalanx of southern democrats , who have traditionally used the filibuster to stop civil rights bills .	80.38415
new mexico ' s clint anderson offered a resolution to change the senate ' s notorious rule 22 to allow three-fifths of the senators present and voting to cut off debate , instead of the current hard-to-get two-thirds .	95.70885
fair dealer humphrey upped the ante , asked cloture power for a mere majority of senators .	31.058842
georgia ' s dick russell objected politely , and the battle was joined .	76.623795
privately , the liberals admitted that the humphrey amendment had no chance of passage .	43.675373
privately , they also admitted that their hopes for clint anderson ' s three-fifths modification depended on none other than republican richard nixon .	122.02116
in 1957 nixon delivered a significant opinion that a majority of senators had the power to adopt new rules at the beginning of each new congress , and that any rules laid down by previous congresses were not binding .	48.310516
armed with the nixon opinion , the senate liberals rounded up their slim majority and prepared to choke off debate on the filibuster battle this week .	102.16964
hopefully , the perennial battle of rule 22 then would be fought to a settlement once and for all .	140.30379
since election day , vice president richard nixon had virtually retired -- by his own wish -- from public view .	256.96985
but with the convening of the new congress , he was the public man again , presiding over the senate until john kennedy ' s inauguration .	69.41078
one day last week , nixon faced a painful constitutional chore that required him to officiate at a joint session of congress to hear the official tally of the electoral college vote , and then to make `` sufficient declaration ' ' of the election of the man who defeated him in the tight 1960 presidential election .	59.92466
nixon fulfilled his assignment with grace , then went beyond the required `` sufficient declaration ' ' .	55.615513
`` this is the first time in 100 years that a candidate for the presidency announced the result of an election in which he was defeated ' ' , he said .	29.899698
the masters golf tournament proved last monday what it can do to the strongest men and the staunchest nerves .	71.143906
gary player , the small , trim south african , was the eventual winner , but in all his 25 years he never spent a more harrowing afternoon as he waited for the victory to drop in his lap .	114.034904
arnold palmer , the defending champion , lost his title on the 72nd hole after a few minutes of misfortune that left even his fellow pros gaping in disbelief .	66.097984
`` just when you think you have it licked , this golf course can get up and bite you ' ' , player had said one afternoon midway through the tournament .	83.07731
and that is just what happened on the last few holes .	113.00879
the augusta national golf club course got up and bit both player and palmer .	195.4684
player was the first to feel its teeth .	4.880343
after playing a splendid first nine holes in 34 -- two strokes under par -- on this fifth and final day of the tournament ( sunday ' s fourth round had been washed out by a violent rainstorm when it was only half completed ) , player ' s game rapidly fell to pieces .	75.247894
after a journey through woods and stream he double-bogeyed the 13th .	45.57775
he bogeyed the 15th by missing a short putt and finally scrambled through the last three holes without further mishap for a 2-over-par 74 and a 72-hole total of 280 .	46.99996
as he signed his scorecard and walked off the course , player was almost in tears .	64.196625
he could read on the nearby scoreboard that palmer , by then playing the 15th hole , was leading him by a stroke .	93.58248
palmer had started the round four strokes behind player , and at one point in the afternoon had trailed by as many as six strokes .	61.421074
now all he had to do was finish in even par to collect the trophy and the biggest single paycheck in golf .	148.91519
when palmer hit a good straight drive up the fairway on the 72nd hole , he seemed to have the championship won .	27.875244
but the seven-iron shot he used to approach the green strayed into a bunker and lodged in a slight depression .	21.293352
in trying to hit it out with a sand wedge palmer bounced the ball over the green , past spectators and down the slope toward a tv tower .	103.46981
afterwards , palmer told charlie coe , his last-round partner , that he simply played the hole too fast .	99.8086
he did seem hasty on his second and third shots , but then there was an agonizing wait of several minutes while coe graciously putted out , giving palmer a chance to recover his composure , which he had quite visibly lost .	63.064762
when the shaken palmer finally did hit his fourth shot , he overshot the hole by 15 feet .	45.63365
palmer was now putting merely for a tie , and player , who was sitting beside his wife and watching it all on television in tournament chairman clifford roberts ' clubhouse apartment , stared in amazement when palmer missed the putt .	91.59375
palmer ' s 281 for the four rounds at augusta was a comfortable four strokes ahead of the next closest pro , but it was barely good enough for a second-place tie with coe .	92.36122
the lean and leathery oklahoma amateur , who has been playing topnotch tournament golf for many years , refused to let the masters jitters overtake him and closed the tournament with his second straight 69 .	43.568
until late last saturday afternoon palmer had played seven consecutive rounds of golf at the masters -- four last year and three this -- without ever being out of first place .	142.10143
as evening approached and palmer finished his saturday round with a disappointing one-over-par 73 , this remarkable record was still intact , thanks to his thursday and friday rounds of 68 and 69 .	87.89181
his three-round total of 210 was three strokes better than the next best score , a 213 by bill collins , the tall and deliberate baltimorean who had been playing very well all winter long .	108.7794
but palmer knew , as did everybody else at augusta , that his streak was about to be broken .	69.12853
half an hour after he finished his round , player holed out at the 18th green with a 69 and a three-round total of 206 , four strokes ahead of palmer .	30.179615
long after the erratic climate and the washed-out final round on sunday have become meteorological footnotes , the 1961 masters will be remembered as the scene of the mano a mano between arnold palmer and gary player .	82.32486
unlike most such sports rivalries , it appeared to have developed almost spontaneously , although this was not exactly the case .	49.37829
when the winter tour began at los angeles last january there was no one in sight to challenge palmer ' s towering prestige .	124.14588
as if to confirm his stature , he quickly won three of the first eight tournaments .	115.64095
but as the tour reached pensacola a month ago , player was leading palmer in official winnings by a few hundred dollars , and the rest of the field was somewhere off in nowhere .	67.30749
on the final round at pensacola , the luck of the draw paired palmer and player in the same threesome and , although it was far from obvious at the time , the gallery was treated to the first chapter of what promises to be one of the most exciting duels in sport for a long time to come .	53.341053
on that final sunday at pensacola neither palmer nor player was leading the tournament and , as it turned out , neither won it .	126.00514
but whichever of these two finished ahead of the other would be the undisputed financial leader of the tour .	74.296936
player immediately proved he was not in the least awed by the dramatic proximity of palmer .	43.57592
he outplayed palmer all around the course and finished with a tremendous 65 to palmer ' s 71 .	67.19983
thereafter , until the masters , player gradually increased his lead over palmer in winnings and added one more tournament victory at miami .	248.11035
when they reached augusta last week , together they had won five of the 13 tournaments to date .	50.54378
on thursday , the first day of the masters , the contest between palmer and player developed instantly .	114.64582
it was a dismal , drizzly day but a good one on which to score over the augusta national course .	118.483315
the usually skiddy greens were moist and soft , so the golfers were able to strike their approach shots boldly at the flag-stick and putt firmly toward the hole without too much worry about the consequences .	99.933365
palmer ' s 4-under-par 68 got him off to an early lead , which he shared with bob rosburg .	65.90089
but player was only one stroke back , with a 69 .	34.86228
even so , it was still not clear to many in the enormous horde of spectators -- unquestionably the largest golf crowd ever -- that this tournament was to be , essentially , a match between palmer and player .	91.36139
a lot of people were still thinking about jack nicklaus , the spectacular young amateur , who had a 70	66.60287
or ken venturi , who had a somewhat shaky 72 but was bound to do better	96.68099
or rosburg , whose accurate short game and supersensitive putter can overcome so many of augusta ' s treacheries	64.42723
or even old byron nelson , whose excellent 71 made one wonder if he had solved the geriatric aspects of golf .	178.72115
( on thursday nobody except charlie coe was thinking of charlie coe .	38.27945
on friday , a day as cloudless and lovely as thursday had been gray and ugly , the plot of the tournament came clearly into focus .	204.00758
rosburg had started early in the day , and by the time palmer and player were on the course -- separated , as they were destined to be for the rest of the weekend , by about half an hour -- they could see on the numerous scoreboards spotted around the course that rosburg , who ended with a 73 , was not having a good day .	53.838078
as player began his second round in a twosome with amateur bill hyndman , his share of the gallery was not conspicuously large for a contender .	82.046585
player began with a birdie on the first hole , added five straight pars and then another birdie at the 9th .	50.346394
on the back nine he began to acquire the tidal wave of a gallery that stayed with him the rest of the tournament .	27.958319
he birdied the 13th , the 15th and the 18th -- five birdies , one bogey and 12 pars for a 68 .	21.530827
starting half an hour behind player in company with british open champion kel nagle , palmer birdied the 2nd , the 9th , the 13th and the 16th -- four birdies , one bogey and 13 pars for a 69 .	35.104527
the roar of palmer ' s gallery as he sank a thrilling putt would roll out across the parklike landscape of augusta , only to be answered moments later by the roar of player ' s gallery for a similar triumph .	85.315636
at one point late in the day , when palmer was lining up a 25-foot putt on the 16th , a thunderous cheer from the direction of the 18th green unmistakably announced that player had birdied the final hole .	59.48958
without so much as a grimace or a gesture to show that he had noticed ( although he later admitted that he had ) palmer proceeded to sink his 25-footer , and his gallery sent its explosive vocalization rolling back along the intervening fairways in reply .	79.81235
anyone who now doubted that a personal duel was under way had only to watch how these exceptionally gifted golfers were playing this most difficult golf course .	100.981834
it is almost axiomatic that golfers who dominate the game of golf for any period of time attack their shots with a vehemence bordering on violence .	87.844
the bad luck that can so often mar a well-played round of golf is simply overpowered and obliterated by the contemptuous boldness of these champions .	38.529655
and last week at the masters palmer and player did .	65.94464
as the third round of the tournament began on saturday and the duel was resumed in earnest , it was player ' s superior aggressiveness that carried him into the lead .	53.757256
as player stepped on the first tee he knew that palmer had birdied the first two holes and already was 2 under par for the day .	66.9455
in fact , he went on to birdie the 6th and 8th as well , to go 4 under par for the first eight holes .	66.89196
but player ' s real test came on the ninth hole , a downhill dogleg to the left measuring 420 yards .	24.791466
he hit a poor tee shot , pulling it off into the pine woods separating the 9th and first fairways .	99.4292
having hit one of the trees , the ball came to rest not more than 160 yards out .	94.076645
player then had the choice of punching the ball safely out of the woods to the 9th fairway and settling for a bogey 5 , or gambling .	59.913372
the latter involved hitting a full four-wood out to the first fairway and toward the clubhouse , hoping to slice it back to the deeply bunkered 9th green .	35.1486
`` i was hitting the ball well ' ' , player said later , `` and i felt strong .	26.75541
when you ' re playing like that you ' d better attack ' ' .	36.95404
player attacked with his four-wood and hit a shot that few who saw it will ever forget .	125.29528
it struck the 9th green on the fly and stopped just off the edge .	78.53351
from there he chipped back and sank his putt for a par 4 .	110.6981
palmer , meanwhile , had been having his troubles .	76.62848
they started on the 4th hole , a 220-yard par-3 .	18.514065
on this day the wind had switched 180-degrees from the northwest to the southeast , and nearly every shot on the course was different from the previous few days .	53.926716
at the 4th tee palmer chose to hit a one-iron when a three-wood was the proper club , so he put the ball in a bunker in front of the green .	43.167355
his bogey 4 on this hole and subsequent bogeys at 5 and 7 along with a birdie at 8 brought him back to even par .	115.69809
starting the second nine , palmer was already four strokes behind player and knew it .	52.957367
when mickey charles mantle , the new york yankees ' man of muscle , drives a home run 450 feet into the bleachers , his feat touches upon the sublime .	119.95326
when roger eugene maris , mantle ' s muscular teammate , powers four home runs in a double-header , his performance merits awe .	74.709145
but when tiny , 145-pound albert gregory pearson of the los angeles angels , who once caught three straight fly balls in center field because , as a teammate explained , `` the other team thought no one was out there ' ' , hits seven home runs in four months ( three more than his total in 1958 , 1959 , and 1960 ) , his achievement borders on the ridiculous .	77.11191
this is the year home runs ranged from the sublime to the ridiculous .	53.687195
it is the year when ( 1 ) amiable jim gentile of the baltimore orioles ambled to the plate in consecutive innings with the bases loaded and , in unprecedented style , delivered consecutive grand-slam home runs	61.2969
( 2 ) willie mays of the san francisco giants borrowed a teammate ' s bat and became the ninth big leaguer to stroke four home runs in a game	39.254913
( 3 ) the milwaukee braves tied a major-league record with fourteen home runs in three games and lost two of them	32.220123
and ( 4 ) catcher johnny blanchard of the new york yankees matched a record with home runs in four successive times at bat , two of them as a pinch-hitter .	31.846354
pitchers grumble about lively balls and lively bats , the shrinking strike zone , and the fact that the knock-down pitch is now illegal .	50.480373
experts point to the thinning of pitching talent in the american league caused by expansion .	68.906136
whatever the reasons , not in 30 years has a single season produced such thunderous assaults upon the bureau of baseball records , home-run division .	193.86874
of all the records in peril , one stands apart , dramatic in its making , dramatic in its endurance , and now , doubly dramatic in its jeopardy .	114.1614
this , of course , is baseball ' s most remarkable mark the 60 home runs hit in 1927 by the incorrigible epicure , the incredible athlete , george herman ( babe ) ruth of the yankees .	46.224354
since 1927 , fewer than a dozen men have made serious runs at babe ruth ' s record and each , in turn , has been thwarted .	86.6859
what ultimately frustrated every challenger was ruth ' s amazing september surge .	159.33899
in the final month of the 1927 season , he hit seventeen home runs , a closing spurt never matched .	102.24802
always , in the abortive attacks upon ruth ' s record , one man alone -- a jimmy foxx ( 58 in 1932 ) or a hank greenberg ( 58 in 1938 ) or a hack wilson ( 56 in 1930 ) -- made the bid .	46.784454
but now , for the first time since lou gehrig ( with 47 home runs ) spurred ruth on in 1927 , two men playing for the same team have zeroed in on 60 .	107.94327
their names are mantle and maris , their team is the yankees , and their threat is real .	91.12684
after 108 games in 1927 , ruth had 35 home runs .	35.806168
after 108 games in 1961 , mickey mantle has 43 , roger maris 41 .	70.373856
extend mantle ' s and maris ' s present paces over the full 1961 schedule of 162 games , and , mathematically , each will hit more than 60 home runs .	89.56162
this is the great edge the two yankees have going for them .	77.873474
to better ruth ' s mark , neither needs a spectacular september flourish .	153.43324
all mantle needs is eight more home runs in august and ten in september , and he will establish a new record .	62.74214
in ruth ' s day -- and until this year -- the schedule was 154 games .	67.07207
baseball commissioner ford frick has ruled that ruth ' s record will remain official unless it is broken in 154 games .	113.8207
`` even on the basis of 154 games , this is the ideal situation ' ' , insists hank greenberg , now vice-president of the chicago white sox .	32.456184
`` it has to be easier with two of them .	10.477616
how can you walk maris to get to mantle ' ' ? ?	11.905923
neither mantle nor maris , understandably , will predict 60 home runs for himself .	88.38985
although both concede they would like to hit 60 , they stick primarily to the baseball player ' s standard quote `` the important thing is to win the pennant ' ' .	78.60964
but one thing is for certain there is no dissension between mantle , the american league ' s most valuable player in 1956 and 1957 , and maris , the mvp in 1960 .	54.28153
each enjoys seeing the other hit home runs ( `` i hope roger hits 80 ' ' , mantle says ) , and each enjoys even more seeing himself hit home runs ( `` and i hope i hit 81 ' ' ) .	95.99684
the sluggers get along so well in fact , that with their families at home for the summer ( mantle ' s in dallas , maris ' s in kansas city ) , they are rooming together .	46.586754
mantle , maris , and bob cerv , a utility outfielder , share an apartment in jamaica , long island , not far from new york international airport .	83.708015
the three pay $251 a month for four rooms ( kitchen , dining room , living room , and bedroom ) , with air-conditioning and new modern furniture .	70.38916
mantle and cerv use the twin beds in the bedroom	25.950422
maris sleeps on a green studio couch in the living room .	12.7444315
they divide up the household chores cerv does most of the cooking ( breakfast and sandwich snacks , with dinner out ) , mantle supplies the transportation ( a white 1961 oldsmobile convertible ) , and maris drives the 25-minute course from the apartment house to yankee stadium .	57.77065
mantle , maris , and cerv probably share one major-league record already among them , they have fifteen children -- eight for cerv , four for mantle , and three for maris .	110.84879
as roommates , teammates , and home-run mates , mantle , 29 , who broke in with the yankees ten years ago , and maris , 26 , who came to the yankees from kansas city two years ago , have strikingly similar backgrounds .	57.92062
both were scholastic stars in football , basketball , and baseball ( mantle in commerce , okla . , maris in fargo , n . d . )	29.541521
as halfbacks , both came close to playing football at the university of oklahoma ( `` sometimes in the minors ' ' , maris recalls , `` i wished i had gone to oklahoma ' ' ) .	31.850426
to an extent , the two even look alike .	66.57099
both have blue eyes and short blond hair .	3.3481066
both are 6 feet tall and weigh between 195 and 200 pounds , but mantle , incredibly muscular ( he has a 17-1/2-inch neck ) , looks bigger .	74.975044
with their huge backs and overdeveloped shoulders , both must have their clothes made to order .	206.55148
maris purchases $100 suits from simpson ' s in new york .	30.72142
mantle , more concerned with dress , buys his suits four at a time at neiman-marcus in dallas and pays as much as $250 each .	173.73915
neither mantle nor maris need fear being classified an intellectual , but lately mantle has shown unusual devotion to an intellectual opus , henry miller ' s `` tropic of cancer ' ' .	39.48425
mantle so appreciated miller ' s delicate literary style that he broadened teammates ' minds by reading sensitive passages aloud during road trips .	171.20422
mantle is not normally given to public speaking -- or , for that matter , to private speaking .	92.87392
`` what do you and mickey talk about at home ' ' ? ?	12.444845
`` to tell you the truth ' ' , maris said , `` mickey don ' t talk much ' ' .	20.4129
this is no surprising trait for a ballplayer .	8.4790325
what is surprising and pleasant is that mantle and maris , under constant pressure from writers and photographers , are trying to be cooperative .	66.270195
of the two , mantle is by nature the less outgoing , maris the more outspoken .	185.4258
but last week , when a reporter was standing near mantle ' s locker , mickey walked up and volunteered an anecdote .	124.81876
he said , pointing to a dark-haired 11-year-old boy .	12.210806
`` that ' s ( yogi ) berra ' s .	7.4553213
i ' ll never forget one time i struck out three times , dropped a fly ball , and we lost the game .	116.29264
i came back , sitting by my locker , feeling real low , and the kid walks over to me , looks up , and says ' you stunk ' ' ' .	64.295456
maris , in talking to reporters , tries to answer all questions candidly and fully , but on rare occasions , he shuns newsmen .	81.428856
`` when i ' ve made a dumb play ' ' , he says , `` i don ' t want to talk to anyone .	10.9232235
by his own confession , maris is an angry young man .	26.857037
benched at tulsa in 1955 , he told manager dutch meyer `` i can ' t play for you .	49.47241
send me where i can play ' ' .	2.8888476
( meyer sent him to reading , pa . .	6.863574
) benched at indianapolis in 1956 , he told manager kerby farrell `` i ' m not learning anything on the bench .	128.2379
( farrell did -- and maris led the team to victory in the little world series .	92.269005
) `` that ' s the way i am ' ' , he says .	5.321023
if you ' re a good ballplayer , you ' ve got to get mad .	18.064308
give me a team of nine angry men and i ' ll give you a team of nine gentlemen and we ' ll beat you nine out of ten times ' ' .	43.55145
one good indication of the two men ' s personalities is the way they reacted to meeting their own heroes .	97.609245
`` when i was a kid ' ' , maris told a sportswriter last week , `` i used to follow williams every day in the box score , just to see whether he got a hit or not ' ' .	54.73714
`` when you came up to the majors , did you seek out williams for advice ' ' ? ?	117.24978
`` you ' re afraid to talk to a guy you idolize ' ' .	14.345368
`` when mickey went to the yankees ' ' , says mark freeman , an ex-yankee pitcher who sells mutual funds in denver , `` dimaggio still was playing and every day mickey would go by his locker , just aching for some word of encouragement from this great man , this hero of his .	136.17119
he told me he vowed right then that if he ever got to be a star , this never would be said of him ' ' .	41.241547
among all the yankees , he is the veteran most friendly to rookies .	139.47578
neither mantle nor maris is totally devoted to baseball above all else .	298.92505
if laying ties on a railroad track , which he once did for $1 an hour , paid more than playing right field for the yankees , maris would lay ties on a railroad track .	109.448814
if working in a zinc mine , which he once did for 87-1/2 cents an hour , paid more than playing center field for the yankees , mantle would work in a zinc mine .	143.31068
but since railroading and mining are not the highest paid arts , mantle and maris concentrate on baseball .	135.18953
they try to play baseball the best they can .	23.656322
mantle , beyond any question , can do more things well .	190.99985
( `` one of the reasons they get along fine ' ' , says a sportswriter who is friendly with the two men , `` is that both realize mantle is head-and-shoulders above maris ' ' .	81.82092
) hitting , mantle has an immediate advantage because he bats both left-handed and right-handed , maris only left-handed .	55.91362
they both possess near classic stances , dug in firmly , arms high , set for fierce swings .	124.58276
both are good bunters maris once beat out eighteen of nineteen in the minor leagues	95.16285
mantle is a master at dragging a bunt toward first base .	199.7561
both have brilliant speed mantle was timed from home plate ( batting left-handed ) to first base in 3 . 1 seconds , faster than any other major leaguer	63.03836
maris ran the 100-yard dash in ten seconds in high school and once won a race against luis aparicio , the swift , base-stealing shortstop of the white sox .	47.302204
both are good , daring fielders mantle covers more ground	1300.1559
yet with all their skills , the appeal of mantle and maris in 1961 comes down to one basic the home run .	209.09439
with this ultimate weapon , the two yankees may have saved baseball from its dullest season .	67.24041
( american league expansion created , inevitably , weaker teams .	107.44157
only two teams in each league ( the yankees and detroit , the dodgers and cincinnati ) are battling for first place .	66.96776
appropriately , the emphasis on the home run , at a peak this year , came into being at baseball ' s lowest moment .	74.684166
in 1920 , as the startling news that the 1919 white sox had conspired to lose the world series leaked out , fans grew disillusioned and disinterested in baseball .	77.33075
into washington on president-elect john f . kennedy ' s convair , the caroline , winged actor-crooner frank sinatra and his close hollywood pal , cinemactor peter lawford , jack kennedy ' s brother-in-law .	39.33886
also included in the entourage a dog in a black sweater , frankie and peter had an urgent mission to stage a mammoth inauguration eve entertainment gala in the capital ' s national guard armory .	74.40602
frankie was fairly glutted with ideas , as he had hinted upon his arrival `` it ' s really tremendous when you think ella fitzgerald is coming from australia .	101.05698
i could talk to you for three hours and still not be able to give you all of our plans ' ' ! !	36.865852
as the plans were laid , some several thousand fat cats were to be ensconced in the armory ' s $100 seats and in 68 ringside boxes priced at $10 , 000 each .	51.378925
the biggest single act would doubtless be staged by frankie himself his inaugural wardrobe had been designed by hollywood couturier don loper , who regularly makes up ladies ' ensembles .	112.70549
soon after loper leaked the news that frankie had ordered `` two of everything ' ' just `` in case he spills anything ' ' , frankie got so mad at the chic designer that he vowed he would not wear a stitch of loper clothing .	87.83499
a year after he was catapulted over nine officers senior to him and made commandant of the marine corps , general david m . shoup delivered a peppery annual report in the form of a `` happy , warless new year ' ' greeting to his pentagon staff .	78.976074
said leatherneck shoup `` a year ago i took the grips of the plow in my hands .	43.499996
