in fact , the neat balance of these pairs , and their subtle equilibrium , would have had special meaning in the minds of the old chinese .	65.92788
for they considered the odd numbers as male and the even ones as female , equating the two groups with the yang and yin principles in nature	107.27488
and in this square , the respective pairs made up of large and small odd ( yang ) numbers , and those composed of large and small even ( yin ) numbers , were all equal to each other .	151.1795
thus all differences were leveled , and all contrasts erased , in a realm of no distinction , and the harmonious balance of the lo shu square could effectively symbolize the world in balanced harmony around a powerful central axis .	78.7563
the tremendous emphasis on the 5 in the lo shu square -- for purely mathematical reasons -- and the fact that this number so neatly symbolized the heart and center of the universe , could well explain why the old chinese seem to have so revered the number 5 , and why they put so much stress on the concept of centrality .	58.901505
these twin tendencies seem to have reached their height in the han dynasty .	17.012934
the existing reverence for centrality must have been still further stimulated toward the close of the second century b . c . , when the han emperor wu ti ordered the dynastic color changed to yellow -- which symbolized the center among the traditional five directions -- and took 5 as the dynastic number , believing that he would thus place himself , his imperial family , and the nation under the most auspicious influences .	96.2169
his immediate motive for doing this may not have been directly inspired by the lo shu , but this measure must inevitably have increased the existing beliefs in the latter ' s efficacy .	58.57001
after this time , inscriptions on the han bronze mirrors , as well as other writings , emphasized the desirability of keeping one ' s self at the center of the universe , where cosmic forces were strongest .	37.648285
later , we shall see what happened when an emperor took this idea too literally .	399.06366
all this emphasis on centrality and on the number 5 as a symbolic expression of the center , which seems to have begun as far back as 400 b . c . , also may conceivably have led to the development of the five-elements school and the subsequent efforts to fit everything into numerical categories of five .	73.758064
we find , for example , such groupings as the five ancient rulers , the five sacred mountains , the five directions ( with center ) , the five metals , five colors , five tastes , five odors , five musical notes , five bodily functions , five viscera , and many others .	70.151794
this trend has often been ascribed to the cult of the five elements itself , as though they had served as the base for all the rest	72.390175
but why did the old chinese postulate five elements , when the ancient near east -- which may have initiated the idea that natural elements exerted influence in human life and activities -- recognized only four ? ?	127.469666
and why did the chinese suddenly begin to talk about the five directions , when the animals they used as symbols of the directions designated only the usual four ? ?	138.18701
obviously , something suddenly caused them to start thinking in terms of fives , and that may have been the workings of the lo shu .	29.040932
this whole tendency had an unfortunate effect on chinese thinking .	311.17056
whereas the primary meanings of the lo shu diagram seemed to have been based on its inner mathematical properties -- and we shall see that even its secondary meanings rested on some mathematical bases -- the urgent desire to place everything into categories of fives led to other groupings based on other numbers , until an exaggerated emphasis on mere numerology pervaded chinese thought .	134.52205
scholars made numbered sets of as many things as possible in nature , or assigned arbitrary numbers to individual things , in a fashion that seems to the modern scientific mind as downright nonsensical , and philosophical ideas based upon all this tended to stifle speculative thought in china for many centuries .	114.71548
yin and yang in the `` lo shu ' ' square	4.7168565
although the primary mathematical properties of the middle number at the center of the lo shu , and the interrelation of all the other numbers to it , might seem enough to account for the deep fascination which the lo shu held for the old chinese philosophers , this was actually only a beginning of wonders .	57.63462
for the lo shu square was a remarkably complete compendium of most of the chief religious and philosophical ideas of its time .	53.040157
as such , one cannot fully understand the thought of the pre-han and han periods without knowing the meanings inherent in the lo shu	112.994995
but , conversely , one cannot begin to understand the lo shu without knowing something about the world view of the old chinese , which they felt they saw expressed in it .	48.910786
the chinese world view during the han dynasty , when the lo shu seems to have been at the height of its popularity , was based in large part on the teachings of the yin-yang and five-elements school , which was traditionally founded by tsou yen .	38.9711
according to this doctrine , the universe was ruled by heaven , t ' ien -- as a natural force , or in the personification of a supreme sky-god -- governing all things by means of a process called the tao , which can be roughly interpreted as `` the order of the universe ' ' or `` the universal way ' ' .	45.26595
heaven , acting through the tao , expressed itself by means of the workings of two basic principles , the yin and the yang .	48.58844
the yang , or male principle , was the source of light , heat , and dynamic vitality , associated with the sun	71.09962
while the yin , or female principle , flourished in darkness , cold , and quiet inactivity , and was associated with the moon .	49.13312
together these two principles influenced all things , and in varying combinations they were present in everything .	76.007904
we have already seen that odd numbers were considered as being yang , while the even numbers were yin , so that the eight outer numbers of the lo shu represented these two principles in balanced equilibrium around the axial center .	130.5567
during the han dynasty , another yin-yang conception was applied to the lo shu , considering the latter as a plan of ancient china .	48.69193
instead of linking the nine numbers of this diagram with the traditional nine provinces , as was usually done , this equated the odd , yang numbers with mountains ( firm and resistant , hence yang ) and the even numbers with rivers ( sinuous and yielding , hence yin )	166.7953
taking the former from the five sacred mountains of the han period and the latter from the principal river systems of old china .	112.44713
thus the middle number , 5 , represented sung-shan in honan , central china	66.62164
the 3 , t ' ai-shan in shantung , east china	30.959034
the 7 , hwa-shan in shensi , west china	6.5361385
the 1 , heng-shan in hopei , north china ( or the mountain with the same name in neighboring shansi )	67.89266
and the 9 , huo-shan in anhwei , which was then the south sacred mountain .	66.88826
for the rivers , the 4 represented the huai , to the ( then ) southeast	84.217964
the 2 , the san kiang ( three rivers ) in the ( then ) southwest	40.47844
and the 6 , the ( upper ) yellow river in the northwest .	48.74476
note that by western standards this plan was `` upside down ' ' , as it put north at the bottom and south at the top , with the other directions correspondingly altered	57.15737
but in this respect it was merely following the accepted chinese convention for all maps .	91.77011
the same arrangement was used when the lo shu was equated with the nine provinces	19.214252
and whenever the lo shu involved directional symbolism , it was oriented in this same fashion .	51.11618
few persons who join the church are insincere .	1.8365618
they earnestly desire to do the will of god .	11.963606
when they fall by the wayside and fail to achieve christian stature , it is an indictment of the church .	34.44054
these fatalities are dramatic evidence of `` halfway evangelism ' ' , a failure to follow through .	39.88129
a program of lay visitation evangelism can end in dismal defeat with half the new members drifting away unless practical plans and strenuous efforts are made to keep them in the active fellowship .	121.84951
the work of lay visitation evangelism is not completed when all of the persons on the responsibility list have been interviewed .	144.5419
in the average situation about one-third of those visited make commitments to christ and the church .	98.15327
the pastor and the membership preparation and assimilation committee must follow through immediately with a carefully planned program .	159.72444
the first thirty to sixty days after individuals make their decision will determine their interest and participation in the life of the church .	40.315697
churches that have a carefully planned program of membership preparation and assimilation often keep 85 to 90 per cent of their new members loyal and active .	68.25853
this is the answer to the problem of `` membership delinquency ' ' .	61.780785
it is important that persons desiring to unite with the church be prepared for this experience so that it may be meaningful and spiritually significant .	55.23178
it is unfair and unchristian to ask a person to take the sacred vows of church membership before he has been carefully instructed concerning their implications .	90.68841
preparation for church membership begins immediately after the commitment is received .	681.4035
the pastor writes a personal letter to each individual , expressing his joy over the decision , assuring him of a pastoral call at the earliest convenient time , and outlining the plan for membership preparation classes and membership sunday .	89.191574
some pastors write a letter the same night the decision is reported by the visitors .	100.56354
it should not be postponed later than the next day .	38.77781
a helpful leaflet may be enclosed in the letter .	35.84335
the pastor calls in the home of each individual or family for a spiritual guidance conference .	129.15645
if possible , he should make an appointment in order that all persons involved may be present .	43.787144
it is definitely a `` spiritual guidance conference ' ' .	1.5741873
he will discuss the significance of christian commitment , the necessity of family religion and private devotions , and the importance of the membership preparation sessions .	38.77781
there may be problems of conduct or questions of belief which will require his counsel .	142.7888
each conference should be concluded naturally with prayer .	4.99046
a piece of devotional material , such as the upper room , may be left in each home .	83.43993
a minimum of four sessions of preparation for membership is necessary for adults .	104.48022
those who join the church need to be instructed in the faith and the meaning of christian discipleship before they take the sacred vows .	59.62561
they will have a greater appreciation for the church and a deeper devotion to it if membership requires something of them .	142.84361
many churches find the sunday school hour to be the most practical time for adult preparation classes .	126.68297
others meet on sunday night , at the mid-week service , or for a series of four nights .	42.41251
some pastors have two sessions in one evening , with a refreshment period between .	168.17598
following each instruction period a piece of literature dealing with the topic should be handed each one for further reading during the week .	105.18054
this procedure is much more effective than giving out a membership packet .	184.9449
most pastors find that the fourth session should take at least two hours and therefore hold it on a week night prior to reception sunday .	135.97672
in this session the persons seeking membership are provided information concerning the work of the denomination as well as the program and activities of the local church .	63.0139
the lay leadership of the church may be invited to speak on the various phases of church life , service opportunities , the church school , missions , men ' s work , women ' s work , youth program , social activities , and finances .	65.20834
the budget of the church may be presented and pledges solicited at this session .	114.59018
an `` interest finder ' ' or `` talent sheet ' ' may be filled out by each person .	48.753716
) the fourth session may be concluded with a tour of the church facilities and refreshments .	48.382492
the social time gives an opportunity for church leaders to become acquainted with the new members .	18.24822
in conducting the membership preparation-inquirers ' class , the pastor should plan a variety of teaching techniques in order to develop greater interest on the part of the class .	42.38452
some churches have six or more training sessions of two hours each , generally held on sunday night or during the week .	71.27314
this gives greater opportunity for the learning process .	4.4190993
use dramatization -- for example , in discussing the lord ' s supper or church symbolism .	45.7215
some excellent filmstrips with recordings and motion pictures may be secured from your denominational headquarters to enrich the class session .	122.95179
some new members will hesitate to ask questions audibly .	39.977093
urge them to write out their questions for the box .	31.240711
use a textbook with assigned readings each week .	3.5749805
select class members for reports on various phases of the study .	8.876731
conduct examinations , using a true-false check sheet .	20.513182
ask each member to write a statement on such topics as `` what christ means to me ' ' , `` what the church means to me ' ' , `` why join the church ' ' , `` the duties of church members ' ' , etc . .	30.12243
assign a series of catechism questions to be memorized .	63.34206
invite class members to share in an extra period of bible study each week .	193.74057
ask each new member to bring his pledge of loyalty to the reception service .	59.877476
there is a growing conviction among pastors and church leaders that all those who come into the fellowship of the church need preparatory training , including those coming by transfer of membership .	85.83063
george e . sweazey writes `` there is danger in trying to make admission to the church so easy and painless that people will scarcely know that anything has happened ' ' .	67.10934
people appreciate experiences that demand something of them .	3.9029553
those who transfer their membership are no exception to the rule .	14.046731
for most of them , it will be their first experience in membership training , since this is a recent development in many churches .	103.178474
those coming from other denominations will welcome the opportunity to become informed .	46.087914
the preparatory class is an introductory face-to-face group in which new members become acquainted with one another .	55.02941
it provides a natural transition into the life of the local church and its organizations .	20.849285
the total process of evangelism reaches the crescendo when the group of new members stands before the congregation to declare publicly their faith and to be received into the fellowship of the church .	47.285435
this should be a high moment in their lives , a never-to-be-forgotten experience .	123.99727
they should sense the tremendous significance of joining the spiritual succession reaching back to christ our lord and forward to an eternal fellowship with the saints of the ages .	77.06898
every detail of the service merits careful attention -- the hymns , the sermon , the ritual , the right hand of fellowship , the introduction to the congregation , the welcome of the congregation .	57.44103
this is a vital part of their spiritual growth and assimilation .	79.67049
it will help to determine the attitude of the new members toward the church .	32.938023
it can mean the difference between participation and inaction , spiritual growth and decay .	103.08116
the worship service is the natural and logical time to receive new members into the church .	80.203545
the atmosphere for this momentous experience can be created most effectively through the worship experience .	218.89366
psychologically the reception should be the climax , following the sermon .	95.59163
ask the new members to meet thirty minutes before the service to complete `` talent sheets ' ' and pledge cards .	141.25629
some denominations ask new members to sign personally the chronological membership register .	237.57613
provide a name card for each new member .	3.8453512
arrange a reserved section in the sanctuary where all new members may sit together .	65.83885
invite sponsors or fellowship friends to stand back of the new members in the reception service .	48.7006
give each new member a certificate of membership .	10.587837
introduce each new member to the congregation , asking him to face the congregation .	52.799698
lead the congregation in a response of welcome .	6.108903
have a reception for new members in the parlor or social hall immediately after the service .	274.2523
take a picture of the group of new members to be put in the church paper or placed on the bulletin board .	53.375107
have a fellowship luncheon or dinner with new members as guests .	50.872986
chapter 6 planning for the assimilation and growth of new members	16.043776
the church is `` the family of god ' ' .	1.7640226
the members of the `` family ' ' are drawn together by a common love for christ and a sincere devotion to his kingdom .	85.90068
every member of the family must have a vital place in its life .	36.049416
yet the most difficult problem in the church ' s program of evangelism is right at this point -- helping new members to become participating , growing parts of the fellowship .	59.582294
very easily they may be neglected and eventually join the ranks of the unconcerned and inactive .	105.62977
a study of major denominational membership statistics over a twenty-year period revealed the appalling fact that nearly 40 per cent of those who joined the church were lost to the church within seven years .	56.768543
one denomination had a membership of 1 , 419 , 833 at the beginning of the period under study , and twenty years later its membership stood at 1 , 541 , 991 -- a net growth of only 122 , 158 .	47.56769
yet during the same period there were 1 , 080 , 062 additions .	37.057186
another major church body had 4 , 499 , 608 members and twenty years later its membership stood at 4 , 622 , 444 .	29.462671
during this time 4 , 122 , 354 new members were brought into the fellowship .	32.12043
still another denomination had 7 , 360 , 187 members twenty years ago .	38.332546
during this period 7 , 484 , 268 members were received , yet the net membership now is only 9 , 910 , 741 .	124.3194
these figures indicate that we are losing almost as many as we are receiving into membership .	84.93594
this problem is illustrated by the fact that many local churches drop from the active membership rolls each year as many as they receive into the fellowship .	90.24419
studies of membership trends , even in some areas where population is expanding , show that numbers of churches have had little net increase , though many new members were received .	140.03403
the local `` family of god ' ' has failed its new members through neglect and unconcern for their spiritual welfare .	142.10156
new members can become participating , growing members .	51.810036
but this will not happen merely through the natural process of social life .	33.913017
the entire membership of the local church must be alerted to their part in this dynamic process .	55.970707
if the church has followed the plan of cultivation of prospects and carried through a program of membership preparation as outlined earlier in this book , the process of assimilation and growth will be well under way .	76.90125
those who enter the front door of the church intelligently and with christian dedication will not so easily step through the back door because of lost interest .	178.42073
however , it is not enough to bring persons to christian commitment and train them in the meaning of christian discipleship .	63.107113
when they unite with the church they must find in this fellowship the satisfaction of their basic spiritual needs or they will never mature into effective christians .	144.94676
the church expects certain things of those who become members .	90.75893
the new members justifiably expect some things from their church family	409.34616
-- opportunities for study of the christian faith and the bible	10.321827
care must be taken neither to confuse unity with uniformity nor god with our parochial ideas about him , but with these two qualifications , the statement stands .	182.96455
the statement also points to a classic paradox the more men turn toward god , who is not only in himself the paradigm of all unity but also the only ground on which human unity can ultimately be established , the more men splinter into groups and set themselves apart from one another .	107.522026
to be reminded of this we need only glance at the world map and note the extent to which religious divisions have compounded political ones , with a resultant fragmentation of the human race .	80.23637
massacres attending the partition of india and the establishment of the state of israel are simply recent grim evidences of the hostility such divisions can engender .	89.809235
the words of cardinal newman come forcibly to mind `` oh how we hate one another for the love of god ' ' ! !	83.87587
the source of this paradox is not difficult to identify .	65.17018
institutions require structure , form , and definition , and these in turn entail differentiation and exclusion .	85.447624
a completely amorphous institution would be a contradiction in terms	30.306181
to escape this fate , it must rule some things out .	107.49286
for every criterion which defines what something is , at the same time proclaims -- implicitly if not openly -- what that something is not .	97.4764
some persons are so sensitive to this truth as to propose that we do away with institutions altogether	259.23264
in the present context this amounts to the advice that while being religious may have a certain justification , we ought to dispense with churches .	251.61081
man is at once a gregarious animal and a form-creating being .	154.28163
having once committed himself to an ideal which he considers worthwhile , he inevitably creates forms for its expression and institutions for its continuance .	148.78587
to propose that men be religious without having religious institutions is like proposing that they be learned without having schools .	150.38051
both eventualities are possible logically , but practically they are impossible .	93.58796
as much as men intrinsically need the unity that is grounded in god , they instrumentally require the institutions that will direct their steps toward him .	126.74587
yet the fact remains that such institutions do set men at odds with their fellows .	160.96382
is there any way out of the predicament ? ?	8.046978
the only way that i can see is through communication .	797.0575
interfaith communication need not be regarded as an unfortunate burden visited upon us by the necessity of maintaining diplomatic relations with our adversaries .	87.279175
approached creatively , it is a high art .	23.581099
it is the art of relating the finite to the infinite , of doing our best to insure that the particularistic requirements of religious institutions will not thwart god ' s intent of unity among men more than is minimally necessary .	124.21119
in a certain sense , interfaith communication parallels diplomatic communication among the nation-states .	131.5264
what are the pertinent facts affecting such communication at the present juncture of history ? ?	56.576084
i shall touch on three areas personal , national , and theological .	86.26905
by personal factors i mean those rooted in personality structure .	125.46561
some interfaith tensions are not occasioned by theological differences at all , but by the need of men to have persons they can blame , distrust , denounce , and even hate .	60.587917
modern psychology has shown that paralleling `` the authoritarian personality ' ' is `` the bigoted personality ' ' in which insecurity , inferiority , suspicion , and distrust combine to provide a target for antagonism so indispensable that it will be manufactured if it does not exist naturally .	60.741722
fortunately the number of pathological bigots appears to be quite small , but it would be a mistake to think that more than a matter of degree separates them from the rest of us .	30.247572
to some extent the personal inadequacies that prejudices attempt to compensate for are to be found in all of us .	46.837883
interfaith conflicts which spring from psychological deficiencies are the most unfortunate of all , for they have no redeeming features whatsoever .	73.207664
it is difficult to say what can be done about them except that we must learn to recognize when it is they , rather than pretexts for them , that are causing the trouble , and do everything possible to nurture the healthy personalities that will prevent the development of such deficiencies .	86.686935
while the personality factors that aggravate interfaith conflict may be perennial , nationalism is more variable .	111.04401
the specific instance i have in mind is the afro-asian version which has gained prominence only in this second half of the twentieth century .	50.284286
emerging from the two centuries of colonial domination , the afro-asian world is aflame with a nationalism that has undone empires .	87.83475
no less than twenty-two nations have already achieved independence since world war 2 , , and the number is growing by the year .	37.325565
as an obvious consequence , obstacles to genuine interfaith communication have grown more formidable in one important area relations between christians and non-christians in these lands .	66.37321
colonialism alone would have been able to make these difficulties serious , for christianity is so closely tied to colonialism in the minds of these people that repudiation of the one has tended automatically toward the repudiation of the other .	114.1737
actually , however , this turns out to be only part of the picture .	27.1948
nationalism has abetted not only the repudiation of foreign religions but the revival of native ones , some of which had been lying in slumber for centuries .	116.12269
the truth is that any revival of traditional and indigenous religion will serve to promote that sense of identity and volksgeist which these young nations very much need .	139.10173
insofar as these nations claim to incarnate traditions and ways of life which constitute ultimate , trans-political justifications for their existence , such people are inevitably led to emphasize the ways in which these traditions and ways are theirs rather than someone else ' s .	88.4746
all this works severely against the kind of cross-cultural communication for which christian missions stand .	243.9313
africans and asians tend to consider not only missions but the local churches they have produced as centers and agents of western culture and ideology if not of direct political propaganda .	193.12057
the people hardest hit by this suspicion are , of course , christians on the mainland of china .	20.502567
for example , in burma and ceylon many buddhists argue that buddhism ought to be the official state religion .	132.38432
in 1960 ceylon nationalized its sectarian -- preponderantly christian -- schools , to the rejoicing of most of its 7 , 000 , 000 buddhists and the lament of its 800 , 000 roman catholics .	53.331184
again , india has imposed formidable barriers against the entrance of additional missionaries , and fanatical hindu parties are expected to seek further action against christians once the influence making for tolerance due to nehru and his followers is gone .	135.42503
the progressive closing of afro-asian ears to the christian message is epitomized in a conversation i had three years ago while flying from jerusalem to cairo .	139.22661
i was seated next to the director of the seventh day adventists ' world radio program .	104.25189
he said that on his tour the preceding year a considerable number of hours would have been available to him on japanese radio networks , but that he had then lacked the funds to contract for them .	66.92039
after returning to the united states and raising the money , he discovered on getting back to japan that the hours were no longer available .	65.24617
it was not that they had been contracted for during the interval	251.49937
they simply could no longer be purchased for missionary purposes .	113.588745
it is not unfair to add on the other side that the crude and almost vitriolic approach of certain fundamentalist sects toward the cultures and religions among which they work has contributed measurably to this heightening of anti-christian sentiment .	86.73746
ironically , these are the groups which have doubled or tripled their missionary efforts since world war 2 , , while the more established denominations are barely maintaining pre-war staffs .	115.44041
although i have emphasized the barriers which an aroused nationalism has raised against relations between christians and non-christians in asia , the fact is that this development has also widened the gulf between certain afro-asian religions themselves .	73.09751
the partition of india has hardly improved relations between hindus and muslims	6.6463127
neither has the establishment of the state of israel fostered harmony between muslims and jews .	48.460358
the modern world has been marked by progressive disaffection with claims to divine sanction for the state , whatever its political form .	97.29353
the american constitution was historic at this point in providing that `` congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion or prohibiting the free exercise thereof ' ' .	85.22436
one of our foremost jurists , david dudley field , has gone so far as to call this provision `` the greatest achievement ever made in the course of human history ' ' .	43.96977
the trend throughout the world ' s religions has been toward a recognition of at least the practical validity of this constitutional enactment .	74.60103
pakistan was created in 1947 expressly as a muslim state , but when the army took over eleven years later it did so on a wave of mass impatience which was directed in part against the inability of political and religious leaders to think their way through to the meaning of islam for the modern political situation .	74.938805
`` what is the point ' ' , charles adams reports the pakistanis as asking , `` in demanding an islamic state and society if no one , not even the doctors of the sacred law themselves , can say clearly and succinctly what the nature of such a state and society is ' ' ? ?	106.18629
the current regime of president mohammad ayub khan is determinedly secular .	113.1757
and while the nation was formerly named `` the islamic republic of pakistan ' ' , it is now simply `` the republic of pakistan ' ' .	17.209246
the new regime in turkey is intentionally less muslim than its predecessor .	20.353846
the religious parties in israel have experienced a great loss of prestige in recent months .	47.185623
during the years when israel was passing from crisis to crisis -- the sinai campaign , the infusion of multitudes of penniless immigrants -- it was felt that the purpose of national unity could be best served if the secular majority were to yield to the religious parties .	80.20278
now that israel enjoys relative prosperity and a reduction of tensions , the secularists are less disposed to compromise .	74.23249
and in this country gustave weigel ' s delineation of the line between the sacral and secular orders during the last presidential campaign served to provide a most impressive roman catholic defense of the practical autonomy of both church and state .	91.06033
the failure at that time of the puerto rican bishops to control the votes of their people added a ring of good sense to father weigel ' s theological argument .	62.620583
everywhere there seems to be a growing recognition of the fact that governments and religious institutions alike are too fallible and corruptible -- in a word , too human -- to warrant any claim of maintaining partnership with the divine .	90.01211
my father went as a missionary to china in a generation that responded to student volunteer movement speakers who held watches in their hands and announced to the students in their audiences how many chinese souls were going to hell each second because these students were not over there saving them .	201.69612
that mention of this should bring smiles to our lips today is as clear an indication as we could wish of the extent to which attitudes have changed .	152.46602
i do not mean to imply that christians have adopted the liberal assumption , so prevalent in hinduism , that all religions are merely different paths to the same summit .	53.182144
leslie newbiggin reflects the dominant position within the world council of churches when he says , `` we must claim absoluteness and finality for christ and his finished work , but that very claim forbids us to claim absoluteness and finality for our understanding of it ' ' .	56.736206
newbiggin ' s qualification on the christian claim is of considerable significance .	39.905544
the roman catholic church has excommunicated one of its priests , father feeney , for insisting that there is no salvation outside the visible church .	75.56399
in mentioning this under `` salvation reconsidered ' ' i do not mean to imply that roman catholic doctrine has changed in this area but rather that it has become clearer to the world community what that doctrine is .	60.914764
when they say that under no circumstances would it ever be right to `` permit ' ' the termination of the human race by human action , because there could not possibly be any proportionate grave reason to justify such a thing , they know exactly what they mean .	49.4358
of course , in prudential calculation , in balancing the good directly intended and done against the evil unintended and indirectly done , no greater precision can be forthcoming than the subject allows .	168.10062
yet it seems clear that there can be no good sufficiently great , or evil repelled sufficiently grave , to warrant the destruction of mankind by man ' s own action .	60.202564
i mean , however , that the moral theologian knows what he means by `` permit ' ' .	51.55669
he is not talking in the main about probabilities , risks and danger in general .	181.65874
he is talking about an action which just as efficaciously does an evil thing ( and is known certainly and unavoidably to lead to this evil result ) as it efficaciously does some good .	169.45815
he is talking about double effects , of which the specific action causes directly the one and indirectly the other , but causes both	178.0399
of which one is deliberately willed or intended and the other not intended or not directly intended , but still both are done , while the evil effect is , with equal consciousness on the part of the agent , foreknown to be among the consequences .	131.22502
this is what , in a technical sense , to `` only permit ' ' an evil result means .	66.775444
it means to do it and to know one is doing it , but as only a secondary if certain effect of the good one primarily does and intends .	189.81662
of course , grave guiltiness may be imputed to the military action of any nation , or to the action of any leader or leaders , which for any supposed good `` permits ' ' , in this sense , the termination of the human race by human action .	43.57439
certainly , in analyzing an action which truly faced such alternatives , `` it is never possible that no world would be preferable to some worlds , and there are in truth no circumstances in which the destruction of human life presents itself as a reasonable alternative ' ' .	57.472317
naturally , where one or the other of the effects of an action is uncertain , this has to be taken into account .	43.19348
especially is this true when , because the good effect is remote and speculative while the evil is certain and grave , the action is prohibited .	110.13085
presumably , if the reverse is the case and the good effect is more certain than the evil result that may be forthcoming , not only must the good and the evil be prudentially weighed and found proportionate , but also calculation of the probabilities and of the degree of certainty or uncertainty in the good or evil effect must be taken into account .	70.20132
there must not only be greater good than evil objectively in view , but also greater probability of actually doing more good than harm .	103.86082
if an evil which is certain and extensive and immediate may rarely be compensated for by a problematic , speculative , future good , by the same token not every present , certain , and immediate good ( or lesser evil ) that may have to be done will be outweighed by a problematic , speculative , and future evil .	115.55458
nevertheless , according to the traditional theory , a man begins in the midst of action and he analyzes its nature and immediate consequences before or while putting it forth and causing these consequences .	138.13155
he does not expect to be able to trammel up all the future consequences of his action .	143.37056
above all , he does not debate mere contingencies , and therefore , if these are possibly dreadful , find himself forced into inaction .	78.91125
he does what he can and may and must , without regarding himself as lord of the future or , on the other hand , as covered with guilt by accident or unforeseen consequences or by results he did not `` permit ' ' in the sense explained .	75.715004
by contrast , a good deal of nuclear pacifism begins with the contingencies and the probabilities , and not with the moral nature of the action to be done	52.911213
and by deriving legitimate decision backward from whatever may conceivably or possibly or probably result , whether by anyone ' s doing or by accident , it finds itself driven to inaction , to non-political action in politics and non-military action in military affairs , and to the not very surprising discovery that there are now no distinctions on which the defense of justice can possibly be based .	103.44031
mr . philip toynbee writes , for example , that `` in terms of probability it is surely as likely as not that mutual fear will lead to accidental war in the near future if the present situation continues .	85.79376
if it continues indefinitely it is nearly a statistical certainty that a mistake will be made and that the devastation will begin ' ' .	72.07911
against such a termination of human life on earth by human action , he then proposes as an alternative that we `` negotiate at once with the russians and get the best terms which are available ' ' , that we deliberately `` negotiate from comparative weakness ' ' .	93.29283
he bravely attempts to face this alternative realistically , i . e . , by considering the worst possible outcome , namely , the total domination of the world by russia within a few years .	37.409115
this would be by far the better choice , when `` it is a question of allowing the human race to survive , possibly under the domination of a regime which most of us detest , or of allowing it to destroy itself in appalling and prolonged anguish ' ' .	55.636574
nevertheless , the consequence of the policy proposed is everywhere subtly qualified it is `` a possible result , however improbable ' '	157.03436
`` the worst , and least probable ' ' result	34.26254
`` if it didn ' t prevail mankind would still be given the opportunity of prevailing ' '	68.52441
for `` surely anything is better than a policy which allows for the possibility of nuclear war ' ' .	31.833466
if we have not thought and made a decision entirely in these terms , then we need to submit ourselves to the following `` simple test ' ' `` have we decided how we are to kill the other members of our household in the event of our being less injured than they are ' ' ? ?	80.84743
thus , moral decision must be entirely deduced backward from the likely eventuality	230.7252
it is no longer to be formulated in terms of the nature of present action itself , its intention , and proximate effect or the thing to be done .	62.860035
several of the replies to mr . toynbee , without conscious resort to the traditional terminology with regard to the permission of evil , succeed in restoring the actual context in which present moral and political decisions must be made , by distinguishing between choosing a great evil and choosing in danger of this evil .	87.62533
`` it is worse for a nation to give in to evil than to run the risk of annihilation ' ' .	72.20712
`` i am consciously prepared to run the continued risk of ' race suicide by accident ' rather than accept the alternative certainty of race slavery by design .	316.8097
but i can only make this choice because i believe that the risk need not increase , but may be deliberately reduced ' ' ( by precautions against accidents or by limiting war ? ?	82.20714
) `` quoting mr . kennan ' s phrase that anything would be better than a policy which led inevitably to nuclear war , he ( toynbee ) says that anything is better than a policy which allows for the possibility of nuclear war ' ' .	57.967396
`` if asked to choose between a terrible probability and a more terrible possibility , most men will choose the latter ' ' .	49.52038
`` if philip toynbee is claiming that the choice lies between capitulation and the risk of nuclear war , i think he is right .	34.47836
i do not accept that the choice is between capitulation and the certainty of nuclear war ' ' .	15.138891
even professor arnold toynbee , agreeing with his son , does so in these terms `` compared to continuing to incur a constant risk of the destruction of the human race , all other evils are lesser evils .	82.581406
let us therefore put first things first , and make sure of preserving the human race at whatever the temporary price may be ' ' .	76.155334
mr . philip toynbee affirms at one point that if he shared the anticipations of orwell in nineteen eighty-four , if he believed communism was not only evil but `` also irredeemably evil ' ' , then he might `` think it right to do anything rather than to take the risk of a communist world .	74.6485
even a nuclear holocaust is a little less frightful to contemplate than a race of dehumanised humans occupying the earth until doomsday ' ' .	34.69595
no political order or economic system is so clearly contrary to nature .	184.23363
but one does not have to affirm the existence of an evil order irredeemable in that sense , or a static order in which no changes will take place in time , to be able truthfully to affirm the following fact there has never been justitia imprinted in social institutions and social relationships except in the context of some pax-ordo preserved by clothed or naked force .	75.645676
on their way to the heavenly city the children of god make use of the pax-ordo of the earthly city and acknowledge their share in responsibility for its preservation .	94.7739
not to repel injury and uphold and improve pax-ordo means not simply to accept the misshapen order and injustice that challenges it at the moment , but also to start down the steep slope along which justice can find no place whereon to stand .	112.9338
toynbee seems to think that there is some other way to give justice social embodiment .	160.54323
`` i would far rather die after a russian occupation of this country -- by some deliberate act of refusal -- than die uselessly by atomisation ' ' .	96.840126
would such an act of refusal be useful ? ?	5.7428336
he does not mean , in fact he addresses himself specifically to reject the proposition , that `` if we took the risk of surrendering , a new generation in britain would soon begin to amass its strength in secret in order to reverse the consequences of that surrender ' ' .	70.14711
he wants to be `` brutally frank and say that these rebellions would be hopeless -- far , far more hopeless than was the hungarian revolution of 1956 ' ' .	62.106247
this is not a project for regaining the ground for limited war , by creating a monopoly in one power of the world ' s arsenal of unlimited weapons .	69.01267
it is a proposal that justice now be served by means other than those that have ever preconditioned the search for it , or preconditioned more positive means for attaining it , in the past .	101.538994
`` it is no good recommending surrender rather than nuclear warfare with the proviso that surrender could be followed by the effective military resistance by occupied peoples .	86.11706
hope for the future would lie in the natural longing of the human race for freedom and the right to develop ' ' .	32.187897
this is to surrender in advance to whatever attack may yet be mounted , to the very last	247.51738
it is to stride along the steep slope downward .	60.096355
the only contrary action , in the future as in the past , runs the risk of war	51.23514
and , now and in the future unlike in the past , any attempt to repel injury and to preserve any particular civilized attainment of mankind or its provisional justice runs some risk of nuclear warfare and the danger that an effect of it will , by human action , render this planet less habitable by the human race .	83.58732
that is why it is so very important that ethical analysis keep clear the problem of decision as to `` permitted ' ' effects , and not draw back in fright from any conceivable contingency or suffer paralysis of action before possibilities or probabilities unrelated , or not directly morally related , to what we can and may and must do as long as human history endures .	142.9172
finally , just as no different issues are posed for thoughtful analysis by the foreshortening of time that may yet pass before the end of human life on this earth , but only stimulation and alarm to the imagination , the same thing must be said in connection with the question of what we may perhaps already be doing , by human action , to accelerate this end .	83.0606
we should not allow the image of an immanent end brought about indirectly by our own action in the continuing human struggle for a just endurable order of existence to blind us to the fact that in some measure accelerating the end of our lease may be one consequence among others of many other of mankind ' s thrusts toward we know not what future .	182.65388
much more than shelter , housing symbolizes social status , a sense of `` belonging ' ' , acceptance within a given group or neighborhood , identification with particular cultural values and social institutions , feelings of pride and worth , aspirations and hopes basic to human well-being .	111.36657
for almost one-sixth of the national population discrimination in the free selection of residence casts a considerable shadow upon these values assumed as self-evident by most americans .	104.09032
few business groups in recent years have come under heavier pressure to face these realities than real estate brokers and home builders .	130.79997
this pressure has urged re-evaluation of the assumptions underlying their professional ethics	168.53137
it has sought new sympathy for the human aspirations of racial minority groups in this country .	42.862026
it is not surprising that , as spokesman for real estate interests , the national association of real estate boards ( nareb ) and its local associations have sought to limit and often ignore much of this pressure .	54.47322
how does the local realtor see himself in the context of housing restrictions based on race , religion or ethnic attachment ? ?	97.5749
what does he conceive his role to be in this area of social unrest ? ?	57.349377
what ought to be , what is his potential role as a force for constructive social change ? ?	99.161255
what social , ethical and theological insights can the church and university help him bring to bear upon his situation ? ?	80.056404
recently , a group of the faculty at wesleyan university ' s public affairs center sought some answers to these questions .	72.28277
several new england realtors were invited to participate in a small colloquium of property lawyers , political scientists , economists , social psychologists , social ethicists and theologians .	40.99175
here , in an atmosphere of forthrightness and mutual criticism , each sought to bring his particular insights to bear upon the question of discrimination in housing and the part each man present played in it .	181.85747
for a number of years , wesleyan has been drawing varied groups of political and business leaders into these informal discussions with members of the faculty and student body , attempting to explore and clarify aspects of their responsibility for public policy .	106.57145
this article presents our observations of that session , of the realtors as they saw themselves and as the faculty and students saw them .	131.93513
such conversation quickly reveals an ethically significant ambivalence in the self-images held by most realtors .	97.68956
within the membership of this group , as has been found true of men in other professional or trade associations , the most ready portrayal of oneself to `` the public ' ' is that of a neutral agent simply serving the interests of a seller or buyer and mediating between them .	97.92654
professional responsibility is seen to consist largely in serving the wishes of the client fairly and in an efficient manner .	183.50136
but as conversation goes on , particularly among the realtors themselves , another image emerges , that of considerable power and influence in the community .	78.2473
obviously , much more than customer expectation is determining the realtor ' s role .	46.30457
judgments are continually rendered regarding the potential buyers ' income , educational level and above all , racial extraction	162.5205
and whether these would qualify them for `` congenial ' ' , `` happy ' ' relations to other people in certain community areas .	39.804546
how explicit such factors have been historically is evident in any chronology of restrictive covenant cases or in a review of nareb ' s code of ethics article 34 in the code , adopted in 1924 , states that `` a realtor should never be instrumental in introducing into a neighborhood a character of property or occupancy , members of any race or nationality or any individuals whose presence will clearly be detrimental to property values in that neighborhood ' ' .	130.25331
though the reference to race was stricken by the association in 1950 , being an agent of such `` detrimental ' ' influences still appears as the cardinal sin realtors see themselves committed to avoid .	112.00394
the rationale for this avoidance was most frequently expressed in economic terms	330.8646
all feared the supposed stigma they believed would inevitably attach to any realtor who openly introduced non-white , particularly negro , peoples into all-white , restricted areas .	144.83365
they would become tagged as men not interested in being purely real estate `` professionals ' ' but agitators for some kind of `` cause ' ' or `` reform ' ' , and this was no longer to be a `` pro ' ' .	32.78873
obviously what we are confronted with here is the identification of `` professional ' ' with narrow skills and specialization , the effective servicing of a client , rather than responsiveness to the wider and deeper meaning and associations of one ' s work .	46.484245
these men -- for the most part educated in our `` best ' ' new england colleges , well established financially and socially in the community -- under kindly but insistent probing , reveal little or no objective or explicit criteria or data for their generalizations about the interests and attitudes of the people they claim to serve , or about the public responses that actually follow their occasional breach of a `` client-service relationship ' ' .	106.85182
this narrow `` professionalism ' ' does not even fit the present realities of their situation , as the pressure of minorities and the power and respectability of the realtors increase .	72.00766
as our discussion continued , the inadequacy of the `` client relationship ' ' as an interpretation of their `` way of operating ' ' became evident .	53.494175
realtors live in their communities as specialists in a given area of work , as members of social and professional organizations , as citizens and civic leaders , as church laymen , as university alumni , as newspaper readers , etc . .	42.335407
from such communal roles the realtor finds the substance that shapes his moral understanding .	250.88826
it seems to us that choices exercised by realtors in moral situations center in at least three areas ( 1 ) the various ways in which they interpret a particular social issue	71.56591
( 2 ) their pattern of involvement in the regular legal and political processes	52.481182
and , most pervasively , ( 3 ) their interpretation of who is a `` real pro ' ' , of what it means to be a professional man in a technical , fragmented society .	64.59476
( 1 ) most of the realtors minimized their own understanding of and role in the racial issue , pleading that they only reflect the attitudes and intentions of their society .	76.09301
the commission on race and housing concluded that `` there is no reason to believe that real estate men are either more or less racially prejudiced , on the whole , than any other segment of the american population ' ' .	27.162361
but such a reaction obscures the powerful efforts made in the past by both nareb and its local boards for the maintenance of restrictive clauses and practices .	45.824097
also , it does not recognize the elements of choice and judgment continually employed .	115.184456
like business and university groups generally , these men had very limited knowledge of recent sociological and psychological studies and findings that might illumine the decisions they make .	106.47001
realtors , both generally and in this group , have invariably equated residential integration with a decline in property values , a circumstance viewed with considerable apprehension .	184.94975
recent studies by the commission on race and housing and others , however , point to a vast complex of factors that often do not warrant this conclusion .	76.054016
there are increasing numbers of neighborhoods that are integrated residentially without great loss of property values , the white population having taken the initiative in preparing the areas for an appreciation of the negroes ' desire for well-kept housing , privacy , etc . .	88.958
data on the decline of property values in an area after a new racial group enters it has to be assessed in terms of the trends in property values before the group comes in .	99.45353
often they are able to get in only because the area is declining economically .	78.830734
significantly , no realtor and few of the faculty present were familiar with any of the six volumes ( published by the university of california press ) that present the commission ' s findings .	84.662155
no one anticipates any radical shift in this situation , but questions concerning reading habits , the availability of such data and the places where it is discussed must surely be raised .	96.97737
the role of both church and university as sources of information and settings within which the implications of such information may be explored needs consideration .	168.29198
relevant `` facts ' ' , however , extend beyond considerations of property values and maintenance of `` harmonious ' ' neighborhoods .	103.782646
discussion of minority housing necessarily involves such basic issues as the intensity of one ' s democratic conviction and religious belief concerning equality of opportunity , the function and limitations of government in the securing of such equality , and the spotlight that world opinion plays upon local incidents of racial agitation and strife .	87.79216
( 2 ) realtors realize , of course , that they are involved in an increasingly complex legal and political system that is opening up opportunities for leverage on their relation to clients as well as opportunities for evasion of their responsibility for racial discrimination in housing .	78.515205
on the positive side , recent federal action has largely undermined the legal sanction so long enjoyed by the segregationist position	177.13554
anti-discriminatory statutes in housing have now been adopted by thirteen states and , while specific provisions have varied , the tendency is clearly toward expanding coverage .	97.21771
realtors in attendance at the colloquium expressed interest , for example , in connecticut ' s new housing law as setting standards of equity that they would like `` to have to obey ' ' , but in support of which none had been willing to go on public record .	56.670826
as far as they were aware , the connecticut association of real estate boards had not officially opposed the bill ' s passage or lobbied in its support .	67.4058
( this has not been the case everywhere .	7.2557073
in 1957 , the real estate boards of new york city actively opposed the then pending private housing anti-discrimination law .	176.47221
official reasoning the bill was a `` wanton invasion of basic property rights ' ' .	17.472853
the attitude adopted by realtors and their associations , either negative or positive , plays a large part in the public acceptance of such measures and the degree to which they may be effectively enforced .	64.82222
judicial opinion since the supreme court decision on shelley v . kraemer ( 1948 ) has rendered racial restrictive covenants unenforcible .	27.390282
such a decision should have placed a powerful weapon in the hands of the entire housing industry , but there is little evidence that realtors , or at least their associations , have repudiated the principle in such clauses .	45.296577
in the states that have passed laws preventing discrimination in the sale or rental of housing , support by real estate associations for compliance and broadened coverage through additional legislation could help remove the label of `` social reformism ' ' that most realtors individually seem determined to avoid .	120.49265
but as yet , no real estate board has been willing officially to support such laws or to admit the permissibility of introducing minority buyers into all-white neighborhoods .	120.90007
one of the roles of the social scientist , ethicist or theologian in our discussions with the realtors became that of encouraging greater awareness of the opportunities offered by the legal and political processes for the exercise of broad social responsibilities in their work .	87.25138
but responsiveness to these opportunities presumes that all of us judge the good as a human good and not simply as a professional , white , american good .	262.53915
such judgments are meaningful only in so far as persons are members of a world , let us say a community , that embraces scarsdale or yonkers , but is also infinitely richer since it is all-inclusive .	60.809155
that community of all creation is , then , the ultimate object of our loyalty and the concrete norm of all moral judgment .	71.41023
racial discrimination is wrong , then , not because it goes against the grain of a faculty member trying to converse with a few realtors but because it goes against the grain of creation and against the will of the creator .	91.23775
thus , moral issues concerning the nature of the legal and political processes take on theological dimensions .	88.853836
( 3 ) over the years , individuals engaged in the sale of real estate have developed remarkable unity in the methods and practices employed .	113.576996
most realtors and real estate brokers talk of themselves as `` professional people ' ' with the cultural and moral values held by the traditional professions .	39.98482
but what significance attaches to `` professional ' ' , beyond the narrow sense of skillfulness in meeting a client ' s stated needs as already noted ? ?	137.95244
our faculty and students pressed this issue more than any other .	12.347816
as a theologian in the group pointed out , a professional was , before the modern period of technical specialization , one who `` professed ' ' to be a bearer and critic of his culture in the use of his particular skills .	69.165695
if we look about the world today , we can see clearly that there are two especially significant factors shaping the future of our civilization science and religion .	57.11103
science is placing in our hands the ultimate power of the universe , the power of the atom .	15.732291
religion , or the lack of it , will decide whether we use this power to build a brave new world of peace and abundance for all mankind , or whether we misuse this power to leave a world utterly destroyed .	94.29577
how can we have the wisdom to meet such a new and difficult challenge ? ?	64.96261
and yet there is a note of hope , because this same science that is giving us the power of the atom is also giving us atomic vision .	89.03574
we are looking inside the atom and seeing there a universe which is not material but something beyond the material , a universe that in a word is not matter but music .	169.8476
and it is in this new vision of the atom that we find an affirmation and an invigoration of our faith .	44.382374
to see this vision in perspective , we need first of all a clear idea of the magnitude of this new power from the atom .	81.69558
you know that i could hold right here in my hand the little chunk of uranium metal that was the heart of the bomb that dropped on hiroshima .	63.642147
it was only about the size of a baseball	1015.63007
but packed in that metallic ball there was the explosive force of 20 , 000 tons of aj .	28.6381
that is enough tnt to fill the tower of the empire state building	152.94121
and with the availability of bombs of that size , war became a new problem .	198.22287
now we might have restricted the use of uranium bombs by controlling the sources of uranium because it is found in only a few places in the world .	43.32189
but we had hardly started to adjust our thinking to this new uranium weapon when we were faced with the hydrogen bomb .	73.16631
hydrogen is just as plentiful as uranium is scarce .	53.804085
water is af and the h stands for hydrogen	850.1196
there is also hydrogen in wood and hydrogen in our bodies .	110.28382
i have calculated that if i could snap my fingers in one magic gesture to release the power of all the hydrogen in my body , i would explode with the force of a hundred bombs of the kind that fell on hiroshima .	83.02231
i won ' t try the experiment , but i think you can see that if we all knew the secret and we could all let ourselves go , there would be quite an explosion .	68.705635
and then think how little hydrogen we have in us compared with the hydrogen in delaware bay or in the ocean beyond .	70.187065
salt water is still af , the same hydrogen is there .	58.146812
and the size of the ocean shows us the magnitude of the destructive power we hold in our hands today .	60.275288
of course , there is also an optimistic side to the picture .	55.475243
for if i knew the secret of letting this power in my body change directly into electricity , i could rent myself out to the electric companies and with just the power in my body i could light all the lights and run all the factories in the entire united states for some days .	110.0318
and think , if we all knew this secret and we could pool our power , what a wonderful public utility company we would make .	168.27707
with just the hydrogen of our bodies , we could run the world for years .	63.6156
then think of delaware bay and the ocean and you see that we have a supply of power for millions of years to come .	51.461212
it is power with which we can literally rebuild the world , provide adequate housing , food , education , abundant living for everyone everywhere .	98.54222
now let us see where this power comes from .	261.35306
to grasp our new view of the atom , we have to appreciate first of all how small the atom is .	104.57248
i have been trying to make this clear to my own class in chemistry .	124.987076
one night there were some dried peas lying on our kitchen table , and these peas looked to me like a little group of atoms	56.23056
and i asked myself a question suppose i had the same number of peas as there are atoms in my body , how large an area would they cover ? ?	94.47827
i calculated first that there are about an octillion atoms in the average human body	79.333435
that is a figure one with 27 ciphers , quite a large number .	53.5533
then i calculated that a million peas would just about fill a household refrigerator	229.36983
a billion peas would fill a small house from cellar to attic	85.21895
a trillion peas would fill all the houses in a town of about ten thousand people	46.983852
and a quadrillion peas would fill all the buildings in the city of philadelphia .	59.189674
i saw that i would soon run out of buildings at this rate , so i decided to take another measure -- the whole state of pennsylvania .	105.39371
imagine that there is a blizzard over pennsylvania , but instead of snowing snow , it snows peas	74.430435
so we get the whole state covered with peas , about four feet deep .	79.50847
you can imagine what it would look like going out on the turnpike with the peas banked up against the houses and covering the cars	93.91888
pennsylvania thus blanketed would contain about a quintillion peas .	13.380107
but we still have a long way to go .	58.70618
next we imagine our blizzard raging over all the land areas of the entire globe -- north america , south america , europe , asia , and africa , all covered with peas four feet deep	40.725582
next we freeze over the oceans and cover the whole earth with peas , then we go out among the neighboring stars , collect 250 planets each the size of the earth , and also cover each of these with peas four feet deep	94.146065
finally we go into the farthest reaches of the milky way	117.97637
we cover each of these with our blanket of peas and then at last we have octillion peas corresponding in number to the atoms in the body .	101.01997
so you see how small an atom is and how complicated you are .	170.13177
now although an atom is small , we can still in imagination have a look at it .	99.71859
let us focus on an atom of calcium from the tip of the bone of my finger and let us suppose that i swallow a magic alice in wonderland growing pill .	68.098
i start growing rapidly and this calcium atom grows along with me .	117.98116
i shoot up through the roof , into the sky , past the clouds , through the stratosphere , out beyond the moon , out among the planets , until i am over a hundred and fifty million miles long .	50.663803
then this atom of calcium will swell to something like a great balloon a hundred yards across , a balloon big enough to put a football field inside .	140.31683
and if you should step inside of such a magnified atom , according to the physics of forty years ago , you would see circulating over your head , down at the sides , and under your feet , some twenty luminous balls about the size of footballs .	56.179535
these balls are moving in great circles and ellipses , and are of course , the electrons , the particles of negative electricity which by their action create the forces that tie this atom of calcium to the neighboring atoms of oxygen and make up the solid structure of my finger bone .	88.480934
since these electrons are moving like planets , you may wonder whether there is an atomic sun at the center of the atom .	35.514256
so you look down there and you see a tiny , whirling point about the size of the head of a pin .	52.941143
this is the atomic sun , the atomic nucleus .	7.5690145
even if the atom were big enough to hold a football field , this nucleus is still only about the size of a pinhead .	69.771484
it is this atomic nucleus that contains the positive charge of electricity holding these negatively charged electrons in their orbits	171.81873
it also contains nearly all the mass , and the atomic energy .	23.704754
you may ask what else there is , and the answer is nothing -- nothing but empty space .	44.799488
and since you are made of atoms , you are nothing much but empty space , too .	65.53187
if i could put your body in an imaginary atomic press and squeeze you down , squeeze these holes out of you in the way we squeeze the holes out of a sponge , you would get smaller and smaller until finally when the last hole was gone , you would be smaller than the smallest speck of dust that you could see on this piece of paper .	70.014046
someone has remarked that this is certainly the ultimate in reducing .	643.8249
at any rate , it shows us how immaterial we are .	99.40782
now this 1920 view of the atom was on the whole a discouraging picture .	70.12383
for we believed that the electrons obeyed the law of mechanics and electrodynamics	60.59996
and therefore the atom was really just a little machine	79.61792
and in mechanics the whole is no more than the sum of the parts .	25.888664
so if you are made of atoms , you are just a big machine	37.679165
and since the universe is also made of atoms , it is just a supermachine .	37.398663
and this would mean that we live in a mechanistic universe , governed by the laws of cause and effect , bound in chains of determinism that hold the universe on a completely predetermined course in which there is not room for soul or spirit or human freedom .	99.32495
and this is why so many scientists a half a century ago were agnostics or atheists .	92.066185
then came the scientific revolution in the late 1920 ' s .	10.329743
a suggestion from louis de broglie , a physicist in france , showed us that these electrons are not point particles but waves .	139.46135
and to see the meaning of this new picture , imagine that you can put on more powerful glasses and go back inside the atom and have a look at it in the way we view it today .	102.55197
now as you step inside , instead of seeing particles orbiting around like planets , you see waves and ripples very much like the ripples that you get on the surface of a pond when you drop a stone into it .	82.566086
these ripples spread out in symmetrical patterns like the rose windows of a great cathedral .	122.02704
and as the waves flow back and forth and merge with the waves from the neighboring atoms , you can put on a magic hearing aid and you hear music .	107.868866
it is a music like the music from a great organ or a vast orchestra playing a symphony .	87.75265
harmony , melody , counterpoint symphonic structure are there	2004.5486
and as this music ebbs and flows , there is an antiphonal chorus from all the atoms outside , in fact from the atoms of the entire universe .	64.889915
and so today when we examine the structure of our knowledge of the atom and of the universe , we are forced to conclude that the best word to describe our universe is music .	41.941223
the island of nantucket , part of the state of massachusetts , lies about thirty-one miles southeast of its mother state .	49.755856
some of the island is sand and is not suitable for living .	36.139477
the island folk have their living almost entirely from summer visitors	819.83307
during about three and a half months of the year , in the summer , there are three boats that run from the mainland to the island carrying passengers , food , and cars	56.04968
but the rest of the year only one boat is needed , which ties up at the mainland nights and makes the trip down to nantucket in the daytime .	147.25581
this is a fine trip , too , on a good day .	38.658062
with martha ' s vineyard on one side and the open sea on the other , it makes an excellent trip of about three hours .	76.287445
to what extent and in what ways did christianity affect the united states of america in the nineteenth century ? ?	21.50092
how far and in what fashion did it modify the new nation which was emerging in the midst of the forces shaping the revolutionary age ? ?	66.209114
to what extent did it mould the morals and the social , economic , and political life and institutions of the country ? ?	25.193935
a complete picture is impossible -- partly because of the limitations of space , partly because for millions of individuals who professed allegiance to the christian faith data are unobtainable .	57.254177
even more of an obstacle is the difficulty of separating the influence of christianity from other factors .	39.09808
although a complete picture cannot be given , we can indicate some aspects of life into which the christian faith entered as at least one creative factor .	79.058624
at times we can say that it was the major factor .	74.10284
what in some ways was the most important aspect was the impact individually on the millions who constituted the nation .	116.340164
as we have seen , a growing proportion , although in 1914 still a minority , were members of churches .	114.51131
presumably those who did not have a formal church connexion had also felt the influence of christianity to a greater or lesser extent .	101.37769
many of them had once been members of a church or at least had been given instruction in christianity but for one or another reason had allowed the connexion to lapse .	125.498215
the form of christianity to which they were exposed was for some the protestantism of the older stock , for others the protestantism of the nineteenth-century immigration	80.825806
for still others , mostly of the nineteenth-century immigration , it was roman catholicism , and for a small minority it was eastern orthodoxy .	42.19372
upon all of them played the intellectual , social , political , and economic attitudes , institutions , and customs of the nation .	23.312843
upon most of these christianity had left an impress and through them had had a share in making the individual what he was .	105.45166
yet to determine precisely to what extent and exactly in what ways any individual showed the effects of christianity would be impossible .	146.7983
at best only an approximation could be arrived at .	56.952267
to generalize for the entire nation would be absurd .	57.130642
for instance , we cannot know whether even for church members the degree of conformity to christian standards of morality increased or declined as the proportion of church members in the population rose .	206.86
the temptation is to say that , as the percentage of church members mounted , the degree of discipline exercised by the churches lessened and the trend was towards conformity to the general level .	97.48858
we know that in the early part of the century many protestant congregations took positive action against members who transgressed the ethical codes to which the majority subscribed .	111.471176
thus baptist churches on the frontier took cognizance of charges against their members of drunkenness , fighting , malicious gossip , lying , cheating , sexual irregularities , gambling , horse racing , and failure to pay just debts .	70.66543
if guilty , the offender might be excluded from membership .	55.07081
as church membership burgeoned , such measures faded into desuetude .	11.464327
but whether this was accompanied by a general lowering of the moral life of the membership we do not know .	30.386316
what we can attempt with some hope of dependable conclusions is to point out the manner in which christianity entered into particular aspects of the life of the nation .	83.80127
we have already hinted at the fashion in which christianity contributed to education and so to intellectual life .	76.95609
we will now speak of the ways in which it helped shape the ideals of the country and of the manner in which it stimulated efforts to attain those ideals through reform movements , through programmes for bringing the collective life to the nation to conformity to christian standards , and through leaders in the government .	83.927956
throughout the nineteenth century christianity exerted its influence on american society as a whole primarily through the protestantism of the older stock .	52.069706
by the end of the century the roman catholic church was beginning to make itself felt , mainly through such institutions as hospitals but also through its attitude towards organized labour .	241.8842
in the twentieth century its influence grew , as did that of the protestantism of the nineteenth-century immigration .	41.94343
the ideals of the country were deeply indebted to the protestantism of the older stock .	17.907976
thus `` america ' ' , the most widely sung of the patriotic songs , was written by a new england baptist clergyman , samuel francis smith ( 1808-1895 ) , while a student in andover theological seminary .	33.43217
with its zeal for liberty and its dependence on god it breathed the spirit which had been nourished on the evangelical revivals .	64.33655
the great seal of the united states was obviously inspired by the christian faith .	34.651905
here was what was called the american dream , namely , the effort to build a structure which would be something new in history and to do so in such fashion that god could bless it .	71.186424
later in the century the dream again found expression in the lines of katherine lee bates ( 1859-1929 ) , daughter and granddaughter of new england congregational ministers , in her widely sung hymn , written in 1893 , `` america the beautiful ' ' , with the words `` o beautiful for pilgrim feet whose stern impassioned stress a thoroughfare for freedom beat across the wilderness .	85.975105
america , america , god mend thy every flaw , confirm thy soul in self control , the liberty in law .	103.633835
o beautiful for patriot dream that sees beyond the years thine alabaster cities gleam undimmed by human tears .	36.27488
america , america , god shed his grace on thee , and crown thy good with brotherhood from sea to shining sea ' ' .	48.36965
the american dream was compounded of many strains .	9.868649
some were clearly of christian origin , among them the great awakening and other revivals which helped to make christian liberty , christian equality , and christian fraternity the passion of the land .	50.906227
some have seen revivalism and the search for christian perfection as the fountain-head of the american hope .	48.120853
here , too , must be placed unitarianism and , less obviously from christian inspiration , emerson , transcendentalism , and the idealism of walt whitman .	88.18193
we must also remember those who reacted against the dream as a kind of myth -- among them melville , hawthorne , and henry james the elder , all of them out of a christian background .	60.277737
with such a dream arising , at least in part , from the protestant heritage of the united states and built into the foundations of the nation , it is not surprising that many efforts were made to give it concrete expression .	36.881916
a number were in the nature of movements to relieve or remove social ills .	152.1935
