however , first i thoughtfully study my sketch for improvement of color and design along the lines i have described .	99.7946
then i plan my attack the parts i will finish first , the range of values , the accenting of minor details -- all in all , mechanics of producing the finished job with a maximum of crispness .	98.477394
the longer i work , the more i am sure that for me , at least , a workmanlike method is important .	43.76598
trial and error are better placed in the preliminary sketch than in hoping for miracles in the final painting .	174.46182
`` as for materials , i use the best available .	24.69266
i work on a watercolor easel in the field , and frequently resort to a large garden umbrella to protect my eyes from undue strain .	84.15325
in my studio i work at a tilt-top table , but leave the paper unfixed so that i can move it freely to control the washes .	95.67941
i have used a variety of heavy-weight hand-made papers , but prefer an english make , rough surface , in 400-pound weight .	110.93007
after selecting a sheet and inspecting it for flaws ( even the best sometimes has foreign ' nubbins ' on its surface ) , i sponge it thoroughly on both sides with clean , cold water .	138.67397
then i dry the sheet under mild pressure so that it will lie flat as a board .	88.41637
`` in addition to the usual tools , i make constant use of cleansing tissue , not only to wipe my brushes , but to mop up certain areas , to soften edges , and to open up lights in dark washes .	78.64492
the great absorbency of this tissue and the fact that it is easier to control than a sponge makes it an ideal tool for the watercolorist .	59.913002
i also use a small electric hand-blower to dry large washes in the studio .	31.681314
`` my brushes are different from those used by most watercolorists , for i combine the sable and the bristle .	73.276085
and a very large , flat wash brush .	4.7898192
the bristles are a fitch 2 and a one-half inch brush shaved to a sharp chisel edge .	47.05059
`` my usual palette consists of top-quality colors alizarin crimson , orange , raw sienna , raw umber , burnt sienna , sepia , cerulean blue , cobalt blue , french ultramarine blue , winsor green , hooker ' s green 2 , cadmium yellow pale , yellow ochre , payne ' s gray , charcoal gray , davy ' s gray , and ivory black ' ' .	14.899875
in analyzing the watercolors of roy mason , the first thing that comes to mind is their essential decorativeness , yet this word has such a varied connotation that it needs some elaboration here .	146.13104
true , a mason watercolor is unmistakably a synthesis of nature rather than a detailed inventory .	59.95041
unlike many decorative patterns that present a static flat convention , this artist ' s pictures are full of atmosphere and climate .	151.73451
long observation has taught mason that most landscape can be reduced to three essential planes a foreground in sharp focus -- either a light area with dark accents or a dark one with lights	149.511
and a background , usually a silhouetted form foiled against the sky .	21.022625
in following this general principle , mason provides the observer with a natural eye progression from foreground to background , and the illusion of depth is instantly created .	66.38725
when painting , mason ' s physical eyes are half-closed , while his mind ' s eye is wide open , and this circumstance accounts in part for the impression he wishes to convey .	123.325645
he does not insist on telling all he knows about any given subject	230.55167
rather his pictures invite the observer to draw on his memory , his imagination , his nostalgia .	93.25702
it is for this reason that roy avoids selecting subjects that require specific recognition of place for their enjoyment .	208.9694
his pictures generalize , though they are inspired by a particular locale	33.822178
they universalize in terms of weather , skies , earth , and people .	30.140629
by dealing with common landscape in an uncommon way , roy mason has found a particular niche in american landscape art .	73.78167
living with his watercolors is a vicarious experience of seeing nature distilled through the eyes of a sensitive interpretor , a breath and breadth of the outdoor world to help man honor the creator of it all .	93.28304
the artist was born in gilbert mills , new york , in 1886 , and until two years ago when he and his wife moved to california , he lived in western new york , in batavia .	43.21322
when i looked up the actual date of his birth and found it to be march 15th , i realized that roy was born under the right zodiacal sign for a watercolorist the water sign of pisces ( february 18 thru march 20 ) .	101.11163
and how very often a water plane is featured in his landscapes , and how appropriate that he should appear in american artist again , in his natal month of march ! !	115.31965
over the years , beginning in 1929 , mason has been awarded seventeen major prizes including two gold medals	134.93417
the blair purchase prize for watercolor , art institute of chicago	104.7486
and others in buffalo , new york , chautauqua , new haven , rochester , rockport , and most recently , the $300 prize for a watercolor at the laguna beach art association ,	58.49817
he was elected to the national academy of design as an associate in the oil class in 1931 ( after receiving his first ranger fund purchase prize at the academy in 1930 ) , and elevated to academicianship in 1940 .	91.8975
other memberships include the american watercolor society , philadelphia water color club , allied artists of america , audubon artists , baltimore watercolor society .	170.69254
the russian gymnasts beat the tar out of the american gymnasts in the 1960 olympics for one reason -- they were better .	70.58585
they were better trained , better looking , better built , better disciplined and something else -- they were better dancers .	118.47462
our athletes are only just beginning to learn that they must study dance .	102.64135
the russians are all trained as dancers before they start to study gymnastics .	39.79206
after all , we did pretty well in some other areas of the olympics competition .	80.59697
but if it is important , what can we do to improve ourselves ? ?	30.056889
it is more than just lack of dance training that is our problem , for just as gymnastics can learn from dance , dance has some very important things to learn from gymnastics .	153.3473
taking first things first , let ' s understand the sport called gymnastics .	291.09933
it is made up of tumbling , which might be said to start with a somersault , run through such stunts as headstands , handstands , cartwheels , backbends , and culminate in nearly impossible combinations of aerial flips and twists and apparatus work .	39.621223
the apparatus used by gymnasts was once a common sight in american gyms , but about 1930 it was dropped in favor of games .	139.68079
the parallel bars , horse , buck , springboard , horizontal bar , rings , and mats formerly in the school gyms were replaced by baseball , volleyball , basketball and football .	50.519684
but the russians use gymnastics as the first step in training for all other sports because it provides training in every basic quality except one , endurance .	176.79648
the gymnast must develop strength , flexibility , coordination , timing , rhythm , courage , discipline , persistence and the desire for perfection .	52.06468
in short , gymnastics uses every part of the body and requires a great deal of character as well .	29.431023
the addition of endurance training later , when the body is mature enough to benefit from it without danger of injury , provides that final quality that makes the top athlete , soldier or citizen .	167.22368
another reason gymnastic study is valuable is that it can be started very early in life .	64.93254
( an enterprising teacher or parent could start training a healthy child at the age of seven days .	51.921753
most europeans have been exercising newborn infants for centuries .	38.36498
) in most sports , as in most walks of life , the angels are on the side of those who begin young , and the russian competitor of 16 has at least thirteen years of training behind him .	77.76449
the american is very lucky if he has three .	200.1788
if a nation wished to get a head start in physical fitness over all other nations , it would start its kindergarten students on a program of gymnastics the day they entered and thus eliminate a large number of the problems that plague american schools .	94.76509
first of the problems attacked would be fatigue and emotional tension , since action relieves both .	181.00092
oddly enough , it is proven that there would be less reading difficulty .	108.65788
certainly there would be less anxiety , fewer accidents ( it is the clumsy child who sustains the worst injuries ) , and higher scholastic averages , since alert children work better .	137.99533
russia knows this , and that is why there were over 800 , 000 competing for places as candidates for the olympic gymnastic team .	80.686676
eighty thousand won top honors and a chance to try for the team itself .	71.430565
we could scarcely find eighty in our great land of over 180 million people .	170.18298
and what has dancing to do with all this ? ?	23.672144
russia ' s young gymnasts have studied dance before having the rigorous training on apparatus .	177.35114
well-stretched , trained in posture and coordinated movement , and wedded to rhythm , they presented the audiences in rome with one of the most beautiful sights ever seen at any olympic contest .	59.372818
american audiences in particular learned two valuable lessons .	5.817055
they saw completely masculine and obviously virile men performing with incredible grace .	96.82369
they were further stripped of old wive ' s tales by seeing the slender , lovely russian girls performing feats requiring tremendous strength and with not one bulging muscle .	125.78447
president kennedy has asked that we become a physically fit nation .	107.54187
if we wait until children are in junior high or high school , we will never manage it .	49.60438
to be fit , one has to start early with young children , and today the only person who really reaches such children is the teacher of dance .	130.25902
if the dance teachers of america make it their business to prepare their young charges for the gymnastics that must come some day if our schools are really responsible , we will be that much ahead .	165.77563
school teachers , all too unprepared for the job they must do , will need demonstrators .	120.30629
there should be youngsters who know how to do a headstand , and also how to help other children learn it .	67.7535
they should know simple exercises that could prepare less fortunate children for the sports we will demand be taught .	174.80598
dance teachers can respond to president kennedy ' s request not only through their regular dance work , but also through the kind of basic gymnastic work that makes for strength and flexibility .	107.82243
very little in today ' s living provides the strength we need and nothing provides the flexibility .	176.22104
they often fail , however , to develop real abdominal , back , chest , shoulder and arm strength .	77.96454
ask any group of ballerinas to do ten push-ups or three chin-ups and the results , considering the amount of physical training they have had , will be very disappointing .	86.67759
even the boys will not be outstanding in these areas .	56.885147
this isn ' t surprising when we consider that over 29 percent of the 11-year-old boys in america cannot chin themselves once , and that english school girls outdo them in almost every test ( even dashes and endurance ) .	150.6131
the only area in which american boys hold their own is the baseball throw .	106.88305
for arm and shoulder strength a chinning bar is recommended .	85.99138
it should be installed over a door that is in full view of everyone , and a chair should be placed under it , a little to one side .	82.29715
those children who can chin themselves should be told to do one chin-up each time they pass under it .	153.14941
those who are too weak , should climb on the chair and , starting at the top of the chin , let themselves slowly down .	85.95272
when they can take ten seconds to accomplish the descent , they will have the strength to chin-up .	58.621063
parents should be informed about this system and encouraged to do the same with the whole family at home .	51.98621
arm , shoulder , chest , upper and lower back strength will be aided with the horse kick .	110.01381
keeping the hands in the starting position , run in place to a quick rhythm .	77.31047
after this has become easy , use slower and slower rhythms , kicking higher and higher .	87.29699
follow this by crossing from one corner of the room to the other on all fours , kicking as high as possible .	69.79128
push-ups are essential , but few have the strength for them at first .	59.45427
start on the knees in a large circle .	5.6193233
fall slowly forward onto the hands and let the body down to rest on the floor .	29.115286
do this exercise six times each class period .	6.654124
as strength improves start in a standing position with legs wide apart and upper body bent forward .	140.28406
start by falling forward to a point close to the feet , and , as strength improves , fall farther and farther out .	40.880596
try to push back to the stand position from the stretched position without any intermediate pushes from the hands .	59.158524
the push-up itself can be taught by starting at the top of the push-up with legs spread wide .	141.61824
let the body down slowly , taking at least five seconds for the letting down .	58.998146
five of these done daily for about a week will develop the strength for one push-up .	104.35445
handstands come after arms , chest and shoulders have developed at least a minimum of strength .	69.6567
of course those who have developed more will find them easier .	83.55644
start with the class standing in a circle , with weight on the right foot and the left extended a little way into the circle .	46.18647
at first each child should do a kick-up by himself so that the teacher can determine those ready to work alone , and those who need help .	104.03935
drop both hands to the floor and at the same time kick the right foot up in back .	64.70243
the right will land first , followed by the left .	60.968323
care should be taken to see that the hands are placed on the floor before the kick starts and also that the landing foot is brought as close to the hands as possible .	77.37176
this will prevent flat falls and toe injuries .	1.8982219
bare feet are better for such work than any form of slipper .	35.498997
eventually the class will be able to kick up high enough so that the teacher can catch the leading leg .	129.84724
the child should then bring both legs together overhead , point the toes and tighten the seat muscles .	102.47429
be sure that the landing foot is brought close to the hands and that only one foot lands at a time .	74.66216
the backbend is of extreme importance to any form of free gymnastics , and , as with all acrobatics , the sooner begun the better the results .	95.74815
have the class lie supine with knees apart and bent .	26.821701
place flat palms on either side of the head a few inches away from the ears , fingers pointing toward the shoulders .	52.274696
arch the back upwards to make a bridge .	5.527161
be sure the head drops backward so that the child looks at the floor rather than toward the ceiling .	80.382805
as flexibility improves , the feet will move closer to the hands and the bridge rise higher .	101.89475
later this can be combined with the handstand to provide a walkover .	23.566338
to further increase back flexibility , work on the back circle .	80.37418
place the hands in front of the chest .	2.240089
keep the legs straight and the toes pointed .	8.499749
straighten the arms slowly , this arches the back .	115.09491
at the peak of the arch , tip the head back and bend the knees in an effort to touch toes to head .	67.37501
improvement can be measured by the lessening distance between toes and head .	17.162909
the last essential to the beginner ' s gymnastic program is the somersault , or forward roll .	150.90279
this used to be part of every child ' s bag of tricks , but few children can do it today	74.93248
some are actually incapable of rolling forward and are completely confused when not sitting or standing upright .	259.43384
for most small children , learning a forward roll is simply a matter of copying another child who can .	121.62335
after it has been seen , have the child start on a mat on hands and knees ( a thin , inexpensive mat is quite sufficient for anything that does not require falling ) .	99.00359
he places the hands on either side of the head , keeping the chin down on the chest .	33.40692
he then pushes his seat into the air and the teacher guides it over .	104.55931
one or two practice runs should be sufficient for solo .	147.90196
if , however , the child is weak , overweight , or afraid , more help will be needed .	42.398987
when the child raises his seat into the air , the teacher takes hold under both sides of the pelvis	104.494316
then no matter what happens , the child ' s performance will be controlled .	28.328133
by lifting the seat upwards a little , the weight is taken off the neck and the back is kept rounded .	71.9998
these are beginnings , but correctly learned they prepare for satisfying and exciting stunts that can be performed by a strong , flexible body ( we are not talking of eccentric extremes ) .	65.665245
even if gymnastics are not the ultimate goal , the good tumbler will be a better dancer , a better athlete , and a human being with a greater margin of safety in any activity .	69.46806
it is very important for parents to understand that early training is imperative .	63.85542
and dancing school , so helpful in artistic and psychological development , also contributes to this essential early training -- and can contribute even more .	93.28896
every taxpayer is well aware of the vast size of our annual defense budget and most of our readers also realize that a large portion of these expenditures go for military electronics .	79.13847
we have noted how some electronic techniques , developed for the defense effort , have evenutally been used in commerce and industry .	108.440025
the host of novel applications of electronics to medical problems is far more thrilling because of their implication in matters concerning our health and vitality .	215.90547
when we consider the electronic industry potential for human betterment , the prospect is staggering .	48.855286
the author has recently studied the field of medical electronics and has been convinced that , in this area alone , the application of electronic equipment has enormous possibilities .	89.31256
the benefits electronics can bring to bio-medicine may be greater by far than any previous medical discovery .	150.5664
we use the term `` bio-medicine ' ' because of the close interrelation between biology and medical research .	46.00486
electronics has been applied to medicine for many years in the form of such familiar equipment as the x-ray machine , the electrocardiograph , and the diathermy machine .	34.546127
recently many doctors have installed ultrasonic vibration machines for deep massage of bruises , contusions , and simple bursitis .	24.091356
commonly used electronic devices which are found in practically every hospital are closed-circuit tv and audio systems for internal paging and instruction , along with radiation counters , timers , and similar devices .	84.01492
in this article we will concentrate on the advances in the application of electronics in bio-medical research laboratories because this is where tomorrow ' s commonplace equipment originates .	127.67461
from the wealth of material and the wide variety of different electronic techniques perfected in the past few years we have selected a few examples which appear to be headed for use in the immediate future and which offer completely new tools in medical research .	54.106438
many cells , bacteria , and other microorganisms are transparent to visible light and must be stained for microscopic investigation .	74.547935
this stain often disrupts the normal cell activity or else colors only the outside .	296.13486
a completely new insight into living cells and their structure will be possible by use of a new technique which replaces visible light with ultraviolet radiation and combines a microscope with a color-tv system to view the results .	75.46025
fig . 1 is a simplified block diagram of the ultraviolet microscopy system developed at the medical electronics center of rockefeller institute .	37.430927
by combining the talents of a medical man , dr . aterman , a biophysicist , mr . berkely , and an electronics expert , dr . zworykin , this novel technique has been developed which promises to open broad avenues to understanding life processes .	52.508343
three different wavelengths of ultraviolet radiation are selected by the variable filters placed in front of the three mercury xenon lights which serve as the ultraviolet sources .	37.32181
these wavelengths are reflected in sequence through the specimen by the rotating mirror	43.095177
instead of the observer ' s eye the image orthicon in the tv camera does the `` looking ' ' .	57.37445
the microscope and orthicon are both selected to operate well into the ultraviolet spectrum , which means that all lenses must be quartz .	101.59468
the video signal is amplified and then switched , in synchronism with the three ultraviolet light sources which are sequenced by the rotating mirror so that during one-twentieth of a second only one wavelength , corresponding to red , green , or blue , is seen .	85.83083
( note because of light leakage from one ultraviolet source to another , the lights are switched by a commutator-like assembly rotated by a synchronous motor .	56.950905
this assembly also supplies a 20-cps switching gate for the electronics circuitry .	26.72542
) this is the same system as was used in the field-sequential color-tv system which preceded the present simultaneous system .	38.44432
three separate amplifiers then drive a 21-inch tricolor tube .	9.778891
the result is a color picture of the specimen where the primary colors correspond to the three different ultraviolet wavelengths .	127.02848
many of the cells and microorganisms which are transparent to visible light , absorb or reflect the much shorter wavelengths of the ultraviolet spectrum .	44.33809
different parts of these cells sometimes absorb or reflect different wavelengths so that it is often possible to see internal portions of cells in a different color .	49.777138
where the microscope under visible light may show only vague shadows or nothing at all , ultraviolet illumination and subsequent translation into a color tv picture reveal a wealth of detail .	138.3368
at the present time the research team which pioneered this new technique is primarily interested in advancing and perfecting it .	66.52695
the medical title of `` lobar ventilation in man ' ' by drs . c . j . martin and a . c . young , covers a brief paper which is one part of a much larger effort to apply electronics to the study of the respiratory process .	50.222874
at the university of washington medical school , the electronics group has developed the `` respiratory gas analyzer ' ' shown in fig . 3 .	31.004911
this unit , affectionately dubbed `` the monster ' ' , can be wheeled to any convenient location and provides a wealth of information about the patient ' s breathing .	44.98108
in the lower center rack an 8-channel recorder indicates the percentage of carbon dioxide and nitrogen from the upper and lower lobes of one lung , the total volume of inhalation per breath , the flow of air from both lobes , and the pressure of the two lobes with respect to each other .	28.376118
usually the patient breathes into a mouthpiece while walking a treadmill , standing still , or in some other medically significant position .	88.77964
from the resulting data the doctor can determine lung defects with hitherto unknown accuracy and detail .	137.44653
the original electrocardiograph primarily indicates irregularities in the heartbeat , but today ' s techniques allow exact measurements of the flow of blood through the aorta , dimensioning of the heart and its chambers , and a much more detailed study of each heartbeat .	43.115185
for many of these measurements the chest must be opened , but the blood vessels and the heart itself remain undisturbed .	66.18714
a group of researchers at the university of washington have given a paper which briefly outlines some of these techniques .	168.75967
one simple method of measuring the expansion of the heart is to tie a thin rubber tube , filled with mercury , around the heart and record the change in resistance as the tube is stretched .	108.68524
a balanced resistance bridge and a pen recorder are all the electronic instrumentation needed .	104.003044
sonar can be used to measure the thickness of the heart by placing small crystal transducers at opposite sides of the heart or blood vessel and exciting one with some pulsed ultrasonic energy .	53.26013
the travel time of sound in tissue is about 1500 meters per second	73.19643
thus it takes about 16 msec . to traverse 25 mm . of tissue .	162.44742
a sonar or radar-type of pulse generator and time-delay measuring system is required for body-tissue evaluation .	36.653324
in addition to the heart and aorta , successful measurements of liver and spleen have also been made by this technique .	126.30147
the doppler effect , using ultrasonic signals , can be employed to measure the flow of blood without cutting into the blood vessel .	39.070133
a still more sophisticated system has been devised for determining the effective power of the heart itself .	33.356613
it uses both an ultrasonic dimensioning arrangement of the heart and a catheter carrying a thermistor inserted into the bloodstream .	34.3386
the latter measures the heat carried away by the bloodstream as an indication of the velocity of the blood flow .	22.325377
it is also possible to utilize a pressure transducer , mounted at the end of a catheter which is inserted into the heart ' s left ventricle , to indicate the blood pressure in the heart itself .	34.880943
this pressure measurement may be made at the same time that the ultrasonic dimensioning measurement is made .	33.541084
a simplified version of the instrumentation for this procedure is shown in fig . 2 .	13.533791
outputs of the two systems are measured by a pulse-timing circuit and a resistance bridge , followed by a simple analogue computer which feeds a multichannel recorder .	38.748936
from this doctors can read heart rate , change in diameter , pressure , and effective heart power .	159.33792
several years ago headlines were made by a small radio transmitter capsule which could be swallowed by the patient and which would then radio internal pressure data to external receivers .	148.92073
this original capsule contained a battery and a transistor oscillator and was about 1 cm . in diameter .	16.775078
battery life limited the use of this `` pill ' ' to about 8 to 30 hours maximum .	45.061104
a refinement of this technique has been described by drs . zworykin and farrar and mr . berkely of the medical electronics center of the rockefeller institute .	19.717228
in this novel arrangement the `` pill ' ' is much smaller and contains only a resonant circuit in which the capacitor is formed by a pressure-sensing transducer .	46.74075
as shown in fig . 4 , an external antenna is placed over or around the patient and excited 3000 times a second with short 400-kc . bursts .	105.542915
the energy received by the `` pill ' ' causes the resonant circuit to `` ring ' ' on after the burst and this `` ringing ' ' takes place at the resonant frequency of the `` pill ' ' .	42.34736
these frequencies are amplified and detected by the fm receiver after each burst of transmitted energy and , after the `` pill ' ' has been calibrated , precise internal pressure indications can be obtained .	90.40535
one of the advantages of this method is that the `` pill ' ' can remain in the patient for several days , permitting observation under natural conditions .	49.21289
applications to organs other than the gastrointestinal tract are planned for future experiments .	98.85948
one of the most gratifying applications of an important technique of submarine detection is in the exploration of the human body .	29.856272
our readers are familiar with the principles of sonar where sound waves are sent out in water and the echoes then indicate submerged objects .	275.10208
various methods of pulsing , scanning , and displaying these sound waves are used to detect submarines , map ocean floors , and even communicate under water .	95.69406
in medicine the frequencies are much higher , transducers and the sonar beams themselves are much smaller , and different scanning techniques may be used , but the principles involved are the same as in sonar .	66.28167
because the body contains so much liquid , transmission of ultrasonic signals proceeds fairly well in muscles and blood vessels .	91.61913
bones and cartilage transmit poorly and tend to reflect the ultrasonic signals .	26.903896
based on this phenomenon , a number of investigators have used this method to `` look through ' ' human organs .	74.16767
a good example of the results obtainable with ultrasonic radiation is contained in papers presented by dr . g . baum who has explored the human eye .	66.4257
he can diagnose detachment of the retina where conventional methods indicate blindness due to glaucoma .	279.2099
the method used to scan the eye ultrasonically is illustrated in fig . 6 .	17.534718
the transducer is coupled to the body through a water bath , not shown .	130.18178
for display , dr . baum uses a portion of an af , an airborne radar indicator , and then photographs the screen to obtain a permanent record .	40.914417
a typical `` sonogram ' ' of a human eye , together with a description of the anatomical parts , is shown in fig . 5 .	32.603523
the frequency used for these experiments is 15 mc . and the transducer is a specially cut crystal with an epoxy lens capable of providing beam diameters smaller than one millimeter .	37.988632
the transducer itself moves the beam in a sector scan , just like a radar antenna , while the entire transducer structure is moved over a 90-degree arc in front of the eye to `` look into ' ' all corners .	65.43292
the total picture is only seen by the camera which integrates the many sector scans over the entire 90-degree rotation period .	117.27136
drs . howry and holmes at the university of colorado medical school have applied the same sonar technique to other areas of soft tissue and have obtained extremely good results .	100.85119
by submerging the patient in a tub and rotating the transducer while the scanning goes on , they have been able to get cross-section views of the neck , as shown in fig . 7 , as well as many other hitherto impossible insights .	50.90192
as mentioned before , bone reflects the sound energy and in fig . 7 the portion of the spine shows as the black area in the center .	53.267582
arteries and veins are apparent by their black , blood-filled centers and the surrounding white walls .	89.69202
a cross-section of a normal lower human leg is shown in fig . 8 with the various parts labeled .	35.968395
oersted ' s boyhood represented a minimal chance of either attaining greatness or serving his people so well and over so long a span of life .	138.08907
he was born in the small danish town of rudkoebing on the island of langeland in the south-central part of denmark on august 14 , 1777 .	40.39253
his father soeren was the village apothecary whose slender income made it difficult to feed his family , let alone educate them in a town without even a school .	111.05635
the two older boys , hans and anders , his junior by a year , therefore went daily to the home of a warm and friendly wigmaker nearby for instruction in german	145.12796
his wife taught the two boys to read and write danish .	130.46733
other brothers later joined them for instruction with oldenburg , the wigmaker , and also arithmetic was added to bible reading , german , and danish in the informal curriculum .	67.261925
oldenburg ' s contributions were soon exhausted and the boys had to turn to a wider circle of the town ' s learned , such as the pastor , to supplement the simple teaching .	73.36062
from the town surveyor , hans learned drawing and mathematics and , from a university student , some academic subjects .	139.77673
the mayor of the town taught them english and french .	16.952002
whatever hans or anders learned separately they passed on to each other	53.998524
they read every book that they could borrow in the village .	42.117146
at 12 , hans was sufficiently mature to help his father in the apothecary shop , which helped stimulate his interest in medicine and science .	47.979088
his earlier love for literature and history remained with him for his entire life .	58.0902
in 1793 the brothers decided to enter the university of copenhagen ( founded in 1479 ) and the following spring found them at the university preparing to matriculate for the autumn session .	70.85053
while hans devoted himself to the sciences of medicine , physics , and astronomy , his brother studied law .	50.801857
the brothers continued to help each other during their studies , sharing a joint purse , lodging together in the dormitory and dining together at the home of their aunt .	98.01595
they supplemented their income by small government assistance , by tutoring and economizing wherever they could .	59.461185
so impressive were those serious years of study at the university that hans later wrote , `` to be perfectly free , the young man must revel in the great kingdom of thought and imagination	74.49876
there is a struggle there , in which , if he falls , it is easy for him to rise again , there is freedom of utterance there , which draws after it no irreparable consequences on society .	100.78888
i lived in this onward-driving contest where each day overcame a new difficulty , gained a new truth , or banished a previous error ' ' .	108.91939
he openly proclaimed his pleasure in lecturing and writing about science .	59.01787
in this third year at the university , hans , in 1797 , was awarded the first important token of recognition , a gold medal for his essay on `` limits of poetry and prose ' ' .	51.009956
he completed his training in pharmacy also , taking his degree with high honors in 1797 , and in 1799 was awarded the degree of doctor of philosophy along with a prize for an essay in medicine .	85.84699
he proposed a fresh theory of alkalis which later was accepted in chemical practices .	193.55553
hans ' student days were at a time when europe was in a new intellectual ferment following the revolutions in america and in france , germany and italy were rising from divisive nationalisms and a strong wave of intellectual awareness was sweeping the continent .	82.298645
the new century opened with oersted beginning his professional career in charge of an apothecary shop in copenhagen and as lecturer at the university .	73.00075
he was stirred by the announcement of volta ' s discovery of chemical electricity and he immediately applied the voltaic pile to experiments with acids and alkalis .	61.897022
the following year he devoted to the customary `` wanderjahr ' ' , traveling in germany , france , and the netherlands , meeting the philosophers schelling , fichte , and tieck .	22.218958
he also met count rumford ( born benjamin thompson in woburn , mass . ) who was then serving the elector of bavaria , and the physicist ritter	42.83274
these were oersted ' s main contacts in science .	54.618355
from gottingen ( 1801 ) where he stayed for 10 days , he wrote , `` the first question asked everywhere is about galvanism .	68.11937
as everybody is curious to see the battery of glass tubes i have invented , i have had quite a small one made here of four glass tubes ( in copenhagen i used 30 ) and intend to carry it with me ' ' .	98.11981
oersted joined ritter at jena and stayed with him for 3 weeks , continuing their correspondence after he left .	125.158714
with ritter he was exposed to the fantastic profusion of ideas that stormed through his host ' s fertile but disorganized mind .	84.73069
oersted remodeled ritter ' s notes into an essay in french which was submitted to the institut de france for its annual prize of 3 , 000 francs .	51.076866
the sound discoveries of this quixotic genius were so diluted by those of fantasy that the prize was never awarded to him .	80.279
in may , 1803 , ritter , in another flight of fancy , wrote to oersted a letter that contained a remarkable prophecy .	156.00285
he related events on earth to periodic celestial phenomena and indicated that the years of maximum inclination of the ecliptic coincided with the years of important electrical discoveries .	62.381176
thus , 1745 corresponded to the invention of the `` leiden ' ' jar by kleist , 1764 that of the electrophorus by wilcke , 1782 produced the condenser of volta , and 1801 the voltaic pile .	28.907833
ritter proceeded , `` you now emerge into a new epoch in which late in the year 1819 or 1820 , you will have to reckon .	63.92171
ritter died in 1810 and oersted not only lived to see the event occur but was the author of it .	94.648315
in 1803 oersted returned to copenhagen and applied for the university ' s chair in physics but was rejected because he was probably considered more a philosopher than a physicist .	74.1544
however , he continued experimenting and lecturing , publishing the results of his experiments in german and danish periodicals .	57.365593
in 1806 his ambition was realized and he became professor of physics at the copenhagen university , though not realizing full professorship ( ordinarius ) until 1817 .	80.83872
during oersted ' s attendance at the university , it was poorly equipped with physical apparatus for experimenting in the sciences .	66.6797
he was , however , fortunate in his contact with prof . j . g . l . manthey ( 1769-1842 ) , teacher of chemistry , who , in addition to his academic chair , was also proprietor of the `` lion pharmacy ' ' in copenhagen where oersted assisted him .	35.79016
manthey maintained a valuable collection of physical and chemical apparatus which was at oersted ' s disposal during and after his graduation .	60.497524
in 1800 , manthey went abroad and oersted was appointed manager of the lion pharmacy .	23.07959
in february 1801 , oersted did manage to experiment with physical apparatus and reported experiments made with a voltaic battery of 600 plates of zinc and silver and of later experiments with a battery of 60 plates of zinc and lead .	70.16012
in the following year , 1803 , oersted , simultaneously with davy , discovered that acids increased the strength of a voltaic battery more than did salts .	56.28303
eager as he was to pursue this promising line , he was so loaded down with the management of the pharmacy and lectures in the medical and pharmaceutical faculties at the university that he could devote only sunday afternoons to `` galvanizing ' ' .	58.7026
he assumed his academic career with the same intensity and thoroughness that had marked every step in his rise from boyhood .	189.59436
the university was the only one in denmark and the status of professor represented the upper social level .	83.79456
his broad interest in literary , political , and philosophical movements opened many doors to him .	83.112854
his friends were numerous and their ties to him were strong .	131.5264
the years 1812 and 1813 saw him in germany and france again , but on this visit to berlin he did not seek out the philosophers as he had on his first journey .	75.17151
in berlin he published his views of the chemical laws of nature in german and this was issued in french translation ( paris , 1813 ) under the title recherches sur l ' identite des forces chimiques et electriques , a work held in very high esteem by the new generation of research chemists .	50.455177
his interest in finding a relationship between voltaic electricity and magnetism is here first indicated .	89.04402
chapter 8 , is entitled `` on magnetism ' ' and in it are included such remarks as , `` one has always been tempted to compare the magnetic forces with the electrical forces .	37.64804
the great resemblance between electrical and magnetic attractions and repulsions and the similarity of their laws necessarily would bring about this comparison .	116.21591
it is true , that nothing has been found comparable with electricity by communication	403.70032
but the phenomena observed had such a degree of analogy to those depending on electrical distribution that one could not find the slightest difference .	84.71385
the form of galvanic activity is halfway between the magnetic form and the electrical form .	35.553394
there , forces are more latent than in electricity , and less than in magnetism .	90.45649
but in such an important question , we would be satisfied if the judgment were that the principal objection to the identity of forces which produce electricity and magnetism were only a difficulty , and not a thing which is contrary to it .	96.0773
one could also add to these analogies that steel loses its magnetism by heat , which proves that steel becomes a better conductor through a rise in temperature , just as electrical bodies do .	230.00209
it is also found that magnetism exists in all bodies of nature , as proven by bruckmann and coulomb .	32.020683
by that , one feels that magnetic forces are as general as electrical forces .	43.472107
an attempt should be made to see if electricity , in its most latent stage , has any action on the magnet as such ' ' .	91.858765
oersted returned in 1814 and resumed an active part in university and political discussions .	93.96613
in one debate he supported the freedom of judgment as opposed to dogma , in another he held that the practice of science was in fact an act of religious worship .	101.20063
he devised a detonating fuse in which a short wire was caused to glow by an electric current .	73.60699
in 1819 under royal command he undertook a very successful geological expedition to bornholm , one of the danish islands , being one of three scientists in the expedition .	61.538017
it was with the assistance of one of the members of this expedition , lauritz esmarch , that oersted succeeded in producing light by creating an electric discharge in mercury vapor through which an electric current was made to flow .	92.003334
together they also developed a new form of voltaic cell in which the wooden trough was replaced by one of copper , thereby producing stronger currents .	56.355247
esmarch was among those who witnessed oersted ' s first demonstration of his discovery .	51.497284
the association between electric ( both electrostatic and voltaic ) forces and magnetic forces had been recognized by investigators for many decades .	59.285007
electrical literature contained numerous references to lightning that had magnetized iron and had altered the polarity of compass needles .	72.16075
in the late 1700 ' s beccaria and van marum , among others , had magnetized iron by sending an electrostatic charge through it .	75.268456
beccaria had almost stumbled on a lead to the relationship between electricity and magnetism when a discharge from a leyden jar was sent transversally through a piece of watch-spring steel making its ends magnetic .	79.6008
the resulting magnetic effect proved stronger than when the discharge was made lengthwise .	35.69039
the experiments of romagnosi and others have already been noted but no one had determined the cause-and-effect relationship between these two primary forces .	72.073204
oersted ' s own earlier experiments were unimpressive , possibly because he had , like other experimenters , laid the conducting wire across the compass needle instead of parallel with it .	122.325195
the sequence of events leading to his important discovery still remains ambiguous but it seems that one of the advanced students at the university related that the first direct event that led to the publication of oersted ' s discovery occurred during a private lecture made before a group of other advanced students in the spring of 1820 .	71.99162
at this lecture oersted happened to place the conducting wire over and parallel to a magnetic needle .	113.69697
knowing specifically what the many feed additives can do and how and when to feed them can make a highly competitive business more profitable for beef , dairy , and sheep men .	85.24382
the target chart quickly and briefly tells you which additives do what .	388.00385
all the additives listed here are sanctioned for use by the food and drug administration of the federal government .	45.21005
all comments concerning effectiveness and use of drugs have been carefully reviewed by a veterinary medical officer with aj .	58.621117
this article assumes that the rations you are feeding your beef , dairy cattle , and sheep are adequately balanced with protein , vitamins , and minerals .	29.883085
the drug ' s chemical name is listed , since most states require feed processors to use this name instead of the trade name on the feed tag .	141.74782
in some instances , the trade name is shown in parentheses following the chemical name .	84.46808
this indicates that this drug is being marketed under one trade name only or state regulatory organizations have approved its use on the feed tag .	183.7334

there are three principal feed bunk types for dairy and beef cattle ( 1 ) fence-line bunks -- cattle eat from one side while feed is put in from the opposite side of the fence by self-unloading wagons	54.625492
( 2 ) mechanized bunks -- they sit within the feed lot , are filled by a mechanical conveyor above feeding surface	120.484375
( 3 ) special bunks -- as discussed here , they permit cattle to eat from all sides .	83.31732
several materials or combinations of materials can be used to construct a satisfactory feed bunk .	32.21966
the selection of materials depends on skills of available labor for installation , cost of materials available locally , and your own preference .	131.59723
no one material is best for all situations .	3.557537
selecting bunks by economic comparison is usually an individual problem .	76.29894
animals eat only from one side , so the fence-line bunk must be twice as long as the mechanical bunk .	57.054222
these bunks also serve as a fence , so part of the additional cost must be attributed to the fence .	76.2099
because of their location , on the edge of the feed lot , fence-line bunks are not in the way of mechanical manure removal .	71.220856
filling these bunks by the same self-unloading wagons used to fill silos spreads cost of the wagons over more time and operations .	147.21573
all-weather roads must be provided next to the feeding floor so access will be possible all year .	339.6874
this will be a problem in areas of heavy snowfall .	130.88712

many companies have upgraded their sales manpower and tested new selling , distribution , and promotion techniques to gain a bigger competitive edge .	172.04582
given this kind of business climate , what competitive marketing problems will your company face in the next 10 yrs . ? ?	60.89487
based on our experience with clients , , we see 14 major problems which fall into three broad groups -- the market place itself , marketing methods , and marketing management .	188.2811
there has been an intensification of price-consciousness in recent years	18.937195
frequently , wittingly or unwittingly , price-consciousness has been fostered by manufacturers , distributors , and dealers .	28.432768
despite generally good levels of income , we see greater price pressures than ever before -- traveling back along the chain from consumer to distributor to manufacturer .	226.19925
here are some key areas to examine to make sure your pricing strategy will be on target	109.695366

this problem can force a change in marketing approach in many kinds of businesses .	65.06358
have you examined this problem of increasing consumer sophistication from the standpoint of your own company ? ?	16.877304
need for service is here to stay -- and the problem is going to be tougher to solve in the sixties .	29.365768
first , most products tend to become more complex .	12.678018
second , in a competitive market , the customer feels his weight and throws it around .	296.13968
providing good customer service requires as thorough a marketing and general management planning job as the original selling of the product .	122.025925
too often it is thought of at the last moment of new product introduction .	104.5844
good service starts with product design and planning many products seem to be designed for a production economy , not for a service one .	104.28814
proper follow-through requires training your own sales organization , and your distributor organizations , not only in the techniques but also in good customer relations .	60.44476
have you assessed the importance of service and given it proper attention ? ?	154.7306
in spending his money today , the consumer is pulled in many directions .	79.59344
to the manufacturer of the more convenient-type product -- the purchase of which can be switched , delayed , or put off entirely -- the implications are important .	86.03169
your competition is now proportionately greater -- you are competing not only against manufacturers in the same field but also against a vast array of manufacturers of other appealing consumer products .	132.79706
many industry trade associations are developing campaigns to protect or enhance the share of the consumer ' s dollar being spent on their particular products .	71.50496
has your company thought through its strategy in this whole `` discretionary buying ' ' area ? ?	48.953606
the trends have been in evidence for many years -- population shifts to the southwest and far west , and from city to suburbs .	119.680855
these shifts will continue in the next 10 yrs . .	3.1276748
have you considered the implications of continuing geographic shifts in terms of sales force allocation , strength of distributor organizations , and even plant location ? ?	72.36626
we have already witnessed great changes through mergers and acquisitions in the food industry -- at both the manufacturing and retail ends .	117.57125
instead of relatively small sales to many accounts , there are now larger sales to or through fewer accounts .	113.13814
the change may require different products , pricing , packaging , warehousing , salesmanship , advertising and executive attention -- practically every link in the marketing network may have to be adjusted .	59.48396
have you examined these trends , forecast the effects , and planned your marketing strategy to compete effectively under changing circumstances ? ?	133.85704
in the area of private label competition , it is logical to expect a continuation of trends which have been under way during the first decade .	37.98248

average manufacturer frequently has helped build private brand business , delivering largely the same qualities and styles in private brand merchandise as in branded .	142.85364

the controversy of the last few years over whether architects or interior designers should plan the interiors of modern buildings has brought clearly into focus one important difference of opinion .	122.73588
the architects do not believe that the education of the interior designer is sufficiently good or sufficiently extended to compare with that of the architect and that , therefore , the interior designer is incapable of understanding the architectural principles involved in planning the interior of a building .	46.30651
ordinary politeness may have militated against this opinion being stated so badly but anyone with a wide acquaintance in both groups and who has sat through the many round tables , workshops or panel discussions -- whatever they are called -- on this subject will recognize that the final , boiled down crux of the matter is education .	198.64412
it is true that most architectural schools have five year courses , some even have six or more .	123.68123
the element of public danger which enters so largely into architectural certification , however , would demand a prolonged study of structure .	106.43027
this would , naturally , lengthen their courses far beyond the largely esthetic demands of interior designer ' s training .	80.80762
we may then dismiss the time difference between these courses and the usual four year course of the interior design student as not having serious bearing on the subject .	110.2783
the real question that follows is -- how are those four years used and what is their value as training ? ?	167.47968
the american institute of interior designers has published a recommended course for designers and a percentage layout of such a course .	147.393
an examination of some forty catalogs of schools offering courses in interior design , for the most part schools accredited by membership in the national association of schools of art , and a further `` on the spot ' ' inspection of a number of schools , show their courses adhere pretty closely to the recommendations .	59.127335
one or two of the schools have a five year curriculum , but the usual pattern of american education has limited most of them to the four-year plan which seems to be the minimum in acceptable institutions .	97.03958
the suggested course of the a . i . d . was based on the usual course offered and on the opinion of many educators as to curricular necessities .	95.88842
obviously , the four year provision limits this to fundamentals and much desirable material must be eliminated .	128.36949
without comparing the relative merits of the two courses -- architecture versus interior design -- let us examine the educational needs of the interior designer .	50.59643
to begin with , what is an interior designer ? ?	4.5609307
`` the dictionary of occupational titles ' ' published by the u . s . department of labor describes him as follows `` designs , plans and furnishes interiors of houses , commercial and institutional structures , hotels , clubs , ships , theaters , as well as set decorations for motion picture arts and television .	70.92953
makes drawings and plans of rooms showing placement of furniture , floor coverings , wall decorations , and determines color schemes .	37.513203
makes necessary purchases , places contracts , supervises construction , installation , finishing and placement of furniture , fixtures and other correlated furnishings , and follows through to completion of project ' ' .	54.308495
in addition to this the u . s . civil service bureau , when examining applicants for government positions as interior designers , expects that `` when various needed objects are not obtainable on the market he will design them .	173.53348
he must be capable of designing for and supervising the manufacture of any craft materials needed in the furnishings ' ' .	34.64433
the interior designer , then , must first be an artist but also understand carpentry and painting and lighting and plumbing and finance .	106.33571
yet nobody will question the necessity of all this and any reputable interior designer does know all this and does practice it .	131.9116
and further he must understand his obligation to the client to not only meet his physical necessities but also to enhance and improve his life and to enlarge the cultural horizon of our society .	51.112877
few will quarrel with the aim of the schools or with the wording of their curriculum .	72.51406
it is in the quality of the teaching of all this that a question may arise .	96.84355
the old established independent art schools try their best to fulfill their obligations .	37.03553
as in a recent design competition with a floor plan and the simple command -- `` design a luxury apartment ' '	167.91428
no description of the client or his cultural level , no assertion of geographical area or local social necessities -- simply `` a luxury apartment ' ' .	85.22959
working in a vacuum of minimal information can result only in show pieces that look good in exhibitions and catalogs and may please the public relations department but have little to do with the essence of interior design .	151.51929
it is possible , of course , to work on extant or projected buildings where either architect or owner will explain their necessities so that the student may get `` the feel ' ' of real interior design demands .	146.50026
unfortunately , the purely synthetic problem is the rule .	202.96684
it is like medical schools in india where , in that fairy-land of religious inhibition , the dissection of dead bodies is frowned upon .	107.1106
instead they learn their dissection on the bulbs of plants .	58.281445
thus technical efficiency is achieved at the expense of actual experience .	69.21608
in the earlier years of training certain phases of the work must be covered and the synthetic problem has its use .	49.032673
but to continue to divorce advanced students from reality is inexcusable .	163.66212
consultation with architects , clients , real estate men , fabric houses and furniture companies is essential to the proper development of class problems just as in actual work .	130.2576
fortunately , although only a few years ago they held the student at arms length , today the business houses welcome the opportunity to aid the student , not only from an increased sense of community responsibility but also from the realization that the student of today is the interior designer of tomorrow -- that the student already is `` in the trade ' ' .	83.6875
even the `` history of furniture ' ' can hardly be taught exclusively from photographs and lantern slides .	93.65046
here , too , the reality of actual furniture must be experienced .	90.36195
the professional organizations such as american institute of interior designers , national society of interior designers , home fashions league and various trade associations , can and do aid greatly in this work .	111.21273
certainly every educator involved in interior design should be a member and active in the work of one of these organizations .	33.439514
not only should every educator above the rank of instructor be expected to be a member of one of the professional organizations , but his first qualification for membership as an educator should be so sharply scrutinized that membership would be equivalent to certification to teach the subject .	60.921703
participation for the educator in this case , however , would have to be raised to full and complete membership .	50.43858
the largest of these organizations at present denies to the full time educator any vote on the conduct and standards of the group and , indeed , refuses him even the right to attach the customary initials after his name in the college catalog .	80.877815
this anomalous status of the educator cannot fail to lower his standing in the eyes of the students .	66.27175
the professor in turn dares not tolerate the influence in his classes of an organization in the policies and standards of which he has no voice .	81.92668
this seems somewhat shortsighted since if the absolute educational qualifications for membership which the organizations profess are ever enforced , the educator will have the molding of the entire profession in his hands .	99.98093
in one way the institutes and societies do a disservice to the schools .	47.88631
that is in the continuance of the `` grandfather clauses ' ' in their membership requirements .	29.514874
when these groups were first formed many prominent and accomplished decorators could not have had the advantage of school training since interior design courses were rare and undeveloped during their youth .	116.53199
long hard years of `` on the job ' ' training had brought them to their competence .	54.305916
the necessity of that day has long disappeared .	7.539619
there is plenty of opportunity for proper education today .	87.649025
it is discouraging for students to realize that the societies do not truly uphold the standards for which they are supposed to stand .	38.642094
the reason and the day of `` grandfather clauses ' ' has long since passed .	37.567467
no one can deny that these `` back door ' ' admissions to membership provisions have been seriously abused nor that they have not resulted in the admission of downright incompetents to membership in supposedly learned societies .	102.95639
beyond any question of curriculum and approach to subject must be the quality of the teachers themselves .	109.10553
it will occur to anyone that the teacher must have adequate education , a depth and breadth of knowledge far beyond the immediate necessities of his course plus complete dedication to his subject and to his students .	87.89106
the local decorator who rushes in for a few hours of teaching may but more likely may not have these qualifications .	147.46205
nor will the hack , the jack-of-all-trades , still found in some of the smaller art schools , suffice .	128.52243
only a few years ago a middle western college circulated a request for a teacher of interior design .	32.1777
at the end of its letter was the information that applicants for this position `` must also be prepared to teach costume design and advertising art ' ' .	73.42634
this kind of irresponsibility toward their students can scarcely build a strong professional attitude in the future designer .	92.799065
we must build a corps of highly professional teachers of interior design who have had education , experience in the profession and are willing to take on the usual accompaniments of teaching -- minimal income and minimal status among their confreres .	158.57663
considerable specialization in teaching subjects such as architecture , furniture design , textiles and color is also desirable .	73.49956
in all `` degree ' ' courses in interior design a number of `` academic ' ' or `` general studies ' ' courses are included .	34.254707
it is only fair to demand that teachers of courses in english , history , psychology and so on be as well informed in matters of art , especially interior design , as are the art teachers educated in the academic subjects .	109.16792
the proper correlation of the art with the academic can be achieved only if this standard is observed .	236.9176
the matter of sympathy of the academic professors for art objectives also must be taken into account .	106.55214
one technical question of school organization comes to mind here .	208.4845
for proper accreditation of schools , teachers in any course must have a degree at least one level above that for which the student is a candidate .	77.40814
since there are almost no schools in the country offering graduate work in interior design this rule cannot at present be observed .	277.5412
indeed , it has only been a matter of the last few years that reputable schools of art have granted degrees at all .	75.82061
the question , however , cannot be ignored for long .	141.99725
the basic problem involved is that a college setting up a graduate school must have an entirely separate faculty for the advanced degree .	104.514946
most professors in the course must , naturally , again have a higher degree than the course offers .	107.57669
one solution is the aquisition of degrees in education but it is a poor substitute .	73.66369
it is a sort of academic ring-around-a-rosy and you solve it .	123.75214
this brings us to the question of accreditation of art schools in general .	84.5018
only the independent art schools , that is , those not connected with any university or college , receive severe and separate investigation before accreditation by the various regional organizations .	235.16649
it has been the custom for most universities to stretch the blanket of accreditation for their liberal arts school to cover the shivering body of their fine arts department .	178.99689
this , plus the habit of many schools of simply adding interior design to the many subjects of their home economics department , yet , nevertheless , claiming that they teach interior design , has contributed to the low repute of many university courses in interior design .	79.556366
in spite of this , many universities offer adequate and even distinguished courses in the subject .	67.48668
there will be no mitigation of these offences until all art schools , whether independent or attached to universities have separate accreditation -- as do medical schools -- by an art accreditation group such as the `` national association of schools of art ' ' .	139.87866
independent art schools granting degrees must , naturally , follow this with academic accreditation by the appropriate regional group .	65.90616
how long has it been since you reviewed the objectives of your benefit and service program ? ?	38.809883
have you permitted it to become a giveaway program rather than one that has the goal of improved employee morale and , consequently , increased productivity ? ?	112.092354
what effort do you make to assess results of your program ? ?	18.156286
do you measure its relation to reduced absenteeism , turnover , accidents , and grievances , and to improved quality and output ? ?	47.745018
have you set specific objectives for your employee publication ? ?	43.902893
is it larger or fancier than you really need ? ?	22.26472
are you using the most economical printing methods , paper , etc . .	24.609097
are there other , cheaper communications techniques that could be substituted ? ?	32.03688
has your attitude toward employee benefits encouraged an excess of free `` government ' ' work in your plant ? ?	65.58792
is your purchasing agent offering too much free-buying service for employees ? ?	104.279045
when improvements are recommended in working conditions -- such as lighting , rest rooms , eating facilities , air-conditioning -- do you try to set a measure of their effectiveness on productivity ? ?	57.421284
when negotiating with your union , do you make sure employees have a choice between new benefits and their cents-per-hour cost in wages .	108.612305
can you consider restricting any additional employee benefits to those paid for by profit-sharing money , such as was done in the union contract recently signed by american motors corporation ? ?	69.65534
do your employees understand all the benefits to which your insurance entitles them ? ?	31.826075
are they encouraged to take full legal advantage of these benefits ? ?	53.419754
have you publicized the cents-per-hour value of the company ' s share of insurance premiums ? ?	30.855356
when did you last compare your present premium costs with the costs of insurance from other sources ? ?	38.096527
can your insurance company aid you in reducing administrative costs ? ?	18.722176
do you try to maintain the principle of employee-contributed ( as opposed to fully company-paid ) programs ? ?	51.079742
do you protect your holiday privileges with an attendance requirement both before and after the holiday ? ?	202.54947
do you plan to limit additional holidays to area and/or industrial patterns ? ?	476.1175
have you investigated the possibility of moving midweek holidays forward to monday or back to friday in order to have an uninterrupted work week ? ?	224.92622
are you carefully policing wash-up time and rest periods to be certain that all other time is productive ? ?	143.04039
are you watching work schedules for boiler operators , guards , and other 24-hour-day , 7-day-week operations in order to minimize overtime ? ?	31.00027
are you careful to restrict the number of people on leave at one time so that your total employment obligation is minimized ? ?	128.31258
have you considered using vending equipment to replace or reduce the number of cafeteria employees ? ?	25.807901
what are the possibilities for operating your cafeteria for a single shift only and relying upon vending machines or prepackaged sandwiches for the second- and third-shift operations ? ?	43.358597
have you checked the cost of subcontracting your cafeteria operation in order to save administrative costs ? ?	33.83952
are there possibilities of having cafeteria help work part-time on custodial or other jobs ? ?	63.053635
can staggered lunch periods relieve the capacity strain on your feeding facilities ? ?	46.585564
would it be feasible to limit the menu in order to reduce feeding costs ? ?	33.2787
have you considered gradual withdrawal of subsidies to your in-plant feeding operation ? ?	69.32253
are you utilizing cafeteria space for company meetings or discussions ? ?	85.65429
are your expenses in this area commensurate with the number of employees who benefit from your program ? ?	44.656845
have you audited your program recently to weed out those phases that draw least participation ? ?	337.22946
do employees contribute their share of money to recreational facilities ? ?	57.01226
have you considered delegating operational responsibility to your employee association and carefully restricting your plant ' s financial contribution ? ?	32.473335
could an employee ' s garden club take over partial care of plant grounds ? ?	94.884415
would a camera club be useful in taking pictures pertinent to plant safety ? ?	151.48625
are you spending too much money on team uniforms that benefit only a few employees ? ?	61.317043
are you utilizing vending machine proceeds to help pay for your program ? ?	53.537724
do you know the trend in your cost of maintaining access roads and parking lots ? ?	37.8538
if you use parking attendants , can they be replaced by automatic parking gates ? ?	42.28198
will your local bus company erect and/or maintain the bus stops at your plant ? ?	34.004013
if you provide inter-plant transportation , can this be replaced by available public transportation ? ?	125.493965
if you use company transportation to meet trains or to haul visitors , would taxis be cheaper ? ?	122.80121
how efficient and necessary are your intra-company vehicles ? ?	6.686417
can part-time drivers be assigned to other productive work ? ?	40.415226
which is more economical for your plant -- a vacation shutdown or spaced vacations that require extra employees for vacation fill-ins ? ?	40.98703
can vacations be spaced throughout the 12 months to minimize the number of employee fill-ins ? ?	35.626945
do you insist that unneeded salary employees take their vacations during plant shutdowns ? ?	122.34095
what can your sales and purchasing departments do to curtail orders , shipments , and receipts during vacation shutdown periods ? ?	78.91833
is an arbitrary retirement age of 65 actually costing your plant money ? ?	38.79801
what sort of effort do you make to assure that older or disabled workers are fully productive ? ?	93.44661
would early retirement of non-productive , disabled employees reduce the number of make-work jobs ? ?	31.642967
will your union accept seniority concessions in assigning work for older or disabled employees ? ?	46.369934
can you share medical facilities and staff with neighboring plants ? ?	41.992123
if you have a full-time doctor now , can he be replaced with a part-time doctor or one who serves on a fee-per-case basis only ? ?	72.74923
can your plant nurse be replaced by a trained first-aid man who works full-time on some other assignment ? ?	145.00836
do you rigidly distinguish between job- and non-job-connected health problems and avoid treating the latter ? ?	184.01202
are you indiscriminantly offering unnecessary medical services -- flu shots , sun lamp treatments , etc . ? ?	82.39366
if you have an annual or regular physical examination program , is it worth what it is costing you ? ?	72.17721
consider what you can afford to spend and what your goals are before setting up or revamping your employee benefit program .	83.35746
too many plant officials are all too eager to buy a package program from an insurance company simply because it works for another plant .	163.75464
but even if that other plant employs the same number of workers and makes the same product , there are other facts to consider .	70.52351
in what section of the country are you located ? ?	117.368256
are you in a rural or urban area ? ?	5.097373
these factors can make the difference between waste and efficiency in any benefit program .	76.47043
above all , don ' t set up extravagant fringe benefits just to buy employee good will .	360.5324
unions stress fringe benefits , but the individual hourly worker prefers cash every time .	162.59778
some plants go overboard on one type of fringe -- say a liberal retirement plan -- and find themselves vulnerable elsewhere .	218.59262
if you want credit for your employee services program , let your workers know what they ' re entitled to .	43.86322
this can be done by stories in your house organs , posters , special publications , letters to workers ' homes as well as by word of mouth through your chain of command .	151.8743
hallmark cards , inc . , kansas city , mo . , has a do-it-yourself quiz game called `` benefit bafflers ' ' , which it distributes to employees .	33.905804
m & r dietetic laboratories , inc . , columbus , gives all its workers a facsimile checkbook -- each check showing the amount the company spends on a particular fringe .	107.96448
u . s . rubber company , new york , passes out a form itemizing the value of benefits .	77.71381
the blue-collar worker thus knows his insurance package , for example , costs $227 . 72 .	24.445774
have the insurance company or your own accounting department break down the cost of your insurance package periodically .	84.99668
you may find certain coverage costing much more than is economically feasible , thereby alerting you to desirable revisions .	86.03891
check to see if some of your benefits -- such as on-the-job disability pay -- can be put on a direct payment rather than an insured basis at a savings to you .	68.36811
it can put an end to marginal claims which play havoc with your insurance rates .	150.73157
also , beware of open-end policies , especially in the medical field .	32.62411
this will mean that every time there ' s an increase in hospital rates your cost will go up in like manner .	112.84321
don ' t go overboard on insurance that pays benefits only upon death .	431.7317
generally , your employee will greatly appreciate benefits that protect him during his working life or during retirement .	224.97223
in granting bereavement leaves , specify the maximum time off and list what the worker ' s relation to the deceased must be to qualify .	119.203
thus , you avoid headaches when an employee wants off for his fourth cousin ' s funeral .	72.47079
also , reserve the right to demand proof of death despite the fact that you ' ll probably never use it .	47.929714
coffee breaks can be a real headache if not regulated .	223.24873
vending machines can alleviate the long hike to the cafeteria during the break with resulting waste of production time .	200.09242
if coffee is sold at the cafeteria , let a few workers in each department get it for the whole group .	127.748604
consider installing supplemental serving lines in production areas .	3.2928462
make sure milk for the coffee is placed in dispensers rather than in containers , if you are supplying the coffee .	57.905598
otherwise , you may be saddled with a good-size milk bill by milk drinkers .	87.96606
keep the retirement age flexible so skilled craftsmen such as tool and die makers can be kept on the job for the convenience of the company .	52.30398
and so deadheads on the payroll can be eased out at the earliest possible age .	89.8008
make sure you have minimum age and time-on-the-job requirements tied into your pension plan .	301.09448
younger men usually don ' t think of pensions as an important job benefit factor anyhow and they ' re liable to change jobs several times before settling down .	154.304
choose carefully between contributory or non-contributory pension plans .	10.033803
there are two sides of a coin for this decision .	54.699333
workers usually think more of a plan they contribute to .	192.33777
and they can at least collect the money they put in , plus interest , when they leave the company .	118.341255
a non-contributory plan usually won ' t pay off for the worker until he retires .	100.17382
thus , there is an added incentive to stay on the job .	16.393284
make sure you don ' t pay for holidays that occur when an employee would not otherwise be working .	137.78697
these include leaves of absences , illnesses , and layoffs .	5.915743
consider adopting a system of holidays in which time off is granted with an eye to minimum inconvenience to the operation of the plant .	71.45686
it ' s usually not too hard to sell workers on this as it gives them longer holiday periods .	124.03547
for example , the friday after thanksgiving can be substituted for washington ' s birthday .	67.01072
this reduces the number of expensive plant shutdowns and startups .	14.606732
require each employee to work his last shift both before and after the holiday to be eligible for pay .	101.31448
consider using vending machines rather than subsidized cafeterias .	8.244985
latest models serve hot meals at reasonable prices , and at a profit to you .	39.74021
if a concessionaire runs the cafeteria , keep an eye out for quality and price .	131.41219
if the soup tastes like dishwater , your employees won ' t blame the concessionaire .	57.337917
check your cafeteria location to make sure it ' s convenient for most employees .	50.072258
you may save valuable production minutes with a change .	60.187893
spread your vacation period over the widest possible span of time or shut the plant down for two weeks .	80.28505
this will cut the expense of vacation replacements .	4.3238983
and with the shutdown method there will be no argument as to who gets the choice vacation dates .	348.62695
also make sure you have reasonable requirements as to hours worked before a production employee is entitled to a vacation .	198.68636
you might try providing standard vacation time off but make the vacation pay depend on the number of hours worked in the previous year .	72.33321
the long and ever-increasing column of sportsmen is now moving into a new era .	46.71944
modern times have changed the world beyond recognition .	5.563553
the early years of the twentieth century seem very far away .	40.63948
but with all the changes in philosophy , dress and terrain -- a few things remain constant , including the devotion of americans to the great field sports , hunting and fishing .	184.24742
as the generations move on , clothes become more suitable for the enjoyment of outdoor sports .	22.025028
sporting firearms change , markedly for the better .	21.879004
just as modern transportation has outmoded the early studebaker covered wagon , the demand of today ' s sportsmen and women has necessitated changes in their equipment .	60.55239
the american firearms and ammunition manufacturers through diligent research and technical development have replaced the muzzle loader and slow-firing single-shot arms with modern fast firing auto-loaders , extremely accurate bolt , lever , and slide action firearms .	73.77593
and millions of rounds of entirely new and modern small-arms ammunition , designed for today ' s hunting and target shooting .	81.173035
