it was there , in the course of trying to prepare new men for the `` culture shock ' ' they might encounter in remote overseas posts , that he first began to develop a system of charting the `` norms of human communication ' ' .	70.62572
to the trained ear of the linguist , talk has always revealed a staggering quantity of information about the talker -- such things as geographical origin and/or history , socio-economic identity , education .	155.5553
it is only fairly recently , however , that linguists have developed a systematic way of charting voices on paper in a way that tells even more about the speakers and about the success or failure of human communication between two people .	102.46193
this , for obvious reasons , makes their techniques superbly useful in studying the psychiatric interview , so useful , in fact , that they have been successfully used to suggest ways to speed diagnosis and to evaluate the progress of therapy .	46.151005
in the early 1950 ' s , smith , together with his distinguished colleague , george trager ( so austerely academic he sometimes fights his own evident charm ) , and a third man with the engaging name of birdwhistell ( ray ) , agreed on some basic premises about the three-part process that makes communication ( 1 ) words or language ( 2 ) paralanguage , a set of phenomena including laughing , weeping , voice breaks , and `` tone ' ' of voice , and ( 3 ) kinesics , the technical name for gestures , facial expressions , and body shifts -- nodding or shaking the head , `` talking ' ' with one ' s hands , et cetera .	66.91097
smith ' s first workout with stresses , pitches , and junctures was based on mother , which spells , in our culture , a good deal more than bread alone .	54.596703
for example , if you are a reasonably well-adjusted person , there are certain ways that are reasonable and appropriate for addressing your mother .	79.91864
the usual u . s . norm would be af middle pitches , slight pause ( juncture ) before mother , slight rise at the end .	115.759735
the symbols of mother ' s status , here , are all usual for culture u . s . a . .	76.34866
quite other feelings are evidenced by this style af note the drop to pitch 1 ( the lowest ) on mother with no rise at the end of the sentence	161.77676
this is a `` fade ' ' ending , and what you have here is a downtalking style of speech , expressing something less than conventional respect for mother .	136.9424
even less regard for mom and mom ' s apple pie goes with af in other words , the way the speaker relates to mother is clearly indicated .	111.09194
and while the meaning of the words is not in this instance altered , the quality of communication in both the second and third examples is definitely impaired .	94.71744
an accompanying record of paralanguage factors for the second example might also note a throaty rasp .	128.40707
with this seven-word sentence -- though the speaker undoubtedly thought he was dealing only with the subject of food -- he was telling things about himself and , in the last two examples , revealing that he had departed from the customs of his culture .	81.69238
the joint investigations of linguistics and psychiatry have established , in point of fact , that no matter what the subject of conversation is or what words are involved , it is impossible for people to talk at all without telling over and over again what sort of people they are and how they relate to the rest of the world .	70.42884
since interviewing is the basic therapeutic and diagnostic instrument of modern psychiatry , the recording of interviews for playbacks and study has been a boost of redstone proportions in new research and training .	57.500607
some of the earliest recordings , made in the 1940 ' s demonstrated that psychiatrists reacted immediately to anger and anxiety in the sound track , whereas written records of the same interview offered far fewer cues to therapy which -- if they were at all discernible in print -- were picked up only by the most skilled and sensitive experts .	134.86382
in a general way , psychiatrists were able to establish on a wide basis what many of them had always felt -- that the most telling cues in psychotherapy are acoustic , that such things as stress and nagging are transmitted by sound alone and not necessarily by words .	104.4084
at a minimum , recording -- usually on tape , which is now in wide professional use -- brings the psychiatric interview alive so that the full range of emotion and meaning can be explored repeatedly by the therapist or by a battery of therapists .	103.65381
newest to this high-powered battery are the experts in linguistics who have carried that minimum to a new level .	190.49059
by adding a systematic analysis with symbols to the typed transcripts of interviews , they have supplied a new set of techniques for the therapist .	43.73629
linguistic charting of the transcribed interview flags points where the patient ' s voice departs from expected norms .	110.02299
it flags such possible breakdowns of communication as rehearsed dialogue , the note of disapproval , ambivalence or ambiguity , annoyance , resentment , and the disinclination to speak at all -- this last often marked by a fade-in beginning of sentences .	97.3795
interpretation , naturally , remains the role of the therapist , but orientation -- not only the patient ' s vocal giveaways of geographical and socio-economic background , but also vocal but non-verbal giveaways of danger spots in his relationship to people -- can be considerably beefed up by the linguist .	121.35398
his esoteric chartings of the voice alert the therapist to areas where deeper probing may bring to light underlying psychological difficulties , making them apparent first to the therapist and eventually to the patient .	266.69263
in one now-historic first interview , for example , the transcript ( reproduced from the book , the first five minutes ) goes like this the therapist ' s level tone is bland and neutral -- he has , for example , avoided stressing `` you ' ' , which would imply disapproval	80.98197
or surprise , which would set the patient apart from other people .	62.212093
the patient , on the other hand , is far from neutral	290.96738
aside from her specifically regional accent , she reveals by the use of the triad , `` irritable , tense , depressed ' ' , a certain pedantic itemization that indicates she has some familiarity with literary or scientific language ( i . e . , she must have had at least a high-school education ) , and she is telling a story she has mentally rehearsed some time before .	74.94813
then she catapults into `` everything and everybody ' ' , putting particular violence on `` everybody ' ' , indicating to the linguist that this is a spot to flag -- that is , it is not congruent to the patient ' s general style of speech up to this point .	43.50714
consequently , it is referred to the therapist for attention .	84.55597
he may then very well conclude that `` everybody ' ' is probably not the true target of her resentment .	61.93812
immediately thereafter , the patient fractures her rehearsed story , veering into an oversoft , breathy , sloppily articulated , `` i don ' t feel like talking right now ' ' .	26.392563
within the first five minutes of this interview it is apparent to the therapist that `` everybody ' ' truthfully refers to the woman ' s husband .	32.880833
she says later , but still within the opening five minutes , `` i keep thinking of a divorce but that ' s another emotional death ' ' .	59.889412
the linguistic and paralinguistic signals of misery are all present in the voice chart for this sentence	206.58133
so are certain signals that she does not accept divorce .	122.759346
by saying `` another emotional death ' ' , she reveals that there has been a previous one , although she has not described it in words .	55.575058
this the therapist may pursue in later questioning .	68.566605
the phrase , `` emotional death ' ' , interesting and , to a non-scientific mind , rather touching , suggests that this woman may have some flair for words , perhaps even something of the temperament regrettably called `` creative ' ' .	80.52978
since the psychiatric interview , like any other interview , depends on communication , it is significant to note that the therapist in this interview was a man of marked skill and long experience .	78.77143
his own communication apparatus operated superbly , and lillian ross readers will note instantly its total lack of resemblance to the blunted , monumentally unmeshed mechanism of dr . blauberman .	66.13597
interestingly enough -- although none of the real-life therapists involved could conceivably compare with blauberman -- when groups of them began playing back interviews , they discovered any number of ways in which they wanted to polish their own interview techniques	209.19691
almost everyone , on first hearing one of his own sessions on tape , expressed some desire to take the whole thing over again .	149.36949
yet , in spite of this , intensive study of the taped interviews by teams of psychotherapists and linguists laid bare the surprising fact that , in the first five minutes of an initial interview , the patient often reveals as many as a dozen times just what ' s wrong with him	76.769394
to spot these giveaways the therapist must know either intuitively or scientifically how to listen .	161.30827
naturally , the patient does not say , `` i hate my father ' ' , or `` sibling rivalry is what bugs me ' ' .	24.015665
what he does do is give himself away by communicating information over and above the words involved .	292.85538
some of the classic indicators , as described by drs . pittenger , hockett , and danehy in the first five minutes , are these ambiguity of pronouns	34.28444
stammering or repetition of i , you , he , she , et cetera may signal ambiguity or uncertainty .	206.68912
on the other hand significant facts may be concealed -- she may mean i or everybody , as it did with the tense and irritable woman mentioned before , may refer to a specific person .	117.94803
the word that is not used can be as important as the word that is used	52.08904
therapist and/or linguist must always consider the alternatives .	18.255991
when someone says , for example , `` they took x-rays to see that there was nothing wrong with me ' ' , it pays to consider how this statement would normally be made .	54.536766
( this patient , in actuality , was a neurasthenic who had almost come to the point of accepting the fact that it was not her soma but her psyche that was the cause of her difficulty .	47.14285
) amateur linguists note here that pursewarden , in durrell ' s alexandria quartet , stammered when he spoke of his wife , which is hardly surprising in view of their disastrous relationship .	60.151543
she was just another freighter from the states , and she seemed as commonplace as her name .	60.101254
she was the john harvey , one of those atlantic sea-horses that had sailed to bari to bring beans , bombs , and bullets to the u . s . fifteenth air force , to field marshal montgomery ' s eighth army then racing up the calf of the boot of italy in that early december of 1943 .	77.64629
the john harvey arrived in bari , a port on the adriatic , on november 28th , making for porto nuovo , which , as the name indicates , was the ancient city ' s new and modern harbor .	49.00787
hardly anyone ashore marked her as she anchored stern-to off berth 29 on the mole .	85.73654
if anyone thought of the john harvey , it was to observe that she was straddled by a pair of ships heavily laden with high explosive and if they were hit the john harvey would likely be blown up with her own ammo and whatever else it was that she carried .	84.926865
it had required the approval of president franklin delano roosevelt before the john harvey could be loaded with 100 tons of mustard gas and despatched to the italian warfront .	35.41046
for in a world as yet unacquainted with the horrors of the mushroom cloud , poison gas was still regarded as the ultimate in hideous weapons .	42.840492
throughout the early years of world war 2 , , reports persisted that the axis powers had used gas -- germany in russia , japan in china again .	142.1341
influential people in america were warning the pentagon to be prepared against desperation gas attacks by the germans in future campaigns .	134.08325
some extremists went so far as to urge our using it first .	349.84198
to silence extremists , to warn the axis , president roosevelt issued this statement for the allies in august	108.79362
`` from time to time since the present war began there have been reports that one or more of the axis powers were seriously contemplating use of poisonous gas or noxious gases or other inhumane devices of warfare .	58.55851
i have been loath to believe that any nation , even our present enemies , could or would be willing to loose upon mankind such terrible and inhumane weapons .	168.72942
`` however , evidence that the axis powers are making significant preparations indicative of such an intention is being reported with increasing frequency from a variety of sources .	73.06674
`` use of such weapons has been outlawed by the general opinion of civilized mankind .	43.060833
this country has not used them , and i hope that we never will be compelled to use them .	31.592264
i state categorically that we shall under no circumstances resort to the use of such weapons unless they are first used by our enemies ' ' .	43.73186
the following month the invasion of italy was begun , and roosevelt gave effect to his warning by consenting to the stockpiling of poison gas in southern italy .	107.1338
bari was chosen as a depot , not only for its seeming safety , but because of its proximity to airfields .	56.594482
it would be made in three waves -- the first to lay down a smokescreen , the second to drop the gas bombs , the third to shower incendiaries which would burn everything below .	114.156715
so the vile cargo went into the hole of the john harvey .	20.733187
a detachment of six men from the 701st chemical maintenance company under first lt . howard d . beckstrom went aboard , followed by lt . thomas h . richardson , the cargo security officer .	73.662254
only a few other people -- very important people -- knew of the nitrogen-mustard eggs nestled below decks .	234.14336
thus , in the immemorial way -- in the way of the right hand that knows and the left that does not -- was the stage set for tragedy at bari .	140.4718
it was the night of december 2 , 1943 , and it was growing dark in bari .	55.616997
it was getting on toward 7 o ' clock and the german me-210 plane had been and gone on its eighth straight visit .	93.796555
capt . a . b . jenks of the office of harbor defense was very worried .	166.48454
he knew that german long-range bombers had been returning to the attack in italy .	74.967575
on november 24th , they had made a raid on la maddalena .	44.411926
two days later , some 30 of them had struck at a convoy off bougie , sinking a troopship -- and it had been that very night that the me-210 had made its first appearance .	77.77936
after it had reappeared the next two nights , jenks went to higher headquarters and said	161.8991
`` for three days now a german reconnaissance plane has been over the city taking pictures .	89.95479
they ' re just waiting for the proper time to come over here and dump this place into the adriatic ' ' .	66.17238
but the older and wiser heads had dismissed his warning as alarmist .	81.34961
even though it was known that the luftwaffe in the north was now being directed by the young and energetic general peltz , the commander who would conduct the `` little blitz ' ' on london in 1944 , a major raid on bari at this juncture of the war was not to be considered seriously .	45.358944
true , there had been raids on naples -- but naples was pretty far north on the opposite coast .	143.81659
more than that , allied air had complete superiority in the eighth army ' s sector .	43.088703
so captain jenks returned to his harbor post to watch the scouting plane put in five more appearances , and to feel the certainty of this dread rising within him .	113.70065
for jenks knew that bari ' s defenses were made of paper .	40.6202
the royal air force had but a single light anti-aircraft squadron and two balloon units available .	194.23999
there were no r . a . f . fighter squadrons on bari airfield .	51.889366
the radar station with the best location was still not serviceable .	57.284355
and everywhere in evidence among the few remaining defensive units was that old handmaiden of disaster -- multiple command .	272.35718
it had been made shockingly evident that very morning to ensign kay k . vesole , in charge of the armed guard aboard the john bascom .	68.7831
a british officer had come aboard and told him that in case of enemy air attack he was not to open fire until bombs were actually dropped .	110.25359
then he was to co-ordinate his fire with a radar-controlled shore gun firing white tracers .	78.42454
`` this harbor is a bomber ' s paradise ' ' , the britisher had said with frank grimness .	51.55721
`` it ' s up to you to protect yourselves .	149.60892
we can ' t expect any help from the fighters at foggia , either .	87.44781
they ' re all being used on offensive missions ' ' .	7.5323887
not fire until the bombs came down ! !	1.1153216
he thought of the tons and tons of flammable fluid beneath his feet and shook his head .	23.752638
like hell he ' d wait -- and supposing the radar-controlled gun got knocked out ? ?	373.37103
what would his guns guide on then -- the north star ? ?	115.10194
ensign vesole decided that he would not tarry until he heard the whispering of the bombs , and when night began to fall , he put seaman 2/c donald l . norton and seaman 1/c william a . rochford on the guns and told them to start shooting the moment they saw an enemy silhouette .	62.046665
below decks , seaman 1/c stanley bishop had begun to write a letter home .	30.244478
above decks on the john harvey , lieutenant richardson gazed at the lights still burning on the port wall and felt uneasy .	55.49133
there were lights glinting in the city , too , even though it was now dark enough for a few stars to become visible .	75.99456
bari was asking for it , he thought .	55.817375
for five days now , they had been in port and that filthy stuff was still in the hold .	102.19322
he hoped they would put in somewhere way , way down in the earth .	107.81076
the burden of his secret was pressing down on him , as it was on lieutenant beckstrom and his six enlisted men .	53.676907
lieutenant richardson could envy the officers and men of the john harvey in their innocent assumption that the ship contained nothing more dangerous than high explosive bombs .	53.678123
they seemed happy at the delay in unloading , glad at the chance to go ashore in a lively liberty port such as bari .	161.47542
nine of them had gone down the gangplank already .	863.46796
deck cadet james l . cahill and seaman walter brooks had been the first to leave .	60.177277
richardson had returned their departing grins with the noncommittal nod that is the security officer ' s stock in trade .	33.096626
the other half of the crew , plus beckstrom and his men , had remained aboard .	56.34826
damned if that wasn ' t a sailing ship standing out of the old harbor -- porto vecchio .	53.410675
the night was so clear that richardson had no difficulty making out the silhouette .	148.33392
then the thought of a cloudless sky made him shiver , and he glanced upward .	82.712395
it was a clear night and it was raining ! !	47.775
capt . michael a . musmanno , military governor of the sorrentine peninsula , had also seen and felt the `` rain ' ' .	47.692913
captain musmanno ' s renovated schooner with the flamboyant name unsinkable had just left porto vecchio with a cargo of badly-needed olive oil for the sorrentine ' s civilian population .	37.44653
at exactly 7 30 , he felt a fluttering object brush his face .	101.94807
he turned the beam of his flashlight on it .	23.299152
it was the silver foil from the chocolate bar he had been eating .	128.54167
another , longer strip of tinsel whipped his mouth .	8.288671
it was `` window ' ' -- the tinsel paper dropped by bombers to jam radar sets , to fill the scope with hundreds of blips that would seem to be approaching bombers .	110.0857
unsinkable slowed and stopped , hundreds of brilliant white flares swayed eerily down from the black , the air raid sirens ashore rose in a keening shriek , the anti-aircraft guns coughed and chattered -- and above it all motors roared and the bombs came whispering and wailing and crashing down among the ships at anchor at bari .	52.080482
they had come from airports in the balkans , these hundred-odd junkers 88 ' s .	23.613363
they had winged over the adriatic , they had taken bari by complete surprise and now they were battering her , attacking with deadly skill .	208.47287
they had ruined the radar warning system with their window , they had made themselves invisible above their flares .	192.36436
and they also had the lights of the city , the port wall lanterns , and a shore crane ' s spotlight to guide on .	65.93395
after the first two were blacked out , the third light was abandoned by a terrified italian crew , who left their light to shine for nine minutes like an unerring homing beacon until british mp ' s shot it out .	84.16032
in that interval , the german bombers made a hell of bari harbor .	62.23218
merchant ships illuminated in the light of the flares , made to seem like stones imbedded in a lake of polished mud , were impossible to miss .	124.36896
captain musmanno roared at his men to lash three of the casks of olive oil together for a raft .	55.92458
they got it over the side and clambered aboard only a few minutes before their schooner went under .	120.33722
ensign vesole and his gunners had fought valiantly , but they had no targets .	27.307219
most of the junkers were above the blinding light of the flares , and the radar-controlled shore gun had been knocked out by one of the first sticks of bombs .	34.175026
vesole rushed from gun to gun , attempting to direct fire .	45.625164
norton and rochford fired wildly at the sounds of the motors .	35.78033
bishop rushed on deck to grab a 20-mm gun , pumping out 400 rounds before sticks of three bombs each crashed into holds one , three and five .	184.52289
luckily , she was not completely aflame and would go down before the gasoline could erupt .	82.38676
the order to abandon ship was given , but cries of pain could be heard from the wounded below decks .	68.828735
there is a pause in the merriment as your friends gaze at you , wondering why you are staring , open-mouthed in amazement .	83.58138
you explain , `` i have the strangest feeling of having lived through this very same event before .	133.62523
i can ' t tell when , but i ' m positive i witnessed this same scene of this particular gathering at some time in the past ' ' ! !	41.645206
this experience will have happened to many of you .	67.66785
emerson , in his lecture , refers to the `` startling experience which almost every person confesses in daylight , that particular passages of conversation and action have occurred to him in the same order before , whether dreaming or waking , a suspicion that they have been with precisely these persons in precisely this room , and heard precisely this dialogue , at some former hour , they know not when ' ' .	136.74123
most psychiatrists dismiss these instances of that weird feeling as the deja vue ( already seen ) illusion , just as they dismiss dream previsions as coincidences .	98.281456
in this manner they side-step the seemingly hopeless investigation of the greater depths of mystery in which all of us grope continually .	59.75762
when a man recognizes a certain experience as the exact pattern of a previous dream , we have an instance of deja vue , except for the fact that he knows just why the experience seems familiar .	58.834335
occasionally there are examples of pre-vision which cannot be pushed aside without confessing an unscientific attitude .	90.639084
one day maeterlinck , coming with a friend upon an event which he recognized as the exact pattern of a previous dream , detailed the ensuing occurrences in advance so accurately that his companion was completely mystified .	89.11475
rudyard kipling ' s scorn for the `` jargon ' ' of psychical research was altered somewhat when he wondered `` how , or why , had i been shown an unreleased roll of my life film ' ' ? ?	66.54852
the famous author tells us of the strange incident in something about myself .	100.66602
one day when he attended a war memorial ceremony in westminster abbey his view was obstructed by a stout man on his left , his attention turned to the irregular pattern of the rough slab flooring and someone , clasping him by the arm , whispered , `` i want a word with you , please ' ' .	59.759785
at that moment kipling was overwhelmed with awed amazement , suddenly recalling that these identical details of scene , action and word had occurred to him in a dream six weeks earlier .	155.19531
freud probably contributed more than anyone else to the understanding of dreams , enabling us to recognize their equivalents in our wakeful thoughts .	70.354225
however , readers who accept freud ' s findings and believe that he has solved completely the mystery of dreams , should ponder over the following words in his interpretation of dreams , chapter 1	98.97206
as `` a matter of fact no such complete solution of the dream has ever been accomplished in any case , , and what is more , every one attempting such solution has found that in most cases there have remained a great many components of the dream the source of which he has been unable to explain nor is the discussion closed on the subject of the mantic or prophetic power of dreams ' ' .	76.05042
dreams present many mysteries of telepathy , clairvoyance , prevision and retrovision .	9.858696
the basic mystery of dreams , which embraces all the others and challenges us from even the most common typical dream , is in the fact that they are original , visual continuities .	87.62738
i recall the startling , vivid realism of a dream in which i lived through the horror of the bombing of a little korean town .	60.02762
i am sure that nothing within me is capable of composing that life-like sequence , so complete in detail , from the hodge-podge of news pictures i have seen .	109.03095
and when psychology explains glibly , `` but the subconscious mind is able to produce it ' ' it refers to a mental region so vaguely identified that it may embrace the entire universal mind as conceivably as part of the individual mind .	97.34532
skeptics may deny the more startling phenomena of dreams as things they have never personally observed , but failure to wonder at their basic mystery is outright avoidance of routine evidence .	201.19672
the question becomes , `` what is a dream ' ' ? ?	13.569166
is a dream simply a mental or cerebral movie ? ?	45.834877
every dream , and this is true of a mental image of any type even though it may be readily interpreted into its equivalent of wakeful thought , is a psychic phenomenon for which no explanation is available .	64.96595
in most cases we recognize certain words , persons , animals or objects .	97.35939
but these are dreamed in original action , in some particular continuity which we don ' t remember having seen in real life .	67.02052
for instance , the dreamer sees himself seated behind neighbor smith and , with photographic realism , sees smith driving the car	302.2369
whereas , it is a matter of fact that smith cannot drive a car .	128.84636
there is nothing to suggest that the brain can alter past impressions to fit into an original , realistic and unbroken continuity like we experience in dreams .	181.37526
the entire concept of cerebral imagery as the physical basis of a mental image can find no logical support .	89.9098
a `` mental image ' ' subconsciously impressing us from beneath its language symbols in wakeful thought , or consciously in light sleep , is actually not an image at all but is comprised of realities , viewed not in the concurrent sensory stream , but within the depths of the fourth dimension .	132.34506
dreams that display events of the future with photographic detail call for a theory explaining their basic mystery and all its components , including that weird feeling of deja vue , inevitably fantastic though that theory must seem .	149.05087
as in the theory of perception , established in psycho-physiology , the eye is recognized as an integral part of the brain .	24.11789
but then this theory confesses that it is completely at a loss as to how the image can possibly be received by the brain .	93.83306
the opening paragraph of the chapter titled the theory of representative perception , in the book philosophies of science by albert g . ramsperger says , `` passed on to the brain , and there , by some unexplained process , it causes the mind to have a perception ' ' .	65.52403
but why is it necessary to reproduce the retinal image within the brain ? ?	32.635914
as retinal images are conceded to be an integral function of the brain it seems logical to suppose that the nerves , between the inner brain and the eyes , carry the direct drive for cooperation from the various brain centers -- rather than to theorize on the transmission of an image which is already in required location .	81.46898
hereby , the external object viewed by the eyes remains the thing that is seen , not the retinal image , the purpose of which would be to achieve perceptive cooperation by stirring sympathetic impulses in the other sensory centers , motor tensions , associated word symbols , and consciousness .	83.59545
modern physics has developed the theory that all matter consists of minute waves of energy .	95.53563
we know that the number of radio and television impulses , sound waves , ultra-violet rays , etc . , that may occupy the very same space , each solitary upon its own frequency , is infinite .	83.13358
so we may conceive the coexistence of the infinite number of universal , apparently momentary states of matter , successive one after another in consciousness , but permanent each on its own basic phase of the progressive frequencies .	152.49947
this theory makes it possible for any event throughout eternity to be continuously available at any moment to consciousness .	174.02945
space in any form is completely measured by the three dimensions .	28.729555
if the fourth dimension is a physical concept and not purely metaphysical , through what medium does it extend ? ?	197.52617
it is not through space nor time that the time machine most approved by science fiction must travel for a visit to the permanent prehistoric past , or the ever-existent past-fantasy future .	115.60033
three seconds flat is the usual time , and the space is crossed by moderate mileage , while the overwhelming immensity of such journeys must be conceived as a static pulsation through an enormous number of coexistent frequencies which perpetuate all events .	53.38165
the body , senses and brain , in common with all matter , have their counterpart on each of a countless number of frequencies .	120.439926
the senses in each counterpart bear the impression only of phenomena that share its own frequency , whereas those upon all other frequencies are invisible , inaudible and intactible to them .	109.834755
consciousness is the factor that provides the progressive continuity to sensory impressions .	89.32956
when consciousness deserts the sleeping body and the wakeful world , it continues in the myriad progressions of the ever-present past and future , in a life as vibrant and real as the one left when the body tired and required sleep .	116.74333
if the photographically realistic continuity of dreams , however bizarre their combinations , denies that it is purely a composition of the brain , it must be compounded from views of diverse realities , although some of them may never be encountered in what we are pleased to call the real life .	65.96668
dr . h . v . hilprecht , professor of assyrian at the university of pennsylvania , dreamed that a babylonian priest , associated with the king kurigalzu , ( 1300 b . c . ) escorted him to the treasure chamber of the temple of bel , gave him six novel points of information about a certain broken relic , and corrected an error in its identification .	54.500774
as a matter of fact , the incorrect classification , the result of many weeks of labor by dr . hilprecht , was about to be published by him the following day .	77.2836
some time later the missing part of the relic was found and the complete inscription , together with other new evidence , fully corroborated the ancient priest ' s information .	91.240105
dr . hilprecht was uncertain as to the language used by the ancient priest in his dream .	90.12046
he was almost positive it was not assyrian nor cassite , and imagined it must have been german or english .	75.2212
we may conclude that all six points of information , ostensibly given by the dream priest , could have been furnished by dr . hilprecht ' s subconscious reasoning .	67.928444
but , in denying any physical reality for this dream , how could the brain possibly compose that realistic , vividly visual continuity uninterrupted by misty fadeout , violent break or sudden substitution ? ?	92.98324
that the perfect continuity was composed from the joblot of memory impressions in the professor ' s brain , or 2 .	61.60742
that the dream was a reality on the infinite progressions of universal , gradient frequencies , across which the modern professor and the priest of ancient nippur met ? ?	86.96544
the degree of circumstance , the ratio of memory to forgetfulness , determines whether a dream will be a recognized , fulfilled prevision , or the vaguely , effective source of the weird deja vue feeling .	83.30322
no doubt some experiences vanish so completely as to leave no trace on the sleeper ' s mind .	70.34273
probably less than one percent of our previsions escape final obliteration before we wake .	451.90692
when we arrive at the events concerned in the vanished majority , they , of course , cannot impress us as anything familiar .	85.06049
nevertheless , there are notably frequent instances of deja vue , in which our recognition of an entirely novel event is a feeling of having lived through it before , a feeling which , though vague , withstands the verbal barrage from the most impressive corps of psychologists .	80.61472
if deja vue is an illusion , then peculiarly , it is a most prevalent mental disturbance affecting even the most level-headed people .	94.97871
chauncey depew , one-time runner-up for the republican presidential nomination , was attending a convention at saratoga , where he was scheduled to nominate colonel theodore roosevelt for governor of new york when he noticed that the temporary chairman was a man he had never met .	46.247417
after the preliminary business affair was finished depew arose and delivered the convincing speech that clinched the nomination for roosevelt .	110.50249
if depew had told any academic psychologist that he had a weird feeling of having lived through that identical convention session at some time in the past , he would have been informed that he was a victim of deja vue .	36.488407
but the famous orator felt more than vague recognition for the scene .	57.578938
he remembered exactly when he had lived through it before , and he had something to prove he had .	52.621822
one week before the convention , depew was seated on the porch of a country home on the hudson , gazing at the opposite shore .	48.474514
`` the food is wonderful and it is a lot of fun to be here ' ' ! !	16.218721
so wrote a ten year old student in a letter to his parents from north country school , lake placid , new york .	87.16077
in this one sentence , he unwittingly revealed the basic philosophy of the nutrition and psychological programs in operation at the school .	79.77179
because the food is selected with thought for its nutritional value , care for its origin , and prepared in a manner that retains the most nutrients , the food does taste good .	94.76857
when served in a psychological atmosphere that allows young bodies to assimilate the greatest good from what they eat because they are free from tension , a foundation is laid for a high level of health that releases the children from physical handicaps to participate with enjoyment in the work assignments , the athletic programs and the most important phase , the educational opportunities .	106.14483
situated in a region of some of the loveliest mountain scenery in the country , the school buildings are located amid open fields and farm lands .	61.05324
these contemporary structures , beautifully adapted to a school in the country , are home to 60 children , ages eight to fourteen , grades four through eight .	133.72134
from fourteen states and three foreign countries they come to spend the months from mid-september to june .	67.812614
the director , walter e . clark , believes that a school with children living full time in its care must take full responsibility for their welfare .	141.29529
to him this means caring for the whole child , providing basic nutrition , and a spiritual attitude that lends freedom for the development of the mind .	74.36857
the concept of good nutrition really began with the garden .	99.0768
the school has always maintained a farm to supply the needs of the school .	45.371002
in a climate hostile to agriculture , mr . clark has had to keep alert to the most productive farm techniques .	61.716183
where a growing season may , with luck , allow 60 days without frost , and where the soil is poor , sandy , quick-drying and subject to erosion , many farmers fail .	134.57774
throughout the adirondack region abandoned farm homes and wild orchards bear ghostly testimony that their owners met defeat .	147.16548
mr . clark found that orthodox procedures of deep plowing , use of chemical fertilizers and insecticides , plus the application of conservation principles of rotation and contouring , did not prevent sheet erosion in the potato fields and depreciation of the soil .	93.20821
`` to give up these notions required a revolution in thought ' ' , mr . clark said in reminiscing about the abrupt changes in ideas he experienced when he began reading `` organic gardening ' ' and `` modern nutrition ' ' in a search for help with his problems .	47.183216
`` louis bromfield ' s writings excited me as a conservationist ' ' .	11.804765
by 1952 he was convinced he would no longer spray .	54.82292
he locked his equipment in a cabinet where it still remains .	146.99883
after reading `` plowman ' s folly ' ' by edward h . faulkner , he stopped plowing .	100.61861
the basis for compost materials already existed on the school farm with a stable of animals for the riding program , poultry for eggs , pigs to eat garbage , a beef herd and wastes of all kinds .	58.43349
separate pails were kept in the kitchen for coffee grounds and egg shells .	93.84908
all these materials and supplementary manure and other fertilizers from neighboring dairy and poultry farms made over 40 tons of finished compost a year .	59.142643
it was applied with a compost shredder made from a converted manure spreader .	42.329174
years of patient application of compost and leaf mulching has changed the structure of the soil and its water-holding capacity .	39.258038
soon after the method changed , visitors began asking how he managed to irrigate his soil to keep it looking moist , when in reality , it was the soil treatment alone that accomplished this .	156.23564
to demonstrate the soil of his vegetable gardens as it is today , mr . clark stooped to scoop up a handful of rich dark earth .	72.66003
sniffing its sweet smell and letting it fall to show its good crumbly consistency , he pointed to the nearby driveway and said , `` this soil used to be like that hard packed road over there ' ' .	75.251625
`` people and soils respond slowly ' ' , says walter clark , `` but the time has now come when the gardens produce delicious long-keeping vegetables due to this enrichment program .	50.944725
no chemical fertilizers and poisonous insecticides and fungicides are used ' ' .	17.808525
the garden supplies enough carrots , turnips , rutabagas , potatoes , beets , cabbage and squash to store for winter meals in the root cellar .	19.414679
the carrots sometimes don ' t make it through the winter	156.89133
the cabbage and squash keep until march or april .	121.19045
there is never enough corn , peas or strawberries .	4.911357
mr . clark still has to use rotenone with potatoes grown on the least fertile fields , but he has watched the insect damage decrease steadily and hopes that continued use of compost and leaf mulch will allow him to do without it in the future .	82.48601
a new project planned is the use of bio-dynamic starter .	8.34952
new ideas for improving nutrition came with the study of soil treatment .	140.47409
`` after the soil , the kitchen ' ' , says mr . clark .	10.768638
the first major change was that of providing wholewheat bread instead of white bread .	88.523476
`` adults take a long time to convince and you are thwarted if you try to push ' ' .	51.403835
at first the kitchen help was tolerant , but ordered their own supply of white bread for themselves .	119.07813
`` you can ' t make french toast with whole-wheat bread ' ' , was an early complaint .	62.986023
of course they learned in time that they not only could use whole-wheat bread , but the children liked it better .	183.58759
mrs . clark , as house manager , planned the menus and cared for the ordering .	43.546806
then miss lillian colman came from vermont to be kitchen manager .	145.92819
today whole grains are freshly ground every day and baked into bread .	73.377625
mr . clark ' s studies taught him that the only way to conserve the vitamins in the whole grain was prompt use of the flour .	83.0589
once the grains are ground , vitamin e begins to deteriorate immediately and half of it is lost by oxidation and exposure to the air within one week .	86.48153
a mill stands in a room off the kitchen .	34.73077
surrounding it are metal cans of grains ordered from organic farms in the state .	22.035408
miss colman pours measures of whole wheat , oats , and soy beans and turns on the motor .	20.078495
she goes on about her work and listens for the completion of the grinding .	56.21756
the bread baked from this mixture is light in color and fragrant in aroma .	27.858795
it is well liked by the children and faculty .	120.87885
`` lillian ' s bread is so good and everything tastes so much better here that it is hard not to eat too much ' ' , said the secretary ruefully eyeing her extra pounds .	48.533596
the school has not used cold prepared cereals for years , though at one time that was all they ever served .	78.07947
when the chance came , they first eliminated cold cereal once a week , then gradually converted to hot fresh-ground cereal every day .	116.782364
they serve cracked wheat , oats or cornmeal .	3.8419409
occasionally , the children find steamed , whole-wheat grains for cereal which they call `` buckshot ' ' .	72.49319
at the beginning of the school year , the new students don ' t eat the cereal right away , but within a short time they are eating it voraciously .	50.80749
when they leave for vacations they miss the hot cereal .	58.454613
the school has received letters from parents asking , `` what happened to johnny ? ?	43.331676
he never used to like any hot cereal , now that ' s the only kind he wants .	55.636124
where can we get this cereal he likes so much ' ' ? ?	13.987897
salads are served at least once a day .	4.9956203
most come from the root cellar or from the freezer .	7.2107363
sprouted grains and seeds are used in salads and dishes such as chop suey .	26.923782
sometimes sprouted wheat is added to bread and causes the children to remark , `` lillian , did you put nuts in the bread today ' ' ? ?	96.921715
the school raises enough poultry , pigs , and beef cattle for most of their needs .	49.37318
lots of cheese made from june grass milk is served .	26.346628
hens are kept on the range and roosters are kept with them for their fertility .	57.701107
organ meats such as beef and chicken liver , tongue and heart are planned once a week .	103.15359
also , salt water fish is on the table once a week .	49.717754
for deserts , puddings and pies are each served once a week .	32.24646
most other desserts are fruit in some form , fresh fruits once daily at least , sometimes at snack time .	90.981995
dried fruits are purchased from sources where they are neither sulphured nor sprayed .	43.596523
apples come from a farm in vermont where they are not sprayed .	51.403698
oranges and grapefruit are shipped from florida weekly from an organic farm .	77.69729
finding sources for these high quality foods is a problem .	22.054636
following a talk by mr . clark at the new york state natural food associates convention , a man from the audience offered to ship his unsprayed apples to the school from vermont .	90.073296
wheat-germ , brewer ' s yeast and ground kelp are used in bread and in dishes such as spaghetti sauce , meat loaves .	32.67584
miss colman hopes to find suitable shakers so that kelp can be available at the tables .	44.71591
raw wheat-germ is available on the breakfast table for the children to help themselves .	44.29604
very few fried foods are used and the use of salt and pepper is discouraged .	32.914623
pitchers of water merely appear on the tables .	1.9930253
the source is known so there is no necessity to remove insecticide residues .	45.379593
the cooking conserves a maximum of the vitamin c content of vegetables by methods which use very little water and cook in the shortest time possible .	233.66844
since mr . clark believes firmly that the chewing of hard foods helps develop healthy gums and teeth , raw vegetables and raw whole-wheat grains are handed out with fresh fruit and whole-wheat cookies at snack time in the afternoons .	70.89277
to solve the problem of the wheat grains spilling on the floor and getting underfoot , a ball of maple syrup boiled to candy consistency was invented to hold the grains .	37.07601
on their frequent hikes into the nearby mountains , the children carry whole grains to munch along the trail .	108.708885
they learn to like these so well that it isn ' t surprising to hear that one boy tried the oats he was feeding his horse at chore time .	65.31475
they tasted good to him , so he brought some to breakfast to eat in his cereal bowl with milk and honey .	112.91485
maple syrup is made by the children in the woods on the school grounds .	38.186535
this and raw sugar replace ordinary refined sugar on the tables and very little sugar is used in cooking .	58.194996
parents are asked in the bulletin to send packages of treats consisting of fruit and nuts , but no candy .	122.613914
mr . clark believes in a good full breakfast of fruit , hot cereal , milk , honey , whole-wheat toast with real butter and eggs .	43.86495
the heavy meal comes in the middle of the day .	9.345295
soup is often the important dish at supper .	3.5725205
homemade of meat , bones and vegetables , it is rich in dissolved minerals and vitamins .	75.29348
the school finds that the children are satisfied with smaller amounts of food since all of it is high in quality .	71.41265
the cost to feed one person is just under one dollar a day .	90.87507
even before he saw the necessity of growing better food and planning good nutrition , mr . clark felt the school had a good health program .	93.012726
rugged outdoor exercise for an hour and a half every day in all kinds of weather was the rule .	53.567596
a vigorous program existed in skiing , skating sports and overnight hiking .	22.480934
since the change to better nutrition , he feels he can report on improvements in health , though he considers the following statements observations and not scientific proof .	203.56662
visitors to the school ask what shampoo they use on the children ' s hair to bring out the sheen .	42.658
the ruddy complexion of the faces also brings comment .	330.80038
buffeted by swirling winds , the little green biplane struggled northward between the mountains beyond northfield gulf .	62.803318
wires whined as a cold november blast rocked the silver wings , but the engine roar was reassuring to the pilot bundled in the open cockpit .	30.381151
he peered ahead and grinned as the railroad tracks came into view again below .	155.00517
`` good old iron compass ' ' ! !	1.130532
a plume of smoke rose from a central vermont locomotive which idled behind a string of gravel cars , and little figures that were workmen labored to set the ruptured roadbed to rights .	77.18133
the girders of a shattered dog river bridge lay strewn for half a mile downstream .	56.711918
vermont ' s main railroad line was prostrate .	4.848486
and in the dark days after the great flood of 1927 -- the worst natural disaster in the state ' s history -- the little plane was its sole replacement in carrying the united states mails .	68.06258
rain of near cloudburst proportions had fallen for three full days and it was still raining on the morning of friday , november 4 , 1927 , when officials of the post office department ' s railway mail service realized that their distribution system for vermont had been almost totally destroyed overnight .	60.521275
clerks and postmasters shoveled muck out of their offices -- those who still had offices -- and wondered how to move the mail .	187.22787
the state ' s railroad system counted miles of broken bridges and missing rights-of-way it would obviously remain out of commission for weeks .	194.92278
and once medicine , food , clothing and shelter had been provided for the flood ' s victims , communications and the mail were the next top problems .	102.009285
from burlington , outgoing mail could be ferried across lake champlain to the railroad at port kent , n . y . .	18.984274
the nearest undisrupted end of track from boston was at concord , n . h . .	15.113111
when governor al smith offered new york national guard planes to fly the mail in and out of the state , it seemed a likely temporary solution , easing burlington ' s bottleneck and that at montpelier too .	81.844795
the question was `` where to land ' ' ? ?	3.2189713
there was no such thing as an airport in vermont .	37.433086
burlington aviator john j . burns suggested the parade ground southwest of fort ethan allen , and soon a dozen hastily-summoned national guard pilots were bringing their wide-winged `` jenny ' ' and dehaviland two-seaters to rest on the frozen sod of the military base .	50.864105
the only available field that could be used near flood-ravaged montpelier was on the towne farm off upper main street , a narrow hillside where takeoffs and landings could be safely made only under light wind conditions .	119.29125
over in barre the streets had been deep in swirling water , and bridges were crumpled and gone .	96.76231
anticipating delivery of medicines and yeast by plane , granite city citizens formed an airfield committee and with the aid of quarrymen and the 172nd infantry , vermont national guard , laid out runways on wilson flat , high on millstone hill .	95.47465
the `` barre aviation field ' ' was set to receive its first aircraft the sunday following the flood .	137.10757
though the makeshift airports were ready , the york state guard flyers proved unable to keep any kind of mail schedule .	106.935104
they had courage but their meager training consisted of weekend hops in good weather , in and out of established airports , and the increasingly cold weather soon raised hob with the water cooled engines of their world war 1 , planes .	87.75391
it seemed like a good time for officials to use a recently-passed law empowering the post office department to contract for the transport of first class mail by air .	110.532524
they had to act fast , for letters were clogging the terminals .	47.473278
down in concord , new hampshire , was a flier in the right place at the right time robert s . fogg , a native new englander , had been a world war 1 , flying instructor , barnstormer , and one of the original planners of the concord airport .	48.106377
tall , wiry , dark-haired bob fogg had already racked up one historical first in air mail history .	234.45015
piloting a curtiss navy mf flying boat off lake winnipesaukee in 1925 , he had inaugurated the original rural delivery air service in america .	71.46634
during the excitement following lindbergh ' s flight to paris earlier in 1927 , dare devil aviators overnight became legendary heroes .	96.76794
in concord , bob fogg was the most prominent new hampshire boy with wings .	245.52583
public-spirited backers staked him to a brand-new airplane , aimed at putting their city and state on the flying map .	146.75847
the ship was a waco biplane , one of the first two of its type to be fitted with the air cooled , 225/hp wright radial engine known as the whirlwind .	42.619297
a trim green and silver-painted craft only 22-1/2 feet long , the waco was entered to compete in the `` on-to-spokane ' ' air derby of 1927 .	46.753357
as a matter of fact , fogg and his plane didn ' t get beyond pennsylvania in the race -- an engine oil leak forced him down -- but the flying service and school he started subsequently were first steps in paying off his wry-faced backers .	203.79932
so with all this experience , bob fogg was a natural choice to receive the first emergency air mail star route contract .	119.35254
his work began just six days after the flood .	101.978935
by airline from concord to burlington is a distance of about 150 miles , counting a slight deviation for the stop at either barre or montpelier .	63.381847
the first few days bob fogg set his plane down on towne field back of the state house when the wind was right , and used wilson flat above barre when it wasn ' t .	112.952324
between the unsafe towne field and the long roundabout back road haul that was necessary to gain access to wilson flat , arrangements at the state capital were far from satisfactory .	167.3431
each time in , the unhappy pilot , pushing his luck , begged the postal officials that met him to find a safer landing place , preferably on the flat-topped hills across the winooski river .	69.900696
`` but fogg ' ' , they countered , `` we can ' t get over there .	20.196753
and besides you seem to make it all right here ' ' .	22.118694
it took a tragedy to bring things to a head .	202.11569
after a week of precarious uphill landings and downwind takeoffs , fogg one day looked down at the shattered yellow wreckage of an army plane strewn across snow-covered towne field .	80.49722
sent to montpelier by secretary herbert hoover , red cross aide reuben sleight had been killed , and his pilot , lt . franklin wolfe , badly injured .	47.9636
with the field a blur of white the unfortunate pilot had simply flown into the hillside .	207.86371
faced with this situation , postmaster charles f . mckenna of montpelier went with fogg on a burlington trip , and together they scouted the terrain on the heights of berlin .	100.14249
a long flat known as the st . john field seemed to answer their purpose , and since the winooski bridges were at last passable , they decided to use it .	85.65833
with a wary eye on the farmer ' s bull , fred somers of montpelier and mr . st . john marked the field with a red table cloth .	75.16484
as a wind direction indicator , they tied a cotton rag to a sapling .	27.990124
with these aids , and a pair of skiis substituting for wheels on the waco , bob fogg made the first landing on what is now part of the barre-montpelier airport on november 21 , 1927 .	83.23294
each trip saw the front cockpit filled higher with mail pouches .	52.360886
during the second week of operations , fogg received a telegram from the post office department , asking him to `` put on two airplanes and make two flights daily , plus one sunday trip ' ' .	75.38896
since fogg ' s was a one-man , one-plane flying service , this meant that he would have to do both trips , flying alone 600 miles a day , under sub-freezing temperature conditions .	101.33632
over the weeks , america ' s first star route air mail settled into a routine pattern despite the vagaries of weather and the lack of ground facilities and aids to navigation .	145.68153
each morning at five fogg crawled out of bed to bundle into flying togs over the furnace register of his home .	112.02386
always troubled by poor circulation in his feet , he experimented with various combinations of socks and shoes before finally adopting old-style felt farmer ' s boots with his sheepskin flying boots pulled over them .	75.240036
a sheep-lined leather flying suit , plus helmet , goggles and mittens completed his attire for the rigors of the open cockpit .	41.450394
the airman ' s stock answer to `` weren ' t you cold ' ' ? ?	16.625792
became `` yes , the first half hour is tough , but by then i ' m so numb i don ' t notice it ' ' ! !	37.64469
as daylight began to show through the frosty windows , fogg would place a call to william a . shaw at the u . s . weather station at northfield , vermont , for temperature and wind-velocity readings .	48.339207
shaw could also give the flyer a pretty good idea of area visibility by a visual check of the mountains to be seen from his station .	130.15173
`` ceilings ' ' were judged by comparison with known mountain heights and cloud positions .	390.56232
later on in the day fogg could get a better weather picture from the burlington weather bureau supervised by frank e . hartwell .	80.686485
out at the airport each morning , fogg ' s skilled mechanic caleb marston would have the waco warmed up and running in the drafty hangar .	39.38308
( he ' d get the engine oil flowing with an electric heater under a big canvas cover .	40.448753
) wishing to show that aviation was dependable and here to stay , bob fogg always made a point of taking off each morning on the dot of seven , disregarding rain , snow and sleet in true postal tradition .	107.13614
concord learned to set its clocks by the rackety bark of the whirlwind ' s exhaust overhead .	64.6227
sometimes the pilot had to turn back if fully blocked by fog , but 85% of his trips were completed .	192.10632
plane radios were not yet available , and once in the air , fogg flew his ship by compass , a good memory for landmarks as seen from above , and a capacity for dead reckoning and quick computation .	125.32205
often , threading through the overcast , he was forced to fly close to the ground by a low ceiling , skimming above the winooski or the white river along the line of the broken railroad .	79.84017
when driving rain or mist socked in one valley , fogg would chandelle up and over to reverse course and try another one , ranging from the ottauquechee up to danville in search of safe passage through the mountain passes .	198.66893
the dependable wright engine was never stopped on these trips .	52.249725
it ticked over smoothly , idling while fogg exchanged mails with the armed messenger from burlington at fort ethan allen , and one from montpelier and barre at the st . john field .	43.40546
sometimes , on a return trip , the aviator would `` go upstairs ' ' high over the clouds .	89.85511
there he ' d take a compass reading , figure his air speed , and deduce that in a certain number of minutes he ' d be over the broad meadows of the merrimack valley where it would be safe to let down through the overcast and see the ground before it hit him .	76.444466
bob fogg didn ' t have today ' s advantages of instrument flight and ground control approach systems .	478.27347
at the end of the calculated time he ' d nose the waco down through the cloud bank and hope to break through where some feature of the winter landscape would be recognizable .	133.22638
usually back in concord by noon , there was just time to get partially thawed out , refuel , and grab a bit of mrs . fogg ' s hot broth before starting the second trip .	47.192295
day after day fogg shuttled back and forth on his one-man air mail route , until the farmers in their snowy barnyards and the road repairmen came to recognize the stubby plane as their link with the rest of the country .	44.290558
at fort ethan allen the ever-present wind off lake champlain could readily flip a puny man-made thing like an airplane if the pilot miscalculated .	92.03151
once the soldiers from the barracks had to hold the ship from blowing away while fogg revved the engine and got the tail up .	66.30181
at a nod of his head they let go , turning to cup their ears against the icy slipstream .	89.204666
tracks in the snow showed the plane was airborne in less than a hundred feet .	30.669628
one afternoon during a cold , powdery snowstorm , fogg took off for concord from the st . john field .	23.879011
if so , are you saying , `` where did the last few years go ? ?	64.63198
how did i get to be sixty-five so fast ? ?	73.39431
what do i do now ' ' ? ?	1.0121918
yes , retirement seems to creep upon you suddenly .	104.88294
somehow we old-timers never figured we would ever retire .	40.303932
we always thought we would die with our boots on .	356.1148
out of the blue comes talk of pension plans .	14.480766
compulsory retirement at sixty-five looms on our horizon .	1.5668355
still , it seems in the far future .	26.720402
suddenly , one day , up it pops ! !	17.0156
sixty-five years and you ' ve had it ! !	15.959742
you ' ve thought about it before in a hazy sort of way .	56.893333
never seemed as if it could happen to you	210.75896
a great many retired people are the so-called white collar workers .	62.848976
if so , you are of the old school .	115.07636
you are conscientious , hard working , honest , accurate , a good penman , and a stickler for a job well done , with no loose ends .	62.994827
also you can spell , without consulting a dictionary for every other word .	149.77351
you never are late for work and seldom absent .	112.644455
actually , you can take no special credit for this .	26.094181
it is the way you were taught and your way of life .	39.55622
all this is standard equipment for a man of your day	101.06257
however , the last few years of your life , things seem to be changing .	129.05418
your way doesn ' t seem to be so darned important any more .	209.33173
you realize you are getting in the old fogy class .	69.84169
to put it bluntly , you are getting out-moded .	55.47572
now , looming on the horizon are such things as estimated totals , calculated risks and i . b . m . machines .	149.1997
this is followed by a boom in conferences .	7.2117343
when a plan burst its seams , hasty conferences supply the necessary patch , and life goes merrily on .	235.82848
you had your day and it was a good day .	19.273052
well , to get back to the problem of retirement .	35.83268
every retiring person has a different situation facing him .	17.316454
some have plenty of money -- some have very little money .	46.7024
some are blest with an abundance of good health -- some are in poor health and many are invalids .	76.644844
some have lovely homes -- some live in small apartments .	95.67408
some have beautiful gardens -- some not even a blade of grass .	59.108444
some have serenity of mind , the ability to accept what they have , and make the most of it ( a wonderful gift to have , believe me ) -- some see only darkness , the bitter side of everything .	112.62121
well , whatever you have , that ' s it ! !	11.620765
you ' ve got to learn to live with it .	16.984634
the question is `` how are you going to live with it ' ' ? ?	9.142089
you can sit back and moan and bewail your lot .	39.43332
but , if you do , your life will be just one thing -- unhappiness -- complete and unabridged .	75.60684
it seems to me , the first thing you ' ve got to do , to be happy , is to face up to your problems , no matter what they may be .	32.255165
make up your mind to pool your resources and get the most out of your remaining years of life .	69.90969
one thing , i am sure of , you must get an interest in life .	54.983093
many of you will say , `` well , what can i do ' ' ? ?	11.367
there are many , many things to do .	12.602567
find out what you like to do most and really give it a whirl .	134.99043
if you can ' t think of a thing to do , try something -- anything .	102.57578
i , frankly , can ' t draw a straight line .	91.89732
maybe you are not that gifted either , but how about puttering around with the old paints ? ?	76.87823
you may amaze yourself and acquire a real knack for it .	28.91425
anyway , i ' ll bet you have a lot of fun .	12.386558
does making your own clothes or even doll clothes , interest you ? ?	81.16219
do you love to run up a hem , sew on buttons , make neat buttonholes ? ?	35.12354
there is always a market for this line of work .	30.681198
some women can sit and sew , crochet , tat or knit by the hour , and look calm and relaxed and turn out beautiful work .	147.76648
where sewing is concerned , i ' m a total loss .	50.169758
when you see a needle in my hands you will know the family buttons have fallen off and i have to sew them back on , or get out the safety pins .	111.05513
then again , there ' s always that lovely old pastime of hooking or braiding rugs .	37.04929
not for me , but perhaps just the thing for you .	50.361732
how ' s about mosaic tile , ceramics or similar arts and crafts ? ?	51.08744
some people love to crack tile and it ' s amazing what beautiful designs they come up with as a result of their cracking good time .	96.65762
do you yearn to make cakes and pies , or special cookies and candies ? ?	22.446993
there is always an open market for this sort of delicacy , in spite of low calorie diets , cottage cheese and hands-off-all-sweets to the contrary .	32.348278
some people can carve most anything out of a piece of wood .	25.45256
some make beautiful chairs , cabinets , chests , doll houses , etc . .	14.871064
perhaps you couldn ' t do that but have you ever tried to see what you could do with a hunk of wood ? ?	30.481583
outside of cutting your fingers , maybe you would come up with nothing at all , but then again , you might turn out some dandy little gadgets .	76.83487
some women get a real thrill out of housework .	173.99858
they love to dust , scrub , polish , wax floors , move the furniture around from place to place , take down the curtains , put up new ones and have themselves a real ball .	105.521935
i can look at furniture in one spot year in and year out and really feel for sure that ' s where it belongs .	233.99133
perhaps you would like to become a writer .	5.4002385
this gives you a wide and varied choice .	13.495298
will it be short stories , fiction , nonfiction , biography , poetry , children ' s stories , or even a book if you are really ambitious ? ?	40.38733
ever since i was a child , i have always had a yen to try my hand at writing .	99.14698
if you do decide to write , you will soon become acquainted with rejection slips and dejection .	54.570625
just let the rejection slips fall where they may , and keep on plugging , and finally you will make the grade .	93.81646
few new writers have their first story accepted , so they tell me .	66.05422
but , it could happen , and it may happen to you .	66.68428
then there ' s always hobbies , collecting stamps , coins , timetables , salt and pepper shakers , elephants , dogs , dolls , shells , or shall we just say collecting anything your heart desires ? ?	65.57761
i can hear some of you folks protesting .	37.990143
you say , `` but it costs a lot of money to have a hobby .	23.713217
i haven ' t got that kind of money ' ' .	8.035583
it does cost a lot of money for most hobbies but there are hobbies that are for free .	123.14631
how about a rock collection , or a collection of leaves from different trees or shrubs and in different colors ? ?	72.537964
also , there ' s scrap books , collecting newspaper pictures and clippings , or any items of interest to you .	78.976524
it ' s getting interested in something that counts .	139.04907
as for me , i am holding in reserve two huge puzzles ( i love puzzles ) to put together when time hangs heavy on my hands .	309.48495
so far , the covers have never been off the boxes .	76.8344
i just don ' t have time to do half the things i want to do now .	67.074684
so in closing , fellow retired members , i advise you to make the most of each day , enjoy each one to the n ' th degree .	76.387146
keep occupied to the point you are not bored with life and you will truly find these final days and years of your lives to be sunshine sweet .	221.22968
to one and all -- good days ahead ! !	23.368887
what does it mean to be creative , a term we hear with increasing frequency these days ? ?	226.94202
when we turn to noah webster we find him helpful as usual .	142.31639
`` to be creative is to have the ability to cause to exist -- to produce where nothing was before -- to bring forth an original production of human intelligence or power ' ' .	112.139725
we are creative , it seems , when we produce something which has not previously existed .	176.03206
thus creativity may run all the way from making a cake , building a chicken coop , or producing a book , to founding a business , creating a league of nations or , developing a mature character .	111.32436
all living creatures from the lowest form of insect or animal life evidence the power of creativity , if it is only to reproduce a form like their own .	104.870834
while man shares this procreative function with all his predecessors in the evolutionary process , he is the only animal with a true non-instinctive and conscious creative ability .	56.923214
an animal , bird or insect creates either a burrow , or nest or hive in unending sameness according to specie .	51.05281
man ' s great superiority over these evolutionary forbears is in the development of his imagination .	18.279964
this gives him the power to form in his mind new image combinations of old memories , ideas and experiences and to project them outside of himself into his environment in new and ever-changing forms .	135.0666
it has been truly said that anything man can imagine he can produce or create by projecting this inner image into its counterpart in the objective world .	107.98213
in our own time we have seen the most fantastic imagery of a jules verne come into actuality .	45.539536
the vision of a lord tennyson expressed in a poem 100 years ago took visible form over london in the air blitzes of 1941 .	170.39516
in fact all of our civilized world is the resultant of man ' s projection of his imagination over the past 60 centuries or more .	61.646507
it is in this one aspect , at least , that man seems to be made in the image of his creator .	28.533274
not only can man project his imagination out into his environment in concrete forms , but even more importantly , he can turn it inward to help create new and better forms of himself .	96.8938
we recognize that young people through imaginative mind and body training can become athletes , acrobats , dancers , musicians and artists , developing many potentialities .	82.17249
we know that actors can learn to portray a wide variety of character roles .	39.691296
by this same combination of the will and the imagination , each one of us can learn to portray permanently the kind of character we would like to be .	81.96638
we must realize with prof . charles morris in his the open self that `` man is the being that can continually remake himself , the artisan that is himself the material for his own creation ' ' .	106.39672
so far in history man has been too greatly over-occupied with projecting things into his environment rather than first creating the sort of person who can make the highest use of the things he has created .	99.17965
is not the present world crisis a race between things we have created which can now destroy us and between populations of sufficient wisdom and character to forestall the tragedy .	134.56715
is it not the obligation of us older citizens to lend our weight to being creative on the character side and to hasten our own maturing process ? ?	88.12031
sir julian huxley in his book uniqueness of man makes the novel point that just as man is unique in being the only animal which requires a long period of infancy and childhood under family protection , so is he the only animal who has a long period after the decline of his procreativity .	108.81707
some recent writings assume that the ignorant young couples are a thing of the remote , victorian past	52.298058
that nowadays all honeymooners are thoroughly familiar with the best sex-manuals and know enough from talk with friends and personal experimentation to take all the anxiety and hazards out of the situation .	103.116806
perhaps -- but extensive discussions with contemporary practitioners , family doctors and gynecologists indicate that this is still an area of enormous ignorance .	67.83632
joking and talking may be freer and easier , but the important factual information is still lacking for far too many newly-married men and women .	85.8888
various factors in the setting can still be of great advantage in making the first intercourse a good rather than a bad memory for one or both .	74.05755
privacy must be highly assured both in time and place .	42.427315
that is , locking the room or stateroom door gives privacy of location , but it is equally important to be sure there is time enough for an utterly unhurried fulfillment .	72.37423
if the wedding party lasted late , and the travel schedule means there are only a few hours before resuming the trip or making an early start , the husband may forestall tensions and uncertainties by confiding to his bride that lying in each other ' s arms will be bliss enough for these few hours .	136.29643
the consummation should come at the next stopping place when they have a long private time ( day or night ) for that purpose .	157.48497
first intercourse for the bride brings with it the various problems connected with virginity and the hymen .	85.09063
one thing should be clear to both husband and wife -- neither pain nor profuse bleeding has to occur when the hymen is ruptured during the first sex act .	140.5931
ignorance on this point has caused a great deal of needless anxiety , misunderstanding and suspicion .	37.79083
the hymen is , in essence , a fragile membrane that more or less completely covers the entrance to the vagina in most female human beings who have not had sex relations .	106.357765
( hymen , in fact , is the greek word for membrane .	45.129665
often it is thin and fragile and gives way readily to the male organ at the first attempt at intercourse .	191.01833
as might be expected , girls in this situation bleed very little and perhaps not at all in the process of losing their virginity .	74.922615
it is also important to realize that many girls are born without a hymen or at most only a tiny trace of one	191.5649
so that the absence of the hymen is by no means positive proof that a girl has had sex relations .	62.257706
but there is a basis in fact for the exaggerations of the folk-lore beliefs .	63.67557
some hymens are so strongly developed that they cannot be torn without considerable pain to the girl and marked loss of blood .	92.56338
more rarely , the hymen is so sturdy that it does not yield to penetration .	35.232723
extreme cases are on record in which the doctor has had to use instruments to cut through the hymen to permit marital relations to be consummated .	82.28012
these cases , for all their rarity , are so dramatic that friends and relations repeat the story until the general population may get an entirely false notion of how often the hymen is a serious problem to newly-weds .	112.14828
in recent times , when sexual matters began to be discussed more scientifically and more openly , the emotional aspects of virginity received considerable attention .	97.734856
obviously , the bridal pair has many adjustments to make to their new situation .	63.78549
is it necessary to add to the other tensions the hazard of making the loving husband the one who brought pain to his bride ? ?	130.20084
gynecologists and marriage manuals began to advise that the bride should consult a physician before marriage .	94.08899
if he foresaw any problem because of the quality of the hymen , it was recommended that simple procedures be undertaken at once to incise the hymen or , preferably , to dilate it .	89.88481
as a natural outgrowth of this approach it was often suggested that the doctor should complete the preparation for painless intercourse by dilating the vagina .	51.11518
this recommendation was based on the fact that the hymen was not the only barrier to smooth consummation of the sex act .	42.65166
the vagina is an organ capable of remarkable contraction and dilation .	11.597739
this is obvious when it is remembered that , during childbirth , the vagina must dilate enough to permit the passage of the baby .	65.48099
the intricate system of muscles that manage the contraction and dilatation of the vagina are partly under voluntary control .	57.48298
but an instinctive reflex may work against the conscious intention of the woman .	84.85494
that is , when first penetration takes place , the pressure and pain signals may involuntarily cause all the vaginal muscles to contract in an effort to bar the intrusion and prevent further pain .	84.12068
the advantages of dilatation by the physician are both physical and psychological .	106.12697
since it is a purely professional situation , none of the pain is associated with love-making or the beloved .	157.46063
by using instruments of gradually increasing size , the vagina is gently , and with minimum pain at each stage , taught to yield to an object of the appropriate shape .	92.02097
in this process the vaginal muscles come under better conscious control by the girl .	168.89798
she learns how to relax them to accept -- instead of contracting them to repel -- the entering object .	171.14943
apart from the standard problem of controlling the vaginal muscles , other serious barriers may exist that need special gynecological treatment .	120.464905
it is far better to have such conditions treated in advance than to have them show up on the honeymoon where they can create a really serious situation .	141.21883
when no medical problems exist , the newly married couple generally prefer to cope with the adjustments of their new relationship by themselves .	83.11036
special information and guidance about the possible difficulties are still of great value .	44.47129
folk-lore , superstition and remembered passages from erotic literature can create physical and emotional problems if blindly taken as scientific facts and useful hints .	222.96544
the long , unhurried approach and the deliberate prolongation of fore-play work on several levels .	58.066685
under the excitement of caresses and sexual stimulation the vagina relaxes and dilates and the local moisture greatly increases , providing an excellent lubricant to help achieve an easier penetration .	60.26483
