extensive observations by physicians during vaginal examinations have established the fact that a single finger inserted along the anterior wall ( the top line of the vagina as the woman lies on her back ) may cause a great deal of distress in a virgin .	63.246986
but during the same examination , two fingers may be inserted along the posterior wall ( the bottom of the vagina in the same position ) without any pain	38.87812
and in fact without any difficulty if the pressure is kept downward at all times .	146.78918
these regional differences of sensitivity to pain may be of crucial significance during the earliest intercourse .	31.15763
the husband and wife should start with this anatomical information clearly in mind .	141.03592
they may then adjust their positions and movements to avoid too much pressure on the urethra and the anterior wall of the vagina	24.270235
at least until repeated intercourse has dilated it and pain is no longer a possible threat against the full pleasure of love-making .	74.005264
in fact , the technical procedure in medical examinations may be wisely adapted to his romantic purposes by the husband during the honeymoon .	69.936935
locker-room talk often stresses the idea that a man is doing the girl a favor if he is forceful and ruthless during the first penetration .	87.18463
the false reasoning is that a gradual advance prolongs the pain while a swift powerful act gets it over with and leaves the girl pleased with his virility and grateful for his decisiveness in settling the problem once and for all .	207.04482
ruthlessness at this time can be a very severe shock to the bride , both physically and psychologically .	77.06324
the insistent , forceful penetration may tear and inflame the vaginal walls as well as do excessive damage to the hymen .	58.50799
the pain and distress associated with the performance may easily give the wife a deep-seated dread of marital relations and cause her , unconsciously , to make the sex act unpleasant and difficult for both by exercising her vaginal muscles to complicate his penetration instead of relaxing them to facilitate it .	119.10625
serious attention must also be given to the husband ' s problems in the honeymoon situation .	60.981987
the necessity for keeping alert to his bride ' s hazards can act as an interference with the man ' s spontaneous desire .	61.433495
the emotional stimulation may be so great that he may experience a premature climax .	152.26202
this is a very common experience and should in no way discourage or dishearten either husband or wife .	134.17892
or the frequent need to check and discipline himself to the wisest pace of the consummation can put him off stride and make it impossible for him to be continuously ready for penetration over a long period .	110.85767
the signals to proceed may therefore come when he is momentarily not able to take advantage of them .	56.509514
the best course is to recover his physical excitement by a change of pace that makes him ardent again .	157.73965
this may require imagination and reminding himself that now he can be demanding and self-centered .	77.19163
he can take security from the fact that the progress he has made by his gentle approach will not be lost .	138.85912
now while he uses talk , caresses or requires caresses from her , his bride will sympathetically understand the situation and eagerly help him restore his physical situation so they can have the consummation they both so eagerly desire .	217.00389
the accumulated information on this point shows that first intercourse , even when it is achieved with minimum pain or difficulty , is seldom an overwhelming sexual experience to a woman .	119.96093
too many new things are happening for it to be a complete erotic fulfillment .	31.400253
only under rare circumstances would a bride experience an orgasm during her first intercourse .	102.72493
both man and wife should be aware of the fact that a lack of climax , and even the absence of the anticipated keen pleasure are not a sign that the wife may be cold or frigid .	62.793346
if the early approaches are wise , understanding and patient , the satisfactions of marital fulfillment will probably be discovered before the marriage is much older .	87.45853
writing in a large volume on the nude in painting and sculptures , titled the nude a study in ideal form , kenneth clark declares `` the human body , as a nucleus , is rich in associations .	88.7009
it is ourselves and arouses memories of all the things we wish to do with ourselves ' ' .	18.91292
perhaps this is a clue to the amazing variety and power of reactions , attitudes , and emotions precipitated by the nude form .	90.527
the wide divergence of reactions is clearly illustrated in the kinsey studies in human sexuality .	47.262344
differences were related to social , economic , and educational backgrounds .	30.974215
whereas persons of eighth grade education or less were more apt to avoid or be shocked by nudity , those educated beyond the eighth grade increasingly welcomed and approved nudity in sexual relations .	123.92067
such understanding helps to explain why one matron celebrating thirty-five years of married life could declare with some pride that her husband had `` never seen her entirely naked ' ' , while another woman , boasting an equal number of years of married life , is proud of having `` shared the nudist way of life -- the really free , natural nude life -- for most of that period ' ' .	86.86373
attempts at censorship always involve and reveal such complex and multiple individual reactions .	127.37415
the indignant crusader sees the nude or semi-nude human form as `` lewd and pornographic , a threat and danger ' ' to all the young , or good , or religious , or moral persons .	80.816444
the equally ardent proponent of freedom from any kind of censorship may find the nude human form the `` natural , honest , free expression of man ' s spirit and the epitome of beauty and inspiration ' ' .	70.73349
one is always a little surprised to bump into such individual distinctions when it is unexpected .	185.90201
i still recall the mild shock i experienced in reading material of an enthusiastic advocate of the `` clean , healthful , free way of natural life in nudism ' ' , who seemed to brave much misunderstanding and persecution in fine spirit .	98.998405
in tradition and in poetry , the marriage bed is a place of unity and harmony .	32.029324
the partners each bring to it unselfish love , and each takes away an equal share of pleasure and joy .	101.782684
at its most ecstatic moments , husband and wife are elevated far above worldly cares .	484.2718
but marriage experts say that such mutual contribution and mutual joy are seldom achieved .	163.29388
instead one partner or the other dominates the sexual relationship .	168.22556
in the past , it has been the husband who has been dominant and the wife passive .	73.2452
but today there are signs that these roles are being reversed .	20.19976
in a growing number of american homes , marriage counselors report , the wife is taking a commanding role in sexual relationships .	116.2429
it is she who decides the time , the place , the surroundings , and the frequency of the sexual act .	51.30094
it is she who says aye or nay to the intimate questions of sexual technique and mechanics -- not the husband .	131.2456
the whole act is tailored to her pleasure , and not to theirs .	38.20034
beyond a certain point , of course , no woman can be dominant -- nature has seen to that .	182.76549
but there is little doubt that in many marriages the wife is boss of the marital bed .	61.164143
of course , there remain many `` old-fashioned ' ' marriages in which the husband maintains his supremacy .	42.717762
yet even in these marriages , psychologists say , wives are asserting themselves more strongly .	88.33436
the meekest , most submissive wife of today is a tiger by her mother ' s or grandmother ' s standards .	27.469406
to many experts , this trend was inevitable .	5.362336
they consider it simply a sign of our times .	158.74269
our society has `` emancipated ' ' the woman , giving her new independence and new authority .	133.40718
it is only natural that she assert herself in the sexual role .	34.913986
`` the sexual relationship does not exist in a vacuum ' ' , declares dr . mary steichen calderone , medical director of the planned parenthood federation of america and author of the recent book , release from sexual tensions .	60.904835
`` it reflects what is going on in other areas of the marriage and in society itself .	79.19876
a world in which wives have taken a more active role is likely to produce sexual relationships in which wives are more self-assertive , too ' ' .	58.122753
yet many psychologists and marriage counselors agree that domination of the sex relationship by one partner or the other can be unhealthy and even dangerous .	75.28486
it can , in fact , wreck a marriage .	74.68998
when a husband is sexually selfish and heedless of his wife ' s desires , she is cheated of the fulfillment and pleasure nature intended for her .	59.01655
and she begins to regard him as savage , bestial and unworthy .	7.1543345
on the other hand , wifely supremacy demeans the husband , saps his self-respect , and robs him of his masculinity .	18.270632
he is a target of ridicule to his wife , and often -- since private affairs rarely remain private -- to the outside world as well .	158.7495
`` a marriage can survive almost any kind of stress except an open and direct challenge to the husband ' s maleness ' ' , declares dr . calderone .	53.169605
this opinion is supported by one of the nation ' s leading psychiatrists , dr . maurice e . linden , director of the mental health division of the philadelphia department of public health .	20.685783
`` when the roles of husband and wife are reversed , so that the wife becomes leader and the husband follower ' ' , dr . linden says , `` the effects on their whole relationship , sexual and otherwise , can be disastrous ' ' .	56.26202
in one extreme case , cited by a pittsburgh psychologist , an office worker ' s wife refused to have sexual relations with her husband unless he bought her the luxuries she demanded .	63.125656
to win her favors , her husband first took an additional job , then desperately began to embezzle from his employer .	136.517
caught at last , he was sentenced to prison .	31.599106
while he was in custody his wife divorced him .	34.220085
more typical is the case of a suburban long island housewife described by a marriage counselor .	97.27572
this woman repeatedly complained she was `` too tired ' ' for marital relations .	15.098599
to please her , her husband assumed some of the domestic chores .	26.527008
finally , he was cooking , washing dishes , bathing the children , and even ironing -- and still his wife refused to have relations as often as he desired them .	59.834034
one wife , described by a new york psychologist , so dominated her husband that she actually placed their sexual relationship on a schedule , writing it down right between the weekly pta meetings and the thursday-night neighborhood card parties .	205.58118
after every money argument , she rebuffed her husband ' s overtures until the matter was settled in her favor .	31.690742
experts say the partners in marriages like these can almost be typed .	178.27353
the wife is likely to be young , sophisticated , smart as a whip -- often a girl who has sacrificed a promising career for marriage .	69.68933
she knows the power of the sex urge and how to use it to manipulate her husband .	47.208817
the husband is usually a well-educated professional , preoccupied with his job -- often an organization man whose motto for getting ahead is `` don ' t rock the boat ' ' .	91.2999
sometimes this leads to his becoming demandingly dominant in marriage .	29.576103
hemmed in on the job and unable to assert himself , he uses the sex act so he can be supreme in at least one area .	87.85808
more often , though , he is so accustomed to submitting to authority on the job without argument that he lives by the same rule at home .	137.08392
some psychologists , in fact , suggest that career-bound husbands often are more to blame for topsy-turvy marriages than their wives .	133.45758
the wife ' s attempt at control , these psychologists contend , is sometimes merely a pathetic effort to compel her husband to pay as much attention to her as he does to his job .	61.014297
naturally no woman can ever completely monopolize the sexual initiative .	84.76836
unless her husband also desires sex , the act cannot be consummated .	62.857006
generally , however , in such marriages as those cited , the husband is at his wife ' s mercy .	50.07703
`` the pattern ' ' , says dr . morton schillinger , psychologist at new york ' s lincoln institute for psychotherapy , `` is for the husband to hover about anxiously and eagerly , virtually trembling in his hope that she will flash him the signal that tonight is the night ' ' .	73.48295
no one seriously contends , of course , that the domineering wife is , sexually speaking , a new character in our world .	62.40995
after all , the henpecked husband with his shrewish wife is a comic figure of long standing , in literature and on the stage , as dr . schillinger points out .	81.12509
there is no evidence that these milquetoasts became suddenly emboldened when they crossed the threshhold of the master bedroom .	72.33062
furthermore , dr . calderone says , a certain number of docile , retiring men always have been around .	106.516426
they aren ' t `` frigid ' ' and they aren ' t homosexual	19.86598
they ' re just restrained in all of life .	31.278938
one such man once confided to dr . theodor reik , new york psychiatrist , that he preferred to have his wife the sexual aggressor .	33.771606
asked why , he replied primly `` because that ' s no activity for a gentleman ' ' .	32.443295
but such cases were , in the past , unusual .	272.36133
society here and abroad has been built around the dominating male -- even the bible appears to endorse the concept .	99.58193
family survival on our own western frontier , for example , could quite literally depend on a man ' s strength and ability to bring home the bacon	78.52976
and the dependent wife seldom questioned his judgment about anything , including the marriage bed .	70.77712
this carried over into the more urbanized late 19th and early 20th centuries , when the man ruled the roost in the best bull-roaring life with father manner .	54.29262
in those days , a wife had mighty few rights in the domestic sphere and even fewer in the sexual sphere .	120.42241
`` grandma wasn ' t expected to like it ' ' , dr . marion hilliard , the late toronto gynecologist , once summed up the attitude of the ' 90s .	27.287474
wives of the period shamefacedly thought of themselves as `` used ' ' by their husbands -- and , history indicates , they often quite literally were .	118.81649
when did women begin to assert themselves sexually ? ?	12.454463
some date it from woman suffrage , others from when women first began to challenge men in the marketplace , still others from the era of the emancipated flapper and bathtub gin .	151.06161
virtually everyone agrees , however , that the trend toward female sexual aggressiveness was tremendously accelerated with the postwar rush to the suburbs .	118.90809
left alone while her husband was miles away in the city , the modern wife assumed more and more duties normally reserved for the male .	122.49734
circumstances gave her almost undisputed sway over child-rearing , money-handling and home maintenance .	165.08304
she found she could cope with all kinds of problems for which she was once considered too helpless .	70.48972
she liked this taste of authority and independence , and , with darkness , was not likely to give it up .	38.384327
`` very few wives ' ' , says dr . calderone , `` who balance the checkbook , fix the car , choose where the family will live and deal with the tradesmen , are suddenly going to become submissive where sex is concerned .	59.954617
a woman who dominates other family affairs will dominate the sexual relationship as well ' ' .	51.036076
and an additional factor was helping to make women more sexually self-assertive -- the comparatively recent discovery of the true depths of female desire and response .	107.746925
marriage manuals and women ' s magazine articles began to stress the importance of the female climax .	50.126965
they began to describe in detail the woman ' s capacity for response .	25.817574
in fact , the noted psychologist and sex researcher , dr . albert ellis , has declared flatly that women are `` sexually superior ' ' to men .	25.329483
according to dr . ellis , the average 20-year-old american woman is capable of far greater sexual arousal than her partner .	86.96947
not surprisingly , dr . ellis says , some recently enlightened wives are out to claim these capabilities .	147.52435
yet , paradoxically , according to dr . maurice linden , many wives despise their husbands for not standing up to them .	82.79933
an aggressive woman wants a man to demand , not knuckle under .	239.74527
`` when the husband becomes passive in the face of his wife ' s aggressiveness ' ' , dr . linden says , `` the wife , in turn , finds him inadequate .	30.829103
often she fails to gain sexual satisfaction ' ' .	1.3448248
one such wife , dr . linden says , became disgusted with her weak husband and flurried through a series of extramarital affairs in the hope of finding a stronger man .	70.944405
but her personality was such that each affair lasted only until that lover , too , had been conquered and reduced to passivity .	117.189804
then the wife bed-hopped to the next on the list .	17.358435
in some cases , however , domination of the sex act by one partner can be temporary , triggered by a passing but urgent emotional need .	97.90701
thus a man who is butting a stone wall at the office may become unusually aggressive in bed -- the one place he can still be champion .	131.81717
if his on-the-job problems work out , he may return to his old pattern .	93.888336
sometimes a burst of aggressiveness will sweep over a man -- or his wife -- because he or she feels age creeping up .	96.466034
on the other hand , a husband who always has been vigorous and assertive may suddenly become passive -- asking , psychologists say , for reassurance that his wife still finds him desirable .	148.83873
or a wife may make sudden demands that she be courted , flattered or coaxed , simply because she needs her ego lifted .	133.34473
in any case , dr . calderone remarks , such problems are a couple ' s own affair , and can ' t always be measured by a general yardstick .	53.12095
`` as long as the couple is in agreement in their approach to sex , it makes little difference if one or the other dominates ' ' , dr . calderone declares .	59.08153
`` the important point is that both be satisfied with the adjustment ' ' .	39.66736
other experts say , however , that if sexual domination by one or the other partner exists for longer than a brief period , it is likely to shake the marriage .	111.13141
and just as domination today often begins with the wife , so the cure generally must lie with the husband .	162.35675
`` to get a marriage back where it belongs ' ' , comments dr . schillinger of the lincoln institute , `` the husband must take some very basic steps .	49.136616
he must begin , paradoxically , by becoming more selfish .	69.34058
he must become more expressive of his own desires , more demanding and less ' understanding ' ' ' .	87.31369
too many husbands , dr . schillinger continues , worry about `` how well they ' re doing ' ' , and fear that their success depends on some trick or technique of sexual play .	82.54609
she gave herself a title , lady diana harrington .	9.298321

houston police gave her a third , less flamboyant , title , prostitute .	55.618088
and houston police have the final say in the matter since she died there on september 20 , 1960 , `` diane harris graham , 30 , d . o . a . , circumstances -- unusual ' ' .	86.943756
early in her life she had discovered that where there were men , there was money , and with the two came luxury and liquor .	146.27032
she was still in the play for pay business when she died , a top trollop who had given the world ' s oldest profession one of its rare flashes of glamour .	64.952515
she never hid the fact that she liked to play .	28.644552
her neighbors in the expensive houston apartment building told reporters that the ash-blonde beauty had talked at times about her past as `` the golden girl of the mickey jelke trial ' ' .	81.67451
it was the trial of oleomargarine heir minot ( mickey ) jelke for compulsory prostitution in new york that put the spotlight on the international play-girl .	78.85701
( jelke later served 21 months when he was found guilty of masterminding a ring of high-priced call girls .	54.01987

`` at deauville she met an egyptian by the name of pulley bey .	10.669233

last may , they said , she admitted being a prostitute .	61.443134
the next time the police saw her she was dead .	13.44176
it was september 20 , 1960 , in a lavishly decorated apartment littered with liquor bottles .	20.494888

mcclellan , who had once lost his medical license temporarily on a charge of drug addiction , was with her when she died .	66.923

i work for one of the biggest chains of retail carpet houses in the east .	45.30073
we cater mostly to nice people in the $5-8 , 000 annual income bracket and we run a string of snazzy , neon-lit , chromium-plated suburban stores .	60.276157

they depend on my supposedly expert knowledge of a trade of which they themselves know little .	148.6894
franklin d . lee proved a man of prompt action when mrs . claire shaefer , accompanied by a friend , visited him in bakersfield , california , several months ago as a prospective patient .	54.053288
`` doctor ' ' lee asked her to lie down on a bed and remove her shoes .	109.70416
then , by squeezing her foot three times , he came up -- presto -- with a different diagnosis with each squeeze .	73.69566
she had -- he informed her -- kidney trouble , liver trouble , and a severe female disorder .	81.21741
( he explained that he could diagnose these ailments from squeezing her foot because all of the nervous system was connected to it .	103.07128

as he applied the applicator extending from the machine -- which consisted of seven differently colored neon tubes superimposed on a rectangular base -- to the supposedly diseased portions of mrs . shaefer ' s body , lee kept up a steady stream of pseudo-scientific mumbo-jumbo .	49.99552
yes , the ozone from his machine would cure practically everything , he assured her .	119.97895

the human body -- he pointed out , for example -- required 33 units of blue light .	174.68425

continuing glibly in this vein , he paused to comfort her	86.764885

why , i once used this machine to cure a woman with 97 pounds of cancer in her body ' ' .	27.152155

he then sold her minerals to cure her kidney ailment , a can of sage `` to make her look like a girl again ' ' , and an application of plain mud to take her wrinkles away .	90.75724
lee renewed his pressure on mrs . shaefer to buy his machine when she visited him the next day .	73.05834
after another treatment with the machine , he told her that `` her entire body was shot through with tumors and cysts ' ' .	50.913486
he then sold her some capsules that he asserted would take care of the tumors and cysts until she could collect the money for buying his machine .	134.58421
when she submitted to his treatment with the capsules , mrs . shaefer felt intense pain .	49.785034
leaving lee ' s office , mrs . shaefer hurried over to her family physician , who treated her for burned tissue .	89.52793
for several days , she was ill as a result of lee ' s treatment .	16.709488
mrs . shaefer never got around to joining the thousand or so people who paid lee some $30 , 000 for his ozone machines .	135.68747
for mrs . shaefer -- who had been given a clean bill of health by her own physician at the time she visited lee -- and her friend were agents for the california pure food and drug inspection bureau .	129.32425
and she felt amply rewarded for her suffering when the evidence of lee ' s quack shenanigans , gathered by the tape recorder under her friend ' s clothing , proved adequate in court for convicting franklin d . lee .	83.68802
the charge violation of the california medical practices act by practicing medicine without a license and selling misbranded drugs .	63.553295
the sentence 360 days ' confinement in the county jail .	25.5575
rather , it is typical of the thousands of quacks who use phony therapeutic devices to fatten themselves on the miseries of hundreds of thousands of americans by robbing them of millions of dollars and luring them away from legitimate , ethical medical treatment of serious diseases .	47.744835
the machine quack makes his rube goldberg devices out of odds and ends of metals , wires , and radio parts .	112.88217
with these gadgets -- impressive to the gullible because of their flashing light bulbs , ticks , and buzzes -- he then carries out a vicious medical con game , capitalizing on people ' s respect for the electrical and atomic wonders of our scientific age .	87.67164
he milks the latest scientific advances , translating them into his own special buck rogers vocabulary to huckster his fake machines as a cure-all for everything from hay fever to sexual impotence and cancer .	80.53028
the gadget faker operates or sells his phony machines for $5 to $10 , 000 -- anything the traffic will bear .	82.90909
he may call himself a anaprapath , a physiotherapist , an electrotherapist , a naturopath , a sanipractor , a medical cultist , a masseur , a `` doctor ' ' -- or what have you .	33.759933
not only do these quacks assume impressive titles , but represent themselves as being associated with various scientific or impressive foundations -- foundations which often have little more than a letterhead existence .	95.82913
the medical device pirate of today , of course , is a far more sophisticated operator than his predecessor of yesteryear -- the gallus-snapping hawker of snake oil and other patent medicines .	61.310642
his plunder is therefore far higher -- running into hundreds of millions .	36.776703
according to the food and drug administration ( fda ) , `` doctor ' ' ghadiali , dr . albert abrams and his clique , and dr . wilhelm reich -- to name three notorious device quacks -- succeeded , respectively , in distributing 10 , 000 , 5000 , and 2000 fake health machines .	53.8524
authorities believe that many of the doctor frauds using these false health gadgets are still in business .	139.6702
look at the sums paid by two device quack victims in cleveland .	26.914316
sarah gross , a dress shop proprietor , paid $1020 to a masseur , and mr . a . , a laborer , paid $4200 to a chiropractor for treatment with two fake health machines -- the `` radioclast ' ' and the `` diagnometer ' ' .	28.797537
multiply these figures by the millions of people known to be conned by medical pirates annually .	119.37144
you will come up with a frightening total .	11.912232
that ' s why the fda , the american medical association ( ama ) , and the national better business bureau ( bbb ) have estimated the toll of mechanical quackery to be a substantial portion of the $610 million or so paid to medical charlatans annually .	46.002678
the postmaster general recently reported that mail order frauds -- among which fake therapeutic devices figure prominently -- are at the highest level in history .	81.66703
similarly , the american cancer society ( acs ) , the arthritis and rheumatism foundation , and the bbb have each stated lately that medical quackery is at a new high .	63.276066
for example , the bbb has reported it was receiving four times as many inquiries about quack devices and 10 times as many complaints compared with two years ago .	130.53224
authorities hesitate to quote exact figures , however , believing that any sum they come up with is only a surface manifestation -- turned up by their inevitably limited policing -- of the real loot of the medical racketeer .	165.99133
in this sense , authorities believe that all estimates of phony device quackery are conservative .	310.03192
the economic toll that the device quack extracts is important , of course .	23.112795
but it is our health -- more precious than all the money in the world -- that these modern witch doctors with their fake therapeutic gadgets are gambling away .	77.54802
by preying on the sick , by playing callously on the hopes of the desperate , by causing the sufferer to delay proper medical care , these medical ghouls create pain and misery by their very activity .	151.24303
typically , sarah gross and mr . a both lost more than their money as the result of their experiences with their cleveland quacks .	135.64044
sarah gross found that the treatments given her for a nervous ailment by the masseur were not helping her .	87.10605
as a result , she consulted medical authorities and learned that the devices her quack `` doctor ' ' was using were phony .	99.833725
she suffered a nervous breakdown and had to be institutionalized .	23.215036
mr . a . , her fellow townsman , also experienced a nervous breakdown just as soon as he discovered that he had been bilked of his life savings by the limited practitioner who had been treating his wife -- a woman suffering from an incurable disease , multiple sclerosis -- and himself .	69.29451
mr . a has recovered , but he is , justifiably , a bitter man .	71.11284
`` that ' s a lot of hard-earned money to lose ' ' , he says today .	21.1167
`` neither me nor my wife were helped by that chiropractor ' s treatments ' ' .	21.584734
and there was the case of tom hepker , a machinist , who was referred by a friend to a health machine quack who treated him with a so-called diagnostic machine for what doctor fraud said was a system full of arsenic and strychnine .	82.50863
after his pains got worse , tom decided to see a real doctor , from whom he learned he was suffering from cancer of the lung .	56.217026
yes , tom caught it in time to stay alive .	172.25038
but he ' s a welfare case now -- a human wreck -- thanks to this modern witch doctor .	93.54852
but the machine quack can cause far more than just suffering .	57.311756
in such diseases as cancer , tuberculosis , and heart disease , early diagnosis and treatment are so vital that the waste of time by the patient with doctor fraud ' s cure-all gadget can prove fatal .	70.86252
moreover , the diabetic patient who relies on cure by the quack device and therefore cuts off his insulin intake can be committing suicide .	104.78442
in chicago , some time ago , mr . h . , age 27 , a diabetic since he was six , stopped using insulin because he had bought a `` magic spike ' ' -- a glass tube about the size of a pencil filled with barium chloride worth a small fraction of a cent -- sold by the vrilium company of chicago for $306 as a cure-all .	60.593086
`` hang this around your neck or attach it to other parts of your anatomy , and its rays will cure any disease you have ' ' , said the company .	60.83912
mr . h . is dead today because he followed this advice .	216.87624
doris hull , suffering from tuberculosis , was taken by her husband to see otis g . carroll , a sanipractor -- a licensed drugless healer -- in spokane .	47.84604
carroll diagnosed mrs . hull by taking a drop of blood from her ear and putting it on his `` radionic ' ' machine and twirling some knobs ( fee $50 ) .	62.463593
his prescription hot and cold compresses to increase her absorption of water .	55.477917
although she weighed only 108 pounds when she visited him , carroll permitted her to go on a 10-day fast in which she took nothing but water .	101.1356
inevitably , mrs . hull died of starvation and tuberculosis , weighing 60 pounds .	24.904425
moreover , her husband and child contracted t . b . from her .	36.31912
( small wonder a spokane jury awarded the husband $35 , 823 for his wife ' s death .	27.178297
in california , a few years ago , a ghoul by the name of h . f . bell sold electric blankets as a cure for cancer .	58.57655
he did this by the charming practice of buying up used electric blankets for $5 to $10 from survivors of patients who had died , reconditioning them , and selling them at $185 each .	87.399956
when authorities convicted him of practicing medicine without a license ( he got off with a suspended sentence of three years because of his advanced age of 77 ) , one of his victims was not around to testify he was dead of cancer .	74.709175
`` unfortunately ' ' , says chief postal inspector david h . stephens , who has prosecuted many device quacks , `` the ghouls who trade on the hopes of the desperately ill often cannot be successfully prosecuted because the patients who are the chief witnesses die before the case is called up in court ' ' .	86.97216
that ' s where device quackery can lead .	7.783718
the evidence shows that fake therapeutic machines , substituted for valid medical cures , have hastened the deaths of thousands .	74.71677
who are the victims of the device quacks ? ?	11.722412
authorities say that oldsters are a prime target .	3.4232874
says wallace f . jannsen , director of the fda ' s division of public information `` quacks are apt to direct their appeal directly to older people , or to sufferers from chronic ailments such as arthritis , rheumatism , diabetes , and cancer .	51.9743
people who have not been able to get relief from regular medical doctors are especially apt to be taken in by quacks ' ' .	108.019066
the victims of the quacks are frequently poor people , like mr . a . , who scrape up their life savings to offer as a sacrifice to doctor fraud ' s avarice .	64.06467
they are often ignorant as well as underprivileged .	3.856462
ten-year-old richard stewart had been irritable and quarrelsome for almost a year .	32.42478
his grades had gone steadily downhill , and he had stopped bringing friends and classmates home from school .	129.98409
mr . and mrs . stewart were puzzled and concerned .	69.25111
then one day dick ' s classmate jimmy , from next door , let the cat out of the bag .	68.87384
the youngsters in the boys ' class had nicknamed dick `` bugs bunny ' ' because his teeth protruded .	30.679787
when richard ' s parents told him they wanted to take him to an orthodontist -- a dentist who specializes in realigning teeth and jaws -- their young son was interested .	74.54591
during the year that followed , dick co-operated whole-heartedly with the dentist and was delighted with the final result achieved -- an upper row of strong straight teeth that completely changed his facial appearance .	141.29906
`` the majority of children in the united states could benefit by some form of orthodontic treatment ' ' , says dr . allan g . brodie , professor and head of the department of orthodontics at the university of illinois and a nationally recognized authority in his field .	26.11288
what do parents need to know about those `` years of the braces ' ' in order not to waste a child ' s time and their money ? ?	77.59847
how can they tell whether a child needs orthodontic treatment ? ?	42.384945
why and when should tooth-straightening be undertaken ? ?	1.0287672
occlusion is the dentist ' s expression for the way teeth fit together when the jaws are closed .	126.986885
malocclusion , or a bad fit , is what parents need to look out for .	170.2876
one main type of malocclusion is characterized by a receding chin and protruding upper front teeth .	51.529163
a chin too prominent in relation to the rest of the face , a thrusting forward of the lower front teeth , an overdeveloped lower jawbone , and an underdeveloped upper jaw indicate the opposite type of malocclusion .	50.899334
these two basic malformations have , of course , many variations .	44.126823
a child probably requires some form of treatment if he has any of the following conditions	92.290344
a noticeable protrusion of the upper or lower jaw .	4.4576874
crooked , overlapping , twisted , or widely spaced teeth .	59.555737
front teeth not meeting when the back teeth close .	163.20732
upper teeth completely covering the lowers when the back teeth close .	68.15696
the eyeteeth ( third from the middle on top , counting each front tooth as the first ) beginning to protrude like fangs .	134.74823
second teeth that have come in before the first ones have fallen out , making a double row .	85.16894
contrary to the thinking of 30 to 40 years ago , when all malocclusion was blamed on some unfortunate habit , recent studies show that most tooth irregularity has at least its beginning in hereditary predisposition .	68.13401
however , this does not mean that a child ' s teeth or jaws must necessarily resemble those of someone in his family .	51.561546
tooth deformity may be the result of excessive thumb- or finger-sucking , tongue-thrusting , or lip-sucking -- but it ' s important to remember that there ' s a difference between normal and excessive sucking habits .	28.944757
it ' s perfectly normal for babies to suck their thumbs , and no mother need worry if a child continues this habit until he is two or three years old .	111.543015
occasional sucking up to the fifth year may not affect a youngster ' s teeth	76.890656
but after that , if thumb-sucking pressure is frequent , it will have an effect .	67.35931
malocclusion can also result if baby teeth are lost too soon or retained too long .	140.13635
if a child loses a molar at the age of two , the adjoining teeth may shift toward the empty space , thus narrowing the place intended for the permanent ones and producing a jumble .	106.72064
if baby teeth are retained too long , the incoming second teeth may be prevented from emerging at the normal time or may have to erupt in the wrong place .	66.965485
every orthodontist sees children who are embarrassed by their malformed teeth .	83.121414
some such youngsters rarely smile , or they try to speak with the mouth closed .	69.115
in certain cases , as in dick stewart ' s , a child ' s personality is affected .	27.677996
yet from the dentist ' s point of view , bad-fitting teeth should be corrected for physical reasons .	55.32799
bad alignment may result in early loss of teeth through a breakdown of the bony structure that supports their roots .	82.00121
this serious condition , popularly known as pyorrhea , is one of the chief causes of tooth loss in adults .	73.05618
then , too , misplaced or jammed-together teeth are prone to trapping food particles , increasing the likelihood of rapid decay .	101.262276
`` for these and other reasons ' ' , says dr . brodie , `` orthodontics can prolong the life of teeth ' ' .	12.318677
the failure of teeth to fit together when closed interferes with normal chewing , so that a child may swallow food whole and put a burden on his digestive system .	102.36592
because of these chewing troubles , a child may avoid certain foods he needs for adequate nutrition .	150.93842
badly placed teeth can also cause such a speech handicap as lisping .	94.09509
`` most orthodontic work is done on children between the ages of 10 and 14 , though there have been patients as young as two and as old as 55 ' ' , says dr . brodie .	48.56712
in the period from 10 to 14 the permanent set of teeth is usually completed , yet the continuing growth of bony tissue makes moving badly placed teeth comparatively easy .	186.02252
orthodontic work is possible because teeth are held firmly but not rigidly , by a system of peridontal membrane with an involved nerve network , to the bone in the jaw	100.02495
they are not anchored directly to the bone .	3.182165
abnormal pressure , applied over a period of time , produces a change in the bony deposit , so a tooth functions normally in the new position into which it has been guided .	82.959785
what can 10-year-old susan expect when she enters the orthodontist ' s office ? ?	10.175897
on her first visit the orthodontist will take x-rays , photographs , tooth measurements , and `` tooth prints ' ' -- an impression of the mouth that permits him to study her teeth and jaws .	70.09254
if he decides to proceed , he will custom-make for susie an appliance consisting of bands , plastic plates , fine wires , and tiny springs .	137.06613
this appliance will exert a gentle and continuous or intermittent pressure on the bone .	32.632656
as the tooth moves , bone cells on the pressure side of it will dissolve , and new ones will form on the side from which the tooth has moved .	111.436584
this must be done at the rate at which new bony tissue grows , and no faster .	184.90804
`` if teeth are moved too rapidly , serious injury can be done to their roots as well as to the surrounding bone holding them in place ' ' , explains dr . brodie .	92.36871
`` moving one or two teeth can affect the whole system , and an ill-conceived plan of treatment can disrupt the growth pattern of a child ' s face ' ' .	46.529484
during the first few days of wearing the appliance and immediately following each adjustment , susan may have a slight discomfort or soreness , but after a short time this will disappear .	112.373055
parents are often concerned that orthodontic appliances may cause teeth to decay .	150.23816
when in place , a well-cemented band actually protects the part of the tooth that is covered .	40.8136
next susie will enter the treatment stage and visit the orthodontist once or twice a month , depending on the severity of her condition .	74.45547
during these visits the dentist will adjust the braces to increase the pressure on her teeth .	63.725563
susie ' s teeth have now been guided into a desirable new position .	39.303627
but because teeth sometimes may drift back to their original position , a retaining appliance is used to lock them in place .	44.61083
usually this is a thin band of wire attached to the molars and stretching across the teeth .	38.206688
susie may wear this only at night or for a few hours during the day .	17.414068
then comes the time when the last wire is removed and susie walks out a healthier and more attractive girl than when she first went to the orthodontist .	73.388466
straightening one tooth that has come in wrong may take only a few months .	64.80201
aligning all the teeth may take a year or more .	16.884882
an added complication such as a malformed jaw may take two or three years to correct .	81.981346
the charge for a complete full-banded job differs in various parts of the country .	16.093473
work that might cost $500 to $750 in the south could cost $750 to $1 , 200 in new york city or chicago .	64.256065
an average national figure for two to three years of treatment would be $650 to $1 , 000 .	55.01619
`` factors in the cost of treatment are the length of time involved and the skill and education of the practitioner ' ' , says dr . brodie .	39.97466
to become an orthodontist , a man must first be licensed by his state as a dentist , then he must spend at least two years in additional training to acquire a license as a specialist .	88.250496
`` costs may seem high , but they used to be even higher ' ' , says dr . brodie .	30.450775
`` fees are about half to a third of what they were 25 years ago ' ' .	28.190315
people today are aware of the value of orthodontics , and as a result there are more practitioners in the field .	39.905136
most orthodontists require an initial payment to cover the cost of diagnostic materials and construction of the appliances , but usually the remainder of the cost may be spread over a period of months or years .	33.56519
in many cities in the united states clinics associated with dental schools will take patients at a nominal fee .	118.84567
some municipal agencies will pay for orthodontic treatment for children of needy parents .	67.04738
growth studies have been carried on consistently by orthodontists .	25.510088
dr . brodie has 30-year records of head growth , started 20 minutes after children ' s births .	115.13267
`` in the past anyone who said that 90% of all malocclusion is hereditary was scoffed at	160.9596
now we know that family characteristics do affect tooth formation to a large extent ' ' , he says .	30.276476
`` fortunately through our growth studies we have been able to see what nature does , and that helps us know what we can do ' ' .	22.837517
this knowledge both modifies and dictates diagnosis and treatment .	59.46215
for example , a boy may inherit a small jaw from one ancestor and large teeth from another .	113.67452
in the past an orthodontist might have tried , over four or five years , to straighten and fit the boy ' s large teeth into a jaw that , despite some growth , would never accommodate them .	127.42008
in other cases , in view of present-day knowledge of head growth , orthodontists will recommend waiting four or five years before treatment .	325.0199
the child is kept on call , and the orthodontist watches the growth .	86.29147
`` nature often takes care of the problem ' ' , says dr . brodie .	5.1056833
`` a child with a certain type of head and teeth will outgrow tooth deformity ' ' .	66.8903
that is why dr . brodie asks parents not to insist , against their dentist ' s advice , that their child have orthodontic work done too early .	94.76844
`` both because of our culture ' s stress on beauty and our improved economic conditions , some parents demand that the dentist try to correct a problem before it is wise to do so .	85.003044
let the orthodontist decide the proper time to start treatment ' ' , he urges .	54.608692
superior new material for orthodontic work is another result of research .	53.64413
plastics are easier to handle than the vulcanized rubber formerly used , and they save time and money .	89.270706
plaster of paris , once utilized in making impressions of teeth , has been replaced by alginates ( gelatin-like material ) that work quickly and accurately and with least discomfort to a child .	96.22672
as a rule , the earlier general dental treatment is started , the less expensive and more satisfactory it is likely to be .	62.508175
`` after your child ' s baby teeth are all in -- usually at the age of two and one half to three -- it ' s time for that first dental appointment ' ' , dr . brodie advises .	56.97693
`` then see that your youngster has a routine checkup once a year ' ' .	26.713547
to help prevent orthodontic problems from arising , your dentist can do these things	91.89022
he can correct decay , thus preventing early loss of teeth .	54.71465
if a child does lose his first teeth prematurely because of decay -- and if no preventive steps are taken -- the other teeth may shift out of position , become overcrowded and malformed .	122.812164
in turn the other teeth are likely to decay because food particles may become impacted in them .	240.92119
from time to time the medium mentions other people `` around him ' ' , who were `` on the other side ' ' , and reports what they are saying .	26.243362
after a while there come initials and names , and he is interested to hear some rather unusual family nicknames .	78.57523
as the hour progresses , the sensitive seems to probe more deeply and to make more personal and specific statements .	97.5984
there are a few prognoses of coming events .	7.5670385
another medium , another sitter , would produce a somewhat different content , but in general it would probably sound much like the foregoing reading .	96.77564
some mediums speak in practical , down-to-earth terms , while others may stress the spiritual .	111.00218
not all , as a matter of fact , consider themselves `` mediums ' ' in the sense of receiving messages from the deceased .	48.024303
in fact , some sensitives rule this out , preferring to consider their expression as strictly extra-sensory perception ( esp ) , on this side of the `` veil ' ' .	51.250904
however that may be , people are known to go to mediums for diverse reasons .	107.9407
perhaps they are mourning a recent death and want comfort , to feel in touch with the deceased , or seek indications for future plans .	144.56725
they may , of course , be curiosity seekers -- or they may just be interested in the phenomenon of mediumship .	88.57364
the mediums with whom the parapsychology foundation is working in this experiment are in a waking or only slightly dissociated state , so that the sitter can make comments , ask and answer questions , instead of talking with a `` control ' ' who speaks through an entranced sensitive .	125.41345
what we have here is in some ways more like an ordinary conversation .	190.36763
but it is not really only a conversation .	15.029828
many a sitter ( in a personal sitting ) has been amazed to realize that the medium was describing very vividly his state of mind .	81.56075
he himself might not have been really aware of his own mood	29.30997
it had been latent , unspecified , semi-conscious and only partly realized -- until she described it to him ! !	118.42892
most striking indeed is this beyond-normal ability to put a finger on `` pre-conscious ' ' moods and to clarify them .	51.15605
however , in the next visit that the researcher made to the medium , he did not receive a personal reading .	77.9568
instead he brought with him the names of some people he had never met and of whom the medium knew nothing .	86.33448
for this was to be a `` proxy sitting ' ' .	4.2729163
as was noted earlier , it is important that in valid , objective study of this sort of communication , the interested sitter should be separated from the sensitive .	89.38768
dr . karlis osis , director of research at the parapsychology foundation , described the basis for the experiment in a tomorrow article , ( `` new research on survival after death ' ' , spring 1958 ) .	133.74234
he remarked `` it has been clearly established that in a number of instances the message did not come from a spirit but was received telepathically by the medium from the sitter ' ' .	55.698902
the possibility has to be ruled out that the medium ' s esp may tap the memory of the sitter , and to do this , the two central characters in this drama must be separated .	62.017437
one way to do this is by `` proxy sittings ' ' , wherein the person seeking a message does not himself meet with the medium but is represented by a substitute , the proxy sitter .	44.886215
if the latter knows nothing about the absent sitter except his name ( given by the experimenter ) , he cannot possibly give any clues , conscious or unconscious , far less ask leading questions .	117.64527
all he can do is to be an objective and careful questioner , seeking to help the sensitive in clarifying and making more specific her paranormal impressions .	151.32779
sometimes in these experiments `` appointment sittings ' ' are used .	27.964489
here the absent sitter makes a `` date ' ' with a communicator ( someone close to him who is deceased ) , asking him to `` come in ' ' at a certain hour , when a channel will be open for him .	39.614723
in this case the proxy sitter will know only the name of the communicator , nothing else .	34.885723
he gives this to the medium at the appointed time , and the reading then will be concerned with material about or messages from the communicator .	117.73703
as always , a tape recording or detailed notes are made , and a typescript of this is sent to the absent sitter .	31.453615
so this proxy situation has set up at least a partial barrier between the medium ' s esp and the absent sitter ' s mind .	21.691986
it is now harder to assume telepathy as a basis for the statements -- though research still does not know how far afield esp can range .	204.83476
now the original absent sitter must decide whether the statements are meaningful to him .	34.462227
here again laboratory approaches are being evolved , for it is recognized how `` elastic ' ' these readings can be , how they can apply to many people , and are often stated in general terms all too easily applied to any individual ' s own case .	79.40167
if you look at a reading meant for someone else , you will probably see that many of the items could be considered as applicable to you , even when you were not in the picture at all ! !	51.255352
an interested sitter may think the sensitive has made a `` hit ' ' , describing something accurately for him , but can he really be sure that another sitter , hearing the same statement , would not apply it subjectively to his own circumstances ? ?	71.858215
it is , of course , easy to see how `` j ' ' will mean uncle jack to one person and little jane to another .	140.98045
`` a journey ' ' , `` a little white house ' ' , `` a change of outlook ' ' , can apply to many people .	23.822533
and even more complex items can be interpreted to conform to one ' s own point of view , which is by nature so personal .	55.876495
one sitter may think `` a leather couch ' ' identifies a reading as surely directed to him	87.33821
to another , it seems that nobody but his father ever used the phrase , `` atta boy ' ' ! !	56.68337
to get around this quite difficult corner , there is one first aid to objectiveness prevent the distant sitter from knowing which reading was for him .	182.1688
if he is not told which of four or five readings was meant for him , he can more readily assess each item in a larger frame `` does that statement really sound as if it were for me , significant in my particular life ? ?	141.03586
or am i taking something that could really apply to almost anybody , and forgetting that many other people probably have had a similar experience ' ' ? ?	89.325554
conversely , experimenters would consider as impressive such statements as the following , which , if they turned out to be hits , are so unusual as to be really significant	79.56415
`` he had four children , two sets of twins .	24.788784
after being a lawyer for twenty-five years he started studying for the ministry .	110.05001
part of his house had been moved to the other side of the road .	19.48488
he died of typhoid in 1921 ' ' .	4.129297
methods have been developed of assigning `` weights ' ' to statements	16.558847
that is , it is known empirically that names beginning with r are more common than those beginning with z	408.8304
that in the united states more people die of heart disease than of smallpox .	145.74913
so each reading can be given a weight and each reading a score by adding up these weights .	122.65222
specific dates would be important , as would double names .	428.74448
various categories have been explored to find out about these `` empirical probabilities ' ' against which to measure the readings .	94.057274
in the parapsychology foundation ' s long-range experiment , readings are made by a variety of sensitives for a large number of cooperating sitters , trying to throw light on this question of the significance of mediumistic statements .	56.023335
it is very important indeed , in the field of extra-sensory perception and its relation to the survival hypothesis , to know whether the statements are actually only those which any intuitive person might venture and an eager sitter attach to himself .	128.54573
or , on the other hand , are unlikely facts being stated , facts which are in themselves significant and not easily applicable to everybody ? ?	141.32103
that is one thing the experiments are designed to find out .	16.99049
so , after the sitting has been held , several readings at one time are mailed , and the distant sitter ( whose name or whose communicator ' s name was given to the medium ) must mark each little item as correct ( hit ) , incorrect ( miss ) , doubtful , or especially significant ( applying to him and , he feels , not to anyone else ) .	88.425095
he is required to mark every item and to indicate which reading he feels is actually his .	287.59506
all these evaluations are then totted up and tabulated , by adding up the hits and significants , with the weight placed on those in the sitter ' s own reading .	47.550465
that is , if he marks as most correct a reading not meant for him , the total experimental score falls .	272.32938
conversely , if he gives a heavy rating to his own reading , and finds more accurate facts in it than in the others , a point is chalked up for the intrinsic , objective meaningfulness of this type of mediumistic material .	69.03172
and there are some positive results , though the final findings will not be known for a long time -- and then further research can be formulated .	59.16233
in another approach to the same procedure , the content of the readings is analyzed so as to see how the particular medium is likely to slant her statements .	80.75554
does she often speak of locations , of cause of death ? ?	208.71895
does she accurately give dates , ages , kind of occupation ? ?	242.39418
it is possible to find out in which categories most of her correct statements fall , and where she makes most of her `` hits ' ' .	133.16078
now when , so to speak , the cream has been skimmed off , and the items in the successful categories separated out , the sitter can be asked to consider and rate only this concentrated `` cream ' ' , where the sensitive is at her best .	131.80157
mediumistic impressions are evidently of all sorts and seem to involve all the senses .	84.59384
`` i feel cold ' ' , the medium says , or `` my leg aches ' ' , `` my head is heavy ' ' .	30.064407
or perhaps she hears words or sounds `` there ' s such a noise of loud machinery ' ' , or `` i hear a child crying ' ' , or `` he says we ' re all here and glad to see you ' ' .	41.023476
maybe an entire scene comes into consciousness , with action and motion , or a static view `` a house under a pine tree , with a little stone path going up to the door ' ' .	59.40669
the sensitive often seems to smell definite odors , too , or subjectively feels emotions .	78.41343
sometimes she displays amazing eidetic imagery and seems to see all details in perspective , as if the scene were actually there .	87.4416
if pressed by the sitter for more detail , she may be able to bring the picture more into focus and see more sharply , almost as if she were physically going closer .	153.7799
if asked how she gets her impressions , she probably can only say that she `` just gets them ' ' -- some more vividly than others .	75.20284
perhaps this is not so extraordinary after all .	11.786303
even in normal experience one gets impressions without knowing exactly how -- of atmosphere , of one another ' s personalities , moods , intentions .	117.3921
of course , there is an element of training here these gifted people , by concentration , study , guidance , have learned to develop their power .	134.4569
simply using it increases its intensity , i was told by one sensitive .	136.24646
nor does a medium automatically know how to interpret her imagery .	166.07335
impressions often appear in a symbolic form and cannot be taken at face value .	215.62213
it is apparently by symbols that the unconscious speaks to the conscious , and the medium has to translate these into meaning .	72.52523
if communication with an entity on the `` other side ' ' is taking place , this too may assume the form of clairvoyant symbolism .	87.32101
during one reading an image appeared of a prisoner in irons .	109.46891
but this did not necessarily refer to an actual jail	1830.8202
taken with other details it could have referred to a state of mental or spiritual confinement .	34.917305
in this connection it is worth noting how names are sometimes obtained .	322.26584
though they are often heard clairaudiently , as if a voice were speaking them , in other cases they are apprehended visually as symbols a slope to signify the name `` hill ' ' , for instance .	90.17497
one medium saw two sheets flapping on a line and found that the name shietz was significant to the sitter .	60.03738
the farmer ' s life must be arranged to meet the demands of crops and livestock .	56.45627
livestock must be tended every day , routinely .	162.99585
a slight change in the work schedule may cut the production of cows or chickens .	32.747505
even if there are no livestock , the farmer cannot leave the farm for long periods , particularly during the growing season .	88.34742
the worker who lives on a farm cannot change jobs readily .	231.88043
he cannot leave the farm to take work in another locality on short notice	262.51462
such a move may mean a loss of capital .	74.47044
hard physical labor and undesirable hours are a part of life .	19.917166
the farmer must get up early , and , at times , work late at night .	191.47485
frequently he must work long hours in the hot sun or cold rain .	93.12109
no matter how well work is planned , bad weather or unexpected setbacks can cause extra work that must be caught up .	221.5227
it may not be profitable for a part-time farmer to own the labor-saving machinery that a full-time farmer can invest in profitably .	46.625977
drought , hail , disease , and insects take their toll of crops .	183.3581
sickness or loss of some of the livestock may cut into the owner ' s earnings , even into his capital .	59.204185
returns for money and labor invested may be small even in a good year .	90.37984
the high cost of land , supplies , and labor make it difficult to farm profitably on a part-time basis .	44.282574
land within commuting distance of a growing city is usually high in price , higher if it has subdivision possibilities .	94.99864
part-time farmers generally must pay higher prices for supplies than full-time farmers because they buy in smaller quantities .	204.53668
if the farm is in an industrial area where wages are high , farm labor costs will also be high .	67.27052
a part-time farmer needs unusual skill to get as high production per hen , per cow , or per acre as can be obtained by a competent full-time farmer .	110.23545
it will frequently be uneconomical for him to own the most up-to-date equipment .	195.76698
he may have to depend upon custom service for specialized operations , such as spraying or threshing , and for these , he may have to wait his turn .	58.409508
there will be losses caused by emergencies that arise while he is away at his off-farm job .	130.08919
the farm may be an additional burden if the main job is lost .	50.29183
this may be true whether the farm is owned or rented .	16.848188
if the farm is rented , the rent must be paid .	14.6548395
if it is owned , taxes must be paid , and if the place is not free of mortgage , there will be interest and payments on the principal to take care of .	70.478294
a farm provides a wholesome and healthful environment for children .	19.134327
it gives them room to play and plenty of fresh air .	70.512146
the children can do chores adapted to their age and ability .	96.03205
caring for a calf , a pig , or some chickens develops in children a sense of responsibility for work .	67.085785
part-time farming gives a measure of security if the regular job is lost , provided the farm is owned free of debt and furnishes enough income to meet fixed expenses and minimum living costs .	109.81061
for some retired persons , part-time farming is a good way to supplement retirement income .	61.89351
it is particularly suitable for those who need to work or exercise out of doors for their health .	73.841995
generally , the same level of living costs less in the country than in the city .	24.892397
the savings are not as great , however , as is sometime supposed .	203.78552
usually , the cost of food and shelter will be somewhat less on the farm and the cost of transportation and utilities somewhat more .	54.870968
where schools , fire and police protection , and similar municipal services are of equal quality in city and country , real estate taxes are usually about the same .	69.29213
a part-time farmer and his family can use their spare time profitably .	100.72512
some persons consider the work on a farm recreational .	61.363197
for some white-collar workers it is a welcome change from the regular job , and a physical conditioner .	55.14499
part-time farming can take comparatively little land , labor , and equipment -- or a great deal .	36.72112
it depends on the kind and the scale of the farming operation .	47.421967
general requirements for land , labor , and equipment are discussed below .	101.796555
specific requirements for each of various types of enterprises are discussed on pages 8 to 14 .	73.18927
three quarters to 1 acre of good land is enough for raising fruits and vegetables for home use , and for a small flock of chickens , a cow , and two pigs .	50.46628
you could not , of course , raise feed for the livestock on a plot this small .	164.67523
if you want to raise feed or carry out some enterprise on a larger scale , you ' ll need more land .	64.65765
in deciding how much land you want , take into account the amount you ' ll need to bring in the income you expect .	43.84274
but consider also how much you and your family can keep up along with your other work .	63.529022
the cost of land and the prospects for appreciation in value may influence your decision .	545.7009
some part-time farmers buy more land than they need in anticipation of suburban development .	141.76979
sometimes a desired acreage is offered only as part of a larger tract .	46.98886
when surplus land is not expensive to buy or to keep up , it is usually better to buy it than to buy so small an acreage that the development of adjoining properties might impair the residential value of the farm .	81.73038
if you have a year-round , full-time job you can ' t expect to grow much more than your family uses -- unless other members of the family do a good deal of the work or you hire help .	36.586338
as a rule , part-time farmers hire little help .	137.46724
in deciding on the enterprises to be managed by family labor , compare the amount of labor that can be supplied by the family with the labor needs of various enterprises listed in table 1 .	81.36101
list the number of hours the family can be expected to work each month .	30.25783
you may want to include your own regular vacation period if you have one .	50.99835
do not include all your spare time or all your family ' s spare time -- only what you are willing to use for farm work .	63.823063
if you are going to produce for home use only , you will need only hand tools .	172.79243
you will probably want to hire someone to do the plowing , however .	55.123325
for larger plantings , you ' ll need some kind of power for plowing , harrowing , disking , and cultivating .	26.49998
if you have a planting of half an acre or more you may want to buy a small garden tractor ( available for $300 to $500 with attachments , 1960 prices ) .	93.161736
these tractors are not entirely satisfactory for plowing , particularly on heavier soils , so you may still want to hire someone to do the plowing .	54.260323
cost of power and machinery is often a serious problem to the small-scale farmer .	46.033344
if you are going to farm for extra cash income on a part-time basis you must keep in mind the needed machinery investments when you choose among farm enterprises .	140.61407
you can keep your machinery investment down by buying good secondhand machinery , by sharing the cost and upkeep of machinery with a neighbor , and by hiring someone with machinery to do certain jobs .	78.135666
if an expensive and specialized piece of machinery is needed -- such as a spray rig , a combine , or a binder -- it is better to pay someone with a machine to do the work .	40.802654
before you look for a farm you ' ll need to know ( 1 ) the kind and scale of farming you want to undertake	43.66029
and ( 2 ) whether you want to buy or rent .	38.64994
information on pages 8 to 14 may help you in deciding on the kind and scale of your farming venture .	93.32482
if you are not well acquainted with the area in which you wish to locate , or if you are not sure that you and your family will like and make a success of farming , usually you would do better to rent a place for a year or two before you buy .	56.015213
discussed below are some of the main things to look for when you select a part-time farm .	80.35195
choose a location within easy commuting distance of both the regular job and other employment opportunities .	135.51405
then if you change jobs you won ' t necessarily have to sell the farm .	34.82322
the presence of alternative job opportunities also will make the place easier to sell if that should become desirable .	70.89382
obviously the farm should be on an all-weather road .	11.602227
if you grow anything to sell you will need markets nearby .	488.31345
if you plan to sell fresh vegetables or whole milk , for example , you should be close to a town or city .	75.112274
look for a farm in a neighborhood of well-kept homes .	5.3168125
there are slums in the country as well as in the city .	14.289969
a tavern , filling station , junk yard , rendering plant , or some other business may go up near enough to hurt your home or to hurt its value .	108.61142
check on the schools in the area , the quality of teaching , and the provision for transportation to and from them .	81.90199
find out whether fire protection , sewage system , gas , water mains , and electrical lines are available in the locality .	25.24521
if these facilities are not at the door , getting them may cost more than you expect .	98.01464
you may have to provide them yourself or get along without them .	141.58199
you cannot get along without an adequate supply of pure water .	12.858648
if you are considering a part-time farm where the water must be provided by a well , find out if there is a good well on the farm or the probable cost of having one drilled .	93.78936
a pond may provide adequate water for livestock and garden .	54.70533
pond water can be filtered for human use , but most part-time farmers would not want to go to so much trouble .	44.701286
the following amounts of water are needed per day for livestock and domestic uses .	55.937675
is the land suited to the crops you intend to raise ? ?	37.90733
if you can ' t tell , get help from your county agricultural agent or other local specialist .	255.84221
soil type , drainage , or degree of slope can make the difference between good crops and poor ones .	94.38975
small areas that aren ' t right for a certain crop may lie next to areas that are well suited to that crop .	181.38374
will the house on any part-time farm you are considering make a satisfactory full-time residence ? ?	98.66606
how much will it cost to do any necessary modernizing and redecorating ? ?	69.30823
if the house is not wired adequately for electricity or if plumbing or a central heating system must be installed , check into the cost of making these improvements .	71.21451
the value of the farm to you will depend on --	317.65848
the value of the products you can raise on it .	34.37671
the possibilities of selling the property later on for suburban subdivision .	101.267105
decide first what the place is worth to you and your family as a home in comparison with what it would cost to live in town .	72.635574
take into account the difference in city and county taxes , insurance rates , utility rates , and the cost of travel to work .	44.278416
next , estimate the value of possible earnings of the farm .	16.96471
to do this , set up a plan on paper for operating the farm .	125.50726
list the kind and quantity of things the farm can be expected to produce in an average year .	48.36957
estimate the value of the produce at normal prices .	8.809002
the total is the probably gross income from farming .	17.806004
to find estimated net farm income , subtract estimated annual farming expenditures from probable gross income from farming .	50.16909
include as expenditures an allowance for depreciation of farm buildings and equipment .	46.183643
also count as an expense a charge for the labor to be contributed by the family .	53.67833
it may be hard to decide what this labor is worth , but charge something for it .	166.68661
otherwise , you may pay too much for the farm and get nothing for your labor .	75.36248
to figure the value of the farm in terms of investment income , divide the estimated annual net farm income by the percentage that you could expect to get in interest if the money were invested in some other way .	68.07238
everyone with a personal or group tragedy to relate had to be given his day in court as in some vast collective dirge .	163.3519
for almost two months , the defendant and the world heard from individuals escaped from the grave about fathers and mothers , graybeards , adolescents , babies , starved , beaten to death , strangled , machine-gunned , gassed , burned .	38.95451
one who had been a boy in auschwitz had to tell how children had been selected by height for the gas chambers .	90.48997
the gruesome humor of the nazis was not forgotten -- the gas chamber with a sign on it with the name of a jewish foundation and bearing a copper star of david -- nor the gratuitous sadism of ss officers .	124.88306
public relations strategists everywhere , watching the reaction of the german press , the liberal press , the lunatic-fringe press , listening to their neighbors , studying interviews with men and women on the street , cried out too much , too much -- the mind of the audience is becoming dulled , the horrors are losing their effect .	66.6407
and still another witness , one who had crawled out from under a heap of corpses , had to tell how the victims had been forced to lay themselves head to foot one on top of the other before being shot .	85.4174
most of this testimony may have been legally admissible as bearing on the corpus delicti of the total nazi crime but seemed subject to question when not tied to the part in it of the defendant ' s department of jewish affairs .	66.40784
counsel for the defense , however , shrewdly allowing himself to be swept by the current of dreadful recollections , rarely raised an objection .	86.01725
would not the emotional catharsis eventually brought on by this awfulness have a calming , if not exhausting , effect likely to improve his client ' s chances ? ?	116.87195
those who feared `` emotionalism ' ' at the trial showed less understanding than dr . servatius of the route by which man achieves the distance necessary for fairness toward enemies .	194.80312
interruptions came largely from the bench , which numerous times rebuked the attorney general for letting his witnesses run on , though it , too , made no serious effort to choke off the flow .	86.98104
but there was a contrast even more decisive than a hunger for fact between the trial in jerusalem and those in moscow and new york .	98.37326
in each of the last , the trial marked the beginning of a new course in moscow the liquidation of the old bolsheviks and the tightening of stalin ' s dictatorship	34.8049
in the united states the initiation of militant anti-communism , with the repentant ex-communist in the vanguard .	16.708815
these trials were properly termed `` political cases ' ' in that the trial itself was a political act producing political consequences .	64.97032
but what could the eichmann trial initiate ? ?	1.0399717
of what new course could it mark the beginning ? ?	44.483105
the eichmann case looked to the past , not to the future .	60.780693
it was the conclusion of the first phase of a process of tragic recollection , and of refining the recollection , that will last as long as there are jews .	78.19403
as such , it was beyond politics and had no need of justification by a `` message ' ' .	58.904118
`` it is not an individual that is in the dock at this historical trial ' ' -- said ben gurion , `` and not the nazi regime alone -- but anti-semitism throughout history ' ' .	100.530365
how could supplying eichmann with a platform on which to maintain that one could collaborate in the murder of millions of jews without being an anti-semite contribute to a verdict against anti-semitism ? ?	101.394135
and if it was not an individual who was in the dock , why was the trial , as we shall observe later , all but scuttled in the attempt to prove eichmann a `` fiend ' ' ? ?	75.64405
these questions touch the root of confusion in the prosecution ' s case .	20.476528
it might be contended , of course , that eichmann in stubbornly denying anti-semitic feelings was lying or insisting on a private definition of anti-semitism .	68.900314
but in either event he was the wrong man for the kind of case outlined by ben gurion and set forth in the indictment .	61.906055
in such a case the defendant should serve as a clear example and not have to be tied to the issue by argument .	84.31348
one who could be linked to anti-semitism only by overcoming his objections is scarcely a good specimen of the jew-baiter throughout the ages .	140.32425
shout at eichmann though he might , the prosecutor could not establish that the defendant was falsifying the way he felt about jews or that what he did feel fell into the generally recognized category of anti-semitism .	131.7331
yes , he believed that the jews were `` enemies of the reich ' ' , and such a belief is , of course , typical of `` patriotic ' ' anti-semites	22.9843
but he believed in the jew-as-enemy in a kind of abstract , theological way , like a member of a cult speculating on the nature of things .	54.705986
the real question was how one passed from anti-semitism of this sort to murder , and the answer to this question is not to be found in anti-semitism itself .	51.1365
in regard to eichmann , it was to be found in the nazi outlook , which contained a principle separate from and far worse than anti-semitism , a principle by which the poison of anti-semitism itself was made more virulent .	89.157295
perhaps under the guidance of this nazi principle one could , as eichmann declared , feel personally friendly toward the jews and still be their murderer .	239.50098
not through fear of disobeying orders , as eichmann kept trying to explain , but through a peculiar giddiness that began in a half-acceptance of the vicious absurdities contained in the nazi interpretation of history and grew with each of hitler ' s victories into a permanent light-mindedness and sense of magical rightness that was able to respond to any proposal , and the more outrageous the better , `` well , let ' s try it ' ' .	73.85647
at any rate , the substance of eichmann ' s testimony was that all his actions flowed from his membership in the party and the ss , and though the prosecutor did his utmost to prove actual personal hatred of jews , his success on this score was doubtful and the anti-semitic lesson weakened to that extent .	89.47838
but if the trial did not expose the special nazi mania so deadly to jews as well as to anyone upon whom it happened to light , neither did it warn very effectively against the ordinary anti-semitism of which the nazis made such effective use in germany and wherever else they could find it .	149.32327
if anti-semitism was on trial in jerusalem , why was it not identified , and with enough emphasis to capture the notice of the world press , in its connection with the activities of eichmann ' s department of jewish affairs , as exemplified by the betrayal and murder of jews by non-police and non-party anti-semites in germany , as well as in poland , czechoslovakia , hungary ? ?	62.969658
