the infamous wansee conference called by heydrich in january 1942 , to organize the material and technical means to put to death the eleven million jews spread throughout the nations of europe , was attended by representatives of major organs of the german state , including the reich minister of the interior , the state secretary in charge of the four year plan , the reich minister of justice , the under secretary of foreign affairs .	75.972565
the measures for annihilation proposed and accepted at the conference affected industry , transportation , civilian agencies of government .	127.41553
heydrich , in opening the conference , followed the reasoning and even the phraseology of the order issued earlier by goering which authorized the final solution as `` a complement to ' ' previous `` solutions ' ' for eliminating the jews from german living space through violence , economic strangulation , forced emigration , and evacuation .	83.92648
in other words , the promulgators of the murder plan made clear that physically exterminating the jews was but an extension of the anti-semitic measures already operating in every phase of german life , and that the new conspiracy counted on the general anti-semitism that had made those measures effective , as a readiness for murder .	129.33658
this , in fact , it turned out to be .	27.0901
since the magnitude of the plan made secrecy impossible , once the wheels had began to turn , persons controlling german industries , social institutions , and armed forces became , through their anti-semitism or their tolerance of it , conscious accomplices of hitler ' s crimes	121.50325
whether in the last degree or a lesser one was a matter to be determined individually .	92.07382
what more could be asked for a trial intended to warn the world against anti-semitism than this opportunity to expose the exact link between the respectable anti-semite and the concentration-camp brute ? ?	70.3552
not in eichmann ' s anti-semitism but in the anti-semitism of the sober german man of affairs lay the potential warning of the trial .	115.77475
no doubt many of the citizens of the third reich had conceived their anti-semitism as an `` innocent ' ' dislike of jews , as do others like them today .	159.82135
the final solution proved that the jew-baiter of any variety exposes himself as being implicated in the criminality and madness of others .	77.25095
ought not an edifying trial have made every effort to demonstrate this once and for all by showing how representative types of `` mere ' ' anti-semites were drawn step by step into the program of skull-bashings and gassings ? ?	106.19323
the prosecutor in his opening remarks did refer to `` the germ of anti-semitism ' ' among the germans which hitler `` stimulated and transformed ' ' .	41.82245
but if there was evidence at the trial that aimed over eichmann ' s head at his collaborators in the societies where he functioned , the press seems to have missed it .	82.46378
nor did the trial devote much attention to exposing the usefulness of anti-semitism to the nazis , both in building their own power and in destroying that of rival organizations and states .	118.36558
certainly , one of the best ways of warning the world against anti-semitism is to demonstrate its workings as a dangerous weapon .	100.688866
eichmann himself is a model of how the myth of the enemy-jew can be used to transform the ordinary man of present-day society into a menace to all his neighbors .	65.60428
do patriots everywhere know enough about how the persecution of the jews in germany and later in the occupied countries contributed to terrorizing the populations , splitting apart individuals and groups , arousing the meanest and most dishonest impulses , pulverizing trust and personal dignity , and finally forcing people to follow their masters into the abyss by making them partners in unspeakable crimes ? ?	80.06385
the career of eichmann made the trial a potential showcase for anti-semitic demoralization fearful of being mistaken for a jew , he seeks protection in his nazi uniform	192.7023
clinging to the enemy-jew idea , he is forced to overcome habits of politeness and neighborliness	149.89362
once in power he begins to give vent to a criminal opportunism that causes him to alternate between megalomania and envy of those above him .	121.854454
`` is this the type of citizen you desire ' ' ? ?	32.061737
but though this characterization in no way diminished eichmann ' s guilt , the prosecutor , more deeply involved in the tactics of a criminal case than a political one , would have none of it .	72.99692
finally , if the mission of the trial was to convict anti-semitism , how could it have failed to post before the world the contrasting fates of the countries in which the final solution was aided by native jew-haters -- i . e . , germany , poland , hungary , czechoslovakia -- and those in which it met the obstacle of human solidarity -- denmark , holland , italy , bulgaria , france ? ?	51.52279
should not everyone have been awakened to it as an outstanding fact of our time that the nations poisoned by anti-semitism proved less fortunate in regard to their own freedom than those whose citizens saved their jewish compatriots from the transports ? ?	81.31645
wasn ' t this meaning of eichmann ' s experience in various countries worth highlighting ? ?	101.65409
as the first collective confrontation of the nazi outrage , the trial of eichmann represents a recovery of the jews from the shock of the death camps , a recovery that took fifteen years and which is still by no means complete ( though let no one believe that it could be hastened by silence ) .	79.40099
only across a distance of time could the epic accounting begin .	146.10387
it is already difficult to recall how little we knew before the trial of what had been done to the jews of europe .	78.94922
it is not that the facts of the persecution were unavailable	407.84244
most of the information elicited in jerusalem had been brought to the surface by the numerous war crimes tribunals and investigating commissions , and by reports , memoirs , and survivors ' accounts .	105.49437
in poughkeepsie , n . y . , , in 1952 , a roman catholic hospital presented seven protestant physicians with an ultimatum to quit the planned parenthood federation or to resign from the hospital staff .	57.432785
three agreed , but four declined and were suspended .	128.57661
after a flood of protests , they were reinstated at the beginning of 1953 .	23.101196
the peace of the community was badly disturbed , and people across the nation , reading of the incident , felt uneasy .	112.73436
in new york city in 1958 , the city ' s commissioner of hospitals refused to permit a physician to provide a protestant mother with a contraceptive device .	54.461628
he thereby precipitated a bitter controversy involving protestants , jews and roman catholics that continued for two months , until the city ' s board of hospitals lifted the ban on birth-control therapy .	73.817314
a year later in albany , n . y . , a roman catholic hospital barred an orthopedic surgeon because of his connection with the planned parenthood association .	39.882652
immediately , the religious groups of the city were embroiled in an angry dispute over the alleged invasion of a man ' s right to freedom of religious belief and conscience .	46.557438
these incidents , typical of many others , dramatize the distressing fact that no controversy during the last several decades has caused more tension , rancor and strife among religious groups in this country than the birth-control issue .	91.15739
it has flared up periodically on the front pages of newspapers in communities divided over birth-prevention regulations in municipal hospitals and health and family-welfare agencies .	266.03204
it has erupted on the national level in the matter of including birth-control information and material in foreign aid to underdeveloped countries .	73.63097
where it is not actually erupting , it rumbles and smolders in sullen resentment like a volcano , ready to explode at any moment .	38.132397
the time has come for citizens of all faiths to unite in an effort to remove this divisive and nettlesome issue from the political and social life of our nation .	36.016243
the first step toward the goal is the establishment of a new atmosphere of mutual good will and friendly communication on other than the polemical level .	102.845
instead of emotional recrimination , loaded phrases and sloganeering , we need a dispassionate study of the facts , a better understanding of the opposite viewpoint and a more serious effort to extend the areas of agreement until a solution is reached .	56.059357
`` all too frequently ' ' , points out james o ' gara , managing editor of commonweal , `` catholics run roughshod over protestant sensibilities in this matter , by failure to consider the reasoning behind the protestant position and , particularly , by their jibes at the fact that protestant opinion on birth control has changed in recent decades ' ' .	78.493034
all too often our language is unduly harsh .	3.2740724
the second step is to recognize the substantial agreement -- frequently blurred by emotionalism and inaccurate newspaper reporting -- already existing between catholics and non-catholics concerning the over-all objectives of family planning .	131.09874
instead of catholics ' being obliged or even encouraged to beget the greatest possible number of offspring , as many non-catholics imagine , the ideal of responsible parenthood is stressed .	86.90094
family planning is encouraged , so that parents will be able to provide properly for their offspring .	36.661144
pope pius 12 , declared in 1951 that it is possible to be exempt from the normal obligation of parenthood for a long time and even for the whole duration of married life , if there are serious reasons , such as those often mentioned in the so-called medical , eugenic , economic and social `` indications ' ' .	52.955143
this means that such factors as the health of the parents , particularly the mother , their ability to provide their children with the necessities of life , the degree of population density of a country and the shortage of housing facilities may legitimately be taken into consideration in determining the number of offspring .	49.06785
these are substantially the same factors considered by non-catholics in family planning .	107.61112
the laws of many states permit birth control only for medical reasons .	105.02553
the roman catholic church , however , sanctions a much more liberal policy on family planning .	127.95393
catholics , protestants and jews are in agreement over the objectives of family planning , but disagree over the methods to be used .	82.4895
the roman catholic church sanctions only abstention or the rhythm method , also known as the use of the infertile or safe period .	92.0326
the church considers this to be the method provided by nature and its divine author it involves no frustration of nature ' s laws , but simply an intelligent and disciplined use of them .	120.8766
with the exception of the roman catholic and the orthodox catholic churches , most churches make no moral distinction between rhythm and mechanical or chemical contraceptives , allowing the couple free choice .	104.6744
there is a difference in theological belief where there seems little chance of agreement .	116.48732
the grounds for the church ' s position are scriptural ( old testament ) , the teachings of the fathers and doctors of the early church , the unbroken tradition of nineteen centuries , the decisions of the highest ecclesiastical authority and the natural law .	39.15854
the latter plays a prominent role in roman catholic theology and is considered decisive , entirely apart from scripture , in determining the ethical character of birth-prevention methods .	66.00007
the roman catholic natural-law tradition regards as self-evident that the primary objective purpose of the conjugal act is procreation and that the fostering of the mutual love of the spouses is the secondary and subjective end .	52.06402
this conclusion is based on two propositions that man by the use of his reason can ascertain god ' s purpose in the universe and that god makes known his purpose by certain `` given ' ' physical arrangements .	113.23793
thus , man can readily deduce that the primary objective end of the conjugal act is procreation , the propagation of the race .	31.849392
moreover , man may not supplant or frustrate the physical arrangements established by god , who through the law of rhythm has provided a natural method for the control of conception .	83.01823
believing that god is the author of this law and of all laws of nature , roman catholics believe that they are obliged to obey those laws , not frustrate or mock them .	72.97924
let it be granted then that the theological differences in this area between protestants and roman catholics appear to be irreconcilable .	20.968868
but people differ in their religious beliefs on scores of doctrines , without taking up arms against those who disagree with them .	75.21485
why is it so different in regard to birth control ? ?	57.049408
it is because each side has sought to implement its distinctive theological belief through legislation and thus indirectly force its belief , or at least the practical consequences thereof , upon others .	118.89362
it is always a temptation for a religious organization , especially a powerful or dominant one , to impose through the clenched fist of the law its creedal viewpoint upon others .	93.2167
both roman catholics and protestants have succumbed to this temptation in the past .	24.270449
consider what happened during world war 1 , , when the protestant churches united to push the prohibition law through congress .	135.67938
many of them sincerely believe that the use of liquor in any form or in any degree is intrinsically evil and sinful .	49.825405
with over four million american men away at war , protestants forced their distinctive theological belief upon the general public .	89.904396
with the return of our soldiers , it soon became apparent that the belief was not shared by the great majority of citizens .	58.00677
the attempt to enforce that belief ushered in a reign of bootleggers , racketeers , hijackers and gangsters that led to a breakdown of law unparalleled in our history .	34.72231
the so-called `` noble experiment ' ' came to an inglorious end .	18.904478
that tumultuous , painful and costly experience shows clearly that a law expressing a moral judgment cannot be enforced when it has little correspondence with the general view of society .	84.618774
that experience holds a lesson for us all in regard to birth control today .	109.068184
up to the turn of the century , contraception was condemned by all christian churches as immoral , unnatural and contrary to divine law .	82.22435
this was generally reflected in the civil laws of christian countries .	49.9326
today , the roman catholic and orthodox churches stand virtually alone in holding that conviction .	507.7826
the various lambeth conferences , expressing the anglican viewpoint , mirror the gradual change that has taken place among protestants generally .	125.43678
in 1920 , the lambeth conference repeated its 1908 condemnation of contraception and issued `` an emphatic warning against the use of unnatural means for the avoidance of conception , together with the grave dangers -- physical , moral , and religious -- thereby incurred , and against the evils which the extension of such use threaten the race ' ' .	61.02713
denouncing the view that the sexual union is an end in itself , the conference declared `` we steadfastly uphold what must always be regarded as the governing considerations of christian marriage .	100.981926
one is the primary purpose for which marriage exists , namely , the continuance of the race through the gift and heritage of children	41.292778
the other is the paramount importance in married life of deliberate and thoughtful self-control ' ' .	47.064796
the conference called for a vigorous campaign against the open or secret sale of contraceptives .	67.6163
in 1930 , the lambeth conference again affirmed the primary purpose of marriage to be the procreation of children , but conceded that , in certain limited circumstances , contraception might be morally legitimate .	63.02643
in 1958 , the conference endorsed birth control as the responsibility laid by god on parents everywhere .	206.93842
many other protestant denominations preceded the anglicans in such action .	94.46016
in march , 1931 , 22 out of 28 members of a committee of the federal council of churches ratified artificial methods of birth control .	44.856422
`` as to the necessity ' ' , the committee declared , `` for some form of effective control of the size of the family and the spacing of children , and consequently of control of conception , there can be no question .	49.81007
there is general agreement also that sex union between husbands and wives as an expression of mutual affection without relation to procreation is right ' ' .	64.43623
since then , many protestant denominations have made separate pronouncements , in which they not only approved birth control , but declared it at times to be a religious duty .	46.4761
what determines the morality , they state , is not the means used , but the motive in general , the means ( excluding abortion ) that prove most effective are considered the most ethical .	99.20633
this development is reflected in the action taken in february , 1961 , by the general board of the national council of churches , the largest protestant organization in the aj .	26.366356
the board approved and commended the use of birth-control devices as a part of christian responsibility in family planning .	111.07753
it called for opposition to laws and institutional practices restricting the information or availability of contraceptives .	102.8503
the general board declared `` most of the protestant churches hold contraception and periodic continence to be morally right when the motives are right .	84.54815
the general protestant conviction is that motives , rather than methods , form the primary moral issue , provided the methods are limited to the prevention of conception ' ' .	90.90978
an action once universally condemned by all christian churches and forbidden by the civil law is now not only approved by the overwhelming majority of protestant denominations , but also deemed , at certain times , to be a positive religious duty .	55.027443
this viewpoint has now been translated into action by the majority of people in this country .	21.595825
repeated polls have disclosed that most married couples are now using contraceptives in the practice of birth control .	40.339
for all concerned with social-welfare legislation , the significance of this radical and revolutionary change in the thought and habits of the vast majority of the american people is clear , profound and far-reaching .	62.218086
to try to oppose the general religious and moral conviction of such a majority by a legislative fiat would be to invite the same breakdown of law and order that was occasioned by the ill-starred prohibition experiment .	122.803505
this brings us to the fact that the realities we are dealing with lie not in the field of civil legislation , but in the realm of conscience and religion they are moral judgments and matters of theological belief .	73.02839
conscience and religion are concerned with private sin the civil law is concerned with public crimes .	92.93616
only confusion , failure and anarchy result when the effort is made to impose upon the civil authority the impossible task of policing private homes to preclude the possibility of sin .	95.84992
among the chief victims of such an ill-conceived imposition would be religion itself .	108.400375
on april 17 , 1610 , the sturdy little three-masted bark , discovery , weighed anchor in st . katherine ' s pool , london , and floated down the thames toward the sea .	29.915462
she carried , besides her captain , a crew of twenty-one and provisions for a voyage of exploration of the arctic waters of north america .	46.032467
seventeen months later , on september 6 , 1611 , an irish fishing boat sighted the discovery limping eastward outside galway bay .	32.414032
when she reached port , she was found to have on board only eight men , all near starvation .	188.02621
the captain was gone , and the mate was gone .	13.571932
the man who now commanded her had started the voyage as an ordinary seaman .	58.426277
what disaster struck the discovery during those seventeen months ? ?	22.975441
what happened to the fourteen missing men ? ?	1.0607259
these questions have remained one of the great sea mysteries of all time .	44.076797
for hundreds of years , the evidence available consisted of ( 1 ) the captain ' s fragmentary journal , ( 2 ) a highly prejudiced account by one of the survivors , ( 3 ) a note found in a dead man ' s desk on board , and ( 4 ) several second-hand reports .	57.371666
all told , they offered a highly confused picture .	106.950356
but since 1927 , researchers digging into ancient court records and legal files have been able to find illuminating pieces of information .	86.52451
not enough to do away with all doubts , but sufficient to give a fairly accurate picture of the events of the voyage .	35.05433
historians have had two reasons for persisting so long in their investigations .	33.814873
first , they wanted to clarify a tantalizing , bizarre enigma .	20.19944
second , they believed it important to determine the fate of the captain -- a man whose name is permanently stamped on our maps , on american towns and counties , on a great american river , and on half a million square miles of arctic seas .	74.0797
this is the story of his last tragic voyage , as nearly as we are able -- or ever , probably , will be able -- to determine	73.52161
the sailing in the spring of 1610 was hudson ' s fourth in four years .	32.417446
each time his objective had been the same -- a direct water passage from western europe to the far east .	106.665596
in 1607 and 1608 , the english muscovy company had sent him northward to look for a route over the north pole or across the top of russia .	63.52527
twice he had failed , and the muscovy company indicated it would not back him again .	155.29051
in 1609 , the dutch east india company hired hudson , gave him two learned geographers , fitted him out with a ship called the half moon , and supplied him with dutch sailors .	109.680305
this time he turned westward , to the middle atlantic coast of north america .	25.454988
his chief discovery was important -- the great north ( later , the hudson ) river -- but it produced no northwest passage .	228.26347
when the half moon put in at dartmouth , england , in the fall of 1609 , word of hudson ' s findings leaked out , and english interest in him revived .	64.01196
the government forbade hudson to return to amsterdam with his ship .	47.18801
he thereupon went to london and spent the winter talking to men of wealth .	259.1114
by springtime , he was supported by a rich merchant syndicate under the patronage of henry , prince of wales .	53.451122
he had obtained and provisioned a veteran ship called the discovery and had recruited a crew of twenty-one , the largest he had ever commanded .	89.02551
the purpose of this fourth voyage was clear .	5.9684224
a century of exploration had established that a great land mass , north and south america , lay between europe and the indies .	91.03011
one by one , the openings in the coast that promised a passage through had been explored and discarded .	253.19287
in fact , hudson ' s sail up the great north river had disposed of one of the last hopes .	186.25027
but there remained one mysterious , unexplored gap , far to the north .	22.723377
nearly twenty-five years before , captain john davis had noted , as he sailed near the arctic circle , `` a very great gulf , the water whirling and roaring , as it were the meeting of tides ' ' .	64.654915
he named this opening , between baffin island and labrador , the `` furious overfall ' ' .	8.142821
( later , it was to be called hudson strait .	39.511616
in 1602 , george waymouth , in the same little discovery that hudson now commanded , had sailed 300 miles up the strait before his frightened men turned the ship back .	162.78156
hudson now proposed to sail all the way through and test the seas beyond for the long-sought waterway .	114.05094
even hudson , experienced in arctic sailing and determined as he was , must have had qualms as he slid down the thames .	130.60432
on previous voyages , it had been in precisely such dangerous situations that he had failed as a leader and captain .	139.8712
on the second voyage , he had turned back at the frozen island of novaya zemlya and meekly given the crew a certificate stating that he did so of his own free will -- which was obviously not the case .	65.32929
on the third voyage , a near-mutiny rising from a quarrel between dutch and english crew members on the half moon had almost forced him to head the ship back to amsterdam in mid-atlantic .	96.20947
worse , his present crew included five men who had sailed with him before .	46.246235
of only one could he be sure -- young john hudson , his second son .	135.54216
the mate , robert juet , who had kept the journal on the half moon , was experienced -- but he was a bitter old man , ready to complain or desert at any opportunity .	107.49337
philip staffe , the ship ' s carpenter , was a good worker , but perversely independent .	48.302986
arnold lodley and michael perse were like the rest -- lukewarm , ready to swing against hudson in a crisis .	180.29776
but men willing to sail at all into waters where wooden ships could be crushed like eggs were hard to find .	197.52559
hudson knew he had to use these men as long as he remained an explorer .	125.66049
it is believed that hudson was related to other seafaring men of the muscovy company and was trained on company ships .	59.25166
he was a londoner , married , with three sons .	51.743057
( the common misconception that he was dutch and that his first name was hendrik stem from dutch documents of his third voyage .	129.27603
) in 1610 , hudson was probably in his early forties , a good navigator , a stubborn voyager , but otherwise fatally unsuited to his chosen profession .	25.476276
hudson ' s first error of the fourth voyage occurred only a few miles down the thames .	29.970297
there at the river ' s edge waited one henry greene , whom hudson listed as a `` clerk ' ' .	76.64401
greene was in actuality a young ruffian from kent , who had broken with his parents in order to keep the company he preferred -- pimps , panders and whores .	41.669918
he was not the sort of sailor hudson wanted his backers to see on board and he had greene wait at gravesend , where the discovery picked him up .	76.11511
for the first three weeks , the ship skirted up the east coast of great britain , then turned westward .	45.127426
poor winds and fog locked her up in a harbor the crew called `` lousie bay ' ' .	48.211346
the subsequent two-weeks wait made the crew quarrelsome .	39.514256
with hudson looking on , his protege greene picked a fight with the ship ' s surgeon , edward wilson .	52.709507
the issue was settled on shore , greene winning and wilson remaining ashore , determined to catch the next fishing boat back to england .	226.18373
with difficulty , hudson persuaded him to rejoin the ship , and they sailed from iceland .	17.210453
early in june , the discovery passed `` desolation ' ' ( southern greenland ) and in mid-june entered the `` furious overfall ' ' .	21.915066
floating ice bore down from the north and west .	44.11229
turbulent tides rose as much as fifty feet .	5.1268177
the ship ' s compass was useless because of the nearness of the magnetic north pole .	82.70779
as the bergs grew larger , hudson was forced to turn south into what is now ungava bay , an inlet of the great strait .	82.124626
after finding that its coasts led nowhere , however , he turned north again , toward the main , ice-filled passageway -- and the crew , at first uneasy , then frightened , rebelled .	75.82625
the trouble was at least partly juet ' s doing .	29.51014
for weeks he had been saying that hudson ' s idea of sailing through to java was absurd .	64.09095
the great , crushing ice masses coming into view made him sound like the voice of pure reason .	241.05899
a group of sailors announced to hudson that they would sail no farther .	89.251854
instead of quelling the dissension , as many captains of the era would have done ( sir francis drake lopped a man ' s head off under similar circumstances ) , hudson decided to be reasonable .	67.56435
he went to his cabin and emerged carrying a large chart , which he set up in view of the crew .	58.355637
patiently , he explained what he knew about their course and their objectives .	120.29259
when hudson had finished , the `` town meeting ' ' broke down into a general , wordy argument .	43.644165
one man remarked that if he had a hundred pounds , he would give ninety of them to be back in england .	50.21184
up spoke carpenter staffe , who said he wouldn ' t give ten pounds to be home .	27.560472
all through july the discovery picked her way along the 450-mile-long strait , avoiding ice and rocky islands .	74.18514
on august 3 , two massive headlands reared out of the mists -- great gateways never before , so far as hudson knew , seen by europeans .	96.854904
to starboard was a cape a thousand feet high , patched with ice and snow , populated by thousands of screaming sea birds .	48.22324
to port was a point 200 feet high rising behind to a precipice of 2 , 000 feet .	31.34997
hudson named the capes digges and wolstenholme , for two of his backers .	39.11295
hudson pointed the discovery down the east coast of the newly discovered sea ( now called hudson bay ) , confident he was on his way to the warm waters of the pacific .	77.672066
after three weeks ' swift sailing , however , the ship entered an area of shallow marshes and river deltas .	54.880306
the great `` sea to the westwards ' ' was a dead end .	37.327854
this must have been hudson ' s blackest discovery .	41.427284
for he seemed to sense at once that before him was no south sea , but the solid bulk of the north american continent .	103.26319
this was the bitter end , and hudson seemed to know he was destined to failure .	74.24593
feverishly , he tried to brush away this intuition .	143.32306
north and south , east and west , back and forth he sailed in the land-locked bay , plowing furiously forward until land appeared , then turning to repeat the process , day after day , week after week .	199.7504
hundreds of miles to the north , the route back to england through the `` furious overfall ' ' was again filling with ice .	51.100437
the men were at first puzzled , then angered by the aimless tacking .	117.38925
once more , juet ' s complaints were the loudest .	40.745045
hudson ' s reply was to accuse the mate of disloyalty .	95.665634
juet demanded that hudson prove his charges in an open trial .	47.074112
hudson , presiding , heard juet ' s defense , then called for testimony from crew members .	373.34753
juet had made plentiful enemies , several men stepped forward .	134.61362
hands on bible , seaman lodley and carpenter staffe swore that juet had tried to persuade them to keep muskets and swords in their cabins .	41.83679
cook bennett mathues said juet had predicted bloodshed on the ship .	19.440004
others added that juet had wanted to turn the ship homeward .	29.116339
the new mate was robert bylot , talented but inexperienced .	57.330864
there were other shifts and pay cuts according to the way individuals had conducted themselves .	228.963
the important result , however , was that juet and francis clemens , the deposed boatswain , became hudson ' s sworn enemies .	63.955338
as hudson resumed his desperate criss-crossing of the little bay , every incident lessened the crew ' s respect for him .	85.33158
once , after the discovery lay for a week in rough weather , hudson ordered the anchor raised before the sea had calmed .	89.60067
just as it was being hauled inboard , a sea hit the ship .	80.75684
michael butt and adame moore were thrown off the capstan and badly injured .	21.892002
the anchor cable would have been lost overboard , but philip staffe was on hand to sever it with his axe .	59.15274
thomas douglas , fifth earl of selkirk , a noble humanitarian scot concerned with the plight of the crofters of his native highlands , conceived a plan to settle them in the valley of the red river of the north .	44.032818
since the land he desired lay within the great northern empire of the hudson ' s bay company , he purchased great blocks of the comany ' s stock with the view to controlling its policies .	64.98179
having achieved this end , he was able to buy 116 , 000 square miles in the valleys of the red and assiniboine rivers .	17.768234
the grant , which stretched southward to lake traverse -- the headwaters of the red -- was made in may , 1811 , and by october of that year a small group of scots was settling for the winter at york factory on hudson bay .	72.971855
thus at the same time that william henry harrison was preparing to pacify the aborigines of indiana territory and winning fame at the battle of tippecanoe , anglo-saxon settlement made a great leap into the center of the north american continent to the west of the american agricultural frontier .	33.04499
seven hundred miles south of york factory , at `` the forks ' ' of the red and the assiniboine , twenty-three men located a settlement in august 1812 .	44.141388
by october the little colony about fort douglas ( present-day winnipeg ) numbered 100 .	35.154392
within a few years the scots , engaged in breaking the thick sod and stirring the rich soil of the valley , were joined by a group called meurons .	43.916557
the latter , members of two regiments of swiss mercenaries transported by great britain to canada to fight the americans in the war of 1812 , had settled in montreal and kingston at the close of the war in 1815 .	55.025867
selkirk persuaded eighty men and four officers to go to red river where they were to serve as a military force to protect his settlers from the hostile northwest company which resented the intrusion of farmers into the fur traders ' empire .	84.81894
the mercenaries were little interested in farming and added nothing to the output of the farm plots on which all work was still done with hoes as late as 1818 .	128.14326
it was the low yield of the selkirk plots and the ravages of grasshoppers in 1818 that led to the dispersal of the settlement southward .	31.252945
when late in the summer the full extent of the damage was assessed , all but fifty of the scots , swiss and metis moved up the red to the mouth of the pembina river .	40.503056
here they built huts and a stockade named fort daer after selkirk ' s barony in scotland .	50.189426
the new site was somewhat warmer than fort douglas and much closer to the great herds of buffalo on which the settlement must depend for food .	92.56943
the selkirk settlers had been anticipated in their move southward by british fur traders .	42.207317
for many years the northwest company had its southern headquarters at prairie du chien on the mississippi river , some 300 miles southeast of present-day st . paul , minnesota .	30.729435
when in 1816 an act of congress forced the foreign firm out of the united states , its british-born employees , now become american citizens -- joseph rolette , joseph renville and alexis bailly -- continued in the fur business .	68.18368
on big stone lake near the headwaters of the red river , robert dickson , superintendent of the western indian department of canada , had a trading post and planned in 1818 to build a fort to be defended by twenty men and two small artillery pieces .	51.616367
his trading goods came from canada to the forks of red river and from selkirk ' s settlement he brought them south in carts .	76.925896
these carts were of a type devised in pembina in the days of alexander henry the younger about a decade before the selkirk colony was begun .	125.72528
in 1802 henry referred to `` our new carts ' ' as being about four feet off the ground and carrying five times as much as a horse could pack .	66.3533
they were held together by pegs and withes and in later times drawn by a single ox in thills .	140.63132
it was dickson who suggested to lord selkirk that he return to the atlantic coast by way of the united states .	29.101593
in september 1817 at fort daer ( pembina ) dickson met the noble lord whom , with the help of a band of sioux , he escorted to prairie du chien .	51.888462
during the trip selkirk decided that the route through illinois territory to indiana and the eastern united states was the best route for goods from england to reach red river and that the united states was a better source of supply for many goods than either canada or england .	82.38667
upon arriving at baltimore , selkirk on december 22 wrote to john quincy adams , secretary of state at washington , inquiring about laws covering trade with `` missouri and illinois territories ' ' .	104.046
this traffic , he declared prophetically , `` tho ' it might be of small account at first , would increase with the progress of our settlements .	130.93794
the route which he had traveled and which he believed might develop into a trade route was followed by his settlers earlier than he might have expected .	141.63397
in 1819 grasshoppers again destroyed the crop at `` the forks ' ' ( fort douglas ) and in december 1819 , twenty men left fort daer for the most northerly american outpost at prairie du chien .	24.137604
it was a three-month journey in the dead of winter followed by three months of labor on mackinac boats .	130.39432
with these completed and ice gone from the st . peter ' s river ( present-day minnesota river ) their 250 bushels of wheat , 100 bushels of oats and barley and 30 bushels of peas and some chickens were loaded onto the flat-bottomed boats and rowed up the river to big stone lake , across into lake traverse , and down the red .	37.84493
this epic effort to secure seed for the colony cost selkirk ab1 , 040 .	132.96738
nevertheless so short was the supply of seed that the settlers were forced to retreat to fort daer for food .	59.47505
thereafter seed and food became more plentiful and the colony remained in the north the year round .	59.196873
activity by british traders and the presence of a colony on the red prompted the united state war department in 1819 to send lieutenant-colonel henry leavenworth from detroit to put a post 300 miles northwest of prairie du chien , until then the most advanced united states post .	74.56948
in september 1822 two companies of infantry arrived at the mouth of the st . peter ' s river , the head of navigation on the mississippi , and began construction of fort st . anthony which , upon completion , was renamed in honor of its commander , colonel josiah snelling .	42.054474
it was from the american outposts that red river shortages of livestock were to be made good .	37.106777
hercules l . dousman , fur trader and merchant at prairie du chien , contracted to supply selkirk ' s people with some 300 head of cattle , and alexis bailly and francois labothe were hired as drovers .	45.58805
bailly , after leaving fort snelling in august 1821 , was forced to leave some of the cattle at the hudson ' s bay company ' s post on lake traverse `` in the sieux country ' ' and reached fort garry , as the selkirk hudson ' s bay company center was now called , late in the fall .	42.88154
he set out on his 700-mile return journey with five families of discontented and disappointed swiss who turned their eyes toward the united states .	74.578514
observing their distressing condition , colonel snelling allowed these half-starved immigrants to settle on the military reservation .	53.66158
as these swiss were moving from the selkirk settlement to become the first civilian residents of minnesota , dousman of michilimackinac , michigan , and prairie du chien was traveling to red river to open a trade in merchandise .	46.76834
early in 1822 he was at fort garry offering to bring in pork , flour , liquor and tobacco .	75.60039
alexander mcdonnell , governor of red river , and james bird , a chief factor of the hudson ' s bay company , ordered such `` sundry articles ' ' to a value of ab4 , 500 .	49.254692
for its part the hudson ' s bay company was troubled by the approach of american settlement .	61.24729
as the time drew near for the drawing of the british-american frontier by terms of the agreement of 1818 , the company suspected that the pembina colony -- its own post and fort daer -- was on american territory .	58.584675
accordingly selkirk ' s agents ordered the settlers to move north , and by october , john halkett had torn down both posts , floating the timber to `` the forks ' ' in rafts .	53.86225
`` i have done everything ' ' , he wrote , `` to break up the whole of that unfortunate establishment .	54.866386
' ' despite company threats , duly carried through , to cut off supplies of powder , ball , and thread for fishing nets , about 350 persons stayed in the village .	84.20998
they would attempt to bring supplies from st . louis or prairie du chien at `` great expense as well as danger ' ' .	26.957258
at fort garry some of the swiss also decided to cast their lot with the united states , and in 1823 several families paid guides to take them to fort snelling .	88.11426
the disasters of 1825-1826 caused more to leave .	7.2678185
after heavy rains and an onslaught of mice , snow fell on october 15 , 1825 , and remained on the ground through a winter so cold that the ice on the red was five feet thick .	78.5846
in april came a rapid thaw that produced high waters which did not recede until mid-june .	74.19569
on june 24 more than 400 families started the three-month trip across the plains to the mississippi .	68.85342
by fall , 443 survivors of this arduous journey were clustered about fort snelling , but most of them were sent on to galena and st . louis , with a few going as far as vevay , indiana , a notable swiss center in the united states .	41.297714
in 1837 , 157 red river people with more than 200 cattle were living on the reservation at fort snelling .	57.583168
below the fort , high bluffs extended uninterruptedly for six miles along the mississippi river .	34.83978
at the point where they ended , another settlement grew up around a chapel built at the boat landing by father lucian galtier in 1840 .	128.1962
its people , including pierre bottineau and other american fur company employees and the refugees from fort garry , were joined by the remaining scots and swiss from fort snelling when major joseph plympton expelled them from the reservation in may 1840 .	62.922623
the resultant town , platted in 1847 and named for the patron of father galtier ' s mission , st . paul , was to become an important center of the fur trade and was to take on a new interest for those selkirkers who remained at red river .	56.576164
while population at fort garry increased rapidly , from 2 , 417 in 1831 to 4 , 369 in 1840 , economic opportunities did not increase at a similar rate .	59.9734
accordingly , though the practice violated the no-trading provision of the selkirk charter which reserved all such activity in merchandise and furs to the hudson ' s bay company , some settlers went into trade .	77.91288
the company maintained a store at which products of england could be purchased and brought in goods for the new merchants on the understanding that they refrain from trading in furs .	147.72357
despite this prohibiton , by 1844 some of the fort garry merchants were trading with the indians for furs .	46.164047
in june 1845 , the governor and council of assiniboia imposed a 20 per cent duty on imports via hudson ' s bay which were viewed as aimed at the `` very vitals of the company ' s trade and power ' ' .	69.47751
to reduce further the flow of goods from england , the company ' s local officials asked that its london authorities refrain from forwarding any more trade goods to these men .	99.86934
with their customary source of supply cut off , the fort garry free traders engaged three men to cart goods to them from the mississippi country .	151.34958
others carried pemmican from `` the forks ' ' to st . paul and goods from st . paul to red river , as in the summer of 1847 when one trader , wells , transported twenty barrels of whisky to the british settlement .	59.904236
this trade was subject to a tariff of 7 . 5 per cent after february 1835 , but much was smuggled into assiniboia with the result that the duty was reduced by 1841 to 4 per cent on the initiative of the london committee .	46.910667
the trade in a few commodities noted above was to grow in volume as a result of changes both north and south of the 49th parallel .	111.56057
the letters of the common soldiers are rich in humor .	97.16409
indeed , no richer humor is to be found in the whole of american literature than in the letters of the semi-literate men who wore the blue and the gray .	56.26892
some of their figures of speech were colorful and expressive .	21.845192
a confederate observed that the yankees were `` thicker than lise on a hen and a dam site ornraier ' ' .	24.486034
another reported that his comrades were `` in fine spirits pitching around like a blind dog in a meat house ' ' .	92.83345
a third wrote that it was `` raining like poring peas on a rawhide ' ' .	16.47526
one wrote `` ( i am so hungry ) i could eat a rider off his horse & snap at the stirups ' ' .	61.56035
a second reported that the dilapidated houses in virginia `` look like the latter end of original sin and hard times ' ' .	132.18526
a third remarked of slowness of southerners `` they moved about from corner to corner , as uneasy as a litter of hungry leaches on the neck of a wooden god ' ' .	78.73674
still another , annoyed by the brevity of a recently received missive , wrote `` yore letter was short and sweet , jist like a roasted maget ' ' .	60.75991
a yankee sergeant gave the following description of his sweetheart `` my girl is none of your one-horse girls .	139.60387
she is a regular stub and twister , double geered .	64.902016
she is well-educated and refined , all wildcat and fur , and union from the muzzle to the crupper ' ' .	43.942585
a texan wrote to a male companion at home `` what has become of halda and laura ? ?	105.53713
when you see them again give them my love -- not best respects now , but love by god ' ' .	103.18783
william r . stillwell , an admirable georgian whose delightful correspondence is preserved in the georgia department of archives and history , liked to tease his wife in his letters .	68.027016
after he had been away from home about a year he wrote `` ( dear wife ) if i did not write and receive letters from you i believe that i would forgit that i was married .	59.074127
i don ' t feel much like a maryed man but i never forgit it sofar as to court enny other lady but if i should you must forgive me as i am so forgitful ' ' .	80.449486
a yank , disturbed by his increasing corpulence , wrote `` i am growing so fat i am a burden 2 myself ' ' .	73.27825
another yank parodied the familiar bedtime prayer `` now i lay me down to sleep , the gray-backs o ' er my body creep	163.69943
if they should bite before i wake , i pray the lord their jaws to break ' ' .	54.550385
charles thiot , a splendid georgia soldier , differed from most of his comrades in the ranks in that he was the owner of a large plantation , well-educated , and nearly fifty years of age .	33.254494
but he was very much like his associates in his hatred of camp routine .	170.34941
near the end of his service he wrote that when the war was over he was going to buy two pups , name one of them `` fall-in ' ' and the other `` close-up ' ' , and then shoot them both , `` and that will be the end of fall-in and close-up ' ' .	39.528664
the soldiers who comprised the rank and file of the civil war armies were an earthy people .	115.823296
they talked and wrote much about the elemental functions of the body .	31.518372
one of the most common of camp maladies was diarrhoea .	93.82917
men of more delicate sensibilities referred to this condition as `` looseness of the bowels ' '	29.21205
but a much more common designation was `` the sh-ts ' ' .	6.4602475
a michigan soldier stationed in georgia wrote in 1864	78.39085
`` i expect to be tough as a knott as soon as i get over the georgia shitts ' ' .	35.43781
johnny rebs from the deep south who were plagued with diarrhoea after transfer to the virginia front often informed their families that they were suffering from the `` the virginia quickstep ' ' .	98.63539
a georgia soldier gave his wife the following description of the cause and consequence of diarrhoea `` i have bin a little sick with diorah two or three days .	102.69515
it sowered ( on ) my stomack and turn loose on me ' ' .	33.41283
a michigan soldier wrote his brother `` i am well at present with the exception i have got the dyerear and i hope thease few lines find you the same ' ' .	84.32007
the letters which poured forth from camps were usually written under adverse circumstances .	64.18505
save for brief periods in garrison or winter quarters , soldiers rarely enjoyed the luxury of a writing desk or table .	240.80106
most of the letters were written in the hubbub of camp , on stumps , pieces of bark , drum heads , or the knee .	102.51755
in the south , after the first year of the war , paper and ink were very poor .	48.868893
scarcity of paper caused many southerners to adopt the practice of cross-writing , i . e . , after writing from left to right of the page in the usual manner , they gave the sheet a half turn and wrote from end to end across the lines previously written .	160.57301
sometimes soldiers wrote letters while bullets were whizzing about their heads .	39.55438
a yank writing from vicksburg , may 28 , 1863 , stated `` not less than 50 balls have passed over me since i commenced writing .	151.37029
i could tell you of plenty narrow escapes , but we take no notice of them now ' ' .	27.279594
a reb stationed near petersburg informed his mother `` i need not tell you that i dodge pretty often for you can see that very plainly by the blots in this letter .	105.58339
just count each blot a dodge and add in a few for i don ' t dodge every time ' ' .	36.946117
another reb writing under similar circumstances before atlanta reported `` the yankees keep shooting so i am afraid they will knock over my ink , so i will close ' ' .	117.35673
the most common type of letter was that of soldier husbands to their wives .	86.771835
but fathers often addressed communications to their small children	109.51537
and these , full of homely advice , are among the most human and revealing of civil war letters .	118.51112
rebs who owned slaves occasionally would include in their letters admonitions or greetings to members of the negro community .	39.454693
early in the war it was not uncommon for planters ' sons to retain in camp negro `` body servants ' ' to perform the menial chores such as cooking , foraging , cleaning the quarters , shining shoes , and laundering clothes .	116.1722
sometimes these servants wrote or dictated for enclosure with the letters of their soldier-masters messages to their relatives and to members of their owners ' families .	72.68695
unmarried soldiers carried on correspondence with sweethearts at home .	10.941363
owing to the restrained usages characteristic of 19th-century america , these letters usually were stereotyped and revealed little depth of feeling .	131.3109
occasionally gay young blades would write vividly to boon companions at home about their amorous exploits in richmond , petersburg , washington , or nashville .	78.86299
an alabama soldier whose feminine associations were of the more admirable type wrote boastfully of his achievements among the virginia belles `` they thout i was a saint .	109.678635
i told them some sweet lies and they believed it all .	69.157814
i would tell them i got a letter from home stating that five of my negroes had runaway and ten of pappy ' s .	59.97509
but i wold say i recond he did not mind it for he had a plenty more left and then they would lean to me like a sore eyd kitten to a basin of milk ' ' .	54.65629
an ohio soldier who , from a comrade just returned from leave , received an unfavorable comment on the conduct of his sister , took pen in hand and delivered himself thus `` dear sis .	115.07302
alf sed he heard that you and hardy was a runing together all the time and he though he wod gust quit having any thing mor to doo with you for he thought it was no more yuse .	121.73319
i think you made a dam good chouise to turn off as nise a feler as alf dyer and let that orney thefin , drunkard , damed card playing sun of a bich com to sea you , the god damed theaf and lop yeard pigen tode helion , he is too orney for hel .	66.34843
i will shute him as shore as i sea him ' ' .	25.923481
initiation into combat sometimes elicited from soldier correspondents choice comments about their experiences and reactions .	126.14035
a federal infantryman wrote to his father shortly after his first skirmish in virginia `` dear pa .	35.350975
we got to one house where there were five secessionists .	107.444695
they brok & run and arch holored out to shoot the ornery suns of biches and we all let go at them .	64.57563
thay may say what they please but godamit pa it is fun ' ' .	28.084036
some of the choicest remarks made by soldiers in their letters were in disparagement of unpopular officers .	74.01893
a mississippi soldier wrote `` our general reub davis is a vain , stuck-up , illiterate ass ' ' .	16.284826
an alabamian wrote `` col . henry is ( an ignoramus ) fit for nothing higher than the cultivation of corn ' ' .	55.982075
a floridian stated that his officers were `` not fit to tote guts to a bear ' ' .	49.778065
on december 9 , 1862 , sergeant edwin h . fay , an unusual louisianan who held a . b . and m . a . degrees from harvard university and who before the war was headmaster of a private school for boys in louisiana , wrote his wife `` i saw pemberton and he is the most insignificant puke i ever saw .	55.43489
his head cannot contain enough sense to command a regiment , much less a corps .	76.97602
jackson runs first and his cavalry are well drilled to follow their leader .	141.64769
but he is a west point graduate and therefore must be born to command ' ' .	74.35825
similar comments about officers are to be found in the letters of northern soldiers .	41.642517
a massachusetts soldier , who seems to have been a civil war version of bill mauldin , wrote `` the officers consider themselves as made of a different material from the low fellows in the ranks .	95.35176
they get all the glory and most of the pay and don ' t earn ten cents apiece on the average , the drunken rascals ' ' .	34.441734
private george gray hunter of pennsylvania wrote `` i am well convinced in my own mind that had it not been for officers this war would have ended long ago ' ' .	71.1359
another yankee became so disgusted as to state `` i wish to god one half of our officers were knocked in the head by slinging them against ( the other half ) ' ' .	125.485954
no group of officers came in for more spirited denunciation than the doctors .	63.94171
one federal soldier wrote `` the docters is no aconte -- hell will be filde with do ( c ) ters and offersey when this war is over ' ' .	67.55681
shortly after the beginning of sherman ' s georgia campaign , an ailing yank wrote his homefolk `` the surgeon insisted on sending me to the hospital for treatment .	70.8998
i insisted on takeing the field and prevailed -- thinking that i had better die by rebel bullets than ( by ) union quackery ' ' .	206.65758
the attitudes which the rebs and yanks took toward each other were very much the same and ranged over the same gamut of feeling , from friendliness to extreme hatred .	101.32217
the rebs were , to a massachusetts corporal , `` fighting madmen or not men at all but whiskey & gunpowder put into a human frame ' ' .	98.11948
a pennsylvania soldier wrote that `` they were the hardest looking set of men that ever i saw .	182.83485
they looked as if they had been fed on vinegar and shavings .	22.11211
' ' private jenkins lloyd jones of the wisconsin light artillery wrote in his diary `` i strolled among the alabamans on the right , found some of the greenest specimens of humanity i think in the universe , their ignorance being little less than the slave they despise with as imperfect a dialect .	86.31193
they recooned as how you ' uns all would be a heap wus to we ' uns all ' ' ' .	33.349323
in a similar vein , but writing from the opposite side , thomas taylor , a private in the 6th alabama volunteers , in a letter to his wife , stated `` you know that my heart is with you but i never could have been satisfied to have staid at home when my country is invaded by a thievin foe , by a set of cowardly skunks whose motto is booty .	52.48291
the popularity of folklore in america stands in direct proportion to the popularity of nationalism in america .	39.79766
and the emphasis on nationalism in america is in proportion to the growth of american influence across the world .	43.318474
thus , if we are to observe american folklore in the twentieth century , we will do well to establish the relationships between folklore , nationalism and imperialism at the outset .	28.107239
historians have come to recognize two cardinal facts concerning nationalism and international influence .	133.72314
1 ) every age rewrites the events of its history in terms of what should have been , creating legends about itself that rationalize contemporary beliefs and excuse contemporary actions .	182.38495
what actually occurred in the past is seldom as important as what a given generation feels must have occurred .	144.5962
2 ) as a country superimposes its cultural and political attitudes on others , it searches its heritage in hopes of justifying its aggressiveness .	133.6724
its folklore and legend , usually disguised as history , are allowed to account for group actions , to provide a focal point for group loyalty , and to become a cohesive force for national identification .	87.770775
one can apply these facts to britain in the late eighteenth and nineteenth centuries as she spread her dominion over palm and pine , and they can be applied again to the united states in more recent years .	44.198097
the popularity of local color literature before the spanish-american war , the steady currency of the lincoln myth , the increased emphasis on the frontier west in our mass media are cases in point .	89.4428
nor is it an accident that baseball , growing into the national game in the last 75 years , has become a microcosm of american life , that learned societies such as the american folklore society and the american historical association were founded in the 1880s , or that courses in american literature , american civilization , american anything have swept our school and college curricula .	95.69657
of course , nationalism has really outlived its usefulness in a country as world-oriented as ours , and its continued existence reflects one of the major culture lags of the twentieth-century united states .	81.13832
yet nationalism has lost few of its charms for the historian , writer or man in the street .	74.21684
it is an understandable paradox that most american history and most american literature is today written from an essentially egocentric and isolationistic point of view at the very time america is spreading her dominion over palm and pine .	72.322
after all , the average american as he lies and waits for the enemy in korea or as she scans the newspaper in some vain hope of personal contact with the front is unconcerned that his or her plight is the result of a complex of personal , economic and governmental actions far beyond the normal citizen ' s comprehension and control .	115.13217
anyone ' s identification with an international struggle , whether warlike or peaceful , requires absurd oversimplification and intense emotional involvement .	73.33477
such identification comes for each group in each crisis by rewriting history into legend and developing appropriate national heroes .	526.4923
in america , such self-deception has served a particularly useful purpose .	171.9757
a heterogeneous people have needed it to attain an element of cultural and political cohesion in a new and ever-changing land .	49.454105
but we must never forget , most of the appropriate heroes and their legends were created overnight , to answer immediate needs , almost always with conscious aims and ends .	299.4105
parson weems ' s george washington became the symbol of honesty and the father image of the uniting states .	86.12445
abraham lincoln emerged as an incarnation of the national constitution .	81.809685
robert e . lee represented the dignity needed by a rebelling confederacy .	18.1603
and their roles are paralleled by those of patrick henry , nathan hale , andrew jackson , davy crockett , theodore roosevelt and many , many more .	74.37318
therefore , the scholar , as he looks at our national folklore of the last 60 years , will be mindful of two facts .	77.150566
1 ) most of the legends that are created to fan the fires of patriotism are essentially propagandistic and are not folk legends at all .	161.48706
2 ) the concept that an `` american national folklore ' ' exists is itself probably another propagandistic legend .	93.68771
folklore is individually created art that a homogeneous group of people preserve , vary and recreate through oral transmission .	110.14062
it has come to mean myths , legends , tales , songs , proverbs , riddles , superstitions , rhymes and such literary forms of expression .	26.63917
related to written literature , and often remaining temporarily frozen in written form , it loses its vitality when transcribed or removed from its oral existence .	218.12804
though it may exist in either literate or illiterate societies , it assumes a role of true cultural importance only in the latter .	74.98917
in its propagandistic and commercial haste to discover our folk heritage , the public has remained ignorant of definitions such as this .	108.91669
enthusiastically , americans have swept subliterary and bogus materials like paul bunyan tales , abe lincoln anecdotes and labor union songs up as true products of our american oral tradition .	132.98456
nor have we remembered that in the melting pot of america the hundreds of isolated and semi-isolated ethnic , regional and occupational groups did not fuse into a homogeneous national unit until long after education and industrialization had caused them to cast oral tradition aside as a means of carrying culturally significant material .	97.236855
naturally , such scholarly facts are of little concern to the man trying to make money or fan patriotism by means of folklore .	102.79583
that much of what he calls folklore is the result of beliefs carefully sown among the people with the conscious aim of producing a desired mass emotional reaction to a particular situation or set of situations is irrelevant .	128.16978
as long as his material is americana , can in some way be ascribed to the masses and appears `` democratic ' ' to his audience , he remains satisfied .	119.21261
from all this we can now see that two streams of development run through the history of twentieth-century american folklore .	81.178375
on the one side we have the university professors and their students , trained in teutonic methods of research , who have sought out , collected and studied the true products of the oral traditions of the ethnic , regional and occupational groups that make up this nation .	75.56456
on the other we have the flag-wavers and the national sentimentalists who have been willing to use any patriotic , `` frontier western ' ' or colonial material willy-nilly .	90.57229
unfortunately , few of the artists ( writers , movie producers , dramatists and musicians ) who have used american folklore since 1900 have known enough to distinguish between the two streams even in the most general of ways .	129.06853
after all , the field is large , difficult to define and seldom taught properly to american undergraduates .	244.73604
in addition , this country has been settled by many peoples of many heritages and their lore has become acculturated slowly , in an age of print and easy communication , within an ever-expanding and changing society .	87.30012
for that matter , the experts themselves are a mixed breed .	77.601166
anthropologists , housewives , historians and such by profession , they approach their discipline as amateurs , collectors , commercial propagandists , analysts or some combination of the four .	97.25731
they have little `` esprit de corps ' ' .	1.8929442
the outlook for the amateur , for instance , is usually dependent on his fondness for local history or for the picturesque .	87.429886
his love of folklore has romanticism in it , and he doesn ' t care much about the dollar-sign or the footnote .	37.86997
folklore is his hobby , and he , all too rightly , wishes it to remain as such .	209.38664
the amateur is closely related to the collector , who is actually no more than the amateur who has taken to the field .	43.655697
he hunts folklore for the very `` field and stream ' ' reasons that many persons hunt game	223.4676
and only rarely is he acutely concerned with the meaning of what he has located .	35.994972
fundamentally , both these types , the amateur and the collector , are uncritical and many of them don ' t distinguish well between real folklore and bogus material .	58.75844
but there are also the commercial propagandists and the analysts -- one dominated by money , the other by nineteenth-century german scholarship .	157.60043
both are primarily concerned with the uses that can be made of the material that the collector has found .	43.11793
both shudder at the thought of proceeding too far beyond the sewage system and the electric light lines .	86.40515
the commercial propagandist , who can ' t afford to be critical , gets along well with the amateur , from whom he feeds , but he frequently steps on the analyst ' s toes by refusing to keep his material genuine .	122.89904
his standards are , of course , completely foreign to those of the analyst .	171.93347
to both the amateur and the commercial progandist the analyst lacks a soul , lacks appreciation with his endless probings and classifications .	88.526764
dominated by the vicious circle of the university promotion system , the analyst looks down on and gets along poorly with the other three groups , although he cannot deny his debt to the collector .	111.94168
the knowledge that most americans have of folklore comes through contact with commercial propagandists and a few energetic amateurs and collectors .	61.30453
the work done by the analysts , the men who really know what folklore is all about , has no more appeal than any other work of a truly scientific sort and reaches a limited , learned audience .	141.30742
publishers want books that will sell , recording studios want discs that will not seem strange to ears used to hillbilly and jazz music , grade and high schools want quaint , but moral , material .	204.6001
the analyst is apt to be too honest to fit in .	115.22955
as a result , most people don ' t have more than a vague idea what folklore actually is	90.05736
they see it as a potpourri of charming , moral legends and patriotic anecdotes , with a superstition or remedy thrown in here and there .	82.13786
and so well is such ignorance preserved by the amateur and the money-maker that even at the college level most of the hundred-odd folklore courses given in the united states survive on sentiment and nationalism alone .	114.81458
if one wishes to discuss a literary figure who uses folklore in his work , the first thing he must realize is that the literary figure is probably part of this ignorant american public .	95.5616
and while every writer must be dealt with as a special case , the interested student will want to ask himself a number of questions about each .	91.41382
does the writer know the difference between an `` ersatz ' ' ballad or tall tale and a true product of the folk ? ?	66.50985
when the writer uses material does he tamper with it to improve its commercial effect or does he leave it pure ? ?	147.62498
is he swept away by sentiment and nostalgia for an america that was ? ?	151.4396
or does he sincerely want to tap the real springs of american attitude and culture regardless of how unpopular and embarrassing they may be ? ?	309.43655
when he gets the answers to his questions he will be discouraged .	45.733665
in the first place , a good many writers who are said to use folklore , do not , unless one counts an occasional superstition or tale .	78.18952
robert frost , for instance , writes about rural life in new england , but he does not include any significant amount of folklore in his poems .	48.47703
this has not , however , prevented publishers from labeling him a `` folk poet ' ' , simply because he is a rural one .	42.3419
in the second place , a large number of writers , making a more direct claim than frost to being `` folk writers ' ' of one sort or another , clearly make no distinctions between genuine and bogus material .	88.090645
stephen vincent benet ' s john brown ' s body comes immediately to mind in this connection , as does john steinbeck ' s the grapes of wrath and carl sandburg ' s the people , yes .	65.404785
the last two writers introduce strong political bias into their works , and not unlike the union leaders that we will discuss soon , see folklore as a reservoir of protest by a downtrodden and publically silenced mass .	85.80251
folklore , as used by such writers , really reflects images engraved into it by the very person using it .	276.7479
the folk are simply not homogeneous with respect to nation or political attitude .	114.31643
in fact , there is much evidence to indicate they don ' t care a bit about anything beyond their particular regional , ethnic and occupational limits .	117.516045
nevertheless , with a reading public that longs for the `` good old days ' ' and with an awareness of our expanding international interests , it is easy for the benets to obtain a magnified position in literature by use of all sorts of americana , real or fake , and it is easy for the steinbecks and sandburgs to support their messages of reform by reading messages of reform into the minds of the folk .	57.37213
as part of the same arrangement , torrio had , in the spirit of peace and good will , and in exchange for armed support in the april election campaign , bestowed upon o ' banion a third share in the hawthorne smoke shop proceeds and a cut in the cicero beer trade .	117.73995
o ' banion was a complex and frightening man , whose bright blue eyes stared with a kind of frozen candour into others ' .	53.067417
he had a round , frank irish face , creased in a jovial grin that stayed bleakly in place even when he was pumping bullets into someone ' s body .	63.39805
he carried three guns -- one in the right trouser pocket , one under his left armpit , one in the left outside coat pocket -- and was equally lethal with both hands .	67.175186
he killed accurately , freely , and dispassionately .	21.249771
the police credited him with twenty-five murders but he was never brought to trial for one of them .	44.119293
like a fair number of bootleggers he disliked alcohol .	121.864395
he was an expert florist , tenderly dextrous in the arrangement of bouquets and wreaths .	38.562935
he divided humanity into `` right guys ' ' and `` wrong guys ' ' , and the wrong ones he was always willing to kill and trample under .	35.013367
he had what was described by a psychologist as a `` sunny brutality ' ' .	15.339828
he walked with a heavy list to the right , as that leg was four inches shorter than the other , but the lurch did not reduce his feline quickness with his guns .	51.322952
landesco thought him `` just a superior sort of plugugly ' ' but he was , in fact , with his aggression and hostility , and nerveless indifference to risking or administering pain , a casebook psychopath .	25.85004
he was also at this time , although not so interwoven in high politics and the rackets as torrio and capone , the most powerful and most dangerous mob leader in the chicago underworld , the roughneck king .	66.54506
o ' banion was born in poverty , the son of an immigrant irish plasterer , in the north side ' s little hell , close by the sicilian quarter and death corner .	58.237022
he had been a choir boy at the holy name cathedral and also served as an acolyte to father o ' brien .	60.39927
the influence of mass was less pervasive than that of the congested , slum tenements among the bawdy houses , honkytonks , and sawdust saloons of his birthplace	50.216152
he ran wild with the child gangs of the neighbourhood , and went through the normal pressure-cooker course of thieving , police-dodging , and housebreaking .	27.581463
at the age of ten , when he was working as a newsboy in the loop , he was knocked down by a streetcar which resulted in his permanently shortened leg .	73.52785
because of this he was known as gimpy ( but , as with capone and his nickname of scarface , never in his presence ) .	74.5495
in his teens o ' banion was enrolled in the vicious market street gang and he became a singing waiter in mcgovern ' s cafe , a notoriously low and rowdy dive in north clark street , where befuddled customers were methodically looted of their money by the singing waiters before being thrown out .	73.119125
he then got a job with the chicago herald-examiner as a circulation slugger , a rough fighter employed to see that his paper ' s news pitches were not trespassed upon by rival vendors .	48.419277
he was also at the same time gaining practical experience as a safe breaker and highwayman , and learning how to shoot to kill from a neanderthal convicted murderer named gene geary , later committed to chester asylum as a homicidal maniac , but whose eyes misted with tears when the young dion sang a ballad about an irish mother in his clear and syrupy tenor .	51.503483
o ' banion ' s first conflict with the police came in 1909 , at seventeen , when he was committed to bridewell prison for three months for burglary	61.098526
two years later he served another three months for assault .	111.92011
those were his only interludes behind bars , although he collected four more charges on his police record in 1921 and 1922 , three for burglary and one for robbery .	165.31827
but by now o ' banion ' s political pull was beginning to be effective .	138.00145
on the occasion of his 1922 indictment the $10 , 000 bond was furnished by an alderman , and the charge was nolle prossed .	36.54149
on one of his 1921 ventures he was actually come upon by a detective sergeant john j . ryan down on his knees with a tool embedded in a labour office safe in the postal telegraph building	103.064644
the jury wanted better evidence than that and he was acquitted , at a cost of $30 , 000 in bribes , it was estimated .	29.916056
as promptly as torrio , o ' banion jumped into bootlegging .	9.943328
he conducted it with less diplomacy and more spontaneous violence than the sicilians , but he had his huge north side portion to exploit and he made a great deal of money .	71.00871
unlike the sicilians , he additionally conducted holdups , robberies , and safe-cracking expeditions , and refused to touch prostitution .	27.872686
he was also personally active in ward politics , and by 1924 o ' banion had acquired sufficient political might to be able to state `` i always deliver my borough as per requirements ' ' .	85.615906
until 1924 o ' banion pistoleers and knuckle-duster bullyboys had kept his north side domain solidly democratic .	207.49533
there was a question-and-answer gag that went around at that time q . `` who ' ll carry the forty-second and forty-third wards ' ' ? ?	23.401505
a . o ' banion , in his pistol pocket ' ' .	8.479823
but as november 1924 drew close the democratic hierarchy was sorely troubled by grapevine reports that o ' banion was being wooed by the opposition , and was meeting and conferring with important republicans .	61.49252
to forestall any change of allegiance , the democrats hastily organised a testimonial banquet for o ' banion , as public reward for his past services and as a reminder of where his loyalties lay .	88.497185
the reception was held in a private dining room of the webster hotel on lincoln park west .	117.00002
it was an interesting fraternisation of ex-convicts , union racketeers , ward heelers , sold-out officials , and gunmen .	41.163303
the guest list is in itself a little parable of the state of american civic life at this time .	33.23434
it included the top o ' banion men and chief of detectives michael hughes .	153.9356
when mayor dever heard of the banquet he summoned hughes for an explanation of why he had been dishonouring the police department by consorting with these felons and fixers .	56.929157
hughes said that he had understood the party was to be in honour of jerry o ' connor , the proprieter of a loop gambling house .	90.19965
`` but when i arrived and recognised a number of notorious characters i had thrown into the detective bureau basement half a dozen times , i knew i had been framed , and withdrew almost at once ' ' .	93.72082
in fact , o ' connor was honoured during the ceremony with the presentation of a $2500 diamond stickpin .	34.754967
there was a brief interruption while one of o ' banion ' s men jerked out both his guns and threatened to shoot a waiter who was pestering him for a tip .	56.679016
then o ' banion was presented with a platinum watch set with rubies and diamonds .	31.152174
this dinner was the start of a new blatancy in the relationship between the gangs and the politicians , which , prior to 1924 , says pasley , `` had been maintained with more or less stealth ' ' , but which henceforth was marked by these ostentatious gatherings , denounced by a clergyman as `` belshazzar feasts ' ' , at which `` politicians fraternized cheek by jowl with gangsters , openly , in the big downtown hotels ' ' .	37.90488
pasley continued `` they became an institution of the chicago scene and marked the way to the moral and financial collapse of the municipal and county governments in 1928-29 ' ' .	81.180855
however , this inaugural feast did its sponsors no good whatever .	198.9468
o ' banion accepted his platinum watch and the tributes to his loyalty , and proceeded with the bigger and better republican deal .	134.53008
on election day -- november 4 -- he energetically marshalled his force of bludgeon men , bribers , and experts in forging repeat votes .	70.36658
the result was a landslide for the republican candidates .	11.552262
this further demonstration of o ' banion ' s ballooning power did not please torrio and capone .	44.67921
in the past year there had been too many examples of his euphoric self-confidence and self-aggrandisement for their liking .	47.161316
