a simpler method was to tie a thread tightly around the wart at its base and wear it this way .	70.29209
one person recommended to me washing the wart with sulphur water	126.632416
another said it should be rubbed with a cut potato three times daily .	326.9979
another common method was to cut an onion in two and place each half on the wart for a moment	57.97033
the onion was then fastened together with string and placed beneath a dripping eave .	30.850912
as the onion decayed , so did the wart .	18.62437
sore feet by calf ' s-foot , an herb from the pioneer ' s ubiquitous herb garden , or by soaking the feet in a pan of hot water in which two cups of salt had been dissolved .	48.233143
leg cramps , one person tells me , were relieved by standing barefoot with the weight of the body on the heel and pressing down hard .	75.54154
this does give relief , as i can testify .	48.065437
one doctor prescribed a tablespoon of whiskey or brandy before each meal for leg cramps .	34.616867
pains in the back of the leg and in the abdomen were prevented from reaching the upper body by tying a rope about the patient ' s waist .	42.230373
for sprains and swellings , one pint of cider vinegar and half a pint of spirits of turpentine added to three well beaten eggs was said to give speedy relief .	76.429375
except for the wine waiter in a restaurant -- always an inscrutable plenipotentiary unto himself , the genii with the keys to unlock the gates of the wine world are one ' s dealer , and the foreign shipper or negociant who in turn supplies him .	117.02245
in instances where both of these are persons or firms with integrity , the situation is ideal .	110.66501
it may , on occasion , be anything but that .	193.08559
however , by cultivating a wine dealer and accepting his advice , one will soon enough ascertain whether he has any knowledge of wines ( as opposed to what he may have been told by salesmen and promoters ) and , better yet , whether he has a taste for wine .	108.121765
again , by spreading one ' s purchases over several wine dealers , one becomes familiar with the names and specialties of reputable wine dealers and shippers abroad .	116.437065
this is important because , despite all the efforts of the french government , an appreciable segment of france ' s export trade in wines is still tainted with a misrepresentation approaching downright dishonesty , and there are many too many negociants who would rather turn a sou than amass a creditable reputation overseas .	55.918526
a good negociant or shipper will not only be the man or the firm which has cornered the wines from the best vineyards , or the best parts of them	74.57418
he may also be the one who makes and bottles the best blends -- sound wines from vineyards generally in his own district .	226.89214
these are the wines the french themselves use for everyday drinking , for even in france virtually no one drinks the grands crus on a meal-to-meal basis .	97.6408
the grands crus are expensive , and even doting palates tire of them .	12.593063
and certainly , in the case of the beginner or the comparatively uninitiated wine drinker , the palate and the capacity for appreciation will not be ready for the grands crus as a steady diet without frequent recourse to crus of less renown .	106.69917
there is nothing infra dig about a good blend from a good shipper .	52.59733
some of them are very delicious indeed , and there are many good ones exported -- unfortunately , along with others not so good , and worse .	85.349525
consultation with a reputable wine dealer and constant experimentation -- `` steering ever from the known to the unknown ' ' -- are the requisites .	74.136024
especially if one is travelling or dining out a great deal , their importance mounts .	69.047005
most of them , the world over , operate on the same principle by which justice is administered in france and some other latin countries the customer is to be considered guilty of abysmal ignorance until proven otherwise , with the burden of proof on the customer himself .	100.35799
now the drinking of wine ( and happily so ! !	110.25149
) is for the most part a recondite affair , for manifestly , if everyone in the world who could afford the best wines also liked them , the supply would dry up in no time at all .	109.25682
this is the only valid , and extenuating , argument that may be advanced in defense of the reprehensible attitude of the common wine waiter .	65.91251
a really good wine waiter is , paradoxically , the guardian ( and not the purveyor ) of his cellar against the visigoths .	72.347046
faced , on the one hand , with an always exhaustible supply of his best wines , and on the other by a clientele usually equipped with inexhaustible pocketbooks , it is a wonder indeed that all wine waiters are not afflicted with chronic ambivalence .	47.655598
the one way to get around them -- short of knowing exactly what one wants and sticking to it -- is to frequent a single establishment until its wine waiter is persuaded that one is at least as interested in wine as in spending money .	188.72252
only then , perhaps , will he reveal his jewels and his bargains .	67.055084
wine bought from a dealer should ideally be allowed to rest for several weeks before it is served .	50.632286
this is especially true of red wines , and a practice which , though not always practicable , is well worth the effort .	119.56637
it does no harm for wine to stand on end for a matter of days , but in terms of months and years it is fatal .	58.80847
wine stored for a long time should be on its side	292.1776
otherwise , the cork dries and air enters to spoil it .	13.342524
when stacking wine on its side in a bin , care should always be taken to be sure there is no air bubble left next to the cork .	55.648724
fat bottles , such as burgundies , have a way of rolling around in the bin and often need little props , such as a bit of cardboard or a chip of wood , to hold them in the proper reclining posture .	56.23692
too much dampness in the cellar rots the corks , again with ill effects .	209.16989
the best rule of thumb for detecting corked wine ( provided the eye has not already spotted it ) is to smell the wet end of the cork after pulling it if it smells of wine , the bottle is probably all right	149.02495
if it smells of cork , one has grounds for suspicion .	761.8952
seasonal rises or drops in temperature are bad for wine they age it prematurely .	316.4348
the ideal storage temperature for long periods is about fifty-five degrees , with an allowable range of five degrees above or below this , provided there are no sudden or frequent changes .	73.57551
consequently , one ' s wine closet or cellar should be away from machines or electrically driven furnaces .	61.68559
if one lives near a subway or an express parkway , the solution is to have one ' s wines stored with a dealer and brought home a few at a time .	59.63067
light , especially daylight , is always bad for wine .	21.953457
all in all , though , there is a good deal of nonsense expended over the preparations thought necessary for ordinary wine drinking	131.21745
many people go to extreme lengths in decanting , chilling or warming , or banishing without further investigation any bottle with so much as a slightly suspicious cork .	62.271244
no one should wish to deny these purists the obvious pleasure they derive from all this , and to give fair warning where warning is due , no one who becomes fond of wines ever avoids acquiring some degree of purism ! !	145.607
but the fact remains that in most restaurants , including some of the best of paris and bordeaux and dijon , the bottle is frankly and simply brought from the cellar to the table when ordered , and all the conditioning or preparation it ever receives takes place while the chef is preparing the meal .	126.86081
a white wine , already at cool cellar temperature , may be adequately chilled in a bucket of ice and water or the freezing compartment of a refrigerator ( the former is far preferable ) in about fifteen minutes	44.925903
for those who live in a winter climate , there is nothing better than a bucket of water and snow .	19.031635
though by no means an ideal procedure , a red wine may similarly be brought from the cellar to the dining room and opened twenty minutes or so before serving time .	59.74927
but again , as one will have observed at any restaurant worth its salt , wine should be served in a large , tulip-shaped glass , which is never filled more than half full .	76.34644
in this way , red wine warms of itself quite rapidly -- and though it is true that it may not attain its potential of taste and fragrance until after the middle of the meal ( or the course ) , in the meantime it will have run the gamut of many beguiling and interesting stages .	68.17532
the only cardinal sin which may be committed in warming a wine is to force it by putting it next to the stove or in front of an open fire .	104.22744
this invariably effaces any wine ' s character , and drives its fragrance underground .	143.07663
it should not be forgotten that wines mature fastest in half-bottles , less fast in full bottles , slowly in magnums -- and slower yet in tregnums , double magnums , jeroboams , methuselahs , and imperiales , respectively .	50.304913
very old red wines often require several hours of aeration , and any red wine , brought from the cellar within half an hour of mealtime , should be uncorked and allowed some air .	61.91293
white wines should be opened when served , having been previously chilled in proportion to their sweetness .	108.79201
thus , sauternes or barsacs should be very cold	169.22197
a pouilly-fuisse or a chablis somewhat less cold .	3.492853
over-chilling is an accepted method for covering up the faults of many a cheap or poor white wine , especially a dry wine -- and certainly less of a crime than serving a wine at a temperature which reveals it as unattractive .	105.40496
the fragrance and taste of any white wine will die a lingering death when it is allowed to warm or is exposed for long to the air .	118.48671
to quote professor saintsbury `` the last glass of claret or burgundy is as good as the first	49.295067
but the first glass of chateau d ' yquem or montrachet is a great deal better than the last ' ' ! !	24.089897
this does not mean , though , that a red wine improves with prolonged aeration there is a reasonable limit -- and wines kept over to the next meal or the next day , after they have once been opened , are never as good .	82.972206
if this must be done , they should always be corked and kept in a cool place	147.8971
it should be remembered that their lasting qualities are appreciably shorter than those of milk .	32.33619
a few red wines , notably those of the beaujolais , are better consumed at cellar temperature .	59.88233
by tradition , a red wine should be served at approximately room temperature -- if anything a little cooler -- and be aged enough for the tannin and acids to have worked out and the sediment have settled well .	164.74255
thus , red wine must , if possible , never be disturbed or shaken	237.20326
very old red wine is often decanted so that the puckering , bitter elements which have settled to the bottom will not be mingled with the wine itself .	95.24075
a tug-of-war between an old bottle and an inefficient corkscrew may do as much harm as a week at sea .	66.17746
the cork should be pulled gradually and smoothly , and the lip of the bottle wiped afterward .	50.93574
many people use wicker cradles for old red wine , lifting the bottle carefully from the bin into the cradle and eventually to the table , without disturbing the sediment .	83.76248
another school frowns on such a shortcut , and insists that after leaving the bin an old red wine should first stand on end for several days to allow the sediment to roll to the very bottom , after which the bottle may be gently eased to a tilted position on its side in the cradle .	92.806046
in france , when one wishes to entertain at a restaurant and serve truly fine old red wines , one visits the restaurant well ahead of time , chooses the wines and , with the advice of the manager and his chef , builds the menu around them .	115.308266
the wine waiter will see to it that the bottles are taken from the bin and opened at least in time to warm and aerate , preferably allowed to stand on end for as long as possible and , perhaps in the case of very old wines , be decanted .	76.693214
it may also be -- practically speaking -- a matter of good economy .	65.35587
for , in the process of decanting , the bottle is only tilted once instead of several or more times at the table hence , a minimum of the undesirable mixture of wine and dregs .	83.06377
though there are many exceptions , which we have noted in preceding pages , white wine is as a rule best consumed between two and six years old , and red wines , nowadays , between three and ten .	122.47397
red wines of good years tend to mature later and to keep longer	125.04496
the average claret is notably longer-lived than its opposite number , red burgundy .	360.73895
some clarets do not come into their own until they are ten or fifteen years of age , or even more .	37.794586
if a red bordeaux of a good name and year is bitter or acid , or cloying and muddy-tasting , leave it alone for a while .	133.99486
most of the wines of beaujolais , on the other hand , should be drunk while very young	59.92992
giffen replied punctually and enthusiastically `` rest assured that your accompanying letter of instructions shall be in the letter and spirit strictly complied with and most particularly in regard to that part of them relative to the completion of your noble and humane views ' ' .	109.081024
giffen lost no time in visiting the plantation .	3.5615888
the slaves appeared to be in good health and at work under john palfrey ' s overseer .	55.81466
william , who lived in neighboring st . mary ' s parish , had taken charge and decided that it would be best for all if the plantation were operated for another year .	55.368687
giffen advised acceptance of this plan , citing the depressed market for land then prevailing and the large stock of provisions at the plantation .	158.9319
if sold then , the land and improvements might bring only $5 , 000 .	85.495224
early in january , 1844 he had a conference with henry and william in new orleans , and upon learning of gorham ' s intention , henry remonstrated calmly but firmly with his brother .	69.04944
the emancipation plan would not only be injurious to all the heirs , he contended , but would be a form of cruelty perpetrated on the hapless negroes .	49.34168
they were not capable of supporting themselves off the plantation , and louisiana law required their removal from the state .	66.154015
gorham refused to accept money for slave property , but did he realize how much expense and trouble the transportation of his negroes to the north involved ? ?	109.66007
the suggestion that giffen hire out the slaves was not realistic , since no planter would take the risk of having negroes who knew they were to be free living with his own slaves .	78.830315
henry hid his annoyance , although both he and william were furious with their yankee brother .	126.02846
william , who did not write to gorham , told giffen that unless he could operate the plantation as usual for a year , he would sue `` amicably ' ' to protect his interests .	52.64631
palfrey was determined that his portion of the slaves be converted to wage laborers during the transition period before emancipation .	111.74953
if william wished to continue operations for a year , why not simply leave the negroes undisturbed and pay them `` as high wages to remain there as are ever paid the labor of persons of their sex & age .	258.9737
a disposition to exert themselves for my benefit would perhaps be a motive with some of them to come into the scheme .	71.26165
their having family ties on our plantation & the adjoining one would be a stronger inducement ' ' .	82.992744
when he heard of his brothers ' anger , palfrey was still hopeful that they could be persuaded to accept his notion of paying wages .	46.359756
if not , he was willing to accede to william ' s wishes in any way that did not block his ultimate aim .	81.79131
william was adamant on one point under no circumstances would he allow the negroes to remain on the plantation with his and henry ' s slaves if they were told of their coming freedom .	68.25274
knowing the antipathy that existed in louisiana against increasing the number of free negroes , giffen suggested that palfrey bring them to boston at once , and then send them on to liberia .	88.87774
lacking specific instructions , he agreed to william ' s condition .	22.24736
in march there was a division of the slaves , and giffen carried out his instructions as nearly as possible .	68.31202
of the fifty-two slaves , giffen succeeded in getting a lot of twenty , twelve of whom were females .	85.96439
`` i considered that your views would be best carried out ' ' , he explained , `` by taking women whose progeny will of course be free & more fully extend the philantrophy of emancipation .	107.11147
i have also taken the old servants of your father as a matter of conscience & justice ' ' .	81.70914
the ages of the slaves ranged from sixty-five , for an old house servant , to an unnamed newborn child .	33.486385
if palfrey ever had any doubts about the wickedness of slavery , they were put aside after he received an inventory of the slave property he had inherited .	71.03049
this cold reckoning of human worth in a legal paper , devoid of compassion or humanity , was all he needed .	126.13073
each human being , known only by a given name , had a cash value .	153.56638
old sam ' s sixty-five years had reduced his value to $150	262.1776
rose , a twelve-year-old with child-bearing potential , was worth $400 .	35.19162
in rejecting any claim to the value of the slave property , palfrey was giving up close to $7 , 000 .	46.956886
palfrey ' s brothers each received lots of sixteen negroes , and for bookkeeping purposes it was agreed that all lots were to be valued at $6 , 666 . 66 .	49.46045
thus twenty `` black souls ' ' were to remain ignorant of their imminent journey to the land of free men .	45.122276
giffen extracted one concession from william the house servants could be free at any time gorham thought expedient .	138.53021
despite giffen ' s warning , palfrey still had plans for freeing his slaves in louisiana .	98.102875
yet even if he could get the necessary approval , fourteen of his negroes could not be manumitted without special permission .	98.1317
according to state law a slave had to be at least thirty years old before he could be freed .	29.096243
palfrey petitioned the state legislature to waive the requirement .	110.26942
otherwise , freedom would mean removal from the state in which `` as the place of their past residence from birth , or for many years , it would be materially for their advantage to be at liberty to remain ' ' .	62.406464
on march 11 the louisiana legislature voted unanimously to table the petition .	57.221207
news of the legislative veto appeared in the new orleans papers , and henry and william became incensed by the fact that they had not been told of the attempt in advance .	44.215908
henry stormed into giffen ' s office waving a copy of the new orleans courier , shouting that the emancipation scheme had become a public affair , and that it would reach the `` ears of the people on the plantation , and make them restless & unhappy ' ' .	40.0899
his brothers ' anger caused palfrey genuine concern , for he had imposed a dual mission upon himself to free his slaves , and to keep the family from falling apart over the issue .	81.33502
when giffen decided to charge him interest on the loan from john palfrey , gorham readily assented , vowing that in a matter of dollars and cents , his brothers would never have any cause to complain of him .	71.815636
in view of these difficulties , palfrey decided to go to louisiana .	32.040176
giffen had already urged him to journey south , if only for a few days to clear up matters .	74.46494
his duties as massachusetts secretary of state obliged him to wait until the adjournment of the legislature in mid-april .	32.613293
palfrey told his wife of his intentions for the first time , and left for new orleans apprehensively invoking a special blessing of providence that he might be allowed to see his family again .	44.571392
during his journey palfrey stopped off to see two abolitionists .	209.06917
in both cases he desired information about placing the freedmen in homes once they arrived in the north .	68.78897
in new york , lydia maria child welcomed him enthusiastically `` i have lately heard of you from the legislature of louisiana , and felt joy at your public recognition of the brotherhood of man ' ' .	79.96327
mrs . child , who had once apologized for sending editor palfrey a book on slavery , now confided that she had helped one of henry palfrey ' s slaves escape to canada some years before , but asked him not to advertise the fact in louisiana .	115.596306
she agreed to take charge of five or six of the negroes should palfrey decide to send them north immediately .	111.955345
at lexington , kentucky , palfrey consulted with cassius m . clay on the same subject , but with no apparent result .	51.554
despite his apprehensions about his personal safety , palfrey ' s reception in new orleans was more than cordial .	36.488407
instead of the expected `` annoyances ' ' due to the nature of his mission , he received many calling cards and invitations from `` gentlemen of mark , on whom i had no sort of claim , & have had many more invitations than i could accept ' ' .	95.2076
he later told abolitionist edmund quincy of the `` marked attention and civility ' ' with which the new orleans gentlemen and the upriver planters greeted him .	57.831814
the memory of this southern hospitality did not survive the trials of coming antislavery years and civil war .	88.03119
palfrey ' s autobiography contains a melodramatic account of two perilous days spent among the planters of attakapas , `` many of whom were coarse & passionate people , much excited by what they heard of my plans ' ' .	80.42161
he proceeded with his task bravely -- in his memoirs , at least -- before the `` passions of my neighbors should have time to boil too high ' ' .	59.096836
palfrey had already made up his mind that he would allow the men , but not the women , to choose freely whether or not to go north for freedom .	104.41692
the women by remaining behind condemned their children , born and unborn , to bondage .	25.53785
he had a short private talk with each adult slave .	281.15015
only one objected , but palfrey soon convinced him that he ought to go with the others .	36.32395
all the slaves joined in requesting that they be allowed to delay their departure until the end of the planting season , so that they could get in `` their own little produce ' ' .	70.108284
the slaves were to remain as wage laborers for his account .	79.94334
william ' s threat that under no conditions would he allow `` freedom-conscious ' ' slaves to mix with his own was not carried out , for the plantation continued in operation as before .	97.29034
palfrey returned to massachusetts greatly relieved to have made an arrangement `` so satisfactory to my judgment & my conscience ' ' .	72.32569
from cambridge , palfrey maintained a close interest in the welfare of his slaves .	35.74992
in fact , as the time for their departure approached , his solicitousness increased .	160.08014
should any slave change his mind and request to leave earlier , giffen was to provide passage at once .	163.63333
when a sailing date of march , 1845 was finally established , palfrey made sure that the negroes would have comfortable quarters in new orleans and aboard ship .	101.528915
giffen assured him that the captain and his mate had personally promised to treat the negroes with consideration .	275.3601
palfrey was also concerned about the question of what wage to pay for their labor throughout 1844 .	229.46051
the plantation was sold in january , 1845 , and palfrey thought the new owner ought to pay his people two months ' wages .	122.72488
giffen suggested fifty dollars as fair compensation for a year ' s work	23.637236
the new owner at attakapas declined to enter into any philanthropic arrangement .	94.922165
on march 21 , 1845 the bark bashaw weighed anchor at new orleans , while on the levee henry and william palfrey waved farewell to their father ' s former chattels who must have looked back at the receding shore with mingled regret and jubilation .	55.16277
not all of palfrey ' s slaves were aboard the bashaw .	148.22101
giffen had advised that it would not be too difficult to obtain freedom locally for the old house servants .	55.286057
two of these were included in palfrey ' s lot .	22.010962
giffen filed a petition for permission to emancipate four slaves ( all more than fifty years old ) with the st . martin ' s parish police jury .	59.995308
after an initial rejection , which he attributed to a `` general excitement against abolition and emancipation ' ' , giffen bribed the right individuals on the jury , and got the permission without further delay .	50.17513
when the negroes landed at boston a month later they were , of course , no longer slaves .	28.379076
slavery was prohibited in massachusetts by the terms of the constitution of 1780 , which declared `` all men are born free and equal ' ' .	23.12144
nevertheless , palfrey arranged a religious ceremony at king ' s chapel to formalize the emancipation .	48.06251
an eyewitness recalled how awkward the red-turbaned colored women appeared as they curtseyed in the church doorway , and the diffidence the former slaves displayed while they listened to the few words that declared them free .	128.33192
once the question of emancipation was settled to palfrey ' s satisfaction , he faced a real problem in placing the freedmen in suitable homes as servants .	117.168465
palfrey tried fruitlessly to place a negro boy in the hopedale community , but he had better luck in his other attempts .	63.00501
mrs . child , true to her word , helped place anna and her four children with a quaker family named hathaway near canandaigua , new york .	101.81651
this group had been palfrey ' s greatest worry since anna was in bad health , and her children were too young to work for their keep .	80.80419
but certainly the new frontier has brought to washington a group more varied in background and interest .	263.54108
secretary of state dean rusk , a former rhodes scholar and mills college dean , has headed the rockefeller foundation and in that role expended large sums for international cultural exchange .	102.19561
one of his initial acts in office was to appoint philip coombs of the ford foundation as the first assistant secretary of state for educational and cultural affairs .	50.78085
( `` in the late forties and fifties ' ' , coombs has declared in defining his role , `` two strong new arms were added to reinforce united states foreign policy economic assistance and military assistance .	107.49906
as we embark upon the sixties we have an opportunity to build a third strong arm , aimed at the development of people , at the fuller realization of their creative human potential , and a better understanding among them ' ' .	63.985687
many of the new appointees are art collectors .	4.3859496
ambassador-at-large averell harriman has returned to the capital with a collection of paintings that include renoir , cezanne , gauguin , van gogh , toulouse-lautrec , degas , matisse , picasso , and walt kuhn .	15.758006
the director of the peace corps , r . sargent shriver , jr . , a kennedy brother-in-law , collects heavily among the moderns , including kenzo okada and josef albers .	19.60585
secretary of the treasury douglas dillon owns a prize monet , femmes dans un jardin .	19.553188
secretary of defense robert mcnamara , former president of the ford motor company , comes from a generation different from that of eisenhower ' s own first secretary of defense , charles wilson , who had been head of general motors .	54.38026
unlike wilson , who at times seemed almost anti-intellectual in his earthy pragmatism .	19.332617
an inveterate reader of books , he chose while working in detroit to live in the university community of ann arbor , almost forty miles away .	72.509056
he selected as comptroller of defense , not a veteran accountant , but a former rhodes scholar , charles hitch , who is author of a study on the economics of defense in the nuclear age .	42.042393
one of the president ' s special assistants , the harvard dean mcgeorge bundy , was co-author with henry l . stimson of the latter ' s classic memoir , on active service .	36.649277
another , arthur m . schlesinger , jr . , has won a pulitzer prize in history	10.964934
his wife , marion , is a portrait painter .	7.494045
the press secretary , pierre salinger , was a child prodigy as a pianist .	45.337524
( `` it is always of sorrow to me when i find people who neither know nor understand music ' ' , he declared not long ago in proposing that white house prizes be awarded for music and art .	102.66631
) mrs . arthur goldberg , wife of the secretary of labor , paints professionally and helps sponsor the associated artists ' gallery in the district of columbia .	68.39827
( `` artists are always at a new frontier ' ' , she claims .	35.170807
`` in fact , the search is almost more important than the find ' ' .	17.840853
) mrs . henry labouisse , wife of the new director of the foreign aid program , is the writer and lecturer eve curie .	34.364567
at last count , sixteen former rhodes scholars ( see box on page 13 ) had been appointed to the administration , second in number only to its harvard graduates .	124.7924
besides schlesinger , the justice department ' s information director , edwin guthman , has won a pulitzer prize ( for national reporting ) .	40.400208
postmaster general j . edward day , who must deal with matters of postal censorship , is himself author of a novel , bartholf street , albeit one he was obliged to publish at his own expense .	127.30536
william walton , a writer-turned-painter , has been a long-time friend of the president .	24.954485
they arrived in washington about the same time during the early postwar years kennedy as the young congressman from massachusetts	81.14765
walton , after a wartime stint with time-life , to become bureau chief for the new republic .	122.12931
both lived in georgetown , were unattached , and shared an active social life .	116.781364
walton , who soon made a break from journalism to become one of the capital ' s leading semi-abstract painters , vows that he and kennedy never once discussed art in those days .	129.19826
during last year ' s campaign , kennedy asked walton , an utter novice in organization politics , to assist him .	99.85681
walton dropped everything to serve as a district co-ordinator in the hard-fought wisconsin primary and proved so useful that he was promoted to be liaison officer to critically important new york city .	62.296753
walton , who served as a correspondent with general james gavin ' s paratroopers during the invasion of france , combines the soul of an artist with the lingo of a tough guy .	57.458424
he provoked outraged editorials when , after a post-inaugural inspection of the white house with mrs . kennedy , he remarked to reporters , `` we just cased the joint to see what was there ' ' .	41.566177
already the president and the first lady have deputized him to advise on matters ranging from the furnishing of the white house to the renovation of lafayette square .	40.775066
a man of great talent , he will continue to serve as a sort of presidential trouble-shooter , strictly ex officio , for culture .	43.611786
a more official representative is the secretary of the interior .	7.507702
udall , who comes from one of the mormon first-families of arizona , is a bluff , plain-spoken man with a lust for politics and a habit of landing right in the middle of the fight .	44.597015
but even while sparring furiously with republican politicians , he displays a deep and awesome veneration for anyone with cultural attainments .	92.15292
his private dining room has become a way station for visiting intellectuals such as c . p . snow , arnold toynbee , and aaron copland .	84.105675
udall argues that interior affairs should cover a great deal more than dams and wildlife preserves .	32.154823
after promoting frost ' s appearance at the inauguration , he persuaded the poet to return several months later to give a reading to a select audience of cabinet members , members of congress , and other washington notables gathered in the state department auditorium .	68.88681
the event was so successful that the interior secretary plans to serve as impresario for similar ones from time to time , hoping thereby to add to the cultural enrichment of the administration .	68.60618
his ideas in this respect , however , sometimes arouse critical response .	420.05643
one tempest was stirred up last march when udall announced that an eight-and-a-half-foot bronze statue of william jennings bryan , sculpted by the late gutzon borglum , would be sent `` on indefinite loan ' ' to salem , illinois , bryan ' s birthplace .	38.570362
spokesmen for the nation ' s tradition-minded sculptors promptly claimed that udall was exiling the statue because of his own hostility to this art form .	100.38182
they dug up a speech he had made two years earlier as a congressman , decrying the more than two hundred statues , monuments , and memorials which `` dot the washington landscape as patriotic societies and zealous friends are constantly hatching new plans ' ' .	100.28293
hoping to cut down on such works , udall had proposed that a politician be at least fifty years departed before he is memorialized .	82.04318
he is not likely to win this battle easily .	239.5533
in the case of the borglum statue an interior aide was obliged to announce that there had been a misunderstanding and that the secretary had no desire to `` hustle ' ' it out of washington .	46.415863
the last congress adopted seven bills for memorials , including one to taras shevchenko , the ukrainian poet laureate	34.650692
active warfare is raging between the forces pressing for a monument to the first roosevelt on theodore roosevelt island in the potomac , and tr . ' s own living children , who wish to preserve the island as a wildlife sanctuary .	58.299957
the hotly debated plan for the capital ' s franklin d . roosevelt memorial , a circle of huge tablets engraved with his speeches ( and promptly dubbed by one of its critics , `` instant stonehenge ' ' ) , is another of udall ' s headaches , since as supervisor of the national parks commission he will share in the responsibility for building it .	61.763435
`` washington ' ' , president kennedy has been heard to remark ironically , `` is a city of southern efficiency and northern charm ' ' .	66.18677
there have been indications that he hopes to redress that situation , commencing with the white house .	79.932434
one of mrs . kennedy ' s initial concerns as first lady was the sad state of the furnishings in a building which is supposed to be a national shrine .	76.82824
ever since the fire of 1812 destroyed the beautiful furniture assembled by president thomas jefferson , the white house has collected a hodgepodge of period pieces , few of them authentic or aesthetic .	130.02786
mrs . kennedy shows a determination to change all this .	88.72915
not long after moving in she turned up a richly carved desk , hewed from the timbers of the british ship h . m . s . resolute and presented to president hayes by queen victoria .	69.35533
it now serves the president in his oval office .	47.432552
later , browsing in an old issue of the gazette des beaux-arts , she found a description of a handsome gilt pier-table purchased in 1817 by president james monroe .	51.749226
with its coating of gold radiator paint removed -- a gaucherie of some earlier tenant -- it will now occupy its rightful place in the oval blue room on the first floor of the white house .	52.984444
but it soon became clear that the search for eighteenth-century furniture ( which mrs . kennedy feels is the proper period for the white house ) must be pursued in places other than government storage rooms .	160.48979
the first lady appointed a fine arts advisory committee for the white house , to locate authentic pieces as well as to arrange ways to acquire them .	33.250706
her effort to put the home of living presidents on the same basis as mount vernon and monticello recognizes no party lines .	126.69142
by rough estimate her committee , headed by henry francis du pont , contains three times as many republicans as democrats .	88.8899
the press releases emanating from the white house give a clue to the activity within .	150.45065
a valuable pencil-and-sepia allegorical drawing of benjamin franklin by jean-honore fragonard has been donated by the art dealer georges wildenstein and now hangs in the blue room .	43.092854
the american institute of interior designers is redecorating the white house library .	10.072306
secretary and mrs . dillon have contributed enough pieces of empire furniture , including dolley madison ' s own sofa , to furnish a room in that style .	46.283344
and part of a fabulous collection of vermeil hollowware , bequeathed to the white house by the late mrs . margaret thompson biddle , has been taken out of its locked cases and put on display in the state dining room .	41.31223
woman ' s place is in the home man must attend to matters of the yard .	144.80742
one of the vexatious problems to first confront president kennedy was the property lying just across pennsylvania avenue from the white house .	88.32383
congress had already appropriated money , and plans were well along to tear down the buildings flanking lafayette square and replace them with what one critic calls the `` marble monumentality ' ' of government office buildings .	58.946323
while a senator , kennedy had unsuccessfully pushed a bill to preserve the belasco theater , as well as the dolley madison and the benjamin taylor houses , all scheduled for razing .	49.409073
what to do about it now that he was president ? ?	85.32113
only a few days after moving into the white house .	12.444238
kennedy made a midnight inspection of the square .	2.9663641
then he called in his friend walton and turned over the problem to him , with instructions to work out what was best -- provided it didn ' t pile unnecessary burdens on the president .	74.55455
one of the offices slated for reconstruction is the aged court of claims , diagonally across the street from the white house .	52.031994
but judge marvin jones , senior member of the court , is an elderly gentleman who lives at the nearby metropolitan club and desires to walk to work .	71.86051
more importantly , he also happens to be the brother-in-law of sam rayburn , speaker of the house .	23.600536
there were aesthetic problems as well as political .	145.03448
on delving deeper , walton discovered that most of the buildings fronting the square could be classified as `` early nondescript ' ' .	40.590572
the old belasco theater , over which many people had grown sentimental , was only a shell of its former self after arduous years as a uso center .	120.804634
the dolley madison house , walton concluded , was scarcely worth preserving .	241.11382
`` the attempt to save the square ' s historic value ' ' , he declares , `` came half a century too late ' ' .	38.148754
surrounded by ancient elms , the campus is spacious and beautiful .	56.938225
the dartmouth student does not live in monastic seclusion , as he once did .	31.394968
but his is still a simple life relatively free of the female presence or influence , and he must go far , even though he may go fast , for sophisticated pleasures .	75.85116
he is still heir to the rare gifts of space and silence , if he chooses to be .	51.04922
he is by no means the country boy he might have been in the last century , down from the hills with bear grease on his hair and a zeal for book learning in his heart .	83.162964
the men ' s shops on hanover ' s main street compare favorably with those in princeton and new haven .	59.205963
and the automobiles that stream out of hanover each weekend , toward smith and wellesley and mount holyoke , are no less rakish than those leaving cambridge or west philadelphia .	88.3072
but there has always been an outdoor air to dartmouth .	282.5387
the would-be sophisticate and the citybred youth adopt this air without embarrassment .	662.36597
no one here pokes fun at manly virtues .	6.8798656
and this gives rise to an easy camaraderie probably unequaled elsewhere in the ivy league .	83.16134
thus , when dartmouth ' s winter carnival -- widely recognized as the greatest , wildest , roaringest college weekend anywhere , any time -- was broadcast over a national television hookup , prexy john sloan dickey appeared on the screen in rugged winter garb , topped off by a tam-o ' -shanter which he confessed had been acquired from a smith girl .	91.5524
president dickey ' s golden retriever , frolicking in the snow at his feet , added to the picture of masculine informality .	55.18358
this carefree disdain for `` side ' ' cropped up again in the same television broadcast .	69.479095
dean thaddeus seymour , wearing ski clothes , was crowning a beauteous damsel queen of the carnival .	20.436628
she must have looked temptingly pretty to the dean as he put the crown on her head .	153.32552
dartmouth students enjoy other unusual diversions with equal sang-froid .	2.4778016
for example , groups regularly canoe down the connecticut river .	86.90856
this is in honor of john ledyard , class of 1773 , who scooped a canoe out of a handy tree and first set the course way back in his own student days .	110.35621
and these hardy travelers are not unappreciated today .	3.5529666
they are hailed by the nation ' s press , and smith girls throng the riverbanks at northampton and refresh the voyageurs with hot soup and kisses .	74.87069
dartmouth ' s favorite and most characteristic recreation is skiing .	47.87155
since the days when their two thousand pairs of skis outnumbered those assembled anywhere else in the united states , the students have stopped regarding the olympic ski team as another name for their own .	84.13752
yet dartmouth still is the dominant member of the intercollegiate ski union , which includes the winter sports colleges of canada as well as those of this country .	31.156027
dartmouth students ski everywhere in winter , starting with their own front door .	76.52956
they can hire a horse and go ski-joring behind him , or move out to oak hill , where there ' s a lift .	58.456566
the dartmouth skiway , at holt ' s ledge , ten miles north of the campus , has one of the best terrains in the east , ranging from novice to expert .	49.219368
forty miles farther north is mount moosilauke , dartmouth ' s own mountain .	34.029057
here , at the ravine lodge , president dickey acts as host every year to about a hundred freshmen who are being introduced by the dartmouth outing club to life on the trails .	87.55458
the lodge , built of hand-hewn virgin spruce , can handle fifty people for dining , sleeping , or lounging in its huge living room .	74.29687
the outing club also owns a chain of fourteen cabins and several shelters , extending from the vermont hills , just across the river from the college , through hanover to the college grant -- 27 , 000 acres of wilderness 140 miles north up in the logging country .	53.254932
the cabins are equipped with bunks , blankets , and cooking equipment and are ideal bases for hikes and skiing trips .	46.807705
the club runs regular trips to the cabins , but many of the students prefer to take off in small unofficial groups for a weekend of hunting , fishing , climbing , or skiing .	29.15595
under the auspices of the outing club , dartmouth also has the mountaineering club , which takes on tough climbs like mount mckinley , and bait & bullet , whose interests are self-evident , and even sports a woodman ' s team , which competes with other new england colleges in wood sawing and chopping , canoe races , and the like .	71.93494
there is much to be said for a college that , while happily attuned to the sophisticated ivies , still gives its students a chance to get up early in the morning and drive along back roads where a glimpse of small game , deer , or even bear is not uncommon .	126.09338
city boys find a lot of learning in the feel of an ax handle or in the sharp tang of a sawmill , come upon suddenly in a backwoods logging camp .	94.0483
and on the summit of mount washington , where thirty-five degrees below zero is commonplace and the wind velocity has registered higher than anywhere else in the world , there is a kind of wisdom to be found that other men often seek in the himalayas `` because it is there ' ' .	62.088184
there is much to be said for such a college -- and dartmouth men have been accused of saying it too often and too loudly .	93.638405
their affection for their college home has even caused president dickey to comment on this `` place loyalty ' ' as something rather specially hanoverian .	161.1535
probably a lawyer once said it best for all time in the supreme court of the united states .	15.580707
early in the nineteenth century the state of new hampshire was casting about for a way to found its own state university .	181.67822
it fixed on dartmouth college , which was ready-made and just what the proctor ordered .	386.2325
the legislators decided to `` liberate ' ' dartmouth and entered into a tug-o ' -war with the college trustees over the control of classrooms , faculty , and chapel .	66.443214
for a time there were two factions on the campus fighting for possession of the student body .	65.158806
the struggle was resolved in 1819 in the supreme court in one of the most intriguing cases in our judicial history .	36.209484
in 1817 the lawyers were generally debating the legal inviolability of private contracts and charters .	70.78728
a lawyer , hired by the college , was arguing specifically for dartmouth daniel webster , class of 1801 , made her plight the dramatic focus of his whole plea .	146.67606
in an age of oratory , he was the king of orators , and both he himself and chief justice marshall were bathed in manly tears , as uncle dan ' l reached his thundering climax	74.558075
`` it is , sir , as i have said , a small college , and yet there are those who love it .	66.31461
dartmouth is today still a small college -- and still a private one , thanks to webster ' s eloquence .	94.371025
this is not out of keeping with its origins , probably the most humble of any in the ivy group .	68.90729
eleazar wheelock , a presbyterian minister , founded the school in 1769 , naming it after the second earl of dartmouth , its sponsor and benefactor .	98.432144
eleazar , pausing on the hanover plain , found its great forests and remoteness good and with his own hands built the first college hall , a log hut dedicated `` for the education & instruction of youth of the indian tribes in this land in reading , writing & all parts of learning which shall appear necessary and expedient for civilizing & christianizing children of pagans as well as in all liberal arts and sciences	147.89265
and also of english youth and any others ' ' .	4.4399524
it was a hardy undertaking , and wheelock ' s was indeed `` a voice crying in the wilderness ' ' .	34.49005
a road had to be hacked through trackless forests between hanover and portsmouth to permit governor wentworth and a company of gentlemen to attend the first dartmouth commencement in 1771 .	68.87805
the governor and his retinue thoughtfully brought with them a glorious silver punchbowl which is still one of the cherished possessions of the college .	31.965672
the exuberance on this occasion set a standard for subsequent dartmouth gatherings .	398.98737
a student orator `` produced tears from a great number of the learned ' ' even before the punch was served .	80.52621
then from the branches of a near-by tree an indian underclassman , disdaining both the platform and the english language , harangued the assemblage in his aboriginal tongue .	50.205944
governor wentworth contributed an ox for a barbecue on the green beneath the three-hundred-foot pines , and a barrel of rum was broached .	27.782825
the cook got drunk , and president wheelock proved to be a man of broad talents by carving the ox himself .	69.95464
future commencements were more decorous perhaps , but the number of graduates increased from the original four at a relatively slow pace .	76.04129
by the end of the nineteenth century , in 1893 , when the big three , columbia , and penn were populous centers of learning , dartmouth graduated only sixty-nine .	165.52942
the dormitories , including the beloved dartmouth hall , could barely house two hundred students in spartan fashion .	187.99788
then in 1893 dr . william jewett tucker became president and the college ' s great awakening began .	69.49779
he transformed dartmouth from a small new hampshire institution into a national college .	115.06555
by 1907 the number of undergraduates had risen to 1 , 107 .	7.673544
and at his last commencement , in that year , dr . tucker and dartmouth were honored by the presence of distinguished academic visitors attesting to the new stature of the college .	47.88805
the presidents of cornell , wisconsin , c . c . n . y . , bowdoin , vermont , brown , columbia , princeton , yale , and harvard and the presidents emeritus of harvard and michigan were there .	20.335152
dartmouth is numerically still a small college today , with approximately twenty-nine hundred undergraduates .	52.626667
but it has achieved a cross-section of students from almost all the states , and two-thirds of its undergraduates come from outside new england .	89.80414
over 450 different schools are usually represented in each entering class .	74.28195
only a dozen or so schools send as many as six students , and there are seldom more than fifteen men in any single delegation .	60.665504
about two-thirds of the boys now come from public schools .	43.300644
it is still a college only and not a university	119.12925
it is , in fact , the only college in the ivy group .	89.14837
however , three distinguished associated graduate schools offer professional curriculums -- the dartmouth medical school ( third oldest in the country and founded in 1797 ) , the thayer school of engineering , and the amos tuck school of business administration .	73.34187
all three are purposely kept small , with a current total enrollment of about two hundred .	126.16604
all three schools coordinate their educational programs with that of the undergraduate college and , like the college proper , place emphasis upon a broad liberal arts course as the proper foundation for specialized study .	150.10182
students of the college who are candidates for the a . b . degree and can satisfy the academic requirements of the medical and business schools , may enter either of these associated schools at the beginning of senior year , thus completing the two-year postgraduate course in one year .	75.65069
the thayer school offers a year of postgraduate study in somewhat the same way , after a boy wins a b . s . in engineering .	51.13054
so dartmouth is moving closer to the others in the ivy group .	28.558014
it is still , however , the junior member of the league , if not in years at least in the catching up it has had to do .	81.02021
it has not been a well-known school for any part of the span the other ivies have enjoyed .	115.27347
however much football has been over-emphasized , the public likes to measure its collegiate favorites by the scoreboard , so , while yale need never give its record a thought again since outscoring its opponents 694 to 0 in the season of 1888 , dartmouth had to wait until its championship team of 1925 for national recognition .	165.66422
it has come on with a rush in more significant areas .	75.63197
today it espouses certain ideas in its curriculum that other institutions might consider somewhat breathtaking .	202.20409
but dartmouth preserves its youthful brashness even in its educational attitudes , and , although some of its experiments may still be in the testing stage , they make for lively copy .	94.77847
president emeritus hopkins once proposed to corral an `` aristocracy of brains ' ' in hanover .	32.888203
the person who left the buggy there has never been identified .	22.54629
it was a busy street , conveniently near the shopping center , and unattended horses and wagons were often left at the curbside .	57.851063
there are , of course , many weaknesses in any case against emma .	86.24252
she didn ' t like her stepmother , but nothing is known to have occurred shortly before the crime that could have caused such a murderous rage .	102.3037
she had no way of knowing in advance whether an opportunity for murder existed .	119.5881
she would have been taking more than a fair risk of being seen and recognized during her travels .	155.87117
if she avoided the train and hired a buggy , the stableman might have recognized her .	75.794395
if police had checked on her more thoroughly than is indicated , she would be completely eliminated as a suspect .	86.9043
uncle john vinnicum morse was the immediate popular suspect .	37.270256
his sudden unannounced appearance at the borden home was strange in that he did not carry an iota of baggage with him , although he clearly intended to stay overnight , if not longer .	96.493645
lizzie stated during the inquest that while her father and uncle were in the sitting room the afternoon before the murders , she had been disturbed by their voices and had closed her door , even though it was a very hot day .	48.158524
it is evident that lizzie did not tell everything she overheard between her father and her uncle morse .	64.64736
at that time jennings had a young law associate named arthur s . phillips .	66.43349
a few years ago , not too long before his death , phillips revealed in a newspaper story that he had always suspected morse of the murders .	71.31635
he said morse and borden had quarreled violently in the house that day , information which must have come from lizzie .	122.704575
it was obviously the sound of this argument that caused lizzie to close her door .	286.88748
the new bedford standard-times has reported knowlton as saying , long after the trial , that if he only knew what borden said during his conversation with morse , he would have convicted `` somebody ' ' .	48.199287
notice , knowlton did not say that he would have obtained a conviction in the trial of lizzie borden .	28.204842
he said he would have convicted `` somebody ' ' .	2.139012
it is known that morse did associate with a group of itinerant horse traders who made their headquarters at westport , a town not far from fall river .	120.4541
they were a vagabond lot and considered to be shady and undesirable characters .	102.13934
fall river police did go to westport to see if they could get any information against morse and possibly find an accomplice whom he might have hired from among these men .	163.26755
morse ' s alibi was not as solid as it seemed .	40.342945
he said he returned from the visit to his niece on the 11 20 streetcar .	43.869923
the woman in the house where the niece was staying backed up his story and said she left when he did to shop for her dinner .	99.0518
if this woman had delayed until after 11 20 to start her shopping , she would have had little time in which to prepare the substantial meal that was eaten at dinner in those days .	101.28367
it is possible that morse told the woman it was 11 20 , but it could have been earlier , since she did serve dinner on time .	91.09534
police did make an attempt to check on morse ' s alibi .	13.886844
they interviewed the conductor of the streetcar morse said he had taken , but the man did not remember morse as a passenger .	45.24866
questioned further , morse said that there had been four or five priests riding on the same car with him .	35.790825
the conductor did recall having priests as passengers and this satisfied police , although the conductor also pointed out that in heavily catholic fall river there were priests riding on almost every trip the streetcar made , so morse ' s statement really proved nothing .	193.10234
we do know that morse left the house before nine o ' clock .	28.786957
bridget testified she saw him leave through the side door .	106.04041
morse said borden let him out and locked the screen door .	28.747238
from that point on he said he went to the post office and then walked leisurely to where his niece was staying , more than a mile away .	36.677616
he met nobody he knew on this walk .	4.448905
there is no accounting of his movements in this long gap of time which covers the early hours when mrs . borden was killed .	77.75378
morse testified that while he was having breakfast in the dining room , mrs . borden told the servant , `` bridget , i want you to wash these windows today ' ' .	32.607613
bridget ' s testimony was in direct contradiction .	6.944621
she said it was after she returned from her vomiting spell in the back yard that mrs . borden told her to wash the windows .	48.95486
this was long after morse had left the house .	14.542642
morse ' s knowledge of what mrs . borden told bridget could indicate that he had returned secretly to the house and was hidden there .	98.77961
he knew the house fairly well , he had been there on two previous visits during the past three or four months alone .	65.502815
and despite knowlton ' s attempts to show that the house was locked up tighter than a drum , this was not true .	67.53014
the screen door was unlocked for some ten or fifteen minutes while bridget was sick in the back .	51.414055
it was unlocked all the time she was washing windows .	524.5583
morse could have returned openly while bridget was sick in the back yard and gone up to the room he had occupied .	54.211575
mrs . borden would not have been alarmed if she saw morse with an ax or hatchet in his hand .	39.19787
he had been to the farm the previous day and he could have said they needed the ax or hatchet at the farm .	74.65049
mrs . borden would have had no reason to disbelieve him and he could have approached close enough to her to swing before she could cry out .	102.495155
he could have left for weybosset street after her murder and made it in plenty of time by using the streetcar .	135.42296
if he took an earlier streetcar than the 11 20 on his return , he could have arrived at the borden house shortly after mr . borden came home .	80.66283
with lizzie in the barn , the screen door unlocked and bridget upstairs in her attic room , he would have had free and easy access to the house .	59.089226
with the second murder over , he could have left , hidden the weapon in some vacant lot or an abandoned cistern in the neighborhood .	121.160225
his unconcerned stroll down the side of the house to a pear tree , with crowds already gathering in front of the building and sawyer guarding the side door , was odd .	66.61303
there was no close examination of his clothes for bloodstains , and certainly no scientific test was made of them .	77.177605
and for a man who traveled around without any change of clothing , a few more stains on his dark suit may very well have gone unnoticed .	262.44952
there was no financial gain for morse in the murders .	21.072405
on the other side of the ledger is the fact that he did see his niece and the woman with whom she was staying .	28.19141
the time would have been shortly after the murder of mrs . borden and they noticed nothing unusual in his behavior .	59.54781
he said he had promised mrs . borden to return in time for dinner and that was close to the time when he did turn up at the borden house .	41.719273
what did pearson say about bridget sullivan as a possible suspect in his trial-book essay ? ?	46.28009
`` the police soon ceased to look upon either bridget or mr . morse as in possession of guilty knowledge .	154.37274
indeed , it was probably to mr . morse ' s advantage to have mr . and mrs . borden alive .	25.04115
both he and bridget were exonerated by lizzie herself ' ' .	10.85113
that was his complete discussion of bridget sullivan as a possible suspect .	30.510664
although pearson disbelieved almost everything lizzie said , and read a sinister purpose into almost everything she did , he happily accepted her statement about bridget as the whole truth .	171.62459
he felt nothing further need be said about the servant girl .	127.19099
the exoneration pearson speaks of is not an exoneration , but lizzie ' s expression of her opinion , as reported in the testimony of assistant marshal fleet .	45.78906
this officer had asked lizzie if she suspected her uncle morse , and she replied she didn ' t think he did it because he left the house before the murders and returned after them .	39.160427
fleet asked the same question about bridget , and lizzie pointed out that as far as she knew bridget had gone up to her room before her father ' s murder and came down when she called her .	49.696007
lizzie , actually , never named any suspect .	4.8413677
she told police about the prospective tenant she had heard quarreling with her father some weeks before the murders , but she said she thought he was from out of town because she heard him mention something about talking to his partner .	83.90139
and , much as she detested hiram harrington , she also did not accuse him .	40.05542
at the inquest she was asked specifically whether she knew anybody her father had bad feelings toward , or who had bad feelings toward her father .	125.653725
she replied , `` i know of one man that has not been friendly with him .	30.950466
they have not been friendly for years ' ' .	1.4467124
asked who this was , she named harrington .	16.791235
the press reported the same facts in using harrington ' s interview , but lizzie did not suggest at the inquest that harrington was the killer .	54.528915
when i interviewed kirby , who as a boy picked up pears in the borden yard , i asked if anybody else in the household besides lizzie and morse had been under any suspicion at the time of the murders .	101.75463
he said he had not heard of anybody else .	5.3563175
`` how about bridget sullivan ' ' ? ?	1.1149262
`` oh , she was just the maid there ' ' , he replied , waving a hand to indicate how completely unimportant she was .	104.25224
kirby was , of course , reflecting the opinion that existed at the time of murders .	44.07374
everyone somehow manages to overlook completely the fact that , as far as we know , there were exactly two people in and about the house at the time of both murders lizzie borden and bridget sullivan .	48.903336
all the officials on the case seem to have been afflicted with a similar myopia as far as bridget was concerned , although records in police files contain many reports of servants who have murdered their employers .	109.93672
true , it is no longer cricket for the butler to be the killer in mystery fiction , but we are dealing here with actual people in real life and not imaginary characters and situations .	101.363
the actions of bridget should be examined , since she was there and opportunity did exist , if only to establish her innocence .	183.58888
there are also other factors that require closer examination .	82.354225
the legend as it exists in fall river today always includes the solemn assurance that bridget returned to ireland after the trial with a `` big bundle ' ' of cash which lizzie gave her for keeping her mouth shut .	99.55667
the people who believe and retell the legend have apparently never troubled to read the trial testimony and do not know that the maid changed her testimony on several key points , always to the detriment of lizzie .	237.90996
if bridget did get any bundles of cash , the last person who would have rewarded her for services rendered would have been lizzie borden .	72.39221
bridget was born in ireland , one of fourteen children .	68.98378
she was apparently the pioneer in her family because she had no close relatives in this country at that time .	51.265755
she worked as a domestic , first in newport for a year , and then in south bethlehem , pennsylvania , for another year .	52.568848
she finally settled in fall river and , after being employed for a time by a mrs . reed , was hired by the bordens .	49.68764
i have previously described how , during the week of the murder , bridget spent the first few hot days scrubbing and ironing clothes .	67.4891
her father , james upton , was the upton mentioned by hawthorne in the famous introduction to the scarlet letter as one of those who came into the old custom house to do business with him as the surveyor of the port .	88.23867
a gentleman of the old school , mr . upton possessed intellectual power , ample means , and withal , was a devoted christian .	103.42196
the daughter profited from his interest in scientific and philosophical subjects .	45.72172
her mother also was a person of superior mind and broad interests .	111.79573
there is clear evidence that lucy from childhood had an unusual mind .	133.00111
she possessed an observant eye , a retentive memory , and a critical faculty .	47.873707
when she was nine years old , she wrote a description of a store she had visited .	62.406555
she named 48 items , and said there were `` many more things which it would take too long to write ' ' .	52.0508
an essay on `` freedom ' ' written at 10 years of age quoted the declaration of independence , the freedom given to slaves in canada , and the views of george washington .	57.74862
lucy upton was graduated from the salem high school when few colleges , only oberlin and elmira , were open to women	96.32653
and she had an appetite for learning that could not be denied .	31.996094
a picture of her in high school comes from a younger schoolmate , albert s . flint , friend of her brother winslow , and later , like winslow , a noted astronomer .	28.382904
he recalled lucy , as `` a bright-looking black-eyed young lady who came regularly through the boys ' study hall to join the class in greek in the little recitation room beyond ' ' .	94.19569
the study of greek was the distinctive mark of boys destined to go to college , and lucy upton too expected to go to college and take the full classical course offered to men .	82.38278
the death of her mother in 1865 prevented this .	105.850464
with four younger children at home , lucy stepped into her mother ' s role , and even after the brothers and sisters were grown , she was her father ' s comfort and stay until he died in 1879 .	39.530357
but even so lucy could not give up her intellectual pursuits .	46.181732
when her brother winslow became a student at brown university in 1874 , she wrote him about a course in history he was taking under professor diman `` what is prof . diman ' s definition of civilization , and take the world through , is its progress ever onward , or does it retrograde at times ? ?	81.101654
do you think i might profitably study some of the history you do , perhaps two weeks behind you .	141.97064
' ' and that she proceeded to do .	18.129156
many years later ( on august 3 , 1915 ) , lucy upton wrote winslow ' s daughter soon to be graduated from smith college `` while i love botany which , after dabbling in for years , i studied according to the methods of that day exactly forty years ago in a summer school , it must be fascinating to take up zoology in the way you are doing .	88.861725
whatever was the science in the high school course for the time being , that was my favorite study .	95.41835
she read maitland ' s dark ages , `` which i enjoyed very much ' '	36.918293
la croix on the customs of the middle ages , 16 chapters of bryce `` and liked it more and more ' '	84.00379
she discussed in her letters to winslow some of the questions that came to her as she studied alone .	73.64711
lucy ' s correspondence with brother winslow during his college days was not entirely taken up with academic studies .	204.57649
also lucy and winslow had a private contest to see which one could make the most words from the letters in `` importunately ' ' .	51.942825
who won is not revealed , but winslow ' s daughter eleanor says they got up to 1 , 212 words .	77.1435
winslow had musical talents , as had his father before him .	55.647747
at different times he served as glee-club and choir leader and as organist .	131.02731
and it was lucy upton who first started the idea of a regular course in music at spelman college .	65.887344
winslow upton after graduation from brown university and two years of graduate study , accepted a position at the harvard observatory .	68.61577
for three years he was connected with the u . s . naval observatory and with the u . s . signal corps	15.340193
and after 1883 , was professor of astronomy at brown university .	26.203625
the six expeditions to study eclipses of the sun , of which he was a member , took him to colorado , virginia , and california as well as to the south pacific and to russia .	47.801334
after her father ' s death , lucy and her youngest sister lived for a few years with winslow in washington , d . c . .	23.687727
`` their house ' ' , writes albert s . flint , `` was always a haven of hospitality and good cheer , especially grateful to one like myself far from home ' ' .	57.14843
lucy was a lively part of the household .	20.116621
moreover , she had physical as well as mental vigor .	269.03192
winslow , as his daughters eleanor and margaret recall , used to characterize her as `` our iron sister ' ' .	42.702785
there is reason to suppose that lucy would have made a record as publicly distinguished as her brother had it not been that her mother ' s death occurred just as she was about to enter college .	76.500626
as a matter of fact , albert s . flint expressed his conviction that `` her physical strength , her mental power , her lively interest in all objects about her and her readiness to serve her fellow beings ' ' would have led her `` to a distinguished career amongst the noted women of this country ' ' .	83.28194
while in washington , d . c . , lucy upton held positions in the u . s . census office , and in the pension bureau .	42.33959
they were not sufficiently challenging however , and she resigned in 1887 , to go to germany with her brother winslow and his family while he was there on study .	76.70583
after the months in europe , she returned to boston and became active in church and community life .	64.3792
what was called an `` accidental meeting ' ' with miss packard in washington turned her attention to spelman .	74.201775
after correspondence with miss packard and to the joy of miss packard and miss giles , she came to atlanta , in the fall of 1888 , to help wherever needed , although there was then no money available to pay her a salary .	52.53484
she served for a number of years without pay beyond her travel and maintenance .	381.30032
her students have spoken of the exacting standards of scholarship and of manners and conduct she expected and achieved from the students	126.25288
of her `` great power of discernment ' '	1.0052774
of `` her exquisiteness of dress ' ' , `` her well-modulated voice that went straight to the hearts of the hearers ' '	36.756824
her great love of flowers and plants and birds	170.36948
she drew on all her resources of mind and heart to help them -- to make them at home in the world	45.41998
and as graduates gratefully recall , she drew on her purse as well .	40.78332
many a student was able to remain at spelman , only because of her unobtrusive help .	102.41201
under miss upton , the work of the year 1909-10 went forward without interruption .	208.30453
after all , she had come to spelman seminary in 1888 , and had been since 1891 except for one year , associate principal or dean .	91.39155
she had taught classes in botany , astronomy ( with the aid of a telescope ) , geometry , and psychology .	57.434784
miss upton and miss packard , as a matter of fact , had many tastes in common .	70.74526
and both believed that intellectual growth must go hand in hand with the development of sturdy character and christian zeal .	144.32083
both loved the out-of-doors , including mountain climbing and horseback riding .	8.837318
in 1890 when the trip to europe and the holy land was arranged for miss packard , it was miss upton who planned the trip , and `` with rare executive ability ' ' bore the brunt of `` the entire pilgrimage from beginning to end ' ' .	59.911236
so strenuous it was physically , with its days of horseback riding over rough roads that it seems an amazing feat of endurance for both miss packard and miss upton .	77.34247
at the fifteenth anniversary ( 1896 ) as already quoted , miss upton projected with force and eloquence the spelman of the future as a college of first rank , with expanding and unlimited horizons .	147.1358
when dr . wallace buttrick , wise in his judgment of people , declined to have the science building named for him , he wrote miss tapley ( april 7 , 1923 ) `` if you had asked me , i think i would have suggested that you name the building for miss upton .	95.22068
her services to the school for many years were of a very high character , and i have often thought that one of the buildings should be named for her ' ' .	43.96
such were the qualities of the acting-president of the seminary after the death of miss giles .	34.586105
at the meeting of the board of trustees , on march 3 , 1910 , miss upton presented the annual report of the president .	29.817404
she noted that no student had been withdrawn through loss of confidence	826.6966
that the enrollment showed an increase of boarding students as was desired	216.07181
and that the year ' s work had gone forward smoothly .	77.1293
she urged the importance of more thorough preparation for admission .	29.143126
the raising of the $25 , 000 improvement fund two days before the time limit expired , and the spontaneous `` praise demonstration ' ' held afterward on the campus , were reported as events which had brought happiness to miss giles .	129.81339
with the fund in hand , the debt on the boilers had been paid	48.557762
and ground had been broken for the superintendent ' s home .	6.9021235
miss upton spoke gratefully of the response of spelman graduates and negro friends in helping to raise the fund , and their continuing efforts to raise money for greatly needed current expenses .	85.332886
she spoke also with deep thankfulness of the many individuals and agencies whose interest and efforts through the years had made the work so fruitful in results .	251.23317
two bequests were recorded one of $200 under the will of mrs . harriet a . copp of los angeles	53.92857
and one of $2 , 000 under the will of miss celia l . brett of hamilton , new york , a friend from the early days .	57.274437
miss upton told the trustees that the death of miss giles was `` the sorest grief ' ' the seminary had ever been called upon to bear .	33.65477
the daughters of spelman , she said , had never known or thought of spelman without her .	241.85109
the removal of miss packard 18 years earlier had caused them great sorrow , but they still had miss giles .	115.68905
`` yet spelman has strong , deep roots , and will live for the blessing of generations to come ' ' .	44.085026
miss mary jane packard , sophia ' s half-sister , became ill in march , 1910	37.279198
and when school closed , she was unable to travel to massachusetts .	31.929491
before coming on a visit to spelman in 1885 , miss mary had been a successful teacher in worcester , and her position there was held open for her for a considerable period .	70.85627
she helped with teaching as well as office work for a few years -- the catalogues show that she had classes in geography , rhetoric and bookkeeping .	63.383755
soon the office work claimed all her time .	9.024656
she was closely associated with the founders in all their trials and hardships .	117.793236
quiet and energetic , cheerful and calm , she too was a power in the development of the seminary .	120.87494
miss giles always used to refer to her as `` sister ' ' .	13.161479
she served as secretary in the seminary office for 25 years , and was in charge of correspondence , records , and bookkeeping .	33.52882
the books of the school hold a memorial to her	56.236435
and so do the hearts of students and of teachers .	68.66797
mary j . packard , states a messenger editorial , was `` efficient , pains-taking , self-effacing , loving , radiating the spirit of her master .	40.337894
with infinite patience she responded to every call , no matter at what cost to herself , and to her all went , for she was sure to have the needed information or word of cheer .	95.57915
in a few school districts one finds a link between school and job .	168.00117
in those vocational programs organized with smith-hughes money , there may be a close tie between the labor union and a local employer on the one hand and the vocational teacher on the other .	52.532974
in these cases a graduate may enter directly into an apprentice program , saving a year because of his vocational courses in grades 11 and 12 .	61.854683
the apprentice program will involve further education on a part-time basis , usually at night , perhaps using some of the same equipment of the high school .	68.83428
these opportunities are to be found in certain cities in such crafts as auto mechanics , carpentry , drafting , electrical work , tool-and-die work , and sheet-metal work .	32.034756
formally organized vocational programs supported by federal funds allow high school students to gain experience in a field of work which is likely to lead to a full-time job on graduation .	69.02261
the `` diversified occupations ' ' program is a part-time trade-preparatory program conducted over two school years on a cooperative basis between the school and local industrial and business employers .	61.890114
the `` distributive education ' ' program operates in a similar way , with arrangements between the school and employers in merchandising fields .	56.820786
in both cases the student attends school half-time and works in a regular job the other half .	83.88827
in a few places cooperative programs between schools and employers in clerical work have shown the same possibilities for allowing the student , while still in school , to develop skills which are immediately marketable upon graduation .	90.53373
adult education courses , work-study programs of various sorts -- these are all evidence of a continuing interest of the schools in furthering educational opportunities for out-of-school youth .	81.24711
in general , however , it may be said that when a boy or a girl leaves the high school , the school authorities play little or no part in the decision of what happens next .	91.905075
if the student drops out of high school , the break with the school is even more complete .	111.32484
when there is employment opportunity for youth , this arrangement -- or lack of arrangement -- works out quite well .	195.47409
