indeed , in some periods of our history and in some neighborhoods the job opportunities have been so good that undoubtedly a great many boys who were potential members of the professions quit school at an early age and went to work .	93.82344
statistically this has represented a loss to the nation , although one must admit that in an individual case the decision in retrospect may have been a wise one .	57.89163
i make no attempt to measure the enduring satisfaction and material well-being of a man who went to work on graduation from high school and was highly successful in the business which he entered .	63.69391
he may or may not be `` better off ' ' than his classmate who went on to a college and professional school .	65.33945
but in the next decades the nation needs to educate for the professions all the potential professional talent .	195.73534
in a later chapter dealing with the suburban school , i shall discuss the importance of arranging a program for the academically talented and highly gifted youth in any high school where he is found .	36.41409
in the negro neighborhoods and also to some extent in the mixed neighborhoods the problem may be one of identification and motivation .	52.91071
high motivation towards higher education must start early enough so that by the time the boy or girl reaches grade 9 he or she has at least developed those basic skills which are essential for academic work .	114.4499
undoubtedly far more can be done in the lower grades in this regard in the negro schools .	79.16067
however , the teacher can only go so far if the attitude of the community and the family is anti-intellectual .	41.090096
and the fact remains that there are today few shining examples of negroes in positions of intellectual leadership .	158.55856
this is not due to any policy of discrimination on the part of the northern universities .	36.24751
quite the contrary , as i can testify from personal experience as a former university president .	90.73655
the absence of successful negroes in the world of scholarship and science has tended to tamp down enthusiasm among negro youth for academic careers .	115.584114
i believe the situation is improving , but the success stories need to be heavily publicized .	110.142136
here again we run into the roadblock that negroes do not like to be designated as negroes in the press .	92.96878
how can the vicious circle be broken ? ?	1.0312023
this is a problem to which leaders of opinion , both negro and white , should devote far more attention .	92.90178
it is at least as important as the more dramatic attempts to break down barriers of inequality in the south .	90.908226
i should like to underline four points i made in my first report with respect to vocational education .	43.460407
first and foremost , vocational courses should not replace courses which are essential parts of the required academic program for graduation .	100.228386
second , vocational courses should be provided in grades 11 and 12 and not require more than half the student ' s time in those years	51.1545
however , for slow learners and prospective dropouts these courses ought to begin earlier .	107.93292
third , the significance of the vocational courses is that those enrolled are keenly interested in the work	64.0871
they realize the relevance of what they are learning to their future careers , and this sense of purpose is carried over to the academic courses which they are studying at the same time .	48.846912
fourth , the type of vocational training programs should be related to the employment opportunities in the general locality .	14.387093
this last point is important because if high school pupils are aware that few , if any , graduates who have chosen a certain vocational program have obtained a job as a consequence of the training , the whole idea of relevance disappears .	77.58086
vocational training which holds no hope that the skill developed will be in fact a marketable skill becomes just another school `` chore ' ' for those whose interest in their studies has begun to falter .	136.97433
those who , because of population mobility and the reputed desire of employers to train their own employees , would limit vocational education to general rather than specific skills ought to bear in mind the importance of motivation in any kind of school experience .	88.93446
i have been using the word `` vocational ' ' as a layman would at first sight think it should be used .	78.00336
i intend to include under the term all the practical courses open to boys and girls .	132.44817
these courses develop skills other than those we think of when we use the adjective `` academic ' ' .	59.987873
practically all of these practical skills are of such a nature that a degree of mastery can be obtained in high school sufficient to enable the youth to get a job at once on the basis of the skill .	41.07842
they are in this sense skills marketable immediately on graduation from high school .	45.03731
to be sure , in tool-and-die work and in the building trades , the first job must be often on an apprentice basis , but two years of half-time vocational training enables the young man thus to anticipate one year of apprentice status .	132.81999
similarly , a girl who graduates with a good working knowledge of stenography and the use of clerical machines and who is able to get a job at once may wish to improve her skill and knowledge by a year or two of further study in a community college or secretarial school .	81.59105
of course , it can be argued that an ability to write english correctly and with some degree of elegance is a marketable skill .	67.71781
so , too , is the mathematical competence of a college graduate who has majored in mathematics .	36.35266
in a sense almost all high school and college courses could be considered as vocational to the extent that later in life the student in his vocation ( which may be a profession ) will be called upon to use some of the skills developed and the competence obtained .	73.49374
in spite of the shading of one type of course into another , i believe it is useful to talk about vocational courses as apart from academic courses .	58.339973
perhaps a course in typewriting might be regarded as the exception which proves the rule .	77.832855
today many college bound students try to take a course in personal typing , as they feel a certain degree of mastery of this skill is almost essential for one who proposes to do academic work in college and a professional school .	75.559845
most of our largest cities have one or more separate vocational or technical high schools .	50.663944
in this respect , public education in the large cities differs from education in the smaller cities and consolidated school districts .	65.25205
the neighborhood high schools are not , strictly speaking , comprehensive schools , because some of the boys and girls may be attending a vocational or technical high school instead of the local school .	48.710136
indeed , one school superintendent in a large city objects to the use of the term comprehensive high school for the senior high schools in his city , because these schools do not offer strictly vocational programs .	55.593216
he prefers to designate such schools as `` general ' ' high schools .	27.920494
the suburban high school , it is worth noting , also is not a widely comprehensive high school because of the absence of vocational programs .	43.96936
the reason is that there is a lack of interest on the part of the community .	11.170176
therefore employment and education in all the schools in a metropolitan area are related in different ways from those which are characteristic of the comprehensive high school described in my first report .	69.75076
the separate vocational or technical high schools in the large cities must be reckoned as permanent institutions .	35.42684
by and large their programs are satisfactorily connected both to the employment situation and to the realities of the apprentice system .	59.004223
it is not often realized to what degree certain trades are in many communities closed areas of employment , except for a lucky few .	122.96258
one has to talk confidentially with some of the directors of vocational high schools to realize that a boy cannot just say , `` i want to be a plumber ' ' , and then , by doing good work , find a job .	42.987404
it is far more difficult in many communities to obtain admission to an apprentice program which involves union approval than to get into the most selective medical school in the nation .	88.06931
two stories will illustrate what i have in mind .	20.128145
one vocational instructor in a city vocational school , speaking of his course in a certain field , said he had no difficulty placing all students in jobs outside of the city .	86.24051
in the city , he said , the waiting list for those who want to join the union is so long that unless a boy has an inside track he can ' t get in .	92.48294
in a far distant part of the united states , i was talking to an instructor about a boy who in the twelfth grade was doing special work .	66.10359
`` what does he have in mind to do when he graduates ' ' ? ?	20.197657
`` oh , he ' ll be a plumber ' ' , came the answer .	17.336155
`` but isn ' t it almost impossible to get into the union ' ' ? ?	14.773402
`` he ' ll have no difficulty ' ' , i was told .	11.222475
`` he has very good connections ' ' .	2.6475496
in my view , there should be a school which offers significant vocational programs for boys within easy reach of every family in a city .	163.52927
ideally these schools should be so located that one or more should be in the area where demand for practical courses is at the highest .	57.48824
an excellent example of a successful location of a new vocational high school is the dunbar vocational high school in chicago .	32.151043
located in a bad slum area now undergoing redevelopment , this school and its program are especially tailored to the vocational aims of its students .	90.01018
hardly a window has been broken since dunbar first was opened ( and vandalism in schools is a major problem in many slum areas ) .	112.57234
i discovered in the course of a visit there that almost all the pupils were negroes .	138.33925
they were learning trades as diverse as shoe repairing , bricklaying , carpentry , cabinet making , auto mechanics , and airplane mechanics .	30.729097
the physical facilities at dunbar are impressive , but more impressive is the attitude of the pupils .	51.523552
the soybean seed is the most important leguminous food in the world .	28.789318
in the united states , where half of the world crop is grown , soybeans are processed for their edible oil .	37.70947
the residue from soybean processing goes mainly into animal feeds .	54.951927
soybeans are extensively processed into a remarkable number of food products in the orient .	51.85109
american chemists , seeking to increase exports of soybeans , have adapted modern techniques and fermentation methods to improve their use in such traditional japanese foods as tofu and miso and in tempeh of indonesia .	78.16578
soybean flour , grits , flakes , `` milk ' ' , and curd can be bought in the united states .	16.727365
peanuts are the world ' s second most important legume .	24.191723
we produce peanut oil , but to a much greater extent we eat the entire seed .	89.091125
blanched peanuts , as prepared for making peanut butter or for eating as nuts , are roasted seeds whose seedcoats have been rubbed off .	67.67833
cereal grains , supplemented with soybeans or dry edible peas or beans , comprise about two-thirds or three-fourths of the diet in parts of asia and africa .	38.351418
in western europe and north america , where the level of economic development is higher , grains and other seed products furnish less than one-third of the food consumed .	54.790127
rather , meat and potatoes , sugar , and dairy products are the main sources of carbohydrate , protein , oils , and fats .	19.48016
people depend less on seeds for foods in australia , new zealand , and argentina , where extensive grazing lands support sheep or cattle , and the consumption of meat is high .	54.91685
feeds for livestock took about one-sixth of the world ' s cereal crop in 1957-1958 .	34.638535
most of the grain is fed to swine and dairy cows and lesser amounts to beef cattle and poultry .	18.551897
about 90 percent of the corn used in the united states is fed to animals .	54.14829
the rest is used for human food and industrial products .	22.268251
more than half of the sorghum and barley seeds we produce and most of the byproducts of the milling of cereals and the crushing of oilseeds are fed to livestock .	71.48611
more than 200 million tons of seeds and seed products are fed to livestock annually in the united states .	18.235264
the efficiency with which animals convert grains and forages to meat has risen steadily in the united states since the 1930 ' s and has paralleled the increased feeding of the cake and meal that are a byproduct when seeds are processed for oil .	43.15035
the demand for food is so great in the world that little arable land can be given over to growing the nonfood crops .	66.02179
seeds grown for industrial uses hold a relatively minor position .	83.060356
chief among the seed crops grown primarily for industrial uses are the oil-bearing seeds -- flax , castor , tung ( nuts from the china wood-oil tree ) , perilla ( from an oriental mint ) , and oiticica ( from a brazilian tree ) .	25.72706
oils , or liquid fats , from the seeds of flax and tung have long been the principal constituents of paints and varnishes for protecting and beautifying the surfaces of wood and metal .	28.264454
these oils develop hard , smooth films when they dry and form resinlike substances .	69.5764
the artist who paints in oil uses drying oils to carry the pigments and to protect his finished work for the ages .	63.87366
one of the finest of artists ' oils comes from poppy seeds .	71.86901
seeds of soybean , cotton , corn , sesame , and rape yield semidrying oils .	64.448524
some are used in paints along with drying oils .	18.880249
palm oil protects the surfaces of steel sheets before they are plated with tin .	54.405224
castor oil , made from castorbeans , has gone out of style as a medicine .	66.77118
this nondrying oil , however , is now more in demand than ever before as a fine lubricant , as a constituent of fluids for hydraulically operated equipment , and as a source of chemicals to make plastics .	52.765923
almond oil , another nondrying oil , was once used extensively in perfumery to extract flower fragrances .	88.73546
it is still used in drugs and cosmetics , but it is rather scarce and sometimes is adulterated with oils from peach and plum seeds .	48.963287
liquid fats from all these oilseeds enter into the manufacture of soaps for industry and the household and of glycerin for such industrial uses as making explosives .	75.1035
sizable amounts of soybean , coconut , and palm kernel oil -- seed oils that are produced primarily for food purposes -- also are used to make soaps , detergents , and paint resins .	33.19968
solid fats from the seeds of the mahua tree , the shea tree , and the coconut palm are used to make candles in tropical countries .	22.999432
seeds are a main source of starch for industrial and food use in many parts of the world .	32.992004
corn and wheat supply most of the starch in the united states , canada , and australia .	19.285582
in other countries where cereal grains are not among the principal crops of a region , starchy tubers or roots are processed for starch .	72.19996
starch is used in the paper , textile , and food-processing industries and in a multitude of other manufacturing operations .	30.121262
gums were extracted from quince , psyllium ( fleawort ) , flax , and locust ( carob ) seeds in ancient times .	15.35715
today the yearly import into the united states of locust bean gum is more than 15 million pounds	33.08248
of psyllium seed , more than 2 . 6 million .	13.449369
the discovery during the second world war that guar gum was similar to imported locust gum increased its cultivation in western asia and initiated it in the united states .	62.2069
water-soluble gums are used in foods and drugs and in the manufacture of pulp and paper as thickeners , stabilizers , or dispersing agents .	40.4051
guar gum thickens salad dressings and stabilizes ice cream .	5.81273
quince seed gum is the main ingredient in wave-setting lotions .	6.864506
once regarded as an agricultural nuisance , psyllium was sold in the 1930 ' s as a mechanical laxative under 117 different brands .	40.19605
locust gum is added to pulp slurries to break up the lumps of fibers in making paper .	37.24856
the seeds of hard , fibrous , stony fruits , called nuts , provide highly concentrated foods , oils , and other materials of value .	35.186115
most nuts consist of the richly packaged storage kernel and its thick , adherent , brown covering -- the seedcoat .	98.47406
the kernels of brazil nuts , cashews , coconuts , filberts , hazelnuts , hickory nuts , pecans , walnuts , and pine nuts are predominantly oily .	11.303643
almonds and pistachio nuts are not so high in oil but are rich in protein .	82.64238
the world production of familiar seed nuts -- almonds , brazil nuts , filberts , and the english walnuts -- totals about 300 thousand tons annually .	24.600046
coconuts , the fruit of the coconut palm , have the largest of all known seeds and are grown in south pacific islands as a crop for domestic and export markets .	119.0435
the oil palm of west africa yields edible oil from both the flesh and the seed or kernel of its fruit .	44.02212
world production of copra , the oil-bearing flesh of the coconut , was a little more than 3 million tons in 1959 .	21.81839
exports from producing countries in terms of equivalent oil were a little more than 1 million tons , about half of which was palm kernels or oil from them and about half was palm oil .	70.487335
other nuts consumed in lesser quantity include the spicy nutmeg	6.221605
the soap nut , which owes its sudsing power to natural saponins	69.15165
the marking nut , used for ink and varnish	12.02898
and the sweet-smelling cumara nut , which is suited for perfumes .	31.162848
a forest crop that has not been extensively cultivated is ivory nuts from the tagua palm .	158.96144
the so-called vegetable ivory is the hard endosperm of the egg-sized seed .	21.91952
it is used for making buttons and other small , hard objects of turnery .	83.763596
seeds of the sago palm are used in bermuda to make heads and faces of dolls sold to tourists .	181.53777
the color and shape of seeds have long made them attractive for ornaments and decorations .	158.24774
since biblical times , rosaries have been made from jobs-tears -- the seeds of an asiatic grass .	114.398224
bead tree seeds are the necklaces of south pacific islanders and the eyes of buddha dolls in cuba .	20.647177
victorian ladies had a fad of stringing unusual seeds to wear as jewelry .	162.98341
handmade christmas wreaths and trees often contain a variety of seeds collected during the year .	23.53609
tradition has assigned medicinal values to seeds because of their alkaloids , aromatic oils , and highly flavored components .	43.49172
although science has given us more effective materials , preparations from anise , castorbean , colchicum , nux vomica , mustard , fennel , and stramonium are familiar to many for the relief of human ailments .	26.42432
flaxseed poultices and mustard plasters still are used by some persons .	102.1466
peanut and sesame oils often are used as carriers or diluents for medicines administered by injection .	45.896194
still another group of seeds ( sometimes tiny , dry , seed-bearing fruits ) provide distinctive flavors and odors to foods , although the nutrients they supply are quite negligible .	68.268326
the common spices , flavorings , and condiments make up this group .	197.5076
each year millions of pounds of anise , caraway , mustard , celery , and coriander and the oils extracted from them are imported .	29.323362
single-seeded dry fruits used for flavoring include several of the carrot family , such as cumin , dill , fennel , and angelica .	15.2796
less common seeds used in cooking and beverages include fenugreek ( artificial maple flavor ) and cardamom .	33.528988
white pepper is the ground seed of the common black pepper fruit .	59.63829
sesame seed , which comes from the tall pods of a plant grown in egypt , brazil , and central america , has a toasted-nut flavor and can be used in almost any dish calling for almonds .	48.599907
it is a main flavoring for halvah , the candy of the middle east .	70.453026
sesame sticks , a snack dip , originated in the southwest .	21.598492
beverages are made from seeds the world over .	47.36558
coffee is made from the roasted and ground seeds of the coffee tree .	19.111094
world production of coffee broke all previous records in 1959 and 1960 at more than 5 million tons .	19.318544
per capita consumption remains around 16 pounds in the united states .	5.564382
cocoa , chocolate , and cocoa butter come from the ground seeds of the cacao tree .	13.555653
world production of about 1 million tons is divided primarily between africa ( 63 percent ) and south america ( 27 percent ) .	52.870796
several soft drinks contain extracts from kola nuts , the seed of the kola tree cultivated in the west indies and south america .	18.78436
cereal grains have been used for centuries to prepare fermented beverages .	18.885332
the japanese sake is wine fermented from rice grain .	20.012955
arrack is distilled from fermented rice in india .	6.129888
beer , generally fermented from barley , is an old alcoholic beverage .	54.666218
beer was brewed by the babylonians and egyptians more than 6 thousand years ago .	37.29988
brewers today use corn , rice , and malted barley .	13.204542
distillers use corn , malt , wheat , grain sorghum , and rye in making beverage alcohol .	36.871746
seed crops hold a prominent place in the agricultural economy of the united states .	16.312387
the farm value of seeds produced in this country for all purposes , including the cereals , is nearly 10 billion dollars a year .	50.367344
cereal grains , oilseeds , and dry beans and peas account for about 57 percent of the farm value of all crops raised .	100.72176
the economic importance of seed crops actually is even greater , because additional returns are obtained from most of the corn , oats , barley , and sorghum -- as well as the cake and meal from the processing of flaxseed , cottonseed , and soybeans -- through conversion to poultry , meat , and dairy products .	32.44166
seeds furnish about 40 percent of the total nutrients consumed by all livestock .	9.125961
hay and pasture are the other chief sources of livestock feed .	83.39754
seeds are the essential raw materials for milling grain , baking , crushing oilseed , refining edible oil , brewing , distilling , and mixing feed .	17.262295
more than 11 thousand business establishments in the united states were based on cereals and oilseeds in 1954 .	24.147324
the value of products from these industries was 15 . 8 billion dollars , of which about one-third was created by manufacturing processes .	91.03559
not included was the value of seed oil in paints and varnishes or the value of the coffee and chocolate industries that are based on imported seed or seed products .	51.7113
cereal grains furnish about one-fourth of the total food calories in the american diet and about one-third of the total nutrients consumed by all livestock and poultry .	17.426838
to hold a herd of cattle on a new range till they felt at home was called `` locatin ' ' ' ' em .	30.608406
to keep ' em scattered somewhat and yet herd ' em was called `` loose herdin ' ' ' .	25.959242
to hold ' em in a compact mass was `` close herdin ' ' ' .	24.296392
cattle were inclined to remain in a territory with which they were acquainted .	77.41749
that became their `` home range ' ' .	5.28637
yet there were always some that moved farther and farther out , seekin ' grass and water .	65.8332
these became `` strays ' ' , the term bein ' restricted to cattle , however , as hosses , under like circumstances , were spoken of as `` stray hosses ' ' , not merely `` strays ' ' .	49.02747
cattle would drift day and night in a blizzard till it was over .	38.724705
you had to go with ' em or wait till the storm was over , and follow .	226.10725
such marchin ' in wholesale numbers was called a `` drift ' ' , or `` winter drift ' ' , and if the storm was prolonged it usually resulted in one of the tragedies of the range .	31.817865
the cowboy made a technical distinction in reference to the number of them animals .	41.086063
the single animal or a small bunch were referred to as `` strays ' '	20.996859
but when a large number were `` bunched up ' ' or `` banded up ' ' , and marched away from their home range , as long as they stayed together the group was said to be a `` drift ' ' .	27.925402
drifts usually occurred in winter in an effort to escape the severe cold winds , but it could also occur in summer as the result of lack of water or grass because of a drought , or as an aftermath of a stampede .	55.619705
drifts usually happened only with cattle , for hosses had ' nough sense to avoid ' em , and to find shelter for ' emselves .	94.07198
the wholesale death of cattle as a result of blizzards , and sometimes droughts , over a wide range of territory was called a `` die-up ' ' .	21.920204
followin ' such an event there was usually a harvest of `` fallen hides ' ' , and the ranchers needed skinnin ' knives instead of brandin ' irons .	21.362455
cattle were said to be `` potted ' ' when `` blizzard choked ' ' , that is , caught in a corner or a draw , or against a `` drift fence ' ' durin ' a storm .	39.419563
cattle which died from them winter storms were referred to as the `` winter kill ' ' .	28.534857
when cattle in winter stopped and humped their backs up they were said to `` bow up ' ' .	43.03511
this term was also used by the cowboy in the sense of a human showin ' fight , as one cowhand was heard to say , `` he arches his back like a mule in a hailstorm ' ' .	43.244633
cattle drove to the northern ranges and held for two winters to mature ' em into prime beef were said to be `` double wintered ' ' .	53.973835
cattle brought into a range from a distance were called `` immigrants ' ' .	51.726048
them new to the country were referred to as `` pilgrims ' ' .	12.5947
this word was first applied to the imported hot-blooded cattle , but later was more commonly used as reference to a human tenderfoot .	61.53664
hereford cattle were often called `` white faces ' ' , or `` open-face cattle ' ' , and the old-time cowman gave the name of `` hothouse stock ' ' to them newly introduced cattle .	26.615751
because holstein cattle weren ' t a beef breed , they were rarely seen on a ranch , though one might be found now and then for the milk supply .	65.58239
the cowboy called this breed of cattle `` magpies ' ' .	2.999866
a `` cattaloe ' ' was a hybrid offspring of buffalo and cattle .	37.76915
`` dry stock ' ' denoted , regardless of age or sex , such bovines as were givin ' no milk .	60.36264
a `` wet herd ' ' was a herd of cattle made up entirely of cows , while `` wet stuff ' ' referred to cows givin ' milk .	43.48665
the cowboy ' s humorous name for a cow givin ' milk was a `` milk pitcher ' ' .	15.087153
cows givin ' no milk were knowed as `` strippers ' ' .	7.0539684
the terminology of the range , in speakin ' of `` dry stock ' ' and `` wet stock ' ' , was confusin ' to the tenderfoot .	37.644054
the most common reference to `` wet stock ' ' was with the meanin ' that such animals had been smuggled across the rio grande after bein ' stolen from their rightful owners .	57.99933
the term soon became used and applied to all stolen animals .	596.1518
`` mixed herd ' ' meant a herd of mixed sexes , while a `` straight steer herd ' ' was one composed entirely of steers , and when the cowman spoke of `` mixed cattle ' ' , he meant cattle of various grades , ages , and sexes .	46.115597
in the spring when penned cattle were turned out to grass , this was spoken of as `` turn-out time ' ' , or `` put to grass ' ' .	38.82654
`` shootin ' ' em out ' ' was gettin ' cattle out of a corral onto the range .	38.70956
when a cow came out of a corral in a crouchin ' run she was said to `` come out a-stoopin ' ' ' .	52.185833
to stir cattle up and get ' em heated and excited was to `` mustard the cattle ' ' , and the act was called `` ginnin ' ' em ' round ' ' , or `` chousin ' ' em ' ' .	18.705778
after a roundup the pushin ' of stray cattle of outside brands toward their home range was called `` throwin ' over ' ' .	50.78291
a cow rose from the ground rear end first .	91.03971
by the time her hindquarters were in a standin ' position , her knees were on the ground in a prayin ' attitude .	72.71021
it was when she was in this position that the name `` prayin ' cow ' ' was suggested to the cowboy .	80.28222
they were said to be `` on their heads ' ' when grazin ' .	51.49909
`` on the hoof ' ' was a reference to live cattle and was also used in referrin ' to cattle travelin ' by trail under their own power as against goin ' by rail .	101.21873
shippin ' cattle by train was called a `` stock run ' ' .	11.985369
a general classification given grass-fed cattle was `` grassers ' ' .	2.6581836
when a cowboy spoke of `` dustin ' ' ' a cow , he meant that he throwed dust into her eyes .	37.245518
the cow , unlike a bull or steer , kept her eyes open and her mind on her business when chargin ' , and a cow `` on the prod ' ' or `` on the peck ' ' was feared by the cowhand more than any of his other charges .	62.19774
the injun ' s name for beef was `` wohaw ' ' , and many of the old frontiersmen adopted it from their association with the injun on the trails .	38.412216
the first cattle the injuns saw under the white man ' s control were the ox teams of the early freighters .	88.51051
listenin ' with wonder at the strange words of the bullwhackers as they shouted `` whoa ' ' , `` haw ' ' , and `` gee ' ' , they thought them words the names of the animals , and began callin ' cattle `` wohaws ' ' .	20.254044
rarely did a trail herd pass through the injun country on its march north that it wasn ' t stopped to receive demand for `` wohaw ' ' .	71.63266
`` tailin ' ' ' was the throwin ' of an animal by the tail in lieu of a rope .	47.935043
any animal could when travelin ' fast , be sent heels over head by the simple process of overtakin ' the brute , seizin ' its tail , and givin ' the latter a pull to one side .	110.90161
this throwed the animal off balance , and over it ' d crash onto its head and shoulders .	196.50339
though the slightest yank was frequently capable of producin ' results , many men assured success through a turn of the tail ' bout the saddle horn , supplemented sometimes , in the case of cattle , by a downward heave of the rider ' s leg upon the strainin ' tail .	92.62435
such tactics were resorted to frequently with the unmanageable longhorns , and a thorough `` tailin ' ' ' usually knocked the breath out of a steer , and so dazed ' im that he ' d behave for the rest of the day .	46.14081
it required both a quick and swift hoss and a darin ' rider .	107.00345
when cattle became more valuable , ranch owners frowned upon this practice and it was discontinued , at least when the boss was ' round .	101.152824
when the cowboy used the word `` tailin ' s ' ' , he meant stragglers .	14.614974
`` bull tailin ' ' ' was a game once pop ' lar with the mexican cowboys of texas .	119.49803
from a pen of wild bulls one would be released , and with much yellin ' a cowhand ' d take after ' im .	64.09428
seizin ' the bull by the tail , he rushed his hoss forward and a little to one side , throwin ' the bull off balance , and `` bustin ' ' ' ' im with terrific force .	54.68705
rammin ' one horn of a downed steer into the ground to hold ' im down was called `` peggin ' ' ' .	38.400826
colors of cattle came in for their special names .	36.58477
an animal covered with splotches or spots of different colors was called a `` brindle ' ' or `` brockle ' ' .	15.362424
a `` lineback ' ' was an animal with a stripe of different color from the rest of its body runnin ' down its back , while a `` lobo stripe ' ' was the white , yeller , or brown stripe runnin ' down the back , from neck to tail , a characteristic of many spanish cattle .	55.853134
a `` mealynose ' ' was a cow or steer of the longhorn type , with lines and dots of a color lighter ' n the rest of its body ' round the eyes , face , and nose .	76.33377
such an animal was said to be `` mealynosed ' ' .	3.858873
`` sabinas ' ' was a spanish word used to describe cattle of red and white peppered and splotched colorin ' .	63.499706
the northern cowboy called all the red mexican cattle which went up the trail `` sonora reds ' ' , while they called all cattle drove up from mexico `` yaks ' ' , because they came from the yaqui injun country , or gave ' em the name of `` mexican buckskins ' ' .	33.14295
near the southern border , cattle of the early longhorn breed whose coloration was black with a lineback , with white speckles frequently appearin ' on the sides and belly , were called `` zorrillas ' ' .	57.34546
this word was from the spanish , meanin ' `` polecat ' ' .	11.523607
`` yeller bellies ' ' were cattle of mexican breed splotched on flank and belly with yellerish color .	66.67674
an animal with distinct coloration , or other marks easily distinguished and remembered by the owner and his riders , was sometimes used as a `` marker ' ' .	68.90002
such an animal has frequently been the downfall of the rustler .	28.11854
countin ' each grazin ' bunch of cattle where it was found on the range and driftin ' it back so that it didn ' t mix with the uncounted cattle was called a `` range count ' ' .	35.66284
the countin ' of cattle in a pasture without throwin ' ' em together for the purpose was called a `` pasture count ' ' .	39.027493
the counters rode through the pasture countin ' each bunch of grazin ' cattle , and drifted it back so that it didn ' t get mixed with the uncounted cattle ahead .	36.96797
this method of countin ' was usually done at the request , and in the presence , of a representative of the bank that held the papers against the herd .	67.204285
them notes and mortgages were spoken of as `` cattle paper ' ' .	37.571407
a `` book count ' ' was the sellin ' of cattle by the books , commonly resorted to in the early days , sometimes much to the profit of the seller .	72.31952
this led to the famous sayin ' in the northwest of the `` books won ' t freeze ' ' .	16.405521
this became a common byword durin ' the boom days when eastern and foreign capital were so eager to buy cattle interests .	206.02837
the origin of this sayin ' was credited to a saloonkeeper by the name of luke murrin .	18.750748
his saloon was a meetin ' place for influential wyoming cattlemen , and one year durin ' a severe blizzard , when his herd-owner customers were wearin ' long faces , he said , `` cheer up , boys , whatever happens , the books won ' t freeze ' ' .	49.124165
in this carefree sentence he summed up the essence of the prevailin ' custom of buyin ' by book count , and created a sayin ' which has survived through the years .	92.06688
`` range delivery ' ' meant that the buyer , after examinin ' the seller ' s ranch records and considerin ' his rep ' tation for truthfulness , paid for what the seller claimed to own , then rode out and tried to find it .	113.44617
when a cowhand said that a man had `` good cow sense ' ' , he meant to pay ' im a high compliment .	36.99326
no matter by what name cattle were called , there was no denyin ' that they not only saved texas from financial ruin , but went far toward redeemin ' from a wilderness vast territories of the northwest .	102.22213
the first use of the word `` rustler ' ' was as a synonym for `` hustler ' ' , becomin ' an established term for any person who was active , pushin ' , and bustlin ' in any enterprise .	60.917004
again it was used as the title for the hoss wrangler , and when the order was given to go out and `` rustle the hosses ' ' , it meant for ' im to go out and herd ' em in .	54.454617
eventually herdin ' the hosses was spoken of as `` hoss rustlin ' ' ' , and the wrangler was called the `` hoss rustler ' ' .	16.458763
later , the word became almost exclusively applied to a cow thief , startin ' from the days of the maverick when cowhands were paid by their employers to `` get out and rustle a few mavericks ' ' .	42.466362
it was john who found the lion tracks .	12.371561
he found them near the carcass of a zebra that had been killed the night before , and he circled once , nose to the ground , hair shooting up along his back , as it did when he was after lion or bear , and then he lifted his head and bayed , and the pack joined in , all heads high , and jones knew it was a hot trail .	89.75367
he stifled the comanche yell and let john lead him straight toward the nearby black volcanic mountain .	86.51474
this mountain was known as the black reef and it rose almost perpendicularly for about two hundred feet , honeycombed with caves , top covered with dense scrub and creepers and tall grass .	76.12277
on the south it ended sharply as though the lava had been cut off there suddenly .	69.73181
kearton and ulyate had started the day together while jones followed the dogs , and means and loveless had taken another route , and now , with the discovery of the fresh trail still unknown to him , ulyate reined in , in the shadow of the reef and pointed .	100.32607
`` that ' s the colonel ' ' , he said , `` but i can ' t see the dogs ' ' .	7.685515
as they watched , jones rode straight for the reef .	26.360151
then they picked up the smaller black specks on the plain in front of him .	31.75912
the dogs were working a trail -- lion ? ?	80.460075
the pack had made a bend to the north , swinging back toward the reef , and kearton and ulyate could hear them faintly .	29.906761
kearton got off and tore up some dry grass that grew in cracks between the rocks and piled it in a heap and wanted to make the smoke signal that would bring loveless and means and the rest of the party .	82.06622
`` not yet ' ' , cautioned ulyate .	6.0954843
jones came toward them fast , now , along the southern toe of the reef , and the dogs could be heard plainly , old john with his grand canyon voice outstanding above the others .	103.3218
there was sounder , too , also a veteran of the north rim , and rastus and the rake from a pack of english fox-hounds , and a collie from a london pound , and simba , a terrier .	56.783325
a motley pack , chosen for effectiveness , not beauty .	315.3474
jones was galloping close behind them leaning down , cheering them on .	71.85109
ulyate said , and kearton touched a match to the pile of grass , blew on it and flame licked out .	56.00338
he threw green stuff on it , and a thin blue column of smoke rose .	97.42181
`` that will fetch the gang and tell the colonel where we are ' ' .	40.189056
then there was a chorus of wild barking and baying .	14.151725
kearton and ulyate looked at each other and began to gallop toward the sound .	48.919624
it came from the top of the reef not half a mile away .	153.23788
at the base of the rocky hillside , they left their horses and climbed on foot .	92.178154
the route was choked with rugged lava-rocks , creepers and bushes , so thickly overgrown that when kearton lost sight of ulyate and called , ulyate answered from ten feet away .	90.89007
nice country to meet a lion in face to face .	17.654009
ulyate and kearton climbed on toward the sound of the barking of the dogs and the sporadic roaring of the lion , till they came , out of breath , to the crest , and peering through the branches of a bush , this is what ulyate saw jones who had apparently ( and actually had ) ridden up the nearly impassable hillside , sitting calmly on his horse within forty feet of a full-grown young lioness , who was crouched on a flat rock and seemed just about to charge him , while the dogs whirled around her .	79.28722
ulyate drew back with a start , and put finger to lips , almost afraid to move or whisper lest it set her off , `` the dogs have got her bayed .	129.22981
she ' s just the other side of that bush ' ' ! !	31.968353
and when they had drawn back a step he added `` jones is sitting on his horse right in front of her .	61.02836
why she doesn ' t charge him , i don ' t know .	14.140606
and he hasn ' t even got a knife on him .	38.791763
he couldn ' t get away from her in this kind of ground .	65.20885
careful , don ' t disturb her ' ' .	1.512006
jones had been about a hundred and fifty feet from her when he first broke through to the top of the reef .	48.755985
she was standing on a flat rock three feet above ground and when she saw him she rose to full height and roared , opening her mouth wide , lashing her tail , and stamping at the rock with both forefeet in irritation , as much as to say `` how dare you disturb me in my sacred precinct ' ' ? ?	67.89826
intuition told him , however , that she was tired and winded from the run up the reef and would not charge , yet .	103.67763
he moved forward to within thirty-five feet of her , being careful , because he knew the female is less predictable than the male .	69.35577
( in the graveyard at nairobi he had been shown the graves of thirty-four big game hunters killed hunting the animals he was attempting to lasso .	203.23608
of the thirty-four , seventeen had been killed by lions , and eleven out of the seventeen by lionesses .	46.42289
) she snarled terribly but intuition told him , again , that she was bluffing , and he could see that half her attention was distracted by the dogs .	50.973595
it was falling over her head when a branch of a bush caught it and it fell in front of her on the rock .	53.479633
even then , if she took one step forward he could catch her .	85.96194
but john nipped her rear end -- one lion ' s rear end was as good as another to john , africa , arizona no matter -- and she changed ends and took a swipe at john , but he ducked back .	115.70245
jones then recoiled his rope and threw again , this time hitting her on the back but failing to encircle her .	140.8223
she whirled and faced him , roaring terribly , and ulyate , watching through the leaves , could not understand why she did not charge and obliterate him , because he wouldn ' t have much of a chance of getting away , in that thick growth , but she seemed just a trace uncertain	86.3517
while jones , on the other hand , appeared perfectly confident and ulyate decided perhaps that was the answer .	317.93958
from the lioness ' point of view , this strange creature on the back of another creature , lashing out with its long thin paw , very likely appeared as something she could not at first cope with .	108.53102
but now she sank lower to the rock .	3.0330672
although she appeared more subdued and defeated , jones knew she was growing more dangerous .	107.591774
she was rested and could mount a charge .	12.515637
just the tip of her tail was moving as she crouched , and she was treading lightly up and down with her hind feet .	51.280693
at this moment , loveless and means arrived , crashing through the undergrowth with their horses , and distracted her , and she ran off a short distance and jumped into a crevice between two rocks .	41.209145
the dogs followed her and she killed three and badly wounded old john .	218.87122
`` we ' ve got to get her out of there ' ' ! !	22.818087
jones yelled , `` or she ' ll kill ' em all .	36.453854
for such an emergency he had included fourth-of-july cannon crackers as part of their equipment .	50.51836
lighting one he pitched it into the crevice , and the lioness left off mauling the dogs and departed .	57.173695
`` ain ' t she a beauty , though ' ' ? ?	30.098259
`` don ' t you go a step nearer her than i do ' ' , jones warned , `` and if you do , go at a run so you ' ll have momentum ' ' ! !	32.306644
for two hours they drove her from one strong point to another along the side of the reef , trying to maneuver her onto the plain where they could get a good throw .	66.134964
but she clung to the rocks and brush , and the day wore away .	47.80059
it was the story of the rhinoceros fight all over again .	67.73131
and the sun was beginning to go down .	12.220918
`` i ' ll get a pole ' ' , jones said finally , `` and i ' ll poke a noose over her head ' ' ! !	18.240656
at this moment she was crouched in a cave-like aperture halfway down the reef .	43.45713
ulyate made no comment but his face showed what he thought of poking ropes over lions ' heads with poles , and of course these were the lions of fifty years ago , not the gentler ones of today , and this one was angry , with good reason .	56.458206
`` it won ' t work , colonel ' ' .	9.330173
`` just the same we ' ll try it ' ' .	4.467812
but without waiting for them to try it , she scattered the dogs and shot down the reef and out across the plain .	71.55858
john led the chase after her and the other dogs strung out behind , many of them trailing blood .	50.573677
john himself was bruised and clawed from head to tail , but he was in this fight to the finish , running almost as strongly now as in the morning .	99.50295
she took refuge on a tongue of land extending into a gully , crouched at the base of a thorn tree , and waited for them to come up .	23.485435
with the gully on three sides , she could be approached only along the tongue of land .	58.501297
`` careful , now ' ' , jones warned .	8.755449
very slowly he maneuvered his rawboned bay gelding , edging closer , watching for a chance to throw , but ready to spin and run , rope whining about his head , horse edging tensely under him , but the gelding was obedient and responded and was not paralyzed by the close proximity of the lion .	50.19851
they tell you horses go crazy at the sight or smell of a bear or a lion , but these didn ' t .	45.909042
again she snarled , and again he edged .	5.4718776
with a whirling jump , it could get into gear .	75.24771
however nothing on four legs was supposed to be faster than a lion over a short distance , unless it was a cheetah .	45.201393
she was closing and within one more bound would have been able to reach the rear end of the bay , but -- and here jones and loveless and ulyate were holding breath for all they were worth -- she never quite caught up that last bound .	113.12611
means held steady one jump ahead of her .	7.573121
a western cowpony had outrun an african lion , from a standing start .	53.34722
photos showed later that she ' d been about six feet from means .	102.15703
of course the factor of head start made all the difference .	56.854797
the lioness quickly changed front , when she saw she couldn ' t catch means , and made for jones .	70.47537
as she had done with means , she gained rapidly at first , but then baldy began to draw away .	102.740654
somewhere in the few scant yards of head start was the determining point .	117.52988
when jones too drew away , she returned to a thorn bush in the neck of land running into the gully , crouched low and waited as before .	58.818737
this new position , however , gave the ropers a better chance .	204.57356
there was room to make a quick dash past the bush and throw as you went .	325.12656
so means edged around on the north side of her , jones moved in from the south .	69.12679
tossing his rope and shouting he attracted her attention .	42.39547
he succeeded almost too well , because once she rose as if to charge , and he half wheeled his horse -- he was within fifty feet -- but she sank back .	126.0468
from behind her means shot forward at a run .	140.25468
kearton began shouting , `` wait , wait -- the camera ' s jammed ' ' ! !	24.20033
he raced by within twenty feet of her , roped her around the neck , but a lioness ' neck is short and thick and with a quick twist she slipped the noose off .	65.6924
the missionary obligation to proclaim the gospel to all the world was once left to zealous individuals and voluntary societies .	142.44966
but the time came when a church that had no part in the missionary movement was looked upon as deficient in its essential life .	76.48173
the christian education of children , too , was once hardly more than a sideshow , but the day came when a congregation that did not assume full oversight of a church school was thought of as failing in its duty .	121.912224
the most serious weakness of the ecumenical movement today is that it is generally regarded as the responsibility of a few national leaders in each denomination and a few interdenominational executives .	50.250813
most pastors and laymen , even though they believe it to be important , assume that the ecumenical movement lies outside the province of their parishes .	87.54227
they may even dismiss it from their minds as something that concerns only the `` ecclesiastical rover boys ' ' , as someone has dubbed them , who like to go to national and international assemblies , and have expense accounts that permit them to do so .	118.8123
as long as this point of view prevails , the ecumenical movement will be lame and halt .	31.972097
the next stage ahead is that of making it thoroughly at home in the local community .	84.2362
progress will take place far less through what is done in any `` summit conference ' ' of the national council or the world council , or even in offices of the denominational boards , than through what happens in the communities where christian people live together as neighbors .	61.986633
the front line of advance is where witnessing and worshiping congregations of different traditions exist side by side .	212.59973
until they see the ecumenical movement in terms of the difference it makes in their own attitudes , programs , and relationships , it will have an inevitable aspect of unreality .	66.588196
as things now stand , there is a grievous disparity between the unity in christ which we profess in ecumenical meetings and the complacent separateness of most congregations on any main street in the nation .	89.22028
the crux of ecumenical advance is an even more personalized matter than the relation between congregations in the same community .	55.259335
the decisive question is what happens within each congregation and , finally , in the minds and hearts of the individual members .	60.43545
it is here that the local and ecumenical must meet .	137.4787
it is here that the ecumenical must become local and the local become ecumenical .	194.38509
it has become almost trite to say that the ecumenical movement must be `` carried down to the grass roots ' ' .	37.54161
this way of describing the matter is unfortunate .	1.9660457
one is that whatever is ecumenical has to do with some over-all organization at `` the top ' ' and needs only to be understood at the so-called `` lower levels ' ' .	57.249264
the truth , however , is that the ecumenical church is just the local church in its own true character as an integral unit of the whole people of god throughout the world .	39.001446
the other misconception is that our ecumenical problems will be solved if only the knowledge of the church in its world-wide extension and its interdenominational connections , now comprehended by many national leaders , can be communicated to all congregations .	74.20881
however needed this may be , the fundamental problem is not information but active commitment to the total mission of the church of christ in the world .	44.116653
the basic unit in the church , of whatever denominational polity , is always the congregation .	65.92555
it is hardly possible to emphasize this too much .	11.447757
most people do not realize that the congregation , as a gathered fellowship meeting regularly face to face , personally sharing in a common experience and expressing that experience in daily relationships with one another , is unique .	110.806206
the idea that it is a feature of all religions is entirely mistaken .	191.53703
the jewish synagogue affords a parallel to the christian congregation , but hinduism , buddhism , islam , confucianism , taoism , shintoism , although they have sacred scriptures , priests , spiritual disciplines , and places of prayer , do not have a congregation as a local household of faith and love .	49.139717
their characteristic experience is that of the individual at an altar or a shrine rather than that of a continuing social group with a distinctive kind of fellowship .	72.840904
how far the fellowship in most local churches falls below what the new testament means by koinonia ! !	189.98277
what is now called christian fellowship is often little more than the social chumminess of having a gracious time with the kind of people one likes .	90.23347
the koinonia of acts and of the epistles means sharing in a common relation to christ .	82.596725
it is an experience of a new depth of community derived from an awareness of the corporate indwelling of christ in his people .	56.636574
as dietrich bonhoffer puts it , `` our community with one another consists solely in what christ has done to both of us ' ' .	120.49001
this may mean having fellowship in the church with people with whom , on the level of merely human agreeableness , we might prefer not to have any association at all .	73.17346
there is a vast difference between the community of reconciliation which the new testament describes and the community of congeniality found in the average church building .	73.188225
whenever a congregation really sees itself as a unit in the universal church , in vital relation with the whole body of christ and participating in his mission to the world , a necessary foundation-stone of the ecumenical movement has been laid .	62.596134
the antithesis of the ecumenical and the local then no longer exists .	71.931335
of course , the perspective of those who are dealing directly with the world-wide problems of the people of god will always be different from the perspective of those who are dealing with the nearby problems of particular persons in a particular place .	65.650566
each viewpoint is valid if it is organically related to the other .	37.800644
our difficulty arises when either viewpoint shuts out the other .	48.3366
and this is what all too often happens .	15.016883
a little parable illustrative of this truth is afforded by an incident related by professor bela vasady at the end of the second world war .	31.637016
with great difficulty he made his way from his native hungary to geneva to renew his contacts as a member of the provisional committee for the world council of churches .	37.05495
when he had the mishap of breaking his spectacles , his ecumenical colleagues insisted on providing him with new ones .	199.77792
he often spoke of them as his `` ecumenical ' ' glasses and used them as a symbol of the kind of vision that is required in the church .	51.958878
it is , he said , a bifocal vision , which can see both the near-at-hand and the distant and keep a christian in right relation to both .	136.05586
as things stand now , the local and the ecumenical tend to compete with each other .	44.20987
on the one hand , there are ecumenists who are so stirred by the crises of the church in its encounter with the world at large that they have no eyes for what the church is doing in their own town .	84.5074
they do not escape the pitfall into which charles dickens pictured mrs . jellyby as falling .	97.38181
her concern for the natives of borrioboola-gha was so intense that she quite forgot and neglected her son peepy ! !	122.7878
likewise , the ecumenist may become so absorbed in the conflict of the church with the totalitarian state in east germany , the precarious situation of the church in revolutionary china , and the anguish of the church over apartheid in south africa that he loses close contact with the parish church in its unspectacular but indispensable ministry of worship , pastoral service and counseling , and christian nurture for a face-to-face group of individuals .	56.36046
on the other hand , many a pastor is so absorbed in ministering to the intimate , personal needs of individuals in his congregation that he does little or nothing to lead them into a sense of social responsibility and world mission .	95.78011
as a result , they go on thinking of the church , with introverted and self-centered satisfaction , only in connection with the way in which it serves them and their families .	42.510113
it would hardly be an exaggeration to say that ninety per cent of the energy of most churches -- whether in terms of finance or spiritual concern -- is poured into the private and domestic interests of the members .	93.58984
the parish lives for itself rather than for the community or the world .	41.898445
the gap between the ecumenical perspective and the parish perspective appears most starkly in a church in any of our comfortable suburbs .	142.95067
it is eminently successful according to all conventional standards .	13.527142
its preaching and its music give refreshment of spirit to men and women living under heavy strain .	86.74788
it provides pastoral care for the sick and troubled .	630.3776
it helps children grow up with at least a nodding acquaintance with the bible .	60.624702
it draws young people into the circle of those who continue the life of the church from generation to generation .	58.65587
and it is easy for the ecumenical enthusiast to lose sight of how basic all this is .	131.647
but what is this church doing to help its members understand their roles as christians in the world ? ?	62.21491
all too often its conception of parish ministry and pastoral care includes no responsibility for them in their relation to issues of the most desperate urgency for the life of mankind .	65.49307
it is not stirring them to confront the racial tensions of today with the mind of christ .	63.718544
it is not helping them face the moral crisis involved in the use of nuclear energy .	22.658058
it is not making them sensitive to the sub-christian level of much of our economic and industrial life .	162.16919
it is raising no disturbing question as to what christian stewardship means for the relationship of the richest nation in the world to economically underdeveloped peoples .	42.422523
it is not developing an awareness of the new kind of missionary strategy that is called for as young churches emerge in asia and africa .	89.40362
to put it bluntly , many a local church is giving its members only what they consciously want .	177.21123
it is not disturbing them by thoughts of their christian responsibility in relation to the world .	35.015694
we shall not make a decisive advance in the ecumenical movement until such a church begins to see itself not merely as a haven of comfort and peace but as a base of christian witness and mission to the world .	73.78332
there is a humorous but revealing story about a rancher who owned a large slice of texas and who wanted to have on it everything that was necessary for a completely pleasant community .	71.812584
he built a school and a library , then a recreation center and an inn .	82.81181
desiring to fill the only remaining lack , he selected the best site on the ranch for a chapel and spared no expense in erecting it .	117.826385
a visitor to the beautiful little building inquired , `` do you belong to this church , mr . rancher ' ' ? ?	30.215132
`` why , no , ma ' am ' ' , he replied , `` this church belongs to me ' ' ! !	11.180839
the story reflects the way too many people feel .	48.551662
as long as the congregation regards the church as `` our ' ' church , or the minister thinks of it as `` my ' ' church , just so long the ecumenical movement will make no significant advance .	74.81174
there must first be a deeper sense that the church belongs not to us but to christ , and that it is his purpose , not our own interests and preferences , that determines what it is to be and do .	53.474766
a local church which conceives its function to be entirely that of ministering to the conscious desires and concerns of its members tends to look on everything ecumenical as an extra , not as a normal aspect of its own life as a church .	101.78447
it would doubtless be greatly surprised to be told that in failing to be ecumenical it is really failing to be the church of christ .	79.92512
yet the truth , according to the new testament , is that every local church has its existence only by being the embodiment of the whole church in that particular place .	96.78011
yet a crowd came out to see some fresh kids from the city try to match the boys from the neighboring farms	73.900955
and buggies and wagons and chugging fords kept gathering all morning , until the edges of the field were packed thick and small boys kept scampering out on the playing field to make fun of the visitors -- whose pitcher was a formidable looking young man with the only baseball cap .	133.75023
this was a bitterly fought game , carrying almost as much grudge as a fist fight , with no friendliness exhibited between the teams except the formal politeness that accompanied the setting forth of ground rules and agreements on balls that went into the crowd .	140.95337
every pitch in the game brought forth a howl from the enraptured audience and every fly ball the visitors dropped ( and because their right fielder was still a little fuzzy from drink , they dropped many ) called forth yelps of derision .	138.23268
at one point in the game when the skinny old man in suspenders who was acting as umpire got in the way of a thrown ball and took it painfully in the kidneys , he lay there unattended while players and spectators wrangled over whether the ball was `` dead ' ' or the base runners were free to score .	95.200066
this was typical of such games , which were earnestly played to win and practically never wound up in an expression of good fellowship .	139.52733
when the visitors , after losing this game , rode along the village streets toward home , the youngsters who could keep abreast of them for a moment or two screamed triumphantly , `` you bunch of hay-shakers ! !	56.06366
baseball was surely the national game in those days , even though professional baseball may have been merely a business .	88.62826
radio broadcasts had not begun and most devotees of baseball attended the games near home , in the town park or a pasture , with perhaps two or three trips to the city each season to see the cubs or the pirates or the indians or the red sox .	78.30384
young men in school could look forward to playing ball for money in a dozen different places , even if they failed to make the major leagues .	95.263916
nearly any lad with a modicum of skill might find a payday awaiting him in the three i league , or the pony league , or the coastal plains league , or the fast eastern league , if not indeed in one of the hundreds of city leagues that abounded everywhere .	115.65976
even a city of thirty thousand might have six baseball teams , sponsored by grocers and hardware merchants or department stores , that played two or three times a week throughout the summer , usually in the cool of the evening , before an earnest and partisan audience who did not begrudge a quarter each , or even more , to be dropped into a hat when the game was half over .	85.39964
babe ruth , of course , was everyone ' s hero , and everyone knew him , even though relatively few ever saw him play ball .	143.78381
his face was always in the newspapers , sometimes in cartoons that seemed nearly as large as life .	209.78719
as the twenties grew older , and as radio broadcasts of baseball games began to involve more and more people daily in the doings of the professionals , the great hitters ( always led by babe ruth ) overshadowed the game so that pitchers were nearly of no account .	113.65035
boys no longer bothered learning to bunt and even school kids scorned to `` choke up ' ' on a bat as willie keeler and the famous hitters of another day had done .	64.89072
other hitters bloomed with more or less vigor in the news and a few even dared to dream of matching ruth , who was still called jidge by all his friends , or leo or two-head by those who dared to taunt him ( leo was the name of the ball player he liked the least ) and who called most of the world `` kid ' ' .	73.60102
lou gehrig was given the nickname buster , and he ran ruth a close race in home runs .	132.4743
but the nickname never stuck and gehrig was no match for ruth in `` color ' ' -- which is sometimes a polite word for delinquent behavior on and off the field .	103.03998
ruth was a delinquent boy still , but he was in every way a great ball player who was out to win the game and occasionally risked a cracked bone to do it .	69.67856
a few professional baseball players cultivated eccentricities , with the encouragement of the press , so that they might see their names in big black print , along with daddy browning ' s , al capone ' s , earl sande ' s , and the prince of wales ' .	36.34571
one who , for a time , succeeded best and was still the sorriest of all was charles arthur shires , who called himself , in the newspapers , art the great , or the great shires .	78.116035
it was his brag that he could beat everybody at anything , but especially at fighting , and he once took on the manager of his club and worked him over thoroughly with his fists .	81.86244
he was given to public carousing and to acting the clown on the diamond	163.34567
and a policeman asserted he had found a pair of brass knuckles in art ' s pocket once when he had occasion to collar the great first baseman for some forgotten reason .	142.21912
( this made a sportswriter named pegler wonder in print if art had worn this armament when he defeated his manager .	175.49008
) the sorry fact about this young man , who was barely of age when he broke into major-league baseball , was that he really was a better ball player than he was given credit for being -- never so good as he claimed , and always an irritant to his associates , but a good steady performer when he could fight down the temptation to orate on his skills or cut up in public .	100.1967
in his minor way charles arthur shires was perhaps more typical of his era than ruth was , for he was but one of many young men who laid waste their talents in these scott fitzgerald days for the sake of earning space in the newspapers .	129.30347
there were others who climbed flagpoles and refused to come down	29.263363
or who ingested strange objects , like live fish	1445.7788
or who undertook to set records for remaining erect on a dance floor , with or without a partner	243.3683
or who essayed to down full bottles of illicit gin without pausing for breath .	74.30799
one young man , exhilarated to the point of insanity by liquor and the excitement of the moment , performed a perfect swan dive out of the stands at the yale bowl during the yale-army football game , landed squarely on his head on the concrete ramp below , and died at once .	74.080894
but the twenties were not all insanity and a striving after recognition .	205.51588
the business of baseball began to prosper along with other entertainments , and performers -- thanks partly to george herman ruth ' s spectacular efforts each season to run his salary higher and higher -- prospered too .	125.315056
while fifty years before , albert goodwill spalding , secretary of the chicago ball club of the national league , could write earnestly to the manager of the buffalo club and request a guarantee of one hundred dollars for a baseball game in august , in this golden era a game at the yankee stadium might bring in nearly a hundred thousand dollars at the gate .	53.12804
and while less than ten years earlier the wayward black sox -- all of them top performers in their positions -- had toiled for stingy charles comiskey at salaries ranging from twenty-five hundred dollars to forty-five hundred dollars a year , stars now were asking ten thousand dollars , twenty thousand dollars , yes , even fifty thousand dollars a season .	87.89286
the greatest team of this period was unquestionably the new york yankees , bought by brewery millions and made into a ball club by men named ed barrow and miller huggins .	112.92906
boston fans sometimes liked to wring some wry satisfaction out of the fact that most of the great 1923-27 crew were graduates of the red sox -- sold to millionaires huston and ruppert by a man who could not deny them their most trifling desire .	58.524006
ruth himself , still owning his farm in massachusetts and an interest in the massachusetts cigar business that printed his round boyish face on the wrappers , had led the parade down from fenway park , followed by pitchers carl mays , leslie `` joe ' ' bush , waite hoyt , herb pennock , and sam jones , catcher wally schang , third baseman joe dugan ( who completed the `` playboy trio ' ' of ruth , dugan , and hoyt ) , and shortstop everett scott .	50.348213
by 1926 , when the mighty yanks were at their mightiest , only a few of these were left but they still shone brightest , even beside able and agile rookies like tony lazzeri ( who managed never to have one of his epileptic fits on the field ) , mark koenig , lou gehrig , george pipgras , and gray-thatched earl combs .	47.12324
the deeds of this team , through two seasons and in the two world ' s series that followed , have been written and talked about until hardly a word is left to be said .	82.5405
but there is one small episode that a few new york fans who happened to sit in the cheap seats for one world ' s series game in 1926 like best to recall .	124.01383
babe ruth , as he always did in the stadium , played right field to avoid having the sun in his eyes , and tommy thevenow , a rather mediocre hitter who played shortstop for the st . louis cardinals , knocked a ball with all his might into the sharp angle formed by the permanent stands and the wooden bleachers , where ruth could not reach it .	101.150024
the ball lay there , shining white on the grass in view of nearly every fan in the park while ruth , red-necked with frustration , charged about the small patch of ground screaming , `` where ' s the -- -ing ball ' ' ? ?	75.84165
but , as he snarled unhappily when the inning was over , `` not a sonofabitch in the place would tell me ' ' , so little tommy ran all the way home .	82.722855
the ordinary man and woman , however , saw little of the great professional games of those golden days , or of any other sporting event for that matter .	148.95703
promoters always hastened to place their choice tickets in the hands of the wealthy speculators , and only the man who knew the man who knew the fellow who had an in with the guy at the box office ever came up with a good seat for a contest of any importance .	69.26174
radio broadcasts , however -- now that even plain people could afford `` loud speakers ' ' on their sets -- held old fans to the major-league races and attracted new ones , chiefly women , who through what the philosopher called the ineluctable modality of audition , became first inured , then attracted , then addicted to the long afternoon recitals of the doings in some distant baseball park .	136.1225
in some cities games were broadcast throughout the week and then on weekends the announcer was silenced , and fans must needs drive to the city from all the broadcast area to discover how their heroes were faring .	135.31543
this had a pleasant effect upon the sunday gate receipts as well as upon the intake of the rail and bus companies , some of which began to offer special excursion rates , including seats at the park , just as the trolley and ferry companies had when baseball was new .	112.19695
while women had always attended ball games in small numbers ( it was the part of a `` dead game sport ' ' in the early years of the twentieth century to be taken out to the ball park and to root , root , root for the home team ) , they had often sat in patient martyrdom , unable even to read the scoreboard , which sometimes seemed to indicate that one team led another by a score of three hundred and eighty to one hundred and fifty-one .	73.120834
the questions women asked at baseball games were standard grist for amateur comedy , as were the doings of women automobile drivers	143.59511
for every grown man ( except a few who were always suspected of being shy on virility ) knew at least the fundamentals of baseball , just as every male american in this era liked to imagine ( or pretend ) that he could fight with his fists .	105.79929
and women were not expected to know that the pitcher was trying not to let the batter hit the ball .	58.424297
radio , however , so increased the interest of women in the game that it was hardly necessary even to have `` ladies ' days ' ' any longer to enable men to get to the ball park without interference at home .	95.85829
women actually began to appear unaccompanied in the stands , where they still occasionally ran the risk of coming home with a tobacco-juice stain on a clean skirt or a new curse word tingling their ears .	104.64555
the radio broadcasts themselves were often so patiently informative , despite the baseball jargon , that girls and women could begin to store up in their minds the same sort of random and meaningless statistics that small boys had long learned better than they ever did their lessons in school .	94.51432
this conclusion is dependent on the assumption that traditional sex mores will continue to sanction both premarital chastity as the `` ideal ' ' , and the double standard holding females primarily responsible for preserving the ideal .	89.687614
our discussion of this involves using erik erikson ' s schema of `` identity vs . identity diffusion ' ' as a conceptual tool in superimposing a few common denominators onto the diverse personality and family configurations of the unwed mothers from whose case histories we quoted earlier .	55.309105
our discussion does not utilize all the identity crises postulated by erikson , but is intended to demonstrate the utility of his theoretical schema for studying unwed mothers .	57.447792
we hope thereby to emphasize that , from a psychological standpoint , the effectual prevention of illegitimacy is a continuous long-term process involving the socialization of the female from infancy through adolescence .	56.147316
hypothesizing a series of developmental stages that begin in the individual ' s infancy and end in his old age , erikson has indicated that the adolescent is faced with a series of identity crises .	46.493202
the successful and positive resolution of these crises during adolescence involves an epigenetic principle -- during adolescence , the individual ' s positive resolutions in each area of identity crisis depend , to a considerable degree , on his already having resolved preliminary and preparatory identity crises during his infancy , childhood , and early adolescence .	76.54141
within erikson ' s schema , the adolescent ' s delinquent behavior -- in this case , her unwed motherhood -- reflects her `` identity diffusion ' ' , or her inability to resolve these various identity crises positively .	47.781208
the adolescent experiences identity crises in terms of time perspective vs . time diffusion .	149.49731
time perspective -- the ability to plan for the future and to postpone gratifying immediate wants in order to achieve long-range objectives -- is more easily developed if , from infancy on , the individual has been able to rely on and trust people and the world in which she lives .	89.425316
erikson has noted that , unless this trust developed early , the time ambivalence experienced , in varying degree and temporarily , by all adolescents ( as a result of their remembering the more immediate gratification of wants during childhood , while not yet having fully accepted the long-range planning required by adulthood ) may develop into a more permanent sense of time diffusion .	152.7947
experience of this time diffusion ranges from a sense of utter apathy to a feeling of desperate urgency to act immediately .	86.73163
these polar extremes in time diffusion were indicated in some of the comments by unwed mothers reported in earlier chapters .	66.147835
some of these mothers , apparently feeling a desperate urgency , made , on the spur of the moment , commitments , in love and sex , that would have life-long consequences .	65.19246
others displayed utter apathy and indifference to any decision about the past or the future .	68.72074
for many of these unwed mothers , the data on their family life and early childhood experiences revealed several indications and sources of their basic mistrust of their parents in particular and of the world in general .	92.26241
however , as erickson has noted , the individual ' s failure to develop preliminary identities during infancy and childhood need not be irreversibly deterministic with respect to a given area of identity diffusion in his ( or her ) adolescence .	65.42674
and , as shown in chapter 6 , , some snp females originally developed such trust only during their adolescence , through the aid of , and their identification with , alter-parents .	163.82257
in the specific case of time diffusion , we must emphasize the significance of the earlier development of mistrust when it is combined with the inevitable time crisis experienced by most ( if not all ) adolescents in our society , and with the failure of the adolescent period to provide opportunities for developing trust .	103.03055
the adolescent experiences two closely related crises self-certainty vs . an identity consciousness	163.1082
a sense of self-certainty and the freedom to experiment with different roles , or confidence in one ' s own unique behavior as an alternative to peer-group conformity , is more easily developed during adolescence if , during early childhood , the individual was permitted to exercise initiative and encouraged to develop some autonomy .	104.75719
however , if the child has been constantly surrounded , during nursery and early school age , by peer groups	134.22034
inculcated with the primacy of group acceptance and group standards	453.20343
and allowed little initiative in early play and work patterns -- then in adolescence her normal degree of vanity , sensitivity , and preoccupation with whether others find her appearance and behavior acceptable , will be compounded .	180.23491
her ostensible indifference to and rebellion against suggestions and criticisms by anyone except peer friends during adolescence are the manifestations , in her adolescence , of her having been indoctrinated in childhood to feel shame , if not guilt , for failing to behave in a manner acceptable to , and judged by , the performance of her nursery- and elementary-school peer friends .	112.25989
to be different is to invite shame and doubt	3845.3562
and it is better to be shamed and criticized by one ' s parents , who already consider one different and difficult to understand , than by one ' s peers , who are also experiencing a similar groping for and denial of adult status .	86.37945
the attitudes of some unwed mothers quoted in chapter 2 , , revealed both considerable preoccupation with being accepted by others and a marked absence of self-certainty .	92.506454
