many appeared to regard their sexual behavior as a justifiable means of gaining acceptance from and identification with others	139.52774
but very few seemed aware that such acceptance and identification need to be supplemented with more enduring and stable identification of and with one ' s self .	75.91966
another identity crisis confronting the adolescent involves anticipation of achievement vs . work-paralysis .	24.672714
the adolescent ' s capacity to anticipate achievement and to exercise the self-discipline necessary to complete tasks successfully depends on the degree to which he or she developed autonomy , initiative , and self-discipline during childhood .	83.04
the developmental process involves the individual ' s progressively experiencing a sense of dignity and achievement resulting from having completed tasks , having kept commitments , and having created something ( however small or simple -- even a doll dress of one ' s own design rather than in the design `` it ought to be ' ' ) .	125.45095
these childhood experiences are sources of the self-certainty that the adolescent needs , for experimenting with many roles , and for the freedom to fail sometimes in the process of exploring and discovering her skills and abilities .	107.04652
if she has not had such experiences , the female ' s normal adolescent degree of indecision will be compounded .	64.41571
she may well be incapacitated by it when she is confronted with present and future alternatives -- e . g . , whether to prepare primarily for a career or for the role of a homemaker	83.21406
whether to stay financially dependent on her parents or help support herself while attending school	824.6906
whether to pursue a college education or a job after high school	171.1474
and whether to attend this or that college and to follow this or that course of study .	194.50655
erikson has noted that , as this indecision mounts , it may result in a `` paralysis of workmanship ' ' .	17.408176
this paralysis may be expressed in the female ' s starting -- and never completing -- many jobs , tasks , and courses of study	152.90715
and in the fact that she bases her decisions about work , college , carreer , and studies on what others are doing , rather than on her own sense of identity with given skills , abilities , likes , and dislikes .	81.55566
the absence , during her childhood and early adolescence , of experiences in developing the self-discipline to complete tasks within her ability -- experiences that would have been subsequent sources of anticipation of achievement -- and her lack of childhood opportunities to practice autonomy and initiative in play and expression , both tend in her adolescence to deprive her of the freedoms to role-experiment and to fail occasionally in experimenting .	146.86761
the comments made by some unwed mothers ( quoted in chapter 2 ) ) reflect this paralysis of workmanship .	37.45922
they attended school and selected courses primarily on the basis of decisions others made	97.22054
they accepted a job primarily because it was available , convenient , and paid reasonably .	131.42941
these things both express and , at the same time , continue contributing to , their identity diffusion in an area that could have become a source of developing dignity and self-certainty .	61.718304
as their identity diffusion increased , they became more susceptible to sporadic diversions in love and sexual affairs .	45.103924
these affairs temporarily relieved the monotony of school or work activities containing no anticipation of achievement and joy of craftsmanship , no sense of dignity derived from a job well done .	194.39835
childhood experiences in learning work and self-discipline habits within a context of developing autonomy and initiative have considerable significance for the prevention of illegitimacy .	44.840984
the excerpts from case histories presented above confirm this significance , though through different facets of experience .	133.46146
for example , some unwed mothers had had no work experiences , household chores , and responsibilities during childhood and early adolescence	89.129875
they subsequently occupied their leisure hours in searching for something exciting and diverting .	137.12177
on the other hand , some unwed mothers had had so much work and responsibility imposed on them at an early age , and had thus had so little freedom or opportunity to develop autonomy and initiative , that their work and responsibilities became dull and unrewarding burdens -- to be escaped and rebelled against through fun and experimentation with forbidden sexual behavior .	139.38722
the adolescent also faces the identity crisis that erikson has termed ideological polarization vs . diffusion of ideals .	80.13928
in discussing the ways this crisis is germane to consderations for the prevention of illegitimacy , we shall again superimpose erikson ' s concept on our data .	44.82204
adolescents have a much-discussed tendency to polarize ideas and values , to perceive things as `` either-or ' ' , black or white -- nuances of meaning are relatively unimportant .	42.511166
this tendency is , perhaps , most clearly revealed in the literature on religious conversions and experiences of adolescents .	91.572136
erikson has postulated that such ideological polarization temporarily resolves their search for something stable and definite in the rapidly changing and fluctuating no-man ' s-land between childhood and adulthood .	65.65598
it provides identification -- with an idea , a value , a cause that cuts through , or even transcends , the multiple and ambivalent identities of their passage from child to adult , and permits their forceful and overt expression of emotion .	118.97501
the positive development , during adolescence , of this capacity to think and to feel strongly and with increasing independence , and to identify overtly either with or against given ideas , values , and practices , depends to a considerable degree on both previous and present opportunities for developing autonomy , initiative , and self-certainty .	116.83255
most adolescents have some ideological diffusion at various developmental stages , as they experience a proliferation of ideas and values .	34.801853
the diffusion is most pronounced and most likely to become fixed , however , in those who have had no or very minimal opportunities to develop the autonomy and initiative that could have been directed into constructive expression and so served as sources of developing self-certainty .	93.35976
a pronounced ideological diffusion -- i . e . , inability to identify independently with given ideas and value systems -- is reflected in many ways .	81.96146
for example , it is evinced by the adolescent ( or adult ) whose beliefs and actions represent primarily his rebellion and reaction against the ideas and behavior patterns of others , rather than his inner conviction and choice .	170.68587
it is mirrored by the individual willie lohmans , whose ideas and behavior patterns are so dependent and relativistic that they always coincide with those of the individual or group present and most important at the moment .	87.00883
in another sense , it is represented in the arguments of the `` true believers ' ' who seek to disprove the validity of all other beliefs and ideas in order to retain confidence in theirs .	39.543083
the case histories provide some interesting illustrations of ideological diffusion , embodied in the unwed mother ' s inability to identify independently a given value system or behavior pattern , , and her subsequent disinclination to assume any individual responsibility for her sexual behavior .	97.02214
for example , the unwed mothers expressed their frustration with males who did not indicate more explicitly `` what it is they really want from a girl so one can act accordingly ' ' .	107.03377
they were disappointed by the physical and emotional hurt of premarital sexual intercourse .	49.41384
they condemned the movie script writers for implying that sex was enjoyable and exhilarating .	47.01044
they criticized parents for never having emphasized traditional concepts of right and wrong	56.42112
and they censured parents who `` never disciplined and were too permissive ' ' or who `` never explained how easy it was to get pregnant ' ' .	60.914124
in the adult world , there are a number of rather general and diffuse sources of ideological diffusion that further compound the adolescent ' s search for meaning during this particular identity crisis .	152.35533
for example , some contemporary writing tends to fuse the `` good guys ' ' and the `` bad guys ' ' , to portray the weak people as heroes and weakness as a virtue , and to explain ( or even justify ) asocial behavior by attributing it to deterministic psychological , familial , and social experiences .	43.549713
in the final accounting , these would have augmented the bill for both sides .	75.44636
an estimate of one million dollars is probably not excessive .	46.11172
yet the huge amount of money consumed by the selden litigation , which many regarded as wasteful , indirectly contributed to constructive changes in legal procedure .	128.86252
the duration and other circumstances of the selden case made it a flagrant example of the gross abuses of patent infringement actions .	42.25111
the suit , as we have seen , came before the courts when patent attorneys , inventors , and laymen were making mounting demands for reforms in the american patent system .	80.95039
chief among the defects they singled out were the complicated and wearisome procedures in equity .	75.10067
in a long and angry footnote to his opinion , judge hough had lent the weight of judicial condemnation to such criticism .	95.57423
`` it is a duty ' ' , said hough , `` not to let pass this opportunity of protesting against the methods of taking and printing testimony in equity , current in this circuit ( and probably others ) , excused if not justified by the rules of the supreme court , especially to be found in patent causes , and flagrantly exemplified in this litigation .	88.17822
as long as the bar prefers to adduce evidence by written deposition , rather than viva voce before an authoritative judicial officer , i fear that the antiquated rules will remain unchanged , and expensive prolixity remain the best known characteristic of equity ' ' .	53.931156
observing that `` reforms sometimes begin with the contemplation of horrible examples ' ' , hough catalogued the many abuses encouraged by existing procedures .	86.50372
he cited the elephantine dimensions of the selden case record	295.1029
the `` objections stated at outrageous length ' '	1.0011702
and the frequent and rancorous verbal bouts , `` uncalled for and unjustifiable , from the retort discourteous to the lie direct ' ' .	66.98573
the fundamental difficulty of which the selden case was `` a striking ( though not singular ) example ' ' , concluded hough , `` will remain as long as testimony is taken without any authoritative judicial officer present , and responsible for the maintenance of discipline , and the reception or exclusion of testimony ' ' .	89.95667
not least among the members of the patent bar who echoed this powerful indictment were those who had participated in the selden suit .	84.85919
william a . redding asserted that if the case had been heard in open court under rules of evidence , the testimony would have been completed in sixty days instead of five years .	95.49319
inventors joined lawyers in the clamor for reform , inevitably centering upon the selden litigation as a `` horrible example ' ' .	35.268993
its costive deliberations were likened to those of the british courts of chancery mercilessly caricatured by dickens in bleak house .	76.85037
parker , who agreed with much of this criticism , did not conceal his dissatisfaction with procedural defects .	47.374718
but he felt that the selden case was being unfairly pilloried .	26.16069
in a detailed letter published in the scientific american in 1912 , he remarked that `` loose statements ' ' about the case showed scant understanding of the facts .	82.00391
the suit , although commonly designated as a single action , actually embraced five cases .	205.47719
parker insisted that the size of the record would have been drastically reduced but for an unavoidable duplication of testimony .	49.712856
in a private communication written in 1911 , parker had been more to the point .	54.79705
noting the complaints of inventors and members of the patent bar , he admitted that some of the strictures `` were fairly well founded ' ' , but he added that under existing rules the courts could not consolidate testimony in a group of suits involving separate infringements of the same patent .	52.110054
the vast industrial interests caught up in the selden suit , as well as the complex character of the automotive art , encouraged both sides to exploit `` every possible chance ' ' for or against the patent , said parker .	93.72743
`` this very seldom happens in this class or in other cases , and of course all of these matters led to a volume and an expense of the record beyond what ordinarily would occur ' ' .	70.09201
parker listed the remedies he deemed essential for reducing the cost and mass of testimony .	109.53355
the most important of these found him in agreement with hough ' s plea for reform .	93.53465
parker called for abolition of the indiscriminate or uncontrolled right of taking depositions before officers of the court who had no authority to limit testimony .	116.1197
the taking of depositions , he suggested , should be placed under a special court examiner empowered to compel responsive and relevant answers and to exclude immaterial testimony .	127.12313
`` i am satisfied that in the selden case had this power existed and this course ( been ) pursued , it would have shortened the depositions of some of the experts nearly one-half and of some of the other witnesses thereto more than that ' ' .	103.980286
in the end hough ' s acidulous protest , which parker called the `` now somewhat famous note on this ' selden ' case ' ' , did not go unheeded .	128.22842
in 1912 the united states supreme court adopted a new set of rules of equity which became effective on february 1 , 1913 .	59.322872
the revised procedure was acclaimed as a long-overdue reform .	55.28854
under the new rules , testimony is taken orally in open court in all cases except those of an extraordinary character .	70.575325
other expeditious methods are designed to prevent prolixity , limit delays , and reduce the expense of infringement suits .	22.137981
one of the a . l . a . m . lawyers observed that if the selden case had been tried under this simplified procedure , the testimony which filled more than a score of volumes , `` at a minimum cost of $1 a page for publication alone , could have been contained in one volume ' ' .	72.06255
while patent suits are still among the most complex and expensive forms of litigation , these rules have saved litigants uncounted sums of money .	118.90446
there is little doubt that they were promulgated by the supreme court as a direct result of the selden patent suit .	11.926208
even before it was formally dissolved in 1912 , the a . l . a . m . was succeeded by the automobile board of trade , the direct lineal ancestor of the present-day automobile manufacturers association .	30.534204
the trade bodies which came in the wake of the a . l . a . m . were more representative , for they never adopted a policy of exclusion .	37.067833
nevertheless , it is from the selden organization that the industry inherited its institutional machinery for furthering the broader interests of the trade .	60.97396
one of the chief features of this community of interest is the automotive patents cross-licensing agreement , a milestone in the development of american industrial cooperation .	68.38326
its origin lies in the selden patent controversy and its aftermath .	102.19225
from the earliest days of the motor car industry , before the a . l . a . m . was established , patent infringement loomed as a serious and vexing problem .	30.990095
many patent contests were waged over automobile components and accessories , among them tires , detachable rims , ball bearings , license brackets , and electric horns .	44.29647
the fluidity and momentum of the young industry abetted a general disregard of patent claims .	46.039955
as early as 1900 a wall street combination acquired detail patents with the intention of exacting heavy tribute from automobile manufacturers .	159.1858
this scheme failed , and the following decade brought a deluge of infringement suits among individual manufacturers that reached its crest in 1912 .	96.30421
in this tangle of conflicting claims , the patent-sharing scheme adopted by the a . l . a . m . at its founding proved to be the best device for avoiding or mitigating the burdens of incessant litigation .	64.475914
the interchange of shop licenses for a nominal royalty eliminated infringement suits among the members of the a . l . a . m . patent pool ( although it did not protect them against outside actions ) and kept open channels for the cross-fertilization of automotive technology .	61.95865
one of the conditions of the pool was a prohibition upon the withholding of patent rights among a . l . a . m . members .	30.159151
within its limits , this arrangement had the actual or potential characteristics of a cross-licensing agreement .	139.60901
its positive features outweighed the fact that the pool was an adjunct of a wouldbe monopoly .	42.41567
since the a . l . a . m . holdings embraced only about twenty-five per cent of motor vehicle patents , the denial of rights to independent companies did not retard technical progress in unlicensed sectors of the industry .	63.605682
the highly important dyer patents on the sliding gear transmission were held by the a . l . a . m . pool .	27.93256
but henry ford used the planetary transmission in his model t and earlier cars and , in 1905 , as a precautionary measure , took out a license from the man who claimed to be its inventor .	102.56307
for those affiliated with it , the a . l . a . m . pool was a haven from the infringement actions involving detail patents that beset the industry with mounting intensity after 1900 .	66.62234
by 1910 the courts were crowded with cases , many of them brought by freebooters who trafficked in disputed inventions .	24.412731
it was commonplace for auto makers , parts-suppliers , and dealers to find warning notices and threats of infringement suits in their daily mail .	54.908657
`` purely from the business man ' s standpoint and without regard to the lawyer ' s view ' ' , commented a trade journal , `` the matter of patents in the automobile and accessory trade is developing some phases and results that challenge thought as to how far patents are to become weapons of warfare in business , instead of simple beneficient protection devices for encouraging inventive creation ' ' .	113.52247
occasionally new enterprise was discouraged by the almost certain prospect of legal complications .	83.888504
one manufacturer who held an allegedly basic patent said `` i would readily put over $50 , 000 into the manufacture of the device , but it is so easy to make that we would enter immediately into a prolonged ordeal of patent litigation which would eat up all our profits ' ' .	60.084606
the prevailing view in the industry was summed up in 1912 by a group of auto makers who told a senate committee `` the exceedingly unsatisfactory and uselessly expensive conditions , including delays surrounding legal disputes , particularly in patent litigation , are items of industrial burden which must be written large in figures of many millions of dollars of industrial waste ' ' .	104.957085
by that time it was commonly agreed that patent warfare was sapping constructive achievement and blocking the free exchange of technical information .	86.31251
at this point charles c . hanch , long an advocate of patent peace in the industry , became chairman of the patents committee of the national automobile chamber of commerce , successor to the automobile board of trade .	62.351078
hanch was treasurer of the nordyke & marmon company , an indianapolis firm which had manufactured flour-milling machinery before producing the marmon car in 1904 .	70.49151
he had first-hand knowledge of the patent wars which had driven about ninety per cent of the milling equipment makers out of business in the mid-1890 ' s .	43.9847
anxious to avoid a similar debacle in the motor car industry , hanch went to detroit in 1909 to enlist the support of leading a . l . a . m . members for an industry-wide patent-sharing plan .	36.20442
the breach created by the selden patent doomed his proposal , but hanch did not abandon his scheme .	78.7216
after the demise of the a . l . a . m . , the time was propitious for establishing such a pool .	27.788252
most manufacturers were now disposed to heed a proposal for the formal interchange of patents .	54.442375
`` it is a much easier course to agree to let one another alone so far as ordinary patents are concerned ' ' , said a trade authority , `` than to continue the costly effort of straightening the tangle in the courts or seeking to reform the patent system , which appears to be getting into deeper confusion every day ' ' .	90.99345
with the other members of the patents committee -- wilfred c . leland , howard e . coffin , windsor t . white , and w . h . vandervoort -- hanch drafted a cross-licensing agreement whose essential feature of royalty-free licensing was his own contribution .	70.83165
the plan was supported by frederick p . fish , counsel for the national automobile chamber of commerce .	41.134796
it will be recalled that in his summation for the a . l . a . m . before judge hough , fish had condemned patent litigation as the curse of the american industrial community .	49.297737
he was well aware that some inventors and their allies used their patents solely for nuisance value .	128.1685
`` my personal view is that not one patented invention in ten is worth making ' ' , he later told a congressional committee .	181.36151
the eloquent persuasions of fish guaranteed the adoption of the plan by the members of the automotive trade association .	23.099012
drawn up in 1914 , the cross-licensing agreement became effective in 1915 .	55.61217
it remained in force for ten years and has been renewed at five-year intervals since 1925 .	48.43564
a little farther along the road you come to the church of santa sabina , called the `` pearl of the aventine ' ' .	18.211124
continue another hundred yards to the piazza of the knights of malta .	22.615444
on the wall of this square there are delightful bas-reliefs of musical instruments .	39.6395
the massive gate of the maltese villa affords one of the most extraordinary views in rome .	27.457033
if you look through the keyhole , you will see an artistically landscaped garden with the white dome of st . peter ' s framed in a long avenue of cropped laurel trees .	29.471313
retrace your steps a few yards on the via di santa sabina and turn right on the via di s . alessio , a street lined with stately homes .	25.469358
oleanders , cypress , and palms in the spacious gardens add much color and beauty to this attractive residential section .	239.31013
turn left a block or so before the street ends , and then turn right down the via di santa prisca to the viale aventino .	27.507877
here you can pick up a taxi or public transport to return to the center of the city .	38.18224
these two walks take you through the heart of rome .	11.067941
you will walk some of the narrow , old streets , hemmed in by massive palazzi .	94.06709
you will visit a few churches that are exceptional yet often by-passed , a magnificent square , the main shopping district , the spanish steps , and the lovely pincian gardens .	67.70886
by seeing such varied places , both interesting and beautiful , you will become aware of the many different civilizations rome has lived through , and in particular , get a feel of renaissance rome .	103.17646
you will realize why rome is indeed the eternal city .	169.41476
start on the via d . teatro di marcello at the foot of the capitoline hill .	12.442686
the majestic circular tiers of stone of the theatre of marcellus give you some idea of the huge edifice that the emperor augustus erected in 13 b . c . .	45.60327
twenty-two thousand spectators used to crowd it in roman days .	235.91034
andrea palladio , an italian architect of the sixteenth century , modeled his designs on its doric and ionic columns .	52.15771
wander past the three superb columns of apollo by the arches of the theatre .	24.662552
the remains of the portico of octavia are now in front of you .	47.487293
climb the steps from the theatre to the via della tribuna di campitelli for an even better view of the columns of apollo .	41.551105
turn to the right along a narrow street to the tiny piazza campitelli , then proceed along the via dei funari to the piazza mattei .	17.724596
here is one of the loveliest fountains in rome , the fontana delle tartarughe or `` fountain of the tortoises ' ' .	14.115985
it ' s typical of rome that in the midst of this rather poor area you should find such an artistic work in the center of a little square .	71.627335
stand here for a few moments and look at this gem of a fountain with its four youths , each holding a tortoise and each with a foot resting on the head of a dolphin .	55.341976
the figures have been executed so skillfully that one senses a great feeling of life and movement .	70.767365
opposite is the palazzo mattei , one of rome ' s oldest palaces , now the headquarters of the italo-american association .	30.971563
go inside for a closer look at a renaissance palace .	38.594673
in the first courtyard there are some fine bas-reliefs and friezes , and in the second a series of delightful terraced roof gardens above an ivy-covered wall .	55.964115
the palazzo caetani , still inhabited by the caetani family , adjoins the palazzo mattei .	46.329815
keep straight ahead on the via falegnami , cross the wide via arenula , and you will come to the piazza b . cairoli , where you should look in at the church of san carlo ai catinari to see the frescoes on the ceiling .	50.465282
follow the colorful and busy via d . giubbonari for a hundred yards or so .	44.698357
now turn left at the via dell ' arco del monte to the piazza dei pellegrini .	9.786797
just a few yards to the right on the via capo di ferro will bring you to the palazzo spada , built in 1540 and now occupied by the council of state .	23.887114
paintings by titian , caravaggio , and rubens are on display ( open 9 30 to 4 00 ) .	47.904675
before you enter the palazzo , note francesco borromini ' s facade .	8.420388
the great architect also designed the fine interior staircase and colonnade which connects the two courts .	48.096066
the large statue on the first floor is believed to be the statue of pompey at the base of which julius caesar was stabbed to death ( if so , the statue once stood in the senate house ) .	81.14146
( this is shown in the afternoon and on sunday morning .	73.74924
by tipping the porter , you can see in the courtyard borromini ' s unusual and fascinating trick in perspective .	43.57708
when you stand before the barrel-vaulted colonnade you have the impression that the statue at the end is at a considerable distance , yet it is actually only a few feet away .	44.139347
the sense of perspective has been created by designing the length of the columns so that those at the far end of the colonnade are much shorter than those in front .	62.136017
the gardens of the palazzo , shaded by a huge magnolia tree , are most attractive .	38.79413
from the palazzo spada you continue another block along the via capo di ferro and vicolo de venti to the imposing palazzo farnese , begun in 1514 and considered by many to be the finest palace of all .	25.695606
michelangelo was the most distinguished of several noted architects who helped design it .	124.59535
today it is occupied by the french embassy .	3.8519225
its lovely seventeenth-century ceiling frescoes , as well as the huge guards room with a tremendously high and beautifully carved wooden ceiling , can be seen sundays ( 11 00 to 12 00 noon ) .	70.21953
ask to see the modern tapestries of paris and rome designed by lurcat .	100.4775
directly in front of the palace along the via d . baullari you will come to the campo di fiori , the famous site of executions during the turbulent days of renaissance rome .	38.89247
today , by contrast it is a lively and colorful fruit , vegetable , and flower market .	82.01818
continue on the via d . baullari to the corso vittorio emanuele , then turn right for a couple of hundred yards to the church of sant ' andrea della valle .	20.87602
as you approach the church on the via d . baullari you are passing within yards of the remains of the roman theatre of pompey , near which is believed to have been the place where julius caesar was assassinated .	63.99704
the dome of the church is , outside of st . peter ' s , one of the largest in rome .	18.282469
opera lovers will be interested to learn that this church was the scene for the first act of tosca .	46.309273
at this point you cross the wide corso vittorio emanuele 2 , , walk along the corso del rinascimento a couple of hundred yards , then turn left on the via dei canestrani to enter the splendid piazza navona , one of the truly glorious sights in rome .	25.490633
your first impression of this elongated square with its three elegant fountains , its two churches that almost face each other , and its russet-colored buildings , is a sense of restful spaciousness -- particularly welcome after wandering around the narrow and dark streets that you have followed since starting this walk .	111.30923
the site of the oblong piazza is domitian ' s ancient stadium , which was probably used for horse and chariot races .	35.24113
for centuries it was the location of historic festivals and open-air sports events .	28.969639
from the seventeenth to the nineteenth century it was a popular practice to flood the piazza in the summer , and the aristocrats would then ride around the inundated square in their carriages .	80.23465
giovanni bernini ' s `` fountain of the rivers ' ' , in the center of the piazza , is built around a roman obelisk from the circus of maxentius which rests on grottoes and rocks , with four huge figures , one at each corner , denoting four great rivers from different continents -- the danube , the ganges , the nile , and the plate .	51.53531
the eyes of the figure of the nile are covered , perhaps either to symbolize the mystery of her source or to obscure from her sight the baroque facade of the church of sant ' agnese in agone , the work of bernini ' s rival , borromini .	53.943707
in the piazza navona there are many delightful cafes where you can sit , have a drink or lunch , and watch the fountains in the square .	48.336823
the scene before you is indeed theatrical and often appears in movies about rome .	165.4801
perhaps a street musician will pass to add that extra touch .	373.1797
take the via di s . agnese in agone , next to the church and opposite the center of the square , then turn right after about two hundred yards to reach the beautiful church of santa maria della pace .	52.47847
inside you will find the lovely sibyls painted by raphael and a chapel designed by michelangelo .	46.517673
the church ' s cloisters are among donato bramante ' s most beautiful creations .	7.9966645
now return to the piazza navona and leave it on the opposite side by the corsia agonale	30.957092
in a moment cross the corso del rinascimento .	13.105148
in front of you is the palazzo madama , once belonging to the medici and now the italian senate .	132.19371
walk by the side of the palazzo and after two blocks along the via giustiniani you will come to the piazza della rotonda .	30.943804
you are now facing the pantheon , the largest and best-preserved building still standing from the days of ancient rome .	93.248665
this circular edifice , constructed by agrippa in b . c . 27 , was rebuilt in its present shape by the emperor hadrian .	32.343815
it was dedicated as a church in the seventh century .	30.44149
as you pause in the piazza by the egyptian obelisk brought from the temple of isis , you will admire the pantheon ' s impressive corinthian columns .	33.305824
the pantheon ' s interior , still in its original form , is truly majestic and an architectural triumph .	89.9804
its rotunda forms a perfect circle whose diameter is equal to the height from the floor to the ceiling .	19.58055
the only means of interior light is the twenty-nine-foot-wide aperture in the stupendous dome .	64.94279
standing before the tomb of raphael , the great genius of the renaissance , when shafts of sunlight are penetrating this great roman temple , you are once again reminded of the varied civilizations so characteristic of rome .	114.97423
as you leave the pantheon , take the narrow street to the right , the via del seminario , a block to sant ' ignazio , one of the most splendid baroque churches in the city .	22.745605
( along the way there , about one hundred yards on your right , you pass a simple restaurant , la sacrestia , where you can have the best pizza in rome .	46.7898
) the curve of faded terra-cotta-colored houses in front of the church seems like a stage set .	52.079117
this is one of the most charming little squares in this part of rome .	47.58458
one block along the via de burro ( in front of the church ) will bring you to the stock exchange in the old temple of neptune .	55.57882
a few yards farther , on the via dei bergamaschi , is the piazza colonna .	12.773815
the great column from which the square takes its name was erected by the emperor marcus aurelius .	18.280212
you are now at the corso , though narrow , one of rome ' s busiest streets .	54.0762
horse races took place here in the middle ages .	5.409688
if you have taken this stroll in the morning , and you have the time and inclination , walk to the right along the crowded corso for half a dozen blocks to visit the fine private collection of paintings -- mainly of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries -- in the palazzo doria ( open sunday , tuesday , and thursday , 10 00 to 1 00 ) .	64.773254
here is your opportunity to see the inside of a palazzo where the family still lives .	68.64044
otherwise , cross over the corso and walk a block or so to the left .	66.16499
you will come to alemagna , a delightful , though moderately expensive restaurant , which is particularly noted for its exceptional selection of ice creams and patisseries .	54.399426
either here , or in one of the modest restaurants nearby , is just the place to end this first walk through the heart of rome .	81.460075
the second walk through the heart of rome should be taken after lunch , so that you will reach the pincian hill when the soft light of the late afternoon is at its best .	70.0774
rare , indeed , is the harlem citizen , from the most circumspect church member to the most shiftless adolescent , who does not have a long tale to tell of police incompetence , injustice , or brutality .	65.53197
i myself have witnessed and endured it more than once .	28.72974
the businessmen and racketeers also have a story .	45.1177
( and this is not , perhaps , the place to discuss harlem ' s very complex attitude toward black policemen , nor the reasons , according to harlem , that they are nearly all downtown .	127.97662
it is hard , on the other hand , to blame the policeman , blank , good-natured , thoughtless , and insuperably innocent , for being such a perfect representative of the people he serves .	63.58106
he , too , believes in good intentions and is astounded and offended when they are not taken for the deed .	58.96679
he has never , himself , done anything for which to be hated -- which of us has ? ?	166.94061
-- and yet he is facing , daily and nightly , people who would gladly see him dead , and he knows it .	57.57422
there is no way for him not to know it there are few things under heaven more unnerving than the silent , accumulating contempt and hatred of a people .	108.00732
he moves through harlem , therefore , like an occupying soldier in a bitterly hostile country	75.09834
which is precisely what , and where , he is , and is the reason he walks in twos and threes .	35.64637
and he is not the only one who knows why he is always in company the people who are watching him know why , too .	125.19178
any street meeting , sacred or secular , which he and his colleagues uneasily cover has as its explicit or implicit burden the cruelty and injustice of the white domination .	194.70596
and these days , of course , in terms increasingly vivid and jubilant , it speaks of the end of that domination .	111.830124
the white policeman standing on a harlem street corner finds himself at the very center of the revolution now occurring in the world .	73.96773
he is not prepared for it -- naturally , nobody is -- and , what is possibly much more to the point , he is exposed , as few white people are , to the anguish of the black people around him .	74.05755
even if he is gifted with the merest mustard grain of imagination , something must seep in .	182.36398
he cannot avoid observing that some of the children , in spite of their color , remind him of children he has known and loved , perhaps even of his own children .	72.46553
he knows that he certainly does not want his children living this way .	111.828255
he can retreat from his uneasiness in only one direction into a callousness which very shortly becomes second nature .	354.96216
he becomes more callous , the population becomes more hostile , the situation grows more tense , and the police force is increased .	101.18553
one day , to everyone ' s astonishment , someone drops a match in the powder keg and everything blows up .	92.59428
before the dust has settled or the blood congealed , editorials , speeches , and civil-rights commissions are loud in the land , demanding to know what happened .	59.111687
what happened is that negroes want to be treated like men .	202.22028
negroes want to be treated like men a perfectly straightforward statement , containing only seven words .	149.1086
people who have mastered kant , hegel , shakespeare , marx , freud , and the bible find this statement utterly impenetrable .	76.509445
the idea seems to threaten profound , barely conscious assumptions .	125.48727
a kind of panic paralyzes their features , as though they found themselves trapped on the edge of a steep place .	39.592434
i once tried to describe to a very well-known american intellectual the conditions among negroes in the south .	163.73253
and he asked me in perfect innocence , `` why don ' t all the negroes in the south move north ' ' ? ?	29.811007
i tried to explain what has happened , unfailingly , whenever a significant body of negroes move north .	295.2079
they do not escape jim crow they merely encounter another , not-less-deadly variety .	319.00012
they do not move to chicago , they move to the south side	32.010735
they do not move to new york , they move to harlem .	43.01691
the pressure within the ghetto causes the ghetto walls to expand , and this expansion is always violent .	122.29778
white people hold the line as long as they can , and in as many ways as they can , from verbal intimidation to physical violence .	57.552505
but inevitably the border which has divided the ghetto from the rest of the world falls into the hands of the ghetto .	25.228907
the white people fall back bitterly before the black horde	153.09853
the landlords make a tidy profit by raising the rent , chopping up the rooms , and all but dispensing with the upkeep	71.719505
and what has once been a neighborhood turns into a `` turf ' ' .	19.076532
this is precisely what happened when the puerto ricans arrived in their thousands -- and the bitterness thus caused is , as i write , being fought out all up and down those streets .	179.93094
they seem to feel that because they fought on the right side during the civil war , and won , they have earned the right merely to deplore what is going on in the south , without taking any responsibility for it	52.39778
and that they can ignore what is happening in northern cities because what is happening in little rock or birmingham is worse .	85.60705
well , in the first place , it is not possible for anyone who has not endured both to know which is `` worse ' ' .	41.746326
i know negroes who prefer the south and white southerners , because `` at least there , you haven ' t got to play any guessing games ' ' ! !	70.73852
the guessing games referred to have driven more than one negro into the narcotics ward , the madhouse , or the river .	69.5631
i know another negro , a man very dear to me , who says , with conviction and with truth , `` the spirit of the south is the spirit of america ' ' .	35.59784
he was born in the north and did his military training in the south .	55.081734
he did not , as far as i can gather , find the south `` worse ' '	114.99742
he found it , if anything , all too familiar .	96.880905
in the second place , though , even if birmingham is worse , no doubt johannesburg , south africa , beats it by several miles , and buchenwald was one of the worst things that ever happened in the entire history of the world .	56.206303
but i do not believe that these examples are meant to be used as justification for our own crimes .	43.119522
this perpetual justification empties the heart of all human feeling .	64.62169
the emptier our hearts become , the greater will be our crimes .	87.71534
thirdly , the south is not merely an embarrassingly backward region , but a part of this country , and what happens there concerns every one of us .	79.535126
as far as the color problem is concerned , there is but one great difference between the southern white and the northerner the southerner remembers , historically and in his own psyche , a kind of eden in which he loved black people and they loved him .	69.01175
historically , the flaming sword laid across this eden is the civil war .	67.28435
personally , it is the southerner ' s sexual coming of age , when , without any warning , unbreakable taboos are set up between himself and his past .	115.815605
everything , thereafter , is permitted him except the love he remembers and has never ceased to need .	131.40529
the resulting , indescribable torment affects every southern mind and is the basis of the southern hysteria .	54.364513
none of this is true for the northerner .	11.631958
negroes represent nothing to him personally , except , perhaps , the dangers of carnality .	74.854416
northerners never think about them whereas southerners are never really thinking of anything else .	71.16057
negroes are , therefore , ignored in the north and are under surveillance in the south , and suffer hideously in both places .	65.635666
neither the southerner nor the northerner is able to look on the negro simply as a man .	47.467304
it seems to be indispensable to the national self-esteem that the negro be considered either as a kind of ward ( in which case we are told how many negroes , comparatively , bought cadillacs last year and how few , comparatively , were lynched ) , or as a victim ( in which case we are promised that he will never vote in our assemblies or go to school with our kids ) .	113.21969
they are two sides of the same coin and the south will not change -- cannot change -- until the north changes .	222.46152
the country will not change until it re-examines itself and discovers what it really means by freedom .	158.1444
in the meantime , generations keep being born , bitterness is increased by incompetence , pride , and folly , and the world shrinks around us .	43.103664
it is a terrible , an inexorable , law that one cannot deny the humanity of another without diminishing one ' s own in the face of one ' s victim , one sees oneself .	65.061035
walk through the streets of harlem and see what we , this nation , have become .	135.04373
east river , downtown postscript to a letter from harlem	119.176636
the fact that american negroes rioted in the u . n . while adlai stevenson was addressing the assembly shocked and baffled most white americans .	53.62854
stevenson ' s speech , and the spectacular disturbance in the gallery , were both touched off by the death , in katanga , the day before , of patrice lumumba .	53.38477
stevenson stated , in the course of his address , that the united states was `` against ' ' colonialism .	28.541103
god knows what the african nations , who hold 25 per cent of the voting stock in the u . n . were thinking -- they may , for example , have been thinking of the u . s . abstention when the vote on algerian freedom was before the assembly -- but i think i have a fairly accurate notion of what the negroes in the gallery were thinking .	53.04284
it was my first reaction upon hearing of lumumba ' s death .	17.03307
i was curious about the impact of this political assassination on negroes in harlem , for lumumba had -- has -- captured the popular imagination there .	334.47974
i was curious to know if lumumba ' s death , which is surely among the most sinister of recent events , would elicit from `` our ' ' side anything more than the usual , well-meaning rhetoric .	81.97787
and i was curious about the african reaction .	12.272464
however , the chaos on my desk prevented my being in the u . n . gallery .	25.711914
had i been there , i , too , in the eyes of most americans , would have been merely a pawn in the hands of the communists .	29.190517
the climate and the events of the last decade , and the steady pressure of the `` cold ' ' war , have given americans yet another means of avoiding self-examination , and so it has been decided that the riots were `` communist ' ' inspired .	59.550083
nor was it long , naturally , before prominent negroes rushed forward to assure the republic that the u . n . rioters do not represent the real feeling of the negro community .	50.38967
according , then , to what i take to be the prevailing view , these rioters were merely a handful of irresponsible , stalinist-corrupted provocateurs .	66.12027
it is a view which even a minimal effort at observation would immediately contradict .	273.83752
one has only , for example , to walk through harlem and ask oneself two questions .	320.5926
the first question is would i like to live here ? ?	32.447586
and the second question is why don ' t those who now live here move out ? ?	85.65854
the answer to both questions is immediately obvious .	2.1927602
unless one takes refuge in the theory -- however disguised -- that negroes are , somehow , different from white people , i do not see how one can escape the conclusion that the negro ' s status in this country is not only a cruel injustice but a grave national liability .	72.105995
now , i do not doubt that , among the people at the u . n . that day , there were stalinist and professional revolutionists acting out of the most cynical motives .	55.51282
wherever there is great social discontent , these people are , sooner or later , to be found .	66.30357
their presence is not as frightening as the discontent which creates their opportunity .	102.91241
what i find appalling -- and really dangerous -- is the american assumption that the negro is so contented with his lot here that only the cynical agents of a foreign power can rouse him to protest .	80.6646
it is a notion which contains a gratuitous insult , implying , as it does , that negroes can make no move unless they are manipulated .	64.80272
color was delayed until 1935 , the wide screen until the early fifties .	110.0542
movement itself was the chief and often the only attraction of the primitive movies of the nineties .	73.38473
each film consisted of fifty feet , which gives a running time of about one minute on the screen .	78.26289
as long as audiences came to see the movement , there seemed little reason to adventure further .	289.34305
motion-picture exhibitions took place in stores in a general atmosphere like that of the penny arcade which can still be found in such urban areas as times square .	105.73167
brief snips of actual events were shown parades , dances , street scenes .	75.75379
the sensational and frightening enjoyed popularity a train rushes straight at the audience , or a great wave threatens to break over the seats .	45.274734
an early edison production was the execution of mary , queen of scots .	99.51927
an early film by a competitor of the wizard of menlo park simply showed a long kiss performed by two actors of the contemporary stage .	134.2444
in the field of entertainment there is no spur to financial daring so effective as audience boredom , and the first decade of the new device was not over before audiences began staying away in large numbers from the simple-minded , one-minute shows .	145.0392
in response , the industry allowed the discovery of the motion picture as a form of fiction and thus gave the movies the essential form they have had to this day .	75.74151
despite the sheer beauty and spectacle of numerous documentaries , art films , and travelogues , despite the impressive financial success of such a recent development as cinerama , the movies are at heart a form of fiction , like the play , the novel , or the short story .	68.419075
moreover , the most artistically successful of the nonfiction films have invariably borrowed the narrative form from the fiction feature .	183.18227
thus such great american documentaries as the river and the plow that broke the plains were composed as visual stories rather than as illustrated lectures .	188.41466
the discovery that movies are a form of fiction was made in the early years of this century and it was made chiefly by two men , a french magician , georges melies , and an american employee of edison , edwin s . porter .	37.6357
of the two , porter is justly the better known , for he went far beyond the vital finding of fiction for films to take the first step toward fashioning a language of film , toward making the motion picture the intricate , efficient time machine that it has remained since , even in the most inept hands .	131.50089
melies , however , out of his professional instincts as a magician , discovered and made use of a number of illusionary techniques that remain part of the vocabulary of film .	58.18892
one of these is the `` dissolve ' ' , which makes possible a visually smooth transition from scene to scene .	90.97449
as the first scene begins to fade , the succeeding scene begins to appear .	122.300476
for a moment or two , both scenes are present simultaneously , one growing weaker , one growing stronger .	217.73233
in a series of fairy tales and fantasies , melies demonstrated that the film is superbly equipped to tell a straightforward story , with beginning , middle and end , complications , resolutions , climaxes , and conclusions .	88.527695
immediately , the film improved and it improved because in narrative it found a content based on time to complement its own unbreakable connection with time .	217.21466
physically , a movie is possible because a series of images is projected one at a time at such a speed that the eye `` remembers ' ' the one that has gone before even as it registers the one now appearing .	157.24545
linking the smoothly changing images together , the eye itself endows them with the illusion of movement .	37.195465
the `` projection ' ' time of painting and sculpture is highly subjective , varying from person to person and even varying for a given person on different occasions .	89.28659
the drama in the theater and the concert in the hall both have a fixed time , but the time is fixed by the director and the players , the conductor and the instrumentalists , subject , therefore , to much variation , as record collectors well know .	97.641365
the time of the motion picture is fixed absolutely .	156.79591
the film consists of a series of still , transparent photographs , or `` frames ' ' , 35-mm . -wide .	40.08155
each frame comes between the light and the lens and is individually projected on the screen , at the rate , for silent movies , of 16 frames per second , and , for sound films , 24 frames per second .	94.24111
time is built into the motion picture , which cannot exist without time .	150.06877
now time is also the concern of the fictional narrative , which is , at its simplest , the story of an action with , usually , a beginning , a middle , and an end -- elements which demand time as the first condition for their existence .	139.08237
the `` moving ' ' picture of the train or the wave coming at the audience is , to be sure , more intense than a still picture of the same subject , but the difference is really one of degree	79.678345
the cinematic element of time is merely used to increase the realism of an object which would still be reasonably realistic in a still photo .	107.01804
in narrative , time is essential , as it is in film .	49.83309
almost everything about the movies that is peculiarly of the movies derives from a tension created and maintained between narrative time and film time .	258.36438
this discovery of melies was vastly more important than his sometimes dazzling , magician ' s tricks produced on film .	129.7163
it was porter , however , who produced the very first movie whose name has lived on through the half century of film history that has since ensued .	169.5718
the movie was the great train robbery and its effects on the young industry and art were all but incalculable .	147.79973
overnight , for one thing , porter ' s film multiplied the standard running time of movies by ten .	228.13681
the great train robbery is a one-reel film .	3.9745295
one reel -- from eight to twelve minutes -- became the standard length from the year of robbery , 1903 , until griffith shattered that limit forever with birth of a nation in 1915 .	106.02908
the reel itself became and still is the standard of measure for the movies .	106.887024
much of it has continued to be used over the years and the heart of it -- good guys and bad guys in the old west -- pretty well dominated television toward the end of the 1950 ' s .	60.417297
a band of robbers enters a railroad station , overpowers and ties up the telegraph operator , holds up the train and escapes .	77.32732
a posse is formed and pursues the robbers , who , having made their escape , are whooping it up with some wild , wild women in a honky-tonk hide-out .	99.343796
the robbers run from the hide-out , take cover in a wooded declivity , and are shot dead by the posse .	69.11473
as a finale is appended a close-up of one of the band taking aim and firing his revolver straight at the audience .	90.652176
all this is simple enough , but in telling the story porter did two important things that had not been done before .	131.60275
each scene is shot straight through , as had been the universal custom , from a camera fixed in a single position , but in the outdoor scenes , especially in the capture and destruction of the outlaws , porter ' s camera position breaks , necessarily , with the camera position standard until then , which had been , roughly , that of a spectator in a center orchestra seat at a play .	138.88593
the plane of the action in the scene is not parallel with the plane of the film in the camera or on the screen .	48.56838
if the change , at first sight , seems minor , we may recall that it took the italian painters about two hundred years to make an analogous change , and the italian painters , by universal consent , were the most brilliant group of geniuses any art has seen .	92.781624
in that apparently simple shift porter opened the way to the sensitive use of the camera as an instrument of art as well as a mechanical recording device .	38.662025
he revealed the potential value of the `` cut ' ' as the basic technique in the art of the film .	27.771132
cutting , of course , takes place automatically in the creation of a film .	55.285007
the meaning of the word is quite physical , to begin with .	109.53548
the physical film is cut with a knife at the end of one complete sequence , and the cut edge is joined physically , by cement , to the cut edge of the beginning of the next sequence .	66.991745
if , as a home movie maker , you shoot the inevitable footage of your child taking its first steps , you have merely recorded an historical event .	110.52404
if , in preparing that shot for the inevitable showing to your friends , you interrupt the sequence to paste in a few frames of the child ' s grandmother watching this event , you have begun to be an artist in film	93.41136
as the robbers leave the looted train , the film suddenly cuts back to the station , where the telegrapher ' s little daughter arrives with her father ' s dinner pail only to find him bound on the floor .	71.31843
the two events are taking place at the same time .	4.3261766
we leap from event to event -- including the formation of the posse -- even though the events , in `` reality ' ' are taking place not in sequence but simultaneously , and not near each other but at a considerable distance .	82.628395
the `` chase ' ' as a standard film device probably dates from the great train robbery , and there is a reason for the continued popularity of the device .	61.46086
it presumes both speed and urgency and it demands cutting -- both from pursued to pursuer and from stage to stage of the journey of both .	249.32239
the simple , naked idea of one man chasing another is of its nature better fitted for the film than it is for any other form of fiction .	90.199005
the cowboy films , the cops and robbers films , and the slapstick comedy films culminating in an insane chase are not only catering to what critics may assume to be a vulgar taste for violence	84.17593
these films and these sequences are also seeking out -- instinctively or by design -- the peculiarly cinematic elements of narrative .	73.01384
the creator of the art of the film d . w . griffith	22.442225
there still remained the need for one great film artist to explore the full potential of the new form and to make it an art .	80.398674
when he came to the movies -- more or less by accident -- they were still cheap entertainment capable of enthralling the unthinking for an idle few minutes .	148.22807
in about seven years griffith either invented or first realized the possibilities of virtually every resource at the disposal of the film maker .	99.812164
before he was forty griffith had created the art of the film .	21.680342
not that there had not been attempts , mostly european , to do exactly that .	235.84657
but in general the european efforts to make an art of the entertainment had ignored the slowly emerging language of the film itself .	85.91354
staggeringly condensed versions of famous novels and famous plays were presented .	54.716682
great actors and actresses -- the most notable being sarah bernhardt -- were hired to repeat their stage performances before the camera .	123.12217
in all of this extensive and expensive effort , the camera was downgraded to the status of recording instrument for art work produced elsewhere by the actor or by the author .	99.094376
the phonograph today , for all its high fidelity and stereophonic sound , is precisely what the early art purveyors in the movies wished to make of the camera .	67.07261
not surprisingly , this approach did not work .	16.170485
the effort produced a valuable record of stage techniques in the early years of the century and some interesting records of great theater figures who would otherwise be only names .	95.78449
but no art at all was born of the art effort in the early movies .	79.899666
in general , religious interest seems to exist in all parts of the metropolis	41.99993
congregational membership , however , is another thing .	21.668184
a congregation survives only if it can sustain a socially homogeneous membership	244.51767
that is , when it can preserve economic integration .	4.9032774
religious faith can be considered a necessary condition of membership in a congregation , since the decision to join a worshiping group requires some motive force , but faith is not a sufficient condition for joining	109.33228
the presence of other members of similar social and economic level is the sufficient condition .	52.198677
the breakdown of social homogeneity in inner city areas and the spread of inner city blight account for the decline of central city churches .	102.00525
central cities reveal two adverse features for the major denominations ( 1 ) central cities tend to be areas of residence for lower social classes	72.99727
( 2 ) central cities tend to be more heterogeneous in social composition .	159.50964
the central city areas , in other words , exhibit the two characteristics which violate the life principle of congregations of the major denominations they have too few middle-class people	104.40945
central city areas have become progressively poorer locales for the major denominations since the exodus of middle-class people from most central cities .	41.297447
with few exceptions , the major denominations are rapidly losing their hold on the central city .	146.32097
the key to protestant development , therefore , is economic integration of the nucleus of the congregation .	38.8421
members of higher and lower social status often cluster around this nucleus , so that protestant figures on social class give the impression of spread over all social classes	227.87502
but this is deceptive , for the core of membership is concentrated in a single social and economic stratum .	39.2436
the congregation perishes when it is no longer possible to replenish that core from the neighborhood	103.46123
moreover , residential mobility is so high in metropolitan areas that churches have to recruit constantly in their core stratum in order to survive	47.292416
they can lose higher- and lower-status members from the church without collapsing , but they need adequate recruits for the core stratum in order to preserve economic integration .	29.295294
the congregation is first and foremost an economic peer group	519.49225
it is secondarily a believing and worshiping fellowship .	2.5605242
if it were primarily a believing fellowship , it would recruit believers from all social and economic ranks , something which most congregations of the new protestantism ( with a few notable exceptions ) have not been able to do .	55.40622
they survive only when they can recruit social and economic peers .	24.68097
the vulnerability of protestant congregations to social differences has often been attributed to the `` folksy spirit ' ' of protestant religious life	47.654915
in fact , a contrast is often drawn in this regard with the `` impersonal ' ' roman catholic parish .	36.483913
we have seen that the folksy spirit is confined to economic peers	211.28593
consequently , the vulnerability to social difference should not be attributed to the stress on personal community in protestant congregations	59.896038
actually , there is little evidence of such personal community in protestant congregations , as we shall see in another connection .	100.47189
the vulnerability of protestantism to social differences stems from the peculiar role of the new religious style in middle-class life , where the congregation is a vehicle of social and economic group identity and must conform , therefore , to the principle of economic integration .	38.404415
this fact is evident in the recruitment of new members .	32.48909
the rule of economic integration in congregational life can be seen in the missionary outreach of the major denominations .	16.562674
there is much talk in theological circles about the `` church as mission ' ' and the `` church ' s mission ' '	28.512403
theologians have been stressing the fact that the church does not exist for its own sake but as a testimony in the world for the healing of the world .	30.840132
a crucial question , therefore , is what evangelism and mission actually mean in metropolitan protestantism .	246.12953
if economic integration really shapes congregational life , then evangelism should be a process of extending economic integration .	69.09977
the task of a congregation would be defined , according to economic integration , as the work of co-opting individuals and families of similar social and economic position to replenish the nuclear core of the congregation .	59.588825
( co-optation means to choose by joint action in order to fill a vacancy	32.02383
it can also mean the assimilation of centers of power from an environment in order to strengthen an organization .	68.230896
) in a mobile society , congregational health depends on a constant process of recruitment	100.85047
this recruitment , however , must follow the pattern of economic integration or it will disrupt the congregation	65.18267
therefore , the recruitment or missionary outreach of the congregation will be co-optation rather than proclamation -- like elements will have to be assimilated .	59.729958
evangelism and congregational outreach have not been carefully studied in the churches	100.152565
one study in pittsburgh , however , has illuminated the situation .	94.19421
in a sample of new members of pittsburgh churches , almost 60 per cent were recruited by initial `` contacts with friendly members ' ' .	69.69587
if we add to these contacts with friendly members the `` contacts with an organization of the church ' ' ( 11 . 2 per cent of the cases ) , then a substantial two thirds of all recruitment is through friendly contact .	61.33076
on the surface , this seems a sound approach to christian mission members of the congregation show by their friendly attitudes that they care for new people	125.83894
the new people respond in kind by joining the church .	6.405736
missionary outreach by friendly contact looks somewhat different when one reflects on what is known about friendly contact in metropolitan neighborhoods	250.21277
the majority of such contacts are with people of similar social and economic position	56.747894
association by level of achievement is the dominant principle of informal relations .	28.84724
this means that the antennae of the congregation are extended into the community , picking up the wave lengths of those who will fit into the social and economic level of the congregation	37.95629
the mission of the church is actually a process of informal co-optation	85.79936
the lay ministry is a means to recruit like-minded people who will strengthen the social class nucleus of the congregation .	23.948038
churches can be strengthened through this process of co-optation so long as the environs of the church provide a sufficient pool of people who can fit the pattern of economic integration	69.19417
once the pool of recruits diminishes , the congregation is helpless -- friendly contacts no longer keep it going .	317.66333
the transmutation of mission to co-optation is further indicated by the insignificance of educational activities , worship , preaching , and publicity in reaching new members .	99.76753
the proclamation of the churches is almost totally confined to pastoral contacts by the clergy ( 17 . 3 per cent of new members ) and friendly contacts by members ( over two thirds if organizational activities are included ) .	123.7289
publicity accounted for 1 . 1 per cent of the initial contacts with new members .	34.007168
in general , friendly contact with a member followed by contact with a clergyman will account for a major share of recruitment by the churches , making it quite evident that the extension of economic integration through co-optation is the principal form of mission in the contemporary church	73.36303
economic integration and co-optation are the two methods by which protestants associate with and recruit from the neighborhood .	187.42717
the inner life of congregations will prosper so long as like-minded people of similar social and economic level can fraternize together	122.26286
the outer life of congregations -- the suitability of the environment to their survival -- will be propitious so long as the people in the area are of the same social and economic level as the membership .	49.83775
economic integration ceases when the social and economic statuses in an area become too mixed or conflict with the status of the congregation .	79.152626
in a rapidly changing society congregations will run into difficulties repeatedly , since such nice balances of economic integration are hard to sustain in the metropolis for more than a single generation .	68.19353
the fact that metropolitan churches of the major denominations have moved approximately every generation for the last hundred years becomes somewhat more intelligible in the light of this struggle to maintain economic balance .	63.58291
the expense of this type of organization in religious life , when one recalls the number of city churches which deteriorated beyond repair before being abandoned , raises fundamental questions about the principle of protestant survival in a mobile society	145.1043
nonetheless , the prevalence of economic integration in congregations illumines the nature of the protestant development .	62.602135
it was observed in the introductory chapter that metropolitan life had split into two trends -- expanding interdependence on an impersonal basis and growing exclusiveness in local communal groupings .	102.3061
these trends seem to be working at cross-purposes in the metropolis .	40.51423
residential associations struggle to insulate themselves against intrusions .	4.870483
the motifs of impersonal interdependence and insulation of residential communities have polarized	320.20517
the schism between central city and suburb , negro and white , blue collar and white collar can be viewed as symptomatic of this deeper polarization of trends in the metropolis .	64.72388
it now becomes evident that the denominational church is intimately involved with the economy of middle-class culture , for it serves to crystallize the social class identity of middle-class residential groupings .	41.94998
the accelerated pace of metropolitan changes has accentuated the drive to conformity in congregations of the major denominations .	38.921413
this conformity represents a desperate attempt to stabilize a hopelessly unstable environment .	106.92133
more than creatures of metropolitan forces , the churches have taken the lead in counteracting the interdependence of metropolitan life , crystallizing and perpetuating the stratification of peoples , giving form to the struggle for social homogeneity in a world of heterogeneous peoples .	61.12242
since american life is committed above all to productivity and a higher standard of economic life , the countervailing forces of residential and religious exclusiveness have fought a desperate , rearguard action against the expanding interdependence of the metropolis .	63.76049
consumer communities have suffered at the hands of the productive interests .	44.28588
negroes , puerto ricans , and rural newcomers are slowly making their way into the cities .	116.56184
soon they will fight their way into the lower middle-class suburbs , and the churches will experience the same decay and rebuilding cycle which has characterized their history for a century .	127.60839
the identification of the basic unit of religious organization -- the parish or congregation -- with a residential area is self-defeating in a modern metropolis , for it simply means the closing of an iron trap on the outreach of the christian fellowship and the transmutation of mission to co-optation .	50.430126
mission to the metropolis contradicts survival of the congregation in the residential community , because the middle classes are fighting metropolitan interdependence with residential exclusion .	103.87027
this interpretation of the role of residence in the economy of middle-class culture could lead to various projections for the churches .	120.977455
it could be argued that any fellowship which centers in residential neighborhoods is doomed to become an expression of the panic for stable identity among the middle classes .	89.99996
it could be argued that only such neighborhoods can sustain religious activity , since worship presupposes some local stabilities .	169.02866
whatever projection one makes , the striking fact about congregational and parochial life is the extent to which it is a vehicle of the social identity of middle-class people .	38.299213
attention will be given in the next chapter to the style of association in the denominational churches	92.82601
this style is characteristically an expression of the communal style of the middle classes .	47.59267
the keynotes of this style are activism and emphasis on achievements in gaining self-esteem .	143.66257
these values give direction to the life of the middle-class man or woman , dictating the methods of child rearing , determining the pattern of community participation , setting the style for the psychiatric treatment of middle-class illness , and informing the congregational life of the major denominations .	56.240376
`` fellowship by likeness ' ' and `` mission by friendly contact ' ' form the iron cage of denominational religion .	92.77424
its contents are another matter , for they reveal the kinds of interests pursued by the congregation .	51.52375
what goes on in the cage will occupy our attention under the rubric of the organization church .	77.410065
an understanding of the new role of residential association in an industrial society serves to illuminate the forces which have fashioned the iron cage of conformity which imprisons the churches in their suburban captivity .	66.13386
the perplexing question still remains as to why the middle classes turn to the churches as a vehicle of social identity when their clubs and charities should fill the same need .	103.12467
with capital largely squandered , there seemed to them no other course to pursue .	137.53497
the directors sold directly to concessionaires , who had to make their profits above the high prices asked by the company .	115.374596
these concessionaires traded where they wished and generally dealt with the indians through engages , who might be habitants , voyageurs , or even soldiers .	92.88034
the concessionaires also had to pay a tax of one-tenth on the goods they traded , and all pelts were to be taken to company stores and shipped to france in company ships .	76.84418
the company disposed of the pelts , but with what profit , the records do not show .	182.04929
in accord with its penurious policy , the company failed to furnish presents to hold the loyalty of the principal indians .	130.15248
the lavish use of presents had been effective in expanding the indian trade of new france and louisiana in the previous century , and the change in liberality aroused resentment in the minds of the red men .	61.74724
traders from the english colonies were far more generous , and indian loyalty turned to them .	81.535
protests from governors and intendants passed unheeded , and the parsimonious policy of the company probably let loose indian insurrections that brought ruin to the company .	103.738754
in 1721 the king sent three commissioners to louisiana with full powers to do all that was necessary to protect the colony .	73.45149
they ordered the raising of troops and obtained 75 , 000 livres with which to build forts .	61.815144
they adopted a program by which louisiana was divided into five districts .	60.951084
in each of these there was to be a strong military post , and a trading depot to supply the smaller trading houses .	62.66159
for southeastern louisiana , mobile was the principal post , and it was to furnish supplies for trade to the north and east , in the region threatened by british traders .	33.025948
mobile was to be the anchor of a chain of posts extending northward to the sources of the tennessee river .	43.04169
fort toulouse , on the alabama river , had been erected in 1714 for trade with the alabamas and choctaws , but money was available for only one other new post , near the present nashville , tennessee , and this was soon abandoned .	59.59553
west of the mobile district was the lower mississippi district , of which new orleans was headquarters .	52.10348
dependent upon it were posts on the lower mississippi and the region westward to the frontiers of new spain .	41.502434
on the middle mississippi a principal post was to be located near the mouth of the arkansas .	25.985987
it was hoped that to this post would flow a large quantity of furs from the west , principally down the arkansas river .	70.677666
on the ohio or wabash was to be built another post `` at the fork of two great rivers ' ' .	92.62576
other posts would be established up the ohio and wabash to protect communication with canada .	113.724724
on the upper mississippi the illinois post was to be established near kaskaskia , and dependent posts were to be built on the missouri , `` where there are mines in abundance ' ' .	43.775223
each of the five principal posts was to have a director , responsible to a director-general at new orleans .	60.372402
an elaborate system of accounting and reports was worked out , and the trade was to be managed in the most scientific way .	57.591957
concessionaires were to be under the supervision of the directors .	14.703805
engages must be loyal to the concessionaires , and must serve until the term provided in the engagement was ended .	84.58158
the habitants were to be encouraged to trade and were to dispose of their pelts to the concessionaires .	44.14466
only two principal storehouses were actually established -- one at mobile , the other at new orleans .	99.14367
new orleans supplied the goods for the trade on the mississippi , and west of that river , and on the ohio and wabash .	38.968742
mobile was also supplied by new orleans with goods for the mobile district .	56.624634
the power that bienville exercised during his first administration cannot be determined .	123.65529
regulations for the indian trade were made by the conseil superieure de la louisiane , and bienville apparently did not have control of that body .	68.42554
the conseil even treated the serious matter of british aggression as its business and , on its own authority , sent to disaffected savages merchandise `` suitable for the peltry trade ' ' .	80.94792
it decided , also , that the purely secular efforts of bienville were insufficient , and sent missionaries to win the savages from the heathen carolinians .	31.306871
during the first administration of bienville , the peltry trade of the mobile district was a lucrative source of revenue .	43.446274
the alabamas brought in annually 15 , 000 to 20 , 000 deerskins , and the choctaws and chickasaws brought the total up to 50 , 000 pelts .	28.45955
these deerskins were the raw material for the manufacture of leather , and were the only articles which the tribes of this district had to exchange for european goods .	138.88347
during his first administration , bienville succeeded in keeping carolina traders out of the alabama country and the choctaw country .	144.59912
the director of the post at mobile kept an adequate amount of french goods , of a kind to which they were accustomed , to supply the indian needs .	70.41242
the alabama and tombigbee rivers furnished a highway by which goods could be moved quickly and cheaply .	49.085037
