de la laude , commander of the alabama post , had the friendship of the natives , and was able to make them look upon the british as poor competitors .	50.348648
diron d ' artaguette , the most prominent trader in the district , was energetic and resourceful , but his methods often aroused the ire of the french governors .	41.91669
he became , after a time , commander of a post on the alabama river , but his operations extended from mobile throughout the district , and he finally obtained a monopoly of the indian trade .	42.979763
the chickasaws were the principal source of trouble in the mobile district .	37.640305
their territory lay to the north , near the sources of the alabama , the tombigbee , the tennessee , and cumberland rivers , and was easily accessible to traders among the near-by cherokees .	42.126587
in 1720 some chickasaws massacred the french traders among them , and did not make peace for four years .	56.67434
venturesome traders , however , continued to come to them from mobile , and to obtain a considerable number of pelts for the french markets .	37.386147
british traders from south carolina incited the indians against the french , and there developed french and british factions in the tribe .	49.796513
the chickasaws finally were the occasion for the most disastrous wars during the french control of louisiana .	151.08554
to hold them was an essential part of french policy , for they controlled the upper termini of the routes from the north to mobile .	56.03346
they threatened constantly to give the british a hold on this region , from whence they could move easily down the rivers to the french settlements near the gulf .	135.58812
bienville realized that if the french were to hold the southeastern tribes against the enticements of british goods , french traders must be able to offer a supply as abundant as the carolinians and at reasonable prices .	50.810062
the company of the indies promised to send over a supply of indian trading goods , and to price them more cheaply in terms of deerskins .	59.62575
but it coupled with this a requirement that indians must bring their pelts to mobile and thus save all costs of transportation into and out of the indian country .	110.53142
the insistence of bienville upon giving liberal prices to the indians , in order to drive back the carolina traders , was probably a factor that led to his recall in 1724 .	67.611626
for two years his friend and cousin , boisbriant , remained as acting governor and could do little to stem the anglican advance .	198.08888
although he incited a few friendly indians to pillage the invaders , and even kill some of them , the carolina advance continued .	103.029854
the company was impressed with some ideas of the danger from carolina , and when perier came over as governor in 1727 , he was given special instructions regarding the trade of the mobile district .	71.88484
but the company of the indies , holding to its program of economy , made no arrangements to furnish better goods at attractive prices .	188.16154
to the directors the problem appeared a matter of intrigue or diplomacy .	38.607174
perier attempted to understand the problem by sending agents to inquire among the indians .	87.99644
these agents were to ascertain the difference between english and french goods , and the prices charged the indians .	56.806805
they were to conciliate the unfriendly savages , and , wherever possible , to incite the natives to pillage the traders from carolina .	55.631294
they were to promise fine presents to the loyal red men , as well as an abundant supply of trading goods at better prices than the opposition was offering .	84.760796
one was british and the other , french .	155.12917
so hostile did these factions become that , among the choctaws , civil war broke out .	72.17713
perier ' s efforts , however , were on the whole ineffective in winning back the tribes of the mobile district , and he decided to send troops into the troubled country .	66.18752
he asked the government for two hundred soldiers , who were to be specifically assigned to arrest english traders and disloyal indians .	60.000175
in spite of the company ' s restrictions , he planned to build new posts in the territory .	46.81486
he asked also for more supplies to trade at a low price for the indians ' pelts .	47.85067
no help came from the crown , and perier , in desperation , gave a monopoly of the indian trade in the district to d ' artaguette .	36.468178
d ' artaguette went vigorously to work , and gave credit to many hunters .	100.19102
but they brought back few pelts to pay their debts , and soon french trade in the region was at an end .	51.427383
perier finally , in one last bid in 1730 , cut the price of goods to an advance of 40 per cent above the cost in france .	47.26322
the indians were not impressed and held to the carolina traders , who swarmed over the country , almost to the mississippi .	70.432304
with the loss of the mobile trade , which ended all profits from louisiana , the natchez indians revolted .	63.280987
they destroyed a trading house and pillaged the goods , and harassed french shipping on the mississippi .	61.547028
the war to subdue them taxed the resources of the colony and piled up enormous debts .	24.800234
in january , 1731 , the company asked the crown to relieve it of the government of the colony .	49.710392
it stated that it had lost 20 , 000 , 000 livres in its operations , and apparently blamed its poor success largely on the indian trade .	45.364113
it offered to surrender its right to exclusive trade , but asked an indemnity .	68.16482
the king accepted the surrender and fixed the compensation of the company at 1 , 450 , 000 livres .	21.650537
thenceforth , the commerce of louisiana was free to all frenchmen .	49.944363
company rule in louisiana left the colony without fortifications , arms , munitions , or supplies .	23.064123
the difficulties of trade had ruined many voyageurs , and numbers of them had gone to live with the natives and rear half-blood families .	44.78033
others left the country , and there was no one familiar with the indian trade .	48.33809
if this trade should be resumed , the habitants who had come to be farmers or artisans , and soldiers discharged from the army , must be hardened to the severe life of coureurs de bois .	76.2753
this was a slow and difficult course , and french trade suffered from the many mistakes of the new group of traders .	89.966415
perier and salmon , the intendant , wished either to entrust the trade to an association of merchants or to have the crown furnish goods on credit to individuals who would repay their debts with pelts .	120.42372
bienville , who returned to succeed perier in 1732 , objected that the merchants would not accept the responsibility of managing a trade in which they could see no hope of profits .	61.446735
he reported , too , that among the habitants there were none of probity and ability sufficient to justify entrusting them with the king ' s goods .	66.83964
he did find some to trust , however , and he employed the king ' s soldiers to trade .	35.032738
with no company to interfere , he kept close control over all the traders .	149.56078
in order to compete with english traders , bienville radically changed the price schedule .	267.78494
the king should expect no profit , and an advance of only 20 per cent above the cost in france , which would cover the expense of transportation and handling , was all he charged the traders .	75.69948
they would not be pleased to have it published back home that they planned a frolic in paris or hong kong at the treasury ' s expense .	106.481895
they would be particularly displeased with the state department if it were the source of such reports .	62.00904
few things are more perilous for the state department than a displeased congressman .	60.72663
the reason for this bears explaining for those who may wonder why state spends so much of its diplomatic energy on congress when the russians are so available .	102.018234
first , the state department is unique among government agencies for its lack of public supporters .	101.14023
the farmers may be aroused if congress cuts into the agriculture department ' s budget .	20.111786
businessmen will rise if congress attacks the commerce department .	12.818886
the chamber of commerce , assaults upon the treasury .	123.8574
a kaleidoscope of pressure groups make it unpleasant for the congressman who becomes ugly toward the department of health , education , and welfare .	43.569622
the congressman ' s patriotism is always involved when he turns upon the defense department .	55.677654
tampering with the post office may infuriate every voter who can write .	122.31662
with all these agencies , the congressman must constantly check the political wind and trim his sails accordingly .	164.96596
no such political restraint subdues his blood when he gazes upon the state department in anger .	47.737164
in many sections he may even reap applause from press and public for giving it a good lesson .	155.8291
after all , the money dispensed by state goes not to the farmer , the laborer , or the businessman , but to foreigners .	102.88145
not only do these foreigners not vote for american congressmen	153.11467
they are also probably ungrateful for uncle ' s sam ' s bounty .	19.54671
and are not the state department men who dispense this largesse merely crackpots and do-gooders who have never met a payroll ? ?	108.36306
will not the righteous congressman be cheered at the polls if he reminds them to get right with america and if he saves the taxpayer some money by spoiling a few of their schemes ? ?	94.05938
the result is that the state department ' s perpetual position before congress is the resigned pose of the whipping boy who expects to be kicked whenever the master has had a dyspeptic outing with his wife .	105.38682
people in this position do not offend the master by relating his peccadilloes to the newspapers .	86.15493
the department expects and receives no thanks from congress for its discretion .	45.807404
state is expected to arrange the touring cicero ' s foreign itinerary	19.603096
its embassies are expected to supply him with reams of local money to pay his way	197.03877
embassy workers are expected to entertain him according to his whim , frequently with their savings for the children ' s college tuition .	59.951897
but come the next session of congress , state can expect only that its summer guest will bite its hand when it goes to the capitol asking money for diplomatic entertaining expenses abroad or for living expenses for its diplomats .	271.6985
the congressman who , in paris , may have stuffed his wallet with enough franc notes to paper the roof of notre-dame will systematically scream that a $200 increase in entertainment allowance for a second secretary is tantamount to debauchery of the treasury .	178.76247
in the matter of money state ' s most unrelenting watchdog during the eisenhower years was representative john j . rooney , of brooklyn , who controlled the purse for diplomatic administrative expenses .	102.600586
diplomats stayed up nights thinking of ways to attain peaceful coexistence , not with nikita khrushchev , but with john rooney .	80.33257
in the most confidential whispers ambassadors told of techniques they had tried to bring rooney around -- friendly persuasion , groveling abasement , pressure subtly exerted through other powerful congressmen , tales of heartbreak and penury among a threadbare diplomatic corps .	108.40187
`` the trouble , ' ' explained loy henderson , then deputy undersecretary for administration , `` is that when we get into an argument with him about this thing , it always turns out that rooney knows more about our budget than we do ' ' .	87.3555
one year the department collected a file of case histories to document its argument that men in the field were paying the government ' s entertainment bills out of personal income .	84.66999
next day , reports went through the department that rooney had been outraged by what he considered a patent attempt to put public pressure on him for increased entertainment allowances and had sworn an oath that , that year , expense allowances would not rise a dollar .	141.07697
the department ' s constant fight with the house for money is a polite minuet compared with its periodic bloody engagements with the senate .	66.90932
armed with constitutional power to negate the executive ' s foreign policy , the senate carries a big stick and is easily provoked to use it on the state department ' s back , or on the head of the secretary of state .	42.477905
with its power to investigate , the senate can paralyze the secretary by keeping him in a state of perpetual testimony before committees , as it did with dean acheson .	103.18468
john foster dulles escaped by keeping his personal show on the road and because lyndon johnson , who was then operating the senate , refused to let it become an inquisition .	92.03068
during dulles ' s first two years in office , while republicans ran the senate , the department was at the mercy of men who had thirsted for its blood since 1945 .	96.01936
an internal police operation managed by scott mcleod , a former f . b . i . man installed as security officer upon congressional insistence , was part of the vengeance .	103.50371
so was the attack upon charles e . bohlen when eisenhower appointed him ambassador to moscow .	257.30103
the principal mauler , however , was senator joseph mccarthy .	7.4498878
where acheson had fought a gallant losing battle for the department , dulles fed the crocodile with his subordinates .	73.16087
fretting privately but eschewing public defense of his terrorized bureaucrats , dulles remained serene and detached while the hatchet men had their way .	93.33576
in view of eisenhower ' s reluctance to concede that anything was amiss in the terror , it is doubtful that heroic intervention by dulles could have produced anything but disaster for him and the country ' s foreign policy .	42.935413
in any event , the example of acheson ' s trampling by the senate did not encourage dulles to provoke it .	44.374836
he elected to `` get along ' ' .	3.157858
during this dark chapter in state department history , men who had offered foreign-policy ideas later proven wrong by events filled the tumbrels sent up to capitol hill .	245.60419
their old errors of judgment were equated , in the curious logic of the time , with present treasonous intent .	49.5631
their successors , absorbing the lesson , made it a point to have few ideas .	109.63957
this , in turn , brought a new fashion in senatorial criticism as the democrats took control .	210.52905
in the new style , the department was berated as intellectually barren and unable to produce the vital ideas needed to outwit the russians .	98.49618
for three or four years in the mid-1950 ' s , this complaint was heard rumbling up from the senate floor whenever there was a dull legislative afternoon .	61.971146
it became smart to say that the fault was with dulles because he would not countenance thinking done by anyone but himself .	193.59059
an equally tenable thesis is that the dearth of new thought was created by the senate ' s own penchant for crucifying anyone whose ideas seem unorthodox to the next generation .	59.89778
there are ninety-eight foreign embassies and legations in washington .	11.997067
they range from the soviet embassy on sixteenth street , a gray shuttered pile suggesting a funeral-accessories display house , to what congressman rooney has called `` that monstrosity on thirty-fourth street ' ' , the modern cement-and-glass chancery of the belgians .	50.612816
here is the world of the chauffeured limousine and the gossip reporter , of caviar on stale crackers and the warm martini , of the poseur , the spy , the party crasher , and the patriot , of the rented tails , the double cross , and the tired lothario .	43.460644
into its chanceries each day pour reports from ministries around the earth and an endless stream of home-office instructions on how to handle uncle sam in an infinite variety of contingencies .	76.96516
here are hatched plans for getting a share of the american bounty , the secret of the anti-missile missile , or an invitation to dinner .	37.314194
out of it each week go hundreds of thousands of words purporting to inform home ministries about what is really happening inside washington .	125.4604
some , like the british and the french , maintain an elaborate system of personal contacts and have experts constantly studying special areas of the american scene .	161.30705
other embassies cable home the new york times without changing a comma .	154.08092
the soviet embassy is popularly regarded as russian espionage headquarters .	19.627447
when ambassador mikhail menshikov took it over in 1957 from georgi zaroubin , he made a determined effort to change this idea .	60.585865
menshikov hit washington with a tv announcer ' s grin and a hearty handclasp .	14.272185
to everyone ' s astonishment he seemed no more like the run-of-the-mine russian ambassador than george babbitt was like fyodor pavlovitch karamazov .	89.85742
where his predecessors had glowered , menshikov smiled .	10.704417
where they had affected the bleak social style of embalmers ' assistants , menshikov went abroad gorgeous in white tie and tails .	95.54606
overnight he became the most available man in washington .	21.21332
speeches by the soviet ambassador became the vogue as he obliged rural maryland rotarians and national press club alike .	169.96863
in senator joseph mccarthy ' s phrase , it was the most unheard-of thing ever heard of .	76.349464
a newspaperman who met him at a reception swore that he asked menshikov `` what should we call you ' ' ? ?	29.686113
and that menshikov replied `` just call me mike ' ' .	18.28798
`` smilin ' mike ' ' was the sobriquet washington gave him .	150.94986
his english was usable and he used it fearlessly .	589.17944
toasting in champagne one night at the embassy , he hoisted his glass to a senator ' s wife and gaily cried `` up your bottom ' ' ! !	46.740807
for a few giddy months that coincided with one of moscow ' s smiling moods , he was the sensation of washington .	40.023174
at the state department , hard-bitten russian experts complained that the capitol was out of its wits .	55.9253
newspaper punditry was inspired to remind everyone that judas , too , had been able to smile .	47.157608
the menshikov interlude ended as larks with the russians usually end .	359.53943
finding peaceful coexistence temporarily unsuitable because of domestic politics , moscow resumed scowling and `` smilin ' mike ' ' dropped quietly out of the press except for an occasional story reporting that he had been stoned somewhere in the middle west .	37.23486
the most inscrutable embassies are the arabs ' , and the most inscrutable of the arabs are the saudi arabians .	29.924686
when king saud visited washington , the overwhelming question consuming the press was the size of his family .	68.94593
rumor had it that his children numbered in the hundreds .	48.615788
the state department was little help on this , or on much else about saudi arabia .	159.63771
a reporter who consulted a middle east information officer for routine vital statistics got nowhere until the state department man produced from his bottom desk drawer a brochure published by the arabian-american oil company .	137.92409
`` this is where i get my information from ' ' , he confided .	33.20768
it ' s the only copy i ' ve got ' ' .	4.9575086
the size of saud ' s family was still being debated when the king appeared for his first meeting with eisenhower .	88.54264
when it ended , a dusky sheik in desert robes flowed into hagerty ' s office to report on the interview .	40.8886
the massed reporters brushed aside the customary bromides about saudi-american friendship to bore in on the central question .	157.67424
how many children did the king have ? ?	1.3241026
`` twenty-one ' ' , replied the sheik .	65.30183
and how many of these were sons ? ?	1.0352682
`` twenty-five ' ' , the sheik replied .	6.732362
`` do you mean to tell us ' ' , a reporter asked , `` that the king has twenty-one children , twenty-five of whom are sons ' ' ? ?	21.357985
the sheik smiled and murmured `` that is precisely correct ' ' .	46.37478
the egyptians are noted for elusiveness of language .	6.0552573
when dag hammarskjold was negotiating the middle east peace after israel ' s 1956 invasion of egypt , he soon found himself speaking the mysterious phrases of cairo , a language as anarchic as casey stengel ' s .	101.30656
the reports of president nasser ' s pledges which hammarskjold was relaying from cairo to washington became increasingly incomprehensible to other diplomats , including the israeli foreign minister , mrs . golda meir .	56.25478
finally he reported that nasser was ready to make a concrete commitment in return for israeli concessions .	104.49995
the deep water is used by many people , but it is always clean , for the washing is done outside .	50.203583
i know now why our japanese friends were surprised when they walked into our bathroom .	75.63093
of course , most toilets are eastern style -- at floor level -- but even when they are raised to chair height , they are actually outside toilets -- inside .	163.74472
a few newer homes have western flush toilets , but even with running water , they are usually eastern style .	113.66932
the next day i visited international christian college which has developed since the war under the leadership of people who were interned and who know japan well .	97.07476
they are trying to demonstrate some different ways of teaching and learning .	57.9088
the library has open shelves even in the unbound periodical stockroom .	87.453064
spiritual life is cultivated , but students do not need to be christian .	18.870127
they have an enviable record of being able to place in employment 100% of their graduates .	117.65874
in the afternoon miss hosaka and her mother invited me to go with them and young mrs . kodama to see the famous spring dances of the geisha dancers .	58.581017
mrs . hosaka is one of the japanese women one reads about -- beautiful , artistically talented , an artful manager of her big household -- ( four boys and four girls ) , and yet looking like a pampered , gentle japanese woman .	130.09886
the dances were as beautiful as anything i have ever seen -- they rival the new york rockettes for scenery and precision as well as imagination .	50.87512
because don was leaving the next day , i spent the evening with him at asia center .	141.66687
the following morning mr . morikawa called for me , and we went to visit schools -- kindergarten , middle-school , elementary school , and high school -- mr . yoshimoto ' s school .	35.508633
there is much more freedom in the schools here than i expected -- some think too much .	288.1775
there is a great deal of thought being given to the question of moral education in the schools .	36.07858
with the loss of the emperor diety in japan , the people are left in confusion with no god or moral teachings that have strength .	86.72025
the older parents continued to teach their children traditional principles , but the younger people , who have lost all faith and convictions , are now parents .	99.6798
there seems to be no purpose in life that is sure -- no certain guiding principles to give stability .	88.80187
as a result , money is spent quickly and freely , with no thought of its value .	62.150036
the government has recognized the dilemma and is beginning to devise some moral education for the schools -- but the teachers often have no firm conviction and are confused .	136.8268
i was told that it is quite likely that japanese soldiers would not fight again -- for why should they ? ?	91.25146
it will be painful , but interesting , to see what kind of a god these people will create or what strong convictions they will develop .	166.4028
in the evening the former oregon state science teachers met for dinner at the new tokyo restaurant where i had my first raw fish and found it good .	94.064766
they suggested several new foods , and usually i found them good , except the sweets , which i think i could learn to like .	132.32127
six of the science teachers were present , and we had great fun .	90.474266
after a day at nikko , mrs . kodama put me on the train for kyoto .	36.126858
my instructions were that mr . nishimo would meet me at the hotel , but instead he and three others were at the station with a very warm welcome .	73.99369
my hotel rooms on the trip were arranged by masu and the japan travel bureau and were more elegant than i would have chosen , but it was fun for once to be elegant -- i did explain to the students , however , that this was not my usual style , for their salaries are very small , and it seemed out of place for me to be housed so well .	71.3273
they understood and teased me a bit about it .	11.021427
i think i would have been much disappointed in japan if i had not seen kyoto , nara , and hiroshima .	55.52682
kyoto is the ancient capital of japan and still its cultural center .	236.81618
it , along with nara , was untouched by the war -- and is now a beautiful example of the loveliness of prewar japan .	47.399857
here i was accompanied by mrs . okamoto ( fumio ' s mother ) , her son , mr . washizu ( a prospective student with whom i have been corresponding for more than a year ) , and mr . nishima , one of the science teachers .	48.546814
i arrived at 7 00 a . m . and by 9 00 a . m . i had finished breakfast and was on my way to see what they had planned .	50.552227
we walked miles and saw various shrines and gardens .	34.376217
we visited the okamoto home -- where for the first time i saw the famous tea ceremony .	41.404938
at 6 00 p . m . we went to the kyoto spring dances at the place where these beautiful dances originated .	97.724464
they were even better than those of tokyo -- more spectacular and more imaginative .	89.54138
after a supper of unagi ( rice with eel -- eel which is raised in an ice-cold pond at the foot of mt . fuji ) , i returned to my beautiful room to sleep as hard as possible to be ready for another busy day .	44.444794
we started at 9 a . m . to visit the kyoto university where mr . washizu is attending .	79.3118
i was amazed at the very poor hospital facilities accompanying the medical school .	88.8366
they apologized for the condition , including dirt and flies , and i was a little at a loss to know what to say .	86.420235
i don ' t have the answer yet .	6.4088354
we had tea at mr . washizu ' s home where i learned that he , too , comes from a very wealthy family .	38.17048
and he , being the eldest , was supposed to be a priest , but he chose to do differently , and one of his brothers is to become the priest .	40.850304
this is a significant fact in japan , for only a few years ago he would have had no choice .	25.318531
in his big home live four families and thirty people , so it needs to be big .	102.20634
also , there are housed here some priceless historical treasures from 400 to 600 years old -- paintings , lacquer , brocade , etc . .	33.37155
he had displayed more of them than usual so that i could enjoy them .	143.53404
about 100 of the most important items he had already given to the museum .	45.393414
the house itself is 400 years old with all the craftsmanship of older , less-hurried times .	79.18524
mr . nishima went with me on the train to nara .	40.4984
we passed his house and school on the way .	20.409477
in nara i stayed at the hotel where the prince and princess had stayed on their honeymoon .	34.078552
a new red carpet had been laid for their coming , but i walked on it , too .	37.063557
here mr . yoneda met us after a three-hour train trip from the town where he teaches .	35.21851
even though we had walked miles in kyoto that day , we started out again to see nara at night .	59.586586
in the evening both of the men went with me on the train 30 miles to osaka to put me on the train for hiroshima .	69.84652
again the plan was for me to go alone , but they wouldn ' t let me .	18.189741
at osaka , mr . yoneda had to leave us to get the train to his home , but mr . nishima and i had an hour and a half before train time to see osaka at night .	45.451195
it is the second largest city in japan , with about four million people .	63.63162
one spot in osaka i shall always remember -- the bridge where we stood to watch the reflections of the elaborate neon signs in the still waters of the river .	68.27272
in the midst of a great busy city , people take time to enjoy the beauty of natural reflection of artificial light .	127.82964
my train arrived in hiroshima at the awful hour of 4 45 a . m . .	22.746393
i had planned to go to the hotel by taxi and sleep a little , after which mr . uno would arrive and pilot me around .	131.08511
but there he was at the train with an oregon state pennant in his hand .	151.63652
i know now why the students insisted that i go to hiroshima even when i told them i didn ' t want to .	48.904884
they knew that i was still grieving over the tragic event , and they felt that if i could see the recovery and the spirit of the people , who hold no grudge , but who also regret pearl harbor , i would be happier and would understand better a new japan .	75.9151
there were no words to say this but there was no need .	32.62554
the teachers of mr . uno ' s school gave me a small gift to thank me for coming .	86.39662
hiroshima is a better city than it was before -- in the minds of the people i met was a strong determination for peace and understanding .	72.35332
i was grateful for their insight into my need for this experience .	59.578373
a better world may yet come out of hiroshima .	204.95161
on arriving in tokyo later we were met by masu who took us immediately to her university , the japanese women ' s university .	79.559326
this day was `` open house for parents ' ' day , and the girls were busy preparing exhibits and arranging tea tables .	90.32736
everything was in an exciting turmoil -- full of anticipation and fun .	41.765083
it was thrilling to see the effect of an american-trained teacher on japanese students in a class in home planning .	110.40821
our masu is one of the very few architects in japan who is trying to plan homes around family functions and women ' s needs .	165.91988
i am told the time will soon come when women will find it necessary to do most of their own work , and even now it is important to have conveniences for the use of servants .	51.546394
many of the features of the homes are the latest modern devices in american homes , but an interesting blend of cultures finds us using japanese artfulness in our own western architecture at the same time that the japanese are adopting western utility patterns .	93.28851
at this women ' s university we find a monument to a courageous family who believed that japanese women also should be educated .	103.703094
even today there are some doubts about the value of education for japanese women , but this university continues to grow and to send its students out into the community .	63.380157
active alumnae have built a fine building on the campus where members can come and stay for a few days or longer and where they can have their social gatherings and professional meetings .	69.60222
as far as i am concerned there is continuous piling up of evidence that the creative fresh ideas which are needed in the world are going to be found by educated women unafraid to break traditions .	147.58867
masu is also teaching in a municipally-sponsored school for japanese widows in tokyo .	34.165432
here the women learn to keep house as maids	14610.039
they become skilled in cooking and cleaning and in receiving guests .	160.89758
they learn how to take care of children and sick members of the family .	30.981703
they have model kitchens , a sick room with a model patient in bed , and a nursery with a life-like doll .	49.50954
although the training is only for one month , it is intensive and thorough .	38.87366
graduates of this maid ' s school are much in demand and can always find work immediately .	295.86697
masu ' s home economics training comes into play as she designs cupboards along modern functional lines for the storage of cleaning materials .	247.64085
masu also uses the training she got in an american home where she learned to polish furniture , clean corners , and work effectively in keeping a shiny house .	110.219536
her education in the united states , not just in a classroom , but also in an american house with an american housekeeper , stands her in good stead .	64.884964
after a fine luncheon in the cafeteria , the kitchen of which masu had planned , mr . washizu and i left to meet representatives of the usis for a visit to the university of tokyo .	83.23556
here again it was vacation time and there were many things i could not see , but i was able to visit with a professor who is famous in japanese circles and be guided through the grounds by his assistant .	84.2135
the achievement of the desegregation of certain lunch counters not only by wise action by local community leaders but by voluntary action following consultation between attorney general rogers and the heads of certain national chain stores should , of course , be applauded .	117.215065
but for it to be just to attain this same result by means of the force of a boycott throughout the nation would require the verification of facts contrary to those assumed in the foregoing case .	75.48814
the suppositions in the previous illustration might be sufficiently altered by establishing a connection between general company practice and local practice in the south , and by establishing such direct connection between the practice and the economic well-being of stores located in new york and general company policy .	94.62719
then the boycott would not be secondary , but a primary one .	49.10264
it would be directed against the actual location of the unjust policy which , for love ' s sake and for the sake of justice , must be removed , and , indivisible from this , to the economic injury of the people directly and objectively a part of this policy .	56.577995
perhaps this would be sufficient to justify an economic boycott of an entire national chain in order , by threatening potential injury to its entire economy , to effect an alteration of the policy of its local stores in the matter of segregation .	63.43773
such a general boycott might still be a blunt or indiscriminating instrument , and therefore of questionable justification .	84.46434
action located where the evil is concentrated will prove most decisive and is most clearly legitimate .	144.77925
moreover , prudence alone would indicate that , unless the local customs are already ready to fall when pushed , the results of direct economic action everywhere upon national chain stores will likely be simply to give undue advantage to local and state stores which conform to these customs , leading to greater decentralization and local autonomy within the company , or even ( as the final self-defeat of an unjust application of economic pressure to correct injustice ) to its going out of business in certain sections of the country ( as , for that matter , the quakers , who once had many meetings in the pre-civil war south , largely went out of business in that part of the country over the slavery issue , never to recover a large number of southern adherents ) .	112.22028
in any case , anyone who fails to make significant distinction between primary and secondary applications of economic pressure would in principle already have justified that use of economic boycott as a means which broke out a few years ago or was skillfully organized by white citizens ' councils in the entire state of mississippi against every local philco dealer in that state , in protest against a philco-sponsored program over a national tv network on which was presented a drama showing , it seemed , a `` high yellow gal ' ' smooching with a white man .	105.14433
it is true , of course , that the end or objective of this action was different .	54.47534
but since this is a world in which people disagree about ends and goals and concerning justice and injustice , and since , in a situation where direct action and economic pressure are called for , the justice of the matter has either not been clearly defined by law or the law is not effectively present , there has to be a morality of means applied in every case in which people take it upon themselves to use economic pressures or other forms of force .	118.296455
the need that we not give unqualified approval to any but a limited use of economic pressure directed against the actual doers of injustice is clear also in light of the fact that white citizens ' councils seem resolved to maintain segregation mainly by the use of these same means and not ordinarily by physical violence .	94.53027
an unlimited use of economic pressures for diametrically opposite causes could devastate the pre-conditions of any fellow humanity as surely as this would be destroyed by the use of more obviously brutal means .	143.88608
the end or aim of the action , of course , is also important , especially where it is not alone a matter of changing community customs but of the use of deadly economic power to intimidate a person from stepping forward to claim his legal rights , e . g . , against negroes who register to vote in fayette county , tennessee , at the present moment .	65.84742
here the recourse is in steps to give economic sustenance to those being despoiled , and to legal remedies .	146.0017
this , however , is sufficient to show that more or less non-violent resistance and economic conflict ( if both sides are strong enough ) can be war of all against all no less than if other means are used .	111.20011
it is also sufficient to show the christian and any other champion of justice that he needs to make sure not only that his cause is just but also that his conduct is just , i . e . , that , if economic pressure has to be resorted to , this be applied directly against those persons directly in the way of some salutary change in business or institutional practices , while , if injury fall upon others , it fall upon them indirectly and secondarily ( however inevitably ) and not by deliberate intent and direct action against them .	112.324196
it is clear that non-violent resistance is a mode of action in need of justification and limitation in christian morality , like any other form of resistance .	89.203476
the language used itself often makes very clear that this is only another form of struggle for victory ( perhaps to be chosen above all others ) .	77.87161
one of the sit-in leaders has said `` nobody from the top of heaven to the bottom of hell can stop the march to freedom .	144.88306
everybody in the world today might as well make up their minds to march with freedom or freedom is going to march over them ' ' .	137.78165
the present writer certainly agrees with that statement , and would also affirm this -- in the order of justice .	40.5554
however , it is also a christian insight to know that unless charity interpenetrates justice it is not likely to be freedom that marches forward .	78.04161
and when charity interpenetrates man ' s struggle for justice and freedom it does not simply surround this with a sentimental good will .	96.58884
it also definitely fashions conduct in the way explained above , and this means far more than in the choice of non-violent means .	73.40579
r . b . gregg has written that `` non-violence and good will of the victim act like the lack of physical opposition by the user of physical jiu-jitsu , to cause the attacker to lose his moral balance .	106.763756
he suddenly and unexpectedly loses the moral support which the usual violent resistance of most victims would render him ' '	136.17645
and again , that `` the object of non-violent resistance is partly analogous to this object of war -- namely , to demoralize the opponent , to break his will , to destroy his confidence , enthusiasm , and hope .	82.78181
in another respect it is dissimilar , for non-violent resistance demoralizes the opponent only to re-establish in him a new morale that is firmer because it is based on sounder values ' ' .	62.771854
a trial of strength , however , is made quite inevitable by virtue of the fact that anyone engaging in non-violent resistance will be convinced that his action is based on sounder values than those of his opponent	73.99123
and in warfare with any means , men commonly disagree over the justice of the cause .	54.28276
this makes necessary a morality of means , and principles governing the conduct of resistance whenever this is thought to be justified .	91.07453
the question , then , is whether sufficient discrimination in the use of even non-violent means of coercion is to be found in the fact that such conduct demoralizes and overcomes the opponent while re-moralizing and re-establishing him .	37.203453
here it is relevant to remember that men commonly regard some causes as more important than their lives	163.71153
and to them it will seem insignificant that it is proposed to defeat such causes non-violently .	78.97024
a technique by which it is proposed to enter with compulsion into the very heart of a man and determine his values may often in fact seem the more unlimited aggression .	215.65637
among christian groups , the mennonites have commonly been aware more than others of the fact that the nature of divine charity raises decisively the question of the christian use of all forms of pressure .	55.7684
since the will and word of god are for them concentrated in christ-like love , it seems clear to them that non-violent resistance is quite another thing .	71.22456
`` the primary objective of non-violence ' ' , writes the outstanding mennonite ethicist , `` is not peace , or obedience to the divine will , but rather certain desired social changes , for personal , or class , or national advantage ' ' .	81.51623
without agreeing with every phrase in this statement , we must certainly assert the great difference between christian love and any form of resistance , and then go on beyond the mennonite position and affirm that christian love-in-action must first justify and then determine the moral principles limiting resistance .	115.56218
economy in the use of power needs not only to be asserted , but clearly specified	107.16629
and when this is done it will be found that the principles governing christian resistance cut across the distinction between violent and non-violent means , and apply to both alike , justifying either on occasion and always limiting either action .	128.81404
economy in the use of power means more than inflicting a barely intolerable pressure upon an opponent and upon the injustice opposed .	75.87768
that would amount to calculating the means and justifying them wholly in terms of their effectiveness in reaching desired goals .	109.33431
there must also be additional and more fundamental discrimination in the use of means of resistance , violent or non-violent .	33.088688
the justification in christian conscience of the use of any mode of resistance also lays down its limitation -- in the distinction between the persons against whom pressure is primarily directed , those upon whom it may be permitted also to fall , and those who may never be directly repressed for the sake even of achieving some great good .	162.89001
in these terms , the `` economic withdrawal ' ' of the negroes of nashville , tennessee , from trading in the center city , for example , was clearly justified , since these distinctions do not require that only people subjectively guilty be singled out .	65.18733
we may now take up for consideration a hard case which seems to require either no action employing economic pressure or else action that would seem to violate the principles set forth above .	210.20555
there may be instances in which , if economic pressure is to be undertaken at all , this would have to be applied without discrimination against a whole people .	46.528744
an excellent article was published recently in the journal of the church peace union by a south african journalist on the inhuman economic conditions of the blacks in south africa , amounting to virtual slavery , and the economic complicity of both the government and the people of the united states in these conditions .	50.801838
`` billions of american dollars , not only from capital investors but also from the pockets of u . s . taxpayers ' ' , this author states , `` are being poured into south africa to support a system dedicated to the oppression , the persecution , and the almost diabolical exploitation of 12 million people the color of whose skins happens not to be white ' ' .	83.144684
both the conditions and the complicity are documented in considerable detail .	25.681717
this leads to the conclusion that `` the fact is inescapable that america does have a say in whether or not apartheid shall continue ' ' .	138.97754
our leadership in a wide economic boycott of south africa would be not only in accord , it seems , with the moral conscience of america , not to be denied because we also as a people have widespread injustice in the relations of the races in our own country , but also in accord with our law , u . s . code title 19 , section 1307 , which forbids the importation of goods made by forced or convict labor .	58.428253
not only should this provision be enforced but other economic and political actions might be taken which , this author believes , `` must surely be supported by every american who values the freedom that has been won for him and whose conscience is not so dominated by the lines in his account books that he can willingly and knowingly contribute to the enslavement of another nation ' ' .	82.4584
northern liberals are the chief supporters of civil rights and of integration .	42.225494
they have also led the nation in the direction of a welfare state .	51.533146
and both in their objectives of non-discrimination and of social progress they have had ranged against them the southerners who are called bourbons .	133.87103
the name presumably derives from the french royal house which never learned and never forgot	140.69235
since bourbon whiskey , though of kentucky origin , is at least as much favored by liberals in the north as by conservatives in the south .	37.62797
the nature of the opposition between liberals and bourbons is too little understood in the north .	50.65064
the race problem has tended to obscure other , less emotional , issues which may fundamentally be even more divisive .	193.27959
it is these other differences between north and south -- other , that is , than those which concern discrimination or social welfare -- which i chiefly discuss herein .	225.44505
i write about northern liberals from considerable personal experience .	9.574413
a southerner married to a new englander , i have lived for many years in a connecticut commuting town with a high percentage of artists , writers , publicity men , and business executives of egghead tastes .	66.76965
most of them are democrats and nearly all consider themselves , and are viewed as , liberals .	246.90182
this is puzzling to an outsider conscious of the classic tradition of liberalism , because it is clear that these democrats who are left-of-center are at opposite poles from the liberal jefferson , who held that the best government was the least government .	93.864075
yet paradoxically my liberal friends continue to view jefferson as one of their patron saints .	57.836662
when i question them as to what they mean by concepts like liberty and democracy , i find that they fall into two categories the simpler ones who have simply accepted the shibboleths of their faith without analysis	120.451866
and the intelligent , cynical ones who scornfully reply that these things don ' t count any more in the world of to-day .	32.579697
i am naive , they say , to make use of such words .	66.24029
i take this to mean that the intelligent -- and therefore necessarily cynical ? ?	135.07639
-- liberal considers that the need for a national economy with controls that will assure his conception of social justice is so great that individual and local liberties as well as democratic processes may have to yield before it .	123.09411
this seems like an attitude favoring a sort of totalitarian bureaucracy which , under a president of the same stamp , would try to coerce an uncooperative congress or supreme court .	59.530582
as for states ' rights , they have never counted in the thinking of my liberal friends except as irritations of a minor and immoral nature which exist now only as anachronisms .	103.44686
the american liberal may , in the world of to-day , have a strong case	96.11832
but he presents it publicly so enmeshed in hypocrisy that it is not an honest one .	44.810886
why , in the first place , call himself a liberal if he is against laissez-faire and favors an authoritarian central government with womb-to-tomb controls over everybody ? ?	139.93884
if he attaches little importance to personal liberty , why not make this known to the world ? ?	56.552563
and if he is so scornful of the rights of states , why not advocate a different sort of constitution that he could more sincerely support ? ?	150.07112
i am concerned here , however , with the northern liberal ' s attitude toward the south .	35.08589
it appears to be one of intense dislike , which he makes little effort to conceal even in the presence of southern friends .	55.192028
his assumption seems to be that any such friends , being tolerable humans , must be more liberal than most southerners and therefore at least partly in sympathy with his views .	131.97333
time ' s editor , thomas griffith , in his book , the waist-high culture , wrote `` most of what was different about it ( the deep south ) i found myself unsympathetic to .	80.06351
' ' this , for the liberals i know , would be an understatement .	27.041605
theirs is no mere lack of sympathy , but something closer to the passionate hatred that was directed against fascism .	82.7987
i do not think that my experience would be typical for southerners living in the north .	49.041264
in business circles , usually conservative , this sort of atmosphere would hardly be found .	64.828125
but in our case -- and neither my wife nor i have extreme views on integration , nor are we given to emotional outbursts -- the situation has ruined one or two valued friendships and come close to wrecking several more .	153.63062
in fact it has caused us to give serious thought to moving our residence south , because it is not easy for the most objective southerner to sit calmly by when his host is telling a roomful of people that the only way to deal with southerners who oppose integration is to send in troops and shoot the bastards down .	124.48822
accounts have been published of northern liberals in the south up against segregationist prejudice , especially in state-supported universities where pressure may be strong to uphold the majority view .	76.1594
but these accounts do not show that northerners have been subjected to embarrassment or provocation by yankee-hatred displayed in social gatherings .	41.9705
from my wife ' s experience and other sources , this seems to be rarely encountered in educated circles .	74.06609
but there is a leavening of liberalism among college graduates throughout the south , especially among those who studied in the north .	57.2701
and social relations arising out of business ties impose courtesy , if not sympathy , toward resident and visiting northerners .	122.37263
also , among the latter a large percentage soon acquire the prevalent southern attitude on most social problems .	556.2233
but for this discussion the most important division is between those who have been reconstructed and those who haven ' t .	62.695576
my definition of this much abused adjective is that a reconstructed rebel is one who is glad that the north won the war .	64.66888
nobody knows how many southerners there are in this category .	13.866814
i suspect that there are far more unreconstructed ones than the north likes to believe .	88.46516
i never heard of a poll being taken on the question .	19.874872
no doubt such a thing would be considered unpatriotic .	74.467896
prior to 1954 i imagine that a majority of southerners would have voted against the confederacy .	28.141878
since the supreme court ' s decision of that year this is more doubtful	183.53139
and if a poll had been taken immediately following the dispatch of troops to little rock i believe the majority would have been for the old south .	89.759834
belief in the traditional way of life persists much more in the older states than in the new ones .	84.24203
probably a larger percentage of virginians and south carolinians remain unreconstructed than elsewhere , with georgia , north carolina , and alabama following along after them .	101.31323
old attitudes are held more tenaciously in the tidewater than the piedmont	484.81403
so that a line running down the length of the south marking the upper limits of tidewater would roughly divide the old south from the new , but with , of course , important minority enclaves .	69.48619
the long-settled areas of states like virginia and south carolina developed the ante-bellum culture to its richest flowering , and there the memory is more precious , and the consciousness of loss the greater .	85.541954
also , we should not even to-day discount the fact that a region such as the coastal lowlands centering on charleston had closer ties with england and the west indies than with the north even after independence .	94.85198
the social and psychological consequences of this continue to affect the area .	31.763662
in certain respects defeat increased the persistent anglophilia of the old south .	14.560995
poor where they had once been rich , humbled where they had been arrogant , having no longer any hope of sharing in the leadership of the nation , the rebels who would not surrender in spirit drew comfort from the sympathy they felt extended to them by the mother country .	95.89536
and no doubt many people in states like the carolinas and georgia , which were among the most tory in sentiment in the eighteenth century , bitterly regretted the revolt against the crown .	55.213478
among bourbons the racial issue may have less to do with their remaining unreconstructed than other factors .	150.27678
but many historians maintain that except for northern meddling it would have ended in states like virginia years before it did .	87.00887
southern resentment has been over the method of its ending , the invasion , and reconstruction	135.50764
their fears now are of miscegenation and negro political control in many counties .	111.01293
but apart from racial problems , the old unreconstructed south -- to use the moderate words favored by mr . thomas griffith -- finds itself unsympathetic to most of what is different about the civilization of the north .	108.956314
and this , in effect , means most of modern america .	44.87239
it is hard to see how the situation could be otherwise .	45.007385
and therein , i feel , many northerners delude themselves about the south .	25.265793
for one thing , this is not a subject often discussed or analyzed .	421.99316
there seems to be almost a conspiracy of silence veiling it .	43.42577
i suppose the reason is a kind of wishful thinking don ' t talk about the final stages of reconstruction and they will take care of themselves .	47.572624
or else the north really believes that all southerners except a few quaint old characters have come around to realizing the errors of their past , and are now at heart sharers of the american dream , like everybody else .	75.86683
if the circumstances are faced frankly it is not reasonable to expect this to be true .	33.289307
the situation of the south since 1865 has been unique in the western world .	29.505552
regardless of rights and wrongs , a population and an area appropriate to a pre-world-war- 1 great power have been , following conquest , ruled against their will by a neighboring people , and have had imposed upon them social and economic controls they dislike .	175.32188
and the great majority of these people are of anglo-saxon or celtic descent .	38.07822
this is the only case in modern history of a people of britannic origin submitting without continued struggle to what they view as foreign domination .	132.2186
the fact is due mainly to international wars , both hot and cold .	73.343864
in every war of the united states since the civil war the south was more belligerent than the rest of the country .	14.294969
so instead of being tests of the south ' s loyalty , the spanish war , the two world wars , and the korean war all served to overcome old grievances and cement reunion .	71.31244
and there is no section of the nation more ardent than the south in the cold war against communism .	47.660393
had the situation been reversed , had , for instance , england been the enemy in 1898 because of issues of concern chiefly to new england , there is little doubt that large numbers of southerners would have happily put on their old confederate uniforms to fight as allies of britain .	78.05281
it is extraordinary that a people as proud and warlike as southerners should have been as docile as they have .	51.856964
the north should thank its stars that such has been the case	76.10041
but at the same time it should not draw false inferences therefrom .	124.42995
the two main charges levelled against the bourbons by liberals is that they are racists and social reactionaries .	58.000854
there is much truth in both these charges , and not many bourbons deny them .	48.512875
whatever their faults , they are not hypocrites .	7.713247
most of them sincerely believe that the anglo-saxon is the best race in the world and that it should remain pure .	81.00993
many northeners believe this , too , but few of them will say so publicly .	117.313194
the bourbon economic philosophy , moreover , is not very different from that of northern conservatives .	46.05038
but those among the bourbons who remain unreconstructed go much further than this .	703.2861
they believe that if the south had been let alone it would have produced a civilization superior to that of modern america .	132.08559
as it is , they consider that the north is now reaping the fruits of excess egalitarianism , that in spite of its high standard of living the `` american way ' ' has been proved inferior to the english and scandinavian ways , although they disapprove of the socialistic features of the latter .	82.82144
the south ' s antipathy to northern civilization includes such charges as poor manners , harsh accents , lack of appreciation of the arts of living like gastronomy and the use of leisure .	80.5854
their own easier , slower tempo is especially dear to southerners	255.94763
and i have heard many say that they are content to earn a half or a third as much as they could up north because they so much prefer the quieter habits of their home town .	140.09387
in the past , the duties of the state , as sir henry maine noted long ago , were only two in number internal order and external security .	207.76213
by prevailing over other claimants for the loyalties of men , the nation-state maintained an adequate measure of certainty and order within its territorial borders .	66.04644
outside those limits it asserted , as against other states , a position of sovereign equality , and , as against the `` inferior ' ' peoples of the non-western world , a position of dominance .	47.390995
it became the sole `` subject ' ' of `` international law ' ' ( a term which , it is pertinent to remember , was coined by bentham ) , a body of legal principle which by and large was made up of what western nations could do in the world arena .	60.460846
( that corpus of law was a reflection of the power system in existence during the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries .	36.345028
speaking generally , it furthered -- and still tends to further -- the interests of the western powers .	87.41499
the enormous changes in world politics have , however , thrown it into confusion , so much so that it is safe to say that all international law is now in need of reexamination and clarification in light of the social conditions of the present era .	54.24433
beyond the two basic tasks mentioned above , no attention was paid by statesman or scholar to an idea of state responsibility , either internally or externally .	96.91164
this was particularly true in the world arena , which was an anarchical battleground characterized by strife and avaricious competition for colonial empires .	40.787415
that any sort of duty was owed by his nation to other nations would have astonished a nineteenth-century statesman .	120.89614
his duty was to his sovereign and to his nation , and an extension to peoples beyond the territorial boundaries was not to be contemplated .	64.56165
thus , to cite but one example , the pax britannica of the nineteenth century , whether with the british navy ruling the seas or with the city of london ruling world finance , was strictly national in motivation , however much other nations ( e . g . , the united states ) may have incidentally benefited .	103.94003
at the same time , all suggestions that some sort of societal responsibility existed for the welfare of the people within the territorial state was strongly resisted .	125.97576
social darwinism was able to stave off the incipient socialist movement until well into the present century .	97.52462
however , in recent decades , for what doubtless are multiple reasons , an unannounced but nonetheless readily observable shift has occurred in both facets of national activity .	149.64096
a concept of responsibility is in process of articulation and establishment .	83.685196
already firmly implanted internally , it is a growing factor in external matters .	84.01384
a little more than twenty years ago the american people turned an important corner .	151.01234
in what has aptly been called a `` constitutional revolution ' ' , the basic nature of government was transformed from one essentially negative in nature ( the `` night-watchman state ' ' ) to one with affirmative duties to perform .	96.678505
the `` positive state ' ' came into existence .	48.278004
for lawyers , reflecting perhaps their parochial preferences , there has been a special fascination since then in the role played by the supreme court in that transformation -- the manner in which its decisions altered in `` the switch in time that saved nine ' ' , president roosevelt ' s ill-starred but in effect victorious `` court-packing plan ' ' , the imprimatur of judicial approval that was finally placed upon social legislation .	83.88711
of greater importance , however , is the content of those programs , which have had and are having enormous consequences for the american people .	76.65472
labor relations have been transformed , income security has become a standardized feature of political platforms , and all the many facets of the american version of the welfare state have become part of the conventional wisdom .	59.2355
a national consensus of near unanimity exists that these governmental efforts are desirable as well as necessary .	69.17312
ratified in the republican party victory in 1952 , the positive state is now evidenced by political campaigns being waged not on whether but on how much social legislation there should be .	133.12999
the general acceptance of the idea of governmental ( i . e . , societal ) responsibility for the economic well-being of the american people is surely one of the two most significant watersheds in american constitutional history .	48.87
the other , of course , was the civil war , the conflict which a century ago insured national unity over fragmentation .	124.09842
a third , one of at least equal and perhaps even greater importance , is now being traversed american immersion and involvement in world affairs .	87.7173
internal national responsibility , now a truism , need not be documented .	115.40337
nevertheless , it may be helpful to cite one example -- that of employment -- for , as will be shown below , it cuts across both facets of the new concept .	126.935715
thirty years ago , while the nation was wallowing in economic depression , the prevailing philosophy of government was to stand aside and allow `` natural forces ' ' to operate and cure the distress .	94.509186
that guiding principle of the hoover administration fell to the siege guns of the new deal	73.630295
less than a score of years later congress enacted the employment act of 1946 , by which the national government assumed the responsibility of taking action to insure conditions of maximum employment .	69.266594
hands-off the economy was replaced by conscious guidance through planning -- the economic side of the constitutional revolution .	196.28586
in 1961 the first important legislative victory of the kennedy administration came when the principle of national responsibility for local economic distress won out over a `` state ' s-responsibility ' ' proposal -- provision was made for payment for unemployment relief by nation-wide taxation rather than by a levy only on those states afflicted with manpower surplus .	120.9759
the american people have indeed come a long way in the brief interval between 1930 and 1961 .	45.662075
internal national responsibility is a societal response to the impact of the industrial revolution .	22.330484
reduced to its simplest terms , it is an assumption of a collective duty to compensate for the inability of individuals to cope with the rigors of the era .	28.16963
national responsibility for individual welfare is a concept not limited to the united states or even to the western nations .	30.922298
a measure of its widespread acceptance may be derived from a statement of the international congress of jurists in 1959 .	54.625233
meeting in new delhi under the auspices of the international commission of jurists , a body of lawyers from the free world , the congress redefined and expanded the traditional rule of law to include affirmative governmental duties .	70.03471
it is noteworthy that the majority of the delegates to the congress were from the less developed , former colonial nations .	129.83084
the rule of law , historically a principle according everyone his `` day in court ' ' before an impartial tribunal , was broadened substantively by making it a responsibility of government to promote individual welfare .	94.77146
recognizing that the rule of law is `` a dynamic concept which should be employed not only to safeguard the civil and political rights of the individual in a free society ' ' , the congress asserted that it also included the responsibility `` to establish social , economic , educational and cultural conditions under which his legitimate aspirations and dignity may be realized ' ' .	59.84813
the idea of national responsibility thus has become a common feature of the nations of the non-soviet world .	38.632523
for better or for worse , we all now live in welfare states , the organizing principle of which is collective responsibility for individual well-being .	89.75276
whether a concept analogous to the principle of internal responsibility operates in a nation ' s external relations is less obvious and more difficult to establish .	55.31929
the hypothesis ventured here is that it does , and that evidence is accumulating validating that proposition .	69.709435
the content is not the same , however rather than individual security , it is the security and continuing existence of an `` ideological group ' ' -- those in the `` free world ' ' -- that is basic .	48.458996
external national responsibility involves a burgeoning requirement that the leaders of the western nations so guide their decisions as to further the viability of other friendly nations .	83.2081
if internal responsibility suggests acceptance of the socialist ideal of equality , then external responsibility implies adherence to principles of ideological supranationalism .	103.49206
reference to two other concepts -- nationalism and sovereignty -- may help to reveal the contours of the new principle .	44.948395
in its beginnings the nation-state had to struggle to assert itself -- internally , against feudal groups , and externally , against the power and influence of such other claimants for loyalty as the church .	89.86385
the breakup of the holy roman empire and the downfall of feudalism led , not more than two centuries ago , to the surge of nationalism .	53.856964
( since the time-span of the nation-state coincides roughly with the separate existence of the united states as an independent entity , it is perhaps natural for americans to think of the nation as representative of the highest form of order , something permanent and unchanging .	57.725628
) the concept of nationalism is the political principle that epitomizes and glorifies the territorial state as the characteristic type of socal structure .	57.92407
for it includes the emotional ties that bind men to their homeland and the complex motivations that hold a large group of people together as a unit .	94.43981
today , as new nations rise from the former colonial empires , nationalism is one of the hurricane forces loose in the world .	53.928413
almost febrile in intensity , the principle has become worldwide in application -- unfortunately at the very time that nationalist fervors can wreak greatest harm .	61.877544
historically , however , the concept is one that has been of marked benefit to the people of the western civilizational group .	78.43909
by subduing disparate lesser groups the nation has , to some degree at least , broadened the capacity for individual liberty .	70.079475
within their confines , moreover , technological and industrial growth has proceeded at an accelerated pace , thus increasing the cornucopia from which material wants can be satisfied .	155.99341
while the pattern is uneven , some having gained more than others , nationalism has in fact served the western peoples well .	190.41022
( whether historical nationalism helped the peoples of the remainder of the world , and whether today ' s nationalism in the former colonial areas has equally beneficial aspects , are other questions .	99.062386
it is one of the ironic quirks of history that the viability and usefulness of nationalism and the territorial state are rapidly dissipating at precisely the time that the nation-state attained its highest number ( approximately 100 ) .	77.22101
but it is more than irony one of the main reasons why nationalism is no longer a tenable concept is because it has spread throughout the planet .	73.03483
in other words , nationalism worked well enough when it had limited application , both as to geography and as to population	216.78513
it becomes a perilous anachronism when adopted on a world-wide basis .	14.903954
complementing the political principle of nationalism is the legal principle of sovereignty .	25.388626
the former receives its legitimacy from the latter .	13.425618
operating side by side , together they helped shore up the nation-state .	232.48181
while sovereignty has roots in antiquity , in its present usage it is essentially modern .	170.18346
jean bodin , writing in the sixteenth century , may have been the seminal thinker , but it was the vastly influential john austin who set out the main lines of the concept as now understood .	57.24386
austin ' s nineteenth-century view of law and sovereignty still dominates much of today ' s legal and political thinking .	110.1465
to him , law is the command of the sovereign ( the english monarch ) who personifies the power of the nation , while sovereignty is the power to make law -- i . e . , to prevail over internal groups and to be free from the commands of other sovereigns in other nations .	57.01658
these fundamental ideas -- the indivisibility of sovereignty and its dual ( internal-external ) aspects -- still remain the core of that concept of ultimate political power .	113.31064
the nation-state , then , exemplifies the principle of nationalism and exercises sovereignty supreme power over domestic affairs and independence from outside control .	177.16374
in fact , however , both principles have always been nebulous and loosely defined .	56.830868
high-level abstractions are always difficult to pin down with precision .	120.71055
that is particularly true of sovereignty when it is applied to democratic societies , in which `` popular ' ' sovereignty is said to exist , and in federal nations , in which the jobs of government are split .	72.589066
nevertheless , nationalism and sovereignty are reputed , in the accepted wisdom , to describe the modern world .	88.7829
is there a different reality behind the facade ? ?	18.521315
does the surface hide a quite different picture ? ?	12.8233795
the short answer to those questions is `` yes ' ' .	5.9864163
to some degree they are being supplanted by a concept of national responsibility .	29.239527
as evidence to support that view , consider the following illustrative instances .	43.95064
can thermonuclear war be set off by accident ? ?	17.645063
what steps have been taken to guard against the one sort of mishap that could trigger the destruction of continents ? ?	79.3376
are we as safe as we should be from such a disaster ? ?	93.21039
is anything being done to increase our margin of safety ? ?	22.280355
i have just asked these questions in the pentagon , in the white house , in offices of key scientists across the country and aboard the submarines that prowl for months underwater , with neat rows of green launch tubes which contain polaris missiles and which are affectionately known as `` sherwood forest ' ' .	66.90405
i asked the same questions inside the launch-control rooms of an atlas missile base in wyoming , where officers who wear sidearms are manning the `` commit buttons ' ' that could start a war -- accidentally or by design -- and in the command centers where other pistol-packing men could give orders to push such buttons .	92.53566
to the men in the instrument-jammed bomber cockpits , submarine compartments and the antiseptic , windowless rooms that would be the foxholes of tomorrow ' s impersonal intercontinental wars , the questions seem farfetched .	58.210648
there is unceasing pressure , but its sources are immediate .	67.39137
`` readiness exercises ' ' are almost continuous .	14.451308
in the command centers there are special clocks ready to tick off the minutes elapsed since `` e hour ' ' .	82.369896
`` e ' ' stands for `` execution ' ' -- the moment a `` go order ' ' would unleash an american nuclear strike .	66.766624
there is little time for the men in the command centers to reflect about the implications of these clocks .	83.43624
they are preoccupied riding herd on control panels , switches , flashing colored lights on pale green or gray consoles that look like business machines .	109.88143
they know little about their machinery beyond mechanical details .	70.42777
accidental war is so sensitive a subject that most of the people who could become directly involved in one are told just enough so they can perform their portions of incredibly complex tasks .	79.17471
among the policy makers , generals , physicists , psychologists and others charged with controlling the actions of the button pushers and their `` hardware ' ' , the answers to my questions varied partly according to a man ' s flair for what the professionals in this field call `` scenarios ' ' .	62.88666
as an air force psychiatrist put it `` you can ' t have dry runs on this one ' ' .	30.095778
the experts are thus forced to hypothesize sequences of events that have never occurred , probably never will -- but possibly might .	225.14008
only one rule prevailed in my conversations with these men the more highly placed they are -- that is , the more they know -- the more concerned they have become .	144.49538
already accidental war is a silent guest at the discussions within the kennedy administration about the urgency of disarmament and nearly all other questions of national security .	71.91707
only recently new `` holes ' ' were discovered in our safety measures , and a search is now on for more .	123.298065
work is under way to see whether new restraining devices should be installed on all nuclear weapons .	72.28136
meanwhile , the experts speak of wars triggered by `` false pre-emption ' ' , `` escalation ' ' , `` unauthorized behavior ' ' and other terms that will be discussed in this report .	20.129948
they inhabit a secret world centered on `` go codes ' ' and `` gold phones ' ' .	13.803955
their conversations were , almost invariably , accompanied by the same gestures -- arms and pointed forefingers darting toward each other in arclike semicircular motions .	52.402016
one arm represented our bombers and missiles , the other arm `` theirs ' ' .	58.48208
yet implicit in each movement was the death of millions , perhaps hundreds of millions , perhaps you and me -- and the experts .	106.40692
it is their job to think about the unthinkable .	308.26813
unanimously they believe that the world would become a safer place if more of us -- and more russians and communist chinese , too -- thought about accidental war .	123.024635
the first systematic thinking about this pandora ' s box within pandora ' s boxes was done four years ago by fred ikle , a frail , meek-mannered swiss-born sociologist .	38.53087
he was , and is , with the rand corporation , a nonprofit pool of thinkers financed by the u . s . air force .	25.733551
his investigations made him the paul revere of accidental war , and safety procedures were enormously increased .	118.7552
in recent weeks , as a result of a sweeping defense policy reappraisal by the kennedy administration , basic united states strategy has been modified -- and large new sums allocated -- to meet the accidental-war danger and to reduce it as quickly as possible .	78.996864
the chain starts at bmews ( ballistic missile early warning system ) in thule , greenland .	120.34927
its radar screens would register soviet missiles shortly after they are launched against the united states .	17.7176
bmews intelligence is simultaneously flashed to norad ( north american air defense command ) in colorado springs , colorado , for interpretation	73.52174
to the sac command and control post , forty-five feet below the ground at offutt air force base , near omaha , nebraska	44.738018
to the joint war room of the joint chiefs of staff in the pentagon and to the president .	13.408089
telephones , teletypes , several kinds of radio systems and , in some cases , television , link all vital points .	111.502754
alternate locations exist for all key command centers .	4.515924
for last-ditch emergencies sac has alternate command posts on kc-135 jet tankers .	16.108145
multiple circuits , routings and frequencies make the chain as unbreakable as possible .	76.524994
the same principle of `` redundancy ' ' applies to all communications on these special networks .	108.39707
and no messages can be transmitted on these circuits until senders and receivers authenticate in advance , by special codes , that the messages actually come from their purported sources .	53.551212
