additional codes can be used to challenge and counterchallenge the authentications .	36.20726
only the president is permitted to authorize the use of nuclear weapons .	11.302948
but what if somebody decides to break it ? ?	11.518515
the president cannot personally remove the safety devices from every nuclear trigger .	106.81391
hundreds of men are required to pass the word to the button pushers and to push the buttons .	27.982363
what if one or more of them turn irrational or suddenly , coolly , decide to clobber the russians ? ?	110.42933
what if the president himself , in the language of the military , `` goes ape ' ' ? ?	39.772694
or singlehandedly decided to reverse national policy and hit the soviets without provocation ? ?	73.5913
nobody can be absolutely certain of the answers .	7.1309905
however , the system is designed , ingeniously and hopefully , so that no one man could initiate a thermonuclear war .	39.083588
even the president cannot pick up his telephone and give a `` go ' ' order .	54.30352
even he does not know the one signal for a nuclear strike -- the `` go code ' ' .	55.237732
in an emergency he would receive available intelligence on the `` gold-phone circuit ' ' .	21.999651
a system of `` gold ' ' -- actually yellow -- phones connects him with the offices and action stations of the secretary of defense , the joint chiefs of staff , the sac commander and other key men .	53.520546
all can be connected with the gold circuit from their homes .	78.98775
all could help the president make his decision .	5.6669292
the talk would not be in code , but neither would it ramble .	141.11464
vital questions would be quickly answered according to a preprepared agenda .	159.51292
officers who participate in the continual practice drills assured me that the president ' s decision could be made and announced on the gold circuit within minutes after the first flash from aj .	84.43755
if communications work , his decision would be instantly known in all command posts that would originate the actual go order .	360.1154
for these centers , too , are on the gold circuit .	26.809132
they include the navy ' s atlantic command at norfolk , virginia , which is in contact with the polaris subs	29.046602
air force forward headquarters in europe and in the pacific , which control tactical fighters on ships and land bases	126.91981
and sac , which controls long-range bombers and atlas missiles .	13.961355
let us look in on one of these nerve centers -- sac at omaha -- and see what must still happen before a wing of b-52 bombers could drop their aj .	161.77129
the key man almost certainly would be col . william w . wisman , sac ' s senior controller .	30.143106
he or his deputy or one of their seven assistants , all full colonels , mans the heart of the command post twenty-four hours a day .	88.16385
it is a quiet but impressive room -- 140 feet long , thirty-nine feet wide , twenty-one feet high .	38.491974
movable panels of floor-to-ceiling maps and charts are crammed with intelligence information .	166.34511
and bill wisman , forty-three , a farmer ' s son from beallsville , ohio , is a quiet but impressive man .	34.91355
his eyes are steady anchors of the deepest brown .	181.54814
his movements and speech are precise , clear and quick .	98.79322
no question ruffles him or causes him to hesitate .	118.254776
wisman , who has had the chief controller ' s job for four years , calls the signals for a team operating three rows of dull-gray consoles studded with lights , switches and buttons .	58.24063
at least a dozen men , some armed , are never far away from him .	70.64784
in front of him is a gold phone .	4.306852
in emergencies the sac commander , gen . thomas power , or his deputies and their staff would occupy a balcony that stretches across the length of the room above wisman and his staff .	124.393036
at general power ' s seat in the balcony there is also a gold phone .	41.48696
general power would participate in the decision making .	12.792696
wisman , below , would listen in and act .	353.92172
his consoles can give him instant contact with more than seventy bases around the world and with every sac aircraft .	73.35803
he need only pick up one of the two red telephone receivers at his extreme left , right next to the big red button marked alert .	278.69644
( there are two receivers in case one should be dropped and damaged .	159.01057
but wisman , too , does not know the go code .	124.07345
he must take it from `` the red box ' ' .	12.606314
in point of fact , this is a beige box with a bright red door , about one and a half feet square and hung from the wall about six feet from the door to wisman ' s right .	59.737278
the box is internally wired so the door can never be opened without setting off a screeching klaxon ( `` it ' s real obnoxious ' ' ) .	34.168385
now we must become vague , for we are approaching one of the nation ' s most guarded secrets .	39.054264
the codes in the red box -- there are several of them covering various contingencies -- are contained in a sealed x-ray-proof `` unique device ' ' .	106.56637
they are supplied , a batch at a time , by a secret source and are continually changed by wisman or his staff , at random intervals .	94.59818
but even the contents of wisman ' s box cannot start a war .	188.18523
they are mere fragments , just one portion of preprepared messages .	81.683426
what these fragments are and how they activate the go order may not be revealed .	233.5625
the pieces must be placed in the context of the prepared messages by wisman ' s staff .	43.372803
in addition to the authentication and acknowledgment procedures which precede and follow the sending of the go messages , again in special codes , each message also contains an `` internal authenticator ' ' , another specific signal to convince the recipient that he is getting the real thing .	82.685
i asked wisman what would happen if he broke out the go codes and tried to start transmitting one .	117.31974
`` i ' d wind up full of bullet holes ' ' , he said , and there was no question that he was talking about bullets fired by his coworkers .	23.75978
now let us imagine a wing of b-52 ' s , on alert near their `` positive control ( or fail-safe ) points ' ' , the spots on the map , many miles from soviet territory , beyond which they are forbidden to fly without specific orders to proceed to their targets .	100.37172
they , too , have fragments of the go code with them .	173.66328
as wisman put it , `` they have separate pieces of the pie , and we have the whole pie .	34.496513
once we send out the whole pie , they can put their pieces into it .	66.71685
unless we send out the whole pie , their pieces mean nothing ' ' .	135.98477
why does wisman ' s ever-changing code always mesh with the fragments in possession of the button pushers ? ?	38.63462
at any rate , three men out of a six-man b-52 crew are required to copy down wisman ' s go-to-war message .	90.59851
each must match wisman ' s `` pie ' ' with the fragment that he carries with him .	24.497965
all three must compare notes and agree to `` go ' ' .	28.201786
after that , it requires several minutes of concentrated work , including six separate and deliberate actions by a minimum of three men sitting at three separate stations in a bomber , each with another man beside him to help , for an armed bomb to be released .	134.74219
unless all gadgets are properly operated -- and the wires and seals from the handles removed first -- no damage can be done .	141.5886
suddenly , however , their posture changed and the game ended .	173.77155
they went as rigid as black statuary six figures , lean and tall and angular , went still .	134.48987
they all swung at the same instant in the same direction .	27.978888
they saw it before i did , even with my binoculars .	71.5171
it was nothing more than a tiny distant rain squall , a dull gray sheet which reached from a layer of clouds to the earth .	43.005352
in the 360 degrees of horizon it obscured only a degree , no more .	160.22997
a white man would not have seen it .	48.20792
the aborigines fastened upon it with a concentration beyond pathos .	49.83531
watching , they waited until the squall thickened and began to move in a long drifting slant across the dry burning land .	67.93107
at once the whole band set off at a lope .	14.085577
they went after the squall as mercilessly as a wolf pack after an abandoned cow .	77.90608
i followed them in the jeep and now they did not care .	50.048435
the games were over , this was life .	22.671995
occasionally , for no reason that i could see , they would suddenly alter the angle of their trot .	67.568535
sometimes i guessed it was because the rain squall had changed direction .	101.949036
their gait is impossible to convey in words .	2.8433921
it has nothing of the proud stride of the trained runner about it , it is not a lope , it is not done with style or verve .	47.550556
it is the gait of the human who must run to live arms dangling , legs barely swinging over the ground , head hung down and only occasionally swinging up to see the target , a loose motion that is just short of stumbling and yet is wonderfully graceful .	99.81278
it is a barely controlled skimming of the ground .	47.11077
finally , avoiding hummocks and seeking low ground , they intercepted the rain squall .	19.69665
for ten minutes they ran beneath the squall , raising their arms and , for the first time , shouting and capering .	33.145885
then the wind died and the rain squall held steady .	131.21588
suddenly one of them shouted , ran a few feet , bent forward and put his mouth to the ground .	33.47498
he had found a depression with rain water in it .	38.82392
he bent down , a black cranelike figure , and put his mouth to the ground .	19.15506
with a lordly and generous gesture , the discoverer stood up and beckoned to the closest of his fellows .	89.17911
the other trotted over and swooped at the tiny puddle .	28.726547
in an instant he had sucked it dry .	2.2316291
the aborigine lives on the cruelest land i have ever seen .	11.322076
which does not mean that it is ugly .	2.1300726
there are thousands of square miles of salt pan which are hideous .	93.601974
they are huge areas which have been swept by winds for so many centuries that there is no soil left , but only deep bare ridges fifty or sixty yards apart with ravines between them thirty or forty feet deep and the only thing that moves is a scuttling layer of sand .	107.99928
but much of the land which the aborigine wanders looks as if it should be hospitable .	43.27287
it is softened by the saltbush and the bluebush , has a peaceful quality , the hills roll softly .	172.30452
the malignancy of such a landscape has been beautifully described by the australian charles bean .	81.7809
he tells of three men who started out on a trip across a single paddock , a ten-by-ten-mile square owned by a sheep grazer .	39.252922
they went well-equipped with everything except knowledge of the `` outback ' ' country .	16.58488
the countryside looked like a beautiful open park with gentle slopes and soft gray tree-clumps .	57.966846
nothing appalling or horrible rushed upon these men .	3.4406612
there might have been a pool of cool water behind any of these tree-clumps only -- there was not .	156.63568
there might have been a fence or a house just over the next rise	237.3182
they lay , with the birds hopping from branch to branch above them and the bright sky peeping down at them .	107.15316
even today range riders will come upon mummified bodies of men who attempted nothing more difficult than a twenty-mile hike and slowly lost direction , were tortured by the heat , driven mad by the constant and unfulfilled promise of the landscape , and who finally died .	128.77321
he knows that the land is hard and pitiless .	15.6755495
he knows that the economy of life in the `` outback ' ' is awful .	15.14817
there is no room for error or waste .	30.013367
any organism that falters or misperceives the signals or weakens is done .	64.82151
i do not know if such a way of life can come to be a self-conscious challenge , but i suspect that it can .	33.84771
perhaps this is what gives the aborigine his odd air of dignity .	392.59903
seeing an aborigine today is a difficult thing .	5.9594045
many of them have drifted into the cities and towns and seaports .	16.83218
others are confined to vast reservations , and not only does the australian government justifiably not wish them to be viewed as exhibits in a zoo , but on their reservations they are extremely fugitive , shunning camps , coming together only for corroborees at which their strange culture comes to its highest pitch -- which is very low indeed .	127.91806
i persuaded an australian friend who had lived `` outback ' ' for years to take me to see some aborigines living in the bush .	66.14238
it was a difficult and ambiguous kind of negotiation , even though the rancher was said to be expert in his knowledge of the aborigines and their language .	69.68211
finally , however , the arrangements were made and we drove out into the bush in a land rover .	50.27333
we followed the asphalt road for a few miles and then swung off onto a smaller road which was nothing more than two tire marks on the earth .	68.604576
the rancher went a mile down this road and then , when he reached a big red boulder , swung off the road .	50.534973
at once he started to glance toward the instrument panel .	613.3231
it took me a moment to realize what was odd about that panel there was a gimbaled compass welded to it , which rocked gently back and forth as the land rover bounced about .	89.476295
the rancher was navigating his way across the flatland .	43.306984
`` do you always navigate like this ' ' ? ?	2.4474676
`` damned right ' ' , he said .	2.088225
`` once i get out on the flat i do .	66.219475
some chaps that know an area well can make their way by landmarks , a tree here , a wash here , a boulder there .	151.75433
but if you don ' t know the place like the palm of your hand , you ' d better use a compass and the speedometer .	80.83883
two miles northeast , then five miles southwest that sort of thing .	225.827
i would try to memorize landmarks and saw in a half-hour that it was hopeless .	72.086365
finally we approached the bivouac of the aborigines .	13.761027
they were camped beside a large column-shaped boulder a man , his lubra , and two children .	58.042072
the sun was not yet high and all of them were in the small area of shade cast by the boulder .	67.041016
there was also a dog , a dingo dog .	23.44864
its ribs showed , it was a yellow nondescript color , it suffered from a variety of sores , hair had scabbed off its body in patches .	66.79255
it lay with its head on its paws and only its eyes moving , watching us carefully .	148.807
it struck me as a very bright and very malnourished dog .	29.937304
`` the buggers love shade ' ' , the rancher said .	47.587112
`` i suppose because it saves them some loss of body water .	279.67972
they ' ll move around that rock all day , following the shade .	117.651886
during the hottest part of the day , of course , the sun comes straight down and there isn ' t any shade ' ' .	33.361774
we drove close to the boulder , stopped the land rover , and walked over toward the family .	34.123146
he gazed away from us as we approached .	194.99017
he was over six feet tall and very thin .	9.326242
every bone and muscle in his body showed , but he did not give the appearance of starving .	24.833326
he had long black hair and a wispy beard .	14.54181
the ridges over his eyes were huge and his eyelids were half shut .	170.50665
there was something about his face that disturbed me and it took several seconds to realize what .	62.30739
it was not merely that flies were crawling over his face but his narrowed eyelids did not blink when the flies crawled into his eye sockets .	49.741978
a fly would crawl down the bulging forehead , into the socket of the eye , walk along the man ' s lashes and across the wet surface of the eyeball , and the eye did not blink .	28.943495
the australian and i both were wearing insect repellent and were not badly bothered by insects , but my eyes watered as we stood watching the aborigine .	114.59712
she remained squatting on her heels all the time we were there	244.69589
like the man , she was entirely naked .	11.982387
her long thin arms moved in a slow rhythmical gesture over the family possessions which were placed in front of her .	54.105766
there were two rubbing sticks for making fire , two stones shaped roughly like knives , a woven-root container which held a few pounds of dried worms and the dead body of some rodent .	58.264633
there was also a long wooden spear and a woomera , a spear-throwing device which gives the spear an enormous velocity and high accuracy .	40.916546
there was also a boomerang , elaborately carved .	73.60495
everything was burnished with sweat and grease so that all of the objects seemed to have been carved from the same material and to be ageless .	39.752293
the two children , both boys , wandered around the australian and me for a few moments and then returned to their work .	85.42294
they squatted on their heels with their heads bent far forward , their eyes only a few inches from the ground .	79.37358
they had located the runway of a colony of ants and as the ants came out of the ground , the boys picked them up , one at a time , and pinched them dead .	57.03268
the tiny bodies , dropped onto a dry leaf , made a pile as big as a small apple .	73.54426
the odor here was more powerful than that which surrounded the town aborigines .	162.15164
the smell at first was more surprising than unpleasant .	119.90602
it was also subtly familiar , for it was the odor of the human body , but multiplied innumerable times because of the fact that the aborigines never bathed .	50.47249
one ' s impulse is to say that the smell was a stink and unpleasant .	38.608643
but that is a cliche and a dishonest one .	16.538921
the smell is sexual , but so powerfully so that a civilized nose must deny it .	133.33894
their skin was covered with a thin coating of sweat and dirt which had almost the consistency of a second skin .	61.482346
they roll at night in ashes to keep warm and their second skin has a light dusty cast to it .	96.387505
in spots such as the elbows and knees the second skin is worn off and i realized the aborigines were much darker than they appeared	85.01451
as if the coating of sweat , dirt , and ashes were a cosmetic .	24.423498
the boys had beautiful dark eyes and unlike their father they brushed constantly at the flies and blinked their eyes .	137.35808
`` that smell is something , eh , mate ' ' ? ?	32.350185
`` they swear that every person smells different and every family smells different from every other .	84.37155
at the corroborees , when they get to dancing and sweating , you ' ll see them rubbing up against a man who ' s supposed to have a specially good smell .	55.126663
idje , here ' ' , and he nodded at the man , `` is said to have great odor .	72.61137
the stink is all the same to me , but i really think they can make one another out blindfolded ' ' .	60.75829
`` here , idje , you fella like tabac ' ' ? ?	5.5727754
idje still stared over our shoulders at the horizon .	40.083992
the australian stopped trying to talk a pidgin i could understand , and spoke strange words from deep in his chest .	181.751
it was a fortunate time in which to build , for the seventeenth century was a great period in persian art .	53.402397
the architects , the tile and carpet makers , the potters , painters , calligraphers , and metalsmiths worked through abbas ' s reign and those of his successors to enrich the city .	58.789608
travelers entering from the desert were confounded by what must have seemed an illusion a great garden filled with nightingales and roses , cut by canals and terraced promenades , studded with water tanks of turquoise tile in which were reflected the glistening blue curves of a hundred domes .	68.89916
at the heart of all of this was the square , which one such traveler declared to be `` as spacious , as pleasant and aromatick a market as any in the universe ' ' .	89.61135
in time isfahan came to be known as `` half the world ' ' , isfahan nisf-i-jahan .	26.521862
in the early eighteenth century this fantastic city , then the size of london , started to decline .	102.96798
isfahan became more of a legend than a place , and now it is for many people simply a name to which they attach their notions of old persia and sometimes of the east .	93.10888
they think of it as a kind of spooky museum in which they may half see and half imagine the old splendor .	239.24178
those who actually get there find that it isn ' t spooky at all but as brilliant as a tile in sunlight .	76.15494
but even for them it remains a museum , or perhaps it would be more accurate to say a tomb , a tomb in which persia lies well preserved but indeed dead .	100.27949
everyone is ready to grant the persians their history , but almost no one is willing to acknowledge their present .	65.16595
it seems that for persia , and especially for this city , there are only two times the glorious past and the corrupt , depressing , sterile present .	84.50961
the one apparent connection between the two is a score of buildings which somehow or other have survived and which naturally enough are called `` historical monuments ' ' .	105.772255
however , just as all the buildings have not fallen and flowed back to their original mud , so the values which wanted them and saw that they were built have not all disappeared .	124.75236
the values and talents which made the tile and the dome , the rug , the poem and the miniature , continue in certain social institutions which rise above the ordinary life of this city , as the great buildings rise above blank walls and dirty lanes .	84.4676
often , too , the social institutions are housed in these pavilions and palaces and bridges , for these great structures are not simply `` historical monuments ' '	48.366184
the promenade , for example , continues to take place on the chahar bagh , a mile-long garden of plane and poplar trees that now serves as the city ' s principal street .	29.08326
it takes place as well along the terraces and through the arcades of the khaju bridge , and also in the gardens of the square .	27.681532
on fridays , the day when many persians relax with poetry , talk , and a samovar , people do not , it is true , stream into chehel sotun -- a pavilion and garden built by shah abbas 2 , in the seventeenth century -- but they do retire into hundreds of pavilions throughout the city and up the river valley , which are smaller , more humble copies of the former .	52.55992
and of course religious life continues to center in the more famous mosques , and commercial life -- very much a social institution -- in the bazaar .	79.32167
those three other great activities of the persians , the bath , the teahouse , and the zur khaneh ( the latter a kind of club in which a leader and a group of men in an octagonal pit move through a rite of calisthenics , dance , chanted poetry , and music ) , do not take place in buildings to which entrance tickets are sold , but some of them occupy splendid examples of persian domestic architecture long , domed , chalk-white rooms with daises of turquoise tile , their end walls cut through to the orchards and the sky by open arches .	83.5515
but more important , and the thing which the casual traveler and the blind sojourner often do not see , is that these places and activities are often the settings in which persians exercise their extraordinary aesthetic sensibilities .	89.90243
water , air , fruit , poetry , music , the human form -- these things are important to persians , and they experience them with an intense and discriminating awareness .	64.02311
i should like , by the way , to make it clear that i am not using the word `` persians ' ' carelessly .	30.876793
i don ' t mean a few aesthetes who play about with sensations , like a young prince in a miniature dabbling his hand in a pool .	128.83954
these things are important to almost all persians and perhaps most important to the most ordinary .	62.553524
the men crying love poems in an orchard on any summer ' s night are as often as not the lutihaw , mustachioed toughs who spend most of their lives in and out of the local prisons , brothels , and teahouses .	58.1786
a few months ago it was a fairly typical landlord who in the dead of night lugged me up a mountainside to drink from a spring famous in the neighborhood for its clarity and flavor .	101.13898
not long ago an acquaintance , a slick-headed water rat of a lad up from the maw of the city , stood on the balcony puffing his first cigarette in weeks .	69.55381
the air , he said , was just right	228.79677
i really didn ' t know what he meant .	44.8039
he sniffed the air and licked it on his lip and knew as a vintner knows a vintage .	146.90907
the natural world then , plus poetry and some kinds of art , receives from the most ordinary of persians a great deal of attention .	72.55498
the line of an eyebrow , the color of the skin , a ghazal from hafiz , the purity of spring water , the long afternoon among the boughs which crowd the upper story of a pavilion -- these things are noticed , judged , and valued .	93.509544
nowhere in isfahan is this rich aesthetic life of the persians shown so well as during the promenade at the khaju bridge .	45.73067
there has probably always been a bridge of some sort at the southeastern corner of the city .	40.81115
for one thing , there is a natural belt of rock across the river bed	399.24808
for another , it was here that one of the old caravan routes came in .	54.305298
it was to provide a safe and spacious crossing for these caravans , and also to make a pleasance for the city , that shah abbas 2 , in about 1657 built , of sun-baked brick , tile , and stone , the present bridge .	47.725876
from upstream it looks like a long arcaded box laid across the river	82.95575
from downstream , where the water level is much lower , it is a high , elaborately facaded pavilion .	23.374947
the top story contains more than thirty alcoves separated from each other by spandrels of blue and yellow tile .	28.508535
at either end and in the center there are bays which contain nine greater alcoves as frescoed and capacious as church apses .	121.73429
here , in the old days -- when they had come to see the moon or displays of fireworks -- sat the king and his court while priests , soldiers , and other members of the party lounged in the smaller alcoves between .	92.56589
below , twenty vaults tunnel through the understructure of the bridge .	44.5387
these are traversed by another line of vaults , and thus rooms , arched on all four sides , are formed .	89.217476
down through the axis of the bridge there is a long diminishing vista like a visual echo of piers and arches , while the vaults fronting upstream and down frame the sunset and sunrise , the mountains and river pools .	73.52431
here , on the hottest day , it is cool beneath the stone and fresh from the water flowing in the sluices at the bottom of the vaults .	38.024006
on the downstream , or `` pavilion ' ' , side these vaults give out onto terraces twice as wide as the bridge itself .	136.26823
from the terraces -- eighteen in all -- broad flights of steps descend into the water or onto still more terraces barely above the level of the river .	94.43827
out of water , brick , and tile they have made far more than just a bridge .	113.598495
on spring and summer evenings people leave their shops and houses and walk up through the lanes of the city to the bridge .	55.984695
the bridge itself rises up from the river , light-flared and enormous , like the outdoor set for an epic opera .	92.84199
crowds press along the terraces , down the steps , in and out of the arcades , massing against it as though it were a fortress under siege .	99.355125
all kinds come to walk in the promenade merchants from the bazaar bickering over a deal	212.47964
a bakhtiari khan in a cap and hacking jacket	29.685547
dervishes who stand with the stillness of the blind , their eyes filmed with rheum and visions	69.23952
the old kajar princes arriving in their ancient limousines	3.4830284
students , civil servants , beggars , musicians , hawkers , and clowns .	9.074498
families go out to the edge of the terraces to sit on carpets around a samovar .	101.17733
below , people line the steps , as though on bleachers , to watch the sky and river .	104.57192
above , in the tiled prosceniums of the alcoves , boys sing the ghazals of hafiz and saadi , while at the very bottom , in the vaults , the toughs and blades of the city hoot and bang their drums , drink arak , play dice , and dance .	39.810528
here in an evening persians enjoy many of the things which are important to them poetry , water , the moon , a beautiful face .	95.185
to a stranger their delight in these things may seem paradoxical , for persians chase the golden calf as much as any people .	149.7633
many of them , moreover , are beginning to complain about the scarcity of western amusements and to ridicule the old life of the bazaar merchant , the mullah , and the peasant .	58.838627
nonetheless , they take time out -- much time -- from the game of grab and these new western experiments to go to the gardens and riverbanks .	136.64099
above all , they will stop in the middle of anything , anywhere , to hear or quote some poetry .	87.02351
poetry in persian life is far more than a common ground on which -- in a society deeply fissured by antagonisms -- all may stand .	103.50233
it contains , in fact , their whole outlook on life .	189.4336
and it is expressed , at least to their taste , in a perfect form .	40.12974
poetry for a persian is nothing less than truth and beauty .	102.71082
in most western cultures today these twins have been sent away to the libraries and museums .	45.095818
in persia , where practically speaking there are no museums or libraries or , for that matter , hardly any books , the twins run free .	188.17778
it is perhaps difficult to conceive , but imagine that tonight on london bridge the teddy boys of the east end will gather to sing marlowe , herrick , shakespeare , and perhaps some lyrics of their own .	117.25682
that , at any rate , is what happens at the khaju bridge .	66.98976
boys and men go along the riverbank or to the alcoves in the top arcade .	36.96233
here in these little rooms -- or stages arched open to the sky and river -- they choose a few lines out of the hundreds they may know and sing them according to one of the modes into which persian music is divided .	123.387344
each mode is believed to have a specific attribute -- one inducing pleasure , another generosity , another love , and so on , to include all of the emotions .	132.46408
the singer simply matches the poem to a mode	733.99426
for example , the mode of bravery to this anonymous folk poem `` they brought me news that spring is in the plains and ahmad ' s blood the crimson tulip stains	131.90771
go , tell his aged mother that her son fought with a thousand foes , and he was one ' ' .	47.12404
or the mode of love to this fragment by a recent poet `` know ye , fair folk who dwell on earth or shall hereafter come to birth , that here , with dust upon his eyes , iraj , the sweet-tongued singer , lies .	135.63947
in this true lover ' s tomb interred a world of love lies sepulchred .	36.44889
these songs ( practically all persian music , for that matter ) are limited to a range of two octaves .	103.198456
yet within this limitation there is an astonishing variety design as intricate as that in the carpet or miniature , with the melodic line like the painted or woven line often flowing into an arabesque .	92.36114
die frist ist um , und wiederum verstrichen sind sieben jahr , the maestro quoted the flying dutchman , as he told of his career and wanderings , explaining that the number seven had significantly recurred in his life several times .	59.999973
the music director of the pittsburgh symphony orchestra , william steinberg , has molded his group into a prominent musical organization , which is his life .	87.08271
when he added to his pittsburgh commitments the directorship of the london philharmonic orchestra in 1958 , he conducted one hundred fifty concerts within nine months , `` commuting ' ' between the two cities .	60.855076
this schedule became too strenuous , even for the energetic and conscientious mr . steinberg .	112.17808
his london contract was rescinded , and now , he explains cheerfully , as a bright smile lightens his intense , mobile face , `` i conduct only one hundred and twenty concerts ' ' ! !	53.521946
our meeting took place in may , 1961 , during one of the maestro ' s stop-overs in new york , before he left for europe .	36.87052
as we began to converse in the lounge of his fifth avenue hotel , his restlessness and sensitivity to light and sound became immediately apparent .	98.471954
seeking an obscure , dark , relatively quiet corner in the airy room otherwise suffused with afternoon sunshine , he asked if the soft background music could be turned off .	108.5009
unfortunately , it was muzak , which automatically is piped into the public rooms , and which nolens volens had to be endured .	56.557095
as he talked about himself , time and again stuffing and dragging on his pipe , steinberg began to relax and the initial hurried feeling grew faint and was dispelled .	158.81773
did he come from a musical family ? ?	1.0156382
yes though not professional musicians , they were a music-loving family .	45.761864
in his native cologne , where his mother taught him to play the piano , he was able to read notes before he learned the alphabet .	47.8949
she even devised a system of colors , whereby the boy could easily distinguish the different note values .	399.33395
when he started school at the age of five-and-a-half , he could not understand why the alphabet begins with the letter a , instead of c , as in the scale .	61.120472
because , like many other children , he intensely disliked practicing czerny etudes , he composed his own studies .	47.48554
when he was eight he began violin lessons .	13.261118
soon he was playing in the cologne municipal orchestra , and during world war 1 , , when musicians were scarce , he joined the opera orchestra as well .	53.851135
steinberg claims that these early years of orchestra participation were of invaluable help to his career .	69.101746
`` by observing the conductor ' ' , he says with a twinkle in his eyes , `` i learned how not to conduct ' ' .	30.135426
the musician ran away from school when he was fifteen , but this escapade did not save him from the gymnasium .	52.05891
simultaneously , he pursued his musical studies at the conservatory , receiving sound training in counterpoint and harmony , as well in the violin and piano .	62.283623
he became otto klemperer ' s personal assistant at the cologne opera , and a year later was promoted to the position of regular conductor .	40.502525
wasn ' t this an unusually young age to fill such a responsible post ? ?	98.13136
had he always wished to be a conductor ? ?	39.333073
no , originally he had hoped to become a concert pianist and had even performed as such .	190.10712
however , when he assumed the duties of a conductor , he relinquished his career as a pianist .	44.156334
five years were spent with the cologne opera , after which he was called to prague by alexander von zemlinsky , teacher of arnold schonberg and erich korngold .	40.47755
in 1927 he succeeded zemlinsky as opera director of the german theater at prague .	41.56815
during his tenure he also fulfilled guest engagements at the berlin state opera .	55.257835
two years later he became director of the frankfurt opera , where he remained until he lost this position in 1933 through the rise of the hitler regime .	81.819626
during these years the youthful conductor had contributed greatly to the high level of musical life in germany .	57.776104
he had presented the first german performances of puccini ' s manon lescaut and de falla ' s la vida breve .	10.581488
the frankfurt years were particularly noteworthy for his performance of berg ' s wozzek soon after the berlin premiere under erich kleiber , and the world premiere of schonberg ' s von heute auf morgen .	27.984066
at the outset of his career , steinberg had dedicated himself to the advancement of contemporary music by vowing to do a schonberg work every year .	58.024033
in frankfurt , too , he directed the museum and opera house concerts which , in addition to the standard repertoire , featured novelties like erdmann ' s piano concerto and mahler ' s sixth symphony .	23.35312
because of the political upheaval in germany in the 1930 ' s , steinberg was forced to restrict his activities to the jewish community .	42.916172
through the frankfurt jewish kulturbund he began to give sonata recitals in synagogues , with cellist emanuel feuermann .	27.34239
as more and more jewish musicians lost their jobs with professional organizations steinberg united them into the frankfurt kulturbund orchestra , which also gave guest performances in other german cities .	94.95321
in 1936 he accepted the leadership of the berlin kulturbund .	74.76477
in the fall of that year the best musicians of the berlin and frankfurt kulturbund orchestras joined under the combined efforts of bronislaw hubermann and steinberg to become the palestine orchestra -- now known as the israel philharmonic orchestra -- with steinberg as founder-conductor .	96.74491
in 1938 , at the insistence of arturo toscanini , steinberg left germany for the united states , by way of switzerland .	42.9695
after he had spent the first three years in new york as associate conductor , at toscanini ' s invitation , of the nbc orchestra , he made numerous guest appearances throughout the united states and latin america .	36.911026
in 1945 he became conductor of the buffalo philharmonic .	13.06202
seven years later he was asked to become director of the pittsburgh symphony .	22.929497
since 1944 he has also conducted regularly at the san francisco opera , where he made his debut with a memorable performance of verdi ' s falstaff .	17.375872
in recent years he has traveled widely in europe , conducting in italy , france , austria , and switzerland .	28.010565
he returned to germany for the first time in 1953 , where he has since conducted in cologne , frankfurt , and berlin .	49.831795
where in europe was he going now ? ?	1.1052164
first of all , to italy for a short vacation -- forte dei marmi , a place he loves .	74.930084
since it is not far from viareggio , he will visit puccini ' s house , as he never fails to do , to pay his respects to the memory of the composer of la boheme , which he considers one of puccini ' s masterpieces .	39.741413
steinberg spoke with warmth and enthusiasm about italy `` rome is my second home .	153.31593
i consider it the center of the world and make it a point to be there once a year ' ' .	53.566566
he will conduct two concerts at the accademia di santa cecilia , as well as concerts in munich and cologne .	16.499489
`` then i return to the united states for engagements at the hollywood bowl and in philadelphia ' ' , he added .	45.338974
the forthcoming season in pittsburgh also promises to be of unusual interest .	51.789772
there will be premieres of new works , made possible through ford foundation commissions carlisle floyd ' s mystery , with phyllis curtin as soprano soloist .	110.7819
other world premieres will be gardner read ' s third symphony and burle marx ' s samba concertante .	15.13158
`` and next year we will do -- also a ford commission -- a piano concerto by elliott carter , with jacob lateiner as soloist .	71.05739
of course , i shall conduct mahler and bruckner works in the coming season , as usual .	63.408783
we ' ll play bruckner ' s fifth symphony in the original version , and mahler ' s seventh -- the least accessible , known , and played of mahler ' s works .	42.975414
my pittsburghers have become real addicts to mahler and bruckner ' ' .	6.4551077
he added that he also stresses the works of these favorite masters on tour , especially mahler ' s first and fourth symphonies , and das lied von der erde , and bruckner ' s sixth -- which is rarely played -- and seventh .	62.873165
bruckner ' s eighth he refers to as `` my travel symphony ' ' .	46.912125
he recalled that in california after a critic had attacked him for `` still trying to sell bruckner to the americans ' ' , the public ' s response at the next concert was a standing ovation .	60.738243
`` now that bruno walter is virtually in retirement and my dear friend dimitri mitropoulos is no longer with us , i am probably the only one -- with the possible exception of leonard bernstein -- who has this special affinity for and champions the works of bruckner and mahler ' ' .	81.498116
since he introduces so much modern music , i could not resist asking how he felt about it .	68.01359
`` there was always and at all times a contemporary music and it expresses the era in which it was created .	87.95495
but i usually stick to the old phrase ' ich habe ein amt , aber keine meinung ( i hold an office , but i do not feel entitled to have an opinion ) .	32.493435
i consider it to be my job to expose the public to what is being written today ' ' .	55.16419
with all his musical activities , did he have the time and inclination to do anything else ? ?	20.768074
he had just paid a brief visit to the frick collection to admire his favorite paintings by rembrandt and franz hals .	45.76472
he was not enthusiastic over the newly acquired claude lorrain , but reminisced with pleasure over a poussin exhibit he had been able to see in paris a year ago .	43.740253
and how did he feel about modern art ? ?	7.0158515
again steinberg was cautious and replied with a smile that he was not exposed to it enough to hazard comments .	72.05708
`` as my wife puts it ' ' , he said , again with a twinkle in his eyes , `` all you know is your music .	30.124334
but after all , you never learned anything else ' ' ! !	8.022169
like his late colleague , mitropoulos , he reads mystery stories , in particular sir arthur conan doyle .	40.974785
he cited heine and stendhal as favorites in literature .	87.18234
but his prime interest , apart from music , he insisted seriously , was his family -- his wife , daughter and son .	63.94863
at the moment he was excited about his son ' s having received the prix de rome in archaeology and was looking forward to being present this summer at the excavation of an etruscan tomb .	71.85017
`` both children are musical and my wife is a music lover of unfailing instinct and judgement ' ' .	31.987986
`` is the attitude of german youth comparable to that of `` the angry young men ' of england ' ' ? ?	31.564663
was the topic for a round-table discussion at the bayerische rundfunk in munich .	11.723634
i was chairman , the only not youthful participant .	7.713339
since attack serves to stimulate interest in broadcasts , i added to my opening statement a sentence in which i claimed that german youth seemed to lack the enthusiasm which is a necessary ingredient of anger , and might be classified as uninterested and bored rather than angry .	113.37436
i was far from convinced of the truth of my statement , but could not think of anything that might evoke responses more quickly .	160.7998
`` it is easy for you to talk ' '	5.8715725
countered a twenty year old law student , `` you travel around the world .	35.519352
we would like to do that too ' ' .	1.7367418
`` but you want a job guaranteed when you return ' ' , i continued my attack .	56.59535
`` you must have some security ' ' , said a young clerk .	33.296272
when i mentioned that for my first long voyage i did not even have the money for the return fare , but had trusted to luck that i would earn a sufficient amount , the young people looked at me doubtingly .	62.59577
one girl expressed what was obviously in their minds .	10.731333
`` would you advise us to act the same way ? ?	20.466146
i think it is rather foolhardy to trust to luck ' ' .	38.530003
others mentioned that i might have had to ask friends or even strangers for help and that to be stranded in a foreign country without sufficient funds did not contribute to international understanding .	126.798645
the debate needed no additional controversy and soon i could ask each individually what he expected from life , what his hopes were and what his fears .	210.86642
though the four boys and two girls , the youngest nineteen years of age , the oldest twenty-four , came from varying backgrounds and had different professional and personal interests , there was surprising agreement among them .	76.602936
what they feared most was war or political instability in their own country .	21.307352
the ideal home , they agreed , would be a small private house or a city apartment of four to five rooms , just enough for a family consisting of husband , wife , and two children .	65.115166
no one wanted a larger family or no children , and none hoped for a castle or said that living in less settled circumstances would be satisfactory .	308.95135
all expressed interest in world affairs but no one offered to make any sacrifices to satisfy this interest .	127.17843
once again , as in the days of the founding fathers , america faces a stern test .	92.15688
that test , as president kennedy forthrightly depicted it in his state of the union message , will determine `` whether a nation organized and governed such as ours can endure ' ' .	75.41201
it is well then that in this hour both of `` national peril ' ' and of `` national opportunity ' ' we can take counsel with the men who made the nation .	56.221878
incapable of self-delusion , the founding fathers found the crisis of their time to be equally grave , and yet they had confidence that america would surmount it and that a republic of free peoples would prosper and serve as an example to a world aching for liberty .	66.46968
seven founders -- george washington , benjamin franklin , john adams , thomas jefferson , alexander hamilton , james madison and john jay -- determined the destinies of the new nation .	35.171158
in certain respects , their task was incomparably greater than ours today , for there was nobody before them to show them the way .	67.77373
as madison commented to jefferson in 1789 , `` we are in a wilderness without a single footstep to guide us .	69.19674
our successors will have an easier task ' ' .	1.5856328
they thought of themselves , to use jefferson ' s words , as `` the argonauts ' ' who had lived in `` the heroic age ' ' .	19.303562
accordingly , they took special pains to preserve their papers as essential sources for posterity .	185.3466
their writings assume more than dramatic or patriotic interest because of their conviction that the struggle in which they were involved was neither selfish nor parochial but , rather , as washington in his last wartime circular reminded his fellow countrymen , that `` with our fate will the destiny of unborn millions be involved ' ' .	125.262184
strong men with strong opinions , frank to the point of being refreshingly indiscreet , the founding seven were essentially congenial minds , and their agreements with each other were more consequential than their differences .	56.737152
even though in most cases the completion of the definitive editions of their writings is still years off , enough documentation has already been assembled to warrant drawing a new composite profile of the leadership which performed the heroic dual feats of winning american independence and founding a new nation .	128.70084
before merging them into a common profile it is well to remember that their separate careers were extraordinary .	99.28896
certainly no other seven american statesmen from any later period achieved so much in so concentrated a span of years .	155.91301
eldest of the seven , benjamin franklin , a new englander transplanted to philadelphia , wrote the most dazzling success story in our history .	44.316025
the young printer ' s apprentice achieved greatness in a half-dozen different fields , as editor and publisher , scientist , inventor , philanthropist and statesman .	45.983765
author of the albany plan of union , which , had it been adopted , might have avoided the revolution , he fought the colonists ' front-line battles in london , negotiated the treaty of alliance with france and the peace that ended the war , headed the state government of pennsylvania , and exercised an important moderating influence at the federal convention .	61.682587
on a military mission for his native virginia the youthful george washington touched off the french and indian war , then guarded his colony ' s frontier as head of its militia .	147.32451
commanding the continental army for six long years of the revolution , he was the indispensable factor in the ultimate victory .	33.968266
retiring to his beloved mount vernon , he returned to preside over the federal convention , and was the only man in history to be unanimously elected president .	69.23813
during his two terms the constitution was tested and found workable , strong national policies were inaugurated , and the traditions and powers of the presidential office firmly fixed .	140.91687
john adams fashioned much of pre-revolutionary radical ideology , wrote the constitution of his home state of massachusetts , negotiated , with franklin and jay , the peace with britain and served as our first vice president and our second president .	80.44254
his political opponent and lifetime friend , thomas jefferson , achieved immortality through his authorship of the declaration of independence , but equally notable were the legal and constitutional reforms he instituted in his native virginia , his role as father of our territorial system , and his acquisition of the louisiana territory during his first term as president .	62.58795
during the greater part of jefferson ' s career he enjoyed the close collaboration of a fellow virginian , james madison , eight years his junior .	116.14866
the active sponsor of jefferson ' s measure for religious liberty in virginia , madison played the most influential single role in the drafting of the constitution and in securing its ratification in virginia , founded the first political party in american history , and , as jefferson ' s secretary of state and his successor in the presidency , guided the nation through the troubled years of our second war with britain .	63.4958
if franklin was an authentic genius , then alexander hamilton , with his exceptional precocity , consuming energy , and high ambition , was a political prodigy .	62.738277
his revolutionary pamphlets , published when he was only 19 , quickly brought him to the attention of the patriot leaders .	101.151474
principal author of `` the federalist ' ' , he swung new york over from opposition to the constitution to ratification almost single-handedly .	185.69566
his collaboration with washington , begun when he was the general ' s aide during the revolution , was resumed when he entered the first cabinet as secretary of the treasury .	30.564081
his bold fiscal program and his broad interpretation of the constitution stand as durable contributions .	58.21073
less dazzling than hamilton , less eloquent than jefferson , john jay commands an equally high rank among the founding fathers .	132.39114
he served as president of the continental congress .	2.518185
he played the leading role in negotiating the treaty with great britain that ended the revolution , and directed america ' s foreign affairs throughout the confederation period .	70.914
as first chief justice , his strong nationalist opinions anticipated john marshall .	253.43639
he ended his public career as a two-term governor of new york .	8.480458
these seven founders constituted an intellectual and social elite , the most respectable and disinterested leadership any revolution ever confessed .	88.23623
their social status was achieved in some cases by birth , as with washington , jefferson and jay	109.28001
in others by business and professional acumen , as with franklin and adams , or , in hamilton ' s case , by an influential marriage .	73.04601
unlike so many of the power-starved intellectuals in underdeveloped nations of our own day , they commanded both prestige and influence before the revolution started .	138.4612
as different physically as the tall , angular jefferson was from the chubby , rotund adams , the seven were striking individualists .	54.945614
ardent , opinionated , even obstinate , they were amazingly articulate , wrote their own copy , and were masters of phrasemaking .	58.655476
capable of enduring friendships , they were also stout controversialists , who could write with a drop of vitriol on their pens .	30.541515
john adams dismissed john dickinson , who voted against the declaration of independence , as `` a certain great fortune and piddling genius ' ' .	29.382807
washington castigated his critic , general conway , as being capable of `` all the meanness of intrigue to gratify the absurd resentment of disappointed vanity ' ' .	54.31681
and hamilton , who felt it `` a religious duty ' ' to oppose aaron burr ' s political ambitions , would have been a better actuarial risk had he shown more literary restraint .	76.295166
the seven founders were completely dedicated to the public service .	29.425802
madison once remarked `` my life has been so much a public one ' ' , a comment which fits the careers of the other six .	70.23286
franklin retired from editing and publishing at the age of 42 , and for the next forty-two years devoted himself to public , scientific , and philanthropic interests .	69.539856
washington never had a chance to work for an extended stretch at the occupation he loved best , plantation management .	428.86676
he served as commander in chief during the revolution without compensation .	354.41098
john adams took to heart the advice given him by his legal mentor , jeremiah gridley , to `` pursue the study of the law , rather than the gain of it ' ' .	24.211931
in taking account of seventeen years of law practice , adams concluded that `` no lawyer in america ever did so much business as i did ' ' and `` for so little profit ' ' .	89.19403
when the revolution broke out , he , along with jefferson and jay , abandoned his career at the bar , with considerable financial sacrifice .	116.54039
hamilton , poorest of the seven , gave up a brilliant law practice to enter washington ' s cabinet .	138.70015
while he was handling the multi-million-dollar funding operations of the government he had to resort to borrowing small sums from friends .	71.07317
`` if you can conveniently let me have twenty dollars ' ' , he wrote one friend in 1791 when he was secretary of the treasury .	39.696575
to support his large family hamilton went back to the law after each spell of public service .	79.084076
talleyrand passed his new york law office one night on the way to a party .	36.989994
hamilton was bent over his desk , drafting a legal paper by the light of a candle .	45.255222
`` i have just come from viewing a man who had made the fortune of his country , but now is working all night in order to support his family ' ' , he reflected .	72.75291
all seven combined ardent devotion to the cause of revolution with a profound respect for legality .	39.18938
john adams asserted in the continental congress ' declaration of rights that the demands of the colonies were in accordance with their charters , the british constitution and the common law , and jefferson appealed in the declaration of independence `` to the tribunal of the world ' ' for support of a revolution justified by `` the laws of nature and of nature ' s god ' ' .	39.734554
they fought hard , but they were forgiving to former foes , and sought to prevent vindictive legislatures from confiscating tory property in violation of the treaty of 1783 .	29.872728
this sense of moderation and fairness is superbly exemplified in an exchange of letters between john jay and a tory refugee , peter van schaack .	62.248264
jay had participated in the decision that exiled his old friend van schaack .	44.37833
yet when , at war ' s end , the ex-tory made the first move to resume correspondence , jay wrote him from paris , where he was negotiating the peace settlement	111.48942
`` as an independent american i considered all who were not for us , and you amongst the rest , as against us , yet be assured that john jay never ceased to be the friend of peter van schaack ' ' .	60.413177
the latter in turn assured him that `` were i arraigned at the bar , and you my judge , i should expect to stand or fall only by the merits of my cause ' ' .	56.654182
all seven recognized that independence was but the first step toward building a nation .	56.619263
`` we have now a national character to establish ' ' , washington wrote in 1783 .	73.251175
`` think continentally ' ' , hamilton counseled the young nation .	83.4329
this new force , love of country , super-imposed upon -- if not displacing -- affectionate ties to one ' s own state , was epitomized by washington .	66.59458
his first inaugural address speaks of `` my country whose voice i can never hear but with veneration and love ' ' .	78.81393
all sought the fruition of that nationalism in a federal government with substantial powers .	89.47727
save jefferson , all participated in the framing or ratification of the federal constitution .	18.390059
they supported it , not as a perfect instrument , but as the best obtainable .	36.00546
historians have traditionally regarded the great debates of the seventeen nineties as polarizing the issues of centralized vs . limited government , with hamilton and the nationalists supporting the former and jefferson and madison upholding the latter position .	107.96344
the state ' s rights position was formulated by jefferson and madison in the kentucky and virginia resolves , but in their later careers as heads of state the two proved themselves better hamiltonians than jeffersonians .	155.94968
in purchasing louisiana , jefferson had to adopt hamilton ' s broad construction of the constitution , and so did madison in advocating the rechartering of hamilton ' s bank , which he had so strenuously opposed at its inception , and in adopting a hamiltonian protective tariff .	56.810654
indeed , the old jeffersonians were far more atune to the hamilton-oriented whigs than they were to the jacksonian democrats .	40.571
when , in 1832 , the south carolina nullifiers adopted the principle of state interposition which madison had advanced in his old virginia resolve , they elicited no encouragement from that senior statesman .	121.91415
in his political testament , `` advice to my country ' ' , penned just before his death , madison expressed the wish `` that the union of the states be cherished and perpetuated .	77.38106
let the open enemy to it be regarded as a pandora with her box opened	145.88109
and the disguised one , as the serpent creeping with his deadly wiles into paradise ' ' .	19.316431
nostalgic yankee readers of erskine caldwell are today informed by proud georgians that tobacco road is buried beneath a four-lane super highway , over which travel each day suburbanite businessmen more concerned with the dow-jones average than with the cotton crop .	170.90071
thus we are compelled to face the urbanization of the south -- an urbanization which , despite its dramatic and overwhelming effects upon the southern culture , has been utterly ignored by the bulk of southern writers .	52.36758
indeed , it seems that only in today ' s southern fiction does tobacco road , with all the traditional trimmings of sowbelly and cornbread and mint juleps , continue to live -- but only as a weary , overexploited phantom .	48.079365
those writers known collectively as the `` southern school ' ' have received accolades from even those critics least prone to eulogize	104.00969
according to many critics , in fact , the south has led the north in literature since the civil war , both quantitatively and qualitatively .	31.732107
such writers as william faulkner and robert penn warren have led the field of somewhat less important writers in a sort of post-bellum renaissance .	103.61714
it is interesting , however , that despite this strong upsurge in southern writing , almost none of the writers has forsaken the firmly entrenched concept of the white-suited big-daddy colonel sipping a mint julep as he silently recounts the revenue from the season ' s cotton and tobacco crops	129.85901
of the stereotyped negro servants chanting hymns as they plow the fields	142.24678
of these and a host of other antiquated legends that deny the south its progressive leaps of the past century .	68.92309
this is not to say that the south is no longer agrarian	39.244217
such a statement would be the rankest form of oversimplification .	25.425966
but the south is , and has been for the past century , engaged in a wide-sweeping urbanization which , oddly enough , is not reflected in its literature .	66.64674
in 1950 it had become 47 . 1% urban .	437.80756
in a mere half-century the south has more than tripled its urban status .	36.092922
there is a new south emerging , a south losing the folksy traditions of an agrarian society with the rapidity of an avalanche -- especially within recent decades .	77.67614
as the new south snowballs toward further urbanization , it becomes more and more homogeneous with the north -- a tendency which willard thorp terms `` yankeefication ' ' , as evidenced in such cities as charlotte , birmingham , and houston .	57.33067
it is said that , even at the present stage of southern urbanization , such a city as atlanta is not distinctly unlike columbus or trenton .	148.9384
undoubtedly even the old southern stalwart richmond has felt the new wind william styron mentions in his latest novel an avenue named for bankhead mcgruder , a civil war general , now renamed , in typical california fashion , `` buena vista terrace ' ' .	78.72499
the effects of television and other mass media are erasing regional dialects and localisms with a startling force .	87.22709
as for progress , the `` backward south ' ' can boast of baton rouge , which increased its population between 1940 and 1950 by two hundred and sixty-two percent , to 126 , 000 , the second largest growth of the period for all cities over 25 , 000 .	55.175922
the field , then , is ripe for new southerners to step to the fore and write of this twentieth-century phenomenon , the southern yankeefication the new urban economy , the city-dweller , the pains of transition , the labor problems	154.4533
truman capote is still reveling in southern gothicism , exaggerating the old southern legends into something beautiful and grotesque , but as unreal as -- or even more unreal than -- yesterday .	119.700195
william styron , while facing the changing economy with a certain uneasy reluctance , insists he is not to be classified as a southern writer and yet includes traditional southern concepts in everything he publishes .	149.52533
even the great god faulkner , the south ' s one probable contender for literary immortality , has little concerned himself with these matters	122.87748
such are simply not within his bounded province .	5.4680405
where are the writers to treat these changes ? ?	8.201372
has the agrarian tradition become such an addiction that the switch to urbanism is somehow dreaded or unwanted ? ?	43.73822
perhaps present writers hypnotically cling to the older order because they consider it useful and reliable through repeated testings over the decades .	220.82549
lacking the pioneer spirit necessary to write of a new economy , these writers seem to be contenting themselves with an old one that is now as defunct as confederate money .	69.30531
an example of the changes which have crept over the southern region may be seen in the southern negro ' s quest for a position in the white-dominated society , a problem that has been reflected in regional fiction especially since 1865 .	56.63333
today the negro must discover his role in an industrialized south , which indicates that the racial aspect of the southern dilemma hasn ' t changed radically , but rather has gradually come to be reflected in this new context , this new coat of paint .	78.89285
the negro faces as much , if not more , difficulty in fitting himself into an urban economy as he did in an agrarian one .	153.17073
this represents a gradual change in an ever-present social problem .	91.90569
but there have been abrupt changes as well the sit-ins , the picket lines , the bus strikes -- all of these were unheard-of even ten years ago .	62.045662
today ' s evidence , such as the fact that only three southern states ( south carolina , alabama and mississippi ) still openly defy integration , would have astounded many of yesterday ' s southerners into speechlessness .	86.97402
other examples of gradual changes that have affected the negro have been his moving up , row by row , in the buses	150.66087
his requesting , and often getting , higher wages , better working conditions , better schools -- changes that were slowly emerging even before the supreme court decision of 1954 .	127.786674
then came this decision , which sped the process of gaining equality ( or perhaps hindered it	144.66725
only historical evolution will determine which ) an abrupt change .	23.106228
since 1954 the negro ' s desire for social justice has led to an ironically anarchical rebellion .	67.35696
he has frequently refused to move from white lunch counters , refused to obey local laws which he considers unjust , while in other cases he has appealed to federal laws .	78.82558
this bold self-assertion , after decades of humble subservience , is indeed a twentieth-century phenomenon , an abrupt change in the southern way of existence .	38.381413
a new order is thrusting itself into being .	108.50385
a new south is emerging after the post-bellum years of hesitation , uncertainty , and lack of action from the negro in defining his new role in the amorphously defined socio-political organizations of the white man .	81.81596
the modern negro has not made a decisive debut into southern fiction .	82.94261
it is clear that , while most writers enjoy picturing the negro as a woolly-headed , humble old agrarian who mutters `` yassuhs ' ' and `` sho ' nufs ' ' with blissful deference to his white employer ( or , in old south terms , `` massuh ' ' ) , this stereotype is doomed to become in reality as obsolete as caldwell ' s lester .	51.069576
while there may still be many faulknerian lucas beauchamps scattered through the rural south , such men appear to be a vanishing breed .	58.782906
writers openly admit that the negro is easier to write than the white man	82.37139
but they obviously mean by this , not a negro personality , but a negro type .	119.9952
presenting an individualized negro character , it would seem , is one of the most difficult assignments a southern writer could tackle	111.17784
and the success of such an endeavor is , as suggested above , glaringly rare .	140.74785
just as the negro situation points up the gradual and abrupt changes affecting southern life , it also points up the non-representation of urbanism in southern literature .	127.04345
the book concerned with the negro ' s role in an urban society is rare indeed	70.54826
recently only keith wheeler ' s novel , peaceable lane , has openly faced the problem .	133.66933
all but the most rabid of confederate flag wavers admit that the old southern tradition is defunct in actuality and sigh that its passing was accompanied by the disappearance of many genteel and aristocratic traditions of the reputedly languid ante-bellum way of life .	53.133564
many earlier writers , mourning the demise of the old order , tended to romanticize and exaggerate this `` gracious old south ' ' imagery , creating such lasting impressions as margaret mitchell ' s `` tara ' ' plantation .	60.37168
modern writers , who are supposed to keep their fingers firmly upon the pulse of their subjects , insist upon drawing out this legend , prolonging its burial , when it well deserves a rest after the overexploitation of the past century .	101.14159
perhaps these writers have been too deeply moved by this romanticizing	81.57028
but they can hardly deny that , exaggerated or not , the old panorama is dead .	50.533875
as john t . westbrook says in his article , `` twilight of southern regionalism ' ' ( southwest review , winter 1957 ) `` the miasmal mausoleum where an old south , already too minutely autopsied in prose and poetry , should be left to rest in peace , forever dead and ( let us fervently hope ) forever done with ' ' .	75.451324
westbrook further bemoans the southern writers ' creation of an unreal image of their homeland , which is too readily assimilated by both foreign readers and visiting yankees `` our northerner is suspicious of all this crass evidence ( of urbanization ) presented to his senses .	152.21332
he is too deeply steeped in william faulkner and robert penn warren .	59.643837
the fumes of progress are in his nose and the bright steel of industry towers before his eyes , but his heart is away in yoknapatawpha county with razorback hogs and night riders .	55.927193
on this trip to the south he wants , above all else , to sniff the effluvium of backwoods-and-sand-hill subhumanity and to see at least one barn burn at midnight ' ' .	77.68825
obviously , such a northern tourist ' s purpose is somewhat akin to a child ' s experience with disneyland he wants to see a world of make-believe .	56.75845
in the meantime , while the south has been undergoing this phenomenal modernization that is so disappointing to the curious yankee , southern writers have certainly done little to reflect and promote their region ' s progress .	133.74036
willard thorp , in his new book , american writing in the twentieth century , observes , quite validly it seems `` certain subjects are conspicuously absent or have been only lightly touched .	81.08143
no southern novelist has done for atlanta or birmingham what herrick , dreiser , and farrell did for chicago or dos passos did for new york .	74.27363
there are almost no fictional treatments of the industrialized south ' ' .	43.695858
not a single southern author , major or minor , has made the urban problems of an urban south his primary source material .	168.2513
faulkner , for one , appears to be safe from the accusing fingers of all assailants in this regard .	201.86768
faulkner culminates the southern legend perhaps more masterfully than it has ever been , or could ever be , done .	61.065384
he has made it his , and his it remains , irrevocably .	284.51065
he treats it with a mythological , universal application .	171.28685
as his disciples boast , even though his emphasis is elsewhere , faulkner does show his awareness of the changing order of the south quite keenly , as can be proven by a quick recalling of his sartoris and snopes families .	102.95315
even two decades ago in go down , moses faulkner was looking to the more urban future with a glimmer of hope that through its youth and its new way of life the south might be reborn and the curse of slavery erased from its soil .	111.49064
yet his concern even here is with a slowly changing socio-economic order in general , and he never deals with such specific aspects of this change as the urban and industrial impact .	130.75969
faulkner traces , in his vast and overpowering saga of yoknapatawpha county , the gradual changes which seep into the south , building layer upon layer of minute , subtle innovation which eventually tend largely to hide the old way .	101.85905
thus faulkner reminds us , and wisely , that the `` new ' ' south has gradually evolved out of the old south , and consequently its agrarian roots persist .	58.701393
yet he presents a realm of source material which may well serve other writers if not himself the problems with which a new south must grapple in groping through a blind adolescence into the maturity of urbanization .	150.1694
with new mechanization the modern farmer must perform the work of six men a machine stands between the agrarian and his soil .	189.38393
the thousands of city migrants who desert the farms yearly must readjust with even greater stress and tension the sacred wilderness is gradually surrendering to suburbs and research parks and industrial areas .	141.29825
another element to concern the choreographer is that of the visual devices of the theatre .	60.990158
most avant-garde creators , true to their interest in the self-sufficiency of pure movement , have tended to dress their dancers in simple lines and solid colors ( often black ) and to give them a bare cyclorama for a setting .	81.7708
but robert rauschenberg , the neo-dadaist artist , has collaborated with several of them .	64.44278
he has designed a matching backdrop and costumes of points of color on white for mr . cunningham ' s summerspace , so that dancers and background merge into a shimmering unity .	90.70554
for mr . taylor ' s images and reflections she made some diaphanous tents that alternately hide and reveal the performer , and a girl ' s cape lined with grass .	170.25002
mr . nikolais has made a distinctive contribution to the arts of costume and decor .	20.233917
in fact , he calls his productions dance-theatre works of motion , shape , light , and sound .	91.22979
to raise the dancer out of his personal , pedestrian self , mr . nikolais has experimented with relating him to a larger , environmental orbit .	104.95859
he began with masks to make the dancer identify himself with the creature he appeared to be .	59.192017
he went on to use objects -- hoops , poles , capes -- which he employed as extensions of the body of the dancer , who moved with them .	67.70809
the depersonalization continued as the dancer was further metamorphosed by the play of lights upon his figure .	53.126408
in each case , the object , the color , even the percussive sounds of the electronic score were designed to become part of the theatrical being of the performer .	79.22909
the dancer who never loosens her hold on a parasol , begins to feel that it is part of herself .	78.79462
or , clad from head to toe in fabric stretched over a series of hoops , the performer may well lose his sense of self in being a `` finial ' ' .	56.235577
as the dancer is depersonalized , his accouterments are animized , and the combined elements give birth to a new being .	69.13559
from this being come new movement ideas that utilize dancer and property as a single unit .	173.27278
thus , the avant-garde choreographers have extended the scope of materials available for dance composition .	53.96973
but , since they have rejected both narrative and emotional continuity , how are they to unify the impressive array of materials at their disposal ? ?	55.82294
some look deliberately to devices used by creators in the other arts and apply corresponding methods to their own work .	78.62587
others , less consciously but quite probably influenced by the trends of the times , experiment with approaches that parallel those of the contemporary poet , painter , and musician .	105.506386
an approach that has appealed to some choreographers is reminiscent of charles olson ' s statement of the process of projective verse `` one perception must immediately and directly lead to a further perception ' ' .	82.3593
the creator trusts his intuition to lead him along a path that has internal validity because it mirrors the reality of his experience .	150.60153
he disdains external restrictions -- conventional syntax , traditional metre .	106.99931
the unit of form is determined subjectively `` the heart , by the way of the breath , to the line ' ' .	36.68671
the test of form is fidelity to the experience , a gauge also accepted by the abstract expressionist painters .	93.49064
an earlier but still influential school of painting , surrealism , had suggested the way of dealing with the dream experience , that event in which seemingly incongruous objects are linked together through the curious associations of the subconscious .	98.56624
the resulting picture might appear a maze of restless confusions and contradictions , but it is more true to life than a portrait of an artificially contrived order .	34.401627
the contemporary painter tends to depict not the concrete objects of his experience but their essences as revealed in abstractions of their lines , colors , masses , and energies .	100.133224
he is still concerned , however , with a personal event .	49.350784
he accepts the accidents of his brushwork because they provide evidence of the vitality of the experience of creation .	49.563908
the work must be true to both the physical and the spiritual character of the experience .	29.307203
some painters have less interest in the experience of the moment , with its attendant urgencies and ambiguities , than in looking beyond the flux of particular impressions to a higher , more serene level of truth .	77.28938
rather than putting their trust in ephemeral sensations they seek form in the stable relationships of pure design , which symbolize an order more real than the disorder of the perceptual world .	112.738434
but in this approach it is the artist ' s ultimate insight , rather than his immediate impressions , that gives form to the work .	45.45914
others look to more objective devices of order .	3.7107513
the musician employing the serial technique of composition establishes a mathematical system of rotations that , once set in motion , determines the sequence of pitches and even of rhythms and intensities .	79.03224
the composer may reverse or invert the order of his original set of intervals ( or rhythms or dynamic changes ) .	121.279526
he may even alter the pattern by applying a scheme of random numbers .	64.44392
but he cannot order his elements by will , either rational or inspired .	120.822556
musicians who use the chance method also exclude subjective control of formal development .	97.01959
again , the composer must select his own materials .	144.27025
but a tossing of coins , with perhaps the added safeguard of reference to the oracles of the i ching , the chinese book of changes , dictates the handling of the chosen materials .	95.55559
avant-garde choreographers , seeking new forms of continuity for their new vocabulary of movements , have turned to similar approaches .	144.70222
some let dances take their form from the experience of creation .	47.980114
according to katherine litz , `` the becoming , the process of realization , is the dance ' ' .	32.03193
the process stipulates that the choreographer sense the quality of the initial movement he has discovered and that he feel the rightness of the quality that is to follow it .	56.91526
the sequence may involve a sharp contrast for example , a quiet meditative sway of the body succeeded by a violent leap	54.825066
or it may involve more subtle distinctions the sway may be gradually minimized or enlarged , its rhythmic emphasis may be slightly modified , or it may be transferred to become a movement of only the arms or the head .	91.27052
even the least alteration will change the quality .	68.91819
