an exploration of these possible relationships constitutes the process of creation and thereby gives form to the dance .	65.243965
the approach to the depiction of the experience of creation may be analytic , as it is for miss litz , or spontaneous , as it is for merle marsicano .	47.79878
she , too , is concerned with `` the becoming , the process of realization ' ' , but she does not think in terms of subtle variations of spatial or temporal patterns .	49.396812
the design is determined emotionally `` i must reach into myself for the spring that will send me catapulting recklessly into the chaos of event with which the dance confronts me ' ' .	36.61609
looking back , miss marsicano feels that her ideas may have been influenced by those of jackson pollock .	84.96957
at one time she felt impelled to make dances that `` moved all over the stage ' ' , much as pollock ' s paintings move violently over the full extent of the canvas .	105.73762
but her conscious need was to break away from constricting patterns of form , a need to let the experience shape itself .	157.74417
midi garth also believes in subjective continuity that begins with the feeling engendered by an initial movement .	87.948364
it may be a free front-back swing of the leg , leading to a sideways swing of the arm that develops into a turn and the sensation of taking off from the ground .	82.70309
this became a dance called prelude to flight .	5.0857058
a pervading quality of free lyricism and a building from turns close to the ground towards jumps into the air gives the work its central focus .	137.66968
alwin nikolais objects to art as an outpouring of personal emotion .	45.37202
he seeks to make his dancers more `` godlike ' ' by relating them to the impersonal elements of shape , light , color , and sound .	27.72406
if his dancers are sometimes made to look as if they might be creatures from mars , this is consistent with his intention of placing them in the orbit of another world , a world in which they are freed of their pedestrian identities .	74.98266
it is through the metamorphosed dancer that the germ of form is discovered .	133.6093
in his recognition of his impersonal self the dancer moves , and this self , in the `` first revealed stroke of its existence ' ' , states the theme from which all else must follow .	102.11762
the theme may be the formation of a shape from which other shapes evolve .	191.5552
it may be a reaction to a percussive sound , the following movements constituting further reactions .	167.67241
it may establish the relation of the figure of the dancer to light and color , in which case changes in the light or color will set off a kaleidescope of visual designs .	71.744026
unconcerned with the practical function of his actions , the dancer is engrossed exclusively in their `` motional content ' ' .	30.428415
movements unfold freely because they are uninhibited by emotional bias or purposive drive .	165.54332
though he is also concerned with freeing dance from pedestrian modes of activity , merce cunningham has selected a very different method for achieving his aim .	179.4606
he rejects all subjectively motivated continuity , any line of action related to the concept of cause and effect .	74.480644
he bases his approach on the belief that anything can follow anything .	167.07193
an order can be chanced rather than chosen , and this approach produces an experience that is `` free and discovered rather than bound and remembered ' ' .	99.39109
thus , there is freshness not only in the individual movements of the dance but in the shape of their continuity as well .	57.959377
chance , he finds , enables him to create `` a world beyond imagination ' ' .	72.75124
he cites with pleasure the comment of a lady , who exclaimed after a concert `` why , it ' s extremely interesting .	69.29682
but i would never have thought of it myself ' ' .	14.570716
the sequence of movements in a cunningham dance is unlike any sequence to be seen in life .	91.06659
at one side of the stage a dancer jumps excitedly	77.80013
nearby , another sits motionless , while still another is twirling an umbrella .	171.89346
they look straight at the audience , not at each other .	45.38363
he lifts her , puts her down , and walks off , neither pleased nor disturbed , as if nothing had happened .	117.230774
if one dancer slaps another , the victim may do a pirouette , sit down , or offer his assailant a fork and spoon .	92.42929
their consequences are irrelevant -- or there are no consequences at all .	52.487675
the sequence is determined by chance , and mr . cunningham makes use of any one of several chance devices .	114.45393
he may take slips of paper from a grab bag .	28.513899
the answers derived by these means may determine not only the temporal organization of the dance but also its spatial design , special slips designating the location on the stage where the movement is to be performed .	62.968727
the other variables include the dancer who is to perform the movement and the length of time he is to take in its performance .	71.35197
the only factors that are personally set by the choreographer are the movements themselves , the number of the dancers , and the approximate total duration of the dance .	58.693333
the `` approximate ' ' is important , because even after the order of the work has been established by the chance method , the result is not inviolable .	46.42155
if a work is divided into several large segments , a last-minute drawing of random numbers may determine the order of the segments for any particular performance .	78.25543
and any sequence can not only change its positions in the work but can even be eliminated from it altogether .	131.16609
mr . cunningham tries not to cheat the chance method	670.3389
he adheres to its dictates as faithfully as he can .	44.68539
however , there is always the possibility that chance will make demands the dancers find impossible to execute .	386.0697
he must rearrange matters so that two performers do not bump into each other .	42.3472
he must construct transitions so that a dancer who is told to lie prone one second and to leap wildly the next will have some physical preparation for the leap .	160.43394
the north and the south were in greater agreement on sovereignty , through all their dispute about it , than were the founding fathers .	116.97827
the truth in their conflicting concepts was expounded by statesmen of the calibre of webster and calhoun , and defended in the end by leaders of the nobility of lincoln and lee .	73.561966
the people everywhere had grown meanwhile in devotion to basic democratic principles , in understanding of and belief in the federal balance , and in love of their union .	86.9995
repeated efforts -- beginning with the missouri compromise of 1821 -- were made by such master moderates as clay and douglas to resolve the difference peacefully by compromise , rather than clear thought and timely action .	153.04962
even so , confusion in this period gained such strength ( from compromise and other factors ) that it led to the bloodiest war of the nineteenth century .	54.960445
nothing can show more than this the immensity of the danger to democratic peoples that lies in even relatively slight deviation from their true concept of sovereignty .	142.07541
the present issue in atlantica -- whether to transform an alliance of sovereign nations into a federal union of sovereign citizens -- resembles the american one of 1787-89 rather than the one that was resolved by civil war .	62.108467
and so i would only touch upon it now ( much as i have long wanted to write a book about it ) .	80.79286
i think it is essential , however , to pinpoint here the difference between the two concepts of sovereignty that went to war in 1861 -- if only to see better how imperative is our need today to clarify completely our far worse confusion on this subject .	132.9138
the difference came down to this the southern states insisted that the united states was , in last analysis , what its name implied -- a union of states .	99.0434
to their leaders the constitution was a compact made by the people of sovereign states , who therefore retained the right to secede from it .	38.43386
this right of the state , its upholders contended , was essential to maintain the federal balance and protect the liberty of the people from the danger of centralizing power in the union government .	37.23476
the champions of the union maintained that the constitution had formed , fundamentally , the united people of america , that it was a compact among sovereign citizens rather than states , and that therefore the states had no right to secede , though the citizens could .	67.458885
writing to speed on august 24 , 1855 , lincoln made the latter point clear .	182.99046
in homely terms whose timeliness is startling today , he thus declared his own right to secede .	55.150406
we began by declaring that all men are created equal .	93.72127
we now practically read it , all men are created equal except negroes .	114.96584
when the know-nothings get control , it will read , all men are created equal except negroes and foreigners and catholics .	156.8167
when it comes to this , i shall prefer emigrating to some country where they make no pretence of loving liberty -- to russia , for instance , where despotism can be taken pure , without the base alloy of hypocrisy ' ' ( his emphasis )	83.27681
when the southern states exercised their `` right to secede ' ' , they formed what they officially styled `` the confederate states of america ' ' .	27.952665
dictionaries , as we have seen , still cite this government , along with the articles of confederation of 1781 , as an example of a confederacy .	53.78601
the fact is that the southern confederacy differed from the earlier one almost as much as the federal constitution did .	88.47131
the confederate constitution copied much of the federal constitution verbatim , and most of the rest in substance .	39.05877
it operated on , by and for the people individually just as did the federal constitution .	260.50424
it made substantially the same division of power between the central and state governments , and among the executive , legislative and judicial branches .	67.82642
the difference between confederacy and federal union in 1861	694.6555
many believe -- and understandably -- that the great difference between the constitution of the southern confederacy and the federal constitution was that the former recognized the right of each state to secede .	41.227413
but though each of its members had asserted this right against the union , the final constitution which the confederacy signed on march 11 -- nearly a month before hostilities began -- included no explicit provision authorizing a state to secede .	108.57849
its drafters discussed this vital point but left it out of their constitution .	80.06553
their president , jefferson davis , interpreted their constitution to mean that it `` admits of no coerced association ' ' , but this remained so doubtful that `` there were frequent demands that the right to secede be put into the constitution ' ' .	57.586735
the constitution of the southern `` confederation ' ' differed from that of the federal union only in two important respects it openly , defiantly , recognized slavery -- an institution which the southerners of 1787 , even though they continued it , found so impossible to reconcile with freedom that they carefully avoided mentioning the word in the federal constitution .	107.34759
they recognized that slavery was a moral issue and not merely an economic interest , and that to recognize it explicitly in their constitution would be in explosive contradiction to the concept of sovereignty they had set forth in the declaration of 1776 that `` all men are created equal , that they are endowed by their creator with certain unalienable rights , that among them are life , liberty and the pursuit of happiness .	57.945675
' ' the other important difference between the two constitutions was that the president of the confederacy held office for six ( instead of four ) years , and was limited to one term .	106.50728
these are not , however , differences in federal structure .	207.59338
the only important differences from that standpoint , between the two constitutions , lies in their preambles .	45.323982
the one of 1861 made clear that in making their government the people were acting through their states , whereas the preamble of 1787-89 expressed , as clearly as language can , the opposite concept , that they were acting directly as citizens .	118.43575
here are the two preambles federal constitution , 1789	1971.0549
`` we the people of the united states , in order to form a more perfect union , establish justice , insure domestic tranquility , provide for the common defence , promote the general welfare , and secure the blessings of liberty to ourselves and our posterity , do ordain and establish this constitution for the united states of america ' ' .	45.026737
`` we the people of the confederate states , each state acting in its sovereign and independent character , in order to form a permanent federal government , establish justice , insure domestic tranquility , and secure the blessings of liberty to ourselves and our posterity -- invoking the favor and the guidance of almighty god -- do ordain and establish this constitution for the confederate states of america ' ' .	65.113335
one is tempted to say that , on the difference between the concepts of sovereignty in these two preambles , the worst war of the nineteenth century was fought .	29.927675
but though the southern states , when drafting a constitution to unite themselves , narrowed the difference to this fine point by omitting to assert the right to secede , the fact remained that by seceding from the union they had already acted on the concept that it was composed primarily of sovereign states .	88.4544
if the union conceded this to them , the same right must be conceded to each remaining state whenever it saw fit to secede this would destroy the federal balance between it and the states , and in the end sacrifice to the sovereignty of the states all the liberty the citizens had gained by their union .	141.47981
lincoln saw that the act of secession made the issue for the union a vital one whether it was a union of sovereign citizens that should continue to live , or an association of sovereign states that must fall prey either to `` anarchy or despotism ' ' .	75.032486
much as he abhorred slavery , lincoln was always willing to concede to each `` slave state ' ' the right to decide independently whether to continue or end it .	81.816475
though his election was interpreted by many southerners as the forerunner of a dangerous shift in the federal balance in favor of the union , lincoln himself proposed no such change in the rights the constitution gave the states .	86.84609
after the war began , he long refused to permit emancipation of the slaves by union action even in the border states that stayed with the union .	85.47289
he issued his emancipation proclamation only when he felt that necessity left him no other way to save the union .	125.26697
in his message of december 2 , 1862 , he put his purpose and his policy in these words -- which i would call the lincoln law of liberty-and-union `` in giving freedom to the slave , we assure freedom to the free ' ' .	76.17011
what lincoln could not concede was that the states rather than the people were sovereign in the union .	60.288055
he fought to the end to preserve it as a `` government of the people , by the people , for the people ' ' .	22.857775
the truth on each side won in the civil war	101.06574
the fact that the americans who upheld the sovereignty of their states did this in order to keep many of their people more securely in slavery -- the antithesis of individual liberty -- made the conflict grimmer , and the greater .	105.31127
out of this ordeal the citizen emerged , in the south as in the north , as america ' s true sovereign , in `` a new birth of freedom ' ' , as lincoln promised .	49.364964
but before this came about , 214 , 938 americans had given their lives in battle for the two concepts of the sovereign rights of men and of states .	64.756546
on their decisive battlefield lincoln did not distinguish between them when he paid tribute to the `` brave men , living and dead , who fought here ' ' .	54.48472
he understood that both sides were at fault , and he reached the height of saying so explicitly in his second inaugural .	72.05266
to my knowledge , lincoln remains the only head of state and commander-in-chief who , while fighting a fearful war whose issue was in doubt , proved man enough to say this publicly -- to give his foe the benefit of the fact that in all human truth there is some error , and in all our error , some truth .	150.48158
so great a man could not but understand , too , that the thing that moves men to sacrifice their lives is not the error of their thought , which their opponents see and attack , but the truth which the latter do not see -- any more than they see the error which mars the truth they themselves defend .	107.9569
it is much less difficult now than in lincoln ' s day to see that on both sides sovereign americans had given their lives in the civil war to maintain the balance between the powers they had delegated to the states and to their union .	60.149994
they differed in the balance they believed essential to the sovereignty of the citizen -- but the supreme sacrifice each made served to maintain a still more fundamental truth that individual life , liberty and happiness depend on a right balance between the two -- and on the limitation of sovereignty , in all its aspects , which this involves .	92.11382
the 140 , 414 americans who gave `` the last full measure of devotion ' ' to prevent disunion , preserved individual freedom in the united states from the dangers of anarchy , inherent in confederations , which throughout history have proved fatal in the end to all associations composed primarily of sovereign states , and to the liberties of their people .	76.941086
but the fact that 70 , 524 other americans gave the same measure of devotion to an opposing concept served liberty-and-union in other essential ways .	125.65697
its appeal from ballots to bullets at fort sumter ended by costing the southerners their right to have slaves -- a right that was even less compatible with the sovereignty of man .	121.64836
the very fact that they came so near to winning by the wrong method , war , led directly to their losing both the war and the wrong thing they fought for , since it forced lincoln to free their slaves as a military measure .	209.2942
there was a divine justice in one wrong thus undoing another .	246.69
there was also a lesson , one that has served ever since to keep americans , in their conflicts with one another , from turning from the ballot to the bullet .	87.023605
yet though the southern states lost the worst errors in their case , they did not lose the truth they fought for .	45.685894
the lives so many of them gave , to forestall what they believed would be a fatal encroachment by the union on the powers reserved to their states have continued ever since to safeguard all americans against freedom ' s other foe .	122.90133
as cells coalesced into organisms , they built new `` unnatural ' ' and internally controlled environments to cope even more successfully with the entropy-increasing properties of the external world .	49.48483
the useful suggestion of professor david hawkins which considers culture as a third stage in biological evolution fits quite beautifully then with our suggestion that science has provided us with a rather successful technique for building protective artificial environments .	183.97263
will advances in human sciences help us build social structures and governments which will enable us to cope with people as effectively as the primitive combination of protein and nucleic acid built a structure of molecules which enabled it to adapt to a sea of molecular interaction ? ?	68.73044
the answer is , of course , yes .	6.122558
for the family is the simplest example of just such a unit , composed of people , which gives us both some immunity from , and a way of dealing with , other people .	133.97678
social invention did not have to await social theory any more than use of the warmth of a fire had to await lavoisier or the buoyant protection of a boat the formulations of archimedes .	68.46036
but it has been during the last two centuries , during the scientific revolution , that our independence from the physical environment has made the most rapid strides .	62.23892
the temperature of our homes is independent of the seasons	134.60342
we fly through the air , although gravity pulls us down	345.14484
at what stage are social sciences then ? ?	1.0538232
is the future of psychology akin to the rich future of physics at the time of newton ? ?	64.864456
there is a haunting resemblance between the notion of cause in copernicus and in freud .	65.43598
and it is certainly no slight to either of them to compare both their achievements and their impact .	95.22041
political theoretical understanding , although almost at a standstill during this century , did develop during the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries , and resulted in a flood of inventions which increased the possibility for man to coexist with man .	65.646996
consitutional government , popular vote , trial by jury , public education , labor unions , cooperatives , communes , socialized ownership , world courts , and the veto power in world councils are but a few examples .	79.66531
most of these , with horrible exceptions , were conceived as is a ship , not as an attempt to quell the ocean of mankind , nor to deny its force , but as a means to survive and enjoy it .	75.65694
the most effective political inventions seem to make maximum use of natural harbors and are aware that restraining breakwaters can play only a minor part in the whole scheme .	75.34681
just as present technology had to await the explanations of physics , so one might expect that social invention will follow growing sociological understanding .	121.135216
we are desperately in the need of such invention , for man is still very much at the mercy of man .	51.214745
in fact the accumulation of the hardware of destruction is day by day increasing our fear of each other .	293.11566
i want , therefore , to discuss a second and quite different fruit of science , the connection between scientific understanding and fear .	91.40836
there are certainly large areas of understanding in the human sciences which in themselves and even without political invention can help to dispel our present fears .	91.527695
lucretius has remarked `` the reason why all mortals are so gripped by fear is that they see all sorts of things happening in the earth and sky with no discernable cause , and these they attribute to the will of god ' ' .	86.867004
it is difficult to reconstruct the primeval fears of man .	9.592511
we get some clue from a few remembrances of childhood and from the circumstance that we are probably not much more afraid of people now than man ever was .	87.803
we are not now afraid of atomic bombs in the same way that people once feared comets .	96.32161
the bombs are as harmless as an automobile in a garage .	37.17296
we are worried about what people may do with them -- that some crazy fool may `` push the button ' ' .	56.347454
i am certainly not adequately trained to describe or enlarge on human fears , but there are certain features of the fears dispelled by scientific explanations that stand out quite clearly .	93.48805
they are in general those fears that once seemed to have been amenable to prayer or ritual .	56.257275
they include both individual fears and collective ones .	3.274984
they arise in situations in which one believes that what happens depends not only on the external world , but also on the precise pattern of behavior of the individual or group .	48.77345
often it is recognized that all the details of the pattern may not be essential to the outcome but , because the pattern was empirically determined and not developed through theoretical understanding , one is never quite certain which behavior elements are effective , and the whole pattern becomes ritualized .	84.965515
yet often fear persists because , even with the most rigid ritual , one is never quite free from the uneasy feeling that one might make some mistake or that in every previous execution one had been unaware of the really decisive act .	119.887276
to say that science had reduced many such fears merely reiterates the obvious and frequent statement that science eliminated much of magic and superstition .	178.57112
but a somewhat more detailed analysis of this process may be illuminating .	103.92229
the frequently postulated antique worry that the daylight hours might dwindle to complete darkness apparently gave rise to a ritual and celebration which we still recognize .	250.1554
it is curious that even centuries of repetition of the yearly cycle did not induce a sufficient degree of confidence to allow people to abandon the ceremonies of the winter solstice .	63.69625
this and other fears of the solar system have disappeared gradually , first , with the ptolemaic system and its built-in concept of periodicity and then , more firmly , with the newtonian innovation of an universal force that could account quantitatively for both terrestial and celestial motions .	80.7326
this understanding provides a very simple example of the fact that one can eliminate fear without instituting any controls .	71.985825
in fact , although we have dispelled the fear , we have not necessarily assured ourselves that there are no dangers .	53.56507
there is still the remote possibility of planetoid collision .	27.902473
solar activities could presumably bring long periods of flood or drought .	46.487362
our understanding of the solar system has taught us to replace our former elaborate rituals with the appropriate action which , in this case , amounts to doing nothing .	79.67087
this almost trivial example is nevertheless suggestive , for there are some elements in common between the antique fear that the days would get shorter and shorter and our present fear of war .	138.8037
we , in our country , think of war as an external threat which , if it occurs , will not be primarily of our own doing .	80.666794
and yet we obviously also believe that the avoidance of the disaster depends in some obscure or at least uncertain way on the details of how we behave .	128.64671
what elements of our behavior are decisive ? ?	1.0144053
our weapons production , our world prestige , our ideas of democracy , our actions of trust or stubbornness or secrecy or espionage ? ?	80.40957
we have staved off a war and , since our behavior has involved all these elements , we can only keep adding to our ritual without daring to abandon any part of it , since we have not the slightest notion which parts are effective .	110.4723
i think that we are here also talking of the kind of fear that a young boy has for a group of boys who are approaching at night along the streets of a large city .	44.761417
if an automobile were approaching him , he would know what was required of him , even though he might not be able to act quickly enough .	34.55836
with the group of boys it is different .	3.3670294
he does not know whether to look up or look aside , to put his hands in his pockets or to clench them at his side , to cross the street , or to continue on the same side .	49.561813
when confronted with a drunk or an insane person i have no notion of what any one of them might do to me or to himself or to others .	66.0102
i believe that what i do has some effect on his actions and i have learned , in a way , to commune with drunks , but certainly my actions seem to resemble more nearly the performance of a rain dance than the carrying out of an experiment in physics .	108.00763
i am usually filled with an uneasiness that through some unwitting slip all hell may break loose .	346.60394
our inability to explain why certain people are fond of us frequently induces the same kind of ritual and malaise .	73.74153
we are forced , in our behavior towards others , to adopt empirically successful patterns in toto because we have such a minimal understanding of their essential elements .	131.91054
our collective policies , group and national , are similarly based on voodoo , but here we often lack even the empirically successful rituals and are still engaged in determing them .	183.71797
we use terms from our personal experience with individuals such as `` trust ' ' , `` cheat ' ' , and `` get tough ' ' .	24.296026
we talk about national character in the same way that copernicus talked of the compulsions of celestial bodies to move in circles .	98.58349
we perform elaborate international exhortations and ceremonies with virtually no understanding of social cause and effect .	98.220505
small wonder , then , that we fear .	31.99939
the achievements which dispelled our fears of the cosmos took place three centuries ago .	101.26802
what additional roles has the scientific understanding of the 19th and 20th centuries played ? ?	89.53921
in the physical sciences , these achievements concern electricity , chemistry , and atomic physics .	29.428806
in the life sciences , there has been an enormous increase in our understanding of disease , in the mechanisms of heredity , and in bio- and physiological chemistry .	31.332396
the major effect of these advances appears to lie in the part they have played in the industrial revolution and in the tools which scientific understanding has given us to build and manipulate a more protective environment .	108.75295
in addition , our way of dealing directly with natural phenomena has also changed .	95.21491
even in domains where detailed and predictive understanding is still lacking , but where some explanations are possible , as with lightning and weather and earthquakes , the appropriate kind of human action has been more adequately indicated .	89.17323
apparently the population as a whole eventually acquires enough confidence in the explanations of the scientists to modify its procedures and its fears .	68.85818
how and why this process occurs would provide an interesting separate subject for study .	79.738014
in some areas , the progress is slower than in others .	49.962997
in agriculture , for example , despite the advances in biology , elaborate rituals tend to persist along with a continued sense of the imminence of some natural disaster .	68.87532
procedures change rapidly and parental confidence probably exceeds anything warranted by established psychological theory .	222.8058
there are many domains in which understanding has brought about widespread and quite appropriate reduction in ritual and fear .	234.801
much of the former extreme uneasiness associated with visions and hallucinations and with death has disappeared .	76.67866
the persistent horror of having a malformed child has , i believe , been reduced , not because we have gained any control over this misfortune , but precisely because we have learned that we have so little control over it .	77.10103
in fact , the recent warnings about the use of x-rays have introduced fears and ambiguities of action which now require more detailed understanding , and thus in this instance , science has momentarily aggravated our fears .	107.6396
in fact , insofar as science generates any fear , it stems not so much from scientific prowess and gadgets but from the fact that new unanswered questions arise , which , until they are understood , create uncertainty .	153.65231
perhaps the most illuminating example of the reduction of fear through understanding is derived from our increased knowledge of the nature of disease .	117.8923
the situation with regard to our attitude and `` control ' ' of disease contains close analogies to problems confronting us with respect to people .	115.08382
the fear of disease was formerly very much the kind of fear i have tried to describe .	49.735966
nothing like godot , he arrived before the hour .	79.68313
his letter had suggested we meet at my hotel at noon on sunday , and i came into the lobby as the clock struck twelve .	72.4324
my wish to meet samuel beckett had been prompted by simple curiosity and interest in his work .	92.75093
american newspaper reviewers like to call his plays nihilistic .	5.1798277
even so astute a commentator as harold clurman of the nation has said that `` waiting for godot ' ' is `` the concentrate of the contemporary european mood of despair ' ' .	32.667168
but to me beckett ' s writing had seemed permeated with love for human beings and with a kind of humor that i could reconcile neither with despair nor with nihilism .	91.43962
could it be that my own eyes and ears had deceived me ? ?	101.73847
is his a literature of defeat , irrelevant to the social crises we face ? ?	67.3959
or is it relevant because it teaches us something useful to know about ourselves ? ?	57.01748
i knew that a conversation with the author would not settle such questions , because a man is not the same as his writing in the last analysis , the questions had to be settled by the work itself .	68.20312
my curiosity was sharpened a day or two before the interview by a conversation i had with a well-informed teacher of literature , a jesuit father , at a conference on religious drama near paris .	73.32533
when beckett ' s name came into the discussion , the priest grew loud and told me that beckett `` hates life ' ' .	88.437195
that , i thought , is at least one thing i can find out when we meet .	42.397415
the features of his face are distinct , but not fine .	42.61631
they look as if they had been sculptured with an unsharpened chisel .	22.123129
unruly hair goes straight up from his forehead , standing so high that the top falls gently over , as if to show that it really is hair and not bristle .	148.65396
for he has the pride that comes of self-acceptance and the humility , perhaps of the same genesis , not to impose himself upon another .	70.11571
his light blue eyes , set deep within the face , are actively and continually looking .	117.92536
he seems , by some unconscious division of labor , to have given them that one function and no other , leaving communication to the rest of the face .	103.69009
the mouth frequently breaks into a disarming smile .	3.4681542
the voice is light in timbre , with a rough edge that corresponds to his visage .	115.48583
the irish accent is , as one would expect , combined with slight inflections from the french .	59.24968
his tweed suit was a baggy gray and green .	120.90802
he wore a brown knit sports shirt with no tie .	156.20839
we walked down the rue de l ' arcade , thence along beside the madeleine and across to a sidewalk cafe opposite that church .	74.91136
the conversation that ensued may have been engrossing but it could hardly be called world-shattering .	41.242794
for one thing , the world that beckett sees is already shattered .	134.43523
his talk turns to what he calls `` the mess ' ' , or sometimes `` this buzzing confusion ' ' .	30.556688
i reconstruct his sentences from notes made immediately after our conversation .	110.58098
what appears here is shorter than what he actually said but very close to his own words .	100.193115
we cannot listen to a conversation for five minutes without being acutely aware of the confusion .	38.545597
it is all around us and our only chance now is to let it in .	126.492775
the only chance of renovation is to open our eyes and see the mess .	43.452812
it is not a mess you can make sense of ' ' .	21.42586
i suggested that one must let it in because it is the truth , but beckett did not take to the word truth .	55.216503
`` what is more true than anything else ? ?	6.53392
to swim is true , and to sink is true .	144.5243
one is not more true than the other .	11.489038
one cannot speak anymore of being , one must speak only of the mess .	43.31542
when heidegger and sartre speak of a contrast between being and existence , they may be right , i don ' t know , but their language is too philosophical for me .	65.54181
one can only speak of what is in front of him , and that now is simply the mess ' ' .	39.77881
then he began to speak about the tension in art between the mess and form .	144.00674
until recently , art has withstood the pressure of chaotic things .	41.619816
it realized that to admit them was to jeopardize form .	426.0011
`` how could the mess be admitted , because it appears to be the very opposite of form and therefore destructive of the very thing that art holds itself to be ' ' ? ?	67.99228
but now we can keep it out no longer , because we have come into a time when `` it invades our experience at every moment .	60.36607
it is there and it must be allowed in ' ' .	32.8044
i granted this might be so , but found the result to be even more attention to form than was the case previously .	154.10098
how , i asked , could chaos be admitted to chaos ? ?	161.54489
would not that be the end of thinking and the end of art ? ?	36.44133
if we look at recent art we find it preoccupied with form .	106.00002
beckett ' s own work is an example .	38.993156
plays more highly formalized than `` waiting for godot ' ' , `` endgame ' ' , and `` krapp ' s last tape ' ' would be hard to find .	15.236663
`` what i am saying does not mean that there will henceforth be no form in art .	60.672737
it only means that there will be new form , and that this form will be of such a type that it admits the chaos and does not try to say that the chaos is really something else .	61.241684
the latter is not reduced to the former .	34.20022
that is why the form itself becomes a preoccupation , because it exists as a problem separate from the material it accommodates .	106.77068
to find a form that accommodates the mess , that is the task of the artist now ' ' .	28.150219
yet , i responded , could not similar things be said about the art of the past ? ?	47.238155
is it not characteristic of the greatest art that it confronts us with something we cannot clarify , demanding that the viewer respond to it in his own never-predictable way ? ?	65.45792
what is the history of criticism but the history of men attempting to make sense of the manifold elements in art that will not allow themselves to be reduced to a single philosophy or a single aesthetic theory ? ?	81.35259
`` not this ' ' , he said , and gestured toward the madeleine .	34.806576
the classical lines of the church which napoleon thought of as a temple of glory , dominated all the scene where we sat .	105.47072
the boulevard de la madeleine , the boulevard malesherbes , and the rue royale ran to it with graceful flattery , bearing tidings of the age of reason .	29.420723
this does not allow the mystery to invade us .	29.417112
there is the unexplainable , and there art raises questions that it does not attempt to answer ' ' .	49.359386
i asked about the battle between life and death in his plays .	43.743008
didi and gogo hover on the edge of suicide	2818.21
hamm ' s world is death and clov may or may not get out of it to join the living child outside .	163.36818
is this life-death question a part of the chaos ? ?	58.341114
if life and death did not both present themselves to us , there would be no inscrutability .	53.138596
if there were only darkness , all would be clear .	16.430475
it is because there is not only darkness but also light that our situation becomes inexplicable .	152.79128
take augustine ' s doctrine of grace given and grace withheld have you pondered the dramatic qualities in this theology ? ?	166.25868
two thieves are crucified with christ , one saved and the other damned .	69.46495
how can we make sense of this division ? ?	4.250607
in classical drama , such problems do not arise .	74.32156
the destiny of racine ' s phedre is sealed from the beginning she will proceed into the dark .	72.20698
as she goes , she herself will be illuminated .	107.02738
at the beginning of the play she has partial illumination and at the end she has complete illumination , but there has been no question but that she moves toward the dark .	64.57056
within this notion clarity is possible , but for us who are neither greek nor jansenist there is not such clarity .	86.809616
the question would also be removed if we believed in the contrary -- total salvation .	333.12253
but where we have both dark and light we have also the inexplicable .	220.32462
the key word in my plays is ' perhaps ' ' ' .	32.389927
given a theological lead , i asked what he thinks about those who find a religious significance to his plays .	53.301514
`` well , really there is none at all .	10.950765
he knelt down at his bed as long as he could kneel .	15.5119505
the family was protestant , but for me it was only irksome and i let it go .	76.56708
my brother and mother got no value from their religion when they died .	252.17065
at the moment of crisis it had no more depth than an old school tie .	124.20527
irish catholicism is not attractive , but it is deeper .	36.748333
when you pass a church on an irish bus , all the hands flurry in the sign of the cross .	37.94614
one day the dogs of ireland will do that too and perhaps also the pigs ' ' .	134.67622
but do the plays deal with the same facets of experience religion must also deal with ? ?	164.21072
`` yes , for they deal with distress .	8.935408
some people object to this in my writing .	4.0143743
at a party an english intellectual -- so-called -- asked me why i write always about distress .	234.52594
as if it were perverse to do so ! !	42.27361
he wanted to know if my father had beaten me or my mother had run away from home to give me an unhappy childhood .	80.55221
i told him no , that i had had a very happy childhood .	78.19582
then he thought me more perverse than ever .	17.069983
i left the party as soon as possible and got into a taxi .	95.686035
on the glass partition between me and the driver were three signs one asked for help for the blind , another help for orphans , and the third for relief for the war refugees .	162.93997
one does not have to look for distress .	4.136879
it is screaming at you even in the taxis of london ' ' .	36.763
lunch was over , and we walked back to the hotel with the light and dark of paris screaming at us .	37.9693
the personal quality of samuel beckett is similar to qualities i had found in the plays .	103.26732
he says nothing that compresses experience within a closed pattern .	141.82233
`` perhaps ' ' stands in place of commitment .	252.4824
at the same time , he is plainly sympathetic , clearly friendly .	297.23975
if there were only the mess , all would be clear	88.84643
as a christian , i know i do not stand where beckett stands , but i do see much of what he sees .	76.84898
as a writer on the theater , i have paid close attention to the plays .	71.10782
harold clurman is right to say that `` waiting for godot ' ' is a reflection ( he calls it a distorted reflection ) `` of the impasse and disarray of europe ' s present politics , ethic , and common way of life ' ' .	42.508217
yet it is not only europe the play refers to .	83.349
`` waiting for godot ' ' sells even better in america than in france .	131.1377
the consciousness it mirrors may have come earlier to europe than to america , but it is the consciousness that most `` mature ' ' societies arrive at when their successes in technological and economic systematization propel them into a time of examining the not-strictly-practical ends of culture .	75.76473
america is now joining europe in this `` mature ' ' phase of development .	44.099014
whether any of us remain in it long will depend on what happens as a result of the technological and economic revolutions now going on in the countries of asia and africa , and also of course on how long the cold war remains cold .	57.916473
even hemingway , for all his efforts to formulate a naturalistic morality in the sun also rises and a farewell to arms never maintained that sex was all .	211.82674
hemingway ' s fiction is supported by a `` moral ' ' backbone and in its search for ultimate meaning hints at a religious dimension .	73.28646
and d . h . lawrence , in fantasia of the unconscious , protested vehemently against the overestimation of the sexual motive .	58.13132
though sex in some form or other enters into all human activity and it was a good thing that freud emphasized this aspect of human nature , it is fantastic to explain everything in terms of sex .	81.694954
`` all is not sex ' ' , declared lawrence .	366.0272
man is not confined to one outlet for his vital energy .	120.452614
the creative urge , for example , transcends the body and the self .	54.11632
but for the beat generation all is sex .	4.179151
nothing is more revealing of the way of life and literary aspirations of this group than their attitude toward sex .	79.15232
for the beatnik , like the hipster , is in opposition to a society that is based on the repression of the sex instinct .	48.725597
he has elevated sex -- not eros or libido but pure , spontaneous , uninhibited sex -- to the rank of the godhead	72.01892
it is astarte , ishtar , venus , yahwe , dionysus , christ , the mysterious and divine orgone energy flowing through the body of the universe .	27.225729
jazz is sex , marijuana is a stimulus to sex , the beat tempo is adjusted to the orgiastic release of the sexual impulse .	41.222546
lawrence lipton , in the holy barbarians , stresses that for the beat generation sex is more than a source of pleasure	53.004143
it is a mystique , and their private language is rich in the multivalent ambiguities of sexual reference so that they dwell in a sexualized universe of discourse .	90.72331
the singular uncompromising force of their revolt against the cult of restraint is illustrated by their refusal to dance in a public place .	89.65947
the dance is but a disguised ritual for the expression of ungratified sexual desire .	84.95227
for this reason , too , their language is more forthright and earthy .	30.398903
the beatniks crave a sexual experience in which their whole being participates .	272.7611
it is therefore not surprising that they resist the lure of marriage and the trap of domesticity , for like cats they are determined not to tame their sexual energy .	95.13036
they withdraw to the underground of the slums where they can defy the precepts of legalized propriety .	31.215658
unlike the heroes and flappers of the lost generation , they disdain the art of `` necking ' ' and `` petting ' ' .	20.661724
if they avoid the use of the pungent , outlawed four-letter word it is because it is taboo	32.670395
as lipton , the prophet of the beat generation , declares `` in the sexual act , the beat are filled with mana , the divine power .	61.759163
this is far from the vulgar , leering sexuality of the middle-class square in heat ' ' .	96.39067
this is the holy grail these knights of the orgasm pursue , this is the irresistible cosmic urge to which they respond .	70.12664
if wilhelm reich is the moses who has led them out of the egypt of sexual slavery , dylan thomas is the poet who offers them the dionysian dialectic of justification for their indulgence in liquor , marijuana , sex , and jazz .	72.78619
in addition , they have been converted to zen buddhism , with its glorification of all that is `` natural ' ' and mysteriously alive , the sense that everything in the world is flowing .	41.662895
thus , paradoxically , the beat writers resort to `` religious ' ' metaphors they are in search of mana , the spiritual , the numinous , but not anything connected with formal religion .	104.37032
what they are after is the beatific vision .	13.046551
and zen buddhism , though it is extremely difficult to understand how these internal contradictions are reconciled , helps them in their struggle to achieve personal salvation through sexual release .	78.99807
the style of life chosen by the beat generation , the rhythm and ritual they have adopted as uniquely their own , is designed to enhance the value of the sexual experience .	60.48567
jazz is good not only because it promotes wholeness but because of its decided sexual effect .	199.55847
jazz is the musical language of sex , the vocabulary of the orgasm	37.8589
indeed , it is maintained that the sexual element in jazz , by freeing the listener of his inhibitions , can have therapeutic value .	99.72697
that is why , the argument runs , the squares are so fearful of jazz and yet perversely fascinated by it .	132.50224
instead of giving themselves spontaneously to the orgiastic release that jazz can give them , they undergo psychoanalysis or flirt with mysticism or turn to prostitutes for satisfaction .	94.697556
thus jazz is transmuted into something holy , the sacred road to integration of being .	252.52718
jazz , like sex , is a mystique .	38.03291
it is not a substitute for sex but a dynamic expression of the creative impulse in unfettered man .	99.9765
the mystique of sex , combined with marijuana and jazz , is intended to provide a design for living .	59.18409
those who are sexually liberated can become creatively alive and free , their instincts put at the service of the imagination .	115.82495
righteous in their denunciation of all that makes for death , the beat prophets bid all men become cool cats	358.12778
let them learn to `` swing ' ' freely , to let go , to become authentically themselves , and then perhaps civilization will be saved .	151.51472
the beatnik , seceding from a society that is fatally afflicted with a deathward drive , is concerned with his personal salvation in the living present .	77.50595
if he is the child of nothingness , if he is the predestined victim of an age of atomic wars , then he will consult only his own organic needs and go beyond good and evil .	90.50295
he will not curb his instinctual desires but release the energy within him that makes him feel truly and fully alive , even if it is only for this brief moment before the apocalypse of annihilation explodes on earth .	115.17275
that is why the members of the beat generation proudly assume the title of the holy barbarians	31.830544
they will destroy the shrines , temples , museums , and churches of the state that is the implacable enemy of the life they believe in .	51.14534
apart from the categorical imperative they derive from the metaphysics of the orgasm , the only affirmation they are capable of making is that art is their only refuge .	49.603863
their writing , born of their experiments in marijuana and untrammeled sexuality , reflects the extremity of their existential alienation .	42.54681
the mind has betrayed them , reason is the foe of life	116.31598
they will trust only their physical sensations , the wisdom of the body , the holy promptings of the unconscious .	19.629658
with lyrical intensity they reveal what they hate , but their faith in love , inspired by the revolutionary rhythms of jazz , culminates in the climax of the orgasm .	29.33316
their work mirrors the mentality of the psychopath , rootless and irresponsible .	13.435717
their rebellion against authoritarian society is not far removed from the violence of revolt characteristic of the juvenile delinquent .	168.77803
and the life they lead is undisciplined and for the most part unproductive , even though they make a fetish of devoting themselves to some creative pursuit -- writing , painting , music .	83.82145
when they express themselves it is incandescent hatred that shines forth , the rage of repudiation , the ecstasy of negation .	66.81354
it is sex that obsesses them , sex that is at the basis of their aesthetic creed .	66.5298
what they discuss with dialectical seriousness is the degree to which sex can inspire the muse .	85.84323
monogamy is the vice from which the abjectly fearful middle class continue to suffer , whereas the beatnik has the courage to break out of that prison of respectability .	99.266945
one girl describes her past , her succession of broken marriages , the abortions she has had and finally confesses that she loves sex and sees no reason why she must justify her passion .	112.62453
if it is an honest feeling , then why should she not yield to it ? ?	147.56136
`` most often ' ' , she says , `` it ' s the monogamous relationship that is dishonest ' ' .	15.281109
this girl soon drops the bourgeois pyschiatrist who disapproves of her life .	19.238007
she finds married life stifling and every prolonged sex relationship unbearably monotonous .	14.911056
this confession serves to make clear in part what is behind this sexual revolution the craving for sensation for its own sake , the need for change , for new experiences .	114.8095
in the realm of physical sensations , sex reigns supreme .	66.73744
hence the beatniks sustain themselves on marijuana , jazz , free swinging poetry , exhausting themselves in orgies of sex	187.33325
some of them are driven over the borderline of sanity and lose contact with reality .	137.53287
one beat poet composes a poem , `` lines on a tijuana john ' ' , which contains a few happy hints for survival .	54.13968
the new fact the initiates of this cult have to learn is that they must move toward simplicity .	115.332184
the professed mission of this disaffiliated generation is to find a new way of life which they can express in poetry and fiction , but what they produce is unfortunately disordered , nourished solely on the hysteria of negation .	64.068275
who are the creative representatives of this movement ? ?	9.6940775
nymphomaniacs , junkies , homosexuals , drug addicts , lesbians , alcoholics , the weak , the frustrated , the irresolute , the despairing , the derelicts and outcasts of society .	47.80254
they embrace independent poverty , usually with a `` shack-up ' ' partner who will help support them .	66.57299
they are full of contempt for the institution of matrimony .	13.733705
their previous legalized marriages do not count , for they hold the laws of the state null and void .	65.16461
they feel they are leagued against a hostile , persecutory world , faced with the concerted malevolent opposition of squares and their hirelings , the police .	57.58514
this is the rhetoric of righteousness the beatniks use in defending their way of life , their search for wholeness , though their actual existence fails to reach these `` religious ' ' heights .	127.08682
one beatnik got the woman he was living with so involved in drugs and self-analysis and all-night sessions of sex that she was beginning to crack up .	79.8232
what obsessions had she picked up during these long nights of talk ? ?	186.07849
sex as the creative principle of the universe , the secret of primitive religion , the life of myth .	34.58164
everything in the final analysis reduced itself to sexual symbolism .	234.44087
in his chapter on `` the loveways of the beat generation ' ' , lipton spares the reader none of the sordid details .	31.67433
no one asks questions about the free union of the sexes in west venice so long as the partners share the negative attitudes of the group .	56.634274
the women who come to west venice , having forsaken radicalism , are interested in living only for the moment , in being constantly on the move .	124.570755
others who are attracted to this mecca of the beat generation are homosexuals , heroin addicts , and smalltime hoodlums .	22.387444
those who are sexual deviants are naturally drawn to join the beatniks .	54.748474
since the homosexuals widely use marijuana , they do not have to be initiated .	18.263506
part of the ritual of sex is the use of marijuana .	23.780903
as lipton puts it `` the eros is felt in the magic circle of marijuana with far greater force , as a unifying principle in human relationships , than at any other time except , perhaps , in the mutual metaphysical orgasms .	86.7081
the magic circle is , in fact , a symbol of and preparation for the metaphysical orgasm ' ' .	67.791214
under the influence of marijuana the beatnik comes alive within and experiences a wonderfully enhanced sense of self as if he had discovered the open sesame to the universe of being .	126.046974
carried high on this `` charge ' ' , he composes `` magical ' ' poetry that captures the organic rhythms of life in words .	66.761566
if he thus achieves a lyrical , dreamlike , drugged intensity , he pays the price for his indulgence by producing work -- allen ginsberg ' s `` howl ' ' is a striking example of this tendency -- that is disoriented , dionysian but without depth and without apollonian control .	57.16007
for drugs are in themselves no royal road to creativity .	38.86319
how is the beat poet to achieve unity of form when he is at the same time engaged in a systematic derangement of senses .	41.20919
if love reflects the nature of man , as ortega y gasset believes , if the person in love betrays decisively what he is by his behavior in love , then the writers of the beat generation are creating a new literary genre .	57.079037
there were fences in the old days when we were children .	148.75516
across the front of a yard and down the side , they were iron , either spiked along the top or arched in half circles .	75.96941
alley fences were made of solid boards higher than one ' s head , but not so high as the golden glow in a corner or the hollyhocks that grew in a line against them .	55.351635
side fences were hidden beneath lilacs and hundred-leaf roses	50.862408
front fences were covered with virginia creeper or trumpet vines or honeysuckle .	9.991385
square corner- and gate posts were an open-work pattern of cast-iron foliage	104.46413
they were topped by steeples complete in every detail high-pitched roof , pinnacle , and narrow gable .	29.294392
on these posts the gates swung open with a squeak and shut with a metallic clang .	27.13022
the only extended view possible to anyone less tall than the fences was that obtained from an upper bough of the apple tree .	81.12362
the primary quality of that view seems , now , to have been its quietness , but that cannot at the time have impressed us .	98.1287
from high in the tree , the whole block lay within range of the eye , but the ground was almost nowhere visible .	76.72328
one looked down on a sea of leaves , a breaking wave of flower .	63.814236
every path from back door to barn was covered by a grape-arbor , and every yard had its fruit trees .	89.30124
in the center of any open space remaining our grandfathers had planted syringa and sweet-shrub , snowball , rose-of-sharon and balm-of-gilead .	21.80281
from above one could only occasionally catch a glimpse of life on the floor of this green sea a neighbor ' s gingham skirt flashing into sight for an instant on the path beneath her grape-arbor , or the movement of hands above a clothesline and the flutter of garments hung there , half-way down the block .	71.932945
time is a queer thing and memory a queerer	282.4257
the tricks that time plays with memory and memory with time are queerest of all .	141.18814
from maturity one looks back at the succession of years , counts them and makes them many , yet cannot feel length in the number , however large .	318.79807
in a stream that turns a mill-wheel there is a lot of water	18.95625
the mill-pond is quiet , its surface dark and shadowed , and there does not seem to be much water in it .	23.99658
and yet -- a year to a child is an eternity , and in the memory that phase of one ' s being -- a certain mental landscape -- will seem to have endured without beginning and without end .	127.08828
the part of the mind that preserves dates and events may remonstrate , `` it could have been like that for only a little while ' '	111.6372
but true memory does not count nor add it holds fast to things that were and they are outside of time .	176.68094
once , then -- for how many years or how few does not matter -- my world was bound round by fences , when i was too small to reach the apple tree bough , to twist my knee over it and pull myself up .	170.27527
that world was in scale with my own smallness .	92.733864
i have no picture in my mind of the garden as a whole -- that i could not see -- but certain aspects of certain corners linger in the memory wind-blown , frost-bitten , white chrysanthemums beneath a window , with their brittle brown leaves and their sharp scent of november	71.01278
ripe pears lying in long grass , to be turned over by a dusty-slippered foot , cautiously , lest bees still worked in the ragged , brown-edged holes	115.20791
hot-colored verbenas in the corner between the dining-room wall and the side porch , where we passed on our way to the pump with the half-gourd tied to it as a cup by my grandmother for our childish pleasure in drinking from it .	117.207184
i think that my grandmother was not an impassioned gardener she was too indulgent a lover of dogs and grandchildren .	62.743576
my great-grandmother , i have been told , made her garden her great pride	419.19223
she cherished rare and delicate plants like oleanders in tubs and wall-flowers and lemon verbenas in pots that had to be wintered in the cellar	47.79504
she filled the waste spots of the yard with common things like the garden heliotrope in a corner by the woodshed , and the plantain lilies along the west side of the house .	43.880142
these my grandmother left in their places ( they are still there , more persistent and longer-lived than the generations of man ) and planted others like them , that flourished without careful tending .	123.66643
three of these only were protected from us by stern commandment the roses , whose petals might not be collected until they had fallen , to be made into perfume or rose-tea to drink	81.06956
the peonies , whose tight sticky buds would be blighted by the laying on of a finger , although they were not apparently harmed by the ants that crawled over them	46.794697
i have more than once sat cross-legged in the grass through a long summer morning and watched without touching while a poppy bud higher than my head slowly but visibly pushed off its cap , unfolded , and shook out like a banner in the sun its flaming vermilion petals .	122.81591
other flowers we might gather as we pleased myrtle and white violets from beneath the lilacs	22.57348
the lilacs themselves , that bloomed so prodigally but for the most part beyond our reach	152.34445
hollyhock blossoms that , turned upside down , make pink-petticoated ladies	281.13916
and the little , dark blue larkspur that scattered its seed everywhere .	156.75786
more potent a charm to bring back that time of life than this record of a few pictures and a few remembered facts would be a catalogue of the minutiae which are of the very stuff of the mind , intrinsic , because they were known in the beginning not by the eye alone but by the hand that held them .	113.81099
flowers , stones , and small creatures , living and dead .	95.231125
pale yellow snapdragons that by pinching could be made to bite	34.087822
seed-pods of the balsams that snapped like fire-crackers at a touch	186.3462
red-and-yellow columbines whose round-tipped spurs were picked off and eaten for the honey in them	89.18293
morning-glory buds which could be so grasped and squeezed that they burst like a blown-up paper bag	221.52144
bright flowers from the trumpet vine that made `` gloves ' ' on the ends of ten waggling fingers .	29.538689
fuzzy caterpillars , snails with their sensitive horns , struggling grasshoppers held by their long hind legs and commanded to `` spit tobacco , spit ' ' .	59.02716
dead fledgling birds , their squashed-looking nakedness and the odor of decay that clung to the hand when they had been buried in our graveyard in front of the purple flags .	52.686214
and the cast shell of a locust , straw-colored and transparent , weighing nothing , fragile but entire , with eyes like bubbles and a gaping slit down its back .	89.376595
every morning early , in the summer , we searched the trunks of the trees as high as we could reach for the locust shells , carefully detached their hooked claws from the bark where they hung , and stabled them , a weird faery herd , in an angle between the high roots of the tulip tree , where no grass grew in the dense shade .	59.324142
we collected `` lucky stones ' ' -- all the creamy translucent pebbles , worn smooth and round , that we could find in the driveway .	39.936405
when these had been pocketed , we could still spend a morning cracking open other pebbles for our delight in seeing how much prettier they were inside than their dull exteriors indicated .	223.12198
we showed them to each other and said `` would you have guessed ' ' ? ?	23.857307
squatting on our haunches beside the flat stone we broke them on , we were safe behind the high closed gates at the end of the drive safe from interruption and the observation and possible amusement of the passers-by .	120.381874
thus shielded , we played many foolish games in comfortable unselfconsciousness	41.14757
even when the fences became a part of the game -- when a vine-embowered gate-post was the sleeping beauty ' s enchanted castle , or when rapunzel let down her golden hair from beneath the crocketed spire , even then we paid little heed to those who went by on the path outside .	67.15283
we enjoyed a paradoxical freedom when we were still too young for school .	104.37147
in the heat of the summer , the garden solitudes were ours alone	187.27083
our elders stayed in the dark house or sat fanning on the front porch .	37.898735
they never troubled themselves about us while we were playing , because the fence formed such a definite boundary and `` don ' t go outside the gate ' ' was a command so impossible of misinterpretation .	110.40727
we were not , however , entirely unacquainted with the varying aspects of the street .	34.608658
we were forbidden to swing on the gates , lest they sag on their hinges in a poor-white-trash way , but we could stand on them , when they were latched , rest our chins on the top , and stare and stare , committing to memory , quite unintentionally , all the details that lay before our eyes .	59.921375
the street that is full now of traffic and parked cars then and for many years drowsed on an august afternoon in the shade of the curbside trees , and silence was a weight , almost palpable , in the air .	94.35415
every slight sound that rose against that pressure fell away again , crushed beneath it .	116.73638
a hay-wagon moved slowly along the gutter , the top of it swept by the low boughs of the maple trees , and loose straws were left hanging tangled among the leaves .	61.102783
a wheel squeaked on a hub , was still , and squeaked again .	101.607956
if a child watched its progress he whispered , `` hay , hay , load of hay -- make a wish and turn away ' ' , and then stared rigidly in the opposite direction until the sound of the horses ' feet returned no more .	83.56899
when the hay wagon had gone , and an interval passed , a huckster ' s cart might turn the corner .	140.1899
the horse walked , the reins were slack , the huckster rode with bowed shoulders , his forearms across his knees .	50.5256
sleepily , as if half-reluctant to break the silence , he lifted his voice `` rhu-beb-ni-ice nice fresh rhu-beb today ' ' ! !	55.720577
the lazy sing-song was spaced in time like the drone of a bumble-bee .	14.628472
no one seemed to hear him , no one heeded .	52.31483
the horse plodded on , and he repeated his call .	80.54107
it became so monotonous as to seem a part of the quietness .	20.27284
after his passage , the street was empty again .	93.66775
the sun moved slant-wise across the sky and down	149.30197
the trees ' shadows circled from street to sidewalk , from sidewalk to lawn .	57.852966
at four-o ' clock , or four-thirty , the coming of the newsboy marked the end of the day	56.381588
he tossed a paper toward every front door , and housewives came down to their steps to pick them up and read what their neighbors had been doing .	91.97571
the streets of any county town were like this on any sunshiny afternoon in summer	365.1141
they were like this fifty-odd years ago , and yesterday .	180.7969
but the fences were still in place fifty-odd years ago , and when we stood on the gate to look over , the sidewalk under our eyes was not cement but two rows of paving stones with grass between and on both sides .	94.30234
the curb was a line of stone laid edgewise in the dirt and tilted this way and that by frost in the ground or the roots of trees .	67.27591
opposite every gate was a hitching post or a stone carriage-step , set with a rusty iron ring for tying a horse .	43.160717
the street was unpaved and rose steeply toward the center	5.874171
it was mud in wet weather and dust , ankle-deep , in dry , and could be crossed only at the corner where there were stepping stones .	85.24459
it had a bucolic atmosphere that it has lost long since .	68.978096
the hoofmarks of cattle and the prints of bare feet in the mud or in the dust were as numerous as the traces of shod horses .	88.63325
cows were kept in backyard barns , boys were hired to drive them to and from the pasture on the edge of town , and familiar to the ear , morning and evening , were the boys ' coaxing voices , the thud of hooves , and the thwack of a stick on cowhide .	41.92125
it is worth dwelling in some detail on the crisis of this story , because it brings together a number of characteristic elements and makes of them a curious , riddling compound obscurely but centrally significant for mann ' s work .	66.26606
the wife , amra , and her lover are both savagely portrayed , she as incarnate sensuality , `` voluptuous ' ' and `` indolent ' ' , possibly `` a mischief maker ' ' , with `` a kind of luxurious cunning ' ' to set against her apparent simplicity , her `` birdlike brain ' ' .	26.362104
lautner , for his part , `` belonged to the present-day race of small artists , who do not demand the utmost of themselves ' ' , and the bitter description of the type includes such epithets as `` wretched little poseurs ' ' , the devastating indictment `` they do not know how to be wretched decently and in order ' ' , and the somewhat extreme prophecy , so far not fulfilled `` they will be destroyed ' ' .	44.6376
the trick these two play upon jacoby reveals their want not simply of decency but of imagination as well .	230.1874
his appearance as lizzy evokes not amusement but horror in the audience	241.47487
it is a spectacle absolutely painful , an epiphany of the suffering flesh unredeemed by spirit , untouched by any spirit other than abasement and humiliation .	126.88797
at the same time the multiple transvestitism involved -- the fat man as girl and as baby , as coquette pretending to be a baby -- touches for a moment horrifyingly upon the secret sources of a life like jacoby ' s , upon the sinister dreams which form the sources of any human life .	87.817955
the music which lautner has composed for this episode is for the most part `` rather pretty and perfectly banal ' ' .	63.51603
but it is characteristic of him , we are told , `` his little artifice ' ' , to be able to introduce `` into a fairly vulgar and humorous piece of hackwork a sudden phrase of genuine creative art ' ' .	45.58061
and this occurs now , at the refrain of jacoby ' s song -- at the point , in fact , of the name `` lizzy ' ' --	23.52399
a modulation described as `` almost a stroke of genius ' ' .	7.1110115
`` a miracle , a revelation , it was like a curtain suddenly torn away to reveal something nude ' ' .	89.9559
it is this modulation which reveals to jacoby his own frightful abjection and , simultaneously , his wife ' s infidelity .	45.207233
by the same means he perceives this fact as having communicated itself to the audience	254.98468
in the work of every artist , i suppose , there may be found one or more moments which strike the student as absolutely decisive , ultimately emblematic of what it is all about	102.49452
not less strikingly so for being mysterious , as though some deeply hidden constatation of thoughts were enciphered in a single image , a single moment .	108.63898
the horrifying humor , the specifically sexual embarrassment of the joke gone wrong , the monstrous image of the fat man dressed up as a whore dressing up as a baby	62.795776
the bringing together around it of the secret liaison between indolent , mindless sensuality and sharp , shrewd talent , cleverness with an occasional touch of genius ( which , however , does not know `` how to attack the problem of suffering ' ' )	52.12012
the miraculous way in which music , revelation and death are associated in a single instant -- all this seems a triumph of art , a rather desperate art , in itself	119.618774
beyond itself , also , it evokes numerous and distant resonances from the entire body of mann ' s work .	39.317688
when i try to work out my reasons for feeling that this passage is of critical significance , i come up with the following ideas , which i shall express very briefly here and revert to in a later essay .	89.48069
love is the crucial dilemma of experience for mann ' s heroes .	23.99798
the dramatic construction of his stories characteristically turns on a situation in which someone is simultaneously compelled and forbidden to love .	94.31052
the release , the freedom , involved in loving another is either terribly difficult or else absolutely impossible	577.1234
this prohibition on love has an especially poignant relation to art	123.01342
it is particularly the artist ( tonio kroger , aschenbach , leverkuhn ) who suffers from it .	44.965782
the specific analogy to the dilemma of love is the problem of the `` breakthrough ' ' in the realm of art .	15.018678
again , the sufferings and disasters produced by any transgression against the commandment not to love are almost invariably associated in one way or another with childhood , with the figure of a child .	89.117386
finally , the theatrical ( and perversely erotic ) notions of dressing up , cosmetics , disguise , and especially change of costume ( or singularity of costume , as with cipolla ) , are characteristically associated with the catastrophes of mann ' s stories .	58.34153
we shall return to these statements and deal with them more fully as the evidence for them accumulates .	141.33344
for the present it is enough to note that in the grotesque figure of jacoby , at the moment of his collapse , all these elements come together in prophetic parody .	60.010506
professionally a lawyer , that is to say associated with dignity , reserve , discipline , with much that is essentially middle-class , he is compelled by an impossible love to exhibit himself dressed up , disguised -- that is , paradoxically , revealed -- as a child , and , worse , as a whore masquerading as a child .	103.44445
that this abandonment takes place on a stage , during an ' artistic ' performance , is enough to associate jacoby with art , and to bring down upon him the punishment for art	142.05875
that is , he is suspect , guilty , punishable , as is anyone in mann ' s stories who produces illusion , and this is true even though the constant elements of the artist-nature , technique , magic , guilt and suffering , are divided in this story between jacoby and lautner .	91.15386
it appears that the dominant tendency of mann ' s early tales , however pictorial or even picturesque the surface , is already toward the symbolic , the emblematic , the expressionistic .	99.07108
in a certain perfectly definite way , the method and the theme of his stories are one and the same .	61.0038
something of this can be learned from `` the way to the churchyard ' ' ( 1901 ) , an anecdote about an old failure whose fit of anger at a passing cyclist causes him to die of a stroke or seizure .	73.18725
there is no more `` plot ' ' than that	218.46352
only slightly more , perhaps , than a newspaper account of such an incident would give .	261.61478
the artistic interest , then , lies in what the encounter may be made to represent , in the power of some central significance to draw the details into relevance and meaningfulness .	107.2444
the first sentence , with its platitudinous irony , announces an emblematic intent `` the way to the churchyard ran along beside the highroad , ran beside it all the way to the end	74.98323
that is to say , to the churchyard ' ' .	4.0061903
and the action is consistently presented with regard for this distinction .	40.70014
the highroad , one might say at first , belongs to life , while the way to the churchyard belongs to death .	38.89988
but that is too simple , and won ' t hold up .	10.98021
as the first sentence suggests , both roads belong to death in the end .	60.551727
but the highroad , according to the description of its traffic , belongs to life as it is lived in unawareness of death , while the way to the churchyard belongs to some other sort of life a suffering form , an existence wholly comprised in the awareness of death .	84.4746
thus , on the highroad , a troop of soldiers `` marched in their own dust and sang ' ' , while on the footpath one man walks alone .	62.374542
this man ' s isolation is not merely momentary , it is permanent .	30.492077
he is a widower , his three children are dead , he has no one left on earth	65.50166
also he is a drunk , and has lost his job on that account .	200.42627
his name is praisegod piepsam , and he is rather fully described as to his clothing and physiognomy in a way which relates him to a sinister type in the author ' s repertory -- he is a forerunner of those enigmatic strangers in `` death in venice ' ' , for example , who represent some combination of cadaver , exotic , and psychopomp .	65.97043
this strange person quarrels with a cyclist because the latter is using the path rather than the highroad .	77.677246
the cyclist , a sufficiently commonplace young fellow , is not named but identified simply as `` life ' ' -- that and a license number , which piepsam uses in addressing him .	144.68457
`` life ' ' points out that `` everybody uses this path ' ' , and starts to ride on .	88.41932
piepsam tries to stop him by force , receives a push in the chest from `` life ' ' , and is left standing in impotent and growing rage , while a crowd begins to gather .	115.23138
that is , on the basis of his own sinfulness and abject wretchedness , piepsam becomes a prophet who in his ecstasy and in the name of god imprecates doom on life -- not only the cyclist now , but the audience , the world , as well `` all you light-headed breed ' ' .	55.98731
this passion brings on a fit which proves fatal .	69.22614
then an ambulance comes along , and they drive praisegod piepsam away .	275.1963
this is simple enough , but several more points of interest may be mentioned as relevant .	85.390884
the season , between spring and summer , belongs to life in its carefree aspect .	165.42125
piepsam ' s fatal rage arises not only because he cannot stop the cyclist , but also because god will not stop him	57.539253
as piepsam says to the crowd in his last moments `` his justice is not of this world ' ' .	64.9473
life is further characterized , in antithesis to piepsam , as animal the image of a dog , which appears at several places , is first given as the criterion of amiable , irrelevant interest aroused by life considered simply as a spectacle a dog in a wagon is `` admirable ' ' , `` a pleasure to contemplate ' '	123.96115
another wagon has no dog , and therefore is `` devoid of interest ' ' .	30.641197
