piepsam calls the cyclist `` cur ' ' and `` puppy ' ' among other things , and at the crisis of his fit a little fox-terrier stands before him and howls into his face .	59.728333
the ambulance is drawn by two `` charming ' ' little horses .	63.875885
piepsam is not , certainly , religious in any conventional sense .	34.63699
his religiousness is intimately , or dialectically , connected with his sinfulness	108.87842
his unsuccessful strivings to give up drink are represented as religious strivings	100.66996
he keeps a bottle in a wardrobe at home , and `` before this wardrobe praisegod piepsam had before now gone literally on his knees , and in his wrestlings had bitten his tongue -- and still in the end capitulated ' ' .	81.235176
the cyclist , by contrast , blond and blue-eyed , is simply unreflective , unproblematic life , `` blithe and carefree ' ' .	18.452938
`` he made no claims to belong to the great and mighty of this earth ' ' .	37.97674
he is `` a man raving mad on the way to the churchyard ' ' .	8.608063
but he is more interesting than the others , the ones who come from the highroad to watch him , more interesting than life considered as a cyclist .	78.664085
and if i have gone into so much detail about so small a work , that is because it is also so typical a work , representing the germinal form of a conflict which remains essential in mann ' s writing the crude sketch of piepsam contains , in its critical , destructive and self-destructive tendencies , much that is enlarged and illuminated in the figures of , for instance , naphta and leverkuhn .	82.230896
in method as well as in theme this little anecdote with its details selected as much for expressiveness and allegory as for `` realism ' ' , anticipates a kind of musical composition , as well as a kind of fictional composition , in which , as leverkuhn says , `` there shall be nothing unthematic ' ' .	43.118866
it resembles , too , pictures such as durer and bruegel did , in which all that looks at first to be solely pictorial proves on inspection to be also literary , the representation of a proverb , for example , or a deadly sin .	78.700745
`` gladius dei ' ' ( 1902 ) resembles `` the way to the churchyard ' ' in its representation of a conflict between light and dark , between `` life ' ' and a spirit of criticism , negation , melancholy , but it goes considerably further in characterizing the elements of this conflict .	42.445892
the monk savonarola , brought over from the renaissance and placed against the background of munich at the turn of the century , protests against the luxurious works displayed in the art-shop of m . bluthenzweig	99.839485
in particular against a madonna portrayed in a voluptuous style and modeled , according to gossip , upon the painter ' s mistress .	50.322544
hieronymus , like piepsam , makes his protest quite in vain , and his rejection , though not fatal , is ridiculous and humiliating	103.326035
he is simply thrown out of the shop by the porter .	38.690998
on the street outside , hieronymus envisions a holocaust of the vanities of this world , such a burning of artistic and erotic productions as his namesake actually brought to pass in florence , and prophetically he issues his curse `` gladius dei super terram cito et velociter ' ' .	54.95709
the `` reality ' ' to which they respond is rationally empty and their art is an imitation of the inescapable powerfulness of this unknown and empty world .	93.6235
their artistic rationale is given to the witness of unreason .	19.802935
these polar concerns ( imitation vs . formalism ) reflect a philosophical and religious situation which has been developing over a long period of time .	31.481764
the breakdown of classical structures of meaning in all realms of western culture has given rise to several generations of artists who have documented the disintegrative processes .	75.88669
thus the image of man has suffered complete fragmentation in personal and spiritual qualities , and complete objectification in sub-human and quasi-mechanistic powers .	56.867188
the image of the world tends to reflect the hostility and indifference of man or else to dissolve into empty spaces and overwhelming mystery .	139.40344
all such imitations of negative quality have given rise to a compensatory response in the form of a heroic and highly individualistic humanism if man can neither know nor love reality as it is , he can at least invent an artistic `` reality ' ' which is its own world and which can speak to man of purely personal and subjective qualities capable of being known and worthy of being loved .	88.154144
the person of the artist becomes a final bastion of meaning in a world rendered meaningless by the march of events and the decay of classical religious and philosophical systems .	82.263725
whatever pole of this contrast one emphasizes and whatever the tension between these two approaches to understanding the artistic imagination , it will be readily seen that they are not mutually exclusive , that they belong together .	68.584816
without the decay of a sense of objective reference ( except as the imitation of mystery ) , the stress on subjective invention would never have been stimulated into being .	68.364815
and although these insights into the nature of art may be in themselves insufficient for a thoroughgoing philosophy of art , their peculiar authenticity in this day and age requires that they be taken seriously and gives promise that from their very substance , new and valid chapters in the philosophy of art may be written .	123.41618
for better or worse we cannot regard `` imitation ' ' in the arts in the simple mode of classical rationalism or detached realism .	37.65621
a broader concept of imitation is needed , one which acknowledges that true invention is important , that the artist ' s creativity in part transcends the non-artistic causal factors out of which it arises .	84.72176
on the other hand , we cannot regard artistic invention as pure , uncaused , and unrelated to the times in which it occurs .	46.798
we need a doctrine of imitation to save us from the solipsism and futility of pure formalism .	23.718718
accordingly , it is the aim of this essay to advance a new theory of imitation ( which i shall call mimesis in order to distinguish it from earlier theories of imitation ) and a new theory of invention ( which i shall call symbol for reasons to be stated hereafter ) .	66.43581
the word `` mimesis ' ' ( `` imitation ' ' ) is usually associated with plato and aristotle .	17.793123
for plato , `` imitation ' ' is twice removed from reality , being a poor copy of physical appearance , which in itself is a poor copy of ideal essence .	146.09439
all artistic and mythological representations , therefore , are `` imitations of imitations ' ' and are completely superseded by the truth value of `` dialectic ' ' , the proper use of the inquiring intellect .	34.625404
in plato ' s judgment , the arts play a meaningful role in society only in the education of the young , prior to the full development of their intellectual powers .	76.496864
presupposed in plato ' s system is a doctrine of levels of insight , in which a certain kind of detached understanding is alone capable of penetrating to the most sublime wisdom .	85.332596
aristotle also tended to stratify all aspects of human nature and activity into levels of excellence and , like plato , he put the pure and unimpassioned intellect on the top level .	77.43742
the poetics , in affirming that all human arts are `` modes of imitation ' ' , gives a more serious role to artistic mimesis than did plato .	90.97431
but aristotle kept the principle of levels and even augmented it by describing in the poetics what kinds of character and action must be imitated if the play is to be a vehicle of serious and important human truths .	83.27677
for both plato and aristotle artistic mimesis , in contrast to the power of dialectic , is relatively incapable of expressing the character of fundamental reality .	66.83897
the central concern of erich auerbach ' s impressive volume called mimesis is to describe the shift from a classic theory of imitation ( based upon a recognition of levels of truth ) to a christian theory of imitation in which the levels are dissolved .	87.613045
following the theme of incarnation in the gospels , the christian artist and critic sees in the most commonplace and ordinary events `` figures ' ' of divine power and reality .	86.1222
here artistic realism involves the audience in an impassioned participation in events whose overtones and implications are transcendent .	119.64296
artistic mimesis under christian influence records the involvement of all persons , however humble , in a divine drama .	58.783325
the artist , unlike the philosopher , is not a removed observer aiming at neutral and rarified high levels of abstraction .	85.10378
he is the conveyor of a sacred reality by which he has been grasped .	45.348736
i have chosen to use the word `` mimesis ' ' in its christian rather than its classic implications and to discover in the concrete forms of both art and myth powers of theological expression which , as in the christian mind , are the direct consequence of involvement in historical experience , which are not reserved , as in the greek mind , only to moments of theoretical reflection .	79.31486
in the first instance , `` mimesis ' ' is here used to mean the recalling of experience in terms of vivid images rather than in terms of abstract ideas or conventional designations .	53.998653
by `` image ' ' is meant not only a visual presentation , but also remembered sensations of any of the five senses plus the feelings which are immediately conjoined therewith .	81.09914
this is the primary function of the imagination operating in the absence of the original experiential stimulus by which the images were first appropriated .	92.770615
mimesis is the nearest possible thing to the actual re-living of experience , in which the imagining person recovers through images something of the force and depth characteristic of experience itself .	97.248634
the images themselves , like their counterparts in experience , are not neutral qualities to be surveyed dispassionately	102.019554
they are fields of force exerting a unique influence on the sensibilities and a unique relatedness to one another .	36.76002
they bring an inextricable component of value within themselves , with attractions and repulsions native to their own quality .	124.23921
as in experience one is seized by given entities and their interrelations and is forced to respond in value feelings to them , so one is similarly seized in the mimetic presentation of images .	108.80285
mimesis here is not to be confused with literalism or realism in the conventional sense .	41.76172
a word taken in its dictionary meaning , a photographic image of a recognizable object , the mere picturing of a `` scene ' ' tends to lose experiential vividness and to connote such conventional abstractions as to invite neutral reception without the incitement of value feelings .	58.316864
similarly experience itself can be conventionalized so that people react to certain preconceived clues for behavior without awareness of the vitality of their experiential field .	104.65239
a truly vivid imagination moves beyond the conventional recollection to a sense of immediacy .	41.09087
the mimetic character of the imaginative consciousness tends to express itself in the presentation of artistic forms and materials .	43.62677
when words can be used in a more fresh and primitive way so that they strike with the force of sights and sounds , when tones of sound and colors of paint and the carven shape all strike the sensibilities with an undeniable force of data in and of themselves , compelling the observer into an attitude of attention , all this imitates the way experience itself in its deepest character strikes upon the door of consciousness and clamors for entrance .	157.19319
these are like the initial ways in which the world forces itself upon the self and thrusts the self into decision and choice .	99.968346
the presence of genuine mimesis in art is marked by the persistence with which the work demands attention and compels valuation even though it is but vaguely understood .	124.65442
underlying these conceptions of mimesis are certain presuppositions concerning the nature of primary human experience which require some exposition before the main argument can proceed .	89.430695
experience is not seen , as it is in classical rationalism , as presenting us initially with clear and distinct objects simply located in space and registering their character , movements , and changes on the tabula rasa of an uninvolved intellect .	82.448494
neither is primary experience understood according to the attitude of modern empiricism in which nothing is thought to be received other than signals of sensory qualities producing their responses in the appropriate sense organs .	197.93149
primary feelings of the world come neither as a collection of clearly known objects ( houses , trees , implements , etc . ) nor a collection of isolated and neutral sensory qualities .	63.350002
in contrast to all this , primary data are data of a self involved in environing processes and powers .	130.25151
the most primitive feelings are rudimentary value feelings , both positive and negative a desire to appropriate this or that part of the environment into oneself	147.55539
a desire to avoid and repel this or that other part .	350.60965
these desires presuppose a sense of causally efficacious powers in which one is involved , some working for one ' s good , others threatening ill .	99.00827
gone is the tabula rasa of the mind .	22.815453
in its place is a passionate consciousness grasped and molded to feelings of positive or negative values even as the actions of one ' s life are determined by constellations of process in which one is caught .	114.63292
the principal defender of this view of primary experience as `` causal efficacy ' ' is alfred north whitehead .	50.754913
our most elemental and unavoidable impressions , he says , are those of being involved in a large arena of powers which have a longer past than our own , which are interrelated in a vast movement through the present toward the future .	91.93988
we feel the quality of these powers initially as in some degree wholesome or threatening .	260.53482
later abstractive and rational processes may indicate errors of judgment in these apprehensions of value , but the apprehensions themselves are the primary stuff of experience .	67.031334
it takes a great deal of abstraction to free oneself from the primitive impression of larger unities of power and influence and to view one ' s world simply as a collection of sense data arranged in such and such sequence and pattern , devoid of all power to move the feelings and actions except in so far as they present themselves for inspection .	129.98099
whitehead is here questioning david hume ' s understanding of the nature of experience	28.804882
he is questioning , also , every epistemology which stems from hume ' s presupposition that experience is merely sense data in abstraction from causal efficacy , and that causal efficacy is something intellectually imputed to the world , not directly perceived .	67.225784
what hume calls `` sensation ' ' is what whitehead calls `` perception in the mode of presentational immediacy ' ' which is a sophisticated abstraction from perception in the mode of causal efficacy .	49.036915
as long as perception is seen as composed only of isolated sense data , most of the quality and interconnectedness of existence loses its objectivity , becomes an invention of consciousness , and the result is a philosophical scepticism .	84.00022
whitehead contends that the human way of understanding existence as a unity of interlocking and interdependent processes which constitute each other and which cause each other to be and not to be is possible only because the basic form of such an understanding , for all its vagueness and tendency to mistake the detail , is initially given in the way man feels the world .	130.59473
in this respect experience is broader and full of a richer variety of potential meanings than the mind of man or any of his arts or culture are capable of making clear and distinct .	96.60008
a chief characteristic of experience in the mode of causal efficacy is one of derivation from the past .	20.34684
both i and my feelings come up out of a chain of events that fan out into the past into sources that are ultimately very unlike the entity which i now am .	164.11359
after only eighteen years of non-interference , there were already indications of melioration , though `` in a slight degree ' ' , to be sure .	40.660404
there were more indications by the mid-twentieth century .	6.0680833
i leave it to the statisticians to say what they were , but i noticed several a few years ago , during an automobile ride from memphis to hattiesburg .	53.313602
in town after town my companion pointed out the negro school and the white school , and in every instance the former made a better appearance ( it was newer , for one thing ) .	80.003975
it really looked as if a change of the sort predicted by booker t . washington had been going on .	93.20013
but with the renewal of interference in 1954 ( as with its beginning in 1835 ) , the improvement was impaired .	69.67052
for over a hundred years southerners have felt that the north was picking on them .	20.890478
it ' s infuriating , this feeling that one is being picked on , continually , constantly .	169.74736
by what right of superior virtue , southerners ask , do the people of the north do this ? ?	73.432014
the traditional strategy of the south has been to expose the vices of the north , to demonstrate that the north possessed no superior virtue , to `` show the world that ' ' as james ' s christopher newman said to his adversaries ) `` however bad i may be , you ' re not quite the people to say it ' ' .	71.114235
in the pre-civil war years , the south argued that the slave was not less humanely treated than the factory worker of the north .	100.37038
at the present time , the counter-attack takes the line that there ' s no more of the true spirit of `` integration ' ' in the north than in the south .	27.372335
people talk about `` the law of the land ' ' .	7.7085843
but people can ' t be made to integrate , socialize ( the two are inseparable by southern standards ) by law .	134.67326
i was having lunch not long ago ( apologies to n . v . peale ) with three distinguished historians ( one specializing in the european middle ages , one in american history , and one in the far east ) , and i asked them if they could name instances where the general mores had been radically changed with `` deliberate speed , majestic instancy ' ' ( francis thompson ' s words for the hound of heaven ' s pursuit ) by judicial fiat .	62.054
they didn ' t seem to be able to think of any .	64.34403
a virginia judge a while back cited a roman jurist to the effect that ten years might be a reasonable length of time for such a change .	40.748447
but i suspect that the old roman was referring to change made under military occupation -- the sort of change which tacitus was talking about when he said , `` they make a desert , and call it peace ' ' ( `` solitudinem faciunt , pacem appellant ' ' .	62.15807
moreover , the law of the land is not irrevocable	77.60258
mr . justice taney ' s dred scott decision in 1857 was unpopular in the north , and soon became a dead letter .	55.795845
prohibition was the law of the land , but it was unpopular ( how many of us oldsters took up drinking in prohibition days , drinking was so gay , so fashionable , especially in the sophisticated northeast ! !	150.98514
the cliche loses its talismanic virtue in the light of a little history .	57.318424
the declaration of independence says that `` governments derive their just powers from the consent of the governed ' ' .	50.30231
the phrase `` consent of the governed ' ' needs a hard look .	114.49836
how do we define it ' ' ? ?	1.0082954
is the consent of the governed a numerical majority ? ?	10.0468855
calhoun dealt with this question in his `` disquisition on government ' ' .	44.91084
to guard against the tyranny of a numerical majority , calhoun developed his theory of `` concurrent majority ' ' , which , he said , `` by giving to each portion of the community which may be unequally affected by the action of government , a negative on the others , prevents all partial or local legislation ' ' .	63.21048
who will say that our country is even now a homogeneous community ? ?	53.834484
that regional peculiarities do not still exist ? ?	1.2229345
that the court order does not unequally affect the southern region ? ?	37.065792
who will deny that in a vast portion of the south the federal action is incompatible with the jeffersonian concept of `` the consent of the governed ' ' ? ?	31.258556
a friend of mine in new mexico said the court order had caused no particular trouble out there , that all had gone as merry as a marriage bell .	79.08955
he seemed a little surprised that it should have caused any particular trouble anywhere .	77.58948
i murmured something about a possible difference between new mexico ' s history and mississippi ' s .	39.38405
one can meet with aloofness almost anywhere the thidiu viewpoint , it doesn ' t affect us ! !	31.509384
southern liberals ( there are a good many ) -- especially if they ' re rich -- often exhibit blithe insouciance .	57.864967
the trouble here is that it ' s almost too easy to take the high moral ground when it doesn ' t cost you anything .	69.25494
you ' ve already sent your daughter to miss x ' s select academy for girls and your son to mr . y ' s select academy for boys , and you can be as liberal as you please with strict impunity .	55.395706
if there ' s no suitable academy in your own neighborhood , there ' s always new england .	35.204525
new england academies welcome fugitives from the provinces , south as well as west .	76.85052
they may even enroll a colored student or two for show , though he usually turns out to be from thailand , or any place other than the american south .	112.37412
it would be interesting to know how much `` integration ' ' there is in the famous , fashionable colleges and prep schools of new england .	65.8359
a recent newspaper report said there were five negroes in the 1960 graduating class of nearly one thousand at yale	95.9433
that is , about one-half of one per cent , which looks pretty `` tokenish ' ' to me , especially in an institution which professes to be `` national ' ' .	25.809593
i must confess that i prefer the liberal who is personally affected , who is willing to send his own children to a mixed school as proof of his faith .	85.8775
i leave out of account the question of the best interests of the children , the question of what their best interests really are .	83.90183
i ' m talking about the grand manner of the liberal -- north and south -- who is not affected personally .	133.82092
if these people were denied a voice ( do they have a moral right to a voice ? ?	70.597435
) , what voices would be left ? ?	1.008544
well , after everybody has followed the new england pattern of segregating one ' s children into private schools , only the poor folks are left .	103.74924
and it is precisely in this poorer economic class that one finds , and has always found , the most racial friction .	85.563416
a dear , respected friend of mine , who like myself grew up in the south and has spent many years in new england , said to me not long ago `` i can ' t forgive new england for rejecting all complicity ' ' .	68.9362
being a teacher of american literature , i remembered whittier ' s `` massachusetts to virginia ' ' , where he said `` but that one dark loathsome burden ye must stagger with alone , and reap the bitter harvest which ye yourselves have sown ' ' .	70.54315
there is a legend ( hawthorne records it in his `` english notebooks ' ' .	22.939344
and one finds it again in thomas nelson page ) to the effect that the mayflower on its second voyage brought a cargo of negro slaves .	111.851295
whether historically a fact or not , the legend has a certain symbolic value .	138.83784
it is something which most of us try to get out from under .	63.192184
like the cowboy in stephen crane ' s `` blue hotel ' ' , we run around crying , `` well , i didn ' t do anything , did i ' ' ? ?	30.657053
robert penn warren puts it this way in `` brother to dragons ' ' `` the recognition of complicity is the beginning of innocence ' ' , where innocence , i think , means about the same thing as redemption .	64.28144
a man must be able to say , `` father , i have sinned ' ' , or there is no hope for him .	26.298927
lincoln understood this better than most when he said in his `` second inaugural ' ' that god `` gives to both north and south this terrible war , as the woe due to those by whom the offense came ' ' .	114.5166
he also spoke of `` the wealth piled by the bondsman ' s two hundred and fifty years in unrequited toil ' ' .	22.228548
lincoln was historian and economist enough to know that a substantial portion of this wealth had accumulated in the hands of the descendants of new englanders engaged in the slave trade .	56.881184
after how many generations is such wealth ( mounting all the while through the manipulations of high finance ) purified of taint ? ?	281.20163
it is a question which new englanders long ago put out of their minds .	27.280005
but didn ' t they get off too easy ? ?	37.01822
the slaves never shared in their profits , while they did share , in a very real sense , in the profits of the slave-owners they were fed , clothed , doctored , and so forth	43.420296
they were the beneficiaries of responsible , paternalistic care .	137.12614
emerson -- platonist , idealist , doctrinaire -- sounded a high transcendental note in his `` boston hymn ' ' , delivered in 1863 in the boston music hall amidst thundering applause `` pay ransom to the owner and fill the bag to the brim .	54.087776
the slave is owner , and ever was .	91.3269
it is the abstractionism , the unrealism , of the pure idealist .	65.0508
it ignores the sordid financial aspects ( quite conveniently , too , for his audience , who could indulge in moral indignation without visible , or even conscious , discomfort , their money from the transaction having been put away long ago in a good antiseptic brokerage ) .	97.22471
like pilate , they had washed their hands .	9.869202
can god be mocked , ever , in the long run ? ?	67.37064
new englanders were a bit sensitive on the subject of their complicity in negro slavery at the time of the drafting of the declaration of independence , as jefferson explained in his `` autobiography ' ' ``	34.404667
the clause reprobating the enslaving the inhabitants of africa was struck out in complaisance to south carolina and georgia , who had never attempted to restrain the importation of slaves , and who on the contrary still wished to continue it .	64.11091
our northern brethren also i believe felt a little tender under those censures	197.53812
for though their people had very few slaves themselves , yet they had been pretty considerable carriers of them to others ' ' .	56.768543
george w . cable ( naturalized new englander ) , writing in 1889 from `` paradise road , northampton ' ' ( lovely symbolic name ) , agitated continuously the `` southern question ' ' .	39.376255
it was nice to be able to isolate it .	11.229591
new england , as everyone knows , has long been schoolmaster to the nation .	52.932674
there one finds concentrated in a comparatively small area the chief universities , colleges , and preparatory schools of the united states .	36.65396
it is true that new england , more than any other section , was dedicated to education from the start .	119.66539
but i think that something more than this is involved .	32.952385
how did it happen , for example , that the state university , that great symbol of american democracy , failed to flourish in new england as it did in other parts of the country ? ?	73.37206
isn ' t it a bit odd that the three states of southern new england ( massachusetts , connecticut , and rhode island ) have had state institutions of university status only in the very recent past , these institutions having previously been a & m colleges ? ?	150.08865
was it supposed , perchance , that a & m ( vocational training , that is ) was quite sufficient for the immigrant class which flooded that part of the new england world in the post-civil war period , the immigrants having been brought in from southern europe , to work in the mills , to make up for the labor shortage caused by migration to the west ? ?	91.04405
is it not ironical that roger williams ' s state , rhode island , should have been the very last of the forty-eight to establish a state university ? ?	86.38369
the state universities of maine , new hampshire , and vermont are older and more `` respectable ' '	48.85544
a yale historian , writing a few years ago in the yale review , said `` we in new england have long since segregated our children ' ' .	46.815887
he was referring not only to the general college situation but more especially to the preparatory schools .	207.34627
and what a galaxy of those adorns that fair land ! !	180.26448
i don ' t propose to go into their history , but i have one or two surmises .	57.557228
one is that they were established , or gained eminence , under pressure provided by these same immigrants , from whom the old families wished to segregate their children .	113.01526
in the early days of a homogeneous population , the public school was quite satisfactory .	79.84744
among the recipients of the nobel prize for literature more than half are practically unknown to readers of english .	223.20084
of these there are surely few that would be more rewarding discoveries than verner von heidenstam , the swedish poet and novelist who received the award in 1916 and whose centennial was celebrated two years ago .	77.2378
equally a master of prose and verse , he recreates the glory of sweden in the past and continues it into the present .	44.661522
in the following sketch we shall present a brief outline of his life and let him as much as possible speak for himself .	77.566025
heidenstam was born in 1859 , of a prosperous family .	54.07416
on his father ' s side he was of german descent , on his mother ' s he came of the old swedish nobility .	68.61037
the family estate was situated near vadstena on lake vattern in south central sweden .	35.39477
it is a lonely , rather desolate region , but full of legendary and historic associations .	86.36948
as a boy in a local school he was shy and solitary , absorbed in his fondness for nature and his visions of sweden ' s ancient glory .	73.993416
he liked to fancy himself as a chieftain and to dress for the part .	66.35678
being somewhat delicate in health , at the age of sixteen he was sent to southern europe , for which he at once developed a passion , so that he spent nearly all of the following ten years abroad , at first in italy , then in greece , egypt , asia minor , and palestine .	62.893764
in one of his summers at home he married , to the great disapproval of his father , who objected because of his extreme youth .	83.38537
deciding to become a painter , he entered the studio of gerome in paris , where he enjoyed the life of the artists , but soon found that whatever talent he might have did not lie in that direction .	74.698524
he gives us an account of this in his lively and humorous poem , `` the happy artists ' ' .	37.28744
`` i scanned the world through printed symbol swart , and through the beggar ' s rags i strove to see the inner man .	47.750416
i looked unceasingly with my cold mind and with my burning heart ' ' .	34.730984
in this final line , we have the key to his nature .	84.351555
few writers have better understood their deepest selves .	2.89894
it may , however , be noted that his gift for color and imagery must have been greatly stimulated by his stay in paris .	88.5057
the first result of heidenstam ' s long sojourn abroad was a volume of poems , pilgrimage and wander-years ( vallfart och vandringsar ) , published in 1888 .	34.7264
it was a brilliant debut , so much so indeed that it aroused a new vitality in the younger poets , as did byron ' s childe harold .	59.580505
professor fredrik book , sweden ' s foremost critic of the period , acclaims it as follows `` in this we have the verse of a painter	89.137024
strongly colorful , plastic , racy , vivid .	22.068367
in a bold , sometimes careless , form there is nothing academic	147.82799
all is seen and felt and experienced , the observation is sharp and the imagination lively .	81.526146
the young poet-painter reproduces the french life of the streets	134.44305
he tells stories of the thousand and one nights , and conjures up before us the bazaars of damascus .	59.03366
in the care-free indolence of the east he sees the last reflection of the old happy existence , and for that reason he loves it .	65.17281
and yet amid all the gay hedonism in pilgrimage and wander-years is a cycle of short poems , `` thoughts in loneliness ' ' , filled with brooding , melancholy , and sombre longing ' ' .	26.727873
of the longer pieces of the volume none is so memorable as `` nameless and immortal ' ' , which at once took rank among the finest poems ever written in the swedish language .	90.24939
it celebrates the unknown architect who designed the temple of neptune at paestum , next to the parthenon the noblest example of grecian classic style now in existence .	94.765144
on the eve of his return to their native naxos he speaks with his wife of the masterpiece which rises before them in its completed perfection .	143.91722
the supreme object of their lives is now fulfilled , says the wife , her husband has achieved immortality .	83.23858
not so , he answers , it is not the architect but the temple that is immortal .	60.6363
`` the man ' s true reputation is his work ' ' .	28.89255
the short poems grouped at the end of the volume as `` thoughts in loneliness ' ' is , as professor book indicated , in sharp contrast with the others .	68.52483
it consists of fragmentary personal revelations , such as `` the spark ' ' `` there is a spark dwells deep within my soul .	56.405655
to get it out into the daylight ' s glow is my life ' s aim both first and last , the whole .	137.39378
it slips away , it burns and tortures me .	28.740784
that little spark is all the wealth i know , that little spark is my life ' s misery ' ' .	24.361246
a dominant motive is the poet ' s longing for his homeland and its boyhood associations `` not men-folk , but the fields where i would stray , the stones where as a child i used to play ' ' .	107.994026
he is utterly disappointed in himself and in the desultory life he has been leading .	84.060005
what he really wants is to find `` a sacred cause ' ' to which he can honestly devote himself .	45.007698
this restless individualism found its answer when he returned to live nearly all the rest of his life in sweden .	59.915
his cause was to commemorate the glory of her past and to incite her people to perpetuate it in the present .	49.45651
he did not , however , find himself at once .	41.71254
his next major work , completed in 1892 , was a long fantastic epic in prose , entitled hans alienus , which professor book describes as a monument on the grave of his carefree and indolent youth .	48.86125
the hero , who is himself , is represented as a pilgrim in the storied lands of the east , a sort of faustus type , who , to quote from professor book again , `` even in the pleasure gardens of sardanapalus can not cease from his painful search after the meaning of life .	86.178314
he is driven back by his yearning to the wintry homeland of his fathers in the forest of tiveden ' ' .	21.334192
from this time on heidenstam proceeded to find his deeper self .	118.98499
by the death of his father in 1888 he had come into possession of the family estate and had re-assumed its traditions .	61.52578
he did not , however , settle back into acquiescence with things as they were .	65.318855
like his friend and contemporary august strindberg he had little patience with collective mediocrity .	52.79435
he saw sweden as a country of smug and narrow provincialism , indifferent to the heroic spirit of its former glory .	54.442608
strindberg ' s remedy for this condition was to tear down the old structures and build anew from the ground up .	99.44238
heidenstam ' s conception , on the contrary , was to revive the present by the memories of the past .	49.301743
whether in prose or poetry , all of heidenstam ' s later work was concerned with sweden .	82.2447
with the first of a group of historical novels , the charles men ( karolinerna ) , published in 1897-8 , he achieved the masterpiece of his career .	59.355267
in scope and power it can only be compared to tolstoy ' s war and peace .	47.083473
about one-third as long , it is less intimate and detailed , but better coordinated , more concise and more dramatic .	61.323246
though it centers around the brilliant and enigmatic figure of charles 12 , , the true hero is not finally the king himself .	69.94183
hence the title of the book , referring to the soldiers and subjects of the king	50.649635
on the fatal battlefield of poltava , to quote from the novel , `` the wreath he twined for himself slipped down upon his people ' ' .	62.833515
the charles men consists not of a connected narrative but of a group of short stories , each depicting a special phase of the general subject .	63.229706
somewhat uneven in interest for an average reader , eight or ten of these are among the finest of their kind in literature .	82.06489
they comprise a great variety of scene and interest grim episodes of war , idyllic interludes , superb canvases of world-shaking events , and delightfully humorous sketches of odd characters .	51.34351
almost nothing is said of charles ' spectacular victories , the central theme being the heroic loyalty of the swedish people to their idolized king in misfortune and defeat .	70.45813
to carry out this exalted conception the author has combined the vivid realism and imaginative power we have noticed in his early poetry and carried them out on a grand scale .	103.67812
his peculiar gift , as had been suggested before , is his intensity .	236.08397
george meredith has said that fervor is the core of style .	80.88981
of few authors is this more true than of heidenstam .	132.02783
the charles men has a tremendous range of characters , of common folk even more than of major figures .	198.88277
the career of charles 12 , is obviously very similar to that of napoleon .	94.85013
his ideal was alexander of macedon , as napoleon ' s was julius caesar .	14.1219
his purpose , however , was not to establish an empire , but to assert the principle of divine justice .	34.147007
each aspired to be a god in human form , but with each it was a different kind of god .	52.41576
each failed catastrophically in an invasion of russia and each brought ruin on the country that worshipped him .	213.65962
each is still glorified as a national hero .	3.2720687
the first half of the charles men , ending on the climax of the battle of poltava in 1709 , is more dramatically coherent than the second .	31.282928
after the collapse of that desperate and ill-fated campaign the character of the king degenerated for a time into a futility that was not merely pitiable but often ridiculous .	66.363235
like napoleon , he was the worst of losers .	33.312157
there are , however , some wonderful chapters at the beginning of the second part , concerning the reactions of the swedes in adversity .	60.03263
then more than ever before did they show their fortitude and patient cheerfulness .	82.99638
this comes out in `` when the bells ring ' ' , which describes the rallying of the peasants in southern sweden to repel an invasion by the danes .	57.809174
in `` the king ' s ride ' ' , charles breaks out of a long period of petulance and inertia , regains his old self , escapes from turkey , and finally reaches his own land after an absence of eighteen years .	59.621597
he finds it in utter misery and desolation .	10.359972
all his people ask for is no more war .	83.21215
but he plunges into yet another , this time with norway , and is killed in an assault on the fortress of fredrikshall , being only thirty-six years of age when he died .	58.081306
then suddenly there was a tremendous revulsion of popular feeling .	208.4844
from being a hated tyrant and madman he was now the symbol of all that was noblest and best in the history of sweden .	48.708233
this is brought out in the next to last chapter of the book , `` a hero ' s funeral ' ' , written in the form of an impassioned prose poem .	30.7414
slowly the procession of warriors and statesmen passes through the snow beside the black water and into the brilliantly lighted cathedral , the shrine of so many precious memories .	70.319176
the guns are fired , the hymns are sung , and the body of charles is carried down to the vault and laid beside the tombs of his ancestors .	67.30659
as he had longed to be , he became the echo of a saga .	54.8183
heidenstam wrote four other works of fiction about earlier figures revered in swedish memory .	415.74823
excellent in their way , they lack the wide appeal of the charles men , and need not detain us here .	136.4333
it is different with his volume the swedes and their chieftains ( svenskarna och deras hovdingar ) , a history intended for the general reader and particularly suited for high school students .	39.345837
admirably written , it is a perfect introduction to swedish history for readers of other countries .	139.22746
some of the earlier episodes have touches of the supernatural , as suited to the legendary background .	54.85038
especially touching is the chapter , `` the little sister ' ' , about a king ' s daughter who became a nun in the convent of st . birgitta .	32.786232
gustaf vasa is a superb example , and charles 10 , , the conqueror of denmark , hardly less so .	137.4957
of gustavus adolphus and charles 12 , it is unnecessary to speak .	84.25191
today the private detective will also investigate insurance claims or handle divorce cases , but his primary function remains what it has always been , to assist those who have money in their unending struggle with those who have not .	70.53461
it is from this unpromising background that the fictional private detective was recruited .	47.41204
the mythological private eye differs from his counterpart in real life in two essential ways .	129.0857
on the one hand , he does not work for a large agency , but is almost always self-employed .	81.5536
as a free-lance investigator , the fictional detective is responsible to no one but himself and his client .	66.91384
for this reason , he appears as an independent and self-reliant figure , whose rugged individualism need not be pressed into the mold of a 9 to 5 routine .	130.37224
on the other hand , the fictional detective does not break strikes or handle divorce cases	268.2747
no client would ever think of asking him to do such things .	18.587421
whatever his original assignment , the fictional private eye ends up by investigating and solving a crime , usually a murder .	155.43533
operating as a one man police force in fact if not in name , he is at once more independent and more dedicated than the police themselves .	111.46348
he catches criminals not merely because he is paid to do so ( frequently he does not receive a fee at all ) , but because he enjoys his work , because he firmly believes that murder must be punished .	71.087105
thus the fictional detective is much more than a simple businessman .	35.542835
he is , first and foremost , a defender of public morals , a servant of society .	55.482758
it is this curious blend of rugged individualism and public service which accounts for the great appeal of the mythological detective .	108.4435
by virtue of his self-reliance , his individualism and his freedom from external restraint , the private eye is a perfect embodiment of the middle class conception of liberty , which amounts to doing what you please and let the devil take the hindmost .	91.63845
at the same time , because the personal code of the detective coincides with the legal dictates of his society , because he likes to catch criminals , he is in middle class eyes a virtuous man .	63.36843
in this way , the private detective gets the best of two possible worlds .	42.683952
he is a public servant but not a cop .	112.25293
in short , the fictional private eye is a specialized version of adam smith ' s ideal entrepreneur , the man whose private ambitions must always and everywhere promote the public welfare .	74.510376
in the mystery story , as in the wealth of nations , individualism and the social good are two sides of the same benevolent coin .	103.38646
there is only one catch to this idyllic arrangement adam smith was wrong .	373.25888
not only did the ideal entrepreneur not produce the greatest good for the greatest number , he ended by destroying himself , by giving birth to monopoly capitalism .	95.36027
the rise of the giant corporations in western europe and the united states dates from the period 1880-1900 .	18.124708
now , although the roots of the mystery story in serious literature go back as far as balzac , dickens , and poe , it was not until the closing decades of the 19th century that the private detective became an established figure in popular fiction .	58.55209
sherlock holmes , the ancestor of all private eyes , was born during the 1890s .	95.61465
thus the transformation of adam smith ' s ideal entrepreneur into a mythological detective coincides closely with the decline of the real entrepreneur in economic life .	70.85587
driven from the marketplace by the course of history , our hero disguises himself as a private detective .	46.376602
the birth of the myth compensates for the death of the ideal .	43.47877
even on the fictional level , however , the contradictions which give rise to the mystery story are not fully resolved .	69.95204
the individualism and public service of the private detective both stem from his dedication to a personal code of conduct he enforces the law without being told to do so .	88.56025
but his morality rests upon that of his society .	46.494453
the basic premise of all mystery stories is that the distinction between good and bad coincides with the distinction between legal and illegal .	55.169132
unfortunately , this assumption does not always hold good .	120.7098
as capitalism in the 20th century has become increasingly dependent upon force and violence for its survival , the private detective is placed in a serious dilemma .	38.989872
if he is good , he may not be legal	124.86692
if he is legal , he may not be good .	25.650972
it is the gradual unfolding and deepening of this contradiction which creates the inner dialectic of the evolution of the mystery story .	56.639244
with the advent of sir arthur conan doyle ' s sherlock holmes , the development of the modern private detective begins .	25.580574
he is very close to being a mental case .	26.25791
a brief list of the great detective ' s little idiosyncrasies would provide dr . freud with ample food for thought .	101.482025
holmes is addicted to the use of cocaine and other refreshing stimulants	27.23402
he is prone to semi-catatonic trances induced by the playing of the vioiln	51.295143
he is a recluse , an incredible egotist , a confirmed misogynist .	31.381811
holmes rebels against the social conventions of his day not on moral but rather on aesthetic grounds .	362.80002
his eccentricity begins as a defense against boredom .	2.3005238
it was in order to avoid the stuffy routine of middle class life that holmes became a detective in the first place .	79.07578
as he informs watson , `` my life is spent in one long effort to escape from the commonplaces of existence .	58.460808
these little problems help me to do so ' ' .	3.1635253
holmes is a public servant , to be sure	6.4995236
but the society which he serves bores him to tears .	45.76984
the curious relationship between holmes and scotland yard provides an important clue to the deeper significance of his eccentric behavior .	55.159718
although he is perfectly willing to cooperate with scotland yard , holmes has nothing but contempt for the intelligence and mentality of the police .	208.28061
they for their part are convinced that holmes is too `` unorthodox ' ' and `` theoretical ' ' to make a good detective .	38.333546
why do the police find holmes `` unorthodox ' ' ? ?	3.6238093
on the face of it , it is because he employs deductive techniques alien to official police routine .	288.0297
another , more interesting explanation , is hinted at by watson when he observes on several occasions that holmes would have made a magnificent criminal .	148.5598
watson ' s insight is verified by the mysterious link between holmes and his arch-opponent , dr . moriarty .	31.349289
the two men resemble each other closely in their cunning , their egotism , their relentlessness .	66.3341
the first series of sherlock holmes adventures ends with holmes and moriarty grappling together on the edge of a cliff .	53.838512
they are presumed to have plunged to a common grave in this fatal embrace .	90.88625
linked to holmes even in death , moriarty represents the alter-ego of the great detective , the image of what our hero might have become were he not a public servant .	48.838703
just as holmes the eccentric stands behind holmes the detective , so holmes the potential criminal lurks behind both .	134.73094
in the modern english `` whodunnit ' ' , this insinuation of latent criminality in the detective himself has almost entirely disappeared .	84.286545
hercule poirot and lord peter whimsey ( the respective creations of agatha christie and dorothy sayers ) have retained holmes ' egotism but not his zest for life and eccentric habits .	42.295326
it is true that they are also extremely dull .	9.117688
their dedication to the status quo has been affirmed at the expense of the fascinating but dangerous individualism of a sherlock holmes .	67.102165
the latter ' s real descendents were unable to take root in england	60.94905
they fled from the victorian parlor and made their way across the stormy atlantic .	85.84135
in the american `` hardboiled ' ' detective story of the ' 20s and ' 30s , the spirit of the mad genius from baker street lives on .	96.75363
like holmes , the american private eye rejects the social conventions of his time .	43.450035
but unlike holmes , he feels his society to be not merely dull but also corrupt .	124.12167
surrounded by crime and violence everywhere , the `` hardboiled ' ' private eye can retain his purity only through a life of self-imposed isolation .	36.826717
his alienation is far more acute than holmes '	4.6819005
he is not an eccentric but rather an outcast .	21.4086
with rex stout ' s nero wolfe , alienation is represented on a purely physical plane .	214.75723
wolfe refuses to ever leave his own house , and spends most of his time drinking beer and playing with orchids .	60.205463
more profound and more disturbing , however , is the moral isolation of raymond chandler ' s philip marlowe .	58.435303
in a society where everything is for sale , marlowe is the only man who cannot be bought .	61.28942
his tough honesty condemns him to a solitary and difficult existence .	97.30166
beaten , bruised and exhausted , he pursues the elusive killer through the demi-monde of high society and low morals , always alone , always despised .	100.9285
in the end , he gets his man , but no one seems to care	86.5161
a similar tone of underlying futility and despair pervades the spy thrillers of eric ambler and dominates the most famous of all american mystery stories , dashiell hammett ' s the maltese falcon .	36.800766
sam spade joins forces with a band of adventurers in search of a priceless jeweled statue of a falcon	59.663433
but when the bird is found at last , it turns out to be a fake .	65.87327
now the detective must save his own skin by informing on the girl he loves , who is also the real murderer .	66.09764
for sam spade , neither crime nor virtue pays	881.67633
moreover , it is increasingly difficult to distinguish between the two .	11.633395
because the private eye intends to save society in spite of himself , he invariably finds himself in trouble with the police .	72.94966
the latter are either too stupid to catch the killer or too corrupt to care .	116.02969
in either case , they do not appreciate the private detective ' s zeal .	37.5506
perry mason and hamilton burger , nero wolfe and inspector cramer spend more time fighting each other than they do in looking for the criminal .	128.93172
frequently enough , the police are themselves in league with the killer	382.95023
dashiell hammett ' s red harvest provides a classic example of this theme .	68.14711
but even when the police are honest , they do not trust the private eye .	48.572495
he is , like phillip marlowe , too alienated to be reliable .	44.543133
finally , in the maltese falcon among others , the clash between detective and police is carried to its logical conclusion sam spade becomes the chief murder suspect .	169.23141
in order to exonerate himself , he is compelled to find the real criminal , who happens to be his girl friend .	73.234375
what was only a vague suspicion in the case of sherlock holmes now appears as a direct accusation the private eye is in danger of turning into his opposite .	68.16004
it is the growing contradiction between individualism and public service in the mystery story which creates this fatal dilemma .	71.81499
by upholding his own personal code of behavior , the private detective has placed himself in opposition to a society whose fabric is permeated with crime and corruption .	64.40383
that society responds by condemning the private eye as a threat to the status quo , a potential criminal .	35.45263
if the detective insists upon retaining his personal standards , he must now do so in conscious defiance of his society .	53.243042
he must , in short , cease to be a detective and become a rebel .	116.62193
on the other hand , if he wishes to continue in his chosen profession , he must abandon his own code and sacrifice his precious individualism .	74.91622
dashiell hammett resolved this contradiction by ceasing to write mystery stories and turning to other pursuits .	150.31985
in order to save the mystery story , they have converted the private detective into an organization man .	63.00648
the first of two possible variations on this theme is symbolized by mickey spillane ' s mike hammer .	37.870293
at first glance , this hero seems to be more rather than less of an individualist than any of his predecessors .	60.891273
he kills when he pleases , takes his women where he finds them and always acts as judge , jury and executioner rolled into one .	233.55048
it will be shown that the objectives of the cooperative people in an organization determine the type of network required , because the type of network functions according to the characteristics of the messages enumerated in table 1 .	57.086605
great stress is placed on the role that the monitoring of information sending plays in maintaining the effectiveness of the network .	53.746185
by monitoring , we mean some system of control over the types of information sent from the various centers .	74.863304
as a word of caution , we should be aware that in actual practice no message is purely one of the four types , question , command , statement , or exclamation .	104.479515
for example , suppose a man wearing a $200 watch , driving a 1959 rolls royce , stops to ask a man on the sidewalk , `` what time is it ' ' ? ?	67.79031
this sentence would have most of the characteristics of a question , but it has some of the characteristics of a statement because the questioner has conveyed the fact that he has no faith in his own timepiece or the one attached to his car .	58.02995
if the man on the sidewalk is surprised at this question , it has served as an exclamation .	61.06518
also , since the man questioned feels a strong compulsion to answer ( and thereby avoid the consequences of being thought queer ) the question has assumed some measurable properties of a command .	179.41295
however , for convenience we will stick to the idea that information can be classified according to table 1 .	47.207664
on this basis , certain extreme kinds of networks will be discussed for illustrative purposes .	31.114813
presumably a cocktail party is expected to fulfill the host ' s desire to get together a number of people who are inadequately acquainted and thereby arrange for bringing the level of acquaintance up to adequacy for future cooperative endeavors .	72.03799
the party is usually in a room small enough so that all guests are within sight and hearing of one another .	124.320526
the information is furnished by each of the guests , is sent by oral broadcasting over the air waves , and is received by the ears .	77.396736
since the air is a continuum , the network of communication remains intact regardless of the positions or motions of the points ( the people ) in the net .	89.41991
as shown in figure 1 , there is a connection for communication between every pair of points .	47.84404
this , and other qualifications , make the cocktail party the most complete and most chaotic communication system ever dreamed up .	184.39323
all four types of message listed in table 1 are permitted , although decorum and cocktail tradition require holding the commands to a minimum , while exclamations having complimentary intonations are more than customarily encouraged .	111.5828
the completeness of the connections provide that , for n people , there are af lines of communication between the pairs , which can become a large number ( 1 , 225 ) for a party of fifty guests .	60.490143
looking at the diagram , we see that af connection lines come in to each member .	212.82196
thus the cocktail party would appear to be the ideal system , but there is one weakness .	114.79789
in spite of the dreams of the host for oneness in the group , the af incoming messages for each guest overload his receiving system beyond comprehension if n exceeds about six .	187.56673
the crowd consequently breaks up into temporary groups ranging in size from two to six , with a half-life for the cluster ranging from three to twenty minutes .	78.424095
for the occasion on which everyone already knows everyone else and the host wishes them to meet one or a few honored newcomers , then the `` open house ' ' system is advantageous because the honored guests are fixed connective points and the drifting guests make and break connections at the door .	114.31894
we consider a rural community as an assemblage of inhabited dwellings whose configuration is determined by the location and size of the arable land sites necessary for family subsistence .	48.21115
we assume for this illustration that the size of the land plots is so great that the distance between dwellings is greater than the voice can carry and that most of the communication is between nearest neighbors only , as shown in figure 2 .	47.63524
information beyond nearest neighbor is carried second- , third- , and fourth-hand as a distortable rumor .	18.446392
in figure 2 , the points in the network are designated by a letter accompanied by a number .	100.66895
the numbers indicate the number of nearest neighbors .	10.982658
it will be noted that point f has seven nearest neighbors , h and e have six , and p has only one , while the remaining points have intermediate numbers .	140.37619
in any social system in which communications have an importance comparable with that of production and other human factors , a point like f in figure 2 would ( other things being equal ) be the dwelling place for the community leader , while e and h would house the next most important citizens .	202.83295
a point like p gets information directly from n , but all information beyond n is indirectly relayed through n .	139.58057
the dweller at p is last to hear about a new cure , the slowest to announce to his neighbors his urgent distresses , the one who goes the farthest to trade , and the one with the greatest difficulty of all in putting over an idea or getting people to join him in a cooperative effort .	100.18929
since the hazards of poor communication are so great , p can be justified as a habitable site only on the basis of unusual productivity such as is made available by a waterfall for milling purposes , a mine , or a sugar maple camp .	81.33394
location theorists have given these matters much consideration .	6.470231
the networks for military communications are one of the best examples of networks which not only must be changed with the changes in objectives but also must be changed with the addition of new machines of war .	55.49723
they also furnish proof that , in modern war , message sending must be monitored .	166.12674
without monitoring , a military hookup becomes a noisy party .	17.686228
the need for monitoring became greater when radio was adopted for military signaling .	134.53218
alexander the great , who used runners as message carriers , did not have to worry about having every officer in his command hear what he said and having hundreds of them comment at once .	153.0951
as time has passed and science has progressed , the speed of military vehicles has increased , the range of missiles has been extended , the use of target-hunting noses on the projectiles has been adopted , and the range and breadth of message sending has increased .	63.647667
next to the old problem of the slowness of decision making , network structure seems to be paramount , and without monitoring no network has value .	156.05107
on the parade ground the net may be similar to that shown in figure 3 .	60.478577
the monitoring is the highest and most restrictive of any organization in existence .	66.65837
no questions , statements , or explanations are permitted -- only commands .	216.9418
commands go only from an officer to the man of nearest lower rank .	127.43715
the same command is repeated as many times as there are levels in rank from general to corporal .	120.85788
all orders originate with the officer of highest rank and terminate with action of the men in the ranks .	51.62337
even the officer in charge , be it a captain ( for small display ) or a general , is restrained by monitoring .	230.18434
this is done for simplicity of commands and to bring the hidden redundancy up to where misunderstanding has almost zero possibility .	453.54868
are few in number , briefly worded , all different in sound	961.1007
and are combinable into sequences which permit any marching maneuver that could be desired on a parade ground .	50.12711
this monitoring is necessary because , on a parade ground , everyone can hear too much , and without monitoring a confused social event would develop .	106.55691
with troops dispersed on fields of battle rather than on the parade ground , it may seem that a certain amount of monitoring is automatically enforced by the lines of communication .	49.513966
years ago this was true , but with the replacement of wires or runners by radio and radar ( and perhaps television ) , these restrictions have disappeared and now again too much is heard .	124.86145
in contrast to cocktail parties , military organizations , even in the field , are more formal .	62.86396
in the extreme and oversimplified example suggested in figure 3 , the organization is more easily understood and more predictable in behavior .	65.25632
a military organization has an objective chosen by the higher command .	123.42301
this objective is adhered to throughout the duration of the action .	7.652884
the connective system , or network , is tailored to meet the requirements of the objective , and it is therefore not surprising that a military body acting as a single coordinated unit has a different communication network than a factory , a college , or a rural village .	62.55084
the assumptions upon which the example shown in figure 3 is based are ( a ) one man can direct about six subordinates if the subordinates are chosen carefully so that they do not need too much personal coaching , indoctrinating , etc . .	95.57204
( b ) a message runs too great a risk of being distorted if it is to be relayed more than about six consecutive times .	64.2493
( c ) decisions of a general kind are made by the central command .	111.31879
and ( d ) all action of a physical kind pertinent to the mission is relegated to the line of men on the lower rank .	64.225685
these assumptions lead to an organization with one man at the top , six directly under him , six under each of these , and so on until there are six levels of personnel .	97.390915
the number of people acting as one body by this scheme gives a surprisingly large army of 55 , 987 men .	167.02844
this organizational network would be of no avail if there were no regulations pertaining to the types of message sent .	49.611217
of types of message listed in table 1 , commands and statements are the only ones sent through the vertical network shown in figure 3 .	94.53551
a further regulation is that commands always go down , unaccompanied by statements , and statements always go up , unaccompanied by commands .	72.979546
questions and , particularly , exclamations are usually channeled along informal , horizontal lines not indicated in figure 3 and seldom are carried beyond the nearest neighbor .	110.85731
it will readily be seen that in this suggested network ( not materially different from some of the networks in vogue today ) greater emphasis on monitoring is implied than is usually put into practice .	225.7791
furthermore , the network in figure 3 is only the basic net through which other networks pertaining to logistics and the like are interlaced .	179.00917
not discussed here are some military problems of modern times such as undersea warfare , where the surveillance , sending , transmitting , and receiving are all so inadequate that networks and decision making are not the bottlenecks .	155.20908
such problems are of extreme interest as well as importance and are so much like fighting in a rain forest or guerrilla warfare at night in tall grass that we might have to re-examine primitive conflicts for what they could teach .	88.811905
this is an unsolved problem which probably has never been seriously investigated , although one frequently hears the comment that we have insufficient specialists of the kind who can compete with the germans or swiss , for example , in precision machinery and mathematics , or the finns in geochemistry .	62.83561
we hear equally fervent concern over the belief that we have not enough generalists who can see the over-all picture and combine our national skills and knowledge for useful purposes .	77.93938
this problem of the optimum balance in the relative numbers of generalists and specialists can be investigated on a communicative network basis .	45.917557
since the difficulty of drawing the net is great , we will merely discuss it .	124.65894
first , we realize that a pure specialist does not exist .	19.7044
but , for practical purposes , we have people who can be considered as such .	127.78711
for example , there are persons who are in physical science , in the field of mineralogy , trained in crystallography , who use only x-rays , applying only the powder technique of x-ray diffraction , to clay minerals only , and who have spent the last fifteen years concentrating on the montmorillonites	105.70071
or persons in the social sciences in the field of anthropology , studying the lung capacity of seven andean indians .	66.158775
so we see that a specialist is a man who knows more and more about less and less as he develops , as contrasted to the generalist , who knows less and less about more and more .	69.54665
american democratic thought , pointed up the relation between the protestant movement in this country and the development of a social religion , which he called the american democratic faith .	28.444466
those familiar with his work will remember that he placed the incipience of the democratic faith at around 1850 .	76.89604
and he describes it as a balanced polarity between the notions of the free individual and what he called the fundamental law .	49.9443
i want to say more about gabriel ' s so-called fundamental law .	35.398247
but first i want to quote him on the relationship that he found between religion and politics in this country and what happened to it .	60.88506
he points out that from the time of jackson on through world war 1 , , evangelical protestantism was a dominant influence in the social and political life of america .	40.425404
he terms this early enthusiasm `` romantic christianity ' ' and concludes that its similarity to democratic beliefs of that day is so great that `` the doctrine of liberty seems but a secular version of its counterpart in evangelical protestantism ' ' .	52.328705
let me quote him even more fully , for his analysis is important to my theme .	78.17163
he says `` beside the protestant philosophy of progress , as expressed in radical or conservative millenarianism , should be placed the doctrine of the democratic faith which affirmed it to be the duty of the destiny of the united states to assist in the creation of a better world by keeping lighted the beacon of democracy ' ' .	51.711742
he specifies , `` in the middle period of the nineteenth century it was colored by christian supernaturalism , in the twentieth century it was affected by naturalism .	26.932083
but in every period it has been humanism ' ' .	4.2674575
and let me add , utopianism , also .	1688.2954
some fourteen or fifteen years ago , in an essay i called the leader follows -- where ? ?	152.83717
i used his polarity to illustrate what i thought had happened to us in that form of liberalism we call progressivism .	92.32331
it seemed to me that the liberals had scrapped the balanced polarity and reposed both liberty and the fundamental law in the common man .	57.1414
that is to say gabriel ' s fundamental law had been so much modified by this time that it was neither fundamental nor law any more .	96.11479
it is a weakness of gabriel ' s analysis that he never seems to realize that his so-called fundamental law had already been cut loose from its foundations when it was adapted to democracy .	76.44057
and with progressivism the religion of humanity was replacing what gabriel called christian supernaturalism .	357.1101
and the common man was developing mythic power , or charisma , on his own .	45.82183
during the decade that followed , the common man , as that piece put it , grew uncomfortable as the voice of god and fled from behind saint woodrow ( wilson ) only to learn from science , to his shocked relief that after all there was no god he had to speak for and that he was just an animal anyhow -- that there was a chemical formula for him , and that too much couldn ' t be expected of him .	89.61446
the socialism implicit in the slogan of the roosevelt revolution , freedom from want and fear , seems a far cry from the individualism of the first amendment to the constitution , or of the jacksonian frontier .	90.653435
what had happened to the common man ? ?	1.0946015
french egalitarianism had had only nominal influence in this country before the days of popularism .	59.808163
the riotous onrush of industrialism after the war for southern independence and the general secular drift to the religion of humanity , however , prepared the way for a reception of the french revolution ' s socialistic offspring of one sort of another .	58.37693
the first of which to find important place in our federal government was the graduated income tax under wilson .	225.01869
moreover the centralization of our economy during the 1920s , the dislocations of the depression , the common ethos of materialism everywhere , all contributed in various ways to the face-lifting that replaced mike fink and the great gatsby with the anonymous physiognomy of the little people .	56.498142
however , it is important to trace the philosophy of the french revolution to its sources to understand the common democratic origin of individualism and socialism and the influence of the latter on the former .	60.939693
that john locke ' s philosophy of the social contract fathered the american revolution with its declaration of independence , i believe , we generally accept .	55.52092
yet , after rousseau had given the social contract a new twist with his notion of the general will , the same philosophy , it may be said , became the idea source of the french revolution also .	104.55493
the importance of rousseau ' s twist has not always been clear to us , however .	49.261574
this notion of the general will gave rise to the commune of paris in the revolution and later brought napoleon to dictatorship .	73.83774
and it is clearly argued by lord percy of newcastle , in his remarkable long essay , the heresy of democracy , and in a more general way by voegelin , in his new science of politics , that this same rousseauan idea , descending through european democracy , is the source of marx ' s theory of the dictatorship of the proletariat .	63.22115
this is important to understanding the position that doctrinaire liberals found themselves in after world war 2 , and our great democratic victory that brought no peace .	143.2311
the long road that had taken liberals in this country into the social religion of democracy , into a worship of man , led logically to the marxist dream of a classless society under a socialist state .	69.39265
and the ussr existed as the revolutionary experiment in radical socialism , the ultimate exemplar .	36.742218
and by the time the war ended , liberal leadership in this country was spiritually marxist .	54.567238
we will recall that the still confident liberals of the truman administration gathered with other western utopians in san francisco to set up the legal framework , finally and at last , to rationalize war -- to rationalize want and fear -- out of the world the united nations .	99.94828
we of the liberal-led world got all set for peace and rehabilitation .	48.21616
then suddenly we found ourselves in the middle of another fight , an irrational , an indecent , an undeclared and immoral war with our strongest ( and some had thought noblest ) ally .	140.40793
during the next five years the leaders of the fair deal reluctantly backed down from the optimistic expectations of the new deal .	73.21654
during the next five years liberal leaders in the united states sank in the cumulative confusion attendant upon and manifested in a negative policy of containment -- and the bitterest irony -- enforced and enforceable only by threat of a weapon that we felt the greatest distaste for but could not abandon the atom bomb .	102.60435
in 1952 , it will be remembered , the g . o . p . without positive program campaigned on the popular disillusionment with liberal leadership and won overwhelmingly .	56.626446
all of this , i know , is recent history familiar to you .	414.0411
but i have been at some pains to review it as the drama of the common man , to point up what happened to him under eisenhower ' s leadership .	76.96413
a perceptive journalist , sam lubell , has phrased it in the title of one of his books as the revolt of the moderates .	65.28694
he opens his discourse , however , with a review of the eisenhower inaugural festivities at which a sympathetic press had assembled its massive talents , all primed to catch some revelation of the emerging new age .	116.93572
the show was colorful , indeed , exuberant , but the press for all its assiduity could detect no note of a fateful rendezvous with destiny .	134.73859
lubell offers his book as an explanation of why there was no clue .	111.92524
and i select this sentence as its pertinent summation `` in essence the drama of his ( eisenhower ' s ) presidency can be described as the ordeal of a nation turned conservative and struggling -- thus far with but limited and precarious success -- to give effective voice and force to that conservatism ' ' .	115.758575
i will assume that we are all aware of the continuing struggle , with its limited and precarious success , toward conservatism .	60.654514
it has moved on various levels , it has been clamorous and confused .	51.1777
obviously there has been no agreement on what american conservatism is , or rather , what it should be .	47.471752
for it was neglected , not to say nascent , when the struggle began .	169.76096
i saw a piece the other day assailing william buckley , author of man and god at yale and publisher of the national review , as no conservative at all , but an old liberal .	84.03985
but i ' m not here to define conservatism .	262.14536
what i am here to do is to report on the gyrations of the struggle -- a struggle that amounts to self-redefinition -- to see if we can predict its future course .	136.34297
one of the obvious conclusions we can make on the basis of the last election , i suppose , is that we , the majority , were dissatisfied with eisenhower conservatism .	66.32679
though , to be sure , we gave kennedy no very positive approval in the margin of his preferment .	169.31874
this is , however , symptomatic of our national malaise .	37.564995
but before i try to diagnose it , i would offer other evidence .	211.65874
i will mention two volumes of specific comment on this malaise that appeared last year .	89.3509
the earlier of them was an unofficial enterprise , sponsored by life magazine , under the title of the national purpose .	36.502686
the contributors to this testament were all well-known a former democratic candidate for president , a new deal poet , the magazine ' s chief editorial writer , two newspaper columnists , head of a national broadcasting company , a popular protestant evangelist , etc . .	66.83954
what i want to point out here is that all of them are ex-liberals , or modified liberals , with perhaps one exception .	74.21256
i suppose we might classify billy graham as an old liberal .	30.68155
and i would further note that they all -- with one exception again -- sang in one key or another the same song .	176.79808
its refrain was `` let us return to the individualistic democracy of our forefathers for our salvation ' ' .	32.41214
adlai stevenson expressed some reservations about this return .	6.3684955
only walter lippman envisioned the possibility of our having `` outlived most of what we used to regard as the program of our national purposes ' ' .	60.4934
but the most notable thing about the incantation of these ex-liberals was that the one-time shibboleth of socialism was conspicuously absent .	54.63974
the second specific comment was the report of eisenhower ' s commission on national goals , titled goals for americans .	142.34415
they , perhaps , gave the pitch of their position in the preface where it was said that eisenhower requested that the commission be administered by the american assembly of columbia university , because it was non-partisan .	65.86642
