the commission seems to represent the viewpoint of what i would call the unconscious liberal , but not unconscious enough , to invoke the now taboo symbolism of socialism .	83.66528
and here again we hear the same refrain mentioned above `` the paramount goal of the united states set long ago was to guard the rights of the individual , ensure his development , enlarge his opportunity ' ' .	83.9052
this group is secularist and their program tends to be technological .	16.78984
but it is the need to undertake these testaments that i would submit here as symptom of the common man ' s malaise .	54.461197
and let me add murray ' s new book as another symptom of it , particularly so in view of the attention time magazine gave it when it came out recently .	151.19768
father murray goes back to the declaration of independence , too , though i may add , with considerably more historical perception .	103.606415
i will reserve discussion of it for a moment , however , to return to president kennedy .	33.893887
as symptomatic of the common man ' s malaise , he is most significant a liberal and a catholic , elected by the skin of his teeth .	63.48233
does that not suggest to you an uncertain and uneasy , not to say confused , state of the public mind ? ?	74.00248
what is the common man ' s complaint ? ?	16.221684
let ' s take a panoramic look back over the course we have come .	53.313427
has not that way been lit always by the lamp of liberalism up until the turning back under eisenhower ? ?	191.26213
and the basic character of that liberalism has been spiritual rather than economic .	94.37913
ralph gabriel gave it the name of protestant philosophy of progress .	115.25181
but there ' s a subjective side to that utopian outlook .	81.27943
does our society have a runaway , uncontrollable growth of technology which may end our civilization , or a normal , healthy growth ? ?	85.89224
here there may be an analogy with cancer we can detect cancers by their rapidly accelerating growth , determinable only when related to the more normal rate of healthy growth .	71.123184
should the accelerating growth of technology then warn us ? ?	18.98792
and almost the only `` cure ' ' is early detection and removal .	229.04457
one way to determine whether we have so dangerous a technology would be to check the strength of our society ' s organs to see if their functioning is as healthy as before .	113.216125
so an objective look at our present procedures may move us to consider seriously this possibly analogous situation .	314.42953
in any event , whether society may have cancer , or merely a virus infection , the `` disease ' ' , we shall find , is political , economical , social , and even medical .	63.368763
have not our physical abilities already deteriorated because of the more sedentary lives we are now living ? ?	61.132244
hence the prime issue , as i see it , is whether a democratic or free society can master technology for the benefit of mankind , or whether technology will rule and develop its own society compatible with its own needs as a force of nature .	91.19043
we are already committed to establishing man ' s supremacy over nature and everywhere on earth , not merely in the limited social-political-economical context we are fond of today .	79.3441
otherwise , we go on endlessly trying to draw the line , color and other , as to which kind of man we wish to see dominate .	118.10894
we have proved so able to solve technological problems that to contend we cannot realize a universal goal in the immediate future is to be extremely shortsighted , if nothing else .	54.942677
we must believe we have the ability to affect our own destinies otherwise why try anything ? ?	340.10165
so in these pages the term `` technology ' ' is used to include any and all means which could amplify , project , or augment man ' s control over himself and over other men .	98.26875
naturally this includes all communication forms , e . g . languages , or any social , political , economic or religious structures employed for such control .	36.290016
properly mindful of all the cultures in existence today throughout the world , we must employ these resources without war or violent revolution .	160.86415
if we were creating a wholly new society , we could insist that our social , political , economic and philosophic institutions foster rather than hamper man	96.00073
but we cannot start off with a clean slate .	63.6038
so we must first analyze our present institutions with respect to the effect of each on man ' s major needs .	52.532032
asked which institution most needs correction , i would say the corporation as it exists in america today .	78.28286
at first glance this appears strange of all people , was not america founded by rugged individualists who established a new way of life still inspiring `` undeveloped ' ' societies abroad ? ?	98.107086
but hear harrison e . salisbury , former moscow correspondent of the new york times , and author of `` to moscow -- and beyond ' ' .	59.31337
in a book review of `` the soviet cultural offensive ' ' , he says , `` long before the state department organized its bureaucracy into an east-west contacts staff in order to wage a cultural counter-offensive within soviet borders , the sharp cutting-edge of american culture had carved its mark across the russian steppes , as when the enterprising promoters of ' porgy and bess ' overrode the state department to carry the contemporary ' cultural warfare ' behind the enemy lines .	69.68581
they were not diplomats or jazz musicians , or even organizers of reading-rooms and photo-montage displays , but rugged capitalist entrepreneurs like henry ford , hugh cooper , thomas campbell , the international harvester co . , and david w . griffith .	32.684517
their kind created an american culture superior to any in the world , an industrial and technological culture which penetrated russia as it did almost every corner of the earth without a nickel from the federal treasury or a single governmental specialist to contrive directives or program a series of consultations of interested agencies .	107.014885
this favorable image of america in the minds of russian men and women is still there despite years of energetic anti-american propaganda ' '	66.87369
perhaps the public ' s present attitude toward business stems from the fact that the `` rugged capitalist entrepreneur ' ' no more exists in america .	50.70508
in his stead is a milquetoast version known as `` the corporation ' ' .	17.206247
but even if we cannot see the repulsive characteristics in this new image of america , foreigners can	101.025375
and our loss of `` prestige ' ' abroad is the direct result .	127.61885
no amount of ballyhoo will cover up the sordid facts .	40.596996
if we want respect from ourselves or others , we will have to earn it .	18.924923
first , let us realize that whatever good this set-up achieved in earlier times , now the corporation per se cannot take economic leadership .	252.01184
businesses must develop as a result of the ideas , energies and ambitions of an individual having purpose and comprehensive ability within one mind .	302.29254
when we `` forced ' ' individuals to assume the corporate structure by means of taxes and other legal statutes , we adopted what i would term `` pseudo-capitalism ' ' and so took a major step toward socialism .	71.23091
the biggest loss , of course , was the individual ' s lessened desire and ability to give his services to the growth of his company and our economy .	47.76442
socialism , i grant , has a definite place in our society .	35.22643
but let us not complain of the evils of capitalism by referring to a form that is not truly capitalistic .	62.464043
some forms of capitalism do indeed work -- superb organizations , a credit to any society .	337.48474
but the pseudo-capitalism which dictates our whole economy as well as our politics and social life , will not stand close scrutiny .	51.54004
its pretense to operate in the public interest is little more than a sham .	42.044056
it serves only its own stockholders and poorly at that .	169.25917
as a creative enterprise , its abilities are primarily in `` swallowing ' ' creative enterprises developed outside its own organization ( an ability made possible by us , and almost mandatory ) .	171.14789
as to benefits to employees , it is notorious for its callous disregard except where it depends on them for services .	139.79712
the corporation in america is in reality our form of socialism , vying in a sense with the other socialistic form that has emerged within governmental bureaucracy .	81.09368
but while the corporation has all the disadvantages of the socialist form of organization ( so cumbersome it cannot constructively do much of anything not compatible with its need to perpetuate itself and maintain its status quo ) , unluckily it does not have the desirable aspect of socialism , the motivation to operate for the benefit of society as a whole .	91.31192
so we are faced with a vast network of amorphous entities perpetuating themselves in whatever manner they can , without regard to the needs of society , controlling society and forcing upon it a regime representing only the corporation ' s needs for survival .	81.163895
the corporation has a limited , specific place in our society .	25.415524
ideally speaking , it should be allowed to operate only where the public has a great stake in the continuity of supply or services , and where the actions of a single proprietor are secondary to the needs of society .	74.6218
examples are in public utilities , making military aircraft and accessories , or where the investment and risk for a proprietorship would be too great for a much needed project impossible to achieve by any means other than the corporate form , e . g . constructing major airports or dams .	69.52626
thus , if corporations are not to run away with us , they must become quasi-governmental institutions , subject to public control and needs .	74.924225
in all other areas , private initiative of the `` proprietorship ' ' type should be urged to produce the desired goods and services .	49.05042
avoiding runaway technology can be done only by assuring a humane society	141.23662
and for this human beings must be firmly in control of the economics on which our society rests .	95.65871
such genuine human leadership the proprietorship can offer , corporations cannot .	451.34055
corporations react violently to short-range stimuli , e . g . , quarterly and annual dividend reports .	17.808626
proprietorships can establish a unity and integrity of control	231.2422
proprietorships can establish a meaningful identity , representing a human personality , and thus establish sincere relationships with customers and community .	73.32376
corporations are apt by nature to be impersonal , inhumane , shortsighted and almost exclusively profit-motivated , a picture they could scarcely afford to present to the public .	76.98593
the proprietor is able to create a leadership impossible in the corporate structure with its board of directors and stockholders .	65.33228
leadership is lacking in our society because it has no legitimate place to develop .	58.50096
men continuously at the head of growing enterprises can acquire experiences of the most varied , complicated and trying type so that at maturation they have developed the competence and willingness to accept the personal responsibility so sorely needed now .	217.12706
hence government must establish greater controls upon corporations so that their activities promote what is deemed essential to the national interest .	63.79075
proprietorships should get the tax advantages now accruing to corporations , e . g . the chance to accumulate capital so vital for growth .	57.602722
corporations should pay added taxes , to be used for educational purposes ( not necessarily of the formal type ) .	110.53648
the right to leave legacies should be substantially reduced and ultimately eliminated .	53.804276
to perpetuate wealth control led by small groups of individuals who played no role in its creation prevents those with real initiative from coming to the fore , and is basically anti-democratic .	83.63341
when the proprietor dies , the establishment should become a corporation until it is either acquired by another proprietor or the government decides to drop it .	114.307
strikes should be declared illegal against corporations because disagreements would have to be settled by government representatives acting as controllers of the corporation whose responsibility to the state would now be defined against proprietorship because employees and proprietors must be completely interdependent , as they are each a part of the whole .	84.92153
strikes threatening the security of the proprietorship , if internally motivated , prevent a healthy relationship .	113.008675
certainly external forces should not be applied arbitrarily out of mere power available to do so .	90.99128
if we cannot stop warfare in our own economic system , how can we expect to abolish it internationally ? ?	53.797825
these proposals would go far toward creating the economic atmosphere favoring growth of the individual , who , in turn , would help us to cope with runaway technology .	84.515175
individual human strength is needed to pit against an inhuman condition .	38.42996
we are tempted to blame others for our problems rather than look them straight in the face and realize they are of our own making and possible of solution only by ourselves with the help of desperately needed , enlightened , competent leaders .	165.22157
persons developed in today ' s corporations cannot hope to serve here -- a judgment based on experiences of my own in business and in activities outside .	240.45764
in my own company , in effect a partnership , although legally a corporation , i have been able to do many things for my employees which `` normal ' ' corporations of comparable size and nature would have been unable to do .	63.11377
also , i am convinced that if my company were a sole proprietorship instead of a partnership , i would have been even abler to solve long-range problems for myself and my fellow-employees .	91.41229
any abilities i may have were achieved in their present shape from experience in sharing in the growth and control of my business , coupled with raising my family .	120.32632
this combined experience , on a foundation of very average , i assure you , intelligence and background , has helped me do things many well-informed people would bet heavily against .	189.31575
perhaps a list of some of the `` practices ' ' of my company will help here .	37.7499
the company grew out of efforts by two completely inexperienced men in their late twenties , neither having a formal education applicable to , or experience in , manufacturing or selling our type of articles .	218.52666
from an initial investment of $1 , 200 in 1943 , it has grown , with no additional capital investment , to a present value estimated by some as exceeding $10 , 000 , 000 ( we don ' t disclose financial figures to the public ) .	71.055016
its growth continues steadily on a par with past growth	773.5125
our pin-curl clips and self-locking nuts achieved dominance in just a few years time , despite substantial , well established competition .	146.54608
during the last years of woodrow wilson ' s administration , a red scare developed in our country .	71.38987
many americans reacted irrationally to the challenge of russia and turned to the repression of ideas by force .	102.97043
postmaster general burleson set about to protect the american people against radical propaganda that might be spread through the mails .	85.68447
attorney general palmer made a series of raids that sent more than 4 , 000 so-called radicals to the jails , in direct violation of their constitutional rights .	55.332
then , not many years later , the un-american activities committee , under the leadership of martin dies , pilloried hundreds of decent , patriotic citizens .	97.83276
anyone who tried to remedy some of the most glaring defects in our form of democracy was denounced as a traitorous red whose real purpose was the destruction of our government .	95.579834
this hysteria reached its height under the leadership of senator joseph mccarthy .	8.225386
demagogues of this sort found communist bogeys lurking behind any new idea that would run counter to stereotyped notions .	117.000916
new ideas were dangerous and must be repressed , no matter how .	34.22833
those who would suppress dangerous thoughts , credit ideas with high potency .	96.615746
they give strict interpretation to william james ' statement that `` every idea that enters the mind tends to express itself ' ' .	48.788605
they seem to believe that a person will act automatically as soon as he contacts something new .	263.03876
hence , the only defensible procedure is to repress any and every notion , unless it gives evidence that it is perfectly safe .	71.80019
despite this danger , however , we are informed on every hand that ideas , not machines , are our finest tools	301.69495
they are priceless even though they cannot be recorded on a ledger page	161.00774
they are the most valuable of commodities -- and the most salable , for their demand far exceeds supply .	153.40324
so all-important are ideas , we are told , that persons successful in business and happy in social life usually fall into two classes those who invent new ideas of their own , and those who borrow , beg , or steal from others .	113.33625
seemingly , with an unrestricted flow of ideas , all will be well , and we are even assured that `` an idea a day will keep the sheriff away ' ' .	70.92148
that , however , may also bring the police , if the thinking does not meet with social approval .	121.23309
criminals , as well as model citizens , exercise their minds .	253.74667
merely having a mental image of some sort is not the all-important consideration .	84.30323
of course , there must be clarity a single distinct impression is more valuable than many fuzzy ones .	109.30705
the writer took a class of college students to the state hospital for the mentally ill in st . joseph , missouri .	46.858566
an inmate , a former university professor , expounded to us , logically and clearly , that someone was pilfering his thoughts .	85.95026
he appealed to us to bring his case to the attention of the authorities that justice might be done .	48.24193
despite the clarity of his presentation , his idea was not of einsteinian calibre .	19.69709
true , ideas are important , perhaps life ' s most precious treasures .	26.497055
but have we not gone overboard in stressing their significance ? ?	113.93169
have we not actually developed idea worship ? ?	1.069503
ideas we must have , and we seek them everywhere .	224.73431
here we find stored the wisdom of great minds .	110.54993
but are all these works worthy of consideration ? ?	42.43016
shakespeare ' s wit and wisdom , his profound insight into human nature , have stood the test of centuries .	66.10066
but was he infallible in all things ? ?	1.1919379
what of his treatment of the jew in the merchant of venice ? ?	31.270655
shakespeare gives us a vivid picture of shylock , but probably he never saw a jew , unless in some of his travels .	76.56872
the jews had been banished from england in 1290 and were not permitted to return before 1655 , when shakespeare had been dead for thirty-nine years .	42.865314
if any had escaped expulsion by hiding , they certainly would not frequent the market-place .	77.53108
shakespeare did not usually invent the incidents in his plays , but borrowed them from old stories , ballads , and plays , wove them together , and then breathed into them his spark of life .	57.339123
rather than from a first-hand study of jewish people , his delineation of shylock stems from a collection of italian stories , il pecorone , published in 1558 , although written almost two centuries earlier .	60.736652
he could learn at second hand from books , but could not thus capture the real jewish spirit .	106.75321
harris j . griston , in shaking the dust from shakespeare ( 216 ) , writes `` there is not a word spoken by shylock which one would expect from a real jew ' ' .	62.249718
he took the story of the pound of flesh and had to fasten it on someone .	70.58528
no jew was on hand to boycott his financially struggling theater .	385.2433
it would have been unwise policy , for instance , to apply the pound-of-flesh characterization to the thrifty scotchman .	33.404667
just as now anyone may hurl insults at a citizen of mars , or even of tikopia , and no senatorial investigation will result .	74.499825
shakespeare does not tell us that shylock was an aberrant individual .	267.73718
he sets him forth as being typical of the group .	11.205358
he tells of his `` jewish heart ' ' -- not a shylockian heart	63.393486
this would make anyone crafty and cruel , capable of fiendish revenge .	15.0094595
if living jews were unavailable for study , the bible was at hand .	57.196877
reading the old testament would have shown the dramatist that the ideas attributed to shylock were abhorrent to the jews .	76.02323
are we better off for having shakespeare ' s idea of shylock ? ?	18.405611
studying the merchant of venice in high school and college has given many young people their notions about jews .	118.45575
does this help the non-jew to understand this group ? ?	37.85324
thomas de torquemada , inquisitor-general of the spanish inquisition , put many persons to death .	75.388824
would we gain by keeping alive his memory and besmirching today ' s roman catholics by saying he had a catholic heart ? ?	87.53196
let his bones and his memory rest in the fifteenth century where they belong	70.36077
he is out of place in our times .	2.9002113
shakespeare ' s shylock , too , is of dubious value in the modern world .	52.33363
ideas , in and of themselves , are not necessarily the greatest good .	75.03813
a successful businessman recently prefaced his address to a luncheon group with the statement that all economists should be sent to the hospitals for the mentally deranged where they and their theories might rot together .	90.835
will his words come to be treasured and quoted through the years ? ?	136.7383
frequently we are given assurance that automatically all ideas will be sifted and resifted and in the end only the good ones will survive .	94.4163
but is that not like going to a chemistry laboratory and blindly pouring out liquids and powders from an array of bottles and then , after stirring , expecting a new wonder drug inevitably to result ? ?	97.00054
what of the efficiency of this natural instrument of free discussion ? ?	73.86192
is there some magic in it that assures results ? ?	162.95459
when peter b . kyne ( pride of palomar , 43 ) informed us in 1921 that we had an instinctive dislike for the japanese , did the heated debates of the californians settle the truth or falsity of the proposition ? ?	42.492542
the leopard ' s spots came from the pen of thomas dixon in 1902 , and in this he announced an `` unchangeable ' ' law .	50.865612
if a child had a single drop of negro blood , he would revert to the ancestral line which , except as slaves under a superior race , had not made one step of progress in 3 , 000 years .	135.09248
that doctrine has been accepted by many , but has it produced good results ? ?	127.56786
in the same vein , a certain short-story plot has been overworked .	75.27219
the son and heir of a prominent family marries a girl who has tell-tale shadows on the half-moons of her finger nails .	46.017082
in time she presents her aristocratic husband with a coal-black child .	73.279434
is the world better for having this idea thrust upon it ? ?	73.84009
will argument and debate decide its truth or falsity ? ?	10.6812105
for answers to such questions we must turn to the anthropologists , the biologists , the historians , the psychologists , and the sociologists .	30.000237
long ago they consigned the notions of kyne and dixon to the scrap heap .	30.47204
false ideas surfeit another sector of our life .	3.894144
for several generations much fiction has appeared dealing with the steprelationship .	24.987028
the stepmother , almost without exception , has been presented as a cruel ogress .	31.448614
children , conditioned by this mistaken notion , have feared stepmothers , while adults , by their antagonistic attitudes , have made the role of the substitute parents a difficult one .	99.00926
debate is not likely to resolve the tensions and make the lot of the stepchild a happier one .	71.91916
research , on the other hand , has shown many stepmothers to be eminently successful , some far better than the real mothers .	72.53249
helen deutsch informed us ( the psychology of women , vol . 2 , , 434 ) that in all cultures `` the term ' stepmother ' automatically evokes deprecatory implications ' ' , a conclusion accepted by many .	76.81656
will mere debate on that proposition , even though it be free and untrammeled , remove the dross and leave a residue of refined gold ? ?	81.99676
that is questionable , to say the least .	48.739677
research into several cultures has proven her position to be a mistaken one .	26.198496
but ideas , just for the sake of having them , are not enough .	100.14669
in the 1930 ' s , cures for the depression literally flooded washington .	139.68684
for a time the president received hundreds of them every day , most of them worthless .	58.106018
ideas need to be tested , and not merely by argument and debate .	214.36693
when some question arises in the medical field concerning cancer , for instance , we do not turn to free and open discussion as in a political campaign .	121.667145
we have recourse to the scientifically-trained specialist in the laboratory .	41.02991
the merits of the salk anti-polio vaccine were not established on the forensic platform or in newspaper editorials , but in the laboratory and by tests in the field on thousands of children .	68.38773
our presidential campaigns provide much debate and argument .	6.7167225
but is the result new barnsful of tested knowledge on the basis of which we can with confidence solve our domestic and international problems ? ?	53.8896
man , we are told , is endowed with reason and is capable of distinguishing good from bad .	98.53254
but what a super-herculean task it is to winnow anything of value from the mud-beplastered arguments used so freely , particularly since such common use is made of cliches and stereotypes , in themselves declarations of intellectual bankruptcy .	192.07188
we are reminded , however , that freedom of thought and discussion , the unfettered exchange of ideas , is basic under our form of government .	147.44025
assuredly in our political campaigns there is freedom to think , to examine any and all issues , and to speak without restraint .	87.22351
may we state with confidence that in such an exhibition a republic will find its greatest security ? ?	98.176765
we must not forget , to be sure , that free discussion and debate have produced beneficial results .	164.08229
in truth , we can say that this broke the power of senator joseph mccarthy , who was finally exposed in full light to the american people .	39.96775
if he had been `` liquidated ' ' in some way , he would have become a martyr , a rallying point for people who shared his ideas .	56.1925
debate in the political arena can be productive of good .	72.340935
but it is a clumsy and wasteful process it can produce negative results but not much that is positive .	85.44526
debate rid us of mccarthy but did not give us much that is positive .	90.26639
it did something to clear the ground , but it erected no striking new structure	323.97052
it did not even provide the architect ' s plan for anything new .	54.768105
in the field of the natural sciences , scientifically verified data are quite readily available and any discussion can be shortened with good results .	96.64541
in the field of the social sciences a considerable fund of tested knowledge has been accumulated that can be used to good advantage .	87.80678
by no means would we discourage the production of ideas they provide raw materials with which to work	115.32388
they provide stimulations that lead to further production .	11.60402
the president ' s personality would have opened that office to him .	169.6933
and for the first time a representative of the highest office in the land would have been liable to the charge that he had attempted to make it a successorship by inheritance .	48.24093
it is testimony to the deep respect in which mr . eisenhower was held by members of all parties that the moral considerations raised by his approach to the matter were not explicitly to be broached .	87.31268
these began to be apparent in a press conference held during the second illness in order that the consulting specialists might clarify the president ' s condition for the nation .	47.533657
and if howard rutstein felt impelled thereafter to formulate the ethics of the medical profession , his article in the atlantic monthly accomplished a good deal more .	57.034145
it forced us to fix the responsibility for the position in which all medical commentators had been placed .	101.47399
the discussion of professional ethics inevitably reminded us that in the historical perspective the president ' s decision will finally clarify itself as a moral , rather than a medical , problem .	87.511925
because the responsibility for resolving the issue lay with the president , rather than with his doctors , nothing raises more surely for us the difficulties simple goodness faces in dealing with complex moral problems under political pressure .	143.75363
for the president had dealt with the matter humbly , in what he conceived as the democratic way .	83.51525
but the problem is one which gives us the measure of a man , rather than a group of men , whether a group of doctors , a group of party members assembled at a dinner to give their opinion , or the masses of the voters .	60.048347
any attempt to reconcile this statement of the central issue in the campaign of 1956 with the nature of the man who could not conceive it as the central issue will at least resolve our confusions about the chaotic and misleading results of the earnestness of both doctors and president in a situation which should never have arisen .	92.39541
it was a response to the conflict between political pressure and the moral intuition which resulted in attempts at prediction .	82.53806
in no other situation would a group of doctors , struggling competently to improve the life expectancy of a man beloved by the world , be subjected to such merciless and persistent questioning , and before they were prepared to demonstrate the kind of verbal precision which alone can clarify for mankind the problems it faces .	120.764725
and though we can look back now and see their errors , we can look back also to the ultimate error .	130.47206
it recurred in the press conferences the president ' s remarks about his running developed a singular tone , one which we find in few statements made by public individuals on such a matter .	130.95137
the press conference became a stage which betrayed the drift of his private thinking , rather than his convictions .	67.49302
he commented -- thoughtfully , a reporter told us -- that it was `` not too important for the individual how he ends up ' ' .	72.888535
he gave us a simile to explain his admission that even at the worst period of his second illness it never occurred to him there was any renewed question about his running as in the battle of the bulge , he had no fears about the outcome until he read the american newspapers .	94.28512
yet the attitude that the fate of the presidency demands in such a situation is quite distinct from the simple courage that can proceed with battles to be fought , regardless of the consequences .	89.62998
in this case others should not have had to raise the doubts and fears .	82.690674
the presidency demands an incisive awareness of the larger implications of the death of any incumbent .	110.71557
it is of the utmost importance to the people of america and of the world how their governing president `` ends up ' ' during the four years of his term .	79.87723
only when that term is ended and he is a private citizen again can he be permitted the freedom and the courage to discount the dangers of his death .	78.577034
ironically enough , in this instance such personal virtues were a luxury .	234.49486
at the national and international level , then , what is the highest kind of morality for the private citizen represents an instance of political immorality .	90.07604
and we had the uneasy sense that the cleavage between the moral and the political progressed amid the events which concern us .	88.73368
for the tone of the editorials which greeted mr . eisenhower ' s original announcement of his running had been strangely disquieting .	48.73556
neither the vibrant enthusiasm which bespeaks a people ' s intuitive sense of the fitness of things at climactic moments nor the vital argumentation betraying its sense that something significant has transpired was in evidence .	97.36157
nothing testifies more clearly to that cleavage than the peculiar editorial page appearing in a july issue of life magazine , the issue which also carried the second announcement of the candidacy .	94.90107
the double editorial on two aspects of `` the u . s . spirit ' ' was subtly calculated to suggest a moral sanction for gambles great as well as small , reflecting popular approval of this questionable attitude toward the highest office in the land .	85.44038
`` the moral creed ' ' and `` the will to risk ' ' live happily together , if we do not examine where the line is to be drawn .	62.40792
`` i may possibly be a greater risk than is the normal person of my age ' ' , the president had said on february 29th of the election year , ignoring the fact that no one of his age had ever lived out another term .	68.28129
`` my doctors assure me that this increased percentage of risk is not great ' ' .	19.278833
but by the time the risk was doubled , events had dismissed from his mind both increased percentages and a previously stated intention of considering carefully anything more serious than a bout of influenza .	239.0648
only infrequently did the situation color his thinking .	10.388901
ironically no president we have had would have regretted more than president eisenhower the possibility to which his own words , in the press conference held at the beginning of august , testified that unable as he was himself to say his running was best for the country , unconsciously he had placed his party before his nation .	91.296585
so it is that we relive his opening statement in the first television address with the dramatic immediacy of the present .	58.381603
no consideration of risk urges itself upon him now for this is what the mind does with the ideas on which it has not properly focussed .	97.28356
yet with a mind less shallow , if less sharp , than some of the fortune-happy syndicates which back him , he feels what he cannot formulate	95.67212
and we watch him amid the overtones which suggest he could never in any conscience urge a risk upon the voters .	186.90817
moving as he is into the phase of the campaign which demands conviction of him , he adopts a position that is morally indefensible .	136.06734
he ascribes to the mercy of god the peace which this personal matter -- the assurance that he can physically sustain the burden of the office longer than any individual in the history of our nation has been able to do -- has brought him .	89.689316
what is simply an opinion formed in defiance of the laws of human probability , whether or not it is later confirmed , has become by september of the election year `` a firm conviction ' ' .	100.89356
as a means of silencing a discussion which ought to have taken place , the statement is an effective one we sympathize with the universal confusion which gives rise to such convictions .	92.507385
but it is also the climax to one of the absorbing chapters in our current political history .	87.63268
in assigning to god the responsibility which he learned could not rest with his doctors , eisenhower gave evidence of that weakening of the moral intuition which was to characterize his administration in the years to follow .	108.54169
in any other man this reassurance to the electorate would have caused us a profound moral shock .	142.26562
about this man we had to think twice .	10.481344
we knew that it was , as reassurance , the ironic fruit of a deeply moral nature .	63.54941
but the fact remains that even the unconscious acceptance of himself as a man of destiny divinely protected must be censored in any man who evades the responsibility for his major decisions , and thus for imposing his will on the people .	90.60322
and in the context of drifting personal utterances we have examined , there was occasional evidence of the origin of all such evasions .	46.83607
when the possibility that he had not given reconsideration to so weighty a decision seemed to disconcert his questioners , mr . eisenhower was known to make his characteristic statement to the press that he was not going to talk about the matter any more .	68.31124
the portrait that had developed , fragmentarily but consistently , was the portrait of a man to whom serious thinking is alien enough that the making of a decision inhibits , when it does not forestall , any ability to review the decision in the light of new evidence .	102.9746
this does not mean that the decision to run for office should inevitably have been revoked .	191.9848
instead it means that the thinking in which decision issues has the power to determine the morality of the decision , as in this instance the pressure for renewed practical or legislative attention to the constitutional problems the decision had uncovered might have done .	121.198425
drifting through a third illness , apparently without any provision for the handling of a major national emergency other than a talk with the vice-president , eisenhower revealed the singularly static quality of his thinking .	93.94055
despite three warnings , no sense of moral urgency impelled him to distinguish his situation , and thus his responsibilities , from wilson ' s .	66.832085
by contrast , the energetic reaction of the leader to the full demands his decision imposes upon him strengthens the moral intuition and gives us the measure of the man .	74.76997
only by means of an intensive preoccupation with the detailed considerations following from any decision can he ensure attention to the practical details to be dealt with if the implications of immorality in the major decision are effectively to be checked .	159.65636
in the incessant struggle with recalcitrant political fact he learns to focus the essence of a problem in the significant detail , and to articulate the distinctions which clarify the detail as significant , with what is sometimes astounding rapidity .	94.653275
like lincoln , he can distinguish his relation to god from the constitutional responsibilities a questionable decision exacts of him .	86.52612
like roosevelt , he can distinguish an attitude toward a russian leader he may share with a host of americans from the responsibilities diplomatic convention may impose upon him .	117.87274
he chooses to subordinate one to the other , sometimes reluctantly , accepting criticism for the lesser immoralities facts breed .	172.6344
the very nature of a choice so grounded in distinction and fact leads to the valid convictions which become force of will in the manifest leader .	311.53546
the capacity for making the distinctions of which diplomacy is compact , and the facility with language which can render them into validity in the eyes of other men are the leader ' s means for transforming the moral intuition into moral leadership .	87.277466
the making of distinctions , like the perception of the great distinctions made , is an inordinately difficult business .	87.87429
lincoln ' s slow progress towards the several marking his achievement is even now unrecognizable as such , and loosely interpreted as the alternation of inconsistency with vision .	149.81473
but because it is the function of the mind to turn the one into the other by means of the capacities with which words endow it , we do not unwisely examine the type of distinction , in the sphere of politics , on which decisions hang .	81.771736
only recently , and perhaps because a television debate can so effectively dramatize president kennedy ' s extraordinary mastery of detail , have the abilities on which the capacity for making distinctions depend begun to be clearly discernible at the level of politics .	84.25367
in his recent evaluation of kennedy ' s potentialities for leadership , walter lippmann has cited the `` precision ' ' of his mind , his `` immense command ' ' of factual detail , and his `` instinct for the crucial point ' ' as impressive in the extreme	64.95288
and it is surely clear that the first of these is the result of the way in which the individual ' s command of language interacts with the other two .	27.57786
for this change is not a change from one positive position to another , but a change from order and truth to disorder and negation .	102.69628
the liberal-conservative division , we might observe in passing , is not of itself directly involved in a private interest conflict nor even in struggle between ruling groups .	213.48018
rather it is rooted in a difference of response to the threat of social disintegration .	59.762264
the division is not between those who wish to preserve what they have and those who want change .	70.62565
rather it is a division established by two absolutely different ways of thought with regard to man ' s life in society .	51.404266
these ways are absolutely irreconcilable because they offer two different recipes for man ' s redemption from chaos .	42.71559
the civilizational crisis , the third type of change raises the question `` what are we to do ' ' ? ?	27.184193
for the answer cannot be derived from any socially cohesive element in the disrupting community .	38.392933
there is no socially existential answer to the question .	19.660555
for the truth formerly experienced by the community no longer has existential status in the community , nor does any answer elaborated by philosophers or theoriticians .	85.9058
in this phase of change , no idea has social acceptance and so none has ontological status in the community .	97.32036
an interregnum ensues in which not men but ideas compete for existence .	538.0941
if we examine the three types of change from the point of view of their internal structure we find an additional profound difference between the third and the first two , one that accounts for the notable difference between the responses they evoke .	94.53541
the first two types of change occur within the inward and immanent structure of the society .	18.817837
the first involves a simple shift of interests in the society .	13.097115
the second involves something deeper , but its characteristic form focuses on a shift in policy for the community , not in the truth on which the community rests .	58.955566
thus in both types attention is focused on the community itself , and its phenomenological life .	63.9968
the third type , however , wrenches attention from the life of action and interests in the community and focuses it on the ground of being on which the community depends for its existence .	58.674637
voegelin has analyzed this experience in the case of the stable , healthy community .	25.784891
there the community , faced with the need to formulate policy on the level of absolute justice , can find the answer to its problem in the absolute truth which it holds as partially experienced .	73.0918
this , however , cannot be done by a community whose very experience of truth is confused and incoherent it has no absolute standard , and consequently cannot distinguish the absolute from the contingent .	146.9008
it has lost its ground of being and floats in a mist of appearances .	65.515625
precisely at the moment when it has lost its vision the mind of the community turns out from itself in a search for the ontological standard whereby it can measure itself .	112.31498
for paradigmatic history `` breaks ' ' rather than unfolds precisely when the movement is from order to disorder , and not from one order to a new order .	82.46044
the liberal-conservative split , to define it further , derives from a basic difference concerning the existential status of standard sought and about the spiritual experience that leads to its identification .	151.36633
when disruptive change has penetrated to the third level of social order , the process of disruption rapidly reaches a point of no return .	91.264336
indeed , it is probable that this point is reached the moment the third level of change begins .	81.87001
at that point we reach the `` closed ' ' historical situation the situation in which man is no longer free to return to a status quo ante .	35.615963
at that point men become aware of the mystery of history called variously `` fate ' ' , or `` destiny ' ' , or `` providence ' ' , and feel themselves caught helplessly in the writhing of a disrupted society .	39.890495
the reasons for this experience are rooted in the metaphysical characteristics of such a change .	37.950466
of all forms of being , society , or community , has the greatest element of determinability .	41.66197
its ontological status is itself most tenuous because apart from individual men , who are its `` matter ' ' , tradition , the `` form ' ' of society exists only as a shared perception of truth .	74.11167
the ontological status of society thus is constituted by the psychological status of society ' s members .	18.615517
the content of that psychological status determines , ultimately , the content of civilization .	50.569237
those social , civilizational factors not rooted in the human spirit of the group , ultimately cease to exist .	45.23442
civilization itself -- tradition -- falls out of existence when the human spirit itself becomes confused .	49.962513
civilization is what man has made of himself .	8.029881
its massive contours are rooted in the simple need of man , since he is always incomplete , to complete himself .	107.13247
it is not enough for man to be an ontological esse .	16.12949
he needs existential completion , he needs , that is , to move in the direction of completion .	46.77741
and the direction of that movement is determined by his perception of the truth about himself .	52.714417
he must , consequently , exist as a self-perceived substantive , developing agent , or he does not exist as man .	72.81135
thus , it is no mystical intuition , but an analyzable conception to say that man and his tradition can `` fall out of existence ' ' .	77.70826
this happens at the moment man loses the perception of moral substance in himself , of a nature that , in maritain ' s words , is perceived as a `` locus of intelligible necessities ' ' .	50.33067
an existentialist is a man who perceives himself only as `` esse ' ' , as existence without substance .	68.5499
thus human perception and human volition is the immanent cause of all social change and this most truly when the change reaches the civilizational level .	172.77843
thus with regard to the loss of tradition , in the change from order to disorder the metaphysics of change works itself out as a disruption of the individual soul , a change in which man continues as an objective ontological existent , but no longer as a man .	71.03936
further , change is a form of motion , it occurs as the act of a being in potency insofar as it is in potency and has not yet reached the terminus of the change .	59.33379
with regard to the change we are examining , the question is , at what point does the change become irreversible ? ?	54.355488
a number of considerations suggest that this occurs early in the process .	68.062706
this means that the inception of change itself can begin only when the factors conducive to change have already become more powerful than those anchoring the existent form in being .	87.955414
if the existent form is to be retained new factors that reinforce it must be introduced into the situation .	113.0856
in the case of social decay , form is displaced simply by the process of dissolution with no form at the terminus of the process .	98.19142
now in the mere fact of the beginning of such displacement we have prima-facie evidence of the ontological weakness of the fading form .	78.52898
and when we consider the tenuous hold tradition has on existence , any weakening of that hold constitutes a crisis of existence .	156.22551
the retention of a tradition confronted with such a crisis necessitates the introduction of new spiritual forces into the situation .	104.884544
however , the crisis occurs precisely as a weakening of spiritual forces .	169.35936
it would seem , therefore , that in a civilizational crisis man cannot save himself .	75.0536
the emergence of the crisis itself would seem to constitute a warranty for the victory of disorder .	34.878933
and it would seem that history is a witness to this truth .	85.38128
as a further characterization of the liberal conservative split we may observe that it involves differences in the formula for escaping inevitabilities in history .	94.54146
these differences , in turn , derive from prior differences concerning the friendly or hostile character of change .	196.02452
anxiety and deep insecurity are the characteristic responses evoked by the crisis in tradition .	43.215496
to experience them , it is not necessary for a people to be actively aware of what is happening to it .	26.515982
the process of erosion need only undermine the tradition and a series of consequences begin unfolding within the individual , while in institutions a quiet but deep transformation of processes occurs .	159.5422
within the individual the reaction has been called various names , all , however , pointing to the same basic experience .	78.13988
weil identifies it as being `` rootless ' ' , guardini as being `` placeless ' ' , riesman as being `` lonely ' ' .	26.697927
others call it `` alienation ' ' , and mean by that no simple economic experience ( as marx does ) but a deep spiritual sense of dislocation .	184.38031
within institutions there is a marked decline of the process of persuasion and the substitution of a force-fear process which masquerades as the earlier one of persuasion .	84.963974
we note the use of rhetoric as a weapon , the manipulation of the masses by propaganda , the `` mobilization ' ' of effort and resources .	55.79518
within this context of spontaneous and unanalyzed responses to the experience of civilizational crisis , two basic organizations of response are observable reaction and ideological progressivism .	103.92561
these responses are explicable in terms of characteristics inherent in the crisis .	27.867437
the response of reaction is dominated by a concern for what is vanishing .	195.84074
its essence lies in its attempt to recover previous order through the repression of disruptive forces .	118.943016
to this end political authority is called upon to exercise its negative and coercive powers .	58.01659
the implicit assumption of this response is that history is reversible .	85.20712
seemingly , order is perceived as a kind of subsistent entity now covered by adventitious accretions .	83.24418
the problem is to remove the accretions and thereby uncover the order that was always there .	76.2006
such a response , of course , misses the point that in crisis order is going out of existence .	118.94024
moreover its posture of stubborn but simple resistance is doomed to failure because of the metaphysical weakness of the existent form of order , once the activation of change has reached visible proportions .	85.39631
the most reaction can achieve is stasis , and a stasis that can be maintained only by the expenditure of an effort which ultimately exhausts itself .	58.9588
despite the hopelessness of the response , it is explicable in terms of the crisis of tradition itself .	29.42858
since a civilizational crisis involves also a crisis in private interests and in the ruling class , reaction is normally found among those who feel themselves to be among the ruling class .	104.60918
their great error is to mingle the responses typical of each of the three types of change .	33.067318
since civilizational change is the most difficult to perceive and analyze , it seldom is given adequate attention .	206.49496
and the anxiety it generates is misinterpreted as anxiety over private interest and threatened social status .	256.31796
the basic truth in the reactionary response is to be found in its realistic assumption of the primacy of the real over the ideational .	53.28759
but this truth is distorted by its extreme application the assumption of the separate existence of tradition .	78.33577
the reactionary misses the point that tradition exists ontologically only in the form of psychological-intellectual relations .	29.5208
reactionary theories , for this reason , usually assume some form of organismic theory .	55.518776
in its defensive formulations , the theory will attack conscious change on the grounds of the independent existence of the community .	67.48141
in its dynamic form , it visualizes the community as the embodiment of an ontological force -- the race , for instance , which unfolds in history .	42.143456
in both cases the individual tends to be treated as an instrument of the organic reality .	33.481922
when the reactionary response is thus bolstered by an intellectual defense , the characteristics of that defense are explicable only in terms of the basic attitudes of unanalyzed reaction .	102.49677
reaction is rooted in a perception of tradition as a whole .	22.07271
it is a total situation that is defended the `` good old days ' ' .	28.624754
even the questionable features of the past are defended .	125.92784
the point is that the reactionary , for whatever motive , perceives himself to have been part or a partner of something that extended beyond himself , something which , consequently , he was not able to accept or reject on the basis of subjective preference .	96.42326
the reactionary is confused about the existential status of a decaying tradition , but he does perceive the unity tradition had when it was healthy .	94.739525
all of which brings up another problem in the use of psychoanalytic insight in a literary work .	46.961807
is the oedipus complex , the clinical syndrome , material for a tragedy ? ?	68.687164
if we remove ourselves for a moment from our time and our infatuation with mental disease , isn ' t there something absurd about a hero in a novel who is defeated by his infantile neurosis ? ?	58.70095
i am not making a clinical judgment here , for such personal tragedies are real and are commonplace in the analyst ' s consulting room , but literature makes a different claim upon our sympathies than tragedy in life .	127.79228
a man in a novel who is defeated in his childhood and condemned by unconscious forces within him to tiredly repeat his earliest failure in love , only makes us a little weary of man	123.18413
now we can argue that the irresistible fate of oedipus rex was nothing more than the irresistible unconscious longings of oedipus projected outward , but this externalization of unconscious conflict makes all the difference between a story and a clinical case history .	58.913162
we can also argue that the three brothers karamazov and smerdyakov were the external representatives of an internal conflict within one man , dostoevsky , a conflict having to do with father-murder and the wish to possess the father ' s woman .	70.69772
but a novel in which one man karamazov explored the divisions within his personality would scarcely merit publication in the psychoanalytic quarterly .	216.02248
it is a mistake to look upon the oedipus of oedipus complex as a literary descendant of oedipus rex .	43.407978
whatever the psychological truth in the oedipus myth , an oedipus who is drawn to his fate by irresistible external forces can carry the symbol of humanity and its archaic crime , and the incest that is unknowing renews the mystery of the eternal dream of childhood and absorbs us in the secret .	74.10549
but a modern oedipus who is doomed because he cannot oppose his own childhood is only pathetic , and for renouncing the mystery in favor of psychological truth he gives up the claim on our sympathies .	93.641624
i am suggesting that a case-history approach to the oedipus complex is a blind alley for a storyteller .	31.642498
the best gifts of the novelist will be wasted on the reader who is insulated against any surprises the novelist may have in store for him .	134.7907
incest is still a durable theme , but if it wants to get written about it will have to find ways to surprise the emotions , and there is no better way to do this than that of concealment and symbolic representation .	65.55919
and the best way to conceal and disguise the elements of an incest story is not to set out to write an incest story .	56.932877
which brings to mind another lawrence story and some interesting comparisons in the treatment of the oedipal theme .	45.568012
`` the rocking horse winner ' ' is also a story about a boy ' s love for his mother .	21.762478
if i now risk some comparisons with sons and lovers let it be clear that i am not comparing the two works or judging their merits	184.28627
i am only singling out differences in treatment of a theme and the resultant effects .	51.626286
`` the rocking horse winner ' ' is a fantasy with extraordinary power to disturb the reader -- but we do not know why .	50.78567
it is the story of the hopeless love of a little boy for his cold and vain mother .	52.689438
there are ghostly scenes in which the little boy on his rocking horse rocks madly toward the climax that will magically give him the name of the winning horse .	103.06701
the child grows rich on his winnings and conspires with his uncle to make secret gifts of his money to his mother .	67.44264
the story ends in the child ' s illness and delirium brought on by the feverish compulsion to ride his horse to win for his mother .	67.04472
the child dies with his mourning mother at his bedside .	39.353523
i had read the story many times without asking myself why it affected me or caring why it did .	143.59538
but on one occasion when i encountered a similar fantasy in a little boy who was my patient i began to understand the uncanny effects of this story .	72.52624
it was , of course , a little boy ' s fantasy of winning his mother to himself , and replacing the father who could not give her the things she wanted -- a classical oedipal fantasy if you like -- but if it were only this the story would be banal .	74.675514
how does the rocking exert its uncanny effect upon the reader ? ?	28.69608
the rocking is actually felt in the story , a terrible and ominous rhythm that prophesies the tragedy .	59.33031
the rocking , i realized , is the single element in the story that carries the erotic message , the unspoken and unconscious undercurrent that would mar the innocence of a child ' s fantasy and disturb the effects of the work if it were made explicit .	72.496056
the rocking has the ambiguous function of keeping the erotic undercurrent silent and making it present	76.245735
and if we understand the rocking as an erotic symbol we can also see how well it serves as the symbol of impending tragedy .	70.8098
for this love of the boy for his mother is a hopeless and forbidden love , doomed by its nature .	96.92347
we are also struck by the fact that this story of a boy ' s love for his mother does not offend , while the incestuous love of the man , paul morel , sometimes repels .	48.786076
we accord it its place there , and in lawrence ' s treatment we are given the innocent fantasy of a child , in fact , the form in which oedipal love is expressed in childhood .	74.07242
and when the child dies in lawrence ' s story in a delirium that is somehow brought on by his mania to win and to make his mother rich , the manifest absurdity of such a disease and such a death does not enter into our thoughts at all .	88.084724
we have so completely entered the child ' s fantasy that his illness and his death are the plausible and the necessary conclusion .	101.01766
i am sure that none of the effects of this story were consciously employed by lawrence to describe an oedipal fantasy in childhood .	129.7809
it is most probable that freud and the oedipus complex never entered his head in the writing of this story .	65.07211
he was simply writing a story that wanted to be told , and in the writing a childhood fantasy of his own emerged .	46.479805
he would not have cared why it emerged , he only wanted to capture a memory to play with it again in his imagination and somehow to fix and hold in the story the disturbing emotions that accompanied the fantasy .	136.06804
in our own time we have seen that the novelist ' s debt to psychoanalysis has increased but that the novel itself has not profited much from this marriage .	99.35228
ortega ' s hope that modern psychology might yet bring forth a last flowering of the novel has only been partially fulfilled .	164.39946
he has lost confidence in his own eyes and in the validity of his own psychological insights .	19.918161
he borrows the insights of psychology to improve his impaired vision but cannot bring to his work the distinctive vision that should be a novelist ' s own .	89.36807
he has been seduced by the marvels of the unconscious and has lost interest in studying the surfaces of character .	100.651955
if many of the characters in contemporary novels appear to be the bloodless relations of characters in a case history it is because the novelist is often forgetful today that those things that we call character manifest themselves in surface behavior , that the ego is still the executive agency of personality , and that all we know of personality must be discerned through the ego .	113.581764
the novelist who has been badly baptized in psychoanalysis often gives us the impression that since all men must have an oedipus complex all men must have the same faces .	109.99188
i have argued that oedipus of the oedipus complex has a doubtful future as a tragic figure in literature .	66.29093
but a writer who has a taste for irony and who sees incest in all its modern dimensions can let his imagination work on the disturbing joke in the incest myth , the joke that strikes right at the center of man ' s humanness .	100.93052
moral dread is seen as the other face of desire , and here psychoanalysis delivers to the writer a magnificent irony and a moral problem of great complexity .	101.65478
there is probably some significance in the fact that two of the best incest stories i have encountered in recent years are burlesques of the incest myth .	52.133575
the ancient types are reassembled in gloom and foreboding to be irresistibly drawn to their destinies , but the myth fails before the modern truth	66.42177
the oracle speaks false and the dream speaks true .	189.16858
in both the farmer ' s tale in ralph ellison ' s invisible man and in thomas mann ' s the holy sinner , the incest hero rises above the myth by accepting the wish as motive	80.39008
the heroic act is the casting off of pretense .	245.7457
thomas mann wrote the holy sinner in 1951 .	4.8829665
it was conceived as a leave-taking , a kind of melancholy gathering-in of the myths of the west , `` bevor die nacht sinkt , eine lange nacht vielleicht und ein tiefes vergessen ' ' .	14.11183
he chose a medieval legend of incest , gregorius vom stein , and freely borrowed and parodied other myths of the west , mixing themes , language , peoples and times in a master myth in which the old forms continually renew themselves , as in his previous treatment of joseph .	76.01949
but the holy sinner is not simply a retelling of old stories for an old man ' s entertainment .	35.486305
mann understood better than most men the incest comedy at the center of the myth and the psychological truth in which dread is shown as the other face as longing was for him just the kind of deep and complicated joke he liked to tell .	91.06264
and when he retold the legend of gregorius he interpolated a modern version in which the medieval players speak contemporary thoughts in archaic language	132.2884
while they move through the pageantry of the ancient incest myth and cover themselves through not-knowing , they reveal the unconscious motive in seeking each other and in the last scene make an extraordinary confession of guilt in the twentieth-century manner .	101.21825
grigorss is the child of an incestuous union between a royal brother and sister , the twins sibylla and wiligis .	81.12072
he is born in secrecy after the death of his father and cast adrift soon after birth .	131.22833
the infant is discovered by a fisherman who brings him home to rear him .	106.00881
an ivory tablet in the infant ' s cask recounts the story of his sinful origins and is preserved for the child by the monks of a monastery in the fishing village .	55.789356
grigorss , at seventeen , learns his story and goes forth as a knight to uncover his origins .	117.032776
his sailing vessel is guided by fate to the shores of his own country at a time when sibylla ' s domain is overrun by the armies of one of her rejected suitors .	48.76226
grigorss overcomes the suitor in battle , delivers the city from its oppressors and marries sibylla who had fallen in love with the beautiful knight the moment she saw him .	76.62007
sibylla is pregnant with their second child when she finds the ivory tablet concealed by her husband , and the identities of mother and son are revealed .	52.143723
grigorss goes off to do penance on a rock for seventeen years .	65.66374
at the end of this period two pious christians in rome receive the revelation which leads them to seek the next pope on the rock .	120.652374
grigorss comes to rome and becomes a great and beloved pope .	108.366005
in the last pages of the book sibylla comes to rome to seek an audience with the great pope and to give her confession .	75.1405
mother and son recognize each other and , in mann ' s version of this legend , make a remarkable confession of guilt to each other , the confession of unconscious motive and unconscious knowledge of their true identities from the time they had first set eyes on each other .	60.785618
in recollection he has said `` natural or man-made objects kept coming into my head , but i would suppress them sternly ' ' .	60.034058
moreover , he organized the movement of his forms , within his rigorously shaped space , into highly complex equilibriums	97.752975
and used gradations of color value as well as sharply contrasting elementary colors .	92.02953
the worthy mondrian , seeing these pictures , said in a tone of kindly reproof `` but you are really an artist of the naturalistic tradition ' ' ! !	56.00466
helion did not realize it at the time , but it was true .	16.824495
his `` monumental ' ' abstraction , made up of smooth , metallic `` non-objects ' ' acting upon each other with great tension , won helion much acclaim during the ' thirties .	140.07169
the play of novel lighting effects also entered into these compositions , whose controlled power and varied activity made them well worth meditating .	216.09665
as helion ' s work showed more and more nostalgia for the world of man and nature , the pure abstractionists expressed some disapproval	78.81934
but leger , arp , lipchitz and alexander calder , at the time , gave him their blessing .	38.89761
his canvases nowadays bore titles frankly declaring them to be `` figures in space ' ' , or `` blue figure ' ' , or `` pink figure ' '	19.993465
and they had ( vaguely ) heads and feet .	107.97091
exhibited in shows in london in 1935 , and in new york the following year , the new , more elaborated abstracts were much favored in the circles of the modernists as three-dimentional dramas of great intellectual coherence .	51.670307
at this period the thirty-year old helion was ranked `` as one of the mature leaders of the modern movement ' ' , according to herbert read , `` and in the direct line of descent from cezanne , seurat , gris and leger ' ' .	52.81879
in america , meyer schapiro observed that , unlike the mondrian school , helion `` sought a return path to the fullness of nature within the framework of abstract art ' ' .	66.693794
it is notable that at this time he was writing with admiration of cimabue ' s and poussin ' s way of filling space .	53.005142
abstract art was still the right path for him	16.47098
but , he held , instead of continuing as an `` art of reduction ' ' , it must grow , must make a place for the contributions of the raphaels and poussins as well as for those of the early cubists and mondrian .	42.829952
later helion wrote of this phase `` for years i built for myself a subtle instrument of relationships -- colors and forms without a name .	296.82037
i played on it my secret songs , unexplained , passionate and peaceful ' ' .	43.605797
the extreme limitations he sensed in all current abstract art made that seem to him increasingly arid and cold .	68.03422
he was engaged in constant experiments that searched for new directions .	90.35643
he himself did not know , as he said in 1935 .	98.16151
but he was `` afraid of the future -- he would in fact welcome a way back to social integration , a functional art of some kind ' ' .	104.82044
during the 1920 ' s the abstractionists , the german bauhaus group of industrial designers , and the new architects all had the dream of some well ordered utopia , or welfare state , in which their neat and logical constructions might find their proper place .	139.97855
but whereas the postwar american abstractionists seem to helion to be determined to `` escape ' ' from the real world , or simply to rebel against it , the ordered abstractions which he and his associates of the 1930 ' s were painting embodied the hope of `` improving ' ' things .	88.657005
`` we were possessed by visions of a new civilization to come , very pure and elevated ' ' , he has said , `` in fact some ideal form of socialism such as we had dreamed of since the war of 1914-1918 ' ' .	53.27613
instead of this the 1930 ' s witnessed a tragic economic depression , the rise of fascist dictators in europe , the wasting civil war in spain .	47.56153
very much the political man , helion felt himself deeply affected by the increasingly pessimistic atmosphere of france and all europe , whose foundations seemed to him more and more shaky .	112.26374
in 1936 he decided to migrate to america .	7.1248045
the rooseveltian america was a haven of liberalism and progress and seemed to him to constitute the last best hope for civilization .	160.56665
helion also hoped that america ' s mastery of technology and industrial efficiency would be accompanied by the production of new and beautiful art works .	60.65139
`` i arrived in the united states with the idea of establishing myself there more or less permanently and finding inspiration for new compositions ' ' .	153.69408
in new york he was well received by what was then only a small brave band of non-figurative artists , including alexander calder , george k . l . morris , de kooning , holty and a few others .	53.520477
after a year in a studio on sheridan square , having married an american girl who was a native of virginia , helion moved to a village in the blue ridge mountains , where he produced some of the most imposing of his abstract canvases .	47.126305
the darkening world scene , at the time of the munich pact , continued to trouble his mind even in his remote virginia studio .	99.92884
`` fear possessed me , and the certainty of war ' ' , he has related .	23.466164
`` i truly smelled blood , death , heaps of corpses everywhere ' ' .	23.989492
in haste he labored to finish some last abstract paintings a three-panel frieze , with a flying figure and a fallen figure	162.72404
a `` double-figure ' ' , which went to the chicago art institute , and is considered by him the most successful of his abstracts	67.855995
and in early 1939 , a `` fallen figure ' ' of very ominous character , which concluded his abstract phase .	108.37117
`` i knew i was carrying on with abstraction to its very end -- for me ' ' , he said of the two years ' output in virginia .	67.92423
with those paintings of big constructions crashing down , he felt he could stop .	79.72669
they were , in effect his last testament to non-objective art .	49.27997
he had taken out first papers for american citizenship	22.938421
but after war came to europe , he decided to return to france , arriving there in january , 1940 .	75.97807
`` i hated the war ' ' , he said , `` but thought i ought to go because i was , perhaps , one of those who hadn ' t done enough to prevent it ' ' .	28.406809
in june , 1940 , sergeant helion , with a company of reserve troops waiting to go into battle , was sketching the hills south of the loire river , when the war suddenly rolled in upon him .	82.943405
its first apparition was a long , gloomy column of refugees riding in farm wagons , or pushing prams .	38.424637
his company then carried out a confused retreating movement until it was surrounded by the germans , a few days before france capitulated .	62.895687
after a sort of death march during four days without food , helion and his comrades were shipped by cattle-car to a labor camp at an estate farm in east germany .	76.0645
a year later they were removed to a stalag in the harbor of stettin .	38.780407
at the time of his capture helion had on his person a sketchbook he had bought at woolworth ' s in new york .	75.53207
when he was stripped , deloused and numbered by his guards , his much-thumbed sketchbook was seized and thrown on a pile of prisoners ' goods to be confiscated .	48.536556
`` it was then i knew that they were making war against man , the individual within ! !	181.67728
-- who questioned things when given orders ' ' .	2.5602043
at stettin the university-educated artist , who had studied german , was chosen to serve as interpreter and clerk in the office of the stalag commander .	36.59706
in secret he also acted as a member of the prisoners ' central committee , which plotted sabotage , planned a few escapes , and maintained a hidden control over the wretched french slave-laborers .	67.970215
in the stalag , helion came to know and love his comrades , most of them plain folk , who , in their extremity , showed true courage and ran great risks to help each other .	107.57089
how much they esteemed him is shown by the fact that their underground committee selected him as one of the few who would be helped to escape .	102.64555
in the prison camp ' s black market civilian clothes were quietly bought and forged papers were devised for him	171.43115
during long weeks the plan for his flight was rehearsed .	14.139907
every morning contingents of prisoners would be sent out to labor in nearby factories .	118.18246
one evening , while a volley-ball game was being played in the yard among the prisoners remaining there , a simulated melee was staged -- just as the gates were opened to admit other prisoners returning from work .	133.5851
four hands were stretched toward me by my comrades behind me .	93.297676
finot held a wallet with my money and papers	5916.6567
moineau and david held nothing but their fingers .	24.746473
at this moment the volley-ball hit the ground .	6.2332106
the guards all rushed up to intervene ' '	1.2189412
shedding his prison cloak , helion shot through the gates , now clad in civilian garments and with the passport of a flemish worker .	70.62491
riding trains , hitching hikes on trucks across germany , slipping through guarded frontiers with the help of secret guides , he eventually reached vichy france , and , by the winter of 1943 , was back in virginia .	45.809883
to escape from a prison camp required a very special state of mind	140.66994
not only loathing of captivity , but a faith , a hope that is even stronger .	107.25289
i left behind me brave men , whom captivity had robbed of all hope .	303.91028
they too loved their families , longed for their villages yet lacked the faith that drove one to dare the fearful chance of escape ' ' .	179.63834
it was a time of revelations for him .	1.9185376
even the most rational of men , under great stress , may be transported by a new faith and behave like mystics .	114.00294
helion knew that he owed his freedom as much to the self-sacrifice of his fellow-men in arbeitskommando 13 , , stettin , as to his own fierce will and love of life .	64.542946
after that , he declared , `` to return to freedom was to fall to one ' s knees before the real world and adore it ' ' .	52.33253
in prison he had been able to sketch nothing but figures from life , his guards , his companions in misery .	131.24643
now all his desires centered on `` rediscovering and singing of the prosaic and yet beautiful world of men and objects so long barred from me by a barbed wire fence ' ' .	81.43717
and , he added `` during the many months in prison camp , all abstract images vanished from my mind ' ' .	46.735016
before leaving for america , he happened to see his old friend jean arp and confided to him his new resolutions .	48.294926
arp protested `` but it is impossible ! !	1.1775173
everything in the way of representation has already been done by the old masters ' ' .	30.358799
helion , however , clung to the belief that `` in escaping from the stalag i had also escaped from abstraction ' ' .	61.963615
while convalescing in his virginia home he wrote a book recording his prison experiences and escape , entitled they shall not have me published originally in ( helion ' s ) english by dutton & co . of new york , in 1943 , the book was received by the press as a work of astonishing literary power and one of the most realistic accounts of world war 2 , from the french side .	75.97873
and the author , who seemed the embodiment of france ' s rising spirit of resistance to her conquerors , was much complimented for his daring military action .	117.69251
but when he showed his new figurative pictures to his artist friends of the abstract camp , they paid him no compliments and drew long faces .	190.21239
between 1944 and 1947 helion had a series of one-man shows -- at the paul rosenberg gallery in new york and in paris -- of his new realistic pictures .	65.00224
they reincarnated the figures of human beings banished from his canvases since the 1920 ' s .	54.510742
these new pictures focussed on the familiar and commonplace objects that he had heard the men in his prison camp talking about as the things they missed most , hence associated with the sense of lost freedom the cafe at the corner , the newspaper kiosk , the girls in doorways and windows along the street , the golden-crusted french bread they lacked , the cigarettes denied them .	117.446075
one of the pictures was of a man with hat drawn over his face ceremoniously lighting a cigarette	84.287346
others were of men doffing their hats to each other , carrying umbrellas with pomp , reading newspapers , or simply showing loaves of bread spread out .	77.806885
