important as was mr . o ' donnell ' s essay , his thesis is so restricting as to deny faulkner the stature which he obviously has .	136.15892
he and also mr . cowley and mr . warren have fallen to the temptation which besets many of us to read into our authors -- nathaniel hawthorne , for example , and herman melville -- protests against modernism , material progress , and science which are genuine protests of our own but may not have been theirs .	77.45009
faulkner ' s total works today , and in fact those of his works which existed in 1946 when mr . cowley made his comment , or in 1939 , when mr . o ' donnell wrote his essay , reveal no such simple attitude toward the south .	63.664547
if he is a traditionalist , he is an eclectic traditionalist .	16.719286
if he condemns the recent or the present , he condemns the past with no less force .	145.62158
if he sees the heroic in a sartoris or a sutpen , he sees also -- and he shows -- the blind and the mean , and he sees the compson family disintegrating from within .	94.47782
if the barn-burner ' s family produces a flem snopes , who personifies commercialism and materialism in hyperbolic crassness , the compson family produces a jason compson 4 .	28.75205
others writing on faulkner have found the phrase `` traditional moralist ' ' either inadequate or misleading .	38.62232
among them are frederick j . hoffman , william van o ' connor , and mrs . olga vickery .	22.65472
they have indicated the direction but they have not been explicit enough , i believe , in pointing out faulkner ' s independence , his questioning if not indeed challenging the southern tradition .	90.93754
faulkner ' s is not the mind of the apologist which mr . o ' donnell implies that it is .	35.58753
he is not one to remain more comfortably and unquestioningly within a body of social , cultural , or literary traditions than he was within the traditions -- or possibly the regulations -- governing his tenure in the post office at oxford , mississippi , thirty-five years ago .	70.9617
that is not to deny that he has been aware of traditions , of course , that he is steeped in them , in fact , or that he has dealt with them , in his books .	43.761692
it is to say rather , i believe , that he has brought to bear on the history , the traditions , and the lore of his region a critical , skeptical mind -- the same mind which has made of him an inveterate experimenter in literary form and technique .	94.59575
he has employed from his section rich immediate materials which in a loose sense can be termed southern .	176.04466
the fact that he has cast over those materials the light of a skeptical mind does not make him any the less southern , i rather think , for the south has been no more solid than other regions except in the political and related areas where patronage and force and intimidation and fear may produce a surface uniformity .	182.6976
some of us might be inclined to argue , in fact , that an independence of mind and action and an intolerance of regimentation , either mental or physical , are particularly southern traits .	75.349754
there is no necessity , i suppose , to assert that mr . faulkner is southern .	70.13437
it would not be easy to discover a more thoroughly southern pedigree than that of his family .	79.01453
and , after all , he has lived comfortably at both oxford , mississippi , and charlottesville , virginia .	56.224396
the young william faulkner in new orleans in the 1920 ' s impressed the novelist hamilton basso as obviously conscious of being a southerner , and there is no evidence that since then he has ever considered himself any less so .	79.80135
besides showing no inclination , apparently , to absent himself from his native region even for short periods , and in addition writing a shelf of books set in the region , he has handled in those books an astonishingly complete list of matters which have been important in the south during the past hundred years .	89.033966
it is more difficult with faulkner than with most authors to say what is the extent and what is the source of his knowledge .	58.82202
his own testimony is that he has read very little in the history of the south , implying that what he knows of that history has come to him orally and that he knows the world around him primarily from his own unassisted observation .	74.94273
his denials of extensive reading notwithstanding , it is no doubt safe to assume that he has spent time schooling himself in southern history and that he has gained some acquaintance with the chief literary authors who have lived in the south or have written about the south .	69.024155
but in looking at faulkner against his background in mississippi and the south , it is important not to lose the broader perspective .	56.53703
his earliest work reflected heavy influences from english and continental writers .	39.617825
evidence is plentiful that early and later also he has been indebted to the gothic romancers , who deal in extravagant horror , to the symbolists writing at the end of the preceding century , and in particular to the stream-of-consciousness novelists , henry james and james joyce among them .	38.559433
his repeated experimentation with the techniques of fiction testifies to an independence of mind and an originality of approach , but it also shows him touching at many points the stream of literary development back of him .	126.30442
my intention , therefore , is not to say that faulkner ' s awareness has been confined within the borders of the south , but rather that he has looked at his world as a southerner and that presumably his outlook is southern .	71.64062
the ingredients of faulkner ' s novels and stories are by no means new with him , and most of the problems he takes up have had the attention of authors before him .	92.5065
a useful comment on his relation to his region may be made , i think , by noting briefly how in handling southern materials and southern problems he has deviated from the pattern set by other southern authors while remaining faithful to the essential character of the region .	173.409
the planter aristocracy has appeared in literature at least since john pendleton kennedy published swallow-barn in 1832 and in his genial portrait of frank meriwether presiding over his plantation dominion initiated the most persistent tradition of southern literature .	112.097435
the thoroughgoing idealization of the planter society did not come , however , until after the civil war when southern writers were eager to defend a way of life which had been destroyed .	51.875065
as they looked with nostalgia to a society which had been swept away , they were probably no more than half-conscious that they painted in colors which had never existed .	78.790184
their books found no less willing readers outside than inside the south , even while memories of the war were still sharp .	107.86958
the tradition reached its apex , perhaps , in the works of thomas nelson page toward the end of the century , and reappeared undiminished as late as 1934 in the best-selling novel so red the rose , by stark young .	107.70697
although faulkner was the heir in his own family to this tradition , he did not have stark young ' s inclination to romanticize and sentimentalize the planter society .	55.411427
the myth of the southern plantation has had only a tangential relation with actuality , as francis pendleton gaines showed forty years ago , and i suspect it has had a far narrower acceptance as something real than has generally been supposed .	88.72145
faulkner has found it useful , but he has employed it with his habitual independence of mind and skeptical outlook .	151.53142
without saying or seeming to say that in portraying the sartoris and the compson families faulkner ' s chief concern is social criticism , we can say nevertheless that through those families he dramatizes his comment on the planter dynasties as they have existed since the decades before the civil war .	113.32836
it may be that in this comment he has broken from the conventional pattern more violently than in any other regard , for the treatment in his books is far removed from even the genial irony of ellen glasgow , who was the only important novelist before him to challenge the conventional picture of planter society .	83.3798
faulkner ' s low-class characters had but few counterparts in earlier southern novels dealing with plantation life .	188.49184
they have an ancestry extending back , however , at least to 1728 , when william byrd described the lubberlanders he encountered in the back country of virginia and north carolina .	45.921883
the chief literary antecedents of the snopes clan appeared in the realistic , humorous writing which originated in the south and the southwest in the three decades before the civil war .	40.533825
these narratives of coarse action and crude language appeared first in local newspapers , as a rule , and later found their way between book covers , though rarely into the planters ' libraries beside the morocco-bound volumes of horace , mr . addison , mr . pope , and sir walter scott .	119.374504
there is evidence to suggest , in fact , that many authors of the humorous sketches were prompted to write them -- or to make them as indelicate as they are -- by way of protesting against the artificial refinements which had come to dominate the polite letters of the south .	56.701153
william gilmore simms , sturdy realist that he was , pleaded for a natural robustness such as he found in his favorites the great elizabethans , to vivify the pale writings being produced around him .	95.24834
simms admired the raucous tales emanating from the backwoods , but he had himself social affiliations which would not allow him to approve them fully .	62.546185
augustus baldwin longstreet , a preacher and a college and university president in four southern states , published the earliest of these backwoods sketches and in the character ransy sniffle , in the accounts of sharp horse-trading and eye-gouging physical combat , and in the shockingly unliterary speech of his characters , he set an example followed by many after him .	88.68643
others who wrote of low characters and low life included thomas bangs thorpe , creator of the big bear of arkansas and tom owen , the bee-hunter	58.172577
johnson jones hooper , whose character simon suggs bears a close kinship to flem snopes in both his willingness to take cruel advantage of all and sundry and the sharpness with which he habitually carried out his will	86.430824
and george washington harris , whose tennessee hillbilly character sut lovingood perpetrated more unmalicious mischief and more unintended pain than any other character in literature .	54.404175
it would be profitable , i believe , to read these realistic humorists alongside faulkner ' s works , the thought being not that he necessarily read them and owed anything to them directly , but rather that they dealt a hundred years ago with a class of people and a type of life which have continued down to our time , to faulkner ' s time .	90.32787
such a comparison reminds us that in employing low characters in his works faulkner is recording actuality in the south and moreover is following a long-established literary precedent .	194.27074
such characters , with their low existence and often low morality , produce humorous effects in his novels and tales , as they did in the writing of longstreet and hooper and harris , but it need not be added that he gives them far subtler and more intricate functions than they had in the earlier writers	109.405914
nor is there need to add that among them are some of the most highly individualized and most successful of his characters .	29.949959
one of the early humorists already mentioned , thomas bangs thorpe , can be used to illustrate another point where faulkner touches authentic southern materials and also earlier literary treatment of those materials .	174.25912
thorpe came to louisiana from the east as a young man prepared to find in the new country the setting of romantic adventure and idealized beauty .	95.03068
but thorpe saw also the hardships of pioneer existence , the cultural poverty of the frontier settlements , and the slack morality which abounded in the new regions .	56.72176
as a consequence of the tensions thus produced in his thoughts and feelings , he wrote on the one hand sketches of idealized hunting trips and on the other an anecdote of the village of hardscrabble , arkansas , where no one had ever seen a piano	73.40195
and he wrote also the masterpiece of frontier humor , `` the big bear of arkansas ' ' , in which earthy realism is placed alongside the exaggeration of the backwoods tall-tale and the awe with which man contemplates the grandeur and the mysteries of nature .	42.52988
some years ago julian huxley proposed to an audience made up of members of the british association for the advancement of science that `` man ' s supernormal or extra-sensory faculties are ( now ) in the same case as were his mathematical faculties during the ice age ' ' .	65.25874
as a humanist , dr . huxley interests himself in the possibilities of human development , and one thing we can say about this suggestion , which comes from a leading zoologist , is that , so far as he is concerned , the scientific outlook places no rigid limitation upon the idea of future human evolution .	76.56722
this text from dr . huxley is sometimes used by enthusiasts to indicate that they have the permission of the scientists to press the case for a wonderful unfoldment of psychic powers in human beings .	57.808598
there may be a case of this sort , but it is not one we wish to argue , here .	38.71909
even if people do , in a not far distant future , begin to read one another ' s minds , there will still be the question of whether what you find in another man ' s mind is especially worth reading -- worth more , that is , than what you can read in good books .	85.12619
even if men eventually find themselves able to look through walls and around corners , one may question whether this will help them to live better lives .	183.05199
there would be side-conclusions to be drawn , of course	7.8745747
such capacities are impressive evidence pointing to a conception of the human being which does not appear in the accounts of biologists and organic evolutionists	57.218067
but the basic puzzles of existence would still be puzzling , and we should still have to work out the sort of problems we plan to discuss in this article .	55.120514
all we want from dr . huxley ' s statement is the feeling that this is an open world , in the view of the best scientific opinion , with practically no directional commitments as to what may happen next , and no important confinements with respect to what may be possible .	73.97958
it seems quite obvious that all the really difficult tasks of human beings arise from the fact that man is not one , but many .	46.82072
each man , that is , is both one and many .	232.11172
he is a dreamer of the good society with a plan to put into effect , and he is an individual craftsman with something to make for himself and the people of his time .	53.400414
he is a parent with a child to nurture , here and now , and he is an educator who worries about the children half way round the world .	168.13083
he is a utopian with a stake in tomorrow and he is a vulnerable human made captive by the circumstances of today .	95.01743
he can sacrifice himself for tomorrow and he can sacrifice tomorrow for himself .	85.65053
he is a craig ' s wife who agonizes about tobacco ash on the living room rug and he is a forgetful genius who goes boating with the town baker when dignitaries from the local university have come to call .	172.6716
he is the stern guardian of the status quo who has raised the utilitarian structures of the age , and he is the revolutionary poet with a gun in his hand who writes a tragic apologetic to posterity for the men he has killed .	75.66801
what will be the final symmetry of the good society ? ?	249.90752
here , on a desk , is a stack of pamphlets representing the efforts of some of the best men of the day to penetrate these questions .	71.68043
the pamphlets are about law , the corporation , forms of government , the idea of freedom , the defense of liberty , the various lethargies which overtake our major institutions , the gap between traditional social ideals and the working mechanisms that have been set in motion for their realization .	81.53827
the thing that is notable in all these discussions is the lack of ideological ardor .	59.66944
there is another kind of ardor , a quiet , sure devotion to the fundamental decencies of human life , but no angry utopian contentions .	55.03912
actually , you could wish for some passion , now and then , but when you look around the world and see the little volcanos of current history which partisan social passions have wrought , you are glad that in these pamphlets there is at least some civilized calm .	89.758415
you could also say that in these pamphlets is a relieving quality of maturity .	48.24361
there is essential pleasantness in reading the writing of men who are not angry , who can contend without quarreling .	65.95955
this is the good kind of sophistication , and with all our problems and crises this kind of sophistication has flowered in the united states during recent years .	53.77373
a characteristic expression of such concern and inquiry is found in joseph p . lyford ' s introduction to the agreeable autocracies , a recent paperback study of the institutions of modern democratic society .	49.566753
mr . lyford gives voice to a temper that represents , we think , an achieved plateau of reflective thinking .	72.38835
after casting about for a way of describing this spirit , we decided that it would be better to use mr . lyford ' s introduction as an illustration .	35.4528
at one time it seemed as if the soviet union had done us a favor by providing a striking example of how not to behave towards other peoples and other nations .	102.4168
as things turned out , however , we have not profited greatly from the lesson instead of persistently following a national program of our own we have often been satisfied to be against whatever soviet policy seemed to be at the moment .	119.14373
such activity may or may not have irritated the kremlin , but it has frequently condemned america to an unnatural defensiveness that has undermined our effort to give leadership to the free world .	33.996696
the defensiveness has been exaggerated by another bad habit , our tendency to rate the `` goodness ' ' or `` badness ' ' of other nations by the extent to which they applaud the slogans we circulate about ourselves .	54.710735
since the slogans have little application to reality and are sanctimonious to boot , the applause is faint even in areas of the world where we should expect to find the greatest affection for free government .	79.193474
shocked at the response to our proclamations , we grow more defensive , and worse , we lose our sense of humor and proportion .	77.709145
mr . nehru is subjected to stern lectures on neutralism by our department of state , and an american president observes sourly that sweden would be a little less neurotic if it were a little more capitalistic ' ' .	54.398727
one thing you can say about mr . lyford is that he does not suffer from any insecurity as an american .	42.784267
those who are insecure fear to be candid in self-examination .	49.398956
the maturity in this point of view lies in its recognition that no basic problem is ever solved without being clearly understood .	96.930725
even if the self portrait we distribute for popular consumption were accurate it would be dangerous to present it as a picture of the ideal society .	109.06323
we would be ignoring the special circumstances of other countries .	42.70816
the picture is the more treacherous when it misrepresents the facts of american life .	52.298645
the discrepancy between what we commonly profess and what we practice or tolerate is great , and it does not escape the notice of others .	69.20859
if our sincerity is granted , and it is granted , the discrepancy can only be explained by the fact that we have come to believe hearsay and legend about ourselves in preference to an understanding gained by earnest self-examination .	75.86006
what is more , the legends have become so sacrosanct that the very habit of self-examination or self-criticism smells of low treason , and men who practice it are defeatists and unpatriotic scoundrels .	53.64978
although we continue to pay our conversational devotions to `` free private enterprise ' ' , `` individual initiative ' ' , `` the democratic way ' ' , `` government of the people ' ' , `` competition of the marketplace ' ' , etc . , we live rather comfortably in a society in which economic competition is diminishing in large areas , bureaucracy is corroding representative government , technology is weakening the citizen ' s confidence in his own power to make decisions , and the threat of war is driving him economically and physically into the ground ' ' .	45.18048
the interesting thing about mr . lyford ' s approach , and the approach of the contributors to the agreeable autocracies ( oceana publications , 1961 ) to the situation of american civilization , is that it is concerned with comprehending the psychological relationships which are having a decisive effect on american life .	37.713924
in an ideological argument , the participants tend to thump the table .	48.93402
the new spirit , so well illustrated by mr . lyford ' s work , is wholly free of this anxiety .	74.14111
the problem is rather to find out what is actually happening , and this is especially difficult for the reason that `` we are busily being defended from a knowledge of the present , sometimes by the very agencies -- our educational system , our mass media , our statesmen -- on which we have had to rely most heavily for understanding of ourselves ' ' .	77.07438
we experience a vague uneasiness about events , a suspicion that our political and economic institutions , like the genie in the bottle , have escaped confinement and that we have lost the power to recall them .	62.953712
we feel uncomfortable at being bossed by a corporation or a union or a television set , but until we have some knowledge about these phenomena and what they are doing to us , we can hardly learn to control them .	65.849556
it does not appear that we will be delivered from our situation by articles on the national purpose .	84.293015
the agreeable autocracies is an attempt to explore some of the institutions which both reflect and determine the character of the free society today .	93.60689
the men who speculate on these institutions have , for the most part , come to at least one common conclusion that many of the great enterprises and associations around which our democracy is formed are in themselves autocratic in nature , and possessed of power which can be used to frustrate the citizen who is trying to assert his individuality in the modern world ' ' .	55.386803
these institutions which mr . lyford names `` agreeable autocracies ' ' -- where did they come from ? ?	41.60253
of one thing we can be sure they were not sketched out by the revolutionary theorists of the eighteenth century who formulated the political principles and originally shaped the political institutions of what we term the `` free society ' ' .	69.279045
no doubt there are historians who can explain to a great extent what happened to the plans and projects of the eighteenth century .	57.171078
going back over this ground and analyzing the composition of forces which have created the present scene is one of the tasks undertaken by the center for the study of democratic institutions , in santa barbara .	70.76615
but however we come , finally , to explain and account for the present , the truth we are trying to expose , right now , is that the makers of constitutions and the designers of institutions find it difficult if not impossible to anticipate the behavior of the host of all their enterprises .	114.4051
the host is the flowing life of the human race .	10.891733
this life has its own currents and rhythms , its own multiple cycles and adaptations .	54.435207
should rousseau have been able to leave room in his social theory for the advent of television , atomic energy , and ibm machines ? ?	50.028927
how would thomas jefferson feel after reading factories in the field ? ?	20.011267
they tell us , sir , that we are free , because we have in one hand a ballot , and in the other a stock certificate .	86.77435
with these we shape our destiny and own private property , and that , sir , makes ours the best of all possible societies .	76.37546
the reality of the situation , however , is described by mr . lyford ``	32.326023
many of us may even be secretly relieved at having a plausible excuse to delegate ancient civic responsibilities to a new bureaucracy of experts .	117.72338
thus the member of an industrial union comes to regard his officers as business agents who may proceed without interference or recall	369.91397
and the citizen narrows his political participation to the mere act of voting -- if he votes at all ' ' .	69.751625
copernicus did not question it , ptolemy could not .	74.67249
given the conceptual context within which ancient thought thrived , how could anyone have questioned this principle ? ?	207.56638
the reasons for this are partly observational , partly philosophical , and reinforced by other aesthetic and cultural factors .	68.05232
the obvious natural fact to ancient thinkers was the diurnal rotation of the heavens .	9.696638
not only did constellations like draco , cepheus , and cassiopeia spin circles around the pole , but stars which were not circumpolar rose and set at the same place on the horizon each night .	78.69177
nor did a constellation ' s stars vary in brightness during the course of their nocturnal flights .	52.528538
the conclusion -- the distances of the constellations did not vary and their paths were circular .	185.22334
moreover , the sun ' s path over earth described a segment of a great circle	71.25717
this was clear from the contour of the shadow traced by a gnomon before and after noon .	126.88234
as early as the 6th century b . c . the earth was seen to be spherical .	36.71636
earth , being at the center of the universe , would have the same shape as the latter	46.612373
so , e . g . did aristotle argue , although this may not be an observational reason in favor of circularity .	35.827168
the discoid shapes of sun and moon were also felt to indicate the shape of celestial things .	77.6661
in light of all this , one would require special reasons for saying that the paths of the heavenly bodies were other than circular .	104.02581
why , for example , should the ancients have supposed the diurnal rotation of the heavens to be elliptical ? ?	30.66304
there were no reasons for such suppositions then .	48.064507
this , conjoined with the considerations above , made the circular motions of heavenly bodies appear an almost directly observed fact .	194.43356
additional philosophical considerations , advanced notably by aristotle , supported further the circularity principle .	78.064125
by distinguishing superlunary ( celestial ) and sublunary ( terrestrial ) existence , and reinforcing this with the four-element physics of empedocles , aristotle came to speak of the stars as perfect bodies , which moved in only a perfect way , viz . in a perfect circle .	74.959816
it must , apparently , be motion without termini .	13.420894
because motion which begins and ends at discrete places would ( e . g . for aristotle ) be incomplete .	63.577267
circular motion , however , since it is eternal and perfectly continuous , lacks termini .	85.89629
only imcomplete , imperfect things move towards what they lack .	72.60769
perfect , complete entities , if they move at all , do not move towards what they lack .	112.18599
they move only in accordance with what is in their natures .	42.90146
thus , circular motion is itself one of the essential characteristics of completely perfect celestial existence .	78.14059
to return now to the four-element physics , a mixture of muddy , frothy water will , when standing in a jar , separate out with earth at the bottom , water on top , and the air on top of that .	97.83874
a candle alight in the air directs its flame and smoke upwards .	61.43619
this gives a clue to the cosmical order of elements .	70.25664
thus earth has fallen to the center of the universe .	6.6402
it is covered ( partly ) with water , air is atop of that .	156.0422
pure fire ( the stars ) is in the heavens .	21.00617
when combined with the metaphysical notion that pure forms of this universe are best appreciated when least embodied in a material substratum , it becomes clear that while earth will be dross on a scale of material-formal ratios , celestial bodies will be of a subtle , quickened , ethereal existence , in whose embodiment pure form will be the dominant component and matter will be absent or remain subsidiary .	125.28823
the stars constitute an order of existence different from what we encounter on earth .	87.52365
this is clear when one distinguishes the types of motion appropriate to both regions .	104.861595
a projectile shot up from earth returns rectlinearly to its ' natural ' place of rest .	227.03662
but the natural condition for the heavenly bodies is neither rest , nor rectilinear motion .	76.387436
being less encumbered by material embodiments they partake more of what is divine .	68.21362
let us re-examine the publicized contrasts between ptolemaic and copernican astronomy .	6.014983
bluntly , there never was a ptolemaic system of astronomy .	29.13204
copernicus ' achievement was to have invented systematic astronomy .	10.024215
the almagest and the hypotheses outline ptolemy ' s conception of his own task as the provision of computational tables , independent calculating devices for the prediction of future planetary perturbations .	57.296047
indeed , in the halma edition of theon ' s presentation of the hypotheses there is a chart setting out ( under six distinct headings ) otherwise unrelated diagrams for describing the planetary motions .	94.89939
no attempt is made by ptolemy to weld into a single scheme ( a-la-aristotle ) , these independent predicting-machines .	63.7091
they all have this in common the earth is situated near the center of the deferent .	20.140789
but that one should superimpose all these charts , run a pin through the common point , and then scale each planetary deferent larger and smaller ( to keep the epicycles from ' bumping ' ) , this is contrary to any intention ptolemy ever expresses .	179.22192
he might even suppose the planets to move at infinity .	56.590626
ptolemy ' s problem is to forecast where , against the inverted bowl of night , some particular light will be found at future times .	102.657455
his problem concerns longitudes , latitudes , and angular velocities .	10.854794
the distances of these points of light is a problem he cannot master , beyond crude conjectures as to the orderings of the planetary orbits viewed outward from earth .	69.58052
but none of this has prevented scientists , philosophers , and even historians of science , from speaking of the ptolemaic system , in contrast to the copernican .	46.778812
it is engendered by confounding the aristotelian cosmology in the almagest with the geocentric astronomy .	35.37485
ptolemy recurrently denies that he could ever explain planetary motion .	238.01425
this is what necessitates the nonsystematic character of his astronomy .	233.26445
so when textbooks , like that of baker set out drawings of the ' ptolemaic system ' , complete with earth in the center and the seven heavenly bodies epicyclically arranged on their several deferents , we have nothing but a misleading 20th-century idea of what never existed historically .	92.34713
it is the chief merit in copernicus ' work that all his planetary calculations are interdependent .	68.80474
he cannot , e . g . compute the retrograde arc traveled by mars , without also making suppositions about the earth ' s own motion .	69.479996
he cannot describe eclipses without entertaining some form of a three-body problem .	19.971354
in ptolemaic terms , however , eclipses and retrograde motion were phenomena simpliciter , to be explained directly as possible resultants of epicyclical combinations .	108.1461
in a systematic astronomy , like that of copernicus , retrogradations become part of the conceptual structure of the system	52.904247
they are no longer a puzzling aspect of intricately variable , local planetary motions .	219.58331
another contrast stressed when discussing ptolemaic vs . copernican astronomy , turns on the idea of simplicity .	30.597242
it is often stated that copernican astronomy is ' simpler ' than ptolemaic .	108.18566
some even say that this is the reason for the ultimate acceptance of the former .	34.144417
thus , margenau remarks `` a large number of unrelated epicycles was needed to explain the observations , but otherwise the ( ptolemaic ) system served well and with quantitative precision .	80.03797
copernicus , by placing the sun at the center of the planetary universe , was able to reduce the number of epicycles from eighty-three to seventeen .	22.691072
historical records indicate that copernicus was unaware of the fundamental aspects of his so-called ' revolution ' , unaware perhaps of its historical importance , he rested content with having produced a simpler scheme for prediction .	142.50517
as an illustration of the principle of simplicity the heliocentric discovery has a peculiar appeal because it allows simplicity to be arithmetized	106.56169
it involves a reduction in the number of epicycles from eighty-three to seventeen ' ' .	19.864536
if in any one calculation ptolemy had had to invoke 83 epicycles all at once , while copernicus never required more than one third this number , then ( in the sense obvious to margenau ) ptolemaic astronomy would be simpler than copernican .	133.80281
but no single planetary problem ever required of ptolemy more than six epicycles at one time .	58.54946
this , of course , results from the non-systematic , ' cellular ' character of ptolemaic theory .	80.84466
calculations within the copernican framework always raised questions about planetary configurations .	22.127209
these could be met only by considering the dynamical elements of several planets at one time .	59.715977
this is more ambitious than ptolemy is ever required to be when he faces his isolated problems .	148.92157
thus , in no ordinary sense of ' simplicity ' is the ptolemaic theory simpler than the copernican .	49.011116
this was not simpler but much more difficult than exercises within ptolemy ' s astronomy .	32.88523
analogously , anyone who argues that einstein ' s theory of gravitation is simpler than newton ' s , must say rather more to explain how it is that the latter is mastered by student-physicists , while the former can be managed ( with difficulty ) only by accomplished experts .	57.727116
in a sense , einstein ' s theory is simpler than newton ' s , and there is a corresponding sense in which copernicus ' theory is simpler than ptolemy ' s .	15.242215
but ' simplicity ' here refers to systematic simplicity .	13.955908
the number of primitive ideas in systematically-simple theories is reduced to a minimum .	42.692257
the axioms required to make the theoretical machinery operate are set out tersely and powerfully , so that all permissible operations within the theory can be traced rigorously back to these axioms , rules , and primitive notions .	113.90371
this characterizes euclid ' s formulation of geometry , but not ptolemy ' s astronomy .	29.349781
there are in the almagest no rules for determining in advance whether a new epicycle will be required for dealing with abberations in lunar , solar , or planetary behavior .	91.16647
the strongest appeal of the copernican formulation consisted in just this ideally , the justification for dealing with special problems in particular ways is completely set out in the basic ' rules ' of the theory .	163.49817
the lower-level hypotheses are never ' ad hoc ' , never introduced ex post facto just to sweep up within the theory some recalcitrant datum .	159.6732
copernicus , to an extent unachieved by ptolemy , approximated to euclid ' s vision .	17.414019
de revolutionibus is not just a collection of facts and techniques .	142.34747
it is an organized system of these things .	9.832861
solving astronomical problems requires , for copernicus , not a random search of unrelated tables , but a regular employment of the rules defining the entire discipline .	74.345314
hence , noting the simplicity achieved in copernicus ' formulation does not provide another reason for the acceptance of de revolutionibus , another reason beyond its systematic superiority .	80.92777
1543 a . d . is often venerated as the birthday of the scientific revolution .	24.340046
it is really the funeral day of scholastic science .	57.75757
granted , the cosmological , philosophical , and cultural reverberations initiated by the de revolutionibus were felt with increasing violence during the 300 years to follow .	71.880356
but , considered within technical astronomy , a different pattern can be traced .	58.621506
in what does the dissatisfaction of copernicus-the-astronomer consist ? ?	21.50621
what in the almagest draws his fire ? ?	1.0189146
the formal displacement of the geocentric principle far from being copernicus ' primary concern , was introduced only to resolve what seemed to him intolerable in orthodox astronomy , namely , the ' unphysical ' triplication of centric reference-points one center from which the planet ' s distances were calculated , another around which planetary velocities were computed , and still a third center ( the earth ) from which the observations originated .	81.92055
this arrangement was for copernicus literally monstrous `` with ( the ptolemaists ) it is as though an artist were to gather the hands , feet , head and other members for his images from divers models , each part excellently drawn , but not related to a single body	141.57976
and since they in no way match each other , the result would be a monster rather than a man ' ' .	29.46391
copernicus required a systematically integrated , physically intelligible astronomy .	8.033269
his objective was , essentially , to repair those aspects of orthodox astronomy responsible for its deficiencies in achieving these ends .	267.07785
that such deficiencies existed within ptolemy ' s theory was not discovered de novo by copernicus .	39.326923
the critical , rigorous examinations of nicholas of cusa and nicholas of oresme provided the context ( a late medieval context ) for nicholas copernicus ' own work .	112.46515
without abandoning too much , copernicus sought to make orthodox astronomy systematically and mechanically acceptable .	116.276886
he did not think himself to be firing the first shot of an intellectual revolution .	61.642483
henrietta ' s feeling of identity with sara sullam was crowned by her discovery of the coincidence that sara ' s epitaph in the jewish cemetery in venice referred to her as `` the sulamite ' ' .	30.49763
into the texture of this tapestry of history and human drama henrietta , as every artist delights to do , wove strands of her own intuitive insights into human nature and -- especially in the remarkable story of the attraction and conflict between two so disparate and fervent characters as this pair -- into the relations of men and women `` in their relations , she was the giver and he the receiver , nay the demander .	93.452934
one is so accustomed to think of men as the privileged who need but ask and receive , and women as submissive and yielding , that our sympathies are usually enlisted on the side of the man whose love is not returned , and we condemn the woman as a coquette .	109.642395
the very firmness of her convictions and logical clearness of her arguments captivated and stimulated him to make greater efforts	81.10715
usually , this is most exasperating to men , who expect every woman to verify their preconceived notions concerning her sex , and when she does not , immediately condemn her as eccentric and unwomanly .	81.01353
she had the opportunity that few clever women can resist , of showing her superiority in argument over a man .	99.973206
women themselves have come to look upon matters in the same light as the outside world , and scarcely find any wrong in submitting to the importunities of a stronger will , even when their affections are withheld .	151.0645
she was exposing herself to temptation which it is best to avoid where it can consistently be done .	59.70006
one who invites such trials of character is either foolhardy , overconfident or too simple and childlike in faith in mankind to see the danger .	110.49116
in any case but the last , such a course is sure to avenge itself upon the individual	66.35624
the moral powers no more than the physical and mental , can bear overstraining .	50.2811
and , in the last case , a bitter disappointment but too often meets the confiding nature .	158.5525
henrietta was discovering in the process of writing , as the born writer does , not merely a channel for the discharge of accumulated information but a stimulus to the development of the creative powers of observation , insight and intuition .	62.673065
dr . isaacs was so pleased with the quality of her biographical study of sara sullam that he considered submitting it to the century magazine or harper ' s but he decided that its jewish subject probably would not interest them and published it in the messenger , `` so our readers will be benefited instead ' ' .	107.157036
under her father ' s influence it did not occur to henrietta that she might write on subjects outside the jewish field , but she did begin writing for other anglo-jewish papers and thus increased her output and her audience .	150.40797
and she wrote the libretto for an oratorio on the subject of judas maccabeus performed at the hanukkah festival which came in december .	41.263588
by her eighteenth birthday her bent for writing was so evident that papa and mamma gave her a life of dickens as a spur to her aspiration .	76.85499
another source of intellectual stimulus was opened to her at that time by the founding of johns hopkins university within walking distance of home .	99.35166
it was established in a couple of buildings in the shopping district , with only a few professors , but all eminent men , and a few hundred eager students housed in nearby dwellings .	60.44891
in september ' 76 thomas huxley , darwin ' s famous disciple , came from england to speak in a crowded auditorium at the formal opening of the university	43.299454
and although it was a school for men only , it afforded henrietta an opportunity to attend its public lectures .	198.18668
in the following year her father undertook to give a course in hebrew theology to johns hopkins students , and this brought to the szold house a group of bright young jews who had come to baltimore to study , and who enjoyed being fed and mothered by mamma and entertained by henrietta and rachel , who played and sang for them in the upstairs sitting room on sunday evenings .	97.27076
from philadelphia came cyrus adler and joseph jastrow .	8.106095
adler , judge sulzberger ' s nephew , came to study assyriology .	74.800934
a smart , shrewd and ambitious young man , well connected , and with a knack for getting in the good graces of important people , he was bound to go far .	75.0269
joseph jastrow , the younger son of the distinguished rabbi , marcus jastrow , was a friendly , round-faced fellow with a little mustache , whose field was psychology , and who was also a punster and a jolly tease .	51.270397
his father was a good friend of rabbi szold , and joe lived with the szolds for a while .	50.65049
both these youths , who greatly admired henrietta , were somewhat younger than she , as were also the neighboring friedenwald boys , who were then studying medicine	151.34619
and bright though they all were , they could not possibly compete for her interest with papa , whose mind -- although he never tried to dazzle or patronize lesser lights with it -- naturally eclipsed theirs and made them seem to her even younger than they were .	133.818
besides , miss henrietta -- as she was generally known since she had put up her hair with a chignon in the back -- had little time to spare them from her teaching and writing	85.74832
so cyrus adler became interested in her friend racie friedenwald , and joe jastrow -- the only young man who when he wrote had the temerity to address her as henrietta , and signed himself joe -- fell in love with pretty sister rachel .	83.585335
henrietta , however , was at that time engaged in a lengthy correspondence with joe ' s older and more serious brother , morris , who was just about her own age and whom she had got to know well during trips to philadelphia with papa , when he substituted for rabbi jastrow at rodeph shalom temple there during its rabbi ' s absence in europe .	80.198
young morris , who , while attending the university of pennsylvania , also taught and edited a paper , found time to write henrietta twenty-page letters on everything that engaged his interest , from the acting of sarah bernhardt in philadelphia to his reactions to the comments of `` sulamith ' ' on the jewish reform movement being promulgated by the hebrew union college in cincinnati .	97.63954
unlike his younger brother , joe , he never presumed to address her more familiarly than as `` my dear friend ' ' , although he praised and envied the elegance and purity of her style .	55.19958
and when he complained of the lack of time for all he wanted to do , henrietta advised him to rise at five in the morning as she and papa did .	88.96275
one thing papa had not taught henrietta was how to handle a young man as high-spirited and opinionated as herself .	98.05666
she could not resist the opportunity `` of showing her superiority in argument over a man ' ' which she had remarked as one of the `` feminine follies ' ' of sara sullam	48.338737
and in her forthright way , henrietta , who in her story of sara had indicated her own unwillingness `` to think of men as the privileged ' ' and `` women as submissive and yielding ' ' , felt obliged to defend vigorously any statement of hers to which morris jastrow took the slightest exception -- he objected to her stand on the corbin affair , as well as on the radical reforms of dr . wise of hebrew union college -- until once , in sheer desperation , he wrote that he had given up hope they would ever agree on anything .	89.90984
but that did not prevent him from writing more long letters , or from coming to spend his christmas vacations with the hospitable , lively szolds in their pleasant house on lombard street .	97.899734
`` we ' ve got father and mother and each other ' ' said beth on the first page of louisa alcott ' s little women	67.452774
and , `` i do think that families are the most beautiful things in all the world ' ' , burst out jo some five hundred pages later in that popular story of the march family , which had first appeared when henrietta was eight	109.22009
and the szold family , as it developed , bore a striking resemblance to the marches .	65.66822
mr . march , like benjamin szold , was a clergyman , although of an indeterminate denomination	45.06236
and `` marmee ' ' march , like sophie szold , was the competent manager of her brood of girls , of whom the marches had only four to the szolds ' five .	67.38712
but the march girls had their counterparts in the szold girls .	31.24627
henrietta could easily identify herself with jo march , although jo was not the eldest sister .	47.172577
neither was henrietta hoydenish like jo , who frankly wished she were a boy and had deliberately shortened her name , which , like henrietta ' s , was the feminine form of a boy ' s name .	55.601883
but both were high-spirited and vivacious , both had tempers to control , both loved languages , especially english and german , both were good teachers and wrote for publication .	197.61943
each was her mother ' s assistant and confidante	1336.03
and each stood out conspicuously in the family picture .	69.799614
bertha szold was more like meg , the eldest march girl , who `` learned that a woman ' s happiest kingdom is home , her highest honor the art of ruling it , not as a queen , but a wise wife and mother ' ' .	75.87525
bertha , blue-eyed like mamma , was from the start her mother ' s daughter , destined for her mother ' s role in life .	21.576685
sadie , like beth march , suffered ill health -- got rheumatic fever and had to be careful of her heart -- but that never dampened her spirits .	62.544006
when her right hand was incapacitated by the rheumatism , sadie learned to write with her left hand .	81.527115
she wrote gay plays about the girls for family entertainments , like `` oh , what fun ! !	83.90631
a comedy in three acts ' ' , in which , under `` personages ' ' , henrietta appeared as `` a schoolmarm ' ' , and bertha , who was only a trifle less brilliant in high school than henrietta had been , appeared as `` dummkopf ' ' .	51.77966
played chopin in the `` soiree musicale of mr . guthrie ' s pupils ' '	31.213575
and she recited `` hector ' s farewell to andromache ' ' most movingly , to the special delight of rabbi jastrow at his home in germantown near philadelphia , where the szold girls took turns visiting between the visits of the jastrow boys at the szolds ' in baltimore .	68.38558
adele , like amy , the youngest of the marches , was the rebellious , mischievous , rather calculating and ambitious one .	35.213043
for rachel , conceded to be the prettiest of the szold girls -- and she did make a pretty picture sitting in the grape-arbor strumming her guitar and singing in her silvery tones -- there was no particular march counterpart	96.07222
but both groups were so closely knit that despite individual differences the family life in both cases was remarkably similar in atmosphere if not entirely in content -- the one being definitely jewish and the other vaguely christian .	237.67424
the szolds , like the marches , enjoyed and loved living together , even in troubled times	205.64215
and , as in the march home , any young man who called on the szolds found himself confronted with a phalanx of femininity which made it rather difficult to direct his particular attention to any one of them .	84.41868
this included mamma , jolly , generous , and pretty , with whom they all fell in love , just as papa had first fallen in love with her mamma before he chose her	88.205734
and when a young man like morris jastrow had enjoyed the szold hospitality , he felt obliged to send his respects and his gifts not merely to henrietta , in whom he was really interested , but to all the szold girls and mamma .	67.874405
and just as `` laurie ' ' lawrence was first attracted to bright jo march , who found him immature by her high standards , and then had to content himself with her younger sister amy , so joe jastrow , who had also been writing henrietta before he came to johns hopkins , had to content himself with her younger sister , pretty rachel .	78.33379
and like jo march , who saw her sisters meg and amy involved in `` lovering ' ' before herself , henrietta saw her sisters rachel and sadie drawn outside their family circle by the attraction of suitors , rachel by joe jastrow , and sadie by max lobl , a young businessman who would write her romantic descriptions of his trips by steamboat down the mississippi .	67.74607
olgivanna -- in her country the nickname was a respectful form of address -- was not only attractive but shrewd , durable , sensible , and smart .	85.4863
no wonder wright was enchanted -- no two better suited people ever met .	303.2383
almost from that day , until his death , olgivanna was to stay at his side	71.73983
but the years that immediately followed were to be extraordinarily trying , both for wright and his montenegrin lady .	90.54712
it must be granted that the flouting of convention , no matter how well intentioned one may be , is sure to lead to trouble , or at least to the discomfort that goes with social disapproval .	96.20489
even so , many of the things that happened to wright and olgivanna seem inordinately severe .	91.40423
their afflictions centered on one maddening difficulty miriam held up the divorce proceedings that she herself had asked for .	269.43274
reporters began to trail miriam everywhere , and to encourage her to make appalling statements about wright and his doings .	55.471355
flocks of writs , attachments , and unpleasant legal papers of every sort began to fly through the air .	119.83681
the distracted miriam would agree to a settlement through her legal representative , then change her mind and make another attack on wright as a person .	119.23768
at last her lawyer , arthur d . cloud , gave up the case because she turned down three successive settlements he arranged .	266.79745
cloud made an interesting statement in parting from his client `` i wanted to be a lawyer , and mrs . wright wanted me to be an avenging angel .	30.196846
the first thing to do is get her some money by a temporary but definite adjustment pending a final disposition of the case .	193.2009
but every time i suggested this to her , mrs . wright turned it down and demanded that i go out and punish mr . wright .	75.68789
i am an attorney , not an instrument of vengeance ' ' .	13.693975
miriam noel disregarded the free advice of her departing counselor , and appointed a heavy-faced young man named harold jackson to take his place .	119.01376
and during the unhappy time , miriam often would charge that wright and olgivanna were misdemeanants against the public order of wisconsin .	92.58615
yet somehow , when officers were prodded into visiting taliesin to execute the warrants , they would find neither wright nor olgivanna at home .	67.26693
this showed that common sense had not died out at the county and village level -- though why the unhappy and obviously unbalanced woman was not restrained remains a puzzle .	205.07852
the misery of miriam ' s bitterness can be felt today by anyone who studies the case -- it was hopeless , agonizing , and destructive , with miriam herself bearing the heaviest burden of shame and pain .	104.73281
to get an idea of the embarrassment and chagrin that was heaped upon wright and olgivanna , we should bear in mind that the raids were sometimes led by miriam in person .	115.997
one of the most distressing of these scenes occurred at spring green toward the end of the open warfare , on a beautiful day in june .	156.12833
at this time miriam noel appeared , urging on constable henry pengally , whose name showed him to be a descendant of the welsh settlers in the neighborhood .	37.7687
a troop of reporters brought up the rear .	12.398817
miriam was stopped at the taliesin gate , and william weston , now the estate foreman , came out to parley .	68.031136
he said that mr . wright was not in , and so could not be arrested on something called a peace warrant that miriam was waving in the air .	114.22804
miriam now ordered pengally to break down the gate , but he said he really couldn ' t go that far .	44.275185
at this point mrs . frances cupply , one of wright ' s handsome daughters by his first wife , came from the house and tried to calm miriam as she tore down a no visitors sign and smashed the glass pane on another sign with a rock .	77.22863
miriam noel wright said , `` here i am at my own home , locked out so i must stand in the road ' ' ! !	43.60743
then she rounded on weston and cried , `` you always did wright ' s dirty work ! !	82.337616
when i take over taliesin , the first thing i ' ll do is fire you ' ' .	35.28636
`` madame noel , i think you had better go ' ' , said mrs . cupply .	25.277416
`` and i think you had better leave ' ' , replied miriam .	15.97948
turning to the reporters , she asked , `` did you hear her ? ?	23.994404
' i think you had better leave ' ! !	65.715645
and this is my own home ' ' .	1.8719382
in the silence that followed , miriam walked close to mrs . cupply , who drew back a step on her side of the gate .	59.886013
then , with staring eyes and lips drawn thin , miriam said to the young woman , `` you are ugly -- uglier than you used to be , and you were always very ugly .	56.070374
you are even uglier than mr . wright ' ' .	3.1332614
the animosity expressed by such a scene had the penetrating quality of a natural force	89.08598
and it gave miriam noel a fund of energy like that of a person inspired to complete some great and universal work of art .	237.83
as if to make certain that wright would be unable to pay any settlement at all , miriam wrote to prospective clients denouncing him	96.177185
she also went to washington and appealed to senator george william norris of nebraska , the fighting liberal , from whose office a sympathetic but cautious harrumphing was heard .	149.01648
then , after overtures to accept a settlement and go through with a divorce , miriam gave a ghastly echo of mrs . micawber by suddenly stating , `` i will never leave mr . wright ' ' .	44.05867
under this kind of pressure , it is not surprising that wright would make sweeping statements to the newspapers .	47.140995
miriam had not yet goaded him into mentioning her directly , but one can feel the generalized anger in wright ' s remarks to reporters when he was asked , one morning on arrival in chicago , what he thought of the city as a whole .	62.076584
first , wright said , he was choked by the smoke , which fortunately kept him from seeing the dreadful town .	95.01091
`` that isn ' t a boulevard , it ' s a racetrack ' ' ! !	13.2095175
cried wright , showing that automobiles were considered to be a danger as early as the 1920 ' s .	36.893982
`` this is a horrible way to live ' ' , wright went on .	27.547499
`` you are being strangled by traffic ' ' .	1.3045508
he was then asked for a solution of the difficulty , and began to talk trenchant sense , though private anguish showed through in the vehemence of his manner .	175.5069
`` take a gigantic knife and sweep it over the loop ' ' , wright said .	27.934597
`` cut off every building at the seventh floor .	9.852298
if you cut down these horrible buildings you ' ll have no more traffic jams .	23.76332
you ' ll have some joy in the life of this city .	34.8821
after all , that ' s the job of the architect -- to give the world a little joy ' ' .	47.705364
little enough joy was afforded wright in the spring of 1925 , when another destructive fire broke out at taliesin .	60.29297
the first news stories had it that this blaze was started by a bolt of lightning , as though miriam could call down fire from heaven like a prophet of the old testament .	74.32709
a storm did take place that night , and fortunately enough , it included a cloudburst that helped put out the flames .	64.873116
later accounts blamed defective wiring for starting the fire	1317.6545
at any rate , heat grew so intense in the main part of the house that it melted the window panes , and fused the k ' ang-si pottery to cinders .	44.421055
wright set his loss at $200 , 000 , a figure perhaps justified by the unique character of the house that had been ruined , and the faultless taste that had gone into the selection of the prints and other things that were destroyed .	68.5153
in spite of the disaster , wright completed during this period plans for the lake tahoe resort , in which he suggested the shapes of american indian tepees -- a project of great and appropriate charm , that came to nothing .	93.6088
amid a shortage of profitable work , the memory of albert johnson ' s $20 , 000 stood out in lonely grandeur -- the money had quickly melted away .	102.58606
a series of conferences with friends and bankers began about this time	148.42789
and the question before these meetings was , here is a man of international reputation and proved earning power	163.29132
how can he be financed so that he can find the work he ought to do ? ?	37.716717
while this was under consideration , dauntless as ever wright set about the building of taliesin 3 .	355.36096
as he made plans for the new taliesin , wright also got on paper his conception of a cathedral of steel and glass to house a congregation of all faiths , and the idea for a planetarium with a sloping ramp .	85.31869
years were to pass before these plans came off the paper , and wright was justified in thinking , as the projects failed , that much of what he had to show his country and the world would never be seen except by visitors to taliesin .	85.46335
and now there was some question as to his continued residence there .	248.97989
billy koch , who had once worked for wright as a chauffeur , gave a deposition for miriam ' s use that he had seen olgivanna living at taliesin .	72.566055
this might put wright in such a bad light before a court that miriam would be awarded taliesin	331.22955
nor was she moved by a letter from wright pointing out that if he was not `` compelled to spend money on useless lawyer ' s bills , useless hotel bills , and useless doctor ' s bills ' ' , he could more quickly provide miriam with a suitable home either in los angeles or paris , as she preferred .	86.676056
miriam sniffed at this , and complained that wright had said unkind things about her to reporters .	86.08857
his reply was , `` everything that has been printed derogatory to you , purporting to have come from me , was a betrayal , and nothing yet has been printed which i have sanctioned ' ' .	48.311947
what irritated miriam was that wright had told the papers about a reasonable offer he had made , which he considered she would accept `` when she tires of publicity ' ' .	90.3863
from her california headquarters , miriam fired back , `` i shall never divorce mr . wright , to permit him to marry olga milanoff ' ' .	24.888195
then miriam varied the senseless psychological warfare by suddenly withdrawing a suit for separate maintenance that had been pending , and asking for divorce on the grounds of cruelty , with the understanding that wright would not contest it .	96.09614
the bank of wisconsin sent a representative to the judge ' s chambers in madison to give information on wright ' s ability to meet the terms .	57.412113
he said that the architect might reasonably be expected to carry his financial burdens if all harrassment could be brought to an end , and that the bank would accept a mortgage on taliesin to help bring this about .	80.46291
miriam said that she must be assured that `` that other woman , olga , will not be in luxury while i am scraping along ' ' .	116.70565
this exhausted wright ' s patience , and in consequence he talked freely to reporters in a madison hotel suite .	125.21119
`` volstead laws , speed laws , divorce laws ' ' , he said , `` as they now stand , demoralize the individual , make liars and law breakers of us in one way or another , and tend to make our experiment in democracy absurd .	57.37366
if mrs . wright doesn ' t accept the terms in the morning , i ' ll go either to tokyo or to holland , to do what i can .	65.2415
i realize , in taking this stand , just what it means to me and mine ' ' .	34.84198
here wright gave a slight sigh of weariness , and continued , `` it means more long years lived across the social grain of the life of our people , making shift to live in the face of popular disrespect and misunderstanding as i best can for myself and those dependent upon me ' ' .	99.55036
next day , word came that miriam was not going through with the divorce	66.6462
his mentioning of japan and holland had been merely the expression of wishful thinking .	68.50709
no matter what troubles might betide him , this most american of artists knew in his heart he could not function properly outside his native land .	260.90543
in a few weeks miriam made another sortie at taliesin , but was repulsed at the locked and guarded gates .	46.274605
more likely , you simply told yourself , as you handed us the book , that it mattered little what we incanted providing we underwent the discipline of incantation .	133.15506
for pride ' s sake , i will not say that the coy and leering vade mecum of those verses insinuated itself into my soul .	37.79602
besides , that particular message does no more than weakly echo the roar in all fresh blood .	109.43608
but what you could not know , of course , was how smoothly the victorian fitzgerald was to lead into an american fitzgerald of my own vintage under whose banner we adolescents were to come , if not of age , then into a bright , taut semblance of it .	114.9988
i do not suppose you ever heard of f . scott fitzgerald , living or dead , and moreover i do not suppose that , even if you had , his legend would have seemed to you to warrant more than a cluck of disapproval .	108.47633
neither his appetites , his exacerbations , nor his despair were kin to yours .	80.51838
he might have been the man in the moon for all you could have understood him .	377.24515
but he was no man in the moon to me .	28.939596
although his tender nights were not the ones i dreamed of , nor was it for yachts , sports cars , tall drinks , and swimming pools , nor yet for money or what money buys that i burned , i too was burning and watching myself burn .	210.34273
the flame was simply of a different kind .	7.312654
it was symbolized ( at least for those of us who recognized ourselves in the image ) by that self-consuming , elegiac candle of edna st . vincent millay ' s , that candle which from the quatrain where she ensconced it became a beacon to us , but which in point of fact would have had to be as tall as a funeral taper to last even the evening , let alone the night .	79.26568
one should not , of course , pluck the head off a flower and expect its perfume to linger on .	124.83025
yet this passion for passion , now that i look back on it with passion spent , seems somewhat overblown and operatic , though as a diva miss millay perfectly controlled her notes .	146.75874
only what else was she singing but the old song of songs , that most ancient of tunes that nature plays with such unfailing response upon young nerves ? ?	151.91043
perhaps the mere fact that by plucking on the nerves nature can awaken in the most ordinary of us , temporarily anyway , the sleeping poet , and in poets can discover their immortality , is the most remarkable of all the remarkable phenomena to which we can attest ? ?	86.861084
one can see it as humiliating that an extra hormone casually fed into our chemistry may induce us to lay down our lives for a lover or a friend	117.01068
one can take it as no more than another veil torn from the mystery of the soul .	41.949486
but it could also be looked at from the other end of the spectrum .	36.864826
one could see this chemical determinant as in itself a miracle .	171.43416
in any case , miss millay ' s sweet-throated bitterness , her variations on the theme that the world was not only well lost for love but even well lost for lost love , her constant and wonderfully tragic posture , so unlike that of fitzgerald since it required no scenery or props , drew from the me that i was when i fell upon her verses an overwhelming yea .	145.4259
but all this , i am well aware , is the bel canto of love , and although i have always liked to think that it was to the bel canto and to that alone that i listened , i know well enough that it was not .	46.06034
if i am to speak the whole truth about my knowledge of love , i will have to stop trying to emulate the transcendant nightingale .	44.425884
there is another side of love , more nearly symbolized by the croak of the mating capercailzie , or better still perhaps by the mute antics of the slug .	81.69523
whether you experienced the passion of desire i have , of course , no way of knowing , nor indeed have i wished with even the most fleeting fragment of a wish to know , for the fact that one constitutes by one ' s mere existence so to speak the proof of some sort of passion makes any speculation upon this part of one ' s parents ' experience more immodest , more scandalizing , more deeply unwelcome than an obscenity from a stranger .	79.559364
at the same time , i am aware that my recoil could be interpreted by readers of the tea leaves at the bottom of my psyche as an incestuous sign , since theirs is a science of paradox if one hates , they say it is because one loves	79.87692
if one bullies , they say it is because one is afraid	176.6918
if one shuns , they say it is because one desires	543.9422
and according to them , whatever one fancies one feels , what one feels in fact is the opposite .	69.27726
well , normally abnormal or normally normal , neurotic or merely fastidious ( do the tea-leaf readers , by the way , allow psyches to have moral taste ? ?	116.22544
) , i have never wanted to know what you knew of passion .	90.04345
you probably would not remember , since you never seemed to remember even the same moments as i , much less their intensity , one sunny midday on fifth avenue when you had set out with me for some final shopping less than a week before the wedding you staged for me with such reluctance at the farm .	146.80963
we had been walking quite briskly , for despite your being so small and me so tall , your stride in those days could easily match mine .	241.64648
we had stopped before a shop window to assess its autumnal display , when you suddenly turned to me , looking up from beneath one of your wrong hats , and with your nervous `` ahem ' ' ! !	56.530132
said `` there are things i must tell you about this man you are marrying which he does not know himself ' ' .	50.078346
if you had screamed right there in the street where we stood , i could not have felt more fear .	71.89503
with scarcely a mumble of excuse , i fled .	129.59717
i fled , however , not from what might have been the natural fear of being unable to disguise from you that the things about my bridegroom -- in the sense you meant the word `` things ' ' -- which you had been galvanizing yourself to tell me as a painful part of your maternal duty were things which i had already insisted upon finding out for myself ( despite , i may now say , the unspeakable awkwardness of making the discovery on principle , yes , on principle , and in cold blood ) because i was resolved , as a modern woman , not to be a mollycoddle waiting for life but to seize life by the throat .	119.64382
i had developed too foolproof a facade to be afraid of self-betrayal .	58.78005
what i fled from was my fear of what , unwittingly , you might betray , without meaning to , about my father and yourself .	184.03485
but i can see from this latest trick of memory how much more arbitrary and influential it is than the will .	242.46284
while my memory holds with relentless tenacity , as i cannot too often stress , to my wrongs , when it comes to my shames , it gestures and jokes and toys with chronology like a prestidigitator in the hope of distracting me from them .	101.13835
just as i was about to enlarge upon my discovery of the underside of the leaf of love , memory , displeased at being asked to yield its unsavory secrets , dashed ahead of me , calling back over its shoulder `` skip it .	164.72574
but i will not skip it or cut it out .	25.854767
it is not my intention in this narrative to picture myself as a helpless victim moored to the rock of experience and left to the buffetings of chance .	99.21641
if to be innocent is to be helpless , then i had been -- as are we all -- helpless at the start .	121.27289
but the time came when i was no longer innocent and therefore no longer helpless .	38.166885
helpless in that sense i can never be again .	315.2688
however , i confess my hope that i will be innocent again , not with a pristine , accidental innocence , but rather with an innocence achieved by the slow cutting away of the flesh to reach the bone .	94.12107
for innocence , of all the graces of the spirit , is i believe the one most to be prayed for .	88.84766
although it is constantly made to look foolish ( too simple to come in out of the rain , people say , who have found in the innocent an impediment ) , it does not mind looking foolish because it is not concerned with how it looks .	69.92383
it assumes that things are as they seem when they seem best , and when they seem worst it overlooks them .	112.77924
to innocence , a word given is a word that will be kept .	39.052708
instinctively , innocence does unto others as it expects to be done by .	115.25258
but when these expectations are once too often ground into the dust , innocence can falter , since its strength is according to the strength of him who possesses it .	113.852455
the innocence of which i speak is , i know , not incorruptible .	69.07605
but i insist upon believing that even when it is lost , it may , like paradise , be regained .	51.940784
however , it was not of innocence in general that i was speaking , but of perhaps the frailest and surely the least important side of it which is innocence in romantic love .	113.00884
here , if anywhere , it is not wholly incontrovertible .	77.35397
to you , for instance , the word innocence , in this connotation , probably retained its biblical , or should i say technical sense , and therefore i suppose i must make myself quite clear by saying that i lost -- or rather handed over -- what you would have considered to be my innocence two weeks before i was legally entitled , and in fact by oath required , to hand it over along with what other goods and bads i had .	132.7438
but to me innocence is far less tangible .	12.267895
i had long since begun to lose my general innocence when i lost my trust in you , but this special innocence i lost before ever i loved , through my discovery that one could tremble with desire and even experience a flaming delight that had nothing , nothing whatever to do with friendship or liking , let alone with love .	172.32777
i knew this knowledge to be corrupting at the time i acquired it	97.63954
today , these many years later , after all the temptations resisted or yielded to , the weasel satisfactions and the engulfing dissatisfactions since endured , i call it corrupting still .	98.29327
you , i could swear to it , remained innocent in this sense until the end .	208.77489
yours , but not mine , was an age in which innocence was fostered and carefully -- if not perhaps altogether innocently -- preserved .	184.89209
you had grown up at a time when the most distinguishing mark of a lady was the noli me tangere writ plain across her face .	82.256744
moreover , because of the particular blot on your family escutcheon through what may only have been one unbridled moment on your grandmother ' s part , and because you had the lean-to kitchen and trundle bed of your childhood to outgrow , what you obviously most desired with both your conscious and unconscious person , what you bent your whole will , sensibility , and intelligence upon , was to be a lady .	150.10562
before being daughter , wife , or mother , before being cultured ( a word now bereft both socially and politically of the sheen you children of frontiersmen bestowed on it ) , before being sorry for the poor , progressive about public health , and prettily if somewhat imprecisely humanitarian , indeed first and foremost , you were a lady .	207.98198
there was , of course , more to the portrait of a lady you carried in your mind ' s eye than the sine qua non of her virtue .	68.65389
a lady , you made clear to me both by precept and example , never raised her voice or slumped in her chair , never failed in social tact ( in heaven , for instance , would not mention st . john the baptist ' s head ) , never pouted or withdrew or scandalized in company , never reminded others of her physical presence by unseemly sound or gesture , never indulged in public scenes or private confidences , never spoke of money save in terms of alleviating suffering , never gossiped or maligned , never stressed but always minimized the hopelessness of anything from sin to death itself .	121.32303
the songs sandburg sang often reminded listeners of songs of a kindred character they knew entirely or in fragments .	198.82455
often these listeners would refer sandburg to persons who had similar ballads or ditties .	37.962547
in due time sandburg was a walking thesaurus of american folk music .	29.568262
after he had finished the first two volumes of his lincoln , sandburg went to work assembling a book of songs out of hobo and childhood days and from the memory of songs others had taught him .	92.32785
he rummaged , found composers and arrangers , collaborated on the main design and outline of harmonization with musicians , ballad singers , and musicologists .	70.30295
the result was a collection of 280 songs , ballads , ditties , brought together from all regions of america , more than one hundred never before published the american songbag .	57.858315
each song or ditty was prefaced by an author ' s note which indicated the origin and meaning of the song as well as special interest the song had , musical arrangement , and most of the chorus and verses .	107.70656
the book , published in 1927 , has been selling steadily ever since .	156.78717
as sandburg said at the time `` it is as ancient as the medieval european ballads brought to the appalachian mountains , it is as modern as skyscrapers , the volstead act , and the latest oil well gusher ' ' .	43.549175
sandburg is in constant demand as an entertainer .	9.925944
first , carl respects his audience and prepares his speeches carefully .	90.26514
even when he is called upon for impromptu remarks , he has notes written on the back of handy envelopes .	69.388214
he has his own system of shorthand , devised by abbreviations `` humility ' ' will be `` humly ' ' , `` with ' ' will be `` w ' ' , and `` that ' ' will be `` tt ' ' .	15.633392
the second reason for his popularity is his complete spontaneity with the guitar .	77.28002
it is a mistake , however , to imagine that sandburg uses the guitar as a prop .	64.79104
he is no dextrous-fingered college boy but rather a dedicated , humble , and bashful apostle of this instrument .	65.76966
at age seventy-four , he became what he shyly terms a `` pupil ' ' of andres segovia , the great guitarist of the western world .	32.452988
it is not easy to become segovia ' s pupil .	37.50666
`` his fingers labor heavily on the strings and he asked for my help in disciplining them .	78.63014
i found that this precocious , grown-up boy of 74 deserved to be taught .	85.401306
there has long existed a brotherly affection between us , thus i accepted him as my pupil .	176.94305
just as in the case of every prodigy child , we must watch for the efficacy of my teaching to show up in the future -- if he should master all the strenuous exercises i inflicted on him .	112.82174
to play the guitar as he aspires will devour his three-fold energy as a historian , a poet and a singer .	57.084915
one cause of schopenhauer ' s pessimism was the fact that he failed to learn the guitar .	33.293495
i am certain that carl sandburg will not fall into the same sad philosophy .	68.54359
