one day he assigned me to lay bare a `` plot ' ' by the duponts to supply munitions to a wholly fictitious revolution he said was about to occur in cuba .	74.69532
he said that his information was so secret that he would not be able to confide in me the origin of his pipeline tip .	60.823975
`` i can tell you this much ' ' , he said .	3.4406445
it ' s bigger than the armistice ' ' .	1.4367057
i worked for a day on this plainly ridiculous assignment and consulted several of my own well-informed sources .	119.14623
then i spent the next two days at the baseball park and at jack doyle ' s pool parlors .	44.364655
when i returned to make my report , the hetman did not remember having sent me on the secret mission .	100.72633
he was busy , he said , in having someone submit to a monkey-gland operation .	223.09987
and i was to go to work on that odd matter .	232.87425
the hetman had a strong liking for a story , any story which was to be had by means of much sleuthing or by roundabout methods .	105.27357
most of my stories were obtained by simply seeking out the person who could give me the facts , and not as a rule by playing clever tricks .	107.168076
one day i tired of following the hetman ' s advice of `` shadowing ' ' and of the `` ring-around-the-rosie ' ' approach to a report that enrico caruso had pinched a lady ' s hip while visiting the central park monkey house .	52.279007
i explained my state of mind to artist winsor mccay and to `` bugs ' ' baer .	19.714798
mr . baer obtained a supply of crepe hair and spirit-gum from an actor at the friars .	33.1342
we fashioned beards , put them on , and reported to the hetman at the city desk .	91.0141
mr . baer had an auburn beard , like longfellow ' s .	14.687197
mr . mccay had on a sort of emperor maximilian beard and mustache .	71.84177
as for myself , i had on an enormous black `` muff ' ' .	30.290518
this , together with a derby hat and horn-rim eyeglasses , gave me the appearance of a russian nihilist .	20.246763
`` we are ready for your next mysterious assignment ' ' , said mr . baer to the hetman .	27.625378
`` where to , sir ' ' ? ?	1.1325397
mr . watson did not have much humor in his make-up , but he managed a mirthless smile .	26.13374
just then a reporter telephoned in from the bronx to give the rewrite desk an account of a murder .	149.11635
the hetman told me to take the story over the phone and to write it .	61.226677
while i was sitting at one of the rewrite telephones with my derby and my great beard , arthur brisbane whizzed in with some editorial copy in his hand .	66.52298
he paused for a moment to look at me , then went on to the city desk to deliver his `` today ' ' column .	58.929123
i thought it expedient to take off my derby , my glasses , and the beard	46.50941
i managed to do this by the time the great a . b . returned to the place where he last had seen the fierce nihilist .	102.518814
he stood there staring with disbelief at the vacant desk .	171.7695
then he wrinkled his huge brow and went slowly out of the room .	24.943632
he had been `` seeing things ' ' .	3.8409567
the hetman ' s `` ideas ' ' for news stories or editorial campaigns were by no means always fruitless or lacking in merit .	123.53182
he campaigned successfully for the riddance of `` death avenue ' ' and also brought about the ending of pollution of metropolitan beaches by sewage .	102.751045
he exposed the bucket-shop racket with the able assistance of two excellent reporters , nat ferber and carl helm .	118.37529
in the conduct of these and many other campaigns , the hetman proved to be a much abler journalist than his critics allowed .	106.949585
it seems to me now , in a long backward glance , that many of the hetman ' s conceits and odd actions -- together with his grim posture when brandishing the hatchet in the name of mr . hearst -- were keyed with the tragedy which was to close over him one day .	65.75878
alone , rejected on every hand , divorced , and in financial trouble , he leaped from an eleventh-floor window of the abbey hotel in 1937 .	72.576126
one finds it difficult to pass censure on the lonely figure who waited for days for a saving word from his zealously served idol , w . r . hearst .	124.19983
that word was withheld when the need of it seemed the measure of his despair .	94.70343
the unfinished note , written in pencil upon the back of a used envelope , and addressed to the coroner , makes one wonder about many things `` god forgive me for everything .	91.09951
much to damon runyon ' s amazement , as well as my own , i got along splendidly with the hetman	56.510296
that is , until i became an editor , hence , in his eyes , a rival .	49.42405
not long after colonel van hamm had foisted me on the watson staff i received a salary raise and a contract on the hetman ' s recommendation .	79.74456
during the next years he gave me the second of the five contracts i would sign with the hearst service .	105.0079
it was a somewhat unusual thing for a reporter to have a contract in those days before the epidemic of syndicated columnists .	69.83423
i would like to believe that my ability warranted this advancement .	405.5199
somehow i think that watson paid more attention to me than he otherwise might have because his foe , colonel van hamm , wouldn ' t touch me with a ten-foot blue pencil .	51.610855
i remember one day when mr . hearst ( and i never knew why he liked me , either ) sent the hetman a telegram `` please find some more reporters like that young man from denver ' ' .	128.635
watson showed this wire to colonel van hamm .	8.795359
the colonel grunted , then made a remark which might be construed in either of two ways .	98.57564
`` don ' t bother to look any further .	64.642365
we already have the only one of its kind ' ' .	9.184052
the hetman did have friends , but they were mostly outside the newspaper profession .	105.25971
sergeant mike donaldson , congressional medal of honor soldier , was one of them .	34.99363
dr . menas s . gregory was another .	17.002201
i used to go with watson to call on the eminent neurologist at his apartment , to sit among the doctor ' s excellent collection of statues , paintings , and books and drink oriental coffee while watson seemed to thaw out and become almost affable .	110.76447
there was one time , however , when his face clouded and he suddenly blurted , `` why did my brother commit suicide ' ' ? ?	29.567057
i cannot remember dr . gregory ' s reply , if , indeed , he made one .	69.81152
if she were not at home , mama would see to it that a fresh white rose was there .	92.06614
sometimes , mrs . coolidge would close herself in the green suite on the second floor , and play the piano she had brought to the white house .	35.164425
mama knew she was playing her son ' s favorite pieces and feeling close to him , and did not disturb her .	51.264164
all the rest of the days in the white house would be shadowed by the tragic loss , even though the president tried harder than ever to make his little dry jokes and to tease the people around him .	76.8385
a little boy came to give the president his personal condolences , and the president gave word that any little boy who wanted to see him was to be shown in .	75.240685
backstairs , the maids cried a little over that , and the standing invitation was not mentioned to mrs . coolidge .	40.765522
the president was even more generous with the first lady than he had been before the tragedy .	122.28245
he would bring her boxes of candy and other presents to coax a smile to her lips .	130.23094
dresses were short in the days of mrs . coolidge , and spanish shawls were thrown over them .	17.402374
one shawl was so tremendous that she could not wear it , so she draped it over the banister on the second floor , and it hung over the stairway .	35.481678
the president used to look at it with a ghost of a smile .	25.391157
mrs . coolidge spent more time in her bedroom among her doll collection .	345.94083
she kept the dolls on the lincoln bed .	1.915953
at night , when mama would turn back the covers , she would have to take all the dolls off the bed and place them elsewhere for the night .	79.38002
mama always felt that the collection symbolized mrs . coolidge ' s wish for a little girl .	16.646906
among the dolls was one that meant very much to the first lady , who would pick it up and look at it often .	74.657646
it had a tiny envelope tied to its wrist .	2.9946506
an accompanying sympathetic letter explained that inside the envelope was a name for mrs . coolidge ' s first granddaughter .	23.199255
mama knew this doll was meant to help mrs . coolidge overcome her grief by turning her eyes to the future .	63.085724
the name inside the envelope was `` cynthia ' ' .	2.5265002
the coolidges ' life , after the death of their son , was quieter than ever .	47.873493
john was away at school most of the time .	15.695567
mrs . coolidge would knit , and the president would sit reading , or playing with the many pets around them .	180.37833
now and then , the president would call for `` little jack , master of the hounds ' ' , which was his nickname for a messenger who had worked in the white house since teddy roosevelt ' s administration , and discuss the welfare of some one of the animals .	52.733036
it was part of little jack ' s work to look after the dogs .	72.046295
one white house dog was immortalized in a painting .	66.09493
that was rob roy , who posed with mrs . coolidge for the portrait by howard chandler christy .	63.321373
to get him to pose , mrs . coolidge would feed him candy , so he enjoyed the portrait sessions as well as she did .	65.8144
i would like to straighten out a misconception about the dress mrs . coolidge is wearing in this painting .	77.34166
it is not the same dress as the one on her manikin in the smithsonian .	117.563965
people think the dress in the picture was lengthened by an artist much later on .	281.53275
the dress in the painting is a bright red , with rhinestones forming a spray on the right side .	22.76306
there is a long train flowing from the shoulders .	39.00354
mrs . coolidge gave mama this dress for me , and i wore it many times .	27.277681
i still have the dress , and i hope to give it to the smithsonian institution as a memento , or , as i more fondly hope , to present it to a museum containing articles showing the daily lives of the presidents -- if i can get it organized .	136.69937
but to get back to the coolidge household , mrs . coolidge so obviously loved dogs , that the public sent her more dogs -- calamity jane , timmy , and blackberry .	71.10023
the last two were a red and a black chow .	14.140085
rob roy remained boss of all the dogs .	5.365449
he showed them what to do , and taught them how to keep the maids around the white house in a state of terror .	59.651485
the dogs would run through the halls after him like a burst of bullets , and all the maids would run for cover .	63.998444
mama didn ' t know what to do -- whether to tell on rob roy or not -- since she had the ear of mrs . coolidge more than the other maids .	74.38109
but she was afraid the first lady would not understand , because rob roy was a perfect angel with the first family .	67.06506
every day , when the president took his nap , rob roy would stretch out on the window seat near him , like a perfect gentleman , and stare thoughtfully out the window , or he would take a little nap himself .	78.35617
he would not make a sound until the president had wakened and left for the office	90.54699
then he would bark to let everyone know the coast was clear .	111.917984
his signal was for the other dogs to come running , but it was also the signal for mama and the other maids to watch out .	53.985573
rob roy was self-appointed to accompany the president to his office every morning .	94.66957
rob roy was well aware of the importance of this mission , and he would walk in front of the president , looking neither to the right nor to the left .	47.887547
at dinner , lunch , or breakfast , the president would call out , `` supper ' ' ! !	40.686802
-- he called all meals supper -- after the butler had announced the meal .	95.78747
all the dogs would dash to get on the elevator with the president and go to the dining room .	26.348238
they would all lie around on the rug during the meal , a very pretty sight as rob roy , prudence , and calamity jane were all snow-white .	94.32108
when prudence and blackberry were too young to be trusted in the dining room , they were tied to the radiator with their leashes , and they would cry .	42.990112
mama tried to talk to them and keep them quiet while she tidied up the sitting room before the first family returned .	72.722664
finally , mama did mention to mrs . coolidge that she felt sorry for the little dogs , and then mrs . coolidge decided to leave the radio on for them while she was gone , even though her husband disapproved of the waste of electricity .	64.93146
mama was now the first maid to mrs . coolidge , because catherine , the previous first maid , had become ill and died .	59.854126
mrs . coolidge chose mama in her place .	6.9208484
every first family seems to have one couple upon whom it relies for true friendship .	567.80975
for the coolidges , it was mr . and mrs . frank w . stearns of boston , massachusetts , owners of a large department store .	32.02368
they seemed to be at the white house half the time .	111.558395
the butlers were amused because when the stearns were there , the president would say grace at breakfast .	162.28183
if the stearns were not there , grace would be omitted .	40.395813
speaking of breakfast , the president inaugurated a new custom -- that of conducting business at the breakfast table .	103.797134
the word was that this too was part of an economy move on his part .	80.20856
a new bill had been passed under harding that designated the government , rather than the president , as the tab-lifter for official meals .	127.58819
so the president would make a hearty breakfast official by inviting government officials to attend .	101.40806
he caused a lot of talk when he also chose the breakfast hour to have the barber come in and trim his hair while he ate .	168.39345
mama said that if presidents were supposed to be colorful , mr . coolidge certainly made a good president .	45.883995
he knew exactly how to be colorful ! !	1.2550274
the favorite guest of the house , as far as the staff was concerned , was mr . wrigley , the chewing gum king .	62.957558
the white house had chewing gum until it could chew no more , and every christmas , mr . wrigley sent the president a check for $100 , to be divided among all the help .	65.14551
you can imagine that he got pretty good service .	126.528175
another good friend of the coolidges ' was george b . harvey , who was the ambassador to great britain from 1921 to 1923 .	42.490047
he had been a friend of the hardings , and continued to be invited by the coolidges .	32.148846
the first royalty whom mama ever waited on in the white house was queen marie of rumania , who came to a state dinner given in her honor on october 21 , 1926 .	66.08402
she was not an overnight guest in the white house , but mr . ike hoover , the chief usher , had mama check her fur coat when she came in , and take care of her needs .	60.833225
mama said she was one of the prettiest ladies she had ever seen .	25.447945
mama was very patriotic , and one of the duties she was proudest of was repairing the edges of the flag that flew above the white house .	51.6892
actually , two flags were used at the mansion -- a small one on rainy days , and a big one on bright days .	121.65514
the wool would become frazzled around the edges from blowing in the wind , and mama would mend it .	54.37933
she would often go up on the roof to see the attendant take down the flag in the evening .	71.21329
she used to tell me , `` when i stand there and look at the flag blowing this way and that way , i have the wonderful , safe feeling that americans are protected no matter which way the wind blows ' ' .	88.853714
even when mrs . coolidge was in mourning for her son , she reached out to help other people in trouble .	43.4759
mama had told her how emmett ' s lungs had been affected when he was gassed in the war .	50.13256
he was in and out of mount alto hospital for veterans any number of times .	141.53796
taking a personal interest , she had the doctor assigned to the white house , dr . james coupal , look emmett over .	46.401943
as a result , he was sent to a hospital in arizona until his health improved enough for him to come back to washington to work in the government service .	81.759186
but again , there was danger that his lungs would suffer in the muggy washington weather , and he had to return to the dry climate of the west to live and work .	48.54892
when mrs . coolidge was in mourning , she did not wear black .	86.4751
she wore grey every day , and white every evening .	198.46365
mama knew that she was out of mourning when she finally wore bright colors .	94.6432
the president helped her a lot by selecting some lovely colored dresses to get her started .	132.20297
she opened the boxes with a tear in her eye and a sad smile on her face .	25.673567
on the social side , the chore mama had at the formal receptions at the white house thrilled her the most .	52.227146
it was her job to stand at the foot of the stairs , and , just as the first lady stepped off the last tread , mama would straighten out her long train before she marched to the blue room to greet her guests with the president .	50.384136
mama would enjoy the sight of the famous guests as much as anyone , and would note a gown here and there to tell me about that night .	137.30064
one night , mama came home practically in a state of shock .	44.500267
she had stood at the bottom of the stairs , as usual , when mrs . coolidge came down , in the same dress that is now in the smithsonian , to greet her guests .	55.626385
mama stooped down to fix the train , but there was no train there ! !	45.70998
she reached and reached around the dress , but there was nothing there .	25.420372
she looked up and saw that , without knowing it , mrs . coolidge was holding it aloft .	38.206116
mrs . coolidge looked down , saw mama ' s horrified expression and quickly let the whole thing fall to the floor .	64.082886
mama swirled the train in place , and not a step was lost .	216.77687
the coolidges did not always live at the white house during the presidency .	33.669945
impressive as this enumeration is , it barely hints at the diverse perceptions of jews , collectively or individually , that have been attested by their gentile environment .	85.88905
it is reasonable to affirm two propositions jews have been perceived by non-jews as all things to all men	65.853516
some jews have in fact been all things to all men .	28.42561
in the arena of power jews have at one time or another been somebody ' s ally	153.85568
in the market place jews have in fact under various circumstances been valued customers and suppliers , or clannish monopolists and cutthroat competitors .	59.57127
and so on through the roles referred to in the previous paragraph .	30.502766
but the two do not invariably or even typically coincide .	419.18362
the `` conventional ' ' image of a particular time and place is not necessarily congruent with the image of the facts as established over the years by scholarly and scientific research .	72.62684
conventional images of jews have this in common with all perceptions of a configuration in which one feature is held constant images can be both true and false .	97.46632
the genuinely interesting question , then , becomes what factors determine the degree of realism or distortion in conventional images of jews ? ?	91.89127
the working test of `` the facts ' ' must always be the best available description obtainable from scholars and scientists who have applied their methods of investigation to relevant situations .	150.06046
granted , such `` functional ' ' images are subject to human error	95.43501
they are self-correcting in the sense that they are subject to disciplined procedures that check and recheck against error .	236.03096
in accounting for realism or distortion two sets of factors can be usefully distinguished current intelligence	206.75299
general grant may have been the victim of false information in the instance reported in this book	156.89778
if so , he would not be the first or last commanding officer who has succumbed to bad information and dubious estimates of the future .	172.50331
he may have entered the situation with predispositions that prepared him to act uncritically in the press of affairs .	57.10332
predispositions , in turn , fall conveniently into two categories for purposes of analysis .	78.42387
to some extent predispositions are shaped by exposure to group environments .	24.072895
in some measure they depend upon the structure of individual personality .	18.608839
the anti-semitism of hitler owed something to his exposure to the ideology of lueger ' s politically successful christian socialist movement in vienna .	56.21501
but millions of human beings were exposed to lueger ' s propaganda and record .	58.951916
after allowing for group exposures , it is apparent that other factors must be considered if we are to comprehend fanaticism .	40.763798
they include harmonies and conflicts within the whole man , and mechanisms whereby inner components are more or less smoothly met .	169.16621
modern psychiatric knowledge provides us with many keys to unlock the significance of behavior of the kind .	41.54643
the foregoing factors are pertinent to the analysis of perceptual images and the broad conditions under which they achieve realism or fall short of it .	116.83774
undoubtedly one merit of the vast panorama of gentile conceptions of the jew unfolded in the present anthology is that it provides a formidable body of material that invites critical examination in terms of reality .	76.797874
many selections are themselves convincing contributions to this appraisal .	253.23344
undoubtedly , however , the significance of the volume is greater than the foregoing paragraphs suggest .	41.357735
speaking as a non-jew i believe that its primary contribution is in the realm of future policy .	34.14904
since we can neither undo nor redo the past , we are limited to the events of today and tomorrow .	55.119198
in this domain the simple fact of coexistence in the same local , national , and world community is enough to guarantee that we cannot refrain from having some effect , large or small , upon gentile-jewish relations .	129.09843
i am deliberately raising the policy problems involved in gentile-jewish relations .	21.076807
comprehensive examination of any policy question calls for the performance of the intellectual tasks inseparable from any problem-solving method .	102.210526
the tasks are briefly indicated by these questions what are my goals in gentile-jewish relations ? ?	101.64275
what are the historical trends in this country and abroad in the extent to which these goals are effectively realized ? ?	38.92824
what factors condition the degree of realization at various times and places ? ?	36.438396
what is the probable course of future developments ? ?	6.186769
what policies if adopted and applied in various circumstances will increase the likelihood that future events will coincide with desired events and do so at least cost in terms of all human values ? ?	103.937454
it is beyond the province of this epilogue to cover policy questions of such depth and range .	291.544
the discussion is therefore limited to a suggested procedure for realizing at least some of the potential importance of this volume for future policy .	80.02782
as a groundwork for the proposal i give some attention to the first task enumerated above , the clarification of goal .	74.46207
my reply is that i associate myself with all those who affirm that gentile-jewish relations should contribute to the theory and practice of human dignity .	49.709778
the basic goal finds partial expression in the universal declaration of human rights , a statement initiated and endorsed by individuals and organizations of many religious and philosophical traditions .	70.86374
within this frame of reference policies appropriate to claims advanced in the name of the jews depend upon which jewish identity is involved , as well as upon the nature of the claim , the characteristics of the claimant , the justifications proposed , and the predispositions of the community decision makers who are called upon to act .	69.43866
if jews are identified as a religious body in a controversy that comes before a national or international tribunal , it is obviously compatible with the goal of human dignity to protect freedom of worship .	63.163383
when decision makers act within this frame they determine whether a claim put forward in the name of religion is to be accepted by the larger community as appropriate to religion .	58.576267
since the recognition of israel as a nation state , claims are made in many cases which identify the claimant as a member of the new body politic .	54.2493
community decision makers must make up their minds whether a claim is acceptable to the larger community in terms of prevailing expectations regarding members of nation states .	162.85072
in free countries many controversies involve self-styled jews who use the symbol in asserting a vaguely `` cultural ' ' rather than religious or political identity .	69.49411
the decision maker who acts for the community as a whole must decide whether the objectives pursued and the methods used are appropriate to public policy regarding cultural groups .	100.24387
we know that much is made of the multiplicity and ambiguity of the identities that cluster around the key symbol of the jew .	84.79549
many public and private controversies will undoubtedly continue to reflect these confusions in the mind and usage of gentile and jew .	67.69085
however , in the context of legal and civic policy , these controversies are less than novel .	99.98575
they involve similar uncertainties regarding the multiple identities of any number of non-jewish groups .	32.766335
so far as the existing body of formal principle and procedure is concerned , categorical novelties are not to be anticipated in jewish-gentile relationships	93.2015
claims are properly disposed of according to norms common to all parties .	141.55005
it is not implied that formal principles and procedures are so firmly entrenched within the public order of the world community or even of free commonwealths that they will control in all circumstances involving jews and gentiles during coming years .	91.19169
but it is perennially restructured in situations where anchors are dragged or lost .	282.09094
in conformance with the maximization principle we affirm that gentile-jewish relations will be harmonious or inharmonious to the degree that one relation or the other is expected by the active participants to yield the greatest net advantage , taking all value outcomes and effects into consideration .	112.55045
it is not difficult to anticipate circumstances in which negative tensions will cumulate	266.26312
for instance , imagine the situation if israel ever joins an enemy coalition .	301.62405
the formal position of americans who identify themselves with one or more of the several identities of the jewish symbol is already clear	53.65402
the future weight of informal factors cannot be so easily assessed .	51.13238
when we consider the disorganized state of the world community , and the legacy of predispositions adversely directed against all who are identified as jews , it is obvious that the struggle for the minds and muscles of men needs to be prosecuted with increasing vigor and skill .	66.62469
during moments of intense crisis the responsibility of political leaders is overwhelming .	75.88003
but their freedom of policy is limited by the pattern of predisposition with which they and the people around them enter the crisis .	57.54858
at such critical moments predispositions favorable to human dignity most obviously `` pay off ' ' .	105.277176
by the same test predispositions destructive of human personality exercise their most sinister impact , with the result that men of good will are often trapped and nullified .	127.34221
among measures in anticipation of crisis are plans to inject into the turmoil as assistants of key decision makers qualified persons who are cognizant of the corrosive effect of crisis upon personal relationships and are also able to raise calm and realistic voices when overburdened leaders near the limit of self-control .	169.99359
we are learning how to do these things in some of the vast organized structures of modern society	91.24907
a truism is that the time to prepare for the worst is when times are best .	226.61154
during intercrisis periods the educational facilities of the community have the possibility of remolding the perspectives and altering the behavior of vast numbers of human beings of every age and condition .	77.46435
as more men and women are made capable of living up to the challenge of decency the chances are improved that the pattern of predisposition prevailing in positions of strength in future crises can be favorably affected .	98.347694
now an abiding difficulty of paragraphs like the foregoing is that they appear to preach	21.27485
and in contemporary society we often complain of too much reaffirmation of the goodness of the good .	49.108788
in any case i do not intend to let the present occasion pass without dealing more directly with the problem of implementing good intentions .	166.50876
i assume that the number of readers of this anthology who regard themselves as morally perfect is small , and that most readers are willing to consider procedures by which they may gain more insight into themselves and better understanding of others .	143.69594
properly used , the present book is an excellent instrument of enlightenment .	31.211475
let us not confuse the issue by labeling the objective or the method `` psychoanalytic ' ' , for this is a well established term of art for the specific ideas and procedures initiated by sigmund freud and his followers for the study and treatment of disordered personalities .	64.66962
the traditional method proceeds by the technique of free association , punctuated by interpretations proposed by the psychoanalytic interviewer .	101.40254
what we have in mind does have something in common with the goals of psychoanalysis and with the methods by which they are sought .	78.360725
for what we propose , however , a psychoanalyst is not necessary , even though one aim is to enable the reader to get beneath his own defenses -- his defenses of himself to himself .	72.1516
for this purpose a degree of intellectual and emotional involvement is necessary	84.47267
but involvement needs to be accompanied by a special frame of mind .	168.20213
the relatively long and often colorful selections in this anthology enable the reader to become genuinely absorbed in what is said , whether he responds with anger or applause .	92.48493
self-discovery calls for an open , permissive , inquiring posture of self-observation .	30.007635
the symposium provides an opportunity to confront the self with specific statements which were made at particular times by identifiable communicators who were addressing definite audiences -- and throughout several hundred pages everyone is talking about the same key symbol of identification .	161.44463
an advantage of being exposed to such specificity about an important and recurring feature of social reality is that it can be taken advantage of by the reader to examine covert as well as overt resonances within himself , resonances triggered by explicit symbols clustering around the central figure of the jew .	55.012253
two facets of this aspect of the literary process have special significance for our time .	199.07832
one , a reservation on the point i have just made , is the phenomenon of pseudo-thinking , pseudo-feeling , and pseudo-willing , which fromm discussed in the escape from freedom .	73.344955
in essence this involves grounding one ' s thought and emotion in the values and experience of others , rather than in one ' s own values and experience .	47.909348
there is a risk that instead of teaching a person how to be himself , reading fiction and drama may teach him how to be somebody else .	74.74666
clearly what the person brings to the reading is important .	47.151863
moreover , if the critic instructs his audience in what to see in a work , he is contributing to this pseudo-thinking	71.96949
if he instructs them in how to evaluate a work , he is helping them to achieve their own identity .	43.78417
the second timely part of this sketch of literature and the search for identity has to do with the difference between good and enduring literary works and the ephemeral mass culture products of today .	100.049515
in the range and variety of characters who , in their literary lives , get along all right with life styles one never imagined possible , there is an implicit lesson in differentiation .	170.76566
the reader , observing this process , might ask `` why not be different ' ' ? ?	45.547276
and find in the answer a license to be a variant of the human species .	28.459068
the observer of television or other products for a mass audience has only a permit to be , like the models he sees , even more like everybody else .	110.07824
and this , i think , holds for values as well as life styles .	71.84245
after all , the large ( and probably unreliable ) reader ' s digest literature on the `` most unforgettable character i ever met ' ' deals with village grocers , country doctors , favorite if illiterate aunts , and so forth .	92.31385
scientists often turn out to be idiosyncratic , too .	73.15497
but still , the proposition is worth examination .	5.6013446
it is possible that the study of literature affects the conscience , the morality , the sensitivity to some code of `` right ' ' and `` wrong ' ' .	39.739857
both flugel and ranyard west deal with the development and nature of conscience , as do such theologians as niebuhr and buber .	80.69699
it forms the core of many , perhaps most , problems of psychotherapy .	203.9365
i am not aware of great attention by any of these authors or by the psychotherapeutic profession to the role of literary study in the development of conscience -- most of their attention is to a pre-literate period of life , or , for the theologians of course , to the influence of religion .	55.90725
still , it would be surprising if what one reads did not contribute to one ' s ideas of right and wrong	87.76893
certainly the awakened alarm over the comic books and the continuous concern over prurient literature indicate some peripheral aspects of this influence .	156.05783
probably the most important thing to focus on is not the development of conscience , which may well be almost beyond the reach of literature , but the contents of conscience , the code which is imparted to the developed or immature conscience available .	95.27382
this is in large part a code of behavior and a glossary of values what is it that people do and should do and how one should regard it .	125.94706
in a small way this is illustrated by the nineteenth-century novelist who argued for the powerful influence of literature as a teacher of society and who illustrated this with the way a girl learned to meet her lover , how to behave , how to think about this new experience , how to exercise restraint .	84.64843
literature may be said to give people a sense of purpose , dedication , mission , significance .	56.501564
this , no doubt , is part of what gilbert seldes implies when he says of the arts , `` they give form and meaning to life which might otherwise seem shapeless and without sense ' ' .	94.30615
men seem almost universally to want a sense of function , that is , a feeling that their existence makes a difference to someone , living or unborn , close and immediate or generalized .	98.49905
feeling useless seems generally to be an unpleasant sensation .	24.589058
a need so deeply planted , asking for direction , so to speak , is likely to be gratified by the vivid examples and heroic proportions of literature .	96.12661
the terms `` renewal ' ' and `` refreshed ' ' , which often come up in aesthetic discussion , seem partly to derive their import from the `` renewal ' ' of purpose and a `` refreshed ' ' sense of significance a person may receive from poetry , drama , and fiction .	69.21776
the notion of `` inspiration ' ' is somehow cognate to this feeling .	64.7621
how literature does this , or for whom , is certainly not clear , but the content , form , and language of the `` message ' ' , as well as the source , would all play differentiated parts in giving and molding a sense of purpose .	52.124928
one of the most salient features of literary value has been deemed to be its influence upon and organization of emotion .	100.24253
let us differentiate a few of these ideas .	9.986576
the aristotelian notion of catharsis , the purging of emotion , is a persistent and viable one .	26.265242
the idea here is one of discharge but this must stand in opposition to a second view , plato ' s notion of the arousal of emotion .	62.172825
a third idea is that artistic literature serves to reduce emotional conflicts , giving a sense of serenity and calm to individuals .	96.00911
this is given some expression in beardsley ' s notion of harmony and the resolution of indecision .	25.988018
a fourth view is the transformation of emotion , as in housman ' s fine phrase on the arts they `` transform and beautify our inner nature ' ' .	34.29527
it is possible that the idea of enrichment of emotion is a fifth idea .	36.580322
f . s . c . northrop , in his discussion of the `` functions and future of poetry ' ' , suggests this `` one of the things which makes our lives drab and empty and which leaves us , at the end of the day , fatigued and deflated spiritually is the pressure of the taxing , practical , utilitarian concern of common-sense objects .	67.09283
if art is to release us from these postulated things ( things we must think symbolically about ) and bring us back to the ineffable beauty and richness of the aesthetic component of reality in its immediacy , it must sever its connection with these common sense entities ' ' .	97.31154
i take the central meaning here to be the contrast between the drab empty quality of life without literature and a life enriched by it .	108.08975
richards ' view of the aesthetic experience might constitute a sixth variety for him it constitutes , in part , the organization of impulses .	196.97151
a sketch of the emotional value of the study of literature would have to take account of all of these .	37.32367
but there is one in particular which , it seems to me , deserves special attention .	52.49883
in the wide range of experiences common to our earth-bound race none is more difficult to manage , more troublesome , and more enduring in its effects than the control of love and hate .	100.33554
the study of literature contributes to this control in a curious way .	60.079132
william wimsatt and cleanth brooks , it seems to me , have a penetrating insight into the way in which this control is effected `` for if we say poetry is to talk of beauty and love ( and yet not aim at exciting erotic emotion or even an emotion of platonic esteem ) and if it is to talk of anger and murder ( and yet not aim at arousing anger and indignation ) -- then it may be that the poetic way of dealing with these emotions will not be any kind of intensification , compounding , or magnification , or any direct assault upon the affections at all .	82.06031
something indirect , mixed , reconciling , tensional might well be the stratagem , the devious technique by which a poet indulged in all kinds of talk about love and anger and even in something like `` expressions ' ' of these emotions , without aiming at their incitement or even uttering anything that essentially involves their incitement ' ' .	76.56561
the rehearsal through literature of emotional life under controlled conditions may be a most valuable human experience .	97.33874
here i do not mean catharsis , the discharge of emotion .	60.46929
i mean something more like freud ' s concept of the utility of `` play ' ' to a small child he plays `` house ' ' or `` doctor ' ' or `` fireman ' ' as a way of mastering slightly frightening experiences , reliving them imaginatively until they are under control .	51.812717
there is a second feature of the influences of literature , good literature , on emotional life which may have some special value for our time .	76.935616
in b . m . spinley ' s portrayal of the underprivileged and undereducated youth of london , a salient finding was the inability to postpone gratification , a need to satisfy impulses immediately without the pleasure of anticipation or of savoring the experience .	89.909546
perhaps it is only an analogy , but one of the most obvious differences between cheap fiction and fiction of an enduring quality is the development of a theme or story with leisure and anticipation .	89.06318
anyone who has watched children develop a taste for literature will understand what i mean .	121.45251
it is at least possible that the capacity to postpone gratification is developed as well as expressed in a continuous and guided exposure to great literature .	66.81309
in any inquiry into the way in which great literature affects the emotions , particularly with respect to the sense of harmony , or relief of tension , or sense of `` a transformed inner nature ' ' which may occur , a most careful exploration of the particular feature of the experience which produces the effect would be required .	57.12767
in the calm which follows the reading of a poem , for example , is the effect produced by the enforced quiet , by the musical quality of words and rhythm , by the sentiments or sense of the poem , by the associations with earlier readings , if it is familiar , by the boost to the self-esteem for the semi-literate , by the diversion of attention , by the sense of security in a legitimized withdrawal , by a kind license for some variety of fantasy life regarded as forbidden , or by half-conscious ideas about the magical power of words ? ?	87.67498
these are , if the research is done with subtlety and skill , researchable topics , but the research is missing .	81.63756
one of the most frequent views of the value of literature is the education of sensibility that it is thought to provide .	56.897705
sensibility is a vague word , covering an area of meaning rather than any precise talent , quality , or skill .	80.92488
among other things it means perception , discrimination , sensitivity to subtle differences .	52.13364
both the extent to which this is true and the limits of the field of perceptual skill involved should be acknowledged .	68.700005
its truth is illustrated by the skill , sensitivity , and general expertise of the english professor with whom one attends the theatre .	112.97291
the limits are suggested by an imaginary experiment contrast the perceptual skill of english professors with that of their colleagues in discriminating among motor cars , political candidates , or female beauty .	183.21616
along these lines , the particular point that sensitivity in literature leads to sensitivity in human relations would require more proof than i have seen .	239.53766
in a symposium and general exploration of the field of personal perception and interpersonal behavior the discussion does not touch upon this aspect of the subject , with one possible exception	85.48492
solomon asch shows the transcultural stability of metaphors based on sensation ( hot , sweet , bitter , etc . ) dealing with personal qualities of human beings and events .	73.29335
but to go from here to the belief that those more sensitive to metaphor and language will also be more sensitive to personal differences is too great an inferential leap .	107.53654
i would say , too , that the study of literature tends to give a person what i shall call depth .	74.32812
i use this term to mean three things a search for the human significance of an event or state of affairs , a tendency to look at wholes rather than parts , and a tendency to respond to these events and wholes with feeling .	84.22909
it is the obverse of triviality , shallowness , emotional anaesthesia .	12.083396
i think these attributes cluster , but i have no evidence .	52.9692
in fact , i can only say this seems to me to follow from a wide , continuous , and properly guided exposure to literary art .	77.52291
the late r . g . collingwood , a philosopher whose work has proved helpful to many students of literature , once wrote ``	107.93369
we are all , though many of us are snobbish enough to wish to deny it , in far closer sympathy with the art of the music-hall and picture-palace than with chaucer and cimabue , or even shakespeare and titian .	61.790714
by an effort of historical sympathy we can cast our minds back into the art of a remote past or an alien present , and enjoy the carvings of cavemen and japanese colour-prints	71.05803
but the possibility of this effort is bound up with that development of historical thought which is the greatest achievement of our civilization in the last two centuries , and it is utterly impossible to people in whom this development has not taken place .	52.86051
the natural and primary aesthetic attitude is to enjoy contemporary art , to despise and dislike the art of the recent past , and wholly to ignore everything else ' ' .	68.62545
one might argue that the ultimate purpose of literary scholarship is to correct this spontaneous provincialism that is likely to obscure the horizons of the general public , of the newspaper critic , and of the creative artist himself .	71.0724
there results a study of literature freed from the tyranny of the contemporary .	54.46456
the study of ideas in literature is one of these .	31.397518
of course , it goes without saying that no student of ideas can justifiably ignore the contemporary scene .	143.11525
the continuities , contrasts , and similarities discernible when past and present are surveyed together are inexhaustible and the one is often understood through the other .	128.24878
when we assert the value of such study , we find ourselves committed to an important assumption .	47.281616
most students of literature , whether they call themselves scholars or critics , are ready to argue that it is possible to understand literary works as well as to enjoy them .	60.052784
many will add that we may find our enjoyment heightened by our understanding .	177.36517
this understanding , of course , may in its turn take many forms and some of these -- especially those most interesting to the student of comparative literature -- are essentially historical .	122.394104
but the historian of literature need not confine his attention to biography or to stylistic questions of form , `` texture ' ' , or technique .	52.045265
it is true that this distinction between style and idea often approaches the arbitrary since in the end we must admit that style and content frequently influence or interpenetrate one another and sometimes appear as expressions of the same insight .	120.737206
but , in general , we may argue that the student can direct the primary emphasis of his attention toward one or the other .	52.280518
at this point a working definition of idea is in order , although our first definition will have to be qualified somewhat as we proceed .	101.118576
the term idea refers to our more reflective or thoughtful consciousness as opposed to the immediacies of sensuous or emotional experience .	135.38403
it is through such reflection that literature approaches philosophy .	108.180244
an idea , let us say , may be roughly defined as a theme or topic with which our reflection may be concerned .	90.263725
in this essay , we are , along with most historians , interested in the more general or more inclusive ideas , that are so to speak `` writ large ' ' in history of literature where they recur continually .	109.64747
outstanding among these is the idea of human nature itself , including the many definitions that have been advanced over the centuries	104.08416
also secondary notions such as the perfectibility of man , the depravity of man , and the dignity of man .	21.319319
one might , indeed , argue that the history of ideas , in so far as it includes the literatures , must center on characterizations of human nature and that the great periods of literary achievement may be distinguished from one another by reference to the images of human nature that they succeed in fashioning .	77.94989
we need not , to be sure , expect to find such ideas in every piece of literature .	88.10732
an idea , of the sort that we have in mind , although of necessity readily available to imagination , is more general in connotation than most poetic or literary images , especially those appearing in lyric poems that seek to capture a moment of personal experience .	128.25146
thus burns ' s `` my love is like a red , red rose ' ' and hopkins ' `` the thunder-purple sea-beach , plumed purple of thunder ' ' although clearly intelligible in content , hardly present ideas of the sort with which we are here concerned .	110.07809
on the other hand , arnold ' s `` the unplumbed , salt , estranging sea ' ' , taken in its context , certainly does so .	75.68129
understanding a work of art involves recognition of the ideas that it reflects or embodies .	88.77232
thus the student of literature may sometimes find it helpful to classify a poem or an essay as being in idea or in ideal content or subject matter typical or atypical of its period .	121.45396
again , he may discover embodied within its texture a theme or idea that has been presented elsewhere and at other times in various ways .	96.879105
our understanding will very probably require both these commentaries .	41.76659
very likely it will also include a recognition that the work we are reading reflects or `` belongs to ' ' some way of thought labelled as a `` school ' ' or an `` -ism ' ' , i . e . a complex or `` syndrome ' ' of ideas occurring together with sufficient prominence to warrant identification .	75.5137
thus ideas like `` grace ' ' , `` salvation ' ' , and `` providence ' ' cluster together in traditional christianity .	37.63841
usually the work studied offers us a special or even an individualized rendering or treatment of the ideas in question , so that the student finds it necessary to distinguish carefully between the several expressions of an `` -ism ' ' or mode of thought .	52.94657
accordingly we may speak of the platonism peculiar to shelley ' s poems or the type of stoicism present in henley ' s `` invictus ' ' , and we may find that describing such platonism or such stoicism and contrasting each with other expressions of the same attitude or mode of thought is a difficult and challenging enterprise .	72.80521
after all , shelley is no `` orthodox ' ' or hellenic platonist , and even his `` romantic ' ' platonism can be distinguished from that of his contemporaries .	32.963947
again , henley ' s attitude of defiance which colors his ideal of self-mastery is far from characteristic of a stoic thinker like marcus aurelius , whose gentle acquiescence is almost christian , comparable to the patience expressed in milton ' s sonnet on his own blindness .	95.11245
in recent years , we have come increasingly to recognize that ideas have a history and that not the least important chapters of this history have to do with thematic or conceptual aspects of literature and the arts , although these aspects should be studied in conjunction with the history of philosophy , of religion , and of the sciences .	63.862907
when these fields are surveyed together , important patterns of relationship emerge indicating a vast community of reciprocal influence , a continuity of thought and expression including many traditions , primarily literary , religious , and philosophical , but frequently including contact with the fine arts and even , to some extent , with science .	117.874596
here we may observe that at least one modern philosophy of history is built on the assumption that ideas are the primary objectives of the historian ' s research .	43.154522
let us quote once more from r . g . collingwood `` history is properly concerned with the actions of human beings regarded from the outside , an action is an event or series of events occurring in the physical world	99.68113
regarded from the inside , it is the carrying into action of a certain thought the historian ' s business is to penetrate to the inside of the actions with which he is dealing and reconstruct or rather rethink the thoughts which constituted them .	118.93213
it is a characteristic of thoughts that in re-thinking them we come , ipso facto , to understand why they were thought ' ' .	74.80742
such an understanding , although it must seek to be sympathetic , is not a matter of intuition .	21.581999
`` history has this in common with every other science that the historian is not allowed to claim any single piece of knowledge , except where he can justify his claim by exhibiting to himself in the first place , and secondly to any one else who is both able and willing to follow his demonstration , the grounds upon which it is based .	99.59951
this is what was meant , above , by describing history as inferential .	154.07005
the knowledge in virtue of which a man is an historian is a knowledge of what the evidence at his disposal proves about certain events ' ' .	68.10449
it is obvious that the historian who seeks to recapture the ideas that have motivated human behavior throughout a given period will find the art and literature of that age one of his central and major concerns , by no means a mere supplement or adjunct of significant historical research .	173.48062
the student of ideas and their place in history will always be concerned with the patterns of transition , which are at the same time patterns of transformation , whereby ideas pass from one area of activity to another .	89.62998
let us survey for a moment the development of modern thought -- turning our attention from the reformation toward the revolutionary and romantic movements that follow and dwelling finally on more recent decades .	149.41522
we may thus trace the notion of individual autonomy from its manifestation in religious practice and theological reflection through practical politics and political theory into literature and the arts .	119.28796
finally we may note that the idea appears in educational theory where its influence is at present widespread .	127.87043
no one will deny that such broad developments and transitions are of great intrinsic interest and the study of ideas in literature would be woefully incomplete without frequent reference to them .	69.27297
still , we must remember that we cannot construct and justify generalizations of this sort unless we are ready to consider many special instances of influence moving between such areas as theology , philosophy , political thought , and literature .	132.18336
the actual moments of contact are vitally important .	5.7624025
these moments are historical events in the lives of individual authors with which the student of comparative literature must be frequently concerned .	51.361225
perhaps the most powerful and most frequently recurring literary influence on the western world has been that of the old and new testament .	39.2008
certainly one of the most important comments that can be made upon the spiritual and cultural life of any period of western civilization during the past sixteen or seventeen centuries has to do with the way in which its leaders have read and interpreted the bible .	69.151054
this reading and the comments that it evoked constitute the influence .	360.00775
a contrast of the scripture reading of , let us say , st . augustine , john bunyan , and thomas jefferson , all three of whom found in such study a real source of enlightenment , can tell us a great deal about these three men and the age that each represented and helped bring to conscious expression .	77.41701
in much the same way , we recognize the importance of shakespeare ' s familarity with plutarch and montaigne , of shelley ' s study of plato ' s dialogues , and of coleridge ' s enthusiastic plundering of the writings of many philosophers and theologians from plato to schelling and william godwin , through which so many abstract ideas were brought to the attention of english men of letters .	42.199
we may also recognize cases in which the poets have influenced the philosophers and even indirectly the scientists .	60.426807
english philosopher samuel alexander ' s debt to wordsworth and meredith is a recent interesting example , as also a . n . whitehead ' s understanding of the english romantics , chiefly shelley and wordsworth .	61.92997
hegel ' s profound admiration for the insights of the greek tragedians indicates a broad channel of classical influence upon nineteenth-century philosophy .	52.495373
again the student of evolutionary biology will find a fascinating , if to our minds grotesque , anticipation of the theory of chance variations and the natural elimination of the unfit in lucretius , who in turn seems to have borrowed the concept from the philosopher empedocles .	104.023224
we must avoid the notion , suggested to some people by examples such as those just mentioned , that ideas are `` units ' ' in some way comparable to coins or counters that can be passed intact from one group of people to another or even , for that matter , from one individual to another .	96.36328
`` suppose you take mr . hearst ' s morning american at $10 , 000 a year ' ' , brisbane proposed .	53.476273
`` you could come down to the office once a day , look over a few exchanges , dictate an editorial , and then have the remainder of your time for your more serious literary labors .	109.44254
if within one year you can make a success out of the american , you can practically name your own salary thereafter .	173.37303
of course , if you don ' t make the american a success , hearst will have no further use for you ' ' .	76.102005
the blue-eyed watson decided that he would dislike living in new york , and the deal fell through .	131.45236
hearst ' s luck was even poorer when he had a chat with franklin k . lane , a prominent california journalist and reform politician , whom he asked for his support .	56.15923
lane was still burning because he had narrowly missed election as governor of california in 1902 and laid his defeat to the antagonism of hearst ' s san francisco examiner .	64.603355
hearst disclaimed blame for this , but the conversation , according to lane , ended on a tart note .	112.51337
`` mr . lane ' ' , hearst said , `` if you ever wish anything that i can do , all you will have to do will be to send me a telegram asking , and it will be done ' ' .	30.057255
`` mr . hearst ' ' , lane replied as he left , `` if you ever get a telegram from me asking you to do anything , you can put the telegram down as a forgery ' ' .	38.788403
hearst took a brief respite to hurry home to new york to become a father .	34.26454
on april 10 , 1904 , his first child was born , a son named george after the late senator .	69.53501
hearst saw his wife and child , sent a joyful message to his mother in california , and soon returned to washington , where on april 22 , for the first time , he opened his mouth in congress .	37.470028
this was not before the house but before the judiciary committee , where he asked for action on one of his pet bills , that calling for an investigation of the coal-railroad monopoly .	83.51676
attorney shearn had worked on this for two years and had succeeded in getting a report supporting his stand from the united states attorney for the southern district of new york .	64.03514
hearst had spent more than $60 , 000 of his own money in the probe , but still attorney general knox was quiescent .	89.616005
six of the railroads carrying coal to tidewater from the pennsylvania fields , hearst said , not only had illegal agreements with coal operators but owned outright at least eleven mines .	169.36024
they had watered their stock at immense profit , then had raised the price of coal fifty cents a ton , netting themselves another $20 , 000 , 000 in annual profit .	51.610954
`` the attorney general has been brooding over that evidence like an old hen on a doorknob for eighteen months ' ' , hearst said .	56.195316
`` he has not acted in any way , and won ' t let anyone take it away from him .	38.45365
what i want is to have this evidence come before congress and if the attorney general does not report it , as i am very sure he won ' t , as he has refused to do anything of the kind , i then wish that a committee of seven representatives be appointed with power to take the evidence .	71.538376
this was the very sort of legislation that roosevelt himself had in mind .	116.39616
there can be little doubt that there was a conspiracy in washington , overt or implied , to block anything hearst wanted , even if it was something good .	111.907364
roosevelt and others considered him partly responsible for the murder of mckinley .	44.04779
they were repelled by his noisy newspapers , his personal publicity , his presumptuous campaign for the presidential nomination , and by the swelling cloud of rumor about his moral lapses .	47.255672
he might get votes from his constituents , but he would never get a helping hand in congress .	55.33126
inherently incapable of cooperating with others , he ran his own show regardless of how many party-line democratic toes he stepped on .	230.52122
he was a political maverick , a reformer with his own program , determined to bulldoze it through or to blazon the infamy of those who balked him .	44.11715
he showed little interest in measures put forward by the regular democrats .	44.255733
he sought to run congress as he ran his new york american or journal , a scheme veteran legislators resisted .	129.5644
for a freshman congressman to read political lessons to graybeard democrats was poor policy for one who needed to make friends .	159.19287
he soon quarreled with all the party leaders in the house , and came to be regarded with detestation by regular democrats as a professional radical leading a small pack of obedient terriers whose constant snapping was demoralizing to party discipline .	72.41779
to old-line democrats , the hearst presidential boom , now in full cry , was the joke of the new century .	51.074703
yet no leader had come to the fore who seemed likely to give the puissant t . r . a semblance of a race .	79.307976
there was talk of dragging old ex-president cleveland out of retirement for another try .	126.05479
some preferred judge alton b . parker of new york .	24.03826
the sneers at hearst changed to concern when it was seen that he had strong support in many parts of the country .	25.224743
platoons of hearst agents were traveling from state to state in a surprisingly successful search for delegates at the coming convention , and there were charges that money was doing a large part of the persuading .	99.10543
just when it was needed for the campaign , hearst paper no . 8 , the boston american , began publication .	246.40738
a bay state supporter said , `` mr . hearst ' s fight has been helped along greatly by the starting of his paper in boston ' ' .	41.488953
he ordered his editors to tone down on sensationalism and to refrain from using such words as `` seduction ' ' , `` rape ' ' , `` abortion ' ' , `` criminal assault ' ' and `` born out of wedlock ' ' .	28.273767
in a story headed , `` hearst offers cash ' ' , the republican new york tribune spread the money rumor , quoting an unnamed `` hearst supporter ' ' as saying	64.28337
`` the argument that is cutting most ice is that hearst is the only candidate who is fighting the trusts fearlessly and who would use all the powers of government to disrupt them if he were elected .	97.45758
the hearst men say that if hearst is nominated , he and his immediate friends will contribute to the democratic national committee the sum of $1 , 500 , 000 .	39.71133
this , it is urged , would relieve the national committee from the necessity of appealing to the trust magnates .	62.177513
the alternative to this is that if a conservative candidate is nominated the national committee will have to appeal to the trusts for their campaign funds , and in doing this will incur obligations which would make a democratic victory absolutely fruitless .	101.75079
the average democratic politician , especially in the country districts , is hungry for the spoils of office .	105.00118
it has been a long time since he has seen any campaign money , and when the proposition is laid down to him as the friends of mr . hearst are laying it down these days he is quite likely to get aboard the hearst bandwagon ' ' .	68.22388
if anything , the conservative democrats were more opposed to hearst than the republicans .	128.50919
in his own state of new york , the two democratic bellwethers , state leader hill and tammany boss murphy , were saying nothing openly against hearst but industriously boosting their own favorites , murphy being for cleveland and hill for parker .	194.92883
they had lost twice with the radical bryan , and were having no part of hearst , whom they considered more radical than bryan .	113.5379
but his increasing strength in the west looked menacing .	3.4432247
it caused henry watterson to sound a blast in his louisville courier-journal	21.001373
`` does any sane democrat believe that mr . hearst , a person unknown even to his constituency and his colleagues , without a word or act in the public life of his country , past or present , that can be shown to be his to commend him , could by any possibility be elected president of the united states ? ?	82.40149
more splenetic was senator edward carmack of tennessee , a parker man .	138.72528
`` the nomination of hearst would compass the ruin of the party ' ' , carmack said .	22.890945
`` it would be a disgrace , and , as i have already said to the people of tennessee , if hearst is nominated , we may as well pen a dispatch , and send it back from the field of battle ' all is lost , including our honor ' ' ' .	93.19017
a lone pro-hearst voice from new york city was that of william devery , who had been expelled as a tammany leader but still claimed strong influence in his own district .	66.97226
`` i understand [ hearst ] is a candidate for presidential honors ' ' , devery said without cracking a smile .	85.11876
`` there ' s nothing like buildin ' from the bottom up .	199.37329
if he ' s going to the st . louis convention as a delegate we ought to know it .	62.172707
he ' s got a lot of friends , and he ought to come along and let us know if he wants our help ' ' .	31.86484
hearst won the iowa state convention , but ran into a bitter battle in indiana before losing to parker , drawing an angry statement from indiana ' s john w . kern	108.99513
`` we are menaced for the first time in the history of the republic by the open and unblushing effort of a multi-millionaire to purchase the presidential nomination .	38.90501
our state has been overrun with a gang of paid agents and retainers .	56.00819
as for the paid hessians from other states , we are here to instruct the indiana democracy in their duty , i have nothing but contempt .	91.246414
the hearst dollar mark is all over them .	3.7242844
the talk of a hearst `` barrel ' ' was increasing .	73.02543
another indiana observer later commented , `` perhaps we shall never know how much was spent ( by hearst ) , but if as much money was expended elsewhere as in indiana a liberal fortune was squandered ' ' .	119.49535
in his fight for the illinois and indiana delegations , hearst made several trips to chicago to confer with andrew lawrence , the former san francisco examiner man who was now his chicago kingpin , and once to meet with bryan .	71.91261
on one visit he stopped at the office of the american , where he was known surreptitiously as `` the great white chief ' ' , and for the first time met his managing editor , fat moses koenigsberg .	45.99296
koenigsberg never did learn what hearst wanted , for the latter shook hands and moved toward the door .	80.887535
`` never mind , thank you ' ' , he said .	4.7204876
`` i must hurry to catch my train ' ' .	2.8197894
another editor pointed despairingly at a bundle of letters that had accumulated for him , saying , `` but mr . hearst , what shall i do with this correspondence ' ' ? ?	37.554302
`` i ' ll show you ' ' , hearst replied , grinning .	40.718876
he took the stack of mail and tossed it into the waste basket .	52.92706
every letter answers itself in a couple of weeks ' ' .	13.602204
hearst hopped into a private railroad car with max ihmsen and made an arduous personal canvass for delegates in the western and southern states , always wearing a frock coat , listening intently to local politicians , and generally making a good impression .	52.08781
he laughed at a story that he planned to bolt the party if he was not nominated .	32.560818
`` i should , of course ' ' , he said , `` like any other man , be honored and gratified should the democrats see fit to nominate me .	79.904045
but i do not have to be bribed by office to be a democrat .	47.552452
i have supported the democratic party in the last five campaigns .	159.63809
i supported cleveland three times and bryan twice .	11.720425
i intend to support the nominee of the party at st . louis , whoever he may be ' ' .	26.995695
the hearst press followed the chief ' s progress at the various state conventions with its usual admiring attention , stressing the `` enthusiasm ' ' and `` loyalty ' ' he inspired .	55.016296
this was historic in its way , for it marked the first time an american presidential aspirant had advertised his own virtues in his own string of newspapers spanning the land .	68.65965
yet his editors did not abandon their sense of story value .	137.16682
when nan patterson , a stunning and money-minded chorus girl who had appeared in a floradora road show , rode down broadway in a hansom cab with her married lover , frank young , she stopped the cab to disclose that young had been shot dead , tearfully insisting that he had shot himself although experts said he could not have done so .	101.75361
trevelyan ' s liberalism was above all a liberalism of the spirit , a deep feeling of communion with men fighting for country and for liberty .	100.42414
his passion and enthusiasm convey the courage and high adventure of garibaldi ' s exploits and give the reader a unique sense of participation in the events described .	54.793133
the three volumes brought to the fore a characteristic of trevelyan ' s prose which remained conspicuous through his later works -- a genius for describing military action with clarity and with authority .	131.10187
the confused rambling of guerrilla warfare , such as most of garibaldi ' s campaigns were , was brought to life by trevelyan ' s pen in some of the best passages in the books .	39.999447
his personal familiarity with the scenes of action undoubtedly contributed much to the final result , but familiarity alone would not have been enough without other qualities .	165.8037
military knowledge , love of detail , and a sure feeling for the portrayal of action were the added ingredients .	227.66777
but the garibaldi volumes were more than a romantic story .	75.25033
trevelyan contributed considerable new knowledge of the issues connected with his subject .	58.663784
the outstanding example was in garibaldi and the thousand , where he made use of unpublished papers of lord john russell and english consular materials to reveal the motives which led the british government to permit garibaldi to cross the straits of messina .	84.397865
in looking back over the volumes , it is possible to find errors of interpretation , some of which were not so evident at the time of writing .	31.829754
thus trevelyan repeats the story which pictured victor emmanuel as refusing to abandon the famous statuto at the insistence of general radetzky .	27.221355
later research has shown this part of the legend of the re galantuomo to be false .	123.7355
trevelyan accepts italian nationalism with little analysis , he is unduly critical of papal and french policy , and he is more than generous in assessing british policy .	91.55642
but fifty years later the trilogy still maintains a firm place in the list of standard works on the unification of italy , a position cautiously prophesied by the reviewers at the time of publication .	51.614487
trevelyan ' s manin and the venetian revolution of 1848 , his last major volume on an italian theme , was written in a minor key .	95.3424
published in 1923 , it did not gain the popular acclaim of the garibaldi volumes , probably because trevelyan felt less at home with manin , the bourgeois lawyer , than with garibaldi , the filibuster .	112.4637
the complexities of venetian politics eluded him , but the story of the revolution itself is told in restrained measures , with no superfluous passages and only an occasional overemphasis of the part played by its leading figure .	87.527824
if it is not one of his best books , it can only be considered unsatisfactory when compared with his own garibaldi .	91.72995
already trevelyan had begun to parallel his nineteenth-century italian studies with several works on english figures of the same period .	139.66074
first the life of john bright appeared and seven years later lord grey of the reform bill .	208.58405
of the two , the life of bright is incomparably the better biography .	82.017006
trevelyan centers too exclusively on bright , is insufficiently appreciative of the views of bright ' s opponents and critics , and makes light of the genuine difficulties faced by peel .	89.89475
yet he is right when he claims in his autobiography that he drew the real features of the man , his tender and selfless motives and his rugged fearless strength .	36.583286
in the story of bright and the corn law agitation , the crimean war , the american civil war , and the franchise struggle trevelyan reflects something of the moral power which enabled this independent man to exercise so immense an influence over his fellow countrymen for so long .	91.071365
because bright ' s speeches were so much a part of him , there are long and numerous quotations , which , far from making the biography diffuse , help to give us the feel of the man .	62.95657
associated in a sense with the manchester school through his mother ' s family , trevelyan conveys in this biography something of its moral conviction and drive .	94.428276
nineteenth-century virtues , however , seem somehow to have gone out of fashion and the bright book has never been particularly popular .	103.09438
the biography of lord grey is strictly speaking not a biography at all .	62.12242
it is a whig history of the `` tory reaction ' ' which preceded the reform bill of 1832 , and it uses the figure of grey to give some unity to the narrative .	90.58629
the volume is a piece of passionate special pleading , written with the heat -- and often with the wisdom , it must be said -- of a liberal damning the shortsightedness of politicians from 1782 to 1832 .	75.593285
the theme of glorious summer coming after a long winter of discontent and repression was , he has told us , congenial to his artistic sense .	64.989655
and grey ' s northumberland background was close to trevelyan ' s own .	13.534913
but his concentration on personalities and his categorical assessment of their actions fail to convey the political complexities of a long generation harassed by world-wide war and confronted with the problem of adjustment to an unprecedented industrial and social transformation .	75.48486
some historians have found his point of view not to their taste , others have complained that he makes the tory tradition appear `` contemptible rather than intelligible ' ' , while a sympathetic critic has remarked that the `` intricate interplay of social dynamics and political activity of which , at times , politicians are the ignorant marionettes is not a field for the exercise of his talents ' ' .	67.71887
the liberal-radical heritage which informs all of trevelyan ' s interpretations of history here seems clearly to have distorted the issues and oversimplified the period .	84.13271
research in the period of grey and bright led naturally to a more ambitious work .	96.47266
britain in the nineteenth century is a textbook designed `` to give the sense of continuous growth , to show how economic led to social , and social to political change , how the political events reacted on the economic and social , and how new thoughts and new ideals accompanied or directed the whole complicated process ' ' .	122.47023
the plan is admirably fulfilled for the period up to 1832 .	104.11553
more temperately than in the study of grey and despite his liberal bias , trevelyan vividly sketches the england of pre-french revolution days , portrays the stresses and strains of the revolutionary period in rich colors , and brings developments leading to the reform bill into sharp and clear focus .	152.3985
by what one reader called a `` series of dissolving views ' ' , he merges one period into another and gives a sense of continuous growth .	54.675186
but after 1832 , the narrative tends to lose its balanced , many-sided quality and to become a medley of topics , often unconnected by any single thread .	59.023643
economic analysis was never trevelyan ' s strong point and the england of the industrial transformation cries out for economic analysis .	146.63689
yet after 1832 , the interrelations of economic and social and political affairs become blurred and the narrative becomes largely a conventional political account .	74.78887
finally , the period after 1870 receives little attention and that quite superficial .	65.23205
yet britain in the nineteenth century became the vade mecum of beginning students of history , went through edition after edition , and continues to be reprinted up to the very present .	150.55894
its success is a tribute , above all , to trevelyan ' s brilliance as a literary stylist .	33.90361
in 1924 trevelyan traveled to the united states , where he delivered the lowell lectures at harvard university .	33.826412
these lectures formed the nucleus of a general survey of english development which took form afterward as a history of england .	113.04824
in short order , the general history became his most popular work and has remained , aside from his later social history , the work most widely favored by the public .	143.179
the history of england has often been compared with green ' s short history .	172.47238
like green , trevelyan aimed to write a history not of `` english kings or english conquests ' ' , but of the english people .	66.602936
the history takes too much for granted to serve as a text for other than english schoolboys , and like britain in the nineteenth century it deteriorates badly as it goes beyond 1870 .	67.64039
trevelyan ' s excursions into contemporary history were rarely happy ones .	892.95404
but as a stimulating , provocative interpretation of the broad sweep of english development it is incomparable .	73.8315
