living pictures of the early boroughs , country life in tudor and stuart times , the impact of the industrial revolution compete with sensitive surveys of language and literature , the common law , parliamentary development .	88.576126
the strength of the history is also its weakness .	45.162903
trevelyan is militantly sure of the superiority of english institutions and character over those of other peoples .	251.25305
his nationalism was not a new characteristic , but its self-consciousness , even its self-satisfaction , is more obvious in a book that stretches over the long reach of english history .	50.425243
and yet the elements which capture his liberal and humanistic imagination are those which make the english story worth telling and worth remembering .	157.33733
tolerance and compromise , social justice and civil liberty , are today too often in short supply for one to be overly critical of trevelyan ' s emphasis on their central place in the english tradition .	111.12749
like most major works of synthesis , the history of england is informed by the positive views of a first-class mind , and this is surely a major work .	43.59806
four years after the publication of the history of england , the first volume of trevelyan ' s queen anne trilogy appeared .	21.003487
by now he had become regius professor of modern history at cambridge and had been honored by the award of the order of merit .	52.360676
his academic duties had little evident effect on his prolific pen .	68.01657
blenheim was followed in rapid succession by ramillies and the union with scotland and by the peace and the protestant succession , the three forming together a detailed picture of england under queen anne .	67.16491
like his volume on wycliffe , the work was accompanied by the publication of a selected group of documents , in this case illustrative of the history of queen anne ' s reign down to 1707 .	42.116673
trevelyan was at least in part attracted to the period by an almost unconscious desire to take up the story where macaulay ' s history of england had broken off .	76.52755
in addition , he believed in the `` dramatic unity and separateness of the period from 1702-14 , lying between the stuart and hanoverian eras with a special ethos of its own ' ' .	39.805847
he saw the age as one in which britain `` settled her free constitution ' ' and attained her modern place in the world .	122.152374
to most observers , there is little doubt that he placed an artificial strait jacket of unity upon the years of anne ' s reign which in reality existed only in the pages of his history .	93.34124
of the three volumes , blenheim is easily the best .	64.46549
in four opening chapters reminiscent of macaulay ' s famous third chapter , trevelyan surveys the state of england at the opening of the eighteenth century .	31.219172
his delightful picture of society and institutions is filled with warm detail that brings the period vividly to life .	170.91946
he tends to underestimate -- or perhaps to view charitably -- the brutality and the violence of the age , so that there is an idyllic quality in these pages which hazes over some of its sharp reality .	73.8209
yet as an evocation of time past , there are few such successful portraits in english historical literature .	67.51945
once the scene is set , trevelyan skilfully builds up the tense story until it reaches its climax in the dramatic victory of marlborough and eugene of savoy at blenheim .	46.781643
the account of the battle is , next to his descriptions of garibaldi ' s campaigns , trevelyan ' s outstanding military narrative .	39.33792
the scene is etched in sharp detail , the military problems brilliantly explained , and the excitement and importance of the battle made evident .	148.7119
if only for this modest masterpiece of military history , blenheim is likely to be read and reread long after newer interpretations have perhaps altered our picture of the marlborough wars .	103.57337
ramillies and the union with scotland has fewer high spots than blenheim and much less of its dramatic unity .	129.95212
yet in several chapters on scotland in the eighteenth century , trevelyan copes persuasively with the tangled confusion of scottish politics against a vivid background of scottish religion , customs , and traditions .	38.27764
i stood on a table , surrounded by hundreds of expectant young faces .	34.6204
questions came to me from all sides about my world citizenship activities .	114.52447
after making a short statement about human rights , and the freedom to travel , i told them i would be going to the kehl bridge the next morning in order to cross the rhine into germany .	45.34171
`` may we come with you ' ' ? ?	2.9851756
`` well , i might not get that far ' ' , i told them , `` as actually i have no papers to enter germany and , as a matter of fact , no permit to return to france once i leave ' ' .	44.902786
we would all meet at ten o ' clock at the kehl bridge , five miles from strasbourg , and march triumphantly across into germany .	29.912302
there was only one hitch the small town of kehl , on the other side of the rhine , was still under french jurisdiction .	25.054892
the real franco-german frontier was beyond the town ' s limits .	21.04906
in fact , all persons were permitted to cross the rhine into kehl , there being no sentry posted on the west side of the river .	28.624939
that evening , as i learned later , the students , enjoying that spontaneous immodesty in action known only to university students , surged out onto the streets of strasbourg , overturning empty streetcars , marking up store fronts , and shouting imprudently , `` garry davis to power ' ' ! !	82.85917
as i got off the trolley at kehl bridge the next morning , i was met by what looked like 5 , 000 students , some of whom were carrying sticks apparently for the coming `` battle ' ' with the police .	70.48687
alarmed by this display of weapons , i looked toward the bridge and there saw , stretched across the near side , a cordon of policemen , their bicycles forming a roadblock before which stood several french officers in uniform and a small waspish man in a brown derby .	107.36479
`` listen please ' ' , i called to the students in french .	63.633713
`` i thank you most heartily for being here .	103.52562
this is full evidence of your support for my principles .	74.77657
these principles , however , will not be served by violence in any form .	62.333515
if they are right , they will prevail of and by themselves .	191.07089
i ask you all to support me in this .	43.587368
if one finger is raised against the authorities , all our moral power will vanish .	203.79408
your self-control in this respect will be the only witness to your understanding of what i am saying .	47.284695
i marched up to the waiting officials , the students massed behind me .	182.56323
as usual , the press photographers were on hand .	25.672857
the waspish man stopped me three paces from the bicycle barricade , and asked me in french if i had papers to leave france .	58.054253
i replied in the affirmative , taking out my recently acquired titre d ' identite et de voyage , on which was stamped a permission to leave france .	62.194324
he examined it carefully , handed it back and said , `` eh bien , you may leave france ' ' .	25.407885
one of the uniformed officers stepped in my way , demanding to know whether i had permission to enter germany .	50.036873
`` no , i have no permission to enter germany ' ' , i told him .	9.388145
`` alors , you may go no farther ' ' , he said imperiously .	12.457937
`` is this then the frontier ' ' ? ?	8.6561365
at this , the students let out a yell , knowing full well the actual frontier was beyond the town of kehl .	153.74495
`` but i have no permission to re-enter france , and i have just left ' ' , i told him .	14.190469
`` i must then be standing on the line between france and germany ' ' .	19.405376
but there is no line between france and germany , that is , no actual line .	127.259476
`` but if there is no line , how can there be two countries ? ?	68.059006
you have just given me permission to leave france , which i did .	46.74105
and as you know , i have no permission to re-enter france once out .	22.311762
obviously i ' m stuck on the line between the two countries ' ' .	10.189885
the students were laughing uproariously at this piece of logic , and even the policemen were trying hard not to smile .	104.8019
`` mais non ' ' , the interior ministry man coaxed , `` you may come back to strasbourg , now , if you wish ' ' .	24.377258
then will you give me a visa to re-enter france ' ' ? ?	3.655794
but there is no question of a visa .	15.198795
`` ah , then please tell me where the frontier is because this gentleman here ' ' -- i indicated the french occupation officer -- `` informs me that germany is just on the other side of him ' ' .	70.472115
the interior man looked uneasily at his french compatriot .	2.0013382
from the crowd were coming cries of `` he ' s right ' ' ! !	14.009477
`` there must be a line ' ' ! !	7.7893114
and `` bravo , garry , continue ' ' ! !	4.058125
seeing their hesitation , i said , `` well , until i have permission to enter germany , or a visa to re-enter france , i shall be obliged to remain here on the line between two countries ' ' , whereupon i moved to the side of the road , parked my backpack against the small guardhouse on the sidewalk , sat down , took out my typewriter , and began typing the above conversation .	50.867176
the reporters were questioning the interior man and the french officer , both of whom remained noncommittal as to what action , if any , would be taken in my regard .	71.83238
finally they went off to file their stories , after the photographers had taken pictures of my latest vigil .	67.03849
the students crowded around asking questions , slapping me on the back , and generally being friendly .	74.83243
`` but what will you do this evening , mr . davis ' ' ? ?	10.881955
`` it will be very cold ' ' .	1.9521334
`` i don ' t know ' ' , i told him , `` except that i will be here ' ' .	12.494068
`` i shall see about getting you a tent ' ' , he said .	9.654157
`` i have a small sports shop in strasbourg ' ' .	13.9886465
that would be a great help , i told him , thanking him for his thoughtfulness .	38.805126
a special guard was posted at my end of the bridge to make sure i didn ' t cross , the ludicrousness of the situation being revealed fully in that everyone else -- men , women , and children , dogs , cats , horses , cars , trucks , baby carriages -- could cross kehl bridge into kehl without surveillance .	52.08432
the day passed eventfully enough , with a constant stream of visitors , some stopping only to say hello , others getting into serious conversations , such as one andre fuchs , a free-lance journalist from strasbourg who wrote an article for the nouvelle alsatian in highly sympathetic terms .	112.22735
some students from the university returned around six with a large pot containing enough hot soup to last me a week .	139.78012
a volunteer food brigade had been arranged , they told me , which would supply me with the necessities as long as i remained at the bridge .	83.40823
a little later , the sports shop man returned with a small pup tent .	24.668915
one of the girl students , sitting by while i ate the thick soup , asked me if i had a sleeping bag .	93.10955
when i informed her that i didn ' t , she said she would borrow her brother ' s and bring it to me later that evening .	57.449493
`` you do not know me ' ' , she said in good english , `` but my mother was your governess in philadelphia when you were a child ' ' .	32.748154
i was delighted to make that personal contact in such trying and unusual circumstances .	186.27238
the peter family proved wonderful and helpful friends in the following days , mrs . peter , little esther , and raoul , who generously lent me his sleeping bag for my `` watch on the rhine ' ' .	36.608624
sighting a line from the bridge to a small field directly to the side , i pitched the tent that evening on the stateless `` line ' ' , digging a small trench around it as best i could with a toy spade donated by a neighborhood child .	100.55596
the wind from the rhine was damp and chill , necessitating a fire for warmth .	30.342577
after scouring around a bit in the open area , i came across what proved to be tar-soaked logs which crackled and burned brightly , giving off vast rolls of smoke into the ashen sky .	108.37861
each evening the students appeared with the soup kettle and several petits pains , esther usually being among them .	83.618454
i had advised friends to write me to `` no man ' s land , pont kehl , between strasbourg and kehl , france-germany ' ' .	34.364353
sure enough , mail began trickling in , delivered by a talkative , highly amused french postman who informed me there had been quite a debate at the post office as to whether that address would be recognized .	63.761433
on christmas eve , students brought out two small christmas trees which i placed on either side of the tent .	68.18362
as the field on which my tent was pitched was a favorite natural playground for the kids of the neighborhood , i had made many friends among them , taking part in their after-school games and trying desperately to translate grimm ' s fairy tales into an understandable french as we gathered around the fire in front of the tent .	78.015305
to my great surprise and delight , when they saw the two trees they went rushing off , returning shortly with decorations from their own trees .	161.35306
it was a merry if somewhat soggy christmas for me that year .	58.446754
in the mail were invitations to speak at the universities of cologne , heidelberg , and baden-baden .	23.09721
twenty thousand world citizens at stuttgart had signed a petition inviting me to visit their town .	86.30868
when dr . adenauer was approached by a world citizen delegation to find out his disposition of my case , he gave them his personal approval of my entry , saying that all men advocating peace should be welcomed into germany .	77.367
the special guard , however , was still posted on kehl bridge .	110.927055
as it began raining at around eight o ' clock on december 26th , i retired into my tent early , somewhat tired and discouraged , my body reacting sluggishly because of the continued exposure .	84.4287
no matter how large the fire , i couldn ' t seem to shake off the chill that day .	27.989923
`` oh , mr . davis , are you there ' ' ? ?	12.52867
a voice drifted in to me above the patter of the rain shortly after i had fallen into a fitful sleep .	68.59807
`` we ' re from the council of europe , british delegation .	94.696754
may we have a word with you ' ' ? ?	2.358828
i ' ve had a trying day and i just can ' t make it out again ' ' , i told them .	20.071531
later i learned that sir hugh dalton had expressed a desire to see me , hence their trip to `` no man ' s land ' ' .	45.962116
on the evening of december 27th , esther noticed my pallid look and rasping voice .	85.10415
she entreated me to see a doctor , and when i refused , brought one out to see me .	87.687485
i wouldn ' t hear of it because it meant giving up the `` line ' ' , though i realized i was in poor shape physically .	106.10303
esther , mistaking my hesitation , assured me that the hospital expense would be taken care of by a leading merchant in strasbourg whom she had already approached .	129.21095
`` no , it ' s not that ' ' , i told her .	15.323722
`` you see , once i relinquish the position i ' ve already established here , i couldn ' t regain it without sacrificing the logic of it ' ' .	36.1592
at that moment , up walked a tall young man with glasses who announced himself as a world citizen from basel , switzerland .	105.07476
without preliminaries , esther asked him , `` if you are a world citizen , will you take garry davis ' place in his tent while he goes to the hospital ' ' ? ?	38.236916
`` but of course , with pleasure ' ' , he replied .	6.960523
`` what is your name ' ' ? ?	1.014486
`` you have just enlisted for the ' rhine campaign ' ' ' .	32.646748
esther jumped up , ran to him and gave him a little hug .	38.292236
now come , garry , we must go quickly .	106.43915
such were the incongruities of the situation that the very police assigned to check up on me were drafted into driving me to the strasbourg hospital while world citizen jean babel waved adieu from the `` line ' ' ! !	94.35991
he remembered every detail of his pre-assault movements but nothing of the final , desperate rush to come to grips with the enemy .	50.86026
when the victory cheer went up this officer found himself still mounted , with his horse pressed broadside against cleburne ' s log parapet in a tangled group of infantrymen .	69.518364
his hat was gone , the tears were streaming from his eyes .	25.485466
six climactic minutes in an individual ' s life left no memory .	324.31244
eight hundred and sixty-five rebels surrendered within their works and a thousand more were captured or surrendered themselves that night and the next day .	187.14648
seven battle flags and fourteen officers ' swords were sent to thomas ' headquarters .	35.970882
it was the only sizable assault upon infantry and artillery behind breastworks successfully made by either side during the atlanta campaign .	79.457954
the fourteenth regiment of ohio volunteers lost one-third of its numbers within a few minutes , among them being several men whose time of service had expired but who had volunteered to advance with their regiment .	157.1848
the thirty-eighth regiment of ohio volunteers , one of the regiments in thomas ' first division during buell ' s command , suffered its greatest loss of the war in this action .	60.30539
a popular belief grew up after the war that the only time during the civil war that thomas ever put his horse to a gallop was when he went to hurry up stanley for this assault .	88.106316
sherman was responsible for the story when he said in his memoirs that this was the only time he could recall seeing thomas ride so fast .	68.41934
while thomas ' injured back led him to restrain his mount from its most violent gait he moved quickly enough when he had to .	205.2221
it is not in the record , but he must have galloped his horse at peach tree creek when he brought up ward ' s guns to save newton ' s crumbling line .	55.21182
while the final combat of the campaign was being worked out at jonesborough , thomas , on sherman ' s instructions , ordered slocum , now commanding the twentieth corps , to make an effort to occupy atlanta if he could do so without exposing his bridgehead to a counterattack .	104.37544
the dispatch must have been sent after sundown on september 1 .	22.557518
slocum made his reconnaissanace the next morning , found the town empty , accepted the surrender of the mayor and occupied the city a little before noon .	131.09113
on the morning of september 2 the fourth corps and the armies of the tennessee and the ohio followed the line of hardee ' s retreat .	37.405315
about noon they came up with the enemy two miles from lovejoy ' s station and deployed .	52.42097
the fourth corps assaulted and carried a small portion of the enemy works but could not hold possession of the gain for want of cooperation from the balance of the line .	84.323166
that night a note written in slocum ' s hand and dated from inside the captured city came to sherman stating that the twentieth corps was in possession of atlanta .	107.64125
before making the news public sherman sent an officer with the note to thomas .	95.16789
in a short time the officer returned and thomas followed on his heels .	81.06469
the cautious thomas re-examined the note and then , making up his mind that it was genuine , snapped his fingers , whistled and almost danced in his exuberance .	46.370304
the next day sherman issued his orders ending the campaign and pulled his armies back to atlanta .	71.64475
the measure of combat efficiency in an indecisive campaign is a matter of personal choice .	19.610146
hood refused to notice anything except captured guns and colors .	45.249428
by both standards thomas had the right to be proud .	52.29215
thomas thanked his men for their tenacity of purpose , unmurmuring endurance , cheerful obedience , brilliant heroism and high qualities in battle .	76.05097
sherman felt that his own part in the campaign was skillful and well executed but that the slowness of a part of his army robbed him of the larger fruits of victory .	108.493095
he supposed the military world would approve of his accomplishment .	45.554817
whatever the military world thought , the political world approved it wholeheartedly .	288.52744
for some time , despondency in some northern quarters had been displayed in two ways -- an eagerness for peace and a dissatisfaction with lincoln .	88.36229
proposals were in the air for a year ' s armistice .	22.585575
lincoln was sure that he would not be re-elected .	93.24013
in the midst of this gloom , at 10 05 p . m . on september 2 , slocum ' s telegram to stanton , `` general sherman has taken atlanta ' ' , shattered the talk of a negotiated peace and boosted lincoln into the white house .	54.12541
to the republicans no victory could have been more complete .	262.11298
official congratulations showered upon sherman and his army .	3.4220629
lincoln mentioned their distinguished ability , courage and perseverance .	27.465445
he felt that this campaign would be famous in the annals of war .	34.19016
grant called it prompt , skillful and brilliant .	28.557909
halleck described it as the most brilliant of the war .	17.77985
actually the atlanta campaign was a military failure .	4.2230973
next best to destroying an army is to deprive it of its freedom of action .	41.753983
sherman had accomplished this much of his job and then inexplicably nullified it by his thirty-mile retreat from lovejoy ' s to atlanta .	66.52945
but , so far as its territorial objectives were concerned , the campaign was successful .	57.05691
within the narrow frame of military tactics , too , the experts agree that the campaign was brilliant .	80.153694
in seventeen weeks the military front was driven southward more than 100 miles .	63.426716
there was a battle on an average of once every three weeks .	113.53357
in the summary of the principal events of the campaign compiled from the official records there are only ten days which show no fighting .	147.79466
the casualties in the army of the cumberland were 22 , 807 , while for all three armies they were 37 , 081 .	122.14526
men were killed in their camps , at their meals and in their sleep .	55.97658
rifle fire often kept the opposing gunners from manning their pieces .	130.99196
modern warfare was born in this campaign -- periscopes , camouflage , booby traps , land mines , extended order , trench raids , foxholes , armored cars , night attacks , flares , sharpshooters in trees , interlaced vines and treetops , which were the forerunners of barbed wire , trip wires to thwart a cavalry charge , which presaged the mine trap , and the general use of anesthetics .	58.873795
the use of map coordinates was begun when the senior officers began to select tactical points by designating a spot as `` near the letter o in the word mountain ' ' .	144.97255
a few weeks later the maps were being divided into squares and a position was described as being `` about lots 239 , 247 and 272 with pickets forward as far as 196 ' ' .	69.612175
this system was dependent upon identical maps and thomas supplied them from a mobile lithograph press .	90.594925
orders of the day began to specify the standard map for the movement .	111.78688
sherman proved that a railway base could be movable and the most brilliant feature of the atlanta campaign was the rapid repair of the tracks .	49.971565
to the rebels it seemed as if sherman carried tunnels and bridges in his pockets .	78.178856
the whistle of sherman ' s locomotives often drowned out the rattle of the skirmish fire .	30.383707
as always , the ranks worked out new and better tactics , but there was brilliance in the way the field commands adopted these methods and in the way the army commanders incorporated them into their military thinking .	85.90498
the fossilized , formalized , precedent-based thinking of the legendary military brain was not evident in sherman ' s armies .	72.06248
sherman could never be accused of sticking too long with the old .	21.670187
one of sherman ' s most serious shortcomings , however , was his mistrust of his cavalry .	50.798325
he never saw that it was a complement to his infantry and not a substitute for it .	49.6977
then , in some way , this lack of faith in the cavalry became mixed up in his mind with the dragging effect of wagon trains and was hardened into a prejudice .	117.25319
a horse needed twenty pounds of food a day but the infantryman got along with two pounds .	130.44002
the horseman required eleven times more than the footman .	26.053692
he would ship by rail five pounds per day per animal and the other fifteen pounds that were needed could be picked up off the country .	83.25545
already debilitated by the chattanooga starvation , the quality of sherman ' s horseflesh ran downhill as the campaign progressed .	39.196793
every recorded request by thomas for a delay in a flank movement or an advance was to gain time to take care of his horses .	81.49614
well led , properly organized cavalry , in its complementary role to infantry , had four functions .	194.3912
first , it could locate the enemy infantry , learn what they were doing , and hold them until the heavy foot columns could come up and take over .	107.514496
second , it could screen its own infantry from the sight of the enemy .	20.179014
third , it could threaten at all times , and destroy when possible , the enemy communications .	96.15622
it could reach key tactical points faster than infantry and destroy them or hold them as the case might be for the foot soldier .	119.137825
its climactic role was to pursue and demoralize a defeated enemy but this chance never came in the atlanta campaign .	162.36255
thomas tried hard to have his cavalry ready for the test it was to meet , but his plans were wrecked when it was forced into a campaign without optimum mobility and with its commander stripped from it .	105.04111
sherman knew the uses of cavalry as well as thomas but he imagined a moving base with infantry wings instead of cavalry wings .	109.279274
his conception proved workable but slower and it enabled his enemy to make clean , deft , well organized retreats with small materiel losses .	96.28846
sherman insisted that cavalry could not successfully break up hostile railways , yet garrard ' s covington raid and rousseau ' s opelika raid cut two-thirds of the rail lines he had to break and sherman lived in mortal fear of what forrest might do to his communications .	101.04739
when mcpherson pushed blindly through snake creek gap in a potentially decisive movement , the only cavalry in his van was the ninth illinois mounted infantry , totally inadequate for its role .	107.39741
it stumbled on infantry where no infantry should have been and mcpherson ' s aggressive impulse faded out , overwhelmed by fears of the unknown .	87.37837
a proper cavalry command in his front would have developed the fact that he had run into one division of polk ' s army of the mississippi moving up from the direction of mobile to join johnston at dalton .	67.47121
from the night of august 30 to the morning of september 2 there was no union cavalry east of the macon railway to disclose to sherman that he was missing the greatest opportunity of his career .	73.08437
a great part of the time , thomas ' infantry never knew the location of the enemy line .	80.714
at such times thomas wondered when and where a counterattack would strike him .	71.40969
it was the hard way to fight a war but thomas did it without making any disastrous mistakes .	195.67682
heat during the atlanta campaign , coupled with unsuitable clothing , caused individual irritation that was compounded by a lack of opportunity to bathe and shift into clean clothing .	69.82355
to relieve the itch and sweat galls , the men got into the water whenever they could and since each sizable stream was generally the dividing line between the armies the pickets declared a private truce while the men went swimming .	164.2191
johnston believed that sherman put his naked engineers into the swimming parties to locate the various fords .	87.34008
lieutenant colonel james p . brownlow , who commanded the first brigade of thomas ' first cavalry division , was ordered across one of these fords .	75.35012
the water was deep and brownlow took his troopers across naked -- except for guns , cartridge boxes and hats .	110.99113
they kicked their horses through the deep water with their bare heels , drove the rebels out of their rifle pits and captured four men .	69.41333
most of the rebels got away since they could make better time through the stiff brush than their naked pursuers .	120.37728
rank was becoming an explosive issue in all three of sherman ' s armies .	27.85167
merited recommendations from army commanders were passed over in favor of political appointees from civil life .	137.68242
in one of the very few letters in which he ever complained of meynell , thompson told patmore of his distress at having had to leave london before this new friendship had developed further ``	160.24425
that was a very absurd and annoying situation in which i was placed by w . m . ' s curious methods of handling me .	48.444614
he never let me know that my visit was about to terminate until the actual morning i was to leave for lymington .	73.52515
the result was that i found myself in the ridiculous position of having made a formal engagement by letter for the next week , only two days before my departure from london .	92.89628
luckily both women knew my position and if anyone suffered in their opinion it was not i ' ' .	70.85529
it need hardly be remarked that thompson was not generally known for his scrupulosity about keeping his social engagements , which makes his irritation in this letter all the more significant .	177.53609
when thompson and her daughter began a correspondence which included fervent verses from pantasaph , mrs . king felt a proper victorian alarm .	120.6617
some , she knew , looked upon thompson almost as a saint , but others read in `` the hound of heaven ' ' what they took to be the confessions of a great sinner , who , like oscar wilde , had -- as one pious writer later put it -- thrown himself `` on the swelling wave of every passion ' ' .	89.08964
consequently , on october 31 , 1896 , mrs . king wrote to thompson , quite against her daughter ' s wishes , asking him not to `` recommence a correspondence which i believe has been dropped for some weeks ' ' .	61.69265
katherine was staying at a convent , and her mother felt that , as thompson himself seems to have suggested , she might eventually stay there .	109.35996
this prospect did not please mrs . king any more than did the possibility that her daughter might marry a bohemian , but she used it to suggest to thompson that , `` it is not in her nature to love you ' ' .	61.2416
for his part , thompson had explained in a previous letter that there would be nothing but an honorable friendship between katie and himself .	54.14604
at no time does he seem to have proposed marriage , and mrs . king was evidently torn between a concern for her daughter ' s emotions and the desire to believe that the friendship might be continued without harm to her reputation .	83.41989
in any case , she told thompson that she saw no reason why he might not see katie again , `` now that this frank explanation has been made & no one can misunderstand ' ' .	92.26438
she ended her letter with the assurance that she considered his friendship for her daughter and herself to be an honor , from which she could not part `` without still more pain ' ' .	77.04862
after thompson came to london to live , he received a letter from katie , which was dated february 8 , 1897 .	26.326204
she regretted what she described as the `` unwarrantable & unnecessary ' ' check to their friendship and said that she felt that they understood one another perfectly .	107.23724
i am a great deal at the little children ' s hospital .	76.634796
i know you are very busy now , you are writing a great deal & your book is coming out , isn ' t it ? ?	76.18265
but if you are able & care to come , you know how glad i shall be .	108.07939
katherine douglas king ' ' the invitation was accepted and other letters followed , in which she spoke of her concern for his health and her delight in seeing him so much at home among the crippled children she served .	134.6391
it is difficult to say what thompson expected would come of their relationship , which had begun so soon after his emotions had been stirred by maggie brien , but when katie wrote on april 11 , 1900 , to tell him that she was to be married to the rev . godfrey burr , the vicar of rushall in staffordshire , the news evidently helped to deepen his discouragement over the failure of his hopes for a new volume of verse .	49.703045
in a letter to meynell , which was written in june , less than a month before katie ' s wedding , he was highly melodramatic in his despair and once again announced his intention of returning to the life of the streets ``	67.98775
a week in arrears , and without means to pay , i must go , it is the only right thing .	68.91418
perhaps mrs . meynell would do me the undeserved kindness to keep my own copy of the first edition of my first book , with all its mementos of her and the dear ones .	45.10397
last , not least , there are some poems which k . king sent me ( addressed to herself ) when i was preparing a fresh volume , asking me to include them .	96.20273
the terrible blow of the new year put an end to that project .	84.56823
i wish you would return them to her .	10.886058
i never had the courage to look at them , when my projected volume became hopeless , fearing they were poor , until now when i was obliged to do so .	85.290695
o my genius , young and ripening , you would swear , -- when i wrote them	159.95546
all chance of fulfilling my destiny is over .	23.58991
i want you to be grandfather to these orphaned poems , dear father-brother , now i am gone	152.71967
and launch them on the world when their time comes .	74.45134
for them a box will be lodgment enough .	2.8683076
since my silence must have ended when i gave the purposed volume to you .	158.39601
i ask you to do me the last favour of reading them by 8 to-morrow evening , about which time i shall come to say my sad good-bye .	129.99103
if you don ' t think much of them , tell me the wholesome truth .	93.548164
if otherwise , you will give me a pleasure .	135.50047
but this -- yes , terrible step i am about to take is lightened with an inundating joy by the new-found hope that here , in these poems , is treasure -- or at least some measure of beauty , which i did not know of ' ' .	63.219456
thompson , of course , was persuaded not to take the `` terrible step ' '	28.599405
meynell once again paid his debts and it was katie , rather than thompson , whose life was soon ended , for she died in childbirth in april , 1901 , in the first year of her marriage .	69.978195
the `` orphaned poems ' ' mentioned in the letter to meynell comprised a group of five sonnets , which were published in the 1913 edition of thompson ' s works under the heading `` ad amicam ' ' , plus certain other completed pieces and rough drafts gathered together in one of the familiar exercise books .	65.23715
the publication of father connolly ' s the man has wings has made more of the group available in print so that a general picture of what it contained can now be had without difficulty .	173.92592
some of the poems express a mood of joy in a newly discovered love	400.9512
